title: Country Cooking By an Urban Chef
description: WHAT is undoubtedly the most unusual background on the New  York food scene belongs to an elegant, handsome cookbook author named Edna Lewis. She is the Virginia, born granddaughter of a onetime slave. He and two acquaintances, also former slaves, were granted substantial parcels of farmland in what was known as Freetown by Claiborn R. Mason Jr., for whom one of them had served as coachman.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table accompanying the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly stated that that toll, for the ChicagoCalumet Skyway Toll Bridges had declined by 14.2 percent for the month of June. The revenues actually rose by that amount.

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Block Shipping Of Used Atomic Fuel to Virginia
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Antinuclear environmentalists in Virginia filed suit here today against the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in an attempt to end the shipment of spent radioactive reactor fuel from Europe through the port of Portsmouth, Va.

title: Tar Sands Plan Backed in Alberta
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 31 The Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board, in a preliminary report today, recommended approval of a $4.3 billion project to extract oil from the province's tar sands deposits.

title: Coal Gas Project Set By Texaco
description: Texaco Inc. and the Southern California Edison Company announced jointly yesterday a $300 million project to test the commercial feasibility of coal gasification.

title: Population Changes in 3 States
description: Following is a chart showing the population gain or loss since 1970 in all the Congressional districts of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. The first number is that of the district. Next are shown the county or counties making up the district (except for Connecticut, described by region). Following that are the current estimate of the district's population and the percentage change in population since 1970.

description: Deaths

title: Cuba Apologizes For Fisticuffs
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 31 (AP)  An official of the Cuban Basketball Federation has wired American officials apologizing for the punching of Kyle Macy of the United States basketball team in the Pan American Games.

title: A New Hand at M.T.A. Throttle
description: When John Duncan Simpson talked recently about his upcoming job as the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority  his feet in tasseled loafers stretched out on a coffee table, his arms folded behind his

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 31  The South Korean Government today appeared to be intensifying its pressure on the opposition New Democratic Party by seizing copies of the party's newspaper, The Democratic Front, and jailing Mun Pu Shik, its editor.

title: U.S. Synthetic Fibers Irk E.E.C.
description: BONN  The European Economic Community is considering whether to take action against imports of synthetic fiber products from the United States on the ground that American chemical companies receive an unfair competitive advantage because of domestic oilpricing policy.

title: Departure Of Gregory Inevitable
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.. July 31  It was inevitable. Out with the old, in with the new. Jack Gregory expected it. He went fishing today.

title: The Conservative Blues
description: WASHINGTON  As the 96th Congress wallows towards the August recess, its conservative Republican members feel vaguely uneasy, like dinosaurs chilled by a sudden breeze.

title: G.P.U. Net Down 26.8% in Quarter
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, citing the continued impact of lost revenues from the accident at its reactor at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, reported yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter had fallen 26.8 percent to $19.9 million, or 33 cents a share, from. $27.2 million;, or 45 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter.

title: Concert: Stoltzman Plays Clarinet With Bravura
description: HERE may be, somewhere in the world, a finer clarinetist than Richard Stoltzman, but you would have had a hard time arguing that point with Monday night's Mostly Mozart audience at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Stoltzman put on a dis play or sheer, uninhibited virtuosity that set off the kind of uproarious demonstration ordinarily granted only to reigning sopranos. The work, an unlikely one to create such a commotion, was Rossini's Introductiop, Theme and Variations for Clarinet and Orchestra, one of those quasioperatic pieces whose aim seems to be to cram as many notes as possible into each measure.

title: A Wing, a Prayer, a Family Affair
description: OSHKOSH, WIS. OFFICIALLY, the noisy, swooping, esoteric happenings here since last Friday are called the annual flyin of the Experimental Airplane Association. But just as flying is more than the airplane, there is much more to the experience here than arcane designs and propellers.

title: Nevada Forbids Burying Of Radioactive Wastes
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., July 31 (UPI) The state of Nevada refused yesterday to accept a shipment of radioactive wastes for burial, saying it contained liquids and thus was unacceptable.

title: Diplomats and Titled Adorn Paris Couture
description: PARIS LONG before the days when photographers lit up the runways with their strobes and their flashes, a couturier's fame was spread by the glamour of his customers. If a woman looked dazzling in his clothes, other women flocked to his salons. That's what made the reputations of Worth, Poiret, Schiaparelli and other precursors of the current stars.

title: Bidding Heavy On Oil Leases

description: PITTSBURGH, July 31  The New York Mets stalled the Pirates pursuit of the Montreal Expos, the leaders in National League East, tonight by stopping Pittsburgh, 21, behind the combined fourhit pitching of Tom Hausman, Wayne Twitchell and Ed Glynn.

title: Hogan to Nicklaus: Work
description: Ever since Jack Nicklaus turned pro in 1962, he has won at least one tournament on the PGA Tour every year until this year. But for him this year ends this week. Unless he changes his mind, he will not compete again this year after the Professional Golfers Association championship that begins tomorrow at the Oakland Hills Country Club near De troit, the course that Ben Hogan termed a monster when he won the 1951 United States Open there. I'm glad, Ben Hogan said after his threeunderpar 67 in the final round. that I brought this monster to its knees. It's not exactly the same monster that Ben Hogan conquered. Over nearly two decades a few subtle changes have been made by Robert Trent Jones, the golf architect a new green that lengthens the seventh

title: Ashe Enters N.Y. Hospital Complaining of Weakness
description: Arthur Ashe, former Wimbledon tennis champion, reported to New York Hospital last night complaining of an episode of weakness and was admitted for observation.

title: Robert D. Jordan, a Former Aide Of Episcopal Church Foundation
description: Robert D. Jordan, former executive vice president of the Protestant Episcopal Church Foundation in New York, died yesterday in Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Mets Stop Pirates, 21
description: Three pitchers  Torn Hausman, Wayne Twitchell and Ed Glynn  combined on a fourhitter as the Mets beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 21. Page A21.

title: Listening to Carter, But Hearing F.D.R.
description: POTSDAM, N.Y.  Jimmy Carter bridged the generation gap in a few intensely felt moments in my household the other night.

title: jets May Finally Have a Rush
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 31 John Mazur, who runs the defense, called them hombres today, and Pat Ryan, one of the quarterbacks, called them the big guys. But whatever their name, they are the key men for the New York Jets in what Mazur terms our new approach.

title: U.S. Steel Net Up 24% For Quarter
description: The United States Steel Corporation, where profits had lagged behind those of other steelmakers, reported secondquarter earnings yesterday of $145.4 million, or $1.69 a share, up 24 percent from $117.3 million, or $1.38 a share, for the comparable quarter of 1978.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: You may have thought your statusquotient was pretty high because you own one of everything that Vuitton produces, including an LV leash for your Yorkshire terrier. But the statusmakers are always one step ahead of the rest of us. Vuitton has now come out with a miniature version of the satchel bag that is at this very moment hanging from your wrist or sitting on your desk. It's only 6 inches long and 4 inches high a size that might be just right for a makeup kit to tuck into your Vuitton shopping bag. Or your 8-year-old daughter might use it as a handbag to hold her bubble gum and Kleenex. If you have to worry about what to use it for, you're not sufficiently statusconscious to fork over $135 to round out your collection. And you probably won't even be interested in going to Saks Fifth Avenue's small leather goods department to see exactly how much will hold.

title: Probe Big Oil Now
description: WASHINGTON  No one in the Goyernment, let alone the public, can say for certain how the oil industry shapes our energy economy.

title: Iraq Reported to Hold 36 in HighLevel Plot To Take Over Regime
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31  About 36 people have been arrested in Iraq, accused of forming an opposition bloc within the regime and planning to seize power eventually, according to an authoritative newspaper report today from Baghdad.

title: Film Production Center Planned For Haaren High School Building
description: The Haaren High School building at 10th Avenue and 59th Street, which was closed a year ago, is scheduled to become the city's first comprehensive independent film and television production center.

title: B.P.'s Nigerian Oil Nationalized
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 31 (Agence FrancePresse)  Nigeria announced today that it was taking over the British Petroleum Company's remaining stake in Nigerian oil operations because of Britain's recent decision to, allow B.P. to sell crude oil to South Africa.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The American Civil Liberties Union charged that some of the licensing regkirements New Jersey imposed on applicants for casino jobs to make sure they had no links to organized crime were an illegal invasion of privacy.

title: Peking Preparing a Drive Aginst Corrupt Officials
description: PEKING, July 31 The Chinese Communist Party appears to be moving toward a campaign to weed out corrupt and incompetent officials and to end factionalism. Unlike previous purges, the campaign appears designed to be carried out by regular procedures in an attempt to restore the rule of law.

title: Paul M. Mazur, at 86; Lehman Bros. Partner More Than 50 Years
description: Paul M. Mazur, a senior partner of Lehman Brothers and a leading investment banker, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 1 Gracie Square, Manhattan, and Fiddler's Creek Farm, Titusville. N.J.

title: New York Buys Bird's Eye View Of Hudson River
description: For nearly a century, travelers along the eastern shore of the Hudson River have had a distant view of a turreted granite castle atop a mountain ridge 800 feet high in Garrison, N.Y., built by a railroad executive and enlarged by his son.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: U.S. NAVY VESSELS RESCUE VIETNAMESE REFUGEES: Clenching his teeth a bag containing his only remaining possessions, a Vietnamese refugee scrambled abord the U.S.S. White Plains on Monday after being rescued, along with 28 others, from a 35foot boat in the South China Sea. It was the third boatload taken aboard.a U.S. Navy ship since President Carter ordered the Seventh Fleet to locate and rescue refugees.

title: Yankees Guidry Halts White Sox
description: CHICAGO, July 31  Jim Spencer's threerun homer in the fourth inning and a threerun outburst in the sixth lifted Ron Guidry and the New York Yankees to a 73 victory over the Chi  cago White Sox tonight in Comiskey Park.

title: Dock Unionist, Executive Draw Terms in Prison
description: A dockunion leader and the owner of a waterfront company were sentenced to prison yesterday and fined $40.000 each on Federal charges involving illegal loans.

title: Where Charity Began in Court
description: ALBANY, July 31  I felt really comfortable with what I did back then at Christmastime, said Walter C. Dunbar, justice of the peace of the village of Watkins Glen in Schuyler County. But I guess I did violate the ethical standards of the legal profession

title: 300 at Picnic to Assist Shakespeare Festival
description: What may be New York's only backstage with a lawn and a lake was the scene of a fundraising picnic for the New York Shakespeare Festival last evening as more than 300 donors dined behind the Delacorte Theater in Central Park before going in to see a performance of Othello.

title: PRESIDENT CHEERED IN KENTUCKY TOWN
description: BARDSTOWN Ky., July 31  President Carter received a tumultuous welcome along the main street of this Kentucky town today and later pledged that he would not let anything erect barriers between your President and the American people.

title: Pop: Rummy Hunt Sings
description: ROMMY HUNT, a tall, goldentanned blond singer who made an impressive debut at Reno Sweeney a little over yeai ago, is back at the West 13th Street Club under slightly different circumstances.

title: Bonn Concern Ends Iran Nuclear Pact
description: BONN, July 31  West Germany's largest nuclear contractor said today that it had terminated a contract with Iran that called for the West German company to build two nuclear reactors worth $9 billion to $6 billion.

title: Film: 'Dallas Forty':Cynicism and Comedy
description: FOR Phil Elliott, the aging football hero of "North Dallas Forty," getting out of bed in the morning is a major production: there is apparently no part of Phil's battle-scarred carcass that doesn't creak. He's in such terrible shape that getting him through a football game now requires drugs, tape, padding and possibly the odd dash of papier-mch or Krazy Glue.Phil's situation isn't funny  but "North Dallas Forty" is, once the movie finally hits its stride. It's also a lot more bitterly critical of professional sports than its ole-buddy levity might at first indicate. The cynicism and the comedy don't always mix, especially during the film's very messy opening segments. But the director, Ted Kotcheff, has arrived at an unexpectedly delicate balance by the time the film is over. And the leading man, Nick Nolte, has a physical authority and a clowning, irreverent manner that lend the film some semblance of continuity, even when it's about to flounder.Much of the early part of the movie, based on the amusing novel by Peter Gent, is devoted to showing what untamed beasts football players can be. This is a weary point that could have been dispensed with quickly, with just the sight of Joe Bob (Bo Svenson)  the meanest, biggest and stupidest man on the team, not to mention one of the funniest  throwing the host's television set into the pool. But the carousing sequence is long and shapeless, serving only to introduce Mr. Nolte to a love interest (Dayle Haddon) who is amazingly uninteresting. Not until he has completed his pass at this latest hopeless addition to the ranks of fashion-models-turned-actresses can the movie go about its real business.Phil Elliott, it turns out, has evolved into too much of a wise guy to play ball. On the field, he's fine, more or less  it's the team's owners and knuckle-rapping coaches that he's tired of tangling with. The management has accused him of having a childish attitude, and during the course of the film, their dissatisfaction will catch up with him. His suspicion, far more insidious, is that the caste system that governs professional sports has turned the owners and coaches into the real football team, and the players themselves into disposable equipment. The movie is full of brutal, vivid incidents that corroborate his idea.It's also full of easygoing, deceptively casual horseplay, even more essential than the pills or the beer or the bandages in getting these players through the day. A lot of real football players have been cast as the North Dallas Bulls, but there's nothing stilted or amateurish in their acting of locker-room scenes or practice sessions: they perfectly capture the nervous camara-derie of men with a shared knowledge of how easily, how effortlessly they can be replaced. Some of them also reveal unexpected comic abilities, most notably John Matuszak, who makes Mr. Svenson a perfect foil.The central friendship in the movie, beautifully delineated, is the one between Mr. Nolte and Mac Davis, who expertly plays the team's quarterback, a man whose calculating nature and complacency make him all the more likable, somehow. Mr. Davis serves Mr. Nolte as the best friend a feller could have, up to a point  the point at which his own self-interest is called into play, in which case all bets are off. Mr. Nolte, whose job it is to wise up to the ways of the world by the end of the story, makes allowances for these limitations. He cares enough for the quarterback to respect and overlook the fact that the man's values are completely at odds with his own."North Dallas Forty," which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, includes a number of well-honed supporting performances, most notably G.D. Spradlin in the role of the coach. But the uncontested star of the show is Mr. Nolte, who may surprise a lot of people who had the ill fortune to see him in "The Deep" and the even worse luck to miss him in "Who'll Stop the Rain?" His performance in "Who'll Stop the Rain?" was altogether stunning; this time out he's merely engaging and full of surprises. Either way, he's something to see.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THERE are some piecs of kitchen equipment that no one really needs. They are the gadgets brought into the world by inventors who noticed one little problem or another and who then stayed awake nights trying to come up with solutions. But I have no intention of demeaning either the inventors or the gadgets. The devices almost always amuse me, and when they work do use them.

title: Cost of Northeast Corridor Rail Project Likely to Rise by $300 Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The huge project to improve rail service between Boston and Washington could cost $300 million more than Federal officials anticipated as recently as last January, when the Department of Transportation asked for a $654 million increase in the original $1.75 billion authorization.

title: News Summary
description: Conditional support for the arms treaty was expressed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. He testified that the Senate should approve the pact with Moscow only if President Carter made a binding pledge to increase military spending. Mr. Kissinger also urged that the Senate vote periodically on whether any treaty talks under way should b continued and should attach several understandings to the pact. [Page Al, Columns.]

title: Lloyd: Old Form Is Elusive
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 30 John Lloyd understands the vagaries of the pro tennis tour only too Well. The 24yearold Englishman, recently married to Chris Evert, was once among the topranked players in the world but now rests uncomfortably at No.168.

title: Deaths
description: MOSSCharles B. The Board of Directors of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club records with deep sorrow the passing of its esteemed member Charles B. Moss. On behalf of the membership we extend sincerest sympathy to the family.

title: Tumbling Into the Thames
description: Youngsters in New London, Conn., employed their own styles as they jumped from old pilings into the Thames River to beat the heat. In the New York area, the temperature reached 89 degrees yesterday. Forecast for today is slightly cooler temperatures and a chance of showers in the afternoon.

title: Black Opposition Leader in Rhodesia Ends Boycott
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, July 31 (AP)  The Rev. Ndabani ngi Sitholeannounced today that his political party had ended its boycott of the twomonthold Government, strengthening Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa's case for international recognition.

title: A Break for Consumers in the Sugar Game
description: In the politics of American sugar, you can hardly tell the players without a scorecard. Consider the number and variety of the players: big unionized Hawaiian cane growers; smaller, nonunionized Louisiana growers; family beet farmers; grainbelt producers of corn sweetener; foreign growers; refiners and major commerical sugar users. All of them have discrete interests and all are vying ter a piece of the action.

title: China Revives Opinion Polls
description: PEKING, July 31 (Reuters)  The public opinion'poll, common in the early days of Communist rule, has made a comeback in China. One being conducted now is believed to be the first since the start of the Cultural Revolution. The Shanghai daily newspaper Liberation has asked its readers to select the city's 10 best athletes of last year. Votes must be in by Aug. 31 and prizes will be awarded to the top 10 athletes, It said.

title: Promoter Is Accused of Stealing RealEstate Funds
description: A promoter said to have posed as the personal representative of a Pope and the confidant of Presidents has been accused of stealing $52,000 in realestate funds after persuading a New York City judge to appoint him receiver of a Times Square building.

title: Associated Press
description: PARIS; July 31  Iran's former Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar, who disappeared on the day the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came to power almost six months ago, emerged here today and accusd the Ayatollah of leading their country into chaos and dictatorship.

title: Best Buys
description: YOU'D be amazed at who strops here, said Steven Basior, as he cut twokilo wheels of almostripe French brie into pie shaped wedges.

title: American Brands Dividend
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that its board had increased the quarterly dividend on its common stock to $1.25 a share from $1.125, payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record Aug. 10.

title: In a Crowded Sandinist Jail, Inmates Express Relief
description: TIPITAPA, Nicaragua, July 31We had been told that if we were captured, we would be taken into a dungeon, have our fingernails pulled out and be tortured to death, said Juan Jos Boddn Espinoza, 28 years old, a former National Guard private standing barechested in the crowded corridor of Nicaragua's largest prison here today.

title: Japan Trade Official Quits
description: TOKYO, July 31 (UPI)  Nobuhiko Ushiba, a former Japanese Ambassador to the United States who played a key role in mending trade friction between Japan and the United States, resigned as chief Government trade negotiator today. He will assist the Government as a member of a special advisory council.

title: Pat Carroll Pat Carroll Pat Carroll
description: Pat Carroll can usually be found on the small stage of the Circle Repertory Theater in Greenwich Village where she portrays Gert vde Stein solo in her artfilled living room at 27 Rue de Fleurus in Paris. But last week, on the 33d anniversary of the death of Stein, the actress sat in her own living room in High Falls, N.Y., softly humming The Trail of the Lonesome Pine, the theme song of a 1934 Henry Fonda film and oddly enough, Stein's favorite piece of music.

title: Rachel I. Becker Is a Bride
description: Rachel I. Becker, daughter of Beverly J. Becker of Slidell, La., and the late Rev. Robert Becker, was married yesterday afternoon to Warren S. Edelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Edelman of West Brighton, S.I. Judge Gustave Fritchie of the Parish Court of Slidell performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Economic Indicators Down 0.1%
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Sluggishness in employment and factory orders helped push the Government index designed to forecast future economic activity down onetenth of percent in June, the Commerce Department retorted today.

title: Judge Fines Publisher on Refusal To Answer Questions on Fiords
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31  A Federal district judge yesterday fined a newspaper publisher, John McGoff. $10,000 for not answering questions about the source of funds for his 1979 purchase of The Sacramento Union.

title: Bodcaw Spurns International Paper
description: Stockholders of the Bodcaw Company voted overwhelmingly yesterday, in a closed meeting in Dallas, not to sell the oil and lumber producer to the International Paper Company for $610 million in preferred stock.

title: $225 Million In Business Bonds Sold
description: A potpourri of corporate bond financing was done yesterday to raise $225 million at yields ranging from 71/4 percent on some mediumgrade convertible debentures to 111/4 percent on speculative bonds.

title: Analyst Finds Sons of Disabled Men FaceProblems
description: The possibility that the son of a physically handicapped father may face greater psychological hazards, especially in sexual adjustment, than a child who is himself handicapped was raised yesterday by a Montreal psychoanalyst.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SALISBURY, ZimbabweRhodesia  Prime Minister Abel T. Mutorewa is still campaining for recognition. of. his new AfroSaxon Government in ZimbabweRhodesia, and hopes for support in his attempt to defeat the Patriotic Front forces in the countryside outright. There is no doubt that the Bishop Muzorewa enjoys substantial popularity, especially among the urban population, though he has been deserted already by a chlet lieutenant in the internal settlement, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole.

title: 2 Girls Lead Youth Trend in Gymnastics
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 31 They are too old and too busy to fret about the Bobbsey Twins and too young for teenage gossip or world gymnastics qualifying standards. They spend more time training than in school and live away from home.

title: Man and 2 Sons Killed by Bolt
description: PLAINVIEW, Tex., July 31 (AP)  A Rio Grande Valley man and his two sons, riding in the back of a pickup truck, were struck by lightning and killed last night. They were identified as Benito Cabello, 38 years old, and his sons Gilbert, 19, and Noel, 12. A third son, Joel, the 12yearold twin of Noel, is in fair condition at Central Plains Regional Hospital here.

title: Hiding Ends For a Soldier AWOL in 43
description: SHADY POINT, Okla., July 31 (UPI)  Pvt. D.B. Benson lived a fife of quiet desperation for 36 years, never marrying, never holding a job, flitting like a shadow through the back reaches of the Kiamichi Mountains of Oklahoma.

title: Hartford Mayor Running Like a Challenger
description: HARTFORD, JULY 31  If we just had a levelheaded and commonsense administration, lamented George A. Athanson, at a recent rally in his campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: Juries Granting More $1 Million Awards for Injuries
description: HOUSTON, July 31  Last fall an Austin, Tex., lawyer who became paralyzed from the waist down after a defective rifle discharged, won an outofcourt settlement of $6.8 million from the Remington Arms Company. Several months earlier two young Houston brothers who had been partly crippled in an airplane accident in which the rest of their family perished won a settlement that will amount to more than $14 million if they live to be 70 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Chrysler sought $1 billion in Federal assistanceafter reporting $207.1 million loss for the second quarter. The company, saying it expected a substantial loss in the third quarter as well, asked for tax credits against earnings of the next 18 months. [Page A1.] The Carter Administration suggested it might ask Congress to give Chrysler significant financial aid for fear that failure of the auto company would shake the overall economy. However, Treasury officials refused to comment on Chrysler's $1 billion request. [D4.]

title: Stocks Gain on Higher Volume
description: The stock market forged ahead on expanded volume yesterday, benefiting from strength in the dollar and weakness in gold bullion prices abroad. On Wall Street, analysts said that Paul A. Volcker, nominated last week as the next Federal Reserve Board chairman, provided the catalyst for the equity market's broad advance by pledging Monday that the fight against inflation will be his top priority.

title: F.D.A. Checking Infant Formulas
description: Two popular infantfeeding formulas have been placed under investigation by the Federal Food and Drug Administration following reports since last week of 31 instances nationwide of infants becoming ill after being fed the formulas, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

title: Basque Moderate Seeks Reconciliation With E.T.A.
description: MADRID, Spain, July 31  You are wishing me luck the way they do matadors before they go into the ring, joked Carlos Garaicoetsea, a 40yearold former industrialist who will shortly have the chore of trying to pacify Spain's Basque region.

title: British Reject Argument
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 31 (Reuters)  A British Government statement issued here by its delegation to the Commonwealth Conference called the Nigerian action an extraordinary move.

title: A Gloomy Vote for SALT
description: In a narrow sense, Henry Kissinger's longawaited lestiniony about SALT II will cheer the Carter Administration and help to resolve the quarrel over the pending arms treaty with the Soviet Union. The nation's most influential Republican and most widely respected voice in foreign affairs set a price for supporting the treaty that President Carter has already vowed to pay: an energetic buildup of both strategic and conventional military forces. Most deftly, the former Secretary of State threw his rhetoric to the Senate hawks but left the President the treaty bone.

description: Far periods as shown.(N) In& cates stock is Usted on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-counter.

title: KISSINGER SUGGESTS SENATE LINK TREATY TO MORE ARMS FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger told senators today that they should approve the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union only if President Carter makes binding and urgent commitment to increase military spending.

title: Meeting on Noted Women Ends
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  At breakfast at the Smithsonian's Museum of History and Technology this morning, 45 women marked the completion of a crash course on women in history with the announcement that they would seek the establishment of an annual Women's History Week.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Film

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter Administration Unveils Proposed F.B.I. Charter
description: WASHINGTON. July 31  The Carter Administration today formally unveiled its proposed governing charter for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The charter, which would be the first for the bureau, restricts but does not prohibit such controversial investigative techniques as the use of informers, under. cover agents and covert criminal activity.

title: Bundy Sentenced to Die In Two Florida Slayings
description: MIAMI, July 31 (AP)  Theodore R. Bundy was sentenced today to die in Florida's electric chair by a judge who called the 1978 slayings of two college sorority sisters indeed heinous, vicious and cruel.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Down
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that it had auctioned $150 million of 91day notes at an average rate of 10.335 percent, down slightly from 10.354 percent last week. The bankholding company reported that it had received $719.5 million of bids and that the ones it had accepted ranged in rate from 10.320 to 10.335. Next Tuesday, it will sell $150 million more.

title: A Festival Becomes A Staple Attraction
description: Back when it all began, it was held in nearby Camden and called the Maine Lobster Festival. You could get all the lobsters you could eat for $1. Festival organizers thought that would be about four.

title: Projections for Census Place New York's Loss Of Seats in House at 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Census Bureau reported today that New York State would probably lose four of its seats in the House of Representatives after the 1980 census, with at least three likely to be lost by New York City. The loss, which would come at a time when both the city and state are struggling to get more aid from the Federal Government, was predicted on the basis of population shifts from 1970 to 1978.

title: CIIRYLER IS SEEKING A BILLION IPI U.S AID AFTER RECORD LOSS
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich.. July 31 The financially troubled Chrysler Corporation, reporting the largest quarterly loss in its history, said today that it had asked the Federal Government to provide it with up to 31 billion in cash over the next 18 months. It also asked for some relief from Federal requirements on exhaust emissions.

title: Letter. On Tagging Explosives
description: To the Editor: The recent editorial advocacy by The New York Times of the concept of adding minute, coded identification tags to explosives as a law enforcement aid in solving bombings, most particularly terrorist acts, suggests an unawareness of the problems with the program.

title: 2 at Galante Death Scene Surrender to Authorities
description: The two missing witnesses and the only survivors of the killing of the reputed underworld leader Carmine Galante emerged unexpectedly yesterday for questioning after a 19day disappearance. But they reportedly told authorities that they had nothing to contribute to the investigation.

title: Plan by Nixon to Buy Coop in City Is Opposed by Some Other Owners
description: Citing fears about potential threats to the building's security, and concern that its ambiance would be altered, some residents at 19 East 72d Street now say they are opposed to former President Richard M. Nixon's plan to buy a penthouse apartment in the cooperative building.

title: Market Place I
description: THE battle for the Flintkote Company, a major producer of construction materials, had been heating up when the company suddenly announced yesterday that it had reached an acquisition agreement with an investor group for $52 a share in cash.

title: As of Old, the Star Is Kissinger And Senators Are Deferential
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Still a star attraction, Henry A. Kissinger played to a standingroomonly audience today on Capitol Hill.

title: Advertising
description: IT may not be unique, but it's a media auction, and it sure sounds unique. Behind it is Indoor Mall Marketing, a subsidiary of Air Time Inc., a mediabuying service. It operates advertising poster displays in 67 indoor malls around the country and is planning to offer an exclusive deal to a cigarette company to be the sole advertiser in that category on 15 percent of its displays at all installations. That comes to 165 backlighted posters.

title: Transcript of Selected Questions and Answers at Carters Meeting in Kentucky
description: Q. Mr. President, why dont you try to do something about the big oil companies that are making so much profit?

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Flintkote Company said yesterday that it had reached agreement in principle to sell the building materials company for $52 a share; or about $380 million iri cash, to a group of investors organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a New York investment banking house specializing in soalled leveraged buyouts of corporations.

title: Personal Health
description: MORE than the viiam,ins; the major mineraLst.  which include calcium phosAborus  emphasize the. importance of getting your essential nutrients from a varied and balanced diet rather than from a vial.

title: Judge Restricts Mail Surveillance
description: NEWARK, July 31 (UPI)  A Federal district judge said today that the Postal Service could not continue to record the names and return addresses on letters sent to groups under national security investigations until new rules on such mail covers were completed.

title: Cornelius Haugh, 43, And Wife, Jane, 41, Killed in Auto Crash
description: Cornelius P. Haugh, a financial consultant specializing in Far East investments, and his wife, Jane, a community leader on the West Side of Manhattan, were killed Saturday in an automobile'accident in Glens Falls, N.Y. Mr. Haugh was 43 years old and his wife was 41.

title: Club Books NewWave Bands
description: An ambitious schedule of newwave rock concerts, most of them featuring bands from Britain, has been planned for Club 57 at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place. The series will include the Cramps Aug. 1819; The Buzzcocks, the Gang of Four and The The, Aug. 31Sept. 1; John Cale and the Only Ones, Sept. 1915; XTC, Sept. 2021; and the Police, Sept. 2729.

title: House Censures Diggs, 414 to 0, Over Diversion of Payroll Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The House formally censured Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. today for padding his office payroll and making personal use of public funds, as the senior black member of Congress stood silent in the well of the chamber.

title: Empty Money Bags Found
description: Two empty money bags were found in a New Jersey motel yesterday, and detectives were attempting to determine if they might have been used in the theft of $600,000 from the Transit Authority's Brooklyn headquarters two weekends, ago. The two 10inch by 14inch bags, one marked Transit Authority and the other, Federal Reserve Bank of New York, are similar to bags used to bring money to the revenue room, according to an authority spokesman. He said the two bags had not immediately been linked to the theft. He said the two bags could not hold all the money from the theft. marked Transit Authority and the other, Federal Reserve Bank of New York, are similar to bags used to bring money to the revenue room, according to an authority spokesman. He said the two bags had not immediately been linked to the theft. He said the two bags could not hold all the money from the theft.

title: Service Stations Permitted Fees On Car Extras
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  Starting tomorrow, service stations may charge motorists extra for cleaning windshields, checking oil, filling tires and honoring credit cards, the Energy Department said today. The department's decision is aimed at appeasing aroused service station owners who planned to demonstrate tomorrow at the White House and the Capitol.

title: Campaign to Renew the Sheep Meadow Gets Under Way
description: Unofficially beginning a project to restore Central Park's Sheep Meadow, James Taylor, the rock and folk singer, gave a free concert there last evening before a crowd that was estimated by the police at 250.000. Meadow at 10 A.M. and began petting down blankets and setting up picnics.

title: Around the Nation
description: WICHITA, Kan., July 31 (UPI) State police agents today dusted for fingerprints a car owned by a bank vice president who was abducted Sunday and slain in an apparent extortion attempt on his father's central Kansas bank.

title: 2 Sentenced in Suffolk Sewer Case
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 31  Two principals in a sewerpipe corporation who had been convicted of conspiring to defraud the Government in Suffolk County's Southwest Sewer District project were given heavy fines and prison sentences here today in Federal Court.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Sells Notes of 9.06%
description: The Treasury sold $2.75 billion of threeyear notes yesterday at an average rate of 9.06 percent, and Government securities dealers estimated that 7year notes scheduled for sale today would likely yield about 9.05 percent.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1979

title: China Oil Cost Rise Cited
description: TOKYO, July 31 (AP)  China raised the price of its crude oil today by 28.5 percent to $21.80 a barrel, the Kyodo news service reported. Kyodo quotes an industry source here as saying the new price was set as China and two Japanese oil importers reached agreement in Peking on importing 7.6 million tons of oil from the Taching field in northeast China for the JulySeptember quarter.

title: Volcker on Interstate Bank Rules
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairmandesignate of the Federal Reserve Board, says current Federal prohibitions on interstate banking should be liberalized.

title: Letters
description: The debate raging over the SALT II treaty seems to leave many people with a sense that they are inadequate to judge among the highly technical factors involved.

title: REBOUND. BY CARTER FORESEEN BY ONEILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. says that he thinks President Carter will rebound politically but that time is growing short for the President to do so.

title: GOIHG OUT Guide
description: SUNS AGO Aztec dances performed in full, colorful regalia, with some numbers dating back a thousand years, are rare to the New York. Tomorrow through Sunday, New Yorkers will be able to see the Xochiquetzal Aztec Indian Dancers for the first time. The troupe is touring the United States from its home base in the Southwest, where the dancers have won popularity for the last decade with their intricate but strenuous movements stemming from a culture that has all but vanished.

title: ABCTV Tops Ratings, CBS Is Close
description: ABCTV, which went virtually unchallenged for ratings leadership last season, has, found CBSTV a troublesome competitor during the summer months. CBS has won four of the last eight weeks, and finished close behind ABC the other four. This includes last week, which went into ABC's column by a slim margin. The Nielsen scores were 14.9 for ABC; 14.6 for CBS and 12.3 for NBCTV.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of precious metals futures were battered again yesterday as most gold and silver deliveries closed down their daily permissible limits for the second consecutive day. However, copper and platinum futures ended with relatively modest losses after posting limit declines last Monday.

title: Rivers Deal in Snag; Gamble Is Offered
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 31 (AP) The management of the Texas Rangers reluctantly offered Oscar Gamble to the New York Yankees tonight after Commissioner Bowie Kuhn objected to certain provisions of a deal that would have sent three minor leaguers and a player to be named later to New York for Mickey Rivers.

title: Q&Z
description: Q. Some years ago you printed a recipe for pickled watermelon rind. I have lost the recipe and would like to pickle some rind this summer. Can you help?

title: 28,000 Deaths in '78 Investigated by Office Of Medical Examiner
description: All the cases examined by the office of the city's Medical Examiner have one thing in common  death.

title: Lorelei Opens Next Week With CountryMusic Act
description: The New Club Lorelei, 231 East 86th Street, will open Aug. 8 with a countrymusic format. Thg debut act, Aug. 89, will be Jerry Lee Lewis, with Otis Blackwell, who wrote several of Mr. Lewis's and Elvis Presley's greatest rockabilly hits, as the opener.

title: Deaths
description: BETTMANMarion Keyes. On July 29 of New York City. Wife of the late Clarence A. Survived by two daughters, Margaret B. Faath of Ridgewood NJ and Marion B. Lutkins of New York City and two grandchildren. Services will be private. Donations to The American Heart Association, would be apprecited.

title: Chess:
description: AMSTERDAM, July 28  Grandmasters Gyula Sax of Hungary and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia tied for first prize in the 19th I.B.M. International Tournament here with 9.4 scores.

title: City Running Buses to Mill Basin To Replace Route Pioneer Ended
description: The threemember panel seeking to restore seivipes dropped, by the Pioneer Bus Company of Brooklyn reported that, starting this morning, city buses would extend their nuts to the borough's Mill Basic area.

title: U.S. and Soviet Rights Activists Linked, Briefly, Over Telephone
description: For 50 seconds yesterday, American and Soviet humanrights activists were linked by telephone from New York to Moscow as both groups held news conferences to mark the fourth anniversary today of the signing of the Helsinki accords.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Testimony on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  Following are excerpts from the statement by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee at hearings on the strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: Borscht and Schav: The Time Is Ripe
description: LTHOUGH the storebought bottled varieties of cold beet borscht and the pungent sorrel soup, schav, can be doctored to fair degrees of palatability, no amount of tampering will make the equals of these same soups when homemade. Both beets and the sour grass, sorrel, are at their seasonal best right now, and are the basis of these cold and refreshing soups that are equally welcome as first courses or in larger portions as complete light lunches. A hot boiled potato added to either makes for a more solid and sustaining dish.

title: Some Businesses Seek Exemption From 78 Order
description: Concerned that compliance with Fed eral regulations limiting airconditioned temperatures in their buildings to 78 degrees would drive away customers, owners of Manhattan theaters and restaurants yesterday requested that their industries be exempted from the regulations.

title: About Real Estate Rural Areas Growing Faster Than Cities, Study Reports
description: Rural areas are growing faster than metropolitan areas and the trend is likely to continue despite a renewed energy crisis, according to a new study published by the Urban Land Institute, a Washingtonbased private research and educational organization.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE extraordinary mechanism of memory; the unbearable is effaced or, ratte er, sinks below the surface, while the banal comes to the fore. Thus writes the Israeli historian Saul Friedlnder (Pius XII and the. Third Reich and Kurt Gerstein: The Ambigusty of Good) midway through this agonized memoir of a childhood spent on the edge of the holocaust. And so, in

title: Henry Robbins, Editor in Chief Of Trade Books at Dutton, Dies
description: Henry Robbins, editor in chief of the tradebook division of E.P. Dutton & Company, and a publisher of many distinguished writers under his own imprint, died yesterday morning of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Charles B. Moss, Theater Owner
description: Charles B. Moss, president of B.S. Moss Enterprises, owner of the Criterion Theater at Broadway and 45th Street, and 16 other movie theaters in the New York area, died yestrday in Greenwich (Conn.)Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Greenwich.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: All About Espresso Machines
description: THOUGH its name derives from the Italian word for speed, and reflects the fast brewing method necessary to its success, Americans tend to drink this strong coffee in a languid, relaxed fashion. Nevertheless, we pronounce it like our word for fast  as if it were the A train. It's not expresso, however, but espresso.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN it was noted recently that chicken, more than any other food, is the most ubiquitous meat, I failed to add that this is not only true of Western cuisine, but also in international kitchens. Some of the greatest dishes in the world are based on chicken. The Indonesian table is well known for its satays of chicken; the Japanese dine finely on mizutake, chicken cooked at table in a broth with noodles and vegetables. Java, Vienna and the American South are noted for fried chicken, though the techniques are disparate.

title: Smoke Fills IRT Train
description: A mechanical problem on a train insulator sent smoke through the cars of a No. 7 IRT Flushingline train at about 11:20 P.M. yesterday. A passenger pulled an emergency cord, halting the train for about 10 minutes just before the JacksonVernon station, the Transit Authority reported. Two persons were treated for smoke inhalation, a spokesman said.

title: Tighter Supplies of Light Oils Felt
description: A series of production cutbacks announced in the last few days by some of the smaller producers in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is tightening supplies of socalled sweet crude oil and leading to widespread violations of OPEC's monthold price ceilings.

title: Sloan Foundation Officer
description: Stewart F. Campbell has been named secretary and treasurer of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, it was announced by Albert Rees, president. Mr. Campbell had been treasurer of the Duke Endowment in New York since 1973. The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and the Duke Endowment are among the country's 15 largest philanthropic foundations in terms of assets

title: 6 Bangladesh Villages Flooded
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, July 31 (AP) Monsoonfed floodwaters of the Brahmaputra River have destroyed six villages in the Rangpur district, 80 miles north of Dacca, in the last week, leaving at least 100,000 people homeless, according to reports from the area today.

title: Rhodesia the Topic as Commonwealth Heads Gather
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 31  The a Commonwealth_ heads of government will begin their 22d conference here tomorrow with tile problems of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, a troUbled nation whose border is just 80 miles from here, expected to dominate, and enliven, the eight days of proceedings.

title: U.S. Panel, in Poland, Visits Treblinka Camp
description: TREBLINKA, Poland, July 31 (UPI) The United State Presidential Commission on the Holocaust toured the Treblinka death camp today and won. longsought access to Polish archives on Nazi war crimes.

title: North Korea Refuses Bodies
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 31 (Reuters)  North Korea rejected today an offer by the Americanled United Nations Command to return the bodies of six crewmen from an armed North Korean boat sunk off the South Korean coast on July 21. The North said the boat incident was a fabrication designed to justify what it called an illegal American occupation of South Korea.

title: DR. GEORGES KLEEFELD
description: Dr. Georges Kleefeld, an ophthalmologist for many years in New York, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old and had been an eye specialist for 65 years until he gave up his practice last October.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation, manufacturer of computer systems, farm equipment and systems for the marine and aviation industries, announced the establishment of a sixman office of the chairman yesterday. The announcement was made after the annual meeting in New York, during which the company's name was changed to the Sperry Corporation.

title: Koch Removes Baden as the City's Medical Examiner
description: Mayor Koch, apparently responding to complaints received from one of the city's five District Attorneys and from the Health Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would nit make permanent the appointment of Dr. Michael M. Baden as Chief Medical Examiner.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: The Rev. Raymond R. Cosgrove, assistant pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in the Avenel section of Woodbridge, N.J., died Sunday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: India's Small Farmers Pleased That Premier Is One of Them
description: CHAPRAULI, India, July 31  This village, the home base of Prime Minister Charan Singh, reflects the prosperity that has come to his fellow Jats, a caste of peasant landowners.

title: EARNINGS
description: The shortage of gasoline and its rising price helped the Greyhound Corportion, the nation's largest bus system, increase its secondquarter earnings by 78.2 percent, the company said yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, July 31, 1979

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 31  A bid to repeat an earlier victory failed today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Two voting experts. Neil Silverman of New York and Bob Lipsitz of Alexandria, Va., were a board ahead of their nearest rivals after the semifinal stage of the life master pair championship, in which 60 pairs survived from an entry of 632, but fell out of contention in the first final session.

title: Farm Prices Rose By 0.75% in July
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)A grainprice boom that began in late spring helped raise the average prices farmers, got for raw food and fiber products by 0.75 percent in July, the Agriculture Department said today. Farm prices in July were up 14 percent from a year earlier.

title: Carter Expects Rise in Joblessness; Believes C.O.P. Will Pick Reagan
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  President Carter expects unemployment to rise during the rest of this year and into 1980, when he is determined to make a fight to hold onto the Presidency, he told a visitor to the White House last night.

title: U.S. Aides Seek Palestinian Role in Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The United States is interested in seeing a new formula for a United Nations resolution that could serve as a basis for bringing Palestinians, and possibly even the Palestine Liberation Organization, into Middle East peace talks, Administration officials said today.

title: 6 Sought in Alleged Fixing Of Milford JaiAlai Games
description: HARTFORD, July 31 (UPI)Arrest warrants were issued today for six Florida men on perjury, rigging and conspiracy charges stemming from an alleged gamefixing scheme at the Milford jaialai fronton.

title: Stage: Never Jam Today By Vinnette Carroll
description: BUT Never Jam Today, Vinnette Carroll's homespun black musical version of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, which opened last night at the Longacre Thea ter, is very freely adapted from Lewis Carroll. The show uses thany of his characters, extracts large sections of the text, but is a rabbit's hole away from the spirit and the humor of the original. The show is more in the nature of a takeoff than a tribute.

title: WHETTV to Produce Series on Jews
description: A major publictelevision series on the impact of the Jews on world civilization during 4,000 years has moved from the project stage to a definite production, as a result of a grant of $1 million from the Charles H. Revson Foundation.

title: Deaths
description: SCHERHarold, beloved husband of Marie D. Services were held July 27, 1979 at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Administration Worried About Chrysler finances
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Carter Administration, suggesting that it may ask Congress to give substantial financial aid to the Chrysler Corporation, expressed the fear today that should the auto company fail, it would shake the overall economy.

title: Grant Given for Dramas On Chicano History
description: KCETTV, the Los Angeles public television station, has been awarded a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to write a pilot script and several story treatments for a series of documentary dramas about the contributions of Chicanos to United States society.

title: The City
description: The 28yearold alleged leader of a major international cocainesmuggling ring was ordered held on $1 million bail at an arraignment yesterday before a Federal magistrate.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Deaths
description: HOFFMANElias A. Sole sacrifice and suffering are walled by love and affection from those who will never forget you.

title: Excerpts From Letters to Koch and Baden's Replies to Charges on Competence
description: Following are excerpts front letters by the city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Reinldo A. Ferrer, and the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, to Mayor Koch regarding the appointment of Dr. Michael M. Baden as Chief Medical Examiner. Each letter is accompanied by excerpts from Dr. Baden's replies to the Mayor:

title: 2 Killed in Air Force Jet Crash
description: JORDAN VALLEY, Ore., July 31 (UPI)  Two crewmen aboard an Air Force F111A Jet from Mountain Home Air Force Base, Idaho, were killed today in the crash of their craft 35 miles southwest of Jordan Valley while on a routine training mission. The names of the two men were, being withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: House Reverses Rationing Curb On the President
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The House of Representatives reversed itself today and voted to give the President strong authority to draft a standby plan for gasoline rationing. The vote on this key amendment to the gasolinerationing bill, supported by vigorous lobbying from the White House and Democratic leaders, was 234 to 189.

title: Careers
description: ENERGY managers, like many people in relatively new fields, find confusion abounds. Just what is an energy manager?

title: Garment Union Calls Some Bronx Factories Sweatshop Operations
description: The signs on deteriorating buildings, Operators Wanted on Dresses, offer the promise of work and wages for people in the South Bronx. But behind the walls, members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union charged yesterday, piecework sweatshops flourish dirty, crowded and hazardous.

title: Bolivian Leftist Calls on Supporters To Protest Official Election Results
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 31  A leftist presidential candidate. and major labor and peasant organizations called today for a peaceful popular mobilization to protest what they said were fraudulent election results.

title: Rhodesia Policy Cited
description: LONDON, July 31  The Nigerian nationalization of B.P. holdings had been a topic of speculation here for some weeks and is seen as a retaliatory move against the moves of Britain's new Conservative . Government to recognize Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: Wine Talk
description: Let's see, was the 64 Lafite picked before the rain or after? Should I drink my 74 Bordeaux before my 71's? Are the 1974 cabernets as good as the 1968's were? What aie the good years in Chianti? In the Rheingau? In the Loire?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONE of those fancy new East Side apartment buildings, writes Florence Conlon, is fortunate to have as a tenant a friend of mine who is a very caring person running over, you might say, with empathy and understanding.

title: Summer Pond
description: Swimming in a summer pond, we notice how natural it is to use all four limbs to travel along. We are a quadruped again; even a stroke is called the crawl. Opening our eyes under water, we look down instead of straight ahead or un. A log sunk on the bottom looms like a snapping turtle. The stems of the pond lilies, rising live feet, tangle one's arms a little frighteningly people sometimes drown that way - and leeches live among them eating bullfrogs eggs. But a porcupine will happily swim out to chew the lily pads, just as a beaver may climb the bank to eat raspberries for a change of fare.

title: N.B.A. Players to Hold Benefit Program Aug. 11
description: The National Basketball Players Association will hold a Give Something Back day Saturday, Aug. 11, at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens. The fournart program, starting at 5 P.M., will include a basketball clinic, an oldtimers game, an allstar game and the finals of a players tennis tournament.

title: Dividends
description: x1 for 10 revere stork, record and paYabN doles unianae1oed.

title: Fire Traps Ohio Motel Guests
description: CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, July 31(UPI)A fierce fire spewing toxic smoke from a vinyl wall covering turned a Holiday ??n jammed with vacationers into a damned death trap before dawn today, killing nine persons, including a woman who died with her baby in her arms.

title: Hispanics Seek Bigger Role at White House
description: Several weeks ago a leading HispanicAmerican political figure from the Southwest gave a senior White House staff member the following assessment of the Carter Administration's chief problem in relations with the nation's fastestgrowing minority group:

title: Notes on People
description: Henry A. Kissinger is going to subject himself to an hourlong interview with David Frost, who conducted muchdiscussed series of inquisitions with Richard M. Nixon in 1977.

title: G.M. to Lay Off 675 More
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 31 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation has announced that it is laying off 675 hourly production workers at its Delco Air Conditioning Division, increasing the number of that company's layoffs in the Dayton area to 1,585. Last week General Motors announced layoffs in Detroit that will idle 12,630 assembly and body plant workers by November.

title: Travel May Link Confessed Killer To Other Deaths
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 31 State police investigators are poring over the travel receipts and telephone bills of Joseph J. Fischer, looking for any evidence that will document the 50yearold paroled murderer's selfdescribed, yearlong, crosscountry odyssey of homicides.

title: Pratt & Whitney Order
description: the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, a unit of United Technologies Inc., said yesterday that its JT9D engines had been selected by Braniff International to power the carrier's new Being 747 SP jetliner. The order is worth about $10 million.

title: Deaths
description: FLYNNThomas J., Jr. on July 29, 1979. Beloved husband of Gertrude (nee Mahoney). Loving father of Mary Ellen Conroy, Patricia and Regina Flynn. Devoted son of Thomas and Margaret Flynn. Reposing Walter B. Cook, Inc., Funeral Home, 85th Street and 3rd Avenue, NYC. Visiting 2.5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Bullet 10AM Thursday, Church of St. Emeric. Interment Calvary Cemetery.
