description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Marathon Oil Plans To Drill Off Tunisia
description: FINDLAY, Ohio, Aug. 1 (Reuters) The Marathon Oil Company said today that a subsidiary, Marathon Exploration Tunisia Ltd., had obtained a 45 percent interest in an exploration and drilling project off Tunisia.

title: Moynihan Opens Way For FavoriteSon Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he would consider running as a favoriteson Presidential candidate from New York State if President Carter is unhorsed in the early primary elections and no clear choice emerges among Democratic party officials in New York State.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Microsystems. Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a manufacturer of semiconductor circuits, has named Marshall A. Petersen a 'senior vice president for corporate administration, secretary and treasurer.

title: Buyer Confidence: 4Year LowFound
description: Consumer confidence in July dropped to its lowest point since the spring of 1975, according to figures to be released today by the Conference Board, a business research organization.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: GIOVANNA COSTA (Costa Line Cargo Services). Barc,tonne Aug. 12, Genoa 13, Naples 16 and Leghorn 17; sails from KaneSt.. Brooklyn.

title: When to Bail Out Chrysler
description: Isn't there something disingenuous about the Chrysler Corporation seeking salivation from the Federal Government? Chrysler calls on Washington for a $1billion loan in the form of accelerated tax credits and for relaxation of deadlines for complying with Federal mileage and pollution standards. The latter are blamed for the company's losses  $207 million in the second quarter. Yet the companyi cannot produce enough of the small cars that are mandated by the Government and cannot sell the big cars it has been building instead in defiance of the spirit of those standards. If Chrysler had built the cars Washington wanted, it would be building the cars consumers now want. And it might well be Chrysler that would be pocketing the $1,000 premium that car buyers are willing to give to Honda.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Shares of the MGIC Investment Corporation, the nation's biggest homeloan insurer, rose more than $7 a share in the last two sessions to $33.25. Executivek in Milwaukee said yesterday that while very preliminary merger talks had been held with several companies, to date nothing has developed from these discussions and MGIC does not know whether anything will.

title: SENATE PANEL SEEKS TO CUT CARTER PLAN FOR SYNTHETIC FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee served notice today that it would film back and slow down President Carter's $88 billion program to develop synthetic fuels, spending less money and making fewer and less dramatic promises.

title: OSRORN MILLER DIES; A NOTED MAPMAKER
description: Osborn Maitland Miilex a past director of the American Geographical Society and a highly respected pioneer of modern cartography' techniques, died yesterday at Roosevelt' Hospital. Mr. Miller, who had been retird since 1968 and lived in New York City, was 83 years old.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, posted a secondquarter net profit of $47.8 million, or $1.77 a share, according to yesterday's report from the company's St. Louis headquarters.

title: How a Home Can Be A Retirement Shelter
description: AHOUSE is not just a home. A new tax break also makes it a splendid way to help finance your retirement. With inflation now rising at a rate equal to 13.2 percent a year, your house is probably the best investment you have ever made. It makes sense  in terms of taxes and economics  to take advantage of some of the gains it has provided.

title: Market Place
description: IS it reasonable to buy shares of a company, the majority of which have been bought up by another company, on the theory that the acquirer will eventually buy out the minority interest?

title: Mrs. Thatcher A rr's Takeover of 0i1 Company
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 1  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took Nigeria to task today for nationalizing British petroleum interests yesterday. She spoke at the opening session of the conference of Commonwealth heads of government here.

title: You Could Look It Up. (In Vain).
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va.  Our legal system is built on judicial precedents. Because of this, there is an elaborate method of reporting the outcome of lawsuits in America. Law libraries and law offices contain thousands of these reports, indexed and crossreferenced by subject, descriptive words, title, style, state and region.

title: About Chautauqua
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 31 Eighty years before Jimmy Carter's cross-of-malaise speech was broadcast instantly to the nation, then summarily shredded for secondslong TV news excerpts, there was, of course, William Jennings Bryan's Cross of Gold speech In contrast to President Carter's plunge from the mountain to sinkorswim trial by national television; Mr. Bryan was able to deliver his speech again and again, year after year, here at the heart. of the once great Chautauqua speaking circuit and could witness the phenomenon President Carter seems to crave so much lately: patient attention from average Americans.

title: China Marks Army Anniversary
description: PEKING, Aug. 1 (UPI)  China today marked the 52d anniversary of the Communist army, calling on the nation's mili. tary forces to step up vigilance against threats of aggression. Peking, with an estimated 3.6 million in the regular forces and about 10 million in the militia, assigned $12.8 billion of its $80 billion national budget this year to military purposes.

title: Debate On in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Official Washington has begun informally debating the Chrysler Corporation's request for up to $1 billion in Federal aid. The dispute is expected to develop into a first

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Kissinger's Revival of the. Linkage. Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Henry A. Kissinger has. dramatically revived linkage as; a political and foreign policy issue by proposing that future strategic arms negottions with the Soviet Union be halted if the Russians doPlotpractice military restraint around the world.

title: Visit by Jesse Jackson Stirs Up a Whirlwind Among Blacks and Whites in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug, 1  Since Aftlither nationalists took power in South Africa three decades ago and began closing off the country to foreigners agitaing against their ratial laws few visitors have provoked the stir aroused by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson. The Chicagobased black activist wound up a twoweektour of the country today and left for the United States.

title: Merchant Ships Now Willing to Help Boat People
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 1  Merchant ships plying the South China Sea have shown a new willingness to help Vietnamese refugees now that Western nations have adopted a climate for accepting them quickly without hindering commerce, according to shipping industry officials here.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The White Motor Corporation has reached outside the company to.name a successor to 66yearold Semon E. Knudsen as chief executive officer.

title: French Leave Is Victor In Orange County Show
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1 French Leave, owned and handled by Tim Herrick, beat 12 rivals to win the first openjumper class today at the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Bagley Acquitted Of Fraud
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 1 (AP)  A Federal court jury today acquitted Smith Bagley, an heir to the R.J. Reynolds tobacco fortune, and four codefendants of stock fraud charges.

title: Books: Helen Strauss
description: HELEN STRAUSS'S talent for luck led her from an apprenticeship in the story department of Paramount Pictures to becoming the founder. 35 years ago, of a literary department in the William Morris Agency, which, until her arrival, had concentrated on showbusiness matters. Over the years, she developed a dazzling array of clients, including a list of Pulitzer Prizewinners such as James Michener, Robert Penn Warren, Leon Edel, Archibald MacLeish and Bill Mauldin.

title: Cranston Sees Room for Negotiation on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  One of the Senate's Democratic leaders said today the chances for approval of the strategic arms treaty would be greatly improved if ratification was linked with some increase in defense spending and a drive for deeper reductions in armaments in future treaties.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  The House of Representatives, for the second time in little over a month, voted tonight to complete work on the $119 million Tellico Dam project despite the threat poses to the tiny snail darter, an endangered species of fish.

title: Carter's Visit Buoys Old Kentucky Homes
description: BARDSTOWN, Ky., Aug. 1  Moments after President Carter left the sweltering highchool auditorium here where he held his town meeting last night, the crowd poured out into the only slightly cooler evening air and Joseph Phillip Bowling, a druggist, said: I'd vote for the man. As of now, I'd say I'd vote for the man.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: GLADYS G. NORTHCROFT

title: Senate Confirms Civiletti
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The Senate confirmed Benjamin R. Civiletti today as Attorney General. Mr. Civiletti, who is 44 years old, replaces Griffin B. Bell, whose request to resign was accepted last month by President Carter in a Cabinet shakeup. The nomination was approved, 94 to 1, with only Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, voting against him.

title: Lockheed Bailout Largest by U.S.
description: As the Chrysler Corporation's financial problems were making news, financial sources recalled yesterday that the largest Government bailout occurred five years ago. It was the 1979 Federal loan guarantee of up to $250 million extended to the Lockheed Corporation, the large aerospace concern based in Burbank, Calif.

title: G.I. PLEDGES EFFORT FOR FUEL EFFICIENCY
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1  The General Motors Corporation, a leader in theautomobile industry's recent  efforts to persuade the Government to relax its fuel economy standards foi automobiles of the 1980's, said today that it might well exceed the Government standard of 27.5 miles per gallon as a fleet average with, its 1985 models.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  A Superior Court judge inTolland ruled terday that the white foster parents of a 4monthold black infant could not adopt the child, whom they had been caring for since March. Michael and Wendy Lusa of Vernon, Coon., said one reason they wanted to adopt a nonwhite child was that they were members of the Bahai faith, which does not recognize racial differences, and they complained that the Department of Children and Youth Services had a policy against interracial adoptions.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchangeand (0) overthecounter.

title: Liberal Group Announces New Party and Plan for Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Asserting that Democrats and Republicans were sidestepping the major economic and social issues facing the United States, a group of disenchanted activists, most of them liberals, today announced the formation of a Citizens Party that would field its own Presidential candiate in 1980.

title: On Carter and the Washington Press Corps
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  After two and a half years in the White House, President Carter and his top aides seem to have concluded, as other Administrations have in the past, that the Washington press corps is more a hindrance than a help in getting the President's message across.

title: Unarmed U.N. Truce Observers Take Over Sinai Posts From Peace Force
description: CHECKPOINT 560, Sinai, Aug. 1  Unarmed United Nations truce observers, minus Soviet. and United. States contingents, have quietly taken over checkpoint and patrol duties in the Sinai buffer zone from the departing united Nations Emergency Force, despite Israeli objections to deployment of the observers.

title: Koch Expected to Name Leventhal Deputy Mayor
description: Mayor Koch is expected to name the Commissionerof the. city's Housing Preservation and Development Department, Nathan Leventhal, as Deputy Mayor with broad responsibilities for administration,coordination andmanagement.

title: Conrail Train Derails
description: NORTH EAST, Md., Aug. 1 (AP) Conrail freight train derailed on Amtrak's northeast corridor today, blocking passenger service between New York and Washington.

title: An Icy Challenge Starts
description: Fool me once, says the coach of the United States Olympic hockey team, and it's shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: FUTILE EFFORT: Dwayne Lineberger of the Rescue Squad in Gastonia, N.C., giving artificial respiration to one of three children removed from a burning home. All three died of smoke inhalation, as did their mother, Jean Gwinn.

title: A Town Refuses To Ask U.S. Aid For the Disabled
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 1  A $178,700 Federal grant to aid handicapped students was overwhelmingly rejected yesterday by town voters following a campaign in which there were warnings that accepting the grant might lead to a Government requirement that the town build public housing.

title: Professionals Voice Concern Over Dismissal of Baden
description: The ouster of Dr. Michael M. Baden as Chief Medical Examiner of New York brought expressions of shock and indignation yesterday among physicians and other professionals in many parts of the country who have worked with him.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Sexual Style: Facing and : Making Choices About Sex,.by Robert Meyners and Claire Wooster (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, S10).

title: Christopher Isherwood, as He Approaches 75, Finds Himself to Be a Cynosure
description: CHRISTOPHER ISHERWOOD will be 75 on Aug. 26. At an age at which even writers Max, without fanfare he will have more works by and about him being published than ever before in one season. That seemed a good enough excuse to call him up to get the directions from Los Angeles to his house in Santa Monica. His final caution was so California:

title: Hers
description: PARENTS who linger at the terminal waving byebye to the fumes of the bus in which their pubescent camper is seated may be compared to the classic mother who weepingly escorts her son to the train that will take him off to battle. Both situations are fraught with self-deception. The soldier's mother convinces herself that someone else's bey will be killed, not hers; the camp. er's mother believes that camp is a hiatus from the tough real world, when actually, as every teenager knows, it is an italicization.

title: Deaths
description: ANGELAnn. Beloved sister of Syrit Sylvia Bluth, Philip and Irving, Adored aunt of Macia Goodman, Barbara, Rhonda and Jim. Services Thursday 1 PM, The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Milton J. Lewine, 50, Professor at Columbia On the History of Art
description: Milton J. Lewin, professor of art history and archeology at Columbia University, died Tuesday of cancer at the. Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 390 Riverside Drive.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: NO HOME RUNS, but Phillies Mike Schmidt, who shares homer lead in majors at 36 with Dave Kingman, drove in three runs in Phillies 96 victory over Mets yesterday.

title: Furnishing A Soap Opera To Imperfection
description: PEOPLE pay their designers a lot of money to make their apartments look perfect. But Robert Franklin is getting paid to design interiors that look ... well, not bad, really  just not perfect.

title: U.S. IS URGING SPEED IN WEST BANK TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  High Administration officials, sensing new diplomatic openings in the Middle East, assert that there must be noticeable progress in negotiations on Palestinian autonomy over the next 10 weeks or the West is likely to face increased pressures on its oil supplies from Arab producers.

title: Arson Suspected in Houston Blaze
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1  Investigators said today that they suspected arson as the cause of a fire here last night that was being described as the worst in the city's recent history.

title: Production Of Gasoline Declines
description: Output at the nation's petroleun refineries rose slightly in the week ended July 27, but gasoline production declined because most of the increase went toward replenishing distillate fuel stocks, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Regrets for a Lost Jasmine Tree
description: I'VE promised myself not to become emotionally involved with my new tree. Our relationship is to be sane, friendly and mutually supportive. I will provide water, sustenance and light from the tall windows that face south, reinforced with 500 watts of mercury vapor lamp for 14 hours a day at an estimated cost of $17.80 a month. The new tree, ficus benjamina, will supply the lacy greenness which the empty upper reaches of my living room cry for, and which the asparagus plumosus and the Norwood fern.don't adequately provide.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Aug. 1, 1979

title: A Better Idea How to Hide A Bed Under A Platform
description: HERE'S a useful way to maximize space: a queensize bed that rolls neatly out on casters from its secret hiding place under a carpeted platform. It was the brainchild of two interior design partners, Rita Falkener and Stan Stuetley of Brooklyn Heights.

title: Don Weiss's Zebra Opens At the Diplomat Aug. 16
description: Zebra, a satire on bigotry by Don Weiss, will have its premiere at the Hotel Diplomat Theater, 108 West 43d Street, on Aug. 16.

title: Technology
description: VOICE pitch analysis, a sort of consumer lie detector test, is finding increasing use as a sup. plementary and more sophisticated tool in the broad field of market research.

title: U.S. Puts Off Ban on DES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) The Government today postponed until Nov. 1 today a ban on the use of the synthetic hormone diethylstilbestrol, known as DES, a drug used to stimulate growth in cattle and sheep.

title: I.M.F. Gold Brings $289.59 an Ounce
description: The International Monetary Fund sold 444,000 ounces of gold at an average price of $289,59 an ounce in its monthly sale yesterday, the agency disclosed in Washington.

title: Town in Italy Bares Its Soul In Annual Play
description: MONTICCHIELLO, Italy, July 29 In this storybook town of a hundred stone houses crowded behind ramparts on a cypressstudded hill in Tuscany. the cobbled town square serves as stage and a cast of townspeople. play out their own lives for an audience of 500 strangers every night for a month.

title: The Banquette: A New Classic
description: THE banquette was once only a'owly bench according to the French definition, a back less seating unit. Often used in large spaces when dozens had to be seated at dinner, the term banquet hall is a reminder of one of its original functions. Restaurants, particularly French restaurants, celebrated the legless banquette. One didn't need to clean under them, and they allowed for more flexible table arrangements. Women were traditionally seated on the banquette, protected from the possible clumsiness of waiters, and reflected in the mirrors that usually lined the walls.

title: Pilot Sets Down a Jet In a Correct Landing But at Wrong Airport
description: BUFFALO, Wyo., Aug. 1 (AP)  The 94 passengers who boarded a Western Airlines Boeing 737 in Denver thought they were flying to Sheridan, Wyo. But in a case of mistaken identity, the pilot set them down 35 miles away in Buffalo.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 1  Four pairs of internationally famous stars were fighting for the life master pair title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here last night, but two littleknown players took the prize. Ralph Katz of Steubenville, Ohio, and Kenneth Schutze of Huntsville, Tex., led throughout the twosession finals and were convincing winners by more than a full board. night, but two littleknown players took the prize. Ralph Katz of Steubenville, Ohio, and Kenneth Schutze of Huntsville, Tex., led throughout the twosession finals and were convincing winners by more than a full board.

title: U.S. Advised Israel on Team
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The State Depattment said last month that the United Stites had long made it clear to Israel and Egypt that the truce observer team in Sinai would include no Soviet or American members, though both had served as members of the organization.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Miller and Volcker Advance in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) President Carter's nominations of G. William Miller to be Treasury Secretary and of Paul A. Volcker to succeed Mr. Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board were approved unanimously today by Senate committees.

title: Ramos, ExYank Reliever, Facing Cocaine Charges
description: MIAMI, Aug. 1 (AP)  Pedro Ramos, the ace reliever in the New York Yankees narrow American League pennant victory in 1964, was released on bond today after his arrest in connection with a seizure of $2 million in drugs.

title: Deaths
description: MOSSSamuel H. I deeply mourn the loss of my grandfather and dearest friend. Ronald Raphael

title: Alitalia May Cancel Order for 6 DC10's
description: ROME, Aug. 1(Reuters)  The Italian national airline, Alitalia, is expected to drop an order for six McDonnell Douglas Corporation DC10 jetliners, sources said today.

title: Bolivia Beckoned by Its Past
description: The luster has already faded from Bolivia's shiny new democracy, unveiled only a month ago. There is even a chance the first popularly elected president in a decade may not take office as scheduled next Monday.

title: PekingMoscow Train Canceld
description: PEKING, Aug 1 (Reuters)  The weekly train linking Peking, Ulan Bator and Moscow was canceled today for third week because of flooding in Mongolia, Chinese railway officials said.

title: Officer in Birmingham Who Killed Black Woman Is Off Police Duty
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1 (AP)  A white police officer who shot and killed a young black woman inan incident that prompted racial demonstrations and a call for a store boycott will not return to .police duty, the mayor's office said today.

title: Freeze Will Be Relaxed In City Hospital Hiring
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation will relax a fourmonthold job freeze in the next few weeks and begin hiring up to 800 people for low and middlelevel positions directly relating to patient care, Joseph C. Hoffman, the corporation president, said last night.

title: Jets Leahy to Watch Rivals
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 1  Pat Leahy, prd football's secondleading scorer last season, will watch from the sidelines on Saturday when two rivals attempt to take bis placekicking job on the Jets.

title: Food Funds Cut in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Aug.1  United Nations officials, short of relief funds, ended daily food allowances of $1 a person to some 17,000 Vietnamese refugees here today.

title: Expert Not Sure Whether DC10 Should Be in Air
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1  A Government expert said today that many qualified engineers, including himself, would question whether the DC10 jumbo jet should be back in airline service in view of unknowns about the vulnerability of its engine mounts to rough air, or gusts.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Beatrix Lehmann, British Actress Of Stage, Screen, TV and Radio
description: Beatrix Lehmann, an actress whose long career in the British theater included appearances in classical dramas as well as in plays by Eugene O'Neill and Tennessee Williams, died yesterday in London. She was 76 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Gasoline Tanker Truck Explodes
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1 (UPI)  A gasoline tanker truck being unloaded at a fuel tank storage area exploded today, sending smoke hundreds of feet into the air and forcing the evacuation of the surrounding residential area. There were no immediate reports of serious injuries, but more than a dozen firemen and other persons reportedly suffered smoke inhalation and were taken to hospitals.

title: New U.S. Price Ceilings on Gas Bring Varying Effects at Pumps
description: New Federal uniformprofit ceilings took effect yesterday at gasoline filling stations throughout the country, and the effects of the price controls, at least throughout New York City and surrounding suburban counties, appeared to vary widely.

title: Dr. Richard H. Heindel, ExPenn State Dean, 66
description: Dr. Richard H. Heindel, an international relations specialist and former dean of Pennsylvania State University's Capitol Campus in Harrisburg and president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, died Tuesday in Harrisburg. He was 66 years old.

title: Advertising
description: WinILE all around him publishers are elaborately researchg and testing new magazine concepts before investing the huge amounts necessary for successful starts, Bob Guccione, publisher and editor, continues to rely only on his own gut feelings. This is according to Kathy Keeton, longtime friend and associate publisher of Omni, which she considers the fourth win in five Guccione starts.

title: 80 Census Is Peril to 2 in Congress
description: New York City's projected loss of three Congressional seats after the 1980 census is likely to touch off a bitter struggle for survival in the city's delegation in the House of Representatives. The careers of two of the city's three minoritygroup members could be jeopardized.

title: Rumania Bars SovietBloc Cash For Gasoline, Stranding Tourists
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 Rumania put into effect today regulations requiring all foreigners to pay in Western currencies for gasoline and oil. The order, at the height of the Black Sea resort season, stranded thousands of East European touristsat the border.

title: City Picks Soccer Coach
description: Gus Naclerio was named yesterday as the City College soccer coach, replacing Felix Fuksman. The 48yearold Naclerio, a selfemployed freelance translator of languags, was a former City College soccer star. An allAmerican in 1954, Naclerio played for the 1951, 1953 and 1954 metropolitan championship teams. He is actively involved in youth soccer.

title: Decoding the Federal Criminal Code
description: The biggest stranded whale on Capitol Hill hit the water yesterday with a welcome splash. As a result, it is possible, even probable, that the 96th Congress will do what other Congresses have been unable or unwilling to try: to clean up the mess that history and changing needs have made of the Federal criminal laws.

title: Keepers of the Dream
description: WASHINGTON  Liberal members of Congress  because liberals increasinglyare becoming former members of Congress  are trying to shed their political label.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354-3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P,M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. (516) 669.1000; CONNECTICUT (203)3457767.

title: Moscow Said to Urge Shaky Afghan Regime to Broaden Its Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan. Aug. 1 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union, concerned by widespread opposition to Afghanistan's leftwing rulers, has urged the Government to broaden its political base in its struggle to survive, according to diplomats here.

title: McEnroe and Gerulaitis Gain
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1 John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis, the tournament favorites, scored easy firstround victories today in the $75,000 Mutual Benefit Life open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (Reuters) James Bond, the film superspy, got a message today from Russia without much love.

title: Damask Fan Captures Feature at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1  If there is a fuel shortage, it was not evident here today as America's oldest active race track began its 112th meeting.

title: GOING OUT
description: ABOUT TIME So far this summer, the ttheater scene has lacked something  one of those coolly calculated mysterythrillers by Christie, always a nice urban counter part to hammock reading during vacation.

title: Kroger Is Charged With Price Fixing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP) The Kroger Company, one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, has been charged in United States District Court witE allegedly trying to monopolize the retail supermarket business in central Ohio.

title: Ellen Burstyn s Career Takes a New Direction
description: ELLEN BURSTYN, on directors: On William Friedkin, who directed her in The Exorcist": I hope Ive, absorbed some of his capacity for directing as one aspect of fierce determination, the desire to do a job as perfectly as it can be done.

title: Cosmos Beat Aztecs, 31
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI) The Cosmos clinched the Eastern Division title in the National Conference of the North American Soccer League tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Aztecs, 31, before 38,606 fans in the Rose Bowl.

title: Dance: Boishol fallet Opens With 'stone Flower
description: IT has been four years since the Bolshoi Ballet appeared in New York and last night at the New York State Theater, the famed company from Moscow opened with Yuri Grigorovich's The Stone Flower, a ballet that has not been seen in New York in 20 years.

title: Yanks Hit 3 Homers, Rout White Sox, 91
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 The New York Yankees smashed three home runs, including the 359th of Reggie Jackson's career, in a 12hit attack tonight and routed the Chicago White Sox, 91, for a sweep of the threegame series in Comiskey Park. It was the seventh straight setback for the White Sox.

title: Midsummer at the Riverside
description: Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream will be given a dozen performances on the roof garden of Riverside Church, 400 Riverside Drive, beginning next Thursday. Rosey Hay, who has worked with the Royal Shakespeare Company, will stage the play, which is being presented as part of, the church's Arts in Religion program. For information, call 7497000, ext. 126.

title: Savings Level Off for June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) Federally insured savings and loan associations attracted $1.5 billion in new deposits in June, the smallest monthly total in three years, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Gas Ration Bill Passed By House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The House. of Representatives voted tonight to give President Carter power to draft a standby gasoline rationing plan. But earlier in the day it amended the bill's energy conservation section by adopting a series of measures meant to protect special interests ranging from hospitals to farmers.

title: SUBWAY CAll HAZARD FROM FAULTY BRAKE IS CITED BY PULLMAN
description: The manufacturer of the troubleplagued R46 subway cars urgently recommended yesterday the removal of hand brake on the vehicles that it said constituted a safety hazard that could not otherwise be remedied.

title: Motorists Stranded as Derailed Train Rams Bridge
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 1 (AP)  Interstate 80 was closed. for 50 miles today after a derailed freight train damaged a bridge, and thousands of motorists were either stranded or sought detours through. the forests of Wyoming and Colorado.

title: Chromalloy Buying Barred
description: A Federal judge granted the Chromalloy American Corporation a temporary restraining order yesterday barring further purchases of its stock by the Sun Chemical Corporation. Chromalloy had filed a lawsuit alleging that Sun Chemical, Sun Chemical's chairman, Norman Alexander, and Jefferies & Company, a brokerdealer, made false and misleading filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and were engaged in unlawful efforts to acquire control of Chromalloy.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold tumbled yesterday as the appointment of Paul A. Volckeras chairman of the Federal Reserve Board was confirmed by the Senate Banking Committee. But the dollar also slipped while the British pound staged a comeback from a battering Tuesday.

title: ChicagoFest Opens Tomorrow
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI)  ChicagoFest, a 10day music and food festival expected to attract 700,000 people, has also become a part of Chicago politics.

title: The Editorial Notebook Mr. Kissinger's Artful Recipe.
description: Now that the stardust has settled, the real significance of Henry Kissinger's SALT testimony is plain. The former Secretary of State has called on the Senate to ratify the pending arms treaty as it stands. All the rest was literature, with some politics mixed in. He made the case of the SALT critics his own, but proposed solutions that should preserve the treaty.

title: COMMODITIES
description: After two days of limit declines, prices of metals, grain and soybean futures snapped back yesterday with substantial advances. But livestock futures continued their steep decline.

title: Giants Send Gregory Back to the Browns
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 1 Jack Gregory got his wish today and will return to Cleveland.

title: Electronic Mail Rift
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Federal Communications Commission, in the opening shot of what promises to be a protracted battle, ruled today that the Postal Service must be regulated by the F.C.C. in any electronic mail system it establishes.

title: Books of The Tirnes
description: WE shall never get to the bottom of Charles Darwin; we are thinking weeds on the sea of his data. He is down below the surface somewhere, synthesizing, writing monographs on Cirripedia, feeding crumbs of cork and slices of the visceral cavity of a toad to his insectavoris sundew flowers. Here is how Loren Eiseley, the anthropologist and historian of science who died two years ago, describes him:

title: Baden Ouster Highlights Pressures on Medical Examiner
description: Let conversation cease. Let laughter flee. This is the place where death delights in helping the living.

title: Skylab Fragment to Be Shown
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The largest piece of Skylab found so far and another fragment will be shown for the first time in the United States at Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry, museum officials announced today. The largest piece is about 7 feet long and 4 feet in diameter, and weighs about a ton. The exhibit will begin tomorrow and will remain at the museum through Aug. 12.

title: Cutting Social Security
description: SAVANNAH. Ga.  Our Social Security laws should be changed so that wealthy people would be disqualified from receiving certain Social Security benefits.

title: Klein Wants Suffolk To Form an Authority To Reduce Sewer Debt
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 1  The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, today proposed a plan to refinance the troubled Southwest Sewer District that he said would lower sewer taxes for district residents and remove the $1 billion project from the political arena.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: WITH a digital garage door opener, one has the convenience and safety of opening and closing the garage door from the car. It also can turn on a light in the garage, which will stay on for several minutes, allowing time to park the car and go into the house with light.

title: Council Panel, Advised About Cost To Consumers, Cuts City Licensing
description: The Consumer Affairs Committee of the City Council voted yesterday to eliminate licensing, requirements for a wide array of industries including miniaturegolf courses, coffeehouses, bowling alleys, hatcheckers and massage parlors.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Aug. 1  Filippo Maria Pandolfi, a hristian.. Democrat, announced tonight that.he had failed in his effort to form a new Italian governzpent. As a result, President Sandro Pentini will name anotherprime ministerdemote.

title: Allied Chemical Charge Shifted
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The Goverment moved today to have an indictment against the president of the Allied Chemical Corporation dropped, but replaced it with one in which it maintained charges against the cornpany and four other men named in the first action.

title: Pertec Informed of Bid
description: The Pertec Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had received a letter from a multinational company expressing an interest in acquiring a significant minority interest in Pertec. The suitor, which Pertec declined to identify, offered to acquire shares partly through the purchase of newly issued shares and partly through a tender for existing shares.

title: Drive to Revamp U.S. CrimeLws Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The first comprehensive revision of Federal criminal laws in the nation's history, including abolition of parole for Federal prisoners, stands a better chanceof passage in Congress this session than at any time since it was first proposed more than a decade ago, Congressional leaders said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article In Metropolitan Report last Tuesday incorrectly identified a lawyer handling the court appeal of Pamela O'Shaughnessy, a reporter convicted of contempt for refusing to identify a confidential source. The lawpers who represented Miss O'Shaughnessy in the appeal were Vincent Farrell and Herald Price Fahringer.

title: U.S. to Let Russians Buy More Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  American wheat is now in large enough supply to allow the Soviet Union to buy at least 10 million additional metric tons in the next 14 months, Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture, announced today.

title: Commonwealth: Quiet Teamwork
description: LONDON, Aug. 1About all that most Britons know about the Commonwealth is that its politicians sometimes have class picture taken in the backyard of 10 Downing Street.

title: Electricity Plant In Queens Shifts From Oil to Gas
description: John S. Dyson, formally elected yesterday as chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, announced that the authority was converting part of its Astoria, Queens, electric generating plant from oil to natural gas as a first blow to break the foreign oilproducing nations stranglehold over this country.

title: Pop: Maxine Sullivan
description: AFTER a venture into theater that produced a Tony nomination for her performance in My Old Friends, Maxine Sullivan is back at her old trade this week, singing at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street.

title: Drew S. Days Jr., ExBudget Aide With City College, Is Dead at 65
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Drew S. Days Jr., a retired budget officer at City College of New York, died in the Washington Hospital Center on Sunday. Mr. Days, a resident of Silver Spring, Md., was 65 years old.

title: GARDENING
description: R ABBI JOSEPH SALAMON carried his ivy plant to church the other day, hoping for blessing from the plant doetor.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: With bond prices impressively strong yesterday, the Treasury sold $2.5 billion of 7year notes at an average yield of 9 percent, well below the level traders expected earlier in the week. Sales of recently marketed notes and bonds picked up speed, and investment bankers lowered yields on new issues to be sold today.

title: Niatross Captures Rich Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Aug. 1  Niatross, a 2-year-old pacer, proved tonight that the best things in life are free. The homebred colt raced off with the richest prize for harness or thoroughbred racing in the $862,750 Woodrow Wilson Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: Gamble Sent to Yankees As Rivers Deal Is Settled
description: Fortyeight hours atter they sent Mickey Rivers to the Texas Rangers, the Yankees finally learned yesterday whom they would receive in exchange in the deal that had its provisions altered and grew from a fiveplayer swap to an eightplayer transaction.

title: 22 Food Places Accused Of Violating City's Code
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 22 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named two restaurants that reopened after correcting earlier violations and one that was closed for failing to do so.

title: Cocoa Price
description: GENEVA, Aug. 1  Negotiations under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development on an international agreement to stabilize cocoa prices collapsed tonight.

title: Phillies Beat Mets, 96
description: Pete Rose collected tour singles yesterday, leading the Phillies to a 9.6 victory over the Mets. Rose needs four more singles to tie Honus Wagner's National League record for singles in a career. Story on page D17.

title: A BLACK IS INSTALLED AScATLIOLIC BISHOP
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 1  Bishop James P. Lyke today became the youngest Bishop in the United States hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church and its fifth black member in ordination rites conducted before 1,100 lay people, clergymen and bishops in St. John's Cathedral here.

title: S. & P. Rating Cut On Chrysler Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its ratings of two issues of Chrysler Corporation securities yesterday, citing operations problems resulting from slow sales and high inventries. It also lowered its rating of the Chrysler Financial Corporation's commercial paper.

title: 3 Concerns Get City Aid to Stay And to Expand
description: Deputy Mayor Peter J. Solomon yesterday unveiled three economic development projects in Queens that he said would help keep 550 jobs in the borough and add 180 others.,

title: Ralph Hendershot, 83, an Editor
description: Ralph Hendershot, a retired financial editor and columnist of The WorldTelegram and The Sun, died last Saturday in Tequesta, Fla., following a prostate operation, according to family sources in New York. He was 83 years old. Funeral services were held in Tequista yesterday.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These we the most popular albums and singles nationwide. compiled by Record World, a trade p+bicafion. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets, and singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Dow Gains On Fall in Gold Prices Composite Index Hits 1979 High
description: The stock market pushed higher yesterday as the drop in gold bullion prices apparently encouraged equity navestors. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of all common stocks finished at its best level of 1979, adding 0.22 to close at 59.36.

title: The City
description: Boy, 15, Missing In Attack at River

title: Calendar of Events
description: Designer Showcase, Newport, R.I.

title: Tiger Says Merger With Seaboard Is Set
description: Tiger International Inc. announced that a definite merger agreement between it and Seaboard World Air Lines Inc. had been approved by both boards. Tiger said that Seaboard shareholders of record Aug. 23 would vote on the agreement at a special meeting at a date to be announced. The merger is still subject to approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board and President Carter.

title: Joseph Kotalla, Nazi War Criminal Known as Amersfoort Hangman
description: BREDA, the Netherlands, Aug. 1 (AP) Joseph J. Kotalla, a Nazi war criminal known as the hangman of Amersfoort, has died in prison at the age of 70, the Dutch radio reported today.

title: Gas Chamber Ordered for Killer
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Aug. 1 (AP)  Jesse Walter Bishop, who pleaded guilty to murdering a man married only three hours, was ordered today by District Judge Paul Goldman to die in the gas chamber Aug. 27. Mr. Bishop, 46 years old, was sentenced to death by a threejudge panel on Feb. 10, 1978, for the murder of David Ballard, 22, of Baltimore, who was on his honeymoon when he was gunned down Dec 20, 1977, while attempting to break up a robbery at the El Morocco casino

title: DogCleanup Law Praised After a Year
description: Charles Hendricks, a patrolman for the Sanitation Department, watched a department news conference yesterday marking the first anniversary of New York's dogcleanup law. He did not seem amused, despite+ the occasional levity of the session conducted by Commissioner Norman Steisel at Central Park West and 68th Street.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Clouds containing some showers and thundershowers extend westward along a front from northern New England to the Mississippi Valley and across the Texas Panhandle. Skies are partly cloudy in the South Atlantic States, with clear skies apparent from tho Pacific Northwest to the Southwest Desert region.

title: Notes on People
description: Just two days shy of her 79th birthday Saturday, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother went to Dover, England, yesterday for a pleasantly historic occasion.

title: New Transit Chief Praised for Role in Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 31  In downtown Portland these days, the sounds of construction crews raising new office towers blend with the odors of fresh roses and carnations sold from new streetcorner stands. There is a sense of vitality in the central city, which a few years ago seemed on the brink of decay; retail sales are booming, and the use of public transit has doubled in less than a decade.

title: Talking Business
description: Like many of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms, Ernst & Whiney is adapting to change, particularly in the international arena. The 76yearold firm took a new name on July 1, borrowing from its Londonbased affiliate, Whiney Murray & Company, and dropping the last part of the familiar American name plate, Ernst & Ernst.

title: E.P.A. Official Asks More Funds To Clean Up Hazardous. Wastes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  A top Environmeptal Protection Agency official asked Congtess today, to give the agency more money and authorftyto deal with hazardous waste. A lowerlevel official said that the agency shook do more with what it has.

title: Home Beat
description: JEFFREY WEISS, above, was asked by Canon, the camera manufacturer, to think of a way for amateur photographers to display their work or show collections of photographs at home. I got the idea for the display rack because I had been spending a lot of time in wallpaper and fabric showrooms and liked the way these firms showed their samples, the New York interior designer said. I felt that flipout wings would be one solution for protecting yet showing photography at home. Mr. Weiss found a source that was making just the kind of unit he needed. This is a product that exists, it's not custom made, he emphasized. But it is available in different sizes, with different numbers of panels, and with a variety of colored boards. The hardware is black painted metal. The MultiPanel Display Corporation, 107 Georgia Avenu, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11207 (4953800), makes the compact units, called Displayors. They can be hung on the wall or attached to a stand, as shown above. Photographs can be stapled, tacked or glued to the panels. The panels fold flat against the wall when not in use, and pivot out. The system, as shown, on a stand with six 24by36inch panels is $145. Six panels mounted on a wall unit are $125. Custom frame or board colors are extra. I think of it as a very, very large photograph album, Mr. Weiss said.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The cedar shakes on our 16year old house seem to be worn in spots. The top portion of each shingle, where it is overlapped by the one above, has become paper thin. Do you think it is necessary to replace these shakes to prevent leaks, or is this how they normally weather?  F.P., Monsey, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: LAWRENCE R. SCHIFF

title: Bluegrass Music Contest Set
description: The seventh annual New York City Bluegrass and Old Time Country Music Contest and Crafts Fair will take place Aug. 1112 at the South Street Seaport Museum. The contest, scheduled for the evenings, will include 22 amateur bands competing for $1,000 in prizes.

title: At Last, A Usable Subway Map
description: THIS is not a good time for the city's transit system, what with news reports of cracked undercarriages in new subway cars, defects in new buses and continued subway crime. But in the midst of deterioration, there is one positive accomplishment: It appears as if at long last we are going to have a decent, clear, workable system of signs and maps in the subway. The cars may break, the stations may be filthy, but now we just may know where we are going.

title: Energy
description: President Carter's synthetic fuel program will be cut back and slowed down, the Senate Energy Committee said. The panel decided to regbest only $3 billion for the program in the 1980 budget, compared to the Cirter Administration's budget proposal of $22 billion. Committee members said they had no way to know which of the proposed experiments to produce artificial energy would be worth the billion to $3 billion investment that each would require. [Page A1.]

title: Israeli Opposition Affirmed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1  Israel's opposition to the use of United Nations military observers in the Sinai buffer zone remains unchanged, a delegation spokesman said today.

title: Senate Votes More Funds and Fewer Cuts for Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Senate, bye vote of 89 toll, adopted today a plan for the Amtrak passenger train system that provides more funds for equipment and wipes out more than half of the service cuts proposed by the Administration.

title: New Orders at Factories And in Construction Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  The value of new orders placed with the nation's factories in June was 1.3 percent lower than in May, another sign that the economy has shifted into low gear, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 4 Rose Hits Help Phils Top Mets
description: When Pete Rose came into Shea Stadium yesterday, he needed only nine more singles to surpass Honus Wagner as the most prolific singles hitter in National League history. Now he needs only five.

title: Overseers of Morgue Often Occasion Spirited Debate
description: The corridors are clean, the atmosphere is antiseptic, the wall of file drawers deceptively like a storage area in any place of business.

title: Karnak Statue Matches Head in Boston Museum
description: CAIRO, Aug. 1  Thanks to a bit of scholarly detective work, a headless statue of a pharaonic priest in the Cairo Museum has been matched to a head now in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Rationing: Some Ins And Outs
description: WELLESLEY, Mass.  The speed of the Congressional process giving President Carter authority to draft standby plan for gasoline rationing probably results from publicopinion polls that show a large majority in favor of rationing. But what does such approval mean?

title: Finland's Spirited Designer
description: BOKORS, FINLAND ARMI RATIA'S story is the story of modern Finland  the innocent excitement of youth, the devastation of two wars, rebirth and triumph when things seemed darkest. She was born in 1912, the Finnish republic seven years later. Her family and its homeland, the border province of Karelia, were shattered in the Winter War, of, 1939 and World War II by the might of the Soviet Union. Yet in the postwar era, as Finland struggled to regain its political and economic balance, she built a fabric company based on little more than strong colors and bold designs: Marimekko.

title: News Summary
description: More Arab oil pressure on the West is likely unless there is marked progress in talks on Palestinian autonomy, according to high Washington officials. They said they seek to encourage Israel and Egypt to be more flexible and specific in defining powers of a Palestinian selfgoverning authority and to encourage moderate Arabs at the U.N. to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to accept a formula recognizing. Israel's right to exist to clear the way for Palestinian participation. in the talks. [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Threat Not Immediate
description: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation asserted yesterday that his company was not about to go bankrupt even though it had asked for $1 billion in Federal aid as its only longterm hope for survival as a fullline auto maker.

title: Sound
description: PLAYING orchestral music in the living room is obviously unnatural. Orchestral sound is conceived with the aura of large spaces for the simple reason that no other kind of space could accommo date a hundred musicians plus their audience. The reverberant character of the concert hall is therefore implicit in symphonic music, and playing such music via records or radio within the narrow confines of a normalsize living room creates a contradiction between sonic and architectural dimensions:

title: Yugoslav Ship Delivers SovietBloc Arms to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The Defense Department, said today that a Yugoslavregistered ship recently delivered Sovietbloc military equipment purchased by the United States Army to a New Jersey port. The equipment included four armored personnel carriers, small arms and ammunition and military uniforms.

title: PRESIDENT ANGERS U.S JEWISH LEADERS
description: President Carter, in likening the Palestinian problem to the civil rights movement in the United States in an interview Tuesday, has provoked statements of anger and dismay from leaders of the organized American Jewish community.

title: Entertainment  Events
description: Theater

title: Economic Forecast Made Bleaker In a Confidential Revision by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Government's senior economists, in a confidential revision of the Administration's July 12 economic forecast, predict a deeper recession this year and an anemic recovery in 1980 that will cause the national unemployment rate to climb to 8.2 percent at about the time of the November Presidential election.

title: Escapee Indicted for Murder
description: An indictment was returned yesterday against a man who authorities said had killed a Brooklyn grocer and then escaped from a hospital after his capture. The suspect, Juan Julbe, 44 years old, of 551 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, is charged with one count of seconddegree murder, one count of attempted murder and one count of possession of a dangerous weapon. The police.saic4he killed Eliezer Lopez last Saturday during a holdup in Mr. Lopez's grocery store at 609 Wilson Avepue in Brooklyn.

title: 6 Justices Picked by Lot for Court Inquiry on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (AP)  Six Court of Appeal justices have been selected by lot to replace six California Supreme Court justices who had disqualified themselves from determining whether a commission investigating alleged misconduct in the high court could hold its hearings in public.

title: Disks: Bartok for Children by Ranki
description: ANYONE who has learned to play the piano using Bela Bartok's music for children or other neophytes realizes how distinctive it is. Bartok is well known as a great master of 20thcentury music and as an ethnomusicologist. But he was also a great pianist and a great pedagogue, and what's so remarkable about his pedagogical music is the way all the facets of his musical personality are combined in them.

title: Ohio Motel Fire Under Inquiry
description: CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Aug. 1 (UPI)Arson investigators and state fire marshals today searched through the charred debris of a Holiday Inn motel, trying to determine the cause of a fire yesterday that roared through one wing of the building, spewing toxic fumes and killing nine persons and injuring 78.

title: Home Improvement
description: AS homeowners become increasingly aware of appliances that use large amounts of energy, or any appliance that seems to be wasting energy, more attention is being paid to the domestic hot water heater. It is the second largest user of energy in the average home (the central heating system is generally rated first). Steps that can be taken to lower the operating cost of this appliance are eagerly studied, and often quickly adopted.

title: Henry W. Putnam Marries Tyler Pratt Mullally on L.I.
description: Tyler Pratt Mullally of Lawrence, L.I., widow of Mandeville Mullally, was married yesterday afternoon to Henry W. Putnam, a widower of Lawrence. Village Justice Charles E. Lapp Jr. performed the ceremony in the Cedarhurst (L.I.) Village Hall.

title: At Small Texas Airline, Large Goals
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1 Last fall, when Texas International Airlines was busily buying stock in National Airlines in an aggressive attempt to take over the much larger carrier, the president of Texas International acknowledged that even if the attempt failed, his company could still reap a large profit.

title: Rule Proposed On Heating Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Department of Energy proposed today to implement a requirement that refiners increase production of heating oil later in the . year if the department's own guardedly optimistic projections of supplies prove to be mistaken.

title: Ashe Undergoes Testing
description: Arthur Ashe was listed in good condition in New York Hospital yesterday while undergoing diagnostic tests for what a hospital spokesman described as the possibility of a heart problem. Ashe, the United States. Open tennis champion in 1968 and Wimbledon champion in 1975, was admitted to the hospital Tuesday night complaining of weakness and pains.

title: Canadian Gas Surplus
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  Imperial Oil Ltd. said today that Canada's natural gas surplus was now estimated to be nine trillion cubic feet. In a report to the National Energy Board, the company said its new calculation exceeded by more than two trillion cubic feet an estimate made by the company year ago. The Canadian Petroleum Association put Canada's natural gas reserves at 67.3 trillion cubic feet, up from 64.3 trillion cubic feet a year ago.

title: Morning
description: 5:55(4)Natural Resources Notebook

title: Satellite Agency Plans Direct Home Broadcasts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Communications Satellite Corporation is making plans to offer the nation its first direct satellitetohome broadcasts, featuring firstrun movie, sports events and even data transmission.

title: Water Pollution Inquiry Planned in Pennsylvania
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP) Residents of the Lower Providence Township in the Philadelphia area are concerned that they may have been drinking water contaminated with a cancerlinked chemical for nearly 10 years, and the Pennsylvania Health Department is planning to investigate the matter.

title: L1011 Jetliner Turns Back
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 2 (AP)  A Delta Airlines L1011 jetliner with 187 passengers aboard turned back on a flight to Dallas and made a safe emergency landing here after one of its three engines went out.

title: Mayor Refuses To Reevaluate Baden's Ouster
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had good reasons for removing Dr. Michael M. Baden as Chief Medical Examiner, but added that even if he learned that some of the allegations against Dr. Baden were untrue, it would not cause him to reevaluate his decision.

title: Union Chief's Son and 2 Officials Of Trucking Concern Are Indicted.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 2 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury today indicted Francis R. Fitzsimmons, son of Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the president of the teamsters union, on charges of illegally accepting mob than $83,000 from two officials of a Detroit trucking company.

title: Rewarding Racial Segregation
description: Congress goes off on summer vacation tonight without having cleaned up a particularly dirty piece business which has been made to look like bureaucratic bumbling, and by everyone's least favorite agency at that  the Internal Revenue Service. But the issue not bureaucracy. It is race. And straightening it out ought to be an early order of business when Congress returns.,

title: Broadway
description: IF he were known for nothing else, and he is known for a good many things, Melvin Van Peebles would be known for his infinite c4pacity for surprise. Among other things, Mr. Van Peebles wrote and starred in the movie Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song, and wrote, produced and directed the Broadway play Don't Play Us Cheap. So, surprise! Mr. Van Peebles and Mildred Kayden have written Becky, a musical version Vanity Fair, and it will be done in London next year. So, surprise again. he has persuaded Glenda Jackson to be the star of Becky. Miss Jackson will play Becky Sharp, of course, and she is cultivating her singing voice now. Becky will be produced by Mr. Van Peebles, along with Eddie Kulukundis and perhaps another producer as well, and it is supposed to go into rehearsal next May. Mr. Van Peebles and Miss Kayden have been working on it since late 1977. And who will be the director?

title: Mississippi Public Apathetic Despite Novel Primary Race
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 2  Mississippi's Aug. 7 primary for the governorship was just a week away when'a farmer in Yazoo County was asked which candidate he preferred.

title: Afloat
description: MORRISTOWN, NJ:  Vo nil Tarn (this is not her real name) is one of the lucky boat people who has gotten to America. She told her story in a small house near Seattle, Wash. She is a softspoken delicate woman of 28 with loose dark hair. Tears stream as she speaks in Vietnamese.

title: Bomb Device Found On Brooklyn Bridge
description: A radiocontrolled bomb that authorities said could have exploded under two police demolition experts at any moment was disarmed yesterday where it had been found, atop a 276foot tower of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Christopher Moore Ely Marries Suk Ja Kim, a Student
description: Suk Ja Kim, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kyeong Hee Kim of Jeonju, Korea, was married yesterday to Christopher Moore Ely, son of. Mr. and Mrs John Wilson Ely of Verona, The Rev. Richard K. Bailey of the Congregational Church in Chatham, Mass., performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents in West Chatham.

title: Carey, After British Talks, Expects Move on Ulster
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  Governor Carey, a frequent critic of Britain's policy on Northern Ireland, spent an hour and a half today with Humphrey. Atkins, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, and indicated later that he expected the new Conservative Government in London to make new attempts to settle the problem.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Mixed Overseas; Gold Gains in New York
description: The dollar turned in a mixed performance against major currencies in world foreign exchange trading yesterday. Analysts said the dollar's doldrums were a result of a lack of news.

title: Bluefish Running In Deeper Water
description: AREA A  The waters off Margate have warmed to 80 degrees, and that has forced the bluefish out to the deeper water where they are still being taken. Ralph Stork of Captain Andy's Marina said yesterday that he expected the arrival of dolphin soon off Ocean City in about 70 feet of water whete the lobsterpot flags bob up and down. The Marina also reported plenty of white marlin, up to 65 pounds, have been caught off 28Mile Wreck, and yellowfin tuna, up to 64 pounds, have been taken in the same area, about 20 miles off Margate. There is excellent fishing for fluke in Great Egg Bay by the Longport Bridge through Risley's Channel. At Ken's Landing in Point Pleasant the report was that bluefishing was excellent off Spring Lake, Belmar and north of the Shrewsbury Rocks. Jigging and chumming have lured the blues.

title: Mavis Harcourt Has Bridal
description: Mavis Feltman Harcourt and James Thomas Urban of New York were married at noon yesterday in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Charles Amstein. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Charles Louis Feltman of Southampton, L.1., and the late Mr. Feltman. Her previous marriage was terminated by divorce. The bridegroom, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lee Urban of Cincinnati, is director of marketing and sales with Janet Sartin Inc., cosmetics.

title: Redskin Owner Buys Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 2  A group headed by Edward Bennett Williams, owner of the Washington Redskins of the National Football League, bought the Baltimore Orioles today for $12 million.

title: U.S. Plans a Campaign For Water Fluoridation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The Government has announced a fluoridation campaign, beginning Oct. 1, to fight tooth decay that is afflicting an estimated 95 percent of the population.

title: Deaths
description: BARTOSEsther of Larchmont, devoted wife of the late Rudolf, beloved mother of Margaret B. Reich, and the late Emil J. Barlos. Loving sister of Elsie Zinser and Eugene Klein, also survived by seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Services 2PM Friday (today) Larchmont Temple. Interment Reading, Pa.

title: Town Gasps as Water Hole Gulps a Truck
description: MAYNARD, Ark., July 27  Phyllis Waddell, owner of the Tiger Mercantile Store here, paused from her work in the muggy, rainpromising heat to raise a blue flyswatter and bat a fly off the counter. It's iust real weird. she said, shaking her head. We're real anxious to have water, and this hole is weird. They say it's fantastic. I haven't seen it myself though. and I wouldn't let my kids go near it.

title: Casino Board Acts in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 2 (UPI) The Casino Control Commission, in a marathon session, approved Ramada Inn's design for a $139 million Boardwalk gambling complex and granted a request by Caesars World to expand its casino.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Progress Seen For Comex
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that the Commodity Exchange Inc., known as the Comex, had made substantal progress in meeting Government standards for selfregulation, but still remained out of compliance.

title: Use of U.S.Built Planes By Israelis Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, introduced a resolution today to compel the State Department to report whether Israel had violated American law by using United Statessupplied warplanes in its recent raids in Lebanon.

title: C.M. Chairman Strongly Opposes Special U.S. Aid Asked by Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Aug. 2  Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that he was firmly opposed to the Government's providing special financial aid to its ailing competitor, the Chrysler Corporation. He urged instead a complete review of Federal regulations that have forced heavy spending by the automobile industry.

title: U.S. Agency Opens Inquiry Into Safety of Subway Cars
description: The Urban Mass Transportation Administration, a branch of the Federal Department of Transportation, has begun an investigation to determine what safety hazards may be posed by defective equipment on New York City's fleet of 754 subway cars built by the Pullman Standard Company.

title: Senate Confirms Miller and Volcker
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The Senate gave enthusiastic confirmation today to President Carter's choices to fill the Government's top two economic, policy lobs.

title: Market in General Outshines the Dow
description: Takeover developments dominated interest in Wall Street yesterday as stock market indicators over all showed little change.

title: Business Records
description: JOHN C. FEARON, 3538 James St., Shrub Oak, N.Y. Liabilities, $5,932; assets, none.

title: Six Slayings in Atlanta in Day
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Six slayings in Atlanta in less than 24 hours have brought the number of homicides in the city to 140, just three short of the number for the entire year in 1978, the police said today. However, the tally is still well short of the 263 slayings in 1973 when Atlanta was known as the nation's murder capital.

title: Auctions
description: THE artauction business continued to boom internationally this season. Gains were reported in virtually every category of sales and records were registered for scores of art works, from a paperweight to a Picasso.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Halliburton Company, specialists in in oilfield services and equipment, yesterday reported a 2.42 percent dip in secondquarter earnings despite a 33.3 percent rise in revenues.

title: Pilot Whale, Alive and Well, Is Returned to Sea
description: $aquish, a pilot whale found Sunday on a Massachusetts beach, was returned to the ocean off Cape Cod on Tuesday. She had been taken to the New England Aquarium in Boston, where she was examined and marked with a yellow identification circle on her fin, below.

title: 35 Namibia Rebels Killed
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  South African forces killed 35 guerrillas in the north of SouthWest Africa, also called Namibia, in the last week, a military spokesman said today.

title: McEnroe Advances
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. Aug. 2 John McEnroe relied on a strong serveandvolley game today and scored a 62, 64 victory over John James of Australia to advance to the quarterfinals in the $75,000 Mutual Benefit Life open tennis tournament.

title: Conrail Chief Cites Its Financial Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Conrail, the federally financed Northeastern railroad system, said today that it was stronger financially than at any time in its history and would need no more Federal money if the railroad industry was dereeulated by 1981.

title: New Face: Dennis Christopher Getting His Break In Breaking Away
description: UNLIKE teenage Dave, the bikeracing Italophile he portrays in the hit movie Breaking Away, 24yearold Dennis Christopher had a good idea at an early age of what he wanted to do with his life: he wanted to be a professional actor.

title: Panel Blames Human Error In Atomic Reactor Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Investigators for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the reactor breakdown at Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa., could be attributed to many factors, but most of all to human error.

title: Around the Nation
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP)  Repeated efforts by the Columbus Board of Education to delay systemwide desegregation were exhausted today when a Federal district judge ordered the busing of more than 35,000 students to begin this fall.

title: U.S. Is Opening Registry On Herbicide Exposure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Government announced today that it will establish a registry of American workers who have been exposed to certain herbicides like Agent Orange, the defoliant used to kill plant life in the Vietnam War.

title: Chrysler Omits A Dividend
description: Directors of the financially troubled Chrysler Corporation voted yesterday to omit the dividend on its common stock for the third quarter, the first time that the nation's No. 3 auto Maker had taken such action in three ye:ars. However, the directors retained the 68cent quarterly dividend on Chrysler's preferred shares.

title: At the Movies
description: AUDIENCES who are enjoying Nick Nolte's performance as the insufficiently conformist professional football player in North Dallas Forty may be interested to know that in Heart Beat, already completed and scheduled for release in January, he plays one of the men who wrote the script on doing your own thing.

title: Rose Murphy's Back With That Old CheeChee
description: Thirty years ago a was impossible to walk the streets of midtown Manhattan without being confronted by Rose Murphy's highpitched, giggling interpretation of a song that, even then, was already 20 years old: I Can't Give You Anything but  CheeChee! Every record store in town seemed to be blasting it into the streets. Miss Murphy remembers being pursued by it relentlessly wherever she went.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Exit the King, the tragic farce by Eugene Ionesco, opens tonight at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 the Bowery, at Second Street. This story of a man's final hours will be performed Fridays and Saturdays through Sept. 1 by members of the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company. Karen Sunde is the director, and in the cast are Craig Smith, Phyllis, Deitschel, Karla Barker, Christina Sluberski, John T. Bower and George Brunner. Each season, the repertory company usually presents more than 250 performances of eight new and classical works  mainly obscure or neglected plays. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3.50. Time: 10 P.M. Information: 6770060.

title: Mets Get Cardenal, Divide With Phillies
description: The Mets split a doubleheader with the Philadelphia Phillies last night and between games managed to bolster their depleted outfield by acquiring Jose Cardenal from the PhiHies.

title: The Region
description: SOUTH ORANGE (UPI)  Robert T. Conley, first layman to serve as president of Seton Hall University, resigned yesterday. The Rev. Laurence T. Murphy was immediately chosen as his successor.

title: Market Place
description: THE green field concept of foreign entry into the United States automobile manufacturing business calls for the purchase of a large farm, the erection thereon of a stamping works and assembly plant and the training of the necessary employees to run it. The elapsed time is about two to three years and the cost about $400 million.

title: Israeli Troops Attack Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3  Israeli ground forces thrust eight miles across the Lebanese border early this morning and killed an undisclosed number of Arab guerrillas, according to an official announcement issued by the military command here. The Israelis returned to their bases without casualties. it was stated.

title: Wilentz Sworn As ChiefJustice OfJersey Court
description: TRENTON Aug. 2  Robert N. Wilentz, a Democrat, was sworn in today as Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court and pledged to preserve the tradition and quality of what many knowledgeable people say is the best state judicial system in the nation.

title: Two Are Killed In a Gun Battle At a Ball Game
description: A policeman who had just finished his tour of duty in the 75th precinct and a resident of the East New York section of Brooklyn where the precinct is located were both shot to death yesterday evening as they were playing softball. An onduty sergeant and another Brooklyn resident were also shot and wounded.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 2  The second round of Spingold knockout team play began here this afternoon with 61 teams, including all the topranked squads, surviving from the original entry of 171. This is the premiere event in the recordbreaking American Contract Bridge League's summer national affair, and the eventual winner next Tuesday will qualify for international team playoffs.

title: Deaths
description: STEINSidney A., 67, of 2560 South Ocean Boulevard, Palm Beach, Fla., passed away on Wednesday, August 1, 1979. Mr. Stein is survived by his wife Violet, three daughters Mice, Marjorie aid Robin. Services will be held cn Sunday, 8/5/79 at 11:30AM from The Riyerside rItemorial Chapel, 180.W. 76 Street at Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y.C. Interment will follow in Sharon Gardens, Vaihala, N.Y.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bluebird Inc., a porkprocessing holding company, has named Michael C. Breen corporate senior vice president and assistant to the president.

title: Judge Lacey Withdraws Candidacy for Justice Post
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 2  Judge Frederick B. Lacey of Federal Ditrict Court in Newark, the Carter Administration's leading candidate for Deputy Attorney General, has taken himself out of the running for the job, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today.

title: Nancy Lopez's 68 Leads By One Stroke in England
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 2 (AP.) Nancy Lopez shot seven birdies and narrowly missed afew more today in taking, the firstround lead in the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association European open with a sixunderpar 68 on the treelined Sunningdale course.

title: Goodrich to Expand Radial Tire Plants
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 2 (Reuters) The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it would spend $40 million to expand its radial tire capacity in North America.

title: Deaths
description: GIRDNERFrederic W. On Aug 1, 1979. Husband of the tate Louise Pratt Girdner. Stepdaughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Rogers; nephews Kimball C. Atwood iii, John G. Atwood, Charles W.. Atwood& Frederic L. Atwood. Family will receive friends at the Overton Funeral Home, 172 Main St, Islip NYSunday 799m. Internment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to Southside Hospital Bayshore.NY would be appreciated.

title: Lusaka Talks Turn to Economics
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 2 (Reuters) Heads of Cox monwealth governments, representing about a quarter of the world's population, were urged today to play a more courageous role in helping promote international economic recovery.

title: Badillo Leaves City Hall Amid Political Setbacks
description: In a day filled with surprising announcements at City Hall, perhaps the least surprising was the news that Herman Badillo would be leaving his position as Deputy Mayor with a possible eye toward running again for elective office.

title: Art: Red Grooms And Dan FlaVin
description: ONE of the livelier institutions in and around New York City is the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. Just half an hour by train from Grand Central Terminal (the station stop is Glenwood), it has a spectacular location. The majestic though muchmisused Hudson flows by right under its windows. The cliffface of the Palisades looks nowhere grander. You can see these things from the park in which the museum stands, and you can also see them, slice by thin vertical slice, through windows cunningly cut into the modern half of the building. As for the street that runs up past the museum on its eastern side, no one can say that it is in perfect condi, tion; but in villa after dilapidated villa we see the remains of an intense local pride and a bygone belief that Yonkers had to be a very pleasant place in which to live.

title: 6 Top Aides in New Britain Held in Corruption Inquiry
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn. Aug. 2  New Britain's top officials  including the Police Chief, the captain of detectives and a detective sergeant, the Fire Chief and deputy Chief and the chairman of the Special to The New York Times civil service Commission  were arrested today in a widespread investigation into allegations that municipal employees must pay bribes to get their jobs or to win promotions.

title: Economic Scene
