description: WITH the Senate's confirmation yesterday G. William Miller as Secretary of the Treasury and Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, President Carter has a new economic policy team.

title: Rock: Peter Frampton
description: IF Peter Frampton was still a minor rock celebrity, coming Into town once a year to play the Paladium or the Bottom Line, he would probably be perceived as a lightweight but conscientious craftsman deserving of wider recognition. But of course mr. Frampton nas oecome one of the topselling rock recording artists, and now his popularity is widely perceived as an indictment of the mass rock audience's vapid tastes.

title: U.S. Is Indirectly Pressing Russians To Halt Afghanistan Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Carter Administration took another step toward a more assertive strategic posture in the Middle EastIndian Ocean region today and reinforced it by putting indirect pressure on the Soviet Union to end its intervention in Afghanistan.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh Sale of More Arms to Morocco
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Carter Administration was reported today to be considering a policy shift that would allow the sale to Morocco of military equipment for use against guerrillas in the disputed Western Sahara.

title: Defending the Dollar Too Much
description: America's trade deficit is worsening, as the trade figures for the second quarter, announced yesterday, make plain. The figures confirm also that the United States must sell more abroad to pay for what it needs. How can the country do that? By doing what West Germany and Japan, among others, wish the United States would not do- namely, by letting the value of the dollar drop still further.

title: U.S.Mexican Gas Talks Stall
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Administration officials said today that United StatesMexican negotiations on natural gas had reached a stalemate over price, but the State Department said it still hoped an agreement could be reached.

title: Senate Hearing Urged By Bell to Support Bill For Charter for F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  Making a farewell appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell urged Congress today to enact charter legislation for the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a contract between the F.B.I. and the American people.

title: Supply Of Money Off in Week
description: The basic measure of the money supply declined by $1.2 billion in the week ended July 25, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: A Parkgoers Baedeker to Flourishing Flushing Meadows
description: YOU might have passed it a hundred times, driving along the Long Island or Van Wyck Expressways or Grand Central Parkway  the greenery, the vast expanses of grass, the rows of trees. It is Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, 1,258 acres of recreational space, a playground for children of all ages and, for many people outside the Borough of Queens, one of the city's almostundiscovered treasures.

title: Jazz: Bob January's Swing Band
description: FOR the last five years,. Bob January, a clarinetist, saxophonist and trumpet player, has been leading a band of 15 to 18 pieces that plays recreations of arrangements of the bigband era, some late Fletcher Henderson, Ozzie Nelson and early Benny Goodman to early Stan Kenton. The band normally plays once a week, on Sundays, and, on that basis, has had long engagements at Barbara's in Greenwich Village, at the Village Gate and most recently at Story Towne.

title: The City
description: A 17yearold youth was charged last night with the murder of a 15yearold boy who had been beaten, tied up and thrown into the Harlem River Wednesday night by a gang of 15 youths.

title: Bilking by ApartmentReferral Services Is Alleged
description: Apartment hunters searching for vacancies in an unusually tight New York City market are being bilked of tens of thousands of dollars a year by many statelicensed referral services, the New York Better Business Bureau charged yesterday.

title: Bilsiness and the Law
description: THE other day, a senior partner at Vinson & Elkins, the largest law firm in Houston (second largest in the country) was graciously and patiently speaking on the telephone to an elderly woman who wished to sell her three houses and needed legal help. The partner called anether partner to make certain a younger associate versed in real estate law would be in the office later in the day to assist the woman.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: Feu period% aS shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Red Sox Rout Brewers on 5 Homers by 101
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (AP)  Bob Watson and Dwight Evans hit a pair of homers and knocked in three runs apiece and Butch Hobson added a basesempty shot to power the Boston Red Sox to a 101 victory over the slumping Milwaukee Brewers tonight.

title: Publishing: New Pocket Books Chief
description: MARTIN ASHER, who has been at Pocket Books for three yearsafter posts at Fawcett Books and Tempo Books, has been named editor in chief of Pocket Books to fill the vacancy created when Carole Baron left the paperback house for Crown Publishers. As senior editor, Mr. Asher was responsible for acquiring the rights to such hardcover titles as Ghost Story'.by Peter Straub, Wiley by Judy Blume and Happy All the Time by Laurie Colwin.

title: Man Indicted in Hijacking
description: OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 2 (AP)  A 36yearold biochemist has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges he hijacked a United Airlines flight from Denver to Omaha July 20. Ronald Rimerman was charged in the indictment with one count each of air piracy and interfering with the duties of a flight officer. The hijacker had asked to be taken to Cuba.

title: New Faces: Jay O. Sanders and Celia Weston Hanging Free in Loose Ends
description: HE talks on stage about getting turned on by the sight of a flower or a light spring rain, and she says that whenever she's depressed, she consoles herself by thinking How bad can it be if there's still sex? And, though they're only on stage for one and a half of eight scenes in Loose Ends, Michael Weller's new play about unstable relationShips, Jay O. Sanders and Celia Weston, who are making their Broadway debuts in supporting roles as Doug and Maraya, a comic, lusty and loving couple, draw belly laughs from the audience, and praise from the critics.

title: Nicaraguan City, Shattered in War, Faces Harsh Peace
description: ESTELI, Nicaragua, Aug. 2  In war Esteli fought the longest and hardest; in peace it is likely to suffer the most.

title: Principals Affected by ShakeUp in Koch Administration
description: Ronay Menschel. Joined Koch Congressional staff in 1969 became his administrative assistant responsible for both his New York and Washington offices in 1973  described by the Mayor yesterday as probably my closest friend in government  spent the first year of the Koch administration as Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Relations, then became Deputy Mayor for Administration  awaiting confirmation of appointment to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority  expects to devote much of her time to transportation issues in new job as executive administrator  introduced to her husband, Richard L. Menschel, by Mr. Koch in 1973 has two daughters and lives on upper Fifth Avenue  says I'm just not interested in power  37 years fold  born in Washington, D.C., the only child of Paul Arlt, former political cartoonist for The New York Herald Tribune  named after a Hebrides island  switched her major at Cornell University from premed to political Science and graduated in 1964  turned down use of a chauffeured car when she joined city government  says I like hard work  softspoken recalls being influenced more by John F. Kennedy's Presidency than by the other events of the 1960's.

title: Queens Man Slain
description: A 46yearold Queens man was found shot to death on a service road near his home in the Whitestone section. The police said the man, who had more than $2,000 in his pocket, was identified as Pasquale DeRosa, of 19961 15th Road. :His body was found about 4:30 A.M. at 150th Street near the Cross Island Parkway.

title: Nixon Drops Purchase of Coop Following Residents' Complaints
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon withdrew his application yesterday to purchase a nineroom penthouse apartment at 19 East 72d Street. His application had been opposed by many of the residents in the building.

title: Pope Planning to Visit Philippines This Year
description: MANILA, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II will visit the Philippines in December after his fall trip to the United States, church leaders said today.

title: Dance Notebook In Summer, Dance Takes to the Streets
description: EIGHT P.M. at Old Broadway and 133d Street. Children dart like minnows through the darkening streets but the sidewalks are empty. A chunk of moon has risen over the warehouses and towering projects. glowing in the sky like a disembodied lit window. A boy in a Que Pasa? Tshirt sails downhill on skateboard, his body arched in a perfect handstand. Then music, loud and raw, suddenly cuts through the night like a shard of glass. The children straggle to a momentary halt and a few heads peer out from kitchens and bedrooms high above. Young men grapple with theater light poles. Jazz musicians climb to a, small platform over the truckstage and begin to tune their instruments, looking down thoughtfully on the gathering crowd, while behind the truck a man twists and bends to warm up his muscles. Dyanne McIntyre's SoundsinMotion Dance Company has come to Harlem.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2  A United Nations report published today said that South Africa used paralyzing gas during an attack last year on the Angolan town of Kassinga, where 3,000 refugees from SouthWest Africa were being sheltered.

title: Action on Gas Rationing Delayed Until September
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Congress postponed today final action on legislation that would give President Carter standby authority to impose gasoline rationing until the lawmakers return from their fourweek summer recess in September.

title: Mrs. Gandhi in Court Appearance
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 2  Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi made her first appearance today before the special court that is processing cases relating to her alleged abuse of powers during the period of her emergency rule.

title: Forecasts on Economy: Candid or Too Hopeful?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Optimistic economic forecasts by the White House are an old, and bipartisan, story. But to the Carter Administration's embarrassment, the pronounced optimism of Administration's midsummer forecast for 1979 and 1980 has been impeached in only three weeks.

title: Fewer Links In the Chain
description: Mayor Koch's shakeup of City Hall yesterday was intended tolighten the chain of command and to return to at least a modified thiefofstaff system that had been used in previous administrations and that had been initially rejected by the Mayor.

title: Rock: British Magazine
description: MAGAZINE is a British rock band fronted by Howard Devoto that is making its first tour of the United States. It ended a threenight run at Hurrah last night.

title: Stage: Waylon Jennings
description: THE Broadway Opry 79 series of countrymusic concerts at the St. James Theater may have been having attendance problems, reflected in the cancellation of the tonight's, tomorrow's and Sunday's shows and the slashing of ticket prices. Bo one wouldn't have known it Wednesday night, when a show headed by Waylon Jennings opened a twonight run. The house looked full, as well it should have been with a star of Mr. Jennings's caliber he's the most popular figure on the whole Broadway Opry schedule, and the chances to see him in a 1,600seat theater these days are rare.

title: Idaho and Mississippi Residents Evacuated After Truck Accidents
description: Residents along highways in Idaho and Mississippi were evacuated from their homes, and traffic was rerouted yesterday after two trucks carrying dangerous cargoes turned over in separate incidents. The driver of one of the trucks was killed.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE CONCORDE..AIREORT 79, directed by David Lowell Rich; stars Altai Delon, Susan Blakely. at the Beekman, Riven and Both Street Twin I Theaters.

title: Kotar Unsung Hero In Giants Backfield
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 Players come, players go; coaches come, coaches go. But Doug Kotar remains the Giants starting halfback. He thinks it must be the coal miner's blood in me.

title: Stage: Gilda Radner Live Is Presented
description: AS we all know from Saturday Night Live, Gilda Radner is an endearing comedienne. Weekly, in league with her clique of clever sidekicks, she lampoons pretentions of stuffy society, and even pokes fun at those of us watching at home. Behind that cute, skinny., girlish exterior is the soul of a satirist.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph of Robert F. Armao: New York's Chief of Protocol, was in. correctly identified in The New York. Times on Wednesday as that of Dr. Rei. naldo A. Ferrer, the city's Health Commissioner.

title: Chrysler's Woes Add to Concern
description: TOKYO, Aug. 2  Do you think there is any possibility that the United States will impose an import surcharge? asked the motor company executive.

title: Newfoundland, Long Poor and Laggard, Enjoys a Revival
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 31 Rufus the fiddler is 80 years old, but at midnight the other night in Bridgett's pub on Cookstown Road, he was still going strong, scraping and stomping out centimesold iin and reels. Members of hisaudience, mainly young people, were obviously enjoying it, for they would stomp along with him or dance or join him with a tin whistle, spoons, an accordion or a flute.

title: Hollywood Notebook The Summer of Fox's Discontent
description: IN Beverly Hills, the streets are full of joggers  barrelchested television producers with terrycloth sweatbands around their heads, notquiteyoung women in flashy red shirts and French Tshirts. This month, their feet quite literally stick to the pavement. The American elms are infested, and the sap forms puddles on the sidewalk below.

title: City's Largest Generator Is Knocked Out of Action
description: The Consolidated Edison Company disclosed yesterday that Big Allis, the city's largest electric generator, had been knocked out of service, forcing the company to draw on outside power sources as the demand for electricity soared amid 90degree temperatures and humidity readings of 79 perent The disclosuricame as water pressure dropped sharply in the city because of what authorities said was a dramatic increase in illegal hydrant openings.

title: About Real Estate Builder Branching Out From Murray Hill
description: Murray Hill might be called home court for Donald Zucker, the builder. He began there and he is building there still.

title: News Summary
description: Pressure for more military spending rose as three Senators demanded that President Carter provide a prompt and detailed commitment on such spending before the Senate considers the nuclear arms treaty with Moscow. Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said that he would urge Senate rejection of the pact if such a commitment and other conditions were not met by Mr. Carter. [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: 1st Penn's New Man In Test
description: Bunting was Mr. Outside and I'm Mr. Inside, says George A. Butlerrthe. 51yearold executive who last week was chosen to succeed the flamboyant John R. Bunting,as chief executive officer of the First Pennsylvania Bank and its parent holding company, the First Pennsylvania Corooration.

title: Dispute on Death Ruling Called Key Factor in Baden Case
description: On May 24, 1975, Robert O. Soman was tilled in a fall from a Manhattan apartment building. That death, ruled a suicide by the Medical Examiner's Office, began a sequence of events that was a Major factor in the dismissal Tuesday of Dr. Michael M. Baden, as the city's Medical Examiner.

title: R.J. Andrews Weds Miss Beardshaw
description: Dorothy Fordyce Beardshaw, daughter of Charlotte Zachry Ervin of New York and New Russia, N.Y., and the late David Fordyce Beardshaw, was married at noon yesterday to Richard John Andrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Andrews of Sheffield, England. The Rev. David S. Langdon, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Elizabethtown, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's family in New Russia.

title: Aspen Study Group Rejects Aid, Charging AntiIsrael Interference
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 2  The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies has rejected the remainder of a $600,000 grant from a corporate foundation, charging that the foundation was trying to attach antiIsraeli political strings to its contribution.

title: Wage Council Cites Eureka
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  A labor contract between the Eureka Company, the vacuum cleaner manufacturer, and a local machinists union violates the nation's antiinflation program, the Council on Wage and Price Stability said today.

title: Woman Files Suit To Recover Costs Of Breast Rebuilding
description: RAPID CITY, S.D.  Patricia Koppmann, a 37yearold housewife and mother of two, was taking a shower four years ago when her hand brushed across a lump that felt like an olive pit in her right breast.

title: Gas CreditUse Charge Is Banned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The Department of Energy reversed itself today and said that service stations could not charge motorists extra if they paid by credit card for gasoline and other services.

title: Carter Phone Call Fulfills Vow
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 2 (AP) When Richard Taylor left his Owensboro law office in the afternoon, he gave his secretary a list of telephone numbers. He did not want to miss his call from the President. Later, he was tracked down near the town square in nearby Leitchfield, and he returned President Carter's call from a drugstore telephone.

title: For Children
description: THE MOPPETS: A CELEBRATION, features the art and history of Jim Hensen's creations on The Mu. pet Show and Sesame Street, Monday and Thursday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Tuesday and Wednesday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Friday and Saturday, noon to 6 P.M., through Aug. 11, at The New York Public Library, Amsterdam Gallery, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Free. Call 7992200.

title: C.A.B. Moves to Ease Possible Airline Strike
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 2  The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized domestic and international airlines to pick up any passengers who hold tickets for scheduled or charter trips.on World Airways.

title: Citizens Ask if Carter Is Part of the Crisis
description: HAMMOND, Ind.  Plenty of folks out here agree with President Carter that there is a crisis of confidence. But here, as in much of the country, there is a belief that he has failed to handle the crisis, that he has, perhaps, added to it. And, increasingly, people seem prepared to punish him politically for it.

title: Basques at Crossroads: Some ElectTerror
description: MADRID, Aug. 1  The bombings Sunday at Madrid's airport and two railroad stations, which killed 5 people and wounded 113, took the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. a long way from Dec. 20, 1973, when, privately, many Spaniards applauded it tor the assassination of Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco,. Francisco Franco's heir apparent.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Prelude and Fugue for Solo Violin in A minor, Reger; Lorelei, Dance of the Water Nymphs, Catalani; Caprice after the Study in form of a Waltz by SaintSaens,YsaYe.

title: Townspeople Join in Hunt for Clues to Killer of Girl
description: BURLINGTON; CONN.; Aug. 2 Driving by the woods, you see nice foliage, hnwhen you pan there, you find, All kinds of stuff. Said John MSLead a state notice spokesman.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Stephen L. Hammerman, 41 years old, will be appointed administrator of the New York regional office of the Securities, and Exchange Commission today, sources close to the commission activities said yesterday. Mr. Hammerman was unavailable for con t ment, and an S. E.C. spokesman in Washington declined to discuss the appointment.

title: Associated Press
description: COLLISION COURSE: Argentine sloop Sur (left) slamming into Japanese sloop Togo VI during second inshore race of Admiral's Cup yesterday, off the Isle of Wight in England. Difficult conditions forced many boats to lose control.

title: TV Weekend NuclearEnergyDebateon Channel 13
description: MIDSUMMER and you are sitting at home in the air conditioning, which uses energy, but staying out of the car, an action that saves energy, and you are looking at television, which may consume whatever of your own energy that remains for the weekend.

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Slide Amid Talk of Recession
description: Aggressive selling by speculators pushed gold and silver futures lower yesterday amid talk that a recent rally was over and the recession was deepening:

title: U.S. Lifts Ban on Aliens Who Are Homosexuals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Government said today that it would no longer cite homosexuality as a reason for denying aliens entry into the United States.

title: Putting Accent on Work and Loyalty to Mayor
description: Nathan Leventhal conceded yesterday that his new job as Deputy Mayor for Operations worried him on one account  whether he still would have time to go to the opera.

title: Celebrating The Works Of Indian Craftsmen
description: From anonymous preColumbian potters to a contemporary jewelry designer, the American Indian craftsman is being celebrated in The Ancestors, Native Artisans of the Americas. The exhibition, which opened this week at the historic Custom House on Bowling Green, includes 400 artifacts from the collections of the Museum of the American Indian, plus films, craft demonstrations, performances of traditional.dances, guided tours and lectures.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE CRAFT OF WRITING. By William  Sloane. Edited by Julia H. Sloane. 123 pages. Norton. $10.95.

title: Deaths
description: EPSTEINGerald William DR., beloved son of Isidore and Marion. Dear brother of Joseph. His uncles and aunts of the Hammerman and Epstein families mourn his sudden passing. Services BoulevardPark West, 115 West 79 St, NYC Friday at 1PM.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A band of clouds stretches from northern New England to the upper Ohio Valley. while clouds are scattered in the Texas Panhandle, the Central Plains States and southern Florida. Clear skies extend from the Pacific Northwest to the Southern Pacific States and across the Rockies.

title: Deaths
description: CREAVYJoseph Edward, of Eastchester, NY. On Aug 2, 1979. Beloved husband of Marion Louise McGovern Creavy, devoted father of Thomas J. Creavy, loving grandfather of Thomas Jr and Pamela, dear brother of Winifred, Grace, Jack and the late Bill, Frances and Tom Creavy. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, from 2PM until 4PM & 7PM until 9PM Friday. Mass of Christian burial, at Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Saturday, Aug 4 at 10AM.

title: 3 SENATORS DEMAND PLEDGE FROM CARTER ON ARMSFUND RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Three Senators demanded today that President Carter furnish a detailed and prompt accounting of his intentions on defense spending before the Senate considers the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home Lines). Left Bermuda Aug. 2; due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Mental Stress Along the Potomac: Is It Really Worse in Washington?
description: WASHINGTON  She was a lawyer in an important government post, an attractive woman, bright and envied, but she was grinding her teeth and waking at night with a vague sense of unease.

title: Yankees Thurman Munson Killed Piloting His Own Small Jet in Ohio
description: Thurman Munson, the 32yearold catcher and team captain of the New York Yankees, was killed yesterday when the plane he was piloting crashed short of the runway while trying to land at the AkronCanton Airport in Ohio.

title: Nurturing Vietnam
description: How many recall that after our Revolutionary War, Tories in the 13 Colonies went to Canada or back to England? Or that after the Civil War many slaveholders fled to South America and thousands of exConfederates roamed the West before findine a new life? The point is, although the parallels may not be entirely accurate, that the situation of the Vietnamese boat people is a cruel but perhaps inevitable aftermath of a terrible revolutionary and civil war.

title: The Baltimore Orioles: Still Soaring
description: I see that the bad news abOUt the Baltimore Oriole has reached. Baltimore: The Baltimore Orioles  the birds, not the firstplace ball team in the America League's Eastern Divisionhave bred themselves out of existence because of an apparently unbridled passion for Western cousins. the Bullock's Oriole. The resulting hybrids are fertile and, therefore, according to a biological rule of thumb, the two must be considered variants of a single species, the prosaically renamed Northern Oriole.

title: Unions Hail the Decision to Relax Job Freeze in City Hospital System
description: Union leaders yesterday characterized as one small step the decision of the New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation to relax the job freeze in the municipalhospital system.

title: Jones Beach Party
description: What kind of birthday cake can you have for 10,000 guests? You can find out tomorrow at Jones Beach, when the Long Island sandandsea playground, named for Mai'. Thomas Jones. a pirate who owned tne property in 1695, will be observing its 50th birthday. There will be a parade at 2 P.M., and the cake will be unveiled at 3:30 P.M. in the Music Shell.

title: Remark by Mrs. Harris Stirs Rift On Politics in Civil Rights Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretarydesignate of Health, Education and Welfare, has indicated to the department's civil rights staff that political sensitivity should be considered in pursuing civil rights cases.

title: Big Retailers Sales Growth Off Again
description: Consumer buying of apparel, home furnishings and related goods slowed in July for the third consecutive month, according to reports yesterday by 15 of the nation's largest retail chains. The chains reported smaller sales gains fog the month than for the first half of the year.

title: Deaths
description: LAMEIROFrank R. Formerly of Brooklyn. Retired From Union Carbide. Died at Fort Collins, August 1, 1979. Husband of Beatrice C. Father of Gerard F.. Raymond A.. Paul A. all of Fort Collins, Aileen T. Povitch of Brooklyn. Mass and burial Fort Collins, Colorado.

title: The Short, Enigmatic Life of Thurman Munson
description: Baseball always was easy for Thurman Munson, but life never was. And now, after only 32 years, that life has ended tragically.

title: Soviet Chief of Staff Charges U. S. Foes of Nuclear Pact Distort the Facts
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2  After weeks of virtual silence on the debate in Washington on the strategic arms treaty, the Soviet Union published a major denunciation of opposition to the SovietAmerican accord today, in the form of an article by the Chief of the General Staff, Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov.

title: Monetary Fund Cuts Growth Projection
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  New forecasts have been submitted by the International Monetary Fund to its 138 member countries projecting economic growth in the industrial countries next year in the range of 2 percent, instead of the 3 percent forecast last spring.

title: U S. Inquiry Acquits Police In 78 Death of Black Leader
description: Federal officials said yesterday that there was insufficient evidence to prove that New York City policemen violated the civil rights of Arthur Miller in the 1978 Brooklyn street struggle in which the 35yearold black businessman and community leader was choked to death.

title: At City Hall, Tension Comes and Goes and Comes
description: Finally, the tension broke  and began again.

title: The Diggs Dilemma
description: After the House voted, 414 to 0, to censure Representative Charles Diggs, Speaker O'Neill struck his gavel and announced, The matter is closed. But it? Mr. Diggs, a 24year veteran of Congress, has, appealed a threeyear sentence for mail fraud and false searing. Whether he remains in Congress may therefore be up to the courts  or to. Mr. Diggs himself, who might save the House considerable embarrassment by resigning.

title: Thurman Munson Was Proud Captain of the Yankees
description: Thurman Munson, the 32yearold New York Yankee catcher killed in an airplane crash yesterday in Canton, Ohio, was the American League rookie of the year in 1970 and the league's most valuable player in his seventh season, in 1976. No member of the New York Yankees ever had won both awards.

title: Restaurants
description: THE iglooshaped clay oven known as the tandoor is most closely identified with Indian cooking. But, in fact, that excellent method of baking meats, poultry, fish and bread is believed to have originated in Afghanistan where it was picked up by the Mogul rulers who took it south to India and north to what is now Soviet Georgia. In all cases, the meat, poultry or fish is first marinated in a roseate spice mixture and is impaled on long skewers that are lowered into the tandoor. Sheets of a pizza.like bread dough, which in India is called nan, are also slapped against the sides of the oven and peeled off when crisply charred and blistered.

title: American Indians Celebration at the Custom House
description: In the great rotunda of the United States Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan the figures of eight explorers of the New World stare down on an exhibition of American Indian culture that the Europeans would never have envisioned taking place centuries after they first came to these shores.

title: WeekendGas Buying Expected to Be Fairly Easy
description: Getting gasoline in the metropolitan area this weekend should be relatively easy, a spokesman for the Automobile Club of New York said yesterday.

title: Talmadge Panel Ruling Is Expected Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The Senate's Select Committee on Ethics will not decide for another month whether Senator Herman E. Talmadge should be punished for financial misconduct, but there are indications that the Georgia Democrat may aet off liehtly.

title: Notes On People
description: A parttime English instructor at Brokenn College and at Long Island University has gone to the trouble of qualifying with the Federal Election Commission to run for Vice President of the United States, even though he is seven years too young to serve.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Willie Mays, scheduled to be inductedinto baseball's Hall of Fame on Sunday, became ill today after returning to the site of the Polo Grounds for a testimonial.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In the July 18 issue of The Times it was reported that the Association of American Medical Colleges and the American Dental Association would stop giving [their] examinations in New York State rather than comply with the truth in testing law signed by Governor Carey.

title: 4 Sentenced in Caverns Seizure
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 2 (AP) - Four men were sentenced today to year in prison when they pleaded guilty to a Federal misdemeanor  damaging Government property in the July 10 seizure of the Carlsbad Caverns. They were Dennis Mark, 39 years old; David Kuczynski, 28; Eugene Meroney, 31, and William Lovejoy, 28. The Government said took into consideration the release, unharmed, of a hostage, Linda Phillips, 25.

title: N.Y.R.A./BobCoglianese
description: SARATOGA VICTOR: Croquis (right), Ruben Hernandez up, won first race yesterday at Saratoga.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Spurred by the spreading conviction that the economy is moving into a deeper recession, the bond market advanced strongly yesterday for the second consecutive day. The Treasury sold $2 billion of longterm bonds at an average rate of 8.92 percent, decidedly lower than government securities dealers had expected earlier this week.

title: Israel Resisting American Pressure For Palestinians in Occupied Lands
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 2  Israel appears determined to resist pressure from the United States to grant Palestinians in occupied territories any form of local government that Israel feels might lead ultimately to sovereignty.

title: New York concern Admits Rigging Pacific Vote to Keep Stamp Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  A New York businessman entered a plea of guilty on behalf of his corporation in Federal District Court today to ;charges that $337,000 was paid to rig a general election in the Cook Islands last year so that the corporation could keep worldwide distribution rights for the South Pacific country's postage stamps.

title: Memorex, Amdahl Hold Talks
description: The Amdahl Corporation, a rapidly growing computer producer, and the Memorex Corporation, a manufacturer of peripheral equipment, are conducting exploratory merger talks, Amdahl said yesterday.

title: Swiss Say Cult Moved $1.8 Million to Banks In U.S. and Panama
description: The Swiss authorities said yesterday that $1.8 million held in three accounts in a Zurich bank in the name of members of the People's Temple commune was transferred to banks in Panama and the United States before more than 900 members of the organization died in their jungle camp in Guyana last November.

title: President Pledges Energy Crisis Won't Alter Environment Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  President Carter, in his longawaited second environmental message to Congress, pledged today that efforts to end the energy crisis would not change his Administration's basic commitment to clean air, clean water and the overall protection of the environment.

title: Orville H. Bullitt of Philadelphia, Philanthropist and Banker, Dies
description: Orville H. Bullitt, a Philadelphia banker and philanthropist, died Tuesday at his home outside Fort Washington, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: Basque Terrorist Group Vows to End Bombings
description: BAYONNE, France, Aug. 2 (UPI) A wing of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. announced today that it was halting its attacks on tourists because the bombings were alienating the Spanish people.

title: What's a Deputy Mayor?
description: Mayor Koch, who was a visitor at President Carter's recent Camp David meetings, appears to be profiting, if that is the right word, from the President's example. The Mayor, flexing his muscles and slapping his lectern, announced a major cabinet shakeup yesterday  but without demonstrating that he understands the defect he wishes to correct.

title: Unfted Preaclaternational
description: WORDS OF COMFORT: Pope John Paul II talking to an ailing nun, brought before him in a stretcher, during his weekly general audience in Vatican City. The audience was held yesterday in St. Peter's Square.

title: New Sculpture Under the Sun, From Staten I. To the Bronx
description: IT'S found on the fringes of Central Park and down near the Battery. You can see it on Roosevelt Island and in the financial district, East Side, West Side and all around the town. Each year a new crop of outdoor sculpture blooms in the city, in the open spaces of bucolic parks and the tight confines of busy squares and traffic islands. Pick a summer weekend to view it, take walking shoes and a picnic lunch, and you're off on a voyage of esthetic discovery, which this year will take you all the way from Staten Island to the Bronx.

title: Film: Aspects of History In Thalia Documentaries:Cromwell's Time
description: ALTHOUGH one is a documentary, made within the last year or so, and the other is a historical drama set in England in the mid-17th century, "Vietnam: An American Journey" and "Winstanley," which will be shown today and tomorrow at the Thalia, establish a certain resonance.The first is mainly devoted to the reconstruction and reunification of a nation. The second tells us virtually all that is known about Gerrard Winstanley, who founded the millennial Christian-Communist sect called the Diggers.Just as angry landlords had the Diggers' commune torn down and burned again and again, Vietnam, both in the north and in parts of the south, was subjected to the most concentrated and prolonged destruction known in the annals of warfare.Both are straightforward, earnest and unadorned narratives, and probably of greater interest for their political and historical content than as conventional entertainment."Vietnam," by Robert Richter, who has made documentaries for CBS-TV, ABC-TV and the Public Broadcasting Service, is described as the first full-length film on the subject by an American since the end of the war. Nonetheless, much of the material has become familiar through the work of others, which may account for the fact, commented on by Mr. Richter, that the three commercial networks and PBS have declined to show it.Mr. Richter's journey in May and June 1978 took him from Hanoi, which suffered so heavily in the bombing attacks of 1972 and has now been largely rebuilt, down Route 1 to Ho Chi Minh City. Along the way he stops at Vinh and Quangtri City, which were all but leveled, and at Mylai, where he speaks to a survivor of the massacre, a woman who is the only survivor of a family of nine.A memorial has been erected on the site of the hamlet, where American troops massacred more than 500 people. It is a place of painful memories for Americans as well as Vietnamese.Most of "Vietnam" is devoted to construction sites; hospitals, where the maimed are being treated, the dismal "cultural activities" that pass for entertainment in Socialist countries and "re-education camps" for prostitutes, narcotics addicts and former adherents of the Saigon Government. Not surprisingly, they say they are grateful for the opportunity to mend their ways.Mr. Richter's hosts did not permit him many detours. One would have been interested in knowing, for example, if the Montagnards in the south were being better treated by their new masters than by their old ones. The expulsion of ethnic Chinese, the fact that tens of thousands of Vietnamese are fleeing their country, the Cambodian invasion and the tension on the Chinese border are scarcely mentioned."Winstanley," which was made in 1975, is the work of Kevin Brownlow, the film historian, and Andrew Mollo. It is based on "Comrade Jacob," a novel by David Caute. The narration is derived from Winstanley's pamphlets, which were written out of the disappointment felt by the rural poor when Cromwell's Government failed to make substantial reforms in the country's social structure. The Digger movement, by the way, had a brief revival in San Francisco and New York as part of the social ferment created by the Vietnam War during the late 60's.The pace of "Winstanley" is glacial, the situations tend to be repetitious, the acting, mainly by nonprofessionals, is rudimentary, and the black-and-white cinematography only occasionally luminous. The overall effect is that of a historical pageant.

title: Watson Leads P.G.A. by Shot
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 2 Tom Watson is back. The most successful player on the PGA Tour, who has had a bad run the last two months, shot a 66 today to lead after the opening round of the 61st Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Rockower Brothers Inc., merchandisers of men's and boys apparel, announced yesterday that its directors at a special meeting had adopted a resolution recommending that the company be dissolved voluntarily.

title: 9 London Insurers Sue Itel, 3 Others
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP) Nine insurance companies in Lon don have filed a $20 million damage suit in the Federal court her against the Itel Corporation anc others alleging misrepresentatior in obtaining reinsurance against risks of loss on computers and corn outer leases.

title: Haines Leads Qualifiers As Darkness Halts Golf
description: WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 2George Haines, who won the New Jersey amateur golf championship in June, was leading in the 36hole qualifying round for the 77th annual Metropolitan Golf Association championship today when play was suspended because of darkness at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.

title: Seventh Fleet's Refugee Mission Evokes a Commitment by Crews
description: .ABOARD U.S.S. KITTY HAWK, off Thailand, Aug. 2  A carrier strike force of the United States Navy's Seventh Fleet led by the 80,000ton U.S.S. Kitty Hawk, lumbered out of the palmfringed port of Phatthaya this afternoon determined to go to the rescue of Vietnamese refugees in the South China Sea.

title: Carter Plans to Visit Baltimore
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  President Carter will go to Baltimore next Tuesday for two appearances, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, announced today. The President is scheduled to visit a neighborhood where older residents have rehabilitated homes to make them more energyefficient, then address the national convention of the Order of the Sons of Italy.

title: Digest BUSINESS. Digest
description: Thomas A. Murphy of General Motors said he did not favor Government financial aidfor Chrysler. The G.M. chairman said such aid would compromise the discipline of the marketplace. The position the largest auto company could have an impact on Chrysler's chances of obtaining the $1 billion in Government loans it is seeking. At the same time, he said G.M. had reduced its estimate of newcar sales in calendar 1979 and said sales next year would be unlikely set a record. [Page Al.]

title: The Pop Life
description: LAST year's Talking Heads album; More Songs About Buildings and Food, was this writer's favorite LP of 1978. The band's new disk, Fear of Music, is being officially released today and should be in the stores by next week, in time for the group's appearance next Friday night at the Dr. Pepper Festival. The album will certainly be a candidate for best of 1979, along with such other contenders as Neil Young's Rust Never Sleeps, The Roches and The B52's.

title: IN THE NATION American Dilemma
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 2- Committees of the House and Senate approved this week a resolution that would commit Congress to support selfdetermination for the 3.2 million people of Puerto Rico. Gov. Carlos RomeroBarcel6 says its passage would be a commitment to statehood for Puerto Rico, if its people should choose that course.

title: Screen: 'Concorde...Airport '79':Airplane on Skis
description: "THE Concorde ... Airport '79" is a movie that shows you the Washington Monument, the Eiffel tower, the Alps, Charo, and a big, scary-looking thing with fins. (This is the plane of the title.) That ought to take care of your summer sightseeing  and it's a good thing, too, since "Concorde" is enough to persuade anyone to stay on the ground. The plane makes 360-degree flip-flops. Pieces of the floor fall out. Martha Raye hogs the bathroom. Aeronautically and otherwise, it's a bumpy trip.The early portion of "Concorde," which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, involves a roundup of hilarious passengers  a little more hilarious than usual this time  in shabby-looking action sequences and an idiotic sabotage scheme, Susan Blakely plays a television newscaster in love with Robert Wagner, who wears enough important-looking gold jewelry to identify him as either Louis XIV or a big-deal business tycoon. He turns out to be the latter, and his gigantic, powerful empire is threatened with scandal. The papers that will prove this have been leaked to Miss Blakely, who clearly needs to be dispatched.Will Mr. Wagner have her murdered in a deserted parking lot, or atop a cliff, or in the privacy of her own home? Of course not. It's much easier to kill her aboard the Concorde, since all this will cost Mr. Wagner's cartel is a guided missile or two. Is this the kind of business savvy that has made this man a zillionaire?Maybe not. But it's the type of bright idea that keeps these "Airport" movies taxiing down the runway. This time, the screenplay packs the plane with a Soviet gymnast (Andrea Marcovicci) and the newscaster she loves (John Davidson); a world-weary pilot (Alain Delon) and the stewardess he fools around with (Sylvia Kristel), a mother whose child needs a heart transplant (Cicely Tyson), a heart (or at least a box that says HEART on the outside), the president of the airline (Eddie Albert), a jazz musician who plays his saxophone on board (Jimmie Walker), and a Russian athlete (Avery Schreiber) who makes a lot of noise talking to his deaf daughter.Nobody here is as much fun as Helen Reddy was, playing a singing nun in an earlier "Airport" movie. And this time George Kennedy is at the controls, not Charlton Heston  any big-name Hollywood star who wanted to appear in one of these films has long since come and gone. But the second-best casting is unexpectedly entertaining, a lot more so than the airplane-in-distress scenes. Watching this crazy lineup of passengers in conversation is a lot more entertaining than watching their hand luggage whiz through the air.The Concorde makes nearly two trips before the action really comes to life, but even then  when the above-mentioned skiing is done by the aircraft itself  it's a bit perfunctory. Until the snowbound finale, most of the film's interest lies in watching the actors and wondering what they're doing here. Miss Blakeley, Mr. Albert and David Warner (as a co-pilot) are the most agreeable players on hand. At the other end of the cabin, so to speak, are Bibi Andersson, who seems unctuous even for the prostitute she's playing, and Martha Raye, whose bladder problems are a big topic of discussion."The Concorde ... Airport '79" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes some salty language from Mr. Kennedy, and some scenes of violent in-flight turbulence that may indeed frighten small children.

title: KOCH SHUFFLES HIGHEST AIDES; 3 DEPUTIES TO LEAVE, 2 SHIFTED; BADILLO IS AMONG THOSE OUT
description: Mayor Koch, saying it was time to pare down and streamline his government, yesterday announced a major shakeup at the highest level.

title: K. G. B. Is Brought In To Break Melon Ring
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The trouble in Tsodniskari cropped up when an entire field of watermelons disappeared and it took an investigation by the K.G.B., the state security agency, to explain what happened.

title: ALASKA LEGISLATOR STALLS CAPITAL MOVE
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 1  At first it sounded like an idea out of a simpler time, such as the mid19th century when state capitals in the West were mostly a set of files and official seals that tended to drift from one city to another as power ebbed and flowed.

title: Newsprint Makers Plan Rise in Price and Output
description: Major producers of newsprint are going to raise their prices by 9 percent in the fall and are acting now to increase capacity as a result of a supply squeeze that has affected many newspapers.

title: Charges Against Sears On Job Discrimination Are Viewed as Flawed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Six years after the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission began its investigation into job discrimination at Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, attorneys for the commission have admitted in confidential memorandums that their case is too weak to stand up in court.

title: NewStyle Flea Market Opens Sunday on Pier 92
description: Gene Stein, bored with his computer job last year, turned to his friend Roger Greenman, who was in the same line of work. How about starting a flea market? he asked. Mr. Greenman said he had no interest in selling used hubcaps. But you don't understand what a flea market is, persisted Mr. Stein, and Mr. Greenman allowed that was true.

title: After DC10 Fell, Airline Changed Rules for Handling Engine Failures
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2American Airlines said todaythat, as a result of the crash of one of its DCI0 jumbojets here on May 25, it had changed its procedures for dealing with an engine failure on takeoff.

title: Hanoi Aide Said to Defect to China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 2  A Hong Kong weekly news magazine, the Far Eastern Economic Review, reported today that a senior Vietnamese official who was a close colleague of Ho Chi Minh and a founder of the Indochina Communist Party defected to China early last month.

title: Bettor Kills Soccer Player
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 2 (UPI) spectator at a soccer game in the Peruvian Andes, apparently angry because his team was losing, 30, fatally.shot player today who had scored for the opposing team. Maximo Ayala, a fan of Deportivo Rayo, killed with a shotgun Rafael Palomino, a forward for Deportivo Atlas, and injured four other players in the closing moments of game in Cobriza.

title: Advertising
description: IF the Federal Trade Commission were monitoring the oral claims of advertising people, Thomas L. Griffin might really be in trouble for saying, I'm not afraid to say that, when it comes to newproduct introductions, we are the best.

description: Following is the text of Mayor Koch's statement on the reorganization of his administration:

title: Youth's Manslaughter Conviction Reopens Debate on Juvenile Law
description: After the jury's deliberation in his murder trial, Louis Bonilla, 14 years old, was convicted of manslaughter in Supreme Court in the Bronx last week. The state had charged that when he was 13 the boy shot 17yearold Israel Garcia twice in the back in an attempt to steal his radio. Because Louis Bonilla was the youngest person to be tried in adult criminal court under the state's Juvenile Offender Law, the trial attracted a great deal of attention and rekindled the bitter debate that preceded enactment of the statute last year.

title: United Press International
description: EXPOS BEAT CUBS: Miguel Dilone of Chicago diving into second base ahead of throw to Chris Speier last night during Cubs 64 loss in Montreal.

title: Ties to Chrysler Embarrass Mitsubishi
description: TOKYO, Aug. 2  Chujiro Fujino, the 78yeati.old doyen of the Mitsubishi Group, has taken charge of urgent consultations on the. future of his company's relations, with, the faltering Chrysler Corporation, its partner in the United States.

title: State Court on Judiciary Orders Ouster of Town Justice Upstate
description: ALBANY  The State Court on the Judiciary ordered the removal of Edward Jones as town justice of Coeymans in Albany County for concealing evidence of ticketfixing and for directing the alteration and destruction of records that had revealed ticketfixing.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A. (5) Pattern for Living

title: Engine Failure Cited by Investigator As Apparent Cause of Munson Crash
description: A Federal airsafety investigator said yesterday that engine failure apparently caused the crash of Thurman Munson's private jet on Thursday. The 32yearold Yankee catcher was killed and two passengers flying with him were injured when the plane, which Munson was piloting, crashed short of the runway at CantonAkron (Ohio) Regional Airport.

title: Control of 21 to Pass To Baroness at a Party Given in Monte Carlo
description: The Baroness Sandra di Portanova will become a 51percent owner of the 21 Club in Manhattan at an exclusive dinner tonight in Monte Carlo, Monaco, according to her lawyer, Roy M. Cohn.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Up Abroad, Off At Home as Gold Falls
description: The dollar gained slightly overseas and lost a little at home in slow foreignexchange trading yesterday, with one dealer describing the market as dead. The price of gold again declined fairly sharply.

title: China Rehabilitates Critics of Mao
description: PEKING, Aug. 3 (Reuters)  The Pe. king Communist Party has rehabilitated a group of writers and editors who fell victim to the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's after their work implicitly criticized the policies of Mao Zedong.

title: Indians Tribal Chairmen's Group Demanding a Voice in Energy Policy
description: DENVER, Aug. 3  The National Tribal Chairmen's Association, which can fairly be said to represent the American Indian establishment, has been voicing some uncharacteristically militant feelings at its convention here this week. The principal complaint was about energy.

title: Dreyfus Redux, in Reverse
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y. How could Dan White, the killer of San Francisco Mayor George Moscone and City Supervisor Harvey Milk  who fired nine bullets into his vic'dms and shot each one twice in the back of the head, executionstyle  not be found guilty of firstdegree murder?

title: Koch to Name Robert Wagner Jr. A Deputy in Aftermath of Shuffles
description: In the aftermath of the reorganization of the Koch administration, it was learned yesterday that the Mayor intends to name Robert F. Wagner Jr., the City Planning Commissioner, to a Deputy Mayor's post.

title: U.S. Freeze on Purchase Of City Buses Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The Transportation Department today allowed cities to buy new buses after a virtual freeze caused by a dispute over designs allowing the handicapped and elderly to board easily.

title: You Can't Look It Up
description: One reason for the appeal of baseball is that so many parts of the game can be talked about objectively. It is possible to add up individual yardage in football, or times in swimming, or total points scored in basketball. But when it comes to things to count, and talk about, baseball is surely king. You could always, as they say, look it up.

title: Israeli Units Infiltrate 9 Miles Into Lebanon And Attack Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 (Reuters)  An Israeli Army raiding force destroyed two Palestinian camps and killed at least 10 guerrillas last night about nine miles inside Lebanon, the army reported today.

title: Miss Lopez Increases Lead To Three Shots on 69137
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 3 (AP)  Nancy Lopez increased her lead to three strokes today after the second round of the $100,000 Ladies FroleSsional Golf Association European open. She carded a birdie on each of the last three holes on the rainsoaked Sunningdale course for a 69 and a total of 137.

title: Crenshaw, on 67136, Leads P.G.A.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 3 Ben Crenshaw, who has knocked often at the doors of major championships, took the lead today after two rounds of the 61st Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Limited Cuban Pullout in Ethiopia Is Reported by American Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Cuba has withdrawn about 2,000 to 3,000 of the soldiers and officers it sent to Ethiopia in 1977 and early 1978 to help the country's military rulers repel an incursion from Somalia, Administration officials said The officials emphasized that the pullout was limited, in nature and said it did not indicate any lessening of Cuba's commitment to support the selfstyled Marxist regime in Ethiopia or other leftwing revolutionary movements in Africa.

title: Radio
description: 74 A.M., WNYCFM. Trots Gymnopdies, Salle; Concerto in for Two Trumpets, Vivaldi; Little Fugue in G, Bach.

title: Face on the Scoreboard
description: Out on the Yankee Stadium scoreboard, Thurman Munson's face looked down from the huge screen, his walrus mustache dominating his familiar glower. Nearby, the American flag hung limply at halfstaff. And for eight minutes, the 51,151 spectators applauded reverently, their ovation slightly louder each time the face reappeared between flashes of the message that George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, had composed for the occasion: Our captain and leader has not left us  today, tomorrow, this year, next. Our endeavors will reflect our love and admiration for him. When the Yankees took the field to hear Terence Cardinal Cooke intone a prayer and Robert Merrill sing America the Beautiful before last night's game with the Baltimore Orioles, the Yankee catcher, Jerry Narron, remained near the dugout, staying there until the game was about to begin. But earlier, two switchboards kept beeping in the Yankee reception area outside George Steinbrenner's office.

title: COMMODITIES Grain and Livestock Climb in Quiet Trading
description: Most grain, livestock and precious metals futures rose moderately yesterday in quiet trading.

title: ElePhant Man Schedules Show for Actors Fund
description: A special Actors Fund performance of The Elephant Man, the Tonyawardwinning drama, will be held tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. Tickets are at regular prices.

title: Energy Project To Add Jobs
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 3 (AP)  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that the selection of its aerospace division by the Department of Energy for the initial manufacturing of gas centrifuge machines might mean 1,200 new jobs.

title: Alfredo Ottaviani, 88; Cardinal Who Headed Vatican's Holy Office
description: ROME, Aug. 3 (AP)  Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani, who was the head of the Vatican's Holy Office under Popes Pius XII and John XXIII, died today in his Vatican apartment, the Holy See announced. He was 88 years old.

title: Iranians in U.S. May Extend Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)  Iranians visiting the United States may stay an extra nine months, until June 1, 1980, because of the continuing upheaval in Iran, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today. It said the State Department had requested the move.

title: Califano Busy Up to the End
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the recently ousted Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, spent his last day in office swearing in a. new deputy inspector general for health for the department and issuing stateand the drug ments on the dangers of Paraquat spray Darvon.

title: OBSERVER
description: Maybe Washington really is another country. Certainly nobody living in the United States could have dreamed up the suggestion, which came out of Washington the other day, that filling stationsle allowed to charge for washing your windshield, checking tire pressures and performing similar small services.

title: Victor Haya de la Torre Is Dead; Elder Statesman of Peru Was 84
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 3 (AP)  Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, the elder statesman of Latin American democracy who never achieved the goal he most wanted, the presidency of Peru, is dead at 84. He died Thursday night of lung cancer.

title: COMPANY NEWS American Airlines To Drop Most Inns
description: American Airlines Inc. said yesterday that the carrier was negotiating the disposal of all but one of its properties in its Americana Hotels subsidiary.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Hampton Band to Play At Snug Harbor Center
description: The Snug Harbor Cultural Center's outdoor summer music festival will present Lionel Hampton and his big band tomorrow at 2 P.M. Mr. Hampton plays drums, piano and vibraharp.

title: South Africa's Reforms
description: JOHANNESBURG  I do not need anyone from abroad reminding me that a society where any man, whatever his creed or color, is denied human rights, is an unjust one. I am fully aware of this and so is my Government.

title: Around the Nation
description: HAYS, Kan., Aug. 3 (UPI)  A private plane attempting an emergency landing crashed tonight about half a mile short of the airport runway, killing all seven persons aboard, including five children.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AN instrument for the diagnosis of ignition trouble in the internalcombustion engines that power most of the country's cars and trucks has been invented at the Automated Systems division of the RCA Corporation in Burlington, Mass. Patent 9,163,192 was granted this week to Eldon M. Sutphin Jr., a staff member.

title: Recapitation
description: The report that the longseparated head and torso of an ancient Egyptian statue have been matched is one of those happy detective stories that make us wish the world at large were more often like the world of archeology. The two pieces were dug up in 1903 from an ancient junkyard near the Temple of Karnak. The head found its way to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the torso to the Cairo Museum.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug 3  The Spingold knockout team championship, the premiere event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, continued here this afternoon with 32 teams in play, but one top squad was missing from the ranks. The eighthseeded Precision team  captained by Kathy Wei of New York and including Judi Radin, Ron Andersen and Dave Berkowitz, all of New York, and Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, who placed second in the Vanderbilt Cup five months ago  lost a cliffhanger in secondround play last night.

title: Chain's Acquisition. of Alaska Paper Steps Up Rivalry
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 2 Vigorous competition has come to the newspaper business here since the. McClatchy chain acquired control of The Anchorage Daily News last January.

title: Canada Nears Gas Sale to U.S.
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 3 (AP)Canada is close to reaching an agreement with Southern Natural Resources Inc. to tap the nation's vast supplies of Arctic natural gas for the first time, an official of the national oil company said today. In Birmingham, Ala., Southern Natural confirmed that it was close to such an agreement.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EYE DEAL The firehousered facade of SoHo's Museum of Holography does not look exactly cooling these summer months, but the place is cooling and provocative. Camera addicts industriously clicking away during the outdoor season are in for a diverting surprise if they step inside this showcase devoted to threedimensional photography. And the red front at 11 Mercer Street, a halfblock above Canal Street, makes the museum easy to spot in a neighborhood of drabcolored structures.

title: Car Sales Improved In Late July
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The pace of newcar sales accelerated in late July from the levels recorded earlier in the month but remained below the yearearlier sales rate, according to reports issued today by the domest;.c automobile manufacturers.

title: Bonn Legislator Dies at 56
description: BONN, Aug. 3 (AP)  Hermann SchmittVockenhausen, a deputy president of West Germany's lower house of Parliament, died in Coblenz last night after a long illness, his Bonn office said today. Mr. SchmittVockenhausen, a Social Democrat, was 56 years Old. A member of Parliament since 1953; he became one of the lower house's four deputy presidents in 1969.

title: Dance: The Oberlin Collective, 10 Lighthearted Performers
description: California's Oberlin Dance Collective, the second attraction in the Dance Theater Workshop's summer OutofTowners festival, opened Thursday at the American Theater Laboratory. The 10member group proved to be if sleek and imaginative addition to the New York dance scene and certainly one of the most lighthearted companies to be seen in the city in many a season.

title: Attempts to Close Trials to Press Increase After High Court Ruling
description: More than 30 attempts have been made by defense attorneys around the country to ban reporters from criminal proceedings as a result of the recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that the press and the public have no constitutional right of access to pretrial hearings.

title: Heat Wave and Water Restraints Continue
description: On another day of muggy heat  and with the prospect of a weekend just about as uncomfortable  the city continued restrictions on the use of water yesterday as a preliminary to a possible water emergency.

title: Disclosure Ordered in Bank Case
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that regulatory authorities can be compelled to turn over bank ex. aminers reports to parties involved in lawsuits.

title: Senate Approves Bill To Help Sections Hit By Joblessness of 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The Senate voted 69 to 23 today to give 2,100 economically depressed cities more than $340 million in Federal aid during the fiscal year 1980. The measure, which it is estimated would provide $99 million for New York City, faces serious opposition in the House of Representatives.

title: Film: 'Rock 'n' Roll High School' With the Ramones 'Punk' Band
description: "Rock 'n' Roll High School" at the Eighth Street Playhouse has its charms; the pity is that with a bit more care and flair, it could have been a really sweet little movie. The film centers on the Ramones, an innocently cartoonish New York "punk" band. However, it's a real movie, as opposed to a vehicle for a rock act. This is partly by design; it has a plot and actors and everything. But it's also partly by omission. The Ramones are so blank and nebulous on screen that they never emerge as individuals, in the manner of the Beatles in their films.Richard Lester's Beatles movies are one obvious inspiration for "Rock 'n' Roll High School." Others are "Grease" and "Animal House," and the biggest is the whole string of amusingly trashy teen flicks put out by Roger Corman  who serves as executive producer here.The plot involves a good girl (Dey Young) and a bad girl (P.J. Soles), although both are really good as good can be. The two unite to thwart an evil new headmistress, bring the Ramones to their school and, ultimately, to blow the place to smithereens.Mixed in with all of this are a myriad of gags, production numbers and mild romantic complications, all directed with some buoyance by Allan Arkush.The troubles are that after awhile all this froth weighs one down, and too often easy solutions are settled for when a bit more wit might have lifted things to a truly inspired level. The Ramones specialize in dull-sounding disks, but that approach seems to have been carried over to the recording of the dialogue, which is so lacking in high frequencies as to be often undecipherable. And ultimately, for a movie meant to exalt rock, it would be nice to have rather better rock music than that made by the Ramones and most of the others on the soundtrack here.Still, "Rock 'n' Roll High School" purports to be little more than summer fun, and, in its zanily unpretentious way, it is certainly that."Rock 'n' Roll High School" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). Aside from its anarchic propaganda, it contains little to offend those troubled by explicit naughty words or nudity.

title: Begin Leaves Hospital for Home; Plans to Resume His Work Soon
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3  Prime Minister Menachem Begin left the hospital today, two weeks after a minor stroke that left his vision slightly impaired.

title: Report in Connecticut Finds Courts Speedier
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 3 The number of serious criminal cases pending in Connecticut courts fell by 5 percent for the year that ended on July 1, despite 32 percent increase in the number of cases added to the docket, according to a study of Connecticut's reorganized court system that was released today.

title: Mondale Attempts to Assure Israel And U.S. Jews About Carter Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Vice President Mondale sought today to alleviate concern of Israelis and American Jews by asserting in remarks on Israeli television that the Administration's policy toward the Palestine Liberation Organization remains unchanged and is totally committed to a secure and permanent Israel.

title: United Press International
description: PLEADING IN VAIN: Ivan DeJesus of Chicago argued with Umpire Paul Runge after being called out trying steal second in the third inning of game with St. Louis. Cubs won, 42, to end sixgame losing streak.

title: Erikson Sees Psychological Danger In Trend of Having Fewer Children
description: Erik H. Erikson, one of the patriarchs of psychoanalysis, suggested yesterday that modern man may be in the process of exchanging one form of repression for another. Just as sexual repression characterized the Victorian era, he said, so repression of the urge to have children may characterize the future.

title: Senators Appeal to Carter to Resist Linking Arms Treaty and Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  More than a dozen Senators urged President Carter today to resist demands that military spending be increased in order to obtain Senate approval of the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: C.A.B. and F.T.C. Members Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) President Carter said today that he was nominating George A. Dailey to the Civil Aeronautics Board and Patricia P. Bailey to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Closure Asked at Tennessee Trial
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 3 (AP)  A Federal judge recessed a trial involving the selling of executive clemency today to study a defense motion to bar reporters and the public. The motion drew a protest from Nashville's newspapers, The Tennessean and The Nashville Banner. Among five defendants are three former aides to former Gov. Ray Blanton who are accused of conspiracy to sell pardons and reprieves during his four years in office.

title: Eisenhower College, I Learn, Has Been Acquired
description: POULTNEY, Vt.  I have just had rather unique experience. I opened letter and was informed that my college had gone under. Not my job. Not my marriage. Not my life. My college.

title: New York City Continues to Show A Rise in Its Unemployment Rate
description: New York City's unemployment rate, which rose sharply in June, continued upward last month to 10.2 percent  the highest rate since January 1978.

title: A Limit on Prophets?
description: On Sunday, July 22, at exactly 4:56 P.M., Daylight Time, hundreds of people were expected to die in Niagara Falls rock slide, as foreseen by a Connecticut woman. The seer turned out to be wrong: No rock slide, no unusual turbulence, no sinking Maid of the Mist. But suppose the rock slide occurs later  today, for instance, 13 superstitious days later? Would the world consider the prophecy a pretty good one after all? Probably. Most people generally refuse to hold prophets, fortunetellers and stock tipsters to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.

title: VINCENT C. ZIEGLER
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 3 (UPI)Vincent C. Ziegler, retired chairman of the the Gillette Company, died Wednesday at his home. He was 68 years old.

title: Sadat Will Not Oppose Amending Resolution 242
description: CAIRO, Aug. 3  President Anwar elSadat said tonight that Egypt would not oppose efforts to amend Resolution 242 in the United Nations Security Council so that the United States could begin discussions with the Palestinians.

title: Long Island's Former Queen City Looks to Gaming Casinos for Revival
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 1  In its heyday as a summer resort in the 1930's and 1940's, Long Beach was the Queen City of the Atlantic. Now, with most of the jewels fallen from the crown, a lot of people here are looking to casino gambling as the key to the economic and social revival of the kingdom.

title: Tests Show Possibility Ashe Had Heart Attack
description: Arthur Ashe, a former Wimbledon and United States Open tennis champion, was reported to be in good condition following tests that indicated that he might have suffered a heart attack Tuesday night.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Chrysler was rebuffed by the United Auto Workers in its appeal for a twoyear freeze on wages and benefits in the wake of a $207 million secondquarter loss. The U.A.W. did, however, schedule a Thursday meeting to discuss what sort of relief labor might give the company, and the union's president, Douglas A. Fraser, said again that the Government should take an equity position in Chrysler, rather than give it the $1 billion in aid it has requested. [Page 1.]

title: Saint Laurent: The Couture Is a Dream, Like Opera or the Ballet
description: The showing of his fall couture collection last week moved some of his audience to tears and brought the house its feet fora rousing chorus of bravos. A few days later, in his sumptuous, Left Bank apartment in Paris, overlooking trees and a garden, Yves Saint Laurent said he was terrified before the show. It was a completely selfish collection, he said. I did to please myself.

title: Ten U.S. Companies Join Search for Oil Off China
description: PEKING, Aug. 2  China has nearly completed a series of agreements with foreign oil companies for comprehensive seismic surveys of what are believed to be Its vast offshore oil reserves.

title: Books of The Times The Soul of Flowers
description: Many years ago I was astonished, on opening a novel by D.H. Lawrence, to come upon what seemed like a 10page catalogue of wildflowers. I looked upon this display of esoteric knowledge with envy and mistrust. No man's man, I thought in my callow male chauvinism, would know so much about flowers. But at the same time, I felt that Lawrence was on better terms with nature than I was and that this close relationship may have given him certain advantages.

title: Moscow Wins Gold Medal In Basketball at Spartakiad
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP)  Moscow, playing cautiously against its taller opponents, defeated the Ukraine, 8581, today and won the men's basketball gold medal of the Spartakiad.

title: Judd Hirsch Plays Dracula In ABC Comedy Special
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 2 (AP)  Judd Hirsch will play Dracula and Mariette Hartley a witch in an ABCTV comedy special, The Halloween That Almost Wasn't, to be telecast in late October.

title: Deaths
description: HALPERINHarry H. The Men's Club of Stephen Wise Free Synagogue mourns the passing of its esteemed Board Member and devoted leader. His dedicated service and constant support are a lasting inspiration to his friends and colleagues. Our deep sympathy goes to his beloved Sarah whom we loin in prayers for strength and healing.

title: Notes on People
description: Lewis Rudin is a prominent New York realestate figure, as president of Rudin Management, and a highpowered New York City booster, as the hardworking chairman of the Association for a Better New York. Yesterday, he was very angry in both capacities. . What infuriated him, he said, was the innate bigotry of the owners of cooperative apartments at 19 East 72d Street, whose opposition to the sale of an apartment to Richard M. Nixon. led to the former President's decision to drop plans for the purchase.

description: Ed Figueroa was supposed to be in California yesterday for surgery on his right elbow, but instead he caught the redeye flight to New York and arrived at 6:30 in the morning.

title: DC10 Manufacturer Terms Slat Locks Unjustified
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3  The manufacturer of the DC10 jumbo jet said today that it saw no justification for adding mechanical locks to the plane's front wing flaps to prevent the type of uneven positioning that was a critical factor in the crash here of an American Airlines DC10 on May 25.

title: Artist Calls Bridge Device His Work
description: A 24yearold SoHo artist took responsibility yesterday for the explosive device found atop a Brooklyn Bridge tower on Thursday.

description: Plans for the Broadway production of If, If, If, starring Dick Van Dyke, have been canceled, it was announced yesterday by the Theater Guild, producers of the play by Lawrence Roman.

title: Itel Now Puts Its Loss In Quarter at $60 Million
description: The Itel Corporation, which sells and arranges lease financing of computer equipment, announced yesterday that its secondquarter net loss would be an estimated $60 million after taxes. A week ago, the company estimated that the loss would be in excess of $10 million.

description: Special to The New York Times

description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 3  Tea of thousands of chanting Nicaraguan marched through the streets of Managui today in a show of support for the coon try's new Sandinist Government. It wa the first such demonstration since tne junta drove into Managua two weeks ago.

title: Stock Prices Ease On Reduced Volume
description: Price changes in stockkaffected by takeover developments continued to draw attention on Wall Street yesterday. Meanwhile, the general market declined slightly.

title: A Bomb Factory Found in Jersey; Police Seeking 2
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 3  The police issued arrest warrants today for a young couple suspected of operating a terrorist bomb factory in a fivestory brick tenement across the street from St. Mary's Hospital here.

title: Mrs. Carter Puts Off Departure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters) Rosalynn Carter announced today that she had postponed her scheduled departure tomorrow for Bolivia because of uncertainty surrounding the election. She had planned to attend the inauguration of the new president in La Paz on Monday.

title: Giants Will Start Randy Dean at Quarterback Against Browns
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 The Giants begin their preseason schedule tomorrow night at the Meadowlands and today Coach Ray Perkins said his first unit would start the 8 P.M. game against the Cleveland Browns.

title: Hartford's Poles Are Dismayed as 2 Feud Over Aliens
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.  To a young woman with an expiring tourist visa, speaking only Polish and wanting to stay in the United States a few more months before returning home, Alexander Gorski seemed like a godsend.

title: Laurie J. Landau Is Married To David I. Weiner, Banker
description: Laurie J. Landau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Landau of Taipei, Taiwan, was married yesterday in New York to David I. Weiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weiner of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue.

title: Auto Workers Reject Chrysler Plea Fora 2Year WageBenefit Freeze
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3  The Chrysler Corporation asked the United Automobile Workers today for a twoyear freeze on wages and benefits for some 124,000 Chrysler employees under contract.

title: Fans Cheer Before Loss
description: With the catcher's spot behind home plate vacant, in the tradition of the riderless horse at a military funeral, crowd of 51,151 gave the late Thurman Munson an extraordinary pregame tribute at Yankee Stadium last nieht.
