title: Mystery Surrounds Fate of Swede Who SavedJews_
description: Nina Lagergren of Stockholm and Annette Lantos of San Francisco, though they met for the first time earlier this summer, have had a common mission for more than three decades.

title: How Not to Subsidize Housing
description: Middleincome families all over the country are complaining that they can't find decent apartments at rents they can afford. Before going to their rescue with a new program, the Department of Housing and Urban Development should take a look at New York's MitchellLama program, which was intended to accomplish this very goal.

title: Letter: On the Peace Corps
description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial, Homing In on the Peace Corps, unwisely endorses the President's executive order which gives the Peace Corps the illusion of independence without the muscle to back it up. Many of the important provisions of the order are left to chance, and insiders have noted that it is disturbingly business as usual within the corps despite the Presidential order. Thus the eversinking morale within the Peace Corps continues, volunteer numbers are still decreasing and excess administrative baggage persists in hobbling Peace Corps pro. grams. How can this be the next best thing to complete independence?

title: About New York
description: There is no way to simplify the paper work involved in a single city application for one small Federal grant, mere frond in the bureaucratic jungle, but one with a myriad of hopes and jobs and administrative notations riding on each page.

title: EARNINGS Grumman Net Off 14.7%
description: The Grumman Corporation, a leading maker of military aircrft as well numerous nonmilitary industrial and consumer products, reported yesteraay that it had secondquarter net income of $5.8 million, or 68 cents a share, down 19.7 percent from $6.8 million, or 83 cents a share, for the similar three months last year.

title: Vidal to Write TV Series About Abraham Lincoln
description: Gore Vidal, whose numerous credits include a trilogy of historical novels, will write a sixhour series about the personal life of Abraham Lincoln for broadcast next year on NBCTV. to drama, which will focus on Lincoln's relationship with his wife and children during the Civil War, is being produced by T.A.T. Communications, with Norman Lear as executive producer. It will go into production early next year.

title: Senate, 50 to 29, Votes to Ease Rules on Financial Disclosures
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The Senate voted today, 50 to 29, to ease its financial disclosure requirements and comply only with the milder disclosure rules observed by the House and the executive and judicial branches.

title: Eats (Blink) Eats (Blink) Eats (Blink)
description: Neon, representing an elegant Parisian art nouveau linear dimension, was first brought to America by a Los Angeles Packard dealer in 1923. He commissioned two signs and they stopped traffic and one is still working. Neon lit up California and the glow traveled East.

title: Westinghouse Awarded Seoul Nuclear Contract
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 3  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation was awarded a $2 billion contract today to build South Korea's seventh and eighth nuclear power units after considerable competition among the world's leading electrical contractors.

title: European Summer: A Trip To the Ultimate Landscape
description: NORTH CAPE, Norway  Where Europe falls away into the Arctic Ocean, there is nothing that distracts from the mean, final landscape: brown crags, gray crags, dirt and rock pushed together and skinned of vegetation as if by a dull knife.

title: Angie Dickinson to Star In Movie for CBSTV
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 2 (AP)  Angie Dickinson will star in the movie The Suicide's Wife for telecast next season on CBSTV.

title: Your Money
description: STORM clouds are gathering again for the nation's automobile insurers. And that, of course, means the rain eventually will fall on automobile owners in the form of higher insurance rates.

description: Dv the Associated Press

title: The City
description: On June 18, Gether Cameau began collecting tolls at the BrooklynBattery Tunnel.

title: Mondale Scolds Congress for Lack Of Energy Progress Before Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Vice President Mondale rebuked Congress today for beginning its monthlong August recess without making adequate progress on President Carter's proposed energy legislation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Wednesday reported incorrectly that a Federal district judge had fined a newspaper publisher, John McGoff, $10,000 for failing to answer questions about the source of funds for Mr. McGoff's purchase of The Sacramento Union. The fine was levied against the Sacramento Publishing Company, solely owned by Mr. McGoff through another corporation, and the Detroit law firm of Miller, Canfield, Paddock and Stone.

title: U.S. Unit, at Babi Yar, Stunned by Soviet Silence on Jews
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Aug. 3  A United States Presidential commission charged with drawing up plans for an American memorial to the Holocaust laid a wreath of carnations today at the monument at Babi Yar, on the edge of Kiev, where Nazi troops machinegunned more than 70,000 Jews over a 1 fldav npriod in 1941 morning morning the Americans climbed the upsweep of stone toward a monument erected by the Soviet Union in 1976 that depicts men, women and children at the point of being shot. The plaque, in Ukrainian, reads: Here, from 1941 to 1943, the German fascist invaders shot and killed more than 100,000 citizens of Kiev. From the visitors came exclamations of disbelief: Not a word about the Jews!

title: $500,000 IS STOLEN AT BANKERS TRUST
description: Four neatly dressed men talked their way into a Manhattan bank vault yesterday and quietly escaped with more than $500,000  the most cash ever stolen from a New York City bank  and five and a half hours later another bank robber wounded a plainclothes policeman and then was shot and captured by the officer's partner.

title: Music: Alicia de Larrocha Plays Mostly Mozart
description: Whenever an artist gains the degree of public acceptance that is now accorded Alicia de Larrocha in New York, the temptation is to utter the faintly praising words cult figure. But cults are in their nature peripheral, faddish and transitory; a cult that survives long enough can come to be known as a religion. So, one may almost say that there now is developing in New York not so much an audience for the Spanish pianist as a congregation, one that has grown steadily in devotion over the last 15 years. Her recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night in the Mostly Mozart Festival offered fresh testimony to the grip of this slight, determinedly reticent musician.

title: Jets to Divide Passing Duties
description: His other pass, too. Robinson, though, was intercepted once and was 0 for 2.

title: Memorial Service Held For Ennio Bolognini,85
description: A memorial service was held in Las Vegas yesterday for'Ennio Bolognini, cellist who died Tuesday at the age of 85. Mr. Bolognini had lived there for about 20 years.

title: I Carter Rates High in IsraeliPoll
description: TEL AVIV, Aug 3 (Reuter)  President Carter is more popular in Israel than in his own country, according to an opinion poll published today. The poll in the Inuepenuent (laity tiaaretz sata 41.1 percent of those questioned were satisfied with Mr. Carter's attitude toward Israel, 32.2 percent were more or less satisfied, and 20.8 percent were dissatisfied.

title: HAROLD M'CLELLAN; PAINT CONCERN HEAD
description: Harold C. McClellan, a millionaire California paint manufacturer and former Assistant Secretary of Commerce, died Thursday at the Eisenhower Medical Center near his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The staterun radio said millions of Iranians voted today in the first nationwide election since the overthrow of the Shah. Twenty political groups boycotted the voting, charging that it was neither free nor fair.

title: News Summary
description: Britain's recognition of Zimbabwe Rhodesia and its removal of sanctions might not be forthcoming unless the Salisbury. Constitution is amended, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher indicated in a speech at a meeting of Commonwealth leaders in Lusaka, Zambia. Mrs. Thatcher said that it is clearly wrong that the Government of Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa should not have adequate control over certain senior appointments. She also said it was a valid criticism that the Constitution under which Bishop Muzorewa rules was defective in certain important respects. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Campuses Astir Over Playboy's Ivy Issue
description: At the Dartmouth College library, Playboy magazine was in such demand this week that the librarians lent it out for only two hours at a time and checked carefully each time it was returned, to see whether any pages were missing.

title: As for Lemons Better Buy Limes
description: It's a sour time for lemons. Prices have hit a record high of 50 cents each, and even when shoppers are willing to pay the price, the quality is decidedly low. Most lemons currently found in New York area markets are thickskinned, blemished and unbecomingly puckered. And growers predict that the shortage, the result of last winter's freeze in California lemon groves, will last through the summer.

title: Gas Squeeze Spurs Fish Hobby
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 3  Nancy Cowell felt the gasoline shortage in a way few others did. Her store, Aquarium Designs, could no longer keep siphons in stock because motorists kept buying them to use with gasoline. But, later, Mrs. Cowell noticed another result: her aquariums started selling out, too.

title: Conflict Found In the Reports On Baden Talk
description: An official in the Corporation Counsel's office said yesterday that he had found conflicting statements about the content of the lecture Dr. Michael M. Baden gave at Lenox Hill Hospital last February. The lecture was said to be a key factor in his dismissal earlier this week as Chief Medical Examiner.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 3  State Police reported that a search of the woods in Burlington, Conn., during the last two days had turned up no evidence in the murder of 12yearold Katherine Ebersold last Friday night.

title: Deaths
description: REDLERJoseph. Beloved husband of Bessie. Devoted father of Abraham Redler and Jenne Hirshan. Adored grandfather. Services Sunday. 12 Neon, Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Carter Son Won't Seek Election
description: CALHOUN, Ga., Aug. 3 (AP)  Presi. dent Carter's eldest son, Jack, said today that he had decided against running for Congress from Georgia's Seventh District. He said he had decided not to becorhe a candidate because it would nut a DIUGen on Ms tamity and take him away from his grain business here. Mr. Carter., who is 31 years old, filed papers with the Federal Election Commission last month registering as a candidate and setting up a campaign committee.

title: South Bronx Cleanup Gets Helping Hands from Georgia Students
description: College students, members of the North Peachtree Baptist Church of Atlanta, working with residents yesterday to clean up a vacant lot on 179th Street and Honeywell Avenue in the South Bronx. The effort is partof a renovation project sponsored by Bronx Shepard's Restoration Corp., a group of 79 ministers formed after the cancellation of the Charlotte Street Project, and nanced by state's Neighborhood Preservation program.

title: Expos Rally to Sink Mets, 106
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 3  The Mets, entrenched in last place in the National League East, started tonight's game against the Montreal Expos, the division leaders, as if the two teams posi: tions were reversed.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A thin layer of clouds extends along the Atlantic Coast from New England to the Middle Atlantic States. Areas of cloudiness are also visible in the upper lake region, the Intermountain Region and through the Texas Panhandle. Skies are clear across the western half of the country.

title: Bolivian Military Threatens to Stay Unless Presidency Deadlock Ends
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 3  Bolivia's political leaders negotiated urgently under threat of military intervention today to break a deadlock in Congress over election of a civilian president.

title: Cabaret: Rosalie Sorrels's Folk
description: Rosalie Sorrels, who ended a threenight run at Kenny's Castaways Thursday night, is an enormously talented folk singer who has never made it in the commercial sense. Partly. that may be because she's older and not so stereotypically pretty as the average young female pop singer  she left Boise, Idaho, a decade ago only after having had five children.

title: Jazz: Jay McShann and the Sound of Kansas City
description: Michael's Pub, which has usually built its programs around the works of individual pop songwriters in recent years, has reverted to a straight jazz policy for this month. Jay McShann. me KansaS City, Mo., pianist and singer, is at the East 55th Street restaurant with Franklin Skeets on bass and Oliver Jackson on drums filling the room with the musical aura of Kansas City when it was a colorful jazz seedbed in the 1920's and 30's.

title: Former Syrian General Is Named To Succeed a Slain P.L.O. Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 3 (AP)  A former Syrian Air Force general, Mohammed Azzam, has been named to succeed Zuheir Mohsen, the slain Palestinian guerrilla leader, it was reported here today.

McCall and another owner of The New York Amsterdam News are attempting to remove the publisher of the weekly newspaper, John Procope, because they contend that insurance contracts held by his wife's company with the City of New York have seriously compromised the integrity of the paper.

description: TOKYO, Aug. 3  The Tokyo stock market hit a record high of 6,356 on the Dow Jones average today amid predictions by political analysts that general elections will be held in Japan late next month or in October.

title: Deaths

title: Opera: Schat's Houdin With Unplanned Twist
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 3  As befits an opera on the life of Harry Houdini, the unexpected happened. Just as the work, which was receiving its American premiere at the Aspen Music Festival, came to an end, there was a blackout. It was part of the show. But the lights never came on again. A main fuse had gone. Stagehands hurried forth with flashlights. An auto was moved to the rear of the tent, and its headlights threw some illumination toward the stage. Those in the audience with their own flashlights helped out. Suddenly the night was full of a thousand eyes. The cast and the composer, Peter Schat, took their applause  and enthusiastic applause it was  mostly in the Colorado dark, flashlights bobbing on and off their faces. It was not a planned effect, but it added to the fun.

title: The Hired Man: Vanishing American
description: CLARENCE, Iowa, July 31  Darryl DenHartog, a tall, quiet fellow, works on a farm. He feeds hogs. He fixes fences. He breeds sows and helps with their litters. He harvests oats and corn.

title: Mattiace Posts Upset
description: WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 3Bob Mattiace, the I7yearold member of, an allgolfing family from Jericho, L.I., took on some older competition today and enjoyed some surprising success. He knocked the medalist out of the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship at Mountain Ridge Country Club.

title: Months of Talk, Then News Leak, Led to Koch's Shuffle
description: Nathan Leventhal was sitting on the back porch of Allen G. Schwartz summer home in Rye, N.Y., last Saturday afternoon when Mayor Koch turned to him and said he was prepared to make sweeping changes in the city government.

title: Ralph Mayer, Expert On Paint Technology, Teacher and Writer
description: Ralph Mayer, a leading authority in the field of paint technology as well as an artist, teacher and writer, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Britain Urges Changes In Rhodesia's Charter.
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 3  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain hinted in a speech here today that her Government would not recognize Zimbabwe Rhodesia or lift sanctions against it unless its Constitution was amended.

title: JOBLESS RATE IN U.S. UP SLIGHTLY IN JULY, TO 5.7% FROM 5.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The nation's unemployment rate held essentially stable in July, rising a tenth of a percentage point to 5.7 percent of the work force.

title: Emirates Seek Development Controls
description: ABU DHABI  In spite of their oil wealth and one of the highest per capita incomes in the world, $11,667 a year, the United Arab Emirates are experiencing an economic slowdown that planners believe makes clear the urgent need for greater coordination of development plans  something that may not come easily to a Government in the throes of political change.

title: SIOUX WINS $300,000 IN RIGHTS VIOLATION
description: NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Aug. 3 (AP) A Federal jury awarded $300,000 yesterday to an Oglala Sioux woman who charged that the city of Gordon, Neb., and one of its police officers had violated her civil rights.

title: C.A.B. Denies Rise To Four Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board re. jected today the requests of four airlines for a 5.2 percent fare increase.

title: Cabaret: Eddie Kirkland
description: The new blues series at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, is already proving its worth by bringing in artists who are heard in New York all too infrequently. Robert Pete Williams, Willie Guy Rainey and Roosevelt Sykes are scheduled to appear this month and next, and Otis Rush, whose Tramps appearances last month yielded some of the best music he's ever made in New York, will return. On Friday and Saturday, Eddie Kirkland was at Tramps, giving local blues fans the opportunity to investigate in greater depth the work of a musician who literally stopped the show at the Palladium two years ago and then more or less vanished into the night.

title: Nobody to Talk to Now
description: Across the field from the Yankees on their weekend of grief, the Baltimore Orioles groped for reasons, too. And Ken Singleton remembered Thurman Munson in a simple workaday way: I'll miss him when I come up to bat. I'll have nobody to talk to now.

title: He Chose Songs Instead of the Sky

Initially, the former seemed a more responsible choice, but ultimately he chose a musicial career as more consistent with his changing world view.

title: Courville, Zahringer Gain Met Golf Final
description: WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 4 Jerry Courville opened another of his many long days of tournament golf by chipping his ball into the cup for a winning birdie 3 at the first hole at the Mountain Ridge Country Club today. He finished 33 holes and eight hours later with a winning par 4 on the last hole that enabled him to reach the final of the 77th annual Metropolitan amateur championship.

Mr. Rockefeller's will. however, rave most of his art collection to museums. Two questions remained unanswered:

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Yet so it was, or so it appeared to be, last week within the Carter Administration. On July 12, in a forecast intended for public distribUtion as part of their regular midyear economic review, the Administration's chief economists forecast an unemployment rate of 6.9 percent by the fall of 1980.

title: Going Westhampton, My Friends? Good!
description: HERE I am, living in a coed group house in East Hampton, with two pools, a Jacuzzi, a private rock garden, a membership in a respectable racauet club, knowledge of the secret routes to bypass summer traffic on Montauk Highway, the ability to crash George Plimpton's parties  yet something is wrong. This summer, the single crowd has disappeared from East Hampton and moved spiritually, as well as geographically, to Westhampton, creating the most important shift in the summer life of New York singles in two decades.

title: ANTIQUES OneStop Antiquing on the Rise
description: GLASTONBURY THE good old days, when one went antiquing and enjoyed a leisurely drive from town to town and shop to shop, are over. Dealers who last year depended on sales to dropin buyers and summer tourists report that ever since Iran curtailed the export of petroleum, there has been a noticeable slump in shop volume.

title: Wine
description: Fronting on Route 14 in Glenora, N.Y., it could be a roadside restaurant. Trucks roar by all day and tourists stream in and out of the parking lot. In fact, it is Glenora Wine cellars, one of New York's newest and most attractive wiremaking facilities. Located in this hamlet on the west shore of Seneca Lake, about 19 miles north of Watkins Glen, the winery is perched on a high slope with a spectacular view of vineyards and the lake. I never tire of looking at the view, says John Williams, Glenora's 27yearold winemaker.

title: Police Are Tracing Knife Believed Used in Slaying

title: Suarez Leaves on Latin Tour
description: MADRID, Aug. 4 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez left for Rio de Janeiro today on the first official visit to Brazil by a Spanish head of government. Mr. Suarez will also visit Ecuador and the Dominican Republic during his nineday Latin American tour.

title: Iran Hotel to Become Hospital
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 (Reuters) A luxury hotel near the ruins of the ancient Persian capital of Persepolis is to be turned into a hospital for drug addicts, the newspaper Ayandegan reported. The I78room Dariush Hotel, which is owned by the national airlines, Iran Air, has been almost empty since the February revolution because the flow of tourists has dropped to a trickle.

title: A Jazzman Comes Into His Own
description: Bob Wilber was one of a number of young musicians who came into jazz in the mid1940's, swimming against the tide. These were musicians who had grown up enthralled by Louis Armstrong, Bix Beiderbecke, Benny Goodman and the jazz style that preceded World War II. But when it came time for them to enter the jazz world, the music had taken a radical turn. Bebop was the way to go for young jazz man. Youngsters such as Mr. Wilber were out of step with their contemporaries. They seemed to be looking to the past instead of to the future.

title: China Charges Vietnam Gunfire

Any of last spring's promising flowers will wilt and fade when exposed to the searing summer sun. And the gardener may find the most pleasant course is to lie back in a hammock in the shade and forget it all. A few pointers may make life easier for both.

title: Injuries Are A Way Of Life
description: In March 1978, early into a performance of Mikhail Baryshnikov's new ballet, Don Quixote, Martine van Hamel, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, slipped and landed on the floor with a crash. Thinking she had only banged herself, she continued to dance. All of a sudden I did one very large movement, she recalled, and the leg went out. There was no support. Soon afterward the curtain was brought down and Miss van Hamel  who says they never really did find out what happened to her leg  began a monthlong recuperation back to the barre and ultimately to the stage.

In Giacomo Meyerbeer's grand opera Le Prophete, there is a ballet sequence danced by what are meant to be ice skaters. In fact, the ballet was inserted at the opera's first performance in 1849 to capitalize on the thennew fashion for roller skating. title: Yes, 'sesame Street
description: Last month, half the world, it seemed, cheered when Big Bird, the perennially cheerful, 7-foot-tall, yellowfeathered mascot of Sesame Street visited China; yet, few people took notice of the death that same week of an educator who. had waged a long campaign against the show's unique style of teaching-by-entertaining. Dorothy Cohen, who believed that the quickcut, fastpaced action format of the children's program and its abrupt switches from humans to puppets to animation did as much harm as good to its young viewers, died in Manhattan. Not a single obituary was published to mark her passing or recall her work. Nor did many people know that

title: Abercrombie Sets Record In Pace at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug.  The fastest mile in the history of harness racing was paced today by Abercrombie at the Meadowlands track. The pacer was clocked for the mile in 1:53, onefifth of a second faster than the previous mark, set by Warm Breeze.

title: Nostalgia in a SmokeFilled Room
description: THE retirement of Jack Zaiman as political reporter of The Hartford Courant for 42 years is worthy of reflection and comment. Mr. Zaiman was the premier reporter of the Connecticut political scene from 1937 to 1979. By virtue of his reporting, he was so identified with development of political events during those, years as to be himself almost political figure. Surely nobody kept informed'of those events without reading his columns and his news stories.

title: Film: Peter Brook on Russian Mystic:New Musical Booked at Goodspeed House
description: In "Meetings With Remarkable Men," Peter Brook's slow and very deliberate film about the early years of the Russian mystic G.I. Gurdjieff, Mr. Brook has chosen neither to represent Gurdjieff as a fully developed character nor to delve very deeply into the nature of his thought. Instead, he concentrates on the visible details of Gurdjieff's search for enlightenment. So the film depicts a great many places the young Gurdjieff visited, events he witnessed, wise men who advised him and rare parchments he happened upon.But Mr. Brook's presentation of this is so solemn, so evidently lacking the joyful guiding spirit of such a search, that his film feels flat. Watching this handsome, affectless effort feels a little like receiving a series of puzzling picture postcards in the mail, each one beautiful but missing a message on the back. The effect is perhaps more mysterious than it means to be.Though Gurdjieff is played vigorously enough by Dragan Maksimovic (Mikica Dimitrijevic briefly portrays the writer as a boy at the beginning of the film), his is not a performance that can do justice to the material. It can't be: it's surrounded by too much deadly seriousness on all sides. Mr. Brook, with a superb eye for pretty compositions but no interest in continuity at all, simply leaps from one portentous episode to the next, with an abruptness that will either leave viewers bewildered or send them back to Gurdjieff's own writings, depending upon the extent of their interest. Certainly "Meetings With Remarkable Men" is a film that requires supplementary energy, whether it comes from the curiosity or the prior knowledge that the right audience may provide.When the writer finally arrives at the remote religious community he has been seeking, "Meetings With Remarkable Men"  which opens today at Cinema 3  becomes unexpectedly vigorous. This is because in large part of some sacred dances that have been "brought" (according to the credits) to the film by Jeanne de Salzmann, the late Gurdjieff's 80-year-old trusted disciple and former aide. These brief sequences are exquisite, filled with the ecstasy and perfect discipline that the rest of the film so sorely lacks.

title: Writing a Life of Shaw
description: FOR someone who tended to belittle the usefulness of biography, George Bernard Shaw helped an astonishing number of biographies of himself into print. The best known were produced by writers he knew and with whom he collaborated extensively. My own copy of Hesketh Pearson's famous Life has been signed by Pearson himself, and below this signature Shaw has modestly added: Also his humble collaborator G. Bernard Shaw. Pearson frankly admitted the scope and nature of Shaw's coauthorship to the extent of inviting his subject to share the title page with him  an invitation that Shaw very properly refused. Other biographers receiving similar help preferred to be more reticent. The manuscript collections of Shaw's papers, particularly those at Chapel Hill, N.C., Austin, Tex., and Cambridge, Mass. reveal in what considerable detail he liked to interfere with his Lives.

title: Two Venturesome Plays at The Warehouse in London
description: LONDON The material is so strong that we can almost smell it; there is a Gauloise pungency in the air. In her search for a woman as heroine, Pam Gems, a British playwright, has uncovered Edith Piaf. Her dramatic portrait Piaf is so abrasive that it seems as if it were written on sandpaper. To a certain ex- tent, Piaf reminds one of Julian Barry's Lenny. Each is episodic and chaotic, and uses language that is vulgar in the extreme  an approach that is apparently as true to Piaf as it was to Lenny Brute. Like Lenny, Piaf scorches its subject with a whitehot spotlight. In both cases, we are eyewitnesses as a kind of genius careens toward suicide.

title: Whose Butter Will Pay for the Guns?
description: The debate over SALT II has shifted lately to the question of how much to increase real defense spending. Vague defense budgets are flying about that would rise by some definitesounding percentage over some indefinite period of time. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and the Joint Chiefs of Staff are demanding commitments to 4 or 5 percent real growth. Former Secretary of State Kissinger thinks the right number may be closer to 5 than 3. Secretary of State Vance has described 3 percent as essential but is not sure that 5 percent is necessary. The President has already promised 3 percent to NATO.

title: A Correction

title: Music Notes: How to Train Conductors
description: Where the next generations of musicians are to come from is most problematic in the field of conductors. Their development depends on an association with too many other people to make it simple. As has been pointed out time and again, the problem has been solved in Europe with the multitude of opera houses. There a budding baton wielder begins as a rehearsal accompanist, learns through observation and experience the ins and outs of operatic production and, if he has any talent, moves into actual conducting. Since the opera orchestras normally give concerts, too, he learns the symphonic repertory at the same time.

title: The Issue Is Blackmail
description: Here is your Independence Day present, said King Khalid on or about July 4 as he promised Jimmy Carter an extra million barrels of Saudi oil each day this summer until the gas lines disappeared. The President has repeated the remark, apparently unembarrassed by its trim humor. He has also recalled his gratitude because other oil nations were then threatening to withhold fuel if Canada moved its embassy Israel to Jerusalem (it didn't) or if Britain lifted sanctions against Rhodesia (it didn't). Yet Mr. Carter denies having said anything more than Thank you the Saudi king.

It drives us crazy, says David W. Wallace, chairman and president of the Bangor Punta Corporation, which acquired Piper last year. We keep them up more because of good will than anything else.

And Before the Cock Crows is no exception. Seen Friday in the first of six performances (weekends through Aug. 18) at the Performing Garage, the 1978 piece draws its inspiration from the New Testament story of the betrayal of Jesus, and, although ritualistic rather than religious in nature, does create an almost animalistic sense of erief and loss.

Yesterday's incident involved an Eastern Air Lines jet bound for New York.

description: BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 5 (UPI) Stuart Stiller, a Washington lawyer who represented John D. Ehrlichman, the former White House aide, during the Watergate appeals, died yesterday from injuries suffered in a traffic accidebt, the police said.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) President Carter said today that he took time during his recent visit to South Korea to do some religious missionary work aimed at President Park Chung Hee, discussing the Christian faith with the Korean leader.

description: In the West Farms section of the Bronx, where vacant lots and condemned buildings are common sights, 63 Youth Conservation Corps workers are rebuilding the heavily eroded east bank of the Bronx River.

title: Around the Nation
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 5 (UPI)  Lightning struck a storage tank at a Gulf Oil Company refinery today, igniting more than 800,000 gallons of gasoline. About 200 firefighters fought the blaze, which company spokesman said had caused more than $1 million in damage.

title: Notes on People
description: When the rejection notices start coming, sometimes there's no stopping them, and the latest people to say no to Jane Fonda are medical students at the Davis campus of the University of California. Miss Fonda, you'll recall, had her nomination to the State Arts Council turned down a few weeks ago by the California Senate. Now she's been taken out of the running as a possible commencement speaker next June at the Davis medical school.

title: Amy Elizabeth Meller, Textile Executive, Bride of Thomas Kurt Gerbe in Chappaqua
description: Amy ElLes th Medlar and Thomas Kurt Gerbe were married yesterday afternoon in the garden at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Greene of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred D. Moore of the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua and Rabbi Abraham Klausner of Temple EmanuEl in Yonkers officiated.

title: Brian Keith Creates a New Da
description: URING two recent weeks, the cast of Da, that haunting, haunted Irish drama of fa- thers and sons, performed on stage at the Morosco Theater 16 times each week. Only half those performances were for the audiences that had come to see the redoubtable Barnard Hughes in the title role before he left New York to head a road company. The other appearances were in fact rehearsals with the actor who last week replaced Mr. Hughes: Brian Keith.

title: Dance: Simone Forti Performs Umi Aui Owe
description: THE phrase umi aui owe is a colloquial expression in the Austrian Alps for over there, up, down, according to program notes for a dance of the same name by Simone Forti, seen Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden in the closing program of a monthlong series devoted to postmodern dance, organized by the School for Movement Research. The program will be repeated independently at the Sculpture Garden, however, Aug. 31 and Sept. 1. And Umi Aui Owe was wellnamed, for it explored the garden as it has probably never before been explored.

title: France Is Said to Soften Tough Steel Revival Plan
description: THIONVILLE, France  This country's Prime Minister, Raymond Barre, has won himself quite a reputation as a fearless defender of free enterprise this year, chiefly as a champion of returning the nation's ailing steel industry to a competitive position, whatever the political risks.

title: O'Neill Center Aids TV Writers
description: WATERFORD, Conn. THE Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's New Drama for Television project is four years old and has become the nation's best known and most important program for deVeloping writers for television. Its approach is basically simple: the center chooses four men and women from among the cream of America's playwriting crop, invites them here for the month of July and then hantmetS, chops, grinds and caresses them into television playwrights.

title: 50 Miles to the Gallon
description: When the thenSecretary of Transportation, Brock Adams, called last winter for Government to force American auto makers to double the fuel efficiency of their cars in the 1990's, economists lined up to sneer. Meeting existing requirements that the car companies conform to a 27.5 mile-per-gallon standard by 1985 would be hard enough, they argued. Setting even higher standards would raise the average cost of a car by thousands of dollars and further punish an industry already shaken by Government safety and pollution controls. Decisions about what kinds of cars are produced, it was said, should be left to consumers in competitive marketplace.

title: Divers Hampered Trying to Free Engine in Ship That Sank in 1858
description: PARADISE, Mich., Aug. 5 (AP) Awkward working space hampered efforts by divers yesterday to free the engine from the sunken 131yearold freighter Indiana, which sank in Lake Superior in 1858.

title: Dumped Hooker Pesticides Poisoned Wells on Coast

description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Monday, Aug. 6 The deadlock over the election of a new Bolivian President reportedly found a solution early today with the compromise choice of a provisional leader.

title: The Baden Affair
description: The bitterness that has burst forth over who should be New York City's Chief Medical Examiner is exceeded only by the confusion. Even New Yorkers possessing delicate political seismographs would have had trouble detecting the rumblings that must have presaged Mayor Koch's removal of Dr. Michael Baden only a day before the end of his oneyear probationary period. The Mayor acted at the urgent request of District Attorney Morgenthau and Health Commissioner Ferrer. Both criticized Dr. Baden for poor judgment, lack of cooperation and rudeness, buttressing their complaints with instances of alleged misbehavior. Dr. Baden has responded with impassioned denials.

title: More Signs Of Slump

The Conference Board, a business research group, reported that its helpwanted advertising index had dropped for the sixth consecutive month in June. The index dropped to 153 for the month, a point below the May level. The indicator, which stood at 100 in 1967, lost 12 points over the first half of 1979.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Whistler and His Noise
description: Somebody kept whistling, tunelessly, outside my apartment window the other day and it got me thinking about why so many people in New York bother other people with their music. The high buildings along the street create a sort of amphitheater and the whistle echoed in the canyon. It went on and off, on and off; intermittent noises are the worst kind. I kept looking out the window for the whistler. Could it be someone indoors, next to an open window? Someone very lonely? A child? Hardly a child; the whistler's lips knew the broken pieces of too many old records. It had to be a person who knew exactly what the canyon was doing to his sound; someone was taking pleasure in its amplification. Perhaps there was pleasure too in driving people crazy.

title: Associated Press
description: OIL SLICK NEARS TEXAS COAST: A Coast Guard ship towed barrier yesterday across part of the Brazos Santiago Pass near the mouth of the Rio Grande River on the south Texas coast. The barriers were placed in an at- tempt to protect area from an oil slick that is now within 10 miles of the coast. The slick is from a Mexican oil well that has been spilling about one million gallons of crude oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico since it blew out June 3d.

title: Grandaddy, Why He Never Heard Of Such a Thing! Gas at 15 Cents A Gallon! For Upkeep of Roads! What Was Alabama Coming To? It sure is something!
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  My Granddaddy, Bub Able, was quite a fellow in his day. I remember him well as storekeeper on the highway south of Birmingham, sitting in the back beyond the great hoop of rat cheese and the Garrett snuff advertisements. He and his friends sat next to the old potbellied stove in the wintertime when glowed red from the heat of a burning coal. They sat back in the cool darkness in the summertime, slowly playing checkers or dominoes, and now and then selling something. Mostly, they talked.

title: Concert: Schuller Dea By Tanglewood Groups
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 6  The 1979 Festival of Contemporary Music got under way over the weekend with three concerts of new or recent works, mostly ingeniously designed, but mostly lacking in individuality or flavor. However, as to illustrate that careful design and inspiration do not have to be mutually exclusive, the weekend's most ingeniously conceived work, Gunther Schuller's Deal, also turned out to be the most noteworthy piece so far. The festival, now in its 16th season, is presented by the'Berkshire Music Center in cooperation with the Fromm Music Foundation at Harvard.

title: 106 Jailed Protesters Give No Name
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Aug. 6  Of the 225 antinuclear protesters arrested for trespassing yesterday at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point power plant, 106 remained in the Westchester County jail today after refusing to identify themselves to authorities.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO MAINTAIN COURSE ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  President Carter, swearing in a new Secretary of the Treasury and chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today, vowed to continue his economic policies as all three men gave gloomy assessments of the scope of the problems facing the nation.

title: Technicon To Be Sold To Revlon
description: The Technicon Corporation, which was founded 40 years ago with $5,000 and three employees to make a diagnostic device for doctors, will be sold to Revlon Inc., the beauty and healthcare products company, for $18 a share in cash or stock, or nearly $400 million, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Trial of Newton Gets Under Way; Newly Named Judge Is Presiding
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP)  The retrial of the Black Panther leader Huey Newton, accused of fatally shooting teenage prostitute five years ago, got under way today as a judge began hearing defense motions.

title: Doors on Heaters Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The Jackes Evans Manufacturing Company, a St. Louis manufacturer, is recalling glass doors on about 1,000 woodburning heaters because the glass can break and allow sparks to fly out, a Government agency announced today. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said that no injuries had been attributed to the doors on the product.

title: Archeologists Begin Dig for the Monitor
description: AT SEA OFF CAPE HATTERAS, N.C., Aug. 4 Twohundredandtwenty feet down in some the most treacherous waters on earth, a diver slowly passes a sand vacuum back and forth across the encrusted hulk of an ancient wreck.

title: MUZOREWA AFFIRMS POSITIVE ELEMENTS OF RHODESIAN PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 6  The Prime Minister of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Abel T. Muzorewa, responded today to a new peace plan from the Commonwealth with a statement welcoming what he called its positive elements. He demanded substantial clarification of some of the points, but indicated outright opposition to only one provision, the call for a new round of Britishsupervised elections.

title: Carter Should Resign
description: TIBURON, Calif.  James Earl Carter  who calls himself Jimmy and has finally convinced his countrymen that they must accept him at his own selfdiminishing evaluation should resign the Presidency of the United States of America.

title: AAR Raises Share In Brooks & Perkins
description: Brooks & Perkins Inc. said it had received a copy of an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicating that the AAR Corporation had acquired additional shares of its stock, increasing its interest to 7.9 percent.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Broadway Opry 79, a countrymusic festival that opened July 27 at the St. James Theater, closed on Thursday with a show featuring Waylon Jennings, the Crickets and the Waylors.

title: 1,200 Policemen at Slain Officer's Memorial Service
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Aug. 6  More than 1,200 policemen, from precincts throughout New York City and representing departments from as far away as Fallsburgh, N.Y., attended a memorial service here today for a policeman shot to death at a softball game in Brooklyn last week.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1979

title: IN THE NATION
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  In five years, declares a mainland American long resident In Puerto Rico and active in Its politics, the trend on this island is to be strongly toward independence.

title: Florida Governor Pursues JaiAlai Investigations
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 6 (AP)  Gov. Bob Graham ordered Dade County State Attorney Janet Reno today to coordinate several investigations into allegations of gamefixing at Florida iaialai frontons.

title: LEON KAHN
description: Leon Kahn, founder and president of the Northeastern Securities Company, an investment concern, died Saturday at the St. Barnabas Medical Center, in Livingston, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: The Region
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Fourteen gasoline stations in Stamford, Greenwich, Darien, New Canaan and Norwalk began selling gasohol yesterday morning, according to Wayne Konitshek, president of the Connectictut Gasoline Retailers Association.

title: Aladdin Casino Ordered Shut
description: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 6 (AP)  The Nevada Gaming Commission voted 50 today to close down the casino at the scandalridden Aladdin Hotel on the Las Vegas Strip. And within minutes, state agents sealed the club.

title: Foreign Stake in Farms Defended by Bergland
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 6 (Reuters) Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland today listed Canadians, West Germans and the Dutch as the biggest foreign investors in United States farmland and denied that such investments posed threat to the nation's security.

title: Carter Sends a Message Supporting Mrs. Thatcher on Rhodesia Accord
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 6  President Carter has sent a message to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain supporting the Commonwealth peace plan for Zimbabwe Rhodesia approved here last night.

title: Taxes
description: MANY taxpayers who itemize deductions like to see how their deductions stack up against those of taxpayers in similar economic circumstances. Although the latest figures, based on 1977 returns, may make interesting reading, bear in mind that they are simply the average amounts deducted by individuals in different income brackets.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: City Newsstands Act to End Decline
description: Angelo Barilla can usually tell, by the ring of the coins dropping on a metal tray, if he's been paid enough for the newspapers he sells from a sparse aluminum sidewalk booth in Rockefeller Center.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1979

title: Ohio Ballet Will Offer Its Own Chamber Look
description: THE stage of the Ted Shawn Theater at Jacob's Pillow might most generously be described as the size of two postage stamps. Twelve dancers and most or a piano wait be tucked onto that stage, however, when the Ohio Ballet takes up a week's residence tonight at the summer dance festival in Becket, Mass.

title: A Top Carter Adviser, in Newark, Urges Support for Urban Aid Plan
description: NEWARK, Aug. 6  The President's chief adviser on domestic affairs, Stuart E. Eizenstat, making his first visit to a major city to see Government programs in operation, today urged passage of the President's urbanaid program, saying that the longterm future of America is in its urban areas.

title: COMMODITIES Silver Down 20 Limit; Gold and Platinum Drop
description: Prices of silver futures plunged the daily permissible limit of 20 cents an ounce shortly after the opening of trading on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday and remained locked there throughout the session. The break in silver exerted heavy pressure on gold futures.

title: EDUCATION
description: IF you want to get ahead, get an education. For generations, that maxim has gone unchallenged. But in recent years, as college graduates have had an increasingly difficult time finding jobs of their choice, the value of postsecondary education has come under question. A growing number of people have asked if college is worth the time, money and effort.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TURIN, Italy, Aug. 6  Five world recordholders, including Sebastian Coe of Britain, head a strong European team of 19 women and 24 men from 14 countries named today to represent Europe in World Cup II track and field meet at Montreal's Olympic Stadium Aug. 2426.

title: Stage: Gerald Freedman Directs The Tempest
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 The Tempest is Shakespeare's most supernatural play. With its magical island, storms that subside at a nod from Prospero, and characters that are as evanescent as air, it is a work that is open to a director's imagination. It is a palette for directoraspainter.

title: VW Holds Talks With East Bloc
description: BONN, Aug. 6  Volkswagenwerk A.G. said today that it was negotiating with the East Bloc about possible licensing agreements that, among other things, might replace the aging Soviet Moskwitsch car with the VW Dasher.

title: Royals Get 11 in 7th, Beat Blue Jays, 1612
description: TORONTO, Aug. 6 (AP)  An 11run seventh inning, which featured George Brett driving in four runs and scoring one and Fred Patek driving in three and scoring one, powered the Kansas City Royals to a wild 1612 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight.

title: G.&W. Unit Extends And Doubles Loan
description: Associates Corporation of North America, a wholly owned subsidiary of Gulf and Western, said it had extended and doubled its sevenyear revolving and term loan facility to $300 million with a group of 24 banks. Merrill Lynch

title: Aerospace and Takeover Issues Lead Market to Moderate Gain
description: The stock market finished moderately higher in slow trading yesterday with the aerospace group and several takeover issues attracting most of the attention.

title: 40,000YearOld Bison Offers Clues to Climate
description: FAIRBANKS, ALASKA GOLD MINERS working the frozen ground near here have sluiced out a partially fleshed body of a bison that is estimated to be 20,000 to 40,000 years old.

title: N.H.L. Rules New Players Now Must Wear Helmets
description: TORONTO, Aug. 6 (AP)  National Hockey League players who signed pro contracts after June 1, 1979 will have to wear helmets next season. Players who signed before then and who sign a waiver will be allowed to play without helmets.

title: Study Examines Children's Attitudes Toward Smoking
description: Like father like son, like mother like daughter. Even if those combinations are scrambled, the chances are that if the parent of a young child smokes, the child is likely to do so in the future.

title: Key Dates in Rhodesia Dispute
description: Following are some of the crucial developments that preceded yesterday's decision by the Commonwealth to back a new plan aimed at ending the guerrilla war in Zimbabwe Rhodesia:

title: Lester Grieb, Former Executive With Several Banks, Dies at 71
description: Lester F. Grieb, a former vice president of the State National Bank of Connecticut in Bridgeport, died Saturday at his home in Norwalk, Conn., following a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Air Force Altering Ban On Wearing of Beards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The Air Force has changed its regulations to allow chaplains in the reserves to wear beards for religious reasons.

title: Man Sought in Officer's Slaying Arrested at Manhattan Terminal
description: The man sought in the murder of an Essex County, NJ., policeman last weekend was arrested in the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan as he got off a bus at about 1:10 A.M. today, the Port Authority police said.

title: Pittsburgh National Lifts Seldon Holding
description: Pittsburgh National Bank said it had increased its holding in Seldon & Associates of Sydney, Australia, from 20 percent to 50 percent through its wholly owned subsidiary, the Pittsburgh International Finance Corporation.

title: Earphones Stir a Dispute in Murder Trial of Doctor
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 6  As spectators and reporters at the firstdegree murder trial of Dr. Jeffrey R. MacDonald fidgeted and whispered their speculations, the judge, jurors, defendant, attorneys, clerks, marshals and secretaries accepted thick typewritten transcripts and plastic earphones and sat listening this afternoon as a reeltoreel tape recorder played for more than an hour.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: A Wheat Deal Worth the Price
description: The announcement that the Russians would be allowed to buy another 2 million metric tons of American wheat raises unsettling memories of the 1972 wheat deal. That sale seriously depleted American stocks, led to rapid food price rises and accelerated the inflation of 19745. Now, the Agriculture Department seeks to understate the inflationary impact. It estimates that this 2 million tons will add only one cent to the cost of a loaf of bread. But a penny on this sale and a penny on that add up to billions of dollars. Big wheat sales are bound to cause some inflation and it would be illusory to pretend otherwise.

title: U.S. Increasing Aid to Nicaragua
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The State Department said today that emergency food aid for Nicaragua would be substantially increased and would average at least 150 tons a day for the next two weeks.

title: Murcer Drives In 5 As Yanks Win, 54
description: Completing a grueling, emotion racked four days, the Yankees returned somberly froM from Thurman Munson's funeral in Ohio and rallied last night at Yankee Stadium for a 59 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. Bobby Murder, one of two Yankee players who eulogized Munson, drove in all five runs.

title: Deaths
description: POTOFSKYJacob Samuel. The Officers. Directors and Staff Of the United Housing Foundation record . with profound sorrow the passing of their distinguished Chairmen d the Board. Jacob S. Potofsky. His entire life was dedicated to improving sodefy and to the welfare and wellbeing of people throughout the world. Through his leadership roles In the Trade union and cooperative movements, his accomplistments were monumental. He was ere of the pioneers in the developrnent of low cost cooperative housing more than a half a century ago. He was a man of peace and principles. His honors were many; none perhaps more revealing than when he placed high, with many other distinguished Americans, on the infamous White House enemies list In 1970. Mr. Potofsky's dedication and wise counsel will be sorely missed by cooperatives and trade unions. His winsome spirit will be missed by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to his devoted and gracious wife. Blanche, and his family.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Market Place
description: WHEN should one take a flyer on officeequipment stocks selling at high priceearnings ratios?

title: At Managua's Busy Market, Business Is Up and the Prices Down
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 6 Business was brisk today at Managua's Eastern Market, As crush of people and smells and colors and sounds heightened because of the lack of supplies elsewhere in this slowly recovering city.

title: Parley on Palestinian Rule Opens in Disagreement
description: HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  A new round of talks on Palestinian autonomy opened today in sharp disagreement, with one Israel official saying that the United States was taking a position even tougher than that of Egypt.

title: Law Firms Drop Shyness and Use A Publicity Man
description: In a departure from the traditional shyness of large law firms, three New York firms have recently retained Howard Rubenstein, a lawyer turned publicrelations consultant.

title: SindonaMissing; Suspect in Fraud AtFranklin Bank
description: Michele Sindona, an Italian financier facing extensive fraud charges involving control of the Franklin National Bank, is missing and may have been kidnapped, his lawyer said yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Relax, Nicaragua Isn't Cuba
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica  The final victory of the Sandinist movement over the Somoza dictatorship in the Nicaragua marked the emergence of the first great LatinAmerican revolution  social, economic, political and military  in 20 years. The previous great upheaval in the hemisphere was, of course, the Cuban Revolution in 1959. But let us beware of easy (and hysterical) analogies or conventionalwisdom conclusions.

title: Around the Nation
description: DALLAS, Aug. 6 (AP)  A Federal judge today sentenced Billie Sol Estes, the former west Texas promoter, to 10 years in prison for concealing assets from the Internal Revenue Service and for scheming to defraud investors.

title: Afghan Regime Reports Its Control Over Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  Afghanistan's Moscowbacked Government reported it was in complete control of the capital city of Kabul today after using the full force of its newlyacquired Soviet arms to crush a mutiny.

title: Jersey Senate Passes Bill to Raise Casino Profits Tax to Aid Elderly
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6  The New Jersey Senate gave final passage today to a bill that would increase temporarily the tax on gamblingcasino profits and apply the proceeds to a lifeline program that would help some elderly persons pay their heating bills this winter.

title: Refinery Prompts Classic Battle of Energy vs. Ecology
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Aug. 6  For nearly five years the fight has raged, swaying first this way, then that. At stake is an oil refinery on the banks of the Chesapeake Bay that would be the first major one to be built on the gasthirsty East Coast in a quarter of a century.

title: Advertising
description: UNLIKELY as it may seem, about $1 billion of available advertising money is lying around ignored.

title: Treasury Halts Study Of Assay Unit Gold Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The Treasury Department said today that it had closed its investigation of the Government's Assay Office in New York, leaving unsolved the disappearance of some 4,100 ounces of gold.

title: EARNINGS Boeing's Net Surges 55%
description: Reflecting the demand for its commercial jet airliners, secondquarter net income of the Boeing Company climbed 55 percent to $120.1 million, or $1.87 a share, from $77.5 million, or $1.21 a share, in the similar three months last year, the company reported yesterday.

title: Science Watch
description: An American astronomer has reported evidence that some galaxies may be cannibals, swallowing up nearby galaxies and thereby casting doubt on some generally accepted theories of how galaxies are born.

title: JOHN COVENEY DIES; RECORD EXECUTIVE
description: John Coveney, director of artist relations for Angel Records and a close friend of such musicians as Maria Callas, Beverly Sills, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Leontyne Price and Carlo Maria Giulini, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: U.S. Judge Rebuffs Bell On Iran Fee
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a request by American Bell Internationai Inc. for an injunction barring Iran from collecting the balance of a $38.8 million down payment that the former Government of the Shah had made to American Bell.

title: Pacific Gas Rate Filing;
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said today that it had filed for a $180.2 million annual gas rate increase to help offset a 22 percent price rise for natural gas from Canada. Canada supplies about half of the company's natural gas.

title: Apes Share Humans Awareness Of Self
description: MAN likes to imagine himself at the top of some evolutionary hierarchy, possessing certain skills that are far beyond the capacity of other animals. That sense of superiority has been shaken in recent years with the awareness that man is not alone in the ability to acquire language chimpanzees can do it, too, within limits

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Aug. 6, 1979

title: Thomas E. Murray 2d, Stockbroker, Dies at 52
description: Thomas Edward Murray 2d, a NeW York stockbroker, died in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital Saturday after he was pulled from rough surf off Southampton where he had been swimming. The cause of his death has not been determined. He was 52 years old and had summered in Southampton for many years.

title: Music: An Array To Dazzle the Ear
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 6Does any music festival in the United States have the sheer spread of the Aspen Music Festival?

title: Research on Male Pikk Intensifies
description: RESEARCH to find a safe, convenient male contraceptive has intensified recently, with some forms of the new contraceptives already in limited use. The study of birth control pills for men has begun in this country, and it is probable, given the pace of the current research, that a male contraceptive pill will be aviailable at the corner drugstore within the next few years. But that is a prospect that does not cause universal rejoicing, in part because of the possibility of side effects such as those encountered with female contraceptives.

title: Here Comes King, Giants New Left Tackle
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 6 Ready or not  and he says he's not quite  Gordon King is the Giants starting left tackle, the only thing standing between the Harvey Martins of the National Football League and whoever turns out to be the team's quarterback.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter vowed that the Administration would hold its course on economic policy. He said he was determined to maintain a responsible monetary policy and a.sound and conservative budget policy. His spoke at a swearingin ceremony for G. William Miller as Secretary of the Treasury and Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Miller, whom the President named the Administration's chief economic spokesman, said, We have inherited the most distressing economic environment in 50 years. [Page A1.]

title: Palm Beach Wardrobe Grows
description: The Palm Beach Company, long identified with men's summer suits, has developed into a highly diversified producer of men's, women's and boys clothing under 32 separate brands. Last week, it added the 33d when it acquired the 109yearold Haspel Brothers Company, a New Orleansbased producer of men's and women's lightweight, washable clothing.

title: Pan Am Employee Accused of Stealing Jet Devices
description: A 35yearold maintenance supervisor for Pan American World Airways was ac.cured by Federal authorities yesterday of having stolen nearly $3 million worth of electronic aviation equipment from the airline, including seven computerized navigation devices used in flying Boeing 747 jumbo jets.

title: Notes on People
description: Back in the late 1960's, one of the more persistent rumors that no one could ever verify was that Jerry Mothers had been killed in Vietnam. The reason no one could verify it was simple enough. It wasn't true.

title: Consumers Cut Back Credit Use
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) American consumers, apparently uneasy about inflation and the talk of a recession, sharply reduced their borrowing and loan payments in June, the Government reported today.

title: About Education
description: JEFFERSONVILLE. VT. THE nation's public school leadership last week was given a disquieting glimpse into the future. The chief state school officers, at their annual institute, were warned that they should expect the following:

title: Tribes Tap Iranian's Fuel Expertise
description: DENVER  A group of American Indians, seeking to develop their mineral resources to best advantage, have turned to the Middle East for expertise, hiring Iran's former Deputy Minister for Finance and Oil.

title: U.S. Plans Farm Cooperatives to Aid Impoverished Rural Areas in South
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 A program to develop new farming cooperatives in the South among owners of small tracts of land and sharecroppers, most of them black, has been started by the Agriculture Department.

title: Text of Commonwealth Accord
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 6 (UPI )  Following is the text of the Zimbabwe Rhodesia agreement approved yesterday by members of the Commonwealth:

title: House Panel's Decision On Renter Tax Aid Due
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)  The House Ways and Means Committee is expected to decide whether or not to ask tax relief for, renters when Congress returns from its August recess, it was disclosed today.

title: Brock Calls Carter Trips Political; White Says They're Presidential
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The photographs of Jimmy Carter sprawled atop the Presidential limousine, shaking hands with some of the 7,000 townspeople who engulfed him last Tuesday in Bardstown, Ky., had a clear meaning to Bill Brock, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: G.O.P. Assails New Charter Plan For C.I.A. as Totally Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)  The Republican National Committee today criticized a proposed new charter for the Central Intelligence Agency as totally inadequate and urged the drafters to go back to the drawing board.

title: Deaths
description: HOCHSTEIN  Abraham, Beloved husband of Rebecca, devoted father of Allen. Stephen, Laurana and Karen. adored grandfather and dear brother. Services 2:15 PM Schwartz Bros. Forest Park Chapels Queens Blvd and 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Fotomat Corporation, a major but slumping concern in the photofinishing field, announced yesterday that the gasoline shortage was seriously affecting its earnings and that Konishiroku Photo Industries of Japan had agreed to invest $12.3 million in Fotomat.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Increase
description: Yields on Treasury bills rose yesterday in the weekly auction in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: The Doctor's World
description: THREEYEAROLD Bill is in the emergency room with a fever of 102 degrees. He has nausea and is confused. His neck is stiff. When the doctor flexes the boy's neck, Bill's knees and hips also flex in what is known as a positive Brudzinski's sign. He does another test called Kernig's. It is positive.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shorwn.(N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 6  Four of the country's topranked teams, recovering from narrow escapes from defeat last night, began play here today in the semifinal stage of the Spingold team championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: NEW YORK PETITIONS FOR RECALL REJECTED; KOCH WAS A TARGET
description: Petitions aimed at putting a recall provision into the City Charter  a move started by critics of Mayor Koch  were ruled yesterday to be far short of the requisite number of signatures.

title: About New York
description: Sometimes the contrast between the city's poor and its latest me generation seems nothing less than Dickensian. A young citizen on one block can grow boutiqueweary searching out the right shade or shape of furnishing for an expensive converted loft. On another block, city people counted in the alarming statistical ghetto of the young unemployed stand and wait and watch their time run on.

title: Two Posing as Officers Get $140,000 in Gold In Brooklyn Hijacking;
description: Two men posing as police officers and driving a car with a revolving red light on the roof hijacked a van on a heavily traveled Brooklyn street yesterday and took two boxes containing $140,000 in gold wire destined for local jewelry manufacturers.

title: Hundreds at Funeral Of YankeesMunson
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 6  More than 500 people, including all Yankee team members and many of their wives, attended Thurman Munson's funeral today in the Canton Civic Center: About 1,000 other people waited outside to pay their last respects, and hundreds more lined the fivemile route to the Sunset Hills Cemetery, where Munson was buried.

title: U.S. Seeks Bar To Eastern Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)  The Justice Department called today for rejection of a proposal by Eastern Air Lines to buy National Airlines, saying it would reduce competition on New YorkWashingtonFlorida routes.

title: 80Mile Oil Slick Is Reported as Tar Balls Wash Onto Beaches of Texas
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Aug. (UPI)  Scientists sighted an 80mile sheen of oil extending from the mouth of the Rio Grande into the Gulf of Mexico today, as ,tar balls washed onto Texas beaches 50 miles to the north, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Slaying Suspect Held Fit for Trial
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Aug. 6 (UPI)  A judge ruled today that Joseph J. Fischer, who has told the police he killed 19 people in a yearlong, acrossthecountry spree, is competent to stand trial in the slaying of his 79yearold wife.

title: Bolivia's Senate Leader is Elected Interim President, Ending Impasse
description: LA PAZ, Aug. 6  The Bolivian Congress tonight elected Walter Guevara Arze as provisional President, ending a deadlock over the choice of a successor to the ruling military Junta.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1979

title: The City
description: A fire that killed two elderly women and heavily damaged a building in the Bronx yesterday was listed as arson, authorities said.

title: Orantes Advances In ClayCourt Tennis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP)Manuel Orantes of Spain, the threetime winner who is recovering from an elbow injury, called his play terrible, but he battled from behind twice today to prevail in the first round of the $275,000 United States claycourt tennis tournament.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STEP RIGHT IN A late afternoon music recital today near Lincoln Center might be called a fringe benefit. The free program takes place directly across the street from the main entrance to Lincoln Center Plaza at the Schirmer Music Store, 40 West 62d Street, and the twohour concert features a pianist and a woodwind trio. The performers are all members of the WNCN Sidewalk Classics series.

title: Study of Nationalizing Oil Is Urged by A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6  The United States should seriously consider nationalizing its oil industry, the A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council said today, unless the industry, in the council's terms, alters its practices and serves the public interest more adequately.

title: New. L.I. Philharmonic Signs Christopher Keene
description: Christopher Keene, the 32yearold American conductor, has been named music director of the newly formed Long Island Phlharrnonic, which has announced a series of 10 events for the 197980 season. The orchestra will play its first concert on Nov. 17 at a site to be announced, and three programs will be given one performance each in Hauppauge, Huntington and Hempstead in the late winter and spring of 1980.

title: Entertainment Events
description: OTHELLO, by William Shakespeare; directed by Wilford Leach; cast Includes Raul Julia. Frances Conroy, Richard Drefuss; presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp, producer. At the Delacorte Theater, West 81st Street, 8.

title: Builder of DC10 Was Delegated To Pass on Design, Hearing Told
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6  The Federal Aviation Administration delegated responsibility for approving almost all structural design of McDonnell Douglas DC10 jumbo jets to the company's own engineers, an agency specialist testified today at a hearing on the nation's worst air disaster.

title: Communication Pact For China and I.T.T.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 6 (AP)  China and the International Telephone and Telegraph. Corporation have reached an agreement in Peking on the repair of communication facilities in Chinese coastal cities, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: Candy? Roses? In Washington They Send Balloons
description: WASHINGTON  Instead of sending chocolates to celebrate birthdays, anniversaries and promotions, or roses to cheer up a sick friend, some people in Washington are now opting for a bouquet of balloons.

title: Federal Energy Cionservation Effort Is Called Inadequate by Auditors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  While President Carter is urging the nation to save energy, auditors for the General Services Administration have found that the Government's own program to conserve energy in Federal buildings is infrequent, inadequate and poorly organized.

title: 2 Casinos Report Winnings for July
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 6 (AP)The Boardwalk's two casinos won an average of $1.14 million a day in July and Resorts International Inc. said the month was its best ever.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production fell to 2.627 million tons in the week ended Aug. 4, a decrease of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.653 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: Snakes in the Gardens of Eden
description: EDEN, N.Y. (AP)  Residents of this town in southern Erie County have been warned of poisonous snakes in local creeks and ponds following the third case of a person being bitten by a snake in two weeks. The third incident occurred

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTMurray, M.D. Beloved husband of Roslyn. devoted father of Andrienne Albert Brecher, dear brother of Seymour M. Albert, M.D. and Robert Albert. Services Wednesday 2PM at Nassau North Chapels', SS North Station Plaza (app. RR station), Great Neck, LI.

title: The Commonwealth Plan for Rhodesia: Promise and Peril
description: News Analysis

title: 2 Jets Succeed Without Trying
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 6  Without punting or kicking a football in game action this year Chuck Ramsey and Pat Leahy of the Jets were assured of their starting jobs today.

title: President as Missionary
description: Nowhere is the line dividing church and state more sensitive than in diplomacy and President Carter leaves us wondering why, by his own account, he seems to have breached it during his visit to South Korea this summer. The President told an adult Bible class Sunday that he had preached the virtues of Christianity to his Buddhist counterpart and host, President Park Chung Hee. Evidently Mr. Carter and a Korean religious leader who solicited his help felt that the South Korean President, whose regime has been charged with, frequent human rights violations, could use some Western religion.

title: Assad Reassures Iraqis That Syria Had No Hand in Attempted Coup
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6  President Hafez alAssad of Syria has assured Iraq's new President, Saddam Hussein, that Damascus was not behind an alleged conspiracy against the Baghdad regime, according to Damascus sources close to the President.

title: Vietnam Cancels Visit By American Delegation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Vietnam today canceled a scheduled visit by nineman delegation from the House of Representatives, led by Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens.

title: OBSERVER Battlers Of the Dew
description: Manhattan police believe that Leo Korbutsky melted last Wednesday night on Columbus Avenue. Dental examination of the bridgework found in a warm puddle that also contained Korbutsky's suit, shirt, necktie, socks. shoes, underwear, eyeglasses, wrist watch, Phi Beta Kappa key and driver's license seems to support the conclusion.

title: West burne Posts Loss Due to Operations in Iran
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 6 (AP) Westburne International Industries, the Canadian oil and gas drilling and construction company, said today it recorded a loss of $8.8 million in Canadian funds in the first fiscal quarter because it had been unable to remove costly equipment from Iran or collect bills since the Iranian revolution.

title: Japan's ForeignCar Sales
description: TOKYO, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  Japanese sales of imported vehicles, mostly cars, rose 13 percent in July from the yearearlier month, to 5,500 units, the Japanese Automobile Importers Association said. The July total comprised 2,800 largesized vehicles, mainly from the United States, up 17 percent from a year earlier, and 2,700 small vehicles, mostly from Europe, up 9 percent.

title: Woman Found Slain in Chelsea
description: The body of a 30yearold woman who had been strangled and shot was found in an apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan at 7:20 last evening. The police said the woman, Elizabeth Lake, who lived alone in the apartment at 410 West 23d Street, had had her hands tied in front of her. She had been gagged, strangled and shot in the head several times. The pilice said they thought the killing might be related to drugs.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has named John C. Marous, 54 years old, to the new position of presidentinternational. He will also become a member of the company's policymaking management committee.

title: House Inflation Unit Warns on Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  A House budget panel issued a 37point proposal today designed to counteract inflation and cautioned against any tax cut unless unemployment rose sharply.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Express International Corporation, Stamford, Conn., engaged in international airfreight forwarding, has appointed Arthur M. Stephenson vice president and general manager for North America.

title: Dorothy Naiman, 70, a Professor Of Physiology at Lehman College
description: Dorothy Naiman, professor emeritus of biological sciences at Lehman College and a longtime resident of Teaneck, N.J., died Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif., following openheart surgery. She was 70 years old.

title: Pipeline Open 2 Years, Alaska Awash in Oil Money
description: ANCHORAGE. Aug. 3  A decade after the Prudhoe Bay oil field revolutionized life in Alaska and two years after the transAlaska pipeline system loaded the first tanker at Valdez, this state's government is rolling in oil money.

title: Ballet: Natalia Bessmertnova in 'swan
description: IT was a highly romantic Swan Lake that Natalia Bessmertnova and her new prince, Aleksandr Bogatyrev, offered with the Bolshol Ballet at the New York State Theater on Sunday afternoon. Substituting for the indisposed Ludmila Semenyaka, Miss Bessmertnova bettered an already fine OdetteOdile of the night before with an even more outstanding performance.

title: Filming of Cruising Goes More Calmly
description: EARLY one morning last week a fifthfloor walkup in an apartment house on Waverly Place, just off Bank Street in Greenwich Village, became the scene of a murder.

title: Deaths
description: POTOFSKYJacob S. We mourn the loss of an outstanding American labor leader, who after many, many years of exceptional service to the garment workers, became Sidney Hillman's assistant when the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America was founded and subsequently, when he was elected President of that union. His life and soul were dedicated to his union and his name will be permanently enshrined in the annals of the history of the American labor movement. For many decades he was In the forefront of leadership and rendered exemplary support to Histadrut and the people of Israel. The Jacob S. Potofsky Clinic In Bled Brak, established In cooperation with Histadrut, was dedicated in his honor by his union and will forever stand as a perpetual symbol of Mr. Potofskys compassionate humanitarianism and abiding concern for the stale of Israel. His will ever be cherished by the HI adrut movement in Israel and America.
