We extend our sympathy to the bereaved family and to the officers and members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers

title: Books of The Times
description: IGUESS I was attracted to Eleanor Coppola's Notes because of the film whose production the book purports to explore. And I wasn't disappointed. Even without having seen Francis Coppola's abouttobereleased Apocalypse Now, I couldn't help being intrigued by the vivid behindthescenes picture .Mrs. Coppola draws of her husband's struggle to film an updated version of Joseph Conrad's The Heart of Darkness, in which Vietnam is substituted for Africa and the Green Beret played by Marion Brando takes the place of mad Mr. Kurtz.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Does it save electricity to turn off an incandescent lamp, a radio or TV set when its use is interrupted for justa few minutes?

title: Tomjanovich Trial Starts
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The trial involving damage suits by Rudy Tomjanovich and the Houston Rockets, with a list of witnesses resembling an allstar basketball lineup, began in a Federal court today with the selection of a sixmember jury.

title: State Argues for a Redesignation To Release 20 Acres for Westway
description: State transportation officials said yesterday that 20 acres of tidal wetlands earmarked for the West Side Highway Project should never have been designated as wetlands and were not entitled to the special protection they now receive under environmental laws.

title: Deaths
description: DAVISDaniel A. Of Charlottesville, Virginia. Formerly of N.Y.C. Died August 4, 1979. He leaves his wife Alicia Davis, two sons Daniel A. Davis Jr. and Michael Hamilton Davis and four grandchildren. Memorial services were held at First Presbyterian Church, Charlottesville, Virginia on August 6th.

title: Deaths
description: POTOFSKYJacob S. Beloved husband of Lydia Blanche, father of Delta and Jacqueline, also survived by four grandthildren and three greatgrandthildren. The family will receive friends Wednesday. August 8th, from 6 to 9 PM. The Riverside 76th St. anSAmstertiam Ave. Funeral services will be held Thursday, August 9th, at 11 AM at the Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68th St. NYC. in lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Cancer Society.

title: Storms Fell Power Lines In New York's Suburbs
description: Severe thunderstorms provided a respite from a muggy 90degree afternoon yesterday at the price of darkened houses and silenced telephones for thousands in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Carter and Strauss Tell Begin of Desire to Ease Strains
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  President Carter and his special Middle East negotiator, Robert S. Strauss, have both assured Prime Minister Menachem Begin personally that they want to ease the tensions with Israel that have arisen recently.

title: Science Library
description: By Harold E. Edgerton and James R. KiUia Jr. 178 Pages. MIT Press. $20.

title: Bethlehem Sets Layoffs, Citing Slow Steel Orders
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 6  In one of the first cutbacks and layoffs resulting from the slowdown in steel orders, Lewis J. Foy, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said in an interview today that the company would shut down one of its older blast furnaces and two openhearth furnaces at its huge Sparrows Point plant in Baltimore.

title: In the Summertime, The Celebrated Find Ordinary Fun
San Franciscans Stunned as Quake, Worst in 68 Years, Strikes the City
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  The earth rolled, buildings swayed, and for a long moment San Francisco held its breath today as it waited out the area's strongest earthquake in more than 68 years.

title: 14YearOld Arias Wins 21andUnder Tennis
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 6 Jimmy Arias of Grand Island, N.Y., who had little expectation of getting past the round of 16 here, completed a weeklong effort yesterday by winning the United States Tennis Association 21yearsandunder tournament at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: Elegant Game of Chance Begins at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6  A year ago this week, a yearling son of Nijinsky was sold here for a Saratoga record of $800.000.

title: Interim Choice Named to Post At City College
description: The Board of Trustees of the City University of New York yesterday named Dr. Alice Chandler, the provost of City College, as the acting president of the college, effective Sept. 1.

title: U.S. PLANS INCREASE IN EUROPE'S MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The Carter Administration has presented a proposal to allied governments calling for the deployment in Western Europe of several hundred nucleararmed missiles capable of reaching Soviet territory, Government officials said today.

title: Carey Invites Officials Of Britain and Ireland To Meeting on Ulster
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that he had invited representatives of the British and Irish Governments to meet in New York in an effort to bring peace to Northern Ireland.

title: Books: Spying on the Sea
description: HERE is a welltold story, a novel that handles with knowledge and a good sense of narrative the naval warfare of World War I, the diplomatic

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Government securities prices rose slightly yesterday following last week's rally that was highlighted by surprisingly strong demand for the Treasury's threepart, $7.25 billion financing.

title: Sohio Tender Expires
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (Reuters) The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said its offer to buy 1.7 million of its own common shares had expired and appeared to be oversubscribed. The company, majorityowned by the British Petroleum Company, said it would announce an estimate of the number of shares tendered as soon as possible.

title: HANOI ASSERTS TIES WITH U.S. WERE SET
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 3  Vietnam's Acting Foreign Minister said in an interview this week that his Government and the United States reached full agreement on normalizing their relations during secret talks in New York last fall, but that the Carter Administration did not follow through on the agreement.

title: Survey Says Only Five of New TV Series Are Likely to Succeed
description: HOLLYWOOD (AP), Aug. 6  Perhaps as few as five new series will emerge as hits in the fall television season, according to an analysis by major advertising agency.

title: Dance Music: Machito
description: WATCHING Machito and his orchestra play, for the dancers at Roseland is an education. Machito is best Known outside the ,Latin music community as the bandleader who worked with Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie and helped create AfroCuban jazz, beginning in the 1940's. He has continued to work with Mr. Gillespie and, in tact, he'll be backing the trumpeter at the Monterrey Jazz Festival next month. But throughout his career, Machito, whose real name is Frank Grillo, has played mostly for dancing, and one suspects this continuing connection is a source of his band's rhythmic strength.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1979

title: Egyptian and Israeli Officers In Sinai Act Like Old Chums
description: CHECKPOINT 206, Sinai  A dusty Israeli Army jeep pulled up to this lonely Egyptian outpost in the desert and two Israeli captains stepped out.

title: New Wage Guideline Is Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The Carter Administration is planning to change its wage guidelines, which now ask that increases not exceed 7 percent a year, to a twoyear standard of about 15 percent, Government officials reported today.

title: From Galanos: Variations On a TwoTone Theme
description: Not everyone is crazy aboutolives  or caviar either, for that matter. So it is perfectly understandable that not every woman will go berserk for clothes by James Galanos. They are, for many, an acquired taste. The best of their breed, you might say, except there isn't any breed. He stands alone.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: The Man In the White Shirt
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 6  Outside the modern orangebrick Civic Center, the sympathetic and the curious were waiting for a glimpse of the Yankees and the other baseball celebrities who had come to Thurman Munson's funeral. Inside, in the McKinley Room, a framed color photo of the late Yankee captain in his pinstriped uniform was above the white chrysanthemums draped over the silvergray coffin. To each side, a vigil candle flickered. More than 200 floral displays bloomed against the wide maroon drapes and along a side wall. And as the family and friends waited for the Yankees to arrive, somebody said, The man over there in the white shirt, that's Thurman's father.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Aug. 6  Three deserters from the Spanish Foreign Legion surrendered peacefully to the police after flying here today in a hijacked DC9 of the Spanish airline Iberia.

title: Union Voting on TVFilm Strike
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 6 (AP)  Entertainmentindustry union locals were sent strike ballots yesterday, after contract negotiations with motionpicture and television producers broke down. About 50,000 members of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees could go on strike as early as next month if no agreement is reached with the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers.

title: Thomas Takes Jersey Golf
description: WARREN, N.J., Aug. 6  Jeff Thomas defeated Chris Cross of Tamarack, 3 and 2, in the final of the New Jersey Public Links Golf Championship yesterday at the 6,462yard Warrenbrook Country Club.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Aide Resigns
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 6 (AP)  Paul Weiner resigned today as a member of the Public Utilities Control Authority, Goy. Ella T. Grasso's office announced. According to a spokesman for the Governor, Mr. Weiner's letter of resignation said he wanted to return to his job as a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut. The 52yearold Democrat joined the fivemember authority in June 1978.

title: Better Ways to Cut Taxes
description: Most economists, in Government and out, are now sure the economy has entered a recession. National output fell at an annual rate of 3.3 percent in April, May and June. And the White House has circulated a confidential memo predicting that unemployment will climb to 8.2 percent over the next year.

title: U.S. Delays Action on Tariff Concessions to China
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The United States has informed China that on the advice of Congressional leaders it is delaying until later this year the sending of legislation to Capitol Hill that would give tariff concessions to Peking, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Letter: On Rent Stabilization
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTMurray, M.D. Beloved husband of Roslyn, devoted father of Andrienne Albert Srecher, dear brother of Seymour M. Albert, M.D. and Robert Albert. Services Wednesday 2PM at Nassau North Chapels, SS North Station Plaza (opp. R R station), Great Neck, LI.

title: Pentagon Chief Backs Circular Track Bases for MX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown has approved a detailed plan for basing the Air Force's new MX mobile missile, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Dow Rises In Best Gain Since May
description: The stock market scored its best advance in almost three months yesterday, with the blue. chip and glamour issues posting the biggest gains.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Aug. 7, 1979 Chapter XI Petition for SP Airattgetgent Filled by:

title: Oil Output Rose After Criticism
description: Three major American oil companies Teported yesterday that production of refined products showed substantial increases last month. The rises came after the Department of Energy criticised the pace of crude.oil refining as sluggish.

title: Farmers Shaken by Poison Case
description: DETROIT, Aug. 7 (UPI)  Depression and guilt feelings plague farmers affected by Michigan's PBB contamination episode, the first psychological study performed on victims of the toxic fire retardant has concluded.

title: Errors by Koch's Reported Choice As Medical Examiner Cited in Trial
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Aug. 7  The prosecutor and chief defense attorney in a murder trial that went to the jury here today said that important evidence in the case had been lost through errors by Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the forensic pathologist who is reportedly Mayor Koch's choice to be Chief Medical Examiner in New York City.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Piano Sonata No. 4, Haydn; La Vida Breve, Fala; The Turk in Italy, Overture, Rossini; Annenpolka, J. Strauss, Jr..

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration acknowledged that the unexpected surge ininflation had created problems in extending its wageprice guidelines: But Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and FriceStability, said the oncoming recession should make the prograin work better by checking both wage and price increases. He said slack markets already were developing in raw materials, which should aid enforcement of new price standards. [Page D1.]

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bose Corporation, Framingham, Mass., a manufacturer of audio products, has named Peter V. Ferguson advertising director.

title: News of the Theater
description: MIA FARROW, a familiar face to British theatergoers, last appeared on the New York stage in an Off Broadway production 16 years ago. She is coming back here in the fall this time for her Broadway debut. She will costar with Anthony Perkins in Bernard Slade's new play, Romantic Comedy, opening Nov. 8 at the Barrymore.

title: TV: 2 Comedies Search For Classroom Laughs
description: IT'S always a pleasure to see two such accomplished farceurs as Dorothy Loudon and Russell Nype, and especially so on television, which is, as they say, a long way from Broadway, but one wishes it were in a stronger vehicle than Dorothy.

title: Hispanic Influx Moving U.S. Closer to Bilingualism
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 7  As increasing numbers of immigrants from Latin America flow across its borders in search of a better life, the United States for the first time is giving recognition to a second language and, in the view of many, encouraging its sustained use.

title: Going out Guide
description: FRANCK AND FRIENDS The other sultry night Columbus Avenue was filled with strollers in light attire. Sidewalk cafe tables were thronged, from the postconcert sitters at the large Cantina, opposite Lincoln Center, up the avenue past Ruskay's and other al fresco spots. Suddenly there was Serenade, one of those New York surprises for walkers  a new restaurant with live music at 79th Street, around the bend from the American Museum of Natural History. Up here the avenue scene becomes more sedate.

title: Market Place
description: NUCLEAR energy, once a growth industry, is now withering on the vine. But one company that just now appears to be sprouting is Brooks & Perkins Inc., a diversified manufacturer of material movement and storage systems, including poison boxes, or modules to store used nuclear fuel.

title: Coast Quake Was Surprise Despite Intense Monitoring
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Aug. 7  Although seismologists have been able to predict some recent earthquakes, yesterday's temblor in northern California came without warning, scientists at the United States Geological Survey said today.

title: U.S. Yachts First, Second In 4th Admiral's Cup Race
description: COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 7Americans finished first and second today in the fourth race in the Admiral's Cup, a biennial gathering of the world's best ocean racing yachts.

title: Entertainment Events
description: HOLIDAY ON ICE, presented by Irvin Feld and Kenneth Feid, starring Peggy Fleming, Madison Square Garden, 7:30.

title: Viguerie Quits Crane Campaign; Joins Connally Staff as Volunteer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)  Richard A. Viguerie, who has run many successful fundraising efforts for various conservative causes and candidates, has joined the campaign of John B. Connally, a Republican Presidential hopeful, as a volunteer, it was announced today.

title: U.S. Tells Macchiarola to Screen Teacher Tests for Discrimination
description: The Federal Government has warned School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola that before any new teachers are hired this fall, all current teacher examinations must be analyzed to determine they discriminate against candidates on the basis of race or sex.

title: Q&A
description: Q.While reading a British novel recently, I noticed a reference to a dessert or so mething served at tea time called angeli on horseback. Are you familiar with this food?

title: Disappearance of Italian Financier Indicted in Fraud Is Still a Mystery
description: Michele Sindona, an Italian finanCier charged with a multimilliondollar fraud involving the Franklin National Bank, remained officially listed yesterday as a missing person.

title: Sands of Time Run Out on the Desert Fox
description: HE'S like an old dog. He knovis what's coming,and what's coming is. that he's going. AcCordingly he's, showing signs of snappish senility, like jumping into Reverse when you think you've started him in. Park. But, skewedlooking though he is, with his driver's door permanently jammed partly open and roped to his body, in these days of monstrous gas prices the Desert Fox still gets 16 miles to the gallon. I will be sorry to see him go.

title: Times Elects 2 Officers
description: The New York Times Company elected two new vice presidents yesterday. David L. Gorham, 46 years old, who joined the Times Company in 1974 as corporate controller, was named a vice president. He continues as controller. Joseph A. Riggs Jr., 46, was appointed vice president, operations, of The New York Times. He joined The Times in 1976 and became director of operations last year.

title: Lamson Sets Itel Deal
description: Lamson & Sessions said yesterday that it had reached.an agreement with the Itel Corporation to purchase most of the assets of Itel Rail Car Inc., the rail car manufacturing subsidiary of Itel.

title: Five Centuries of Cutlery
description: LONDON Five centuries of table manners come under scrutiny in an exhibition sponsored here by the Worshipful Company of Cutlers, the ancient London craftsmen's guild. The small but finely honed exhibition, which will be at the Victoria and Albert Museum through Aug. 26, uses cutlery from the late Middle Ages to the present to show changes in the art of eating.

title: NuclearPower Opponents Continuing Protest in Court
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y. Aug. 7More than half of the 106 antinuclear protesters arraigned in Village Court here today on charges of trespassing at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point power plant refused to give their names and were returned to the Westchester County Jail pending a hearing on Monday.

title: AlliedEltra Deal
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N.J, Aug. 7 (Reuters) The Allied Chemical Corporation said today that it had received 93 percent of the shares of the Eltra Company under its tender offer, and it had extended the offer of $51.50 a share until 5 P.M. on Aug. 15 from Aug. 6.

title: N.H.L. Tour for Russians
description: TORONTO, Aug. 7 (AP)  Two Soviet hockey teams, the Red Army squad and the Moscow Dynamo, will play nine games against National Hockey League opponents this season. The announcement was made today as the N.H.L. Players Association concluded two days of meetings with the N.H.L. owners.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1979

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Of obvious concern to Nick A. Caporella, president and chief executive officer of Burnup & Sims Inc. are reports that his company may be a takeover target of Victor Posner.

title: RHODESIAN CABINET WEIGHS LUSAKA PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 7  Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith. whose attitude is likely to be crucial to the success of the Commonwealth peace plan, said today that the Lusaka conference that produced the plan was characterized by an overabundance of hot air.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Council Supports Strategic Arms Treaty
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7  The executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. today announced its support of the treaty with the Soviet Union to limit strategic nuclear arms. But it conditioned its support on formal stipulations by the Senate that the nation modernize its strategic forces and that in negotiating the next such treaty the United States set a deadline for establishing whether future talks represented a genuine effort toward arms reduction.

title: Personal Health
description: TOM SAWYER and Huck Finn went to the cemetery at midnight and swung a dead cat around their heads. A Minne sota grandmother rubbed chalk on her skin and then on the underside of the stove top and waited for the mark to disappear. Francis Bacon had his skin rubbed with bacon, which was then hung outside to rot. In the first century. Pliny the Elder advised Romans to touch their skin with peas, then wrap the peas in a cloth and throw them away.

title: Oil Reaches Texas Shore, Raising Fear Along Gulf
description: PORT ISABEL, Tex., Aug. 7 (AP) Patchy oil slicks and tarry globs of crude as big as baseballs washed onto the white resort beaches of south Texas today, and scientists said that history's worst oil spill could defile the Gulf Coast of the United States all the way to Florida.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 (Reuters)The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its 100,000barreladay refinery in Antwerp, Belgium, to the Coastal States Gas Corporation for more than $25 million.

title: About Real Estate Reducing Losses on Commercial Property in Hard Times
description: When a commercial property becomes distressed, that is, under severe financial strain, drastic remedies may be invoked and a tenant in the building may not be worth two prospects on the street.

title: Burger King in Orient
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 7, (Reuters)The Burger King Corporation expanded into the Far East today with the opening of its first restaurant in this British colony.

title: Jackson, on China Visit, Supports Trade Accord
description: PEKING, Aug. 7 (UPI)  China should be granted mostfavorednation status in trade with the United States, regardless of whether the Soviet Union qualifies for it, Senator Henry M. Jackson said today.

title: Around the Nation
description: MACON, Ga., Aug. 7 (AP)  Despite denials by hospital officials, a Bibb County prosecutor says he has independent corroboration that a saboteur lurked in the intensivecare ward of Macon hospital and caused the deaths of three or four patients.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although it by no means runs pristine from its source to the sea, the continuing and growing vitality of the Connecticut River is nicely demonstrated by the variety of fish captured and released at the Holyoke (Mass.) Water Power Company's fishlift operation at the Holyoke Dam.

title: Mike Curtis, 36, Cut by Redskins
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP)  The Washington Redskins continued their youth movement today by cutting Mike Curtis, a veteran linebacker.

title: CITY TO GET U.S. AID ON SUBWAY STATIONS
description: New York City will receive $10 million from the Federal Government to restore the Grand Central Terminal subway complex and expects to receive $22 million more to renovate the subway stations at Herald Square and at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: DR. MARIO FONTANA
description: ROME, Aug. 7 (AP)  Dr. Mario Fontana, longtime physician of Pope Paul VI, died at his home here last night, one year to the day after the Pontiff's death. He was 75 years old. Friends said he suffered a stroke Saturday.

title: DC10 Maker Links Tooling Problem to Shim Use
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7  An official of the company that builds the DC10 jumbo jet said today that a problem with production tooling was responsible for the tiny gap that required the installation of a controversial gapfiller in an engine mount of the plane that crashed here May 25.

title: Best Buys
description: YOU'RE traveling. The surroundings are unfamiliar: The bed is lumpy, the room is too cold, the faucet leaks. All could be forgiven, if only you could awaken to a fresh cup of your favorite coffee or a mild, flowerscented herbal tea. Instead, you call room service and pay $1 or more, plus tip, for a cup of odoriferous mud.

title: Times Mirror Net Up 5.8%
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 (AP)  The Times Mirror Company said today that strong gains by its newspaper publishing group helped lift its secondquarter earnings by 5.8 percent. Revenues rose by 10.3 percent.

title: INCREASE PROPOSED IN COAL AND GAS USE IN NEW YORK STATE
description: In a move to reduce sharply New York's dependence on oil, the state's Energy Office called yesterday for an increase in the use of coal and natural as over the next 15 years but opposed any new nuclearpower plants beyond two that are already near completion.

title: Deaths
description: POTOFSKYJacob S. The Infants & Juvenile Manufacturer's Association was saddened to learn of the demise of Jacob S. Potofsky, former President of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. His understanding of the problems of the children's wear manufacturers and his devotion to the betterment of the working conditions of the employees. helped establish for upwards of 40 years outstanding labor relations between the Association and the Union. His support of the managers of the Union was car stent. We extend our sympathies to his widow, Blanche and to his daughters Delia and Jacqueline.

title: James C. Caraley Presumed Dead In the Rockies; Student Was 19
description: James Christopher Caraley, a Columbia University student who had been mountainclimbing in the Canadian Rockies, has been reported missing and presumed dead, although his body has not been recovered. He was 19 years'old.

title: Munson Crash Survivors Differ
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP)  The two survivors of the plane crash that took the life of Thurman Munson of the New York Yankees have differing accounts of the seconds before the accident.

title: From Provence, the Flavors of Sun and Sea
description: IF ever I were forced to limit my eating to the food of only one part of the world, my choice, without hesitation, woild be the cooking of Provence, the sundrenched, flowery French region that appeals so strongly to all the senses. The food one finds along the Mediterranean from Menton to Marseilles and in the antique towns that wind up into the AlpesMaritimes is soulsatisfying and varied, tempering the Italian richness of flavor and perfume with the strictly French talent for style and balance. Provencale flower gardens with their rainbow arrays of pinks, orange, purple; red and gold are rivaled by fruit and vegetable markets.

title: Joyce Arnold, Stablehand, Dies After Horse Hits Her
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 7  Joyce Arnold, a 25yearold stablehand employed by Jim Doherty, died Sunday night of head injuries incurred in a stall accident earlier that day at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Federal Judge Refuses to Reduce Bail for Jailed Dominican Consul
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP)  A Federal magistrate has rejected a request to reduce the $3 million bail imposed on the Dominican Republic's Consul General, who was arrested here last month on conspiracy charges involving alleged gunrunning for Nicaragua's Sandinist rebels and cocaine smuggling.

title: This Time All Means It, Maybe
description: Any time it begins to seem that the world is standing still, go away for a month and see what happens. Abrupt change isn't confined to Jimmy Carter's cabinet. Even in the quiet backwater of sports, a man who has been out of touch through July makes many discoveries on his return Mickey Rivers and Al Rosen are Yankees no longer, but Bobby Murcer Is a Yankee again; Jerry Hoffberger, who has been putting the Orioles up for sale and snatching them off the market for years, has finally sold the club when it was the biggest winner in baseball; Alydar is retired, his classic rivalry with Affirmed unfinished; Jeff Torborg, manager of the Indians, isn't manager of the Indians anymore.

title: Tour of Guinea Arrives For Carter Visit Today
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  President Ahmed Skou Tour of Guinea will arrive tomorrow for what officials describe as a private, working visit with President Carter. It will be his first visit here since the early 1960's.

title: AlbanianAmericans Find Better Life in Real Estate
description: Nikon Vataj, a husky, powerfully built AlbanianAmerican, leaned back in a chair in his office in the Bronx, puffed on a cigarette and talked about how he had become a landlord.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. July 30, to Sunday. August 5). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7, (UPI)The Vietnamese Government today announced measures to spur lagging production, Including Government loans to private enterprise.

title: The Thatcher Gambit in Africa
description: The talent of the British for diplomacy must lie the genes. The Empire is lost, yet give them a problem in foreign policy and they revert instinctively to the style that long kept them great. After only a few weeks in office, Mrs. Thatcher is proving it again with the problem of Zimbabwe Rhodesia. The British way is to find the British interest in broad international terms and then to offer promises, even incompatible promises to seemingly irreconcilable forces. It does not always succeed. Its genius lies in the recognition that in diplomacy there are also right and wrong ways to fail.

title: The City
description: A 74yearold Manhattan executive was sentenced in United States District Court to three years in jail for defrauding seven banks of $35 million.

title: Revitalizing A Venerable Magazine
description: Carll Tucker rolled up his shirt sleeves, scooped up a cow bell and rang it. Meeting. Editorial meeting, he boomed over the thunder of voices in the midtown offices of The Saturday Review magazine

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown, ( N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: NOT often is mankind vouchsafed a tangible vision of the future. But 40 years ago, on the 30th day of April in the year 1939, the gates swung open on such a rarity. It was the start of the New York World's Fair, and despite the imminence of world war and the immanence of Depression, the schedule called for ceremonies of the first water  the presence of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia, massed military bands and speeches.

title: 3 State Agencies Battle for Rights To City Garbage
description: Three state agencies are fighting for garbage.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 8, 1979

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THERE are a lot of luxury or grand luxe restaurants around the world that offer specialties that never appear on the menu. These dishes are available to special patrons for very subtle psychological reasons best known to the restaurant's proprietor and maitre d'htel. The practice offers the owner or maitre d'htel the opportunity whisper into a favored customer's ear, I have something created especially for you and I think you'll like it. Very comforting to the customer's ego and an enticement for continued patronage.

title: Cures Can Be Found For Ailing Shirts
description: In these days of medical miracles, why should a shirt have to die?

title: Vast Western Forest Lands Laid Waste by Fires
TV: 2 Essays on Youths
description: THE Land, the Sea, the Children There is a pretty visual essay about two youngsters, one the 12yearold son of a Maine lobsterman and the other the 10yearold daughter of a Nebraska farmer. Scheduled on WNBCTV tonight at 7:30, it is a Norman Rockwelltype portrait that can only breed jealousy in a city child looking at it after a day spent on steaming hot pavement.

title: Delfo Gets Rail Post in Rich Trot
description: Delfo, the Italian speedster, drew the inside post yesterday for the Roosevelt International Trot and thereby set up an intriguing start for Saturday night's harness racing showcase.

title: Neighbors
description: Like other communities, Plainfield, N.J., has used zoning to insulate itself from communes and other experimental life styles. No more than four unrelated people could live together in a singlefamily dwelling unit. Now the New Jersey Supreme Court has struck down the limit saying it does not accurately reflect the way people live today. To enforce it would impose a fanciful way to avoid such perceived social ills as overcrowding, the court said. Plainfield can limit the number of people who may live in a house, but the people don't have to be related.

title: Coke Challenges Pepsi in Soviet Union
4 Connecticut Papers Bid U.S. Block Courant's Sale
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 7 (AP)  Four Connecticut newspapers said today that they had asked the United States Department of Justice to block the proposed sale of The Hartford Courant to the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles.

title: Britain, Angry About Carey's Ulster Plan, Sees It as More U.S. Meddling
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  The British are seething again at what they consider unwarranted American interference in the delicate problem of Northern Ireland, this time because of remarks made yesterday by Governor Carey of New York.

title: Reporter Given a 3Day Sentence For Trial Article Barred by Judge
description: ONEONTA, Ala., Aug. 7 (UPI)  A Birmingham newspaper reporter was found in contempt of court today and sentenced to three days in jail for violating an order prohibiting publication of a trial account.

title: Bell Wins Stay On Iranian Fee
description: A unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company won a temporary court order today preventing the new Islamic Government of Iran from collecting $30.2 million in a disputed letter of credit being held by a bank here.

title: Deaths
description: KLAUERMafilda H. on August 5, 1979 (formerly of Mt. Vernon, N.Y.). Sister of Alma and Sr. John. S.S.N.D., aunt of John Klauer. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home. 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, N.Y. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, N.Y. on Thursday at 10AM. Visiting hours 24 and 79PM.

title: 300 Youngsters Protest Failure To Pay Them for Brooklyn Jobs
description: For the third time in more than a week, young people gathered yesterday in Tompkins Park, in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section, to protest not having been paid for days spent at the bidding of a man who promised to pay them $2.40 an hour for demonstrating against the acquisition of neighborhood businesses by Arab immigrants.

title: Where to Send A Frayed Shirt For Alterations
description: Here is a list of local practitioners of shirt alterations, prepared by Mr. Meer on the basis of their recent ministrations to his shirts:

title: U.S. Senator Appeals For an Increase in Aid To Nicaragua Regime
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 7  After three days of meetings with Nicaraguan leaders, Senator Edward Zorinsky, the chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, said today that the United States must not abdicate its responsibilities in aiding the new Government.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on bamboo plants in The Times on July 19 omitted, as a result of an editing error, the initial source of the information, which was Garden magazine, published by the New York Botanical Garden

title: Woman Wins Spot in Runoff for Mississippi Governor
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 7  Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Gandy won a runoff spot in the Democratic primary for Governor tonight, leading five male opponents from the start.

title: Joseph Canatalupo, 73; Helped Seaport Museum
description: Joseph Anthony Cantalupo, a founder of the South Street Seaport Museum and a member of its board of trustees, died of a heart attack Sunday in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 73 years old and had lived in Brooklyn for most of his life.

title: Deaths
description: SCHULDERLeo Young Israel of Flattest records with deep sorrow the passing of Leo Schulder, a founder and former CoChairman of its Chevra Kadisha. May the mourners be consoled together with all the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Solomon J. Shartman. Rabbi Sheldon J. David. Pres Dudley Felt. Chairman Chevra Kadisha

title: Wine Talk
description: ACCORDING to the maitre d'htel at the rooftop grill at the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo, the best local wine he has is a fragrant young Bellet. It may well be, but I've never seen anyone drink it there or anyplace else.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Salmon Pipeline From Alaskan Seas
description: HOMER, ALASKA THIS is the season the humpback salmon come home from the sea to spawn and die. Darkskinned and somber, they crowd the clear, quiet waters of gravelbottomed pools along Humpy Creek's five miles, from the beaver dam lakes at the foot of the mountains to the mouth at Kachemak Bay.

title: Deaths
description: FABRIKANTBernard. The Officers. Board of Trustees, Members of Central Synagogue and Its Brotherhood deeply mourn the passing of an esteemed member of many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife and all the members of the family.

title: Advertising
description: IF it weren't for cooperative advertising allowances, retailers' advertising in national magazines would drop by 50 percent, the publishers of two of America's most widely known magazines agree.

title: Mexico Plans Art Show
description: At the invitation of Mexican authorities, the Rainbow Art Foundation of New York has commissioned 12 artists to prepare works for an exhibition, The Icarus Odyssey, to be mounted in Guadalajara in October.

title: Deaths
description: ISENBERGIrwin M., on August 3rd. Beloved husband of Milda, devoted fatter of Errol Clyde and Brenda Nadine, loving son of Emma(Slate) Iseberg and the late Harry Iseberg of Chelsea, Mass. and dear brother of Phyllis Vigoda, also of Chelsea.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson, on China Visit, Supports Trade Accord
description: PEKING, Aug. 7 (UPI)  China should be granted mostfavorednation status in trade with the United States, regardless of whether the Soviet Union qualifies for it, Senator Henry M. Jackson said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: CONDUCTING was not invented by Arturo Toscanini, but sometimes it seems to have been invented for him. Since that extraordinary night in 1886, when  without rehearsal, without prior warning the then 19yearold cellist of a touring Italian opera company led a performance of Aida in Sao Paulo, Brazil, the art and craft of conducting have never been the same. Toscanini never forgot the two errors he made that first night: he gave one wrong downbeat and, conducting without the score, he experienced one brief memory lapse. The debut took place on June 30. By Aug. 16 the youth had conducted 26 performances of 11 operas  all from memory  and there is no record of any further errors.

title: Economic Scene
description: IN the halcyon days of the 1950's and 1960's, business investment decisions seemed appropriately focused on longerterm payoffs. There seemed to be nothing in the then perceived distant future that would significantly alter the type of economic environment that would prevail.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IS this an example of grace under pressure? asks John Meehan. Amid the lunchtime heat and hullabaloo of the Grand Central area, I was waiting the other day to cross East 48th Street at Lexington Avenue. Illegal sidewalk merchants blocked each intersection. Across the street, two threecard monte games were in full swing. Prostitutes solicited in front of an elderly, unappetizing hotel. Dozens of youths swaggered in every direction carrying monstrous portable radios playing at full blast.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported yesterday that sustained customer demand across its entire range of hardware and software products had pushed up earnings 33.3 percent for the fourth fiscal quarter on a 27 percent advance in sales.

title: Egypt, Israel and U.S. Spell Out Election Procedures for Palestinian Rule
description: HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 7  Israel, Egypt and the United States ended a ministerial session here today with the publication of an agenda outlining election procedures for Palestinian rule in Gaza and the West Bank but leaving the details, along with some crucial principles, to be tackled at later meetings.

title: Opera: Mostly Mozart Presents Concert Tito
description: THE word that seldom fails to get mentioned when anyone talks about Mozart's La Clemenza di Tito is static, and for good reason. The libretto of this impossibly stiff opera seria, concerning a Roman emperor who discovers a plot against his life but who in a surge of magnaminity decides to pardon everyone involved, is filled with noble sentiments, but is about as dramatically taut as a testimonial dinner. And yet there is magnificent music in this work that Mozart finished in the final year of his life; the problem is how to rescue it without abandoning the Baroque formality of the opera seria form itself. This fall, in its first production of Tito, the New York City Opera will be facing precisely that stylistic challenge.

title: Pipers Overlooked But Still Has Jets Job
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 7  Lawrence Pillers, somewhat of a forgotten man since the New York Jets camp opened, was accounted for at practice today and on the first unit at left defensive end. That is where he will probably be on Sunday when the Jets play the Oilers in an exhibition game in Houston.

title: City Is Ouches Ahead in Health Immunization
Vance Asserts Israel May Violate Pact by Using U.S. Jets in Air Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The Carter Administration said today that Israel might have violated an agreement with the United States by using Americansupplied planes against Lebanon last month. At the same time, officials tried to reassure Israel that the United States had not changed its policy toward the Palestine Liberation Organization and that anxiety over oil supplies was not causing pressure to be brought against Israel.

title: THOMAS FINNEGAN
description: Thomas Finnegan, a former political reporter for the defunct Long Island StarJournal and a freelance editor, died of cancer. Saturday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Smithtown, L.I. In 1954, he received the George Polk Award for outstanding suburban reporting.

title: 22 SENTENCED TO DIE IN IRAQI CONSPIRACY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 7  A special Iraqi court has sentenced 22 persons to death, including five members of the country's ruling Revolutionary Cornmand Council, for plotting against the state, the Iraqi press agency announced today.

title: Kitchen Equipment Supermixer
description: IN the race to see who can create a machine that will perform more transmutations on food than any other, the British appear to be in the lead. What they've done is to take a powerful Kenwood mixer and then use its motor as the driving force for 14 removable attachments that do 55 different tasks.

title: Carter, Abandoning Copter, Rides the Future a Train to Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 7  President Carter boarded the 8 o'clock Metroliner at Washington's Union Station this morning and journeyed here in a snackbar coach to rally support for his energy program and praise the contributions of ethnic Americans.

title: Three Yankee Relievers Falter. As White Sox Triumph by 95
description: If Bobby Murcer's dramatic hits 24 hours earlier had been a sign and his three hits last night another sign that the Yankees might be able to stage another lateseason comeback, the work of the team's relief pitchers last night should serve as another sign to the Yankeesto forget it.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS India's `KingMaker
description: NEW DELHIThe whirlpool of Indian politics, which has sucked down many celebrities into oblivion, has also hurled the most bizarre of characters to the top.

title: Vanessa Redgrave's Casting Is Protested
description: The casting of Vanessa Redgrave, an outspoken proponent of the Palestinian cause, to play an Auschwitz concentrationcamp survivor in a television drama to be made for showing on CBSTV drew sharp protests yesterday from Jewish groups and from people in the entertainment industry.

title: Delich Is Upset by Lohren In L.I. P.G.A. First Round
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 7 Jim Delich of Deepdale, seeking his third straight Long Island Professional Golfers' Association title, was upset today in the opening round at The Creek Club.

title: Boston Globe Owner In Radio Station Bid
description: BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP)  Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe, announced today that its broadcast subsidiary had agreed in principle to buy two Springfield, Mass., radio stations for $5.1 million.

title: Houston Surgeon Testifies In Tomjanovich Trial
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) A Houston surgeon testified today that the face of Rudy Toinjanovich, the professional basketball player, had to be rebuilt like a jigsaw puzzle.

title: Baden Planning To Sue the City Over His Ouster
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden said yesterday he would file a lawsuit against the Koch administration seeking reinstatement as New York City's Chief Medical. Examiner.

title: Theodore Galusha, 68; Was a Paleontololgist At New York Museum
description: Theodore Galusha, a geologist and paleontologist who helped amass the Frick collections of fossil mammals at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, died last Thursday at the age of 68 in Chadron, Neb. A native of Nebraska, he returned to live on a farm near Chadron when he retired from the museum in 1975.

title: Iran Closes a Leading Paper in Crackdown on the Press
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 7 (AP)Armed Islamic revolutionary guards occupied the offices of a leading Teheran newspaper today, and a Government official said its publishers and editors would be prosecuted for counterrevolutionary policies and acts.

title: H.U.D. Sells Housing Notes
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said that it sold $1.1 billion in taxexempt project notes for lowincome housing yesterday on behalf of 117 public housing agencies. The notes, which had an average maturity of 8.7 months, carried an average interest rate of 5.254 percent.

title: Dole Speech Assays His Prospects Of a 1980 Race Against Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  On his way back here from Iowa a couple of days ago, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, one of nine announced or unannounced Republican Presidential candidates, was asked what he was going to do at a National Press Club speech this week that would be different.

title: City Begins a New Effort Against Loft Conversions
description: As part of a new effort to halt the illegal conversion of industrial loft buildings to residential spaces, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city had gone to court to block the owners of a building in lower Manhattan from converting it. The city is also requesting that the owners be required to restore the building to industrial use.

title: Sockers Suspend Smith
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 7 (AP)  Bobby Smith, centerdefender for the San Diego Sockers, has been suspended indefinitely for throwing his jersey at his coach during a North American Soccer League game. Smith took off the jersey after Coach Hubert Vogelsinger had taken him out of the game against Seattle last Saturday. Then he threw it at Vogelsinger when the coach turned his head.

title: At Long Last on the Top Rung in Bolivia Walter Guevara Arze
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 7  Walter Guevara Arze has achieved the presidency of Bolivia almost by accident, but he has been well prepared for the task through a long political career.

title: Dominican Truck Strike Warning Issued in Bid for Cut in Gas Price
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 7 (UPI)  Truck drivers threatened today to stage a strike unless President Antonio Guzmn lowers fuel prices.

title: Askew Trade Job Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  Reubin O. Askew, former Governor of Florida, is expected to be nominated by President Carter to replace Robert S. Strauss as special trade representative. Mr. Strauss will resign this month to serve as the President's special Middle East negotiator.

title: Promotions at Daily News
description: The Daily News, New York, has promoted Michael O'Neill, editor and vice president, to editor and executive vice president; Al Heitman, circulation airector, to vice president, and James Artz, business manager and vice president, to assistant to the president and vice president. The News also named Henry Wurzer, advertising and marketing director of The Chicago Tribune, executive vice president and director of sales. terest rate on the oneyear notes was 5.185 percent.

title: Accent on I Love New York
description: J'aime New York, Yo adoro New York and Ich Liebe New York proclaim the colorful brochures aimed at enticing wary foreigners to explore La Grande Pomme, La Manzana Grande or, simply, the Big Apple.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plan Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  President Carter's proposal to invest $88 billion in synthetic fuel development encountered renewed opposition today in significant Congressional quarters.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Pendant With Sound Effects

title: U.S. to Upgrade Small Airports In an Effort to Ease Congestion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administration announced today that it would improve 86 satellite airports in a safety move to divert thousands of small planes away from congested metropolitan fields

title: An Alabaster Egg a Ming Plate, Cloisonne
description: The auction of the Benjamin Sonnenberg Collection, which took place in June at Sotheby Parke Bernet, proved to be (if I may use a favorite word of Sonnenberg's) a swagger one. It brought a total of just under S5 million, which even in these inflationary times is no mean sum, and yet I heard few exclamations of surprise when the final tally was announced.

title: East German Output Sags
description: EAST BERLIN  East Germany, troubled for some time by energy problems and supply shortages, has failed to meet production targets in the first half of this year in several vital fields.

title: TOP F.B.I. STRUCTURE REVISED BY WEBSTER; 3 CHIEF AIDES NAMED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  William H. Webster shuffled the top management structure of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today, appointing three new assistant directors, none of whom was closely identified with J. Edgar Hoover.

title: KURT KASZNAR DIES; BROADWAY ACTOR
description: Kurt Kasznar, an actor who played memorable roles on Broadway in Barefoot in the Park, The Sound of Music and Waiting for Godot, and who, as a soldier in World War II, was among the first Army motionpicture photographers to enter and film the ruins of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died Monday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: 21 Teams Still Vying For Soccer Playoffs
description: With only five days left in the regular season, 21 of the North American Soccer League's 24 teams are still in the running for the playoffs, which start next Tuesday. But seven of the 16 playoff teams could have losing records.

title: Byrne's Chief of Staff Quits to Take Position With Sports Complex
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 7In a surprise development, the appointment of Governor Byrne's chief of staff, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, as executive director of the Meadowlands Sports Complex was announced today. He succeeds Robert G. Harter, who resigned to become president of a Texas company that owns and operates the Houston Astrodome and the Houston Astros baseball team.

title: Connors and Mrs. Lloyd Advance in Tennis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (AP)  The defending champion, Jimmy Connors, turned in a close firstround victory tonight, beating Australia's Mark Edmondson, 64, 75, in the United States open claycourt tennis tournament.

title: W. Robert La Vine, 59, Stage Costume Designer
description: W. Robert LaVine, a theatrical costume designer, died following heart surgery Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Recession Held Aid to Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Carter Administiation acknowledged today that the recent unexpected surge in inflation had created problems in extending its wageprice guidelines for a second year but predicted the oncoming recession would make the program work better by checking both wage and price increases.

title: CREDIT MARKETS TaxFree California Bond Offer
description: The State of California's $125 million issue of general obligation bondsthis week's big event in the taxexempt sectorcame to market yesterday with a group. headed by the Bankers. Trust Company as the winning bidder.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk. of Pay.riod Rate record able

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: COMNIODMES Grain Trading Is Quiet In Advance of Forecast
description: The normally turbulent Chicago markets in grain and soybean futures became extremely cautious late yesterday as the trade awaited the crop estimates of Conrad Leslie, the leading private forecaster in the industry.

title: Study Reports Cancer Agents Also in Scotch
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)  Minute amounts of cancercausing agents called nitrosamines have been found in six brands of Scotch whisky, the National Science Foundation reported today.

title: Champion Jumping Horse Dies of Colic in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 7 (UPI)Simpatico, a Canadianowned horse and gold medal winner at the recent Pan American Games, died today of colic.

title: Careers
description: THE fact that there is an eightyearold organization called the Association of Internal Management Consultants can lead to at least two conclusions.

title: Commonwealth Talks End; Hopes Voiced on Rhodesia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 7  The Commonwealth heads of government concluded a weeklong meeting here tonight, a day ahead of schedule, guardedly optimistic about their peace plan for Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: Japan Oil Supply Found Ample
description: TOKYO, Aug. 7  (Reuters) The Japanese Cabinet today ruled out an imminent oilsupply crisis here, because of increased Saudi Arabian production and a calmer spot market, a Government spokesman said.

title: 5 of Rickover's Aides Are Retiring
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  Five civilian deputies to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the crusty, blunt and allbutuntouchable architect of America's nuclear Navy, are retiring this month, raising anew speculation on the admiral's future.

title: Exxon Finds Oil Off Florida
description: MIAMI, Aug. 7 (AP)  Exxon USA said today that it had drilled a test well 50 miles northwest of here that was, capable of producing Oil in paying quantities. The 11,000foot well yielded 106 42gallon barrels of oil a day. The oil is highly viscous and was high in sulfur content, Exxon said.

title: U.S. DELEGATION GETS INVITATION TO HANOI
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7 (AP)Vietnam today reinvited a United States Congressional delegation to Hanoi to discuss the refugee situation in Southeast Asia, a day after it had abruptly barred the delegation because one of the legislators had accused Hanoi of humanrights violations.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  The president of the Police Benevolent Association of the New York State Troopers Inc., a union that represents about 3,000 troopers in labor negotiations with the state, must be allowed back into his office here, a State Supreme Court justice has ruled. Mr. Stuart, 45 years old and a trooper for 22 years, was arrested July 30 on thirddegree grand larceny charges relating to alleged expense account padding. The board also suspended him as president.

title: Private Lives
description: WE came back to Sweat City from the mountains of California just in time to read about Richard Nixon's problems in finding a suitable apartment on the Upper East Side. This was no surprise. Everybody I know who is looking for a suitable apartment anywhere in Manhattan can't find one; there aren't even any unsuitable apartments. All of these everybodies, except Mr. Nixon, are bivouacked in my house in sleeping bags. By day, they trudge the gray streets, being spat upon by doormen and custodial engineers. At night, they weep into the petunias and whimper bedroom, bedroom. Perhaps they are dreaming of San Clemente.

title: Record Industry's Sales Slowing After 25 Years of Steady Growth
description: The 54 billionayear record business, after 25 years of nearly uninterrupted growth, has suddenly run into a period of faltering sales, staff cutsand general demoralization. Although record executives differ in their assessment of the extent and causes of the industry's troubles, all of them suggest that the days of strong, steady growth of the popmusic industry may be over. And some fear, that the situation, it it continues, may affect the ability of record labels to sign and promote new artists.

title: Continental Ends Talks With Western
description: Continental Air Lines said that its directors had voted to end the company's merger proposal with Western Airlines. The proposal had been rejected by the Civil Aeronautics Board on July 21.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Crime

title: Bank Ousts Poullain Again
description: BONN, Aug. 7  Ludwig Poullain, the former chairman of Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, was retroactively dismissed today by the bank for the second time.

title: Recipes From the SunDrenched Land of Provence
description: 1. Preheat over to 475 degrees.

title: 2.25 Million cambodians Are Said to Face Starvation
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 3  United Nations and Red Cross officials said in interviews here and in Ho Chi Minh City this week that 2.25 million Cambodians were facing starvation.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Cost of Overpolicing Prices
description: Has some advertisement lied to you lately? Thanks to the vigilance of the Federal Trade Commission, claims that this pill will grow hair or that that compound will double gas mileage have become rare. Thus it's ironic that the Commission's staff, in its zeal to protect gullible consumers, may be making it impossible for honest retailers to compete by advertising lower prices. Consider the sad tale of Kroger versus the F.T.C. staff.

title: A Contest That Lives Not by Bread Alone
description: It was almost enough to make us wish we had brought our own B.L.T. down, hold the mayo, as the Top Four contenders chosen from 400 original contestants gathered for the final judging of the 24th annual National Sandwich Idea Contest at the Excelsior Club yesterday.

title: Chess:
description: The seventh annual World Open Tournament in Philadelphia saw seven players tie for first, each getting $1,686. Grandmasters Anthony Miles of Britain. Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania. Walter Browne and Arthur Bisguier of the United States, International Masters Bernard Zuckerman and John Fedorowicz of the United States and Haukur Angantysson, an Icelandic master, each scored 82 in the 374player tourney.

title: Jeopardizing American Prisoners Abroad
description: A Federal court in Connecticut has freed three United States cocaine smugglers from prison sentences imposed by Mexico because of the torture and other injustices they suffered there at the hands of policemen, judges and jailers. The ruling may look like a blow for civil liberties and human rights. Unfortunately, it could be a blow instead to the humane treaty that allows this country to repatriate imprisoned Americans and let them serve out their sentences here.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 7  It was solid experience against hungry youth in the final of the Spingold knockout team championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here this afternoon. At stake was the right to contend for. places on the 1980 American world championship team.

title: Notes on People
description: Erik Estrada, the widesmiling costar of the CHiPs television series about motorcycle policemen, was taken off the critical list yesterday after suffering extensive injuries in a fall from his motorcycle during filming. In late afternoon the administrator of the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles said the 30yearold actor was awake and alert and that no surgery was being considered.

title: Calm in the Storm Over Baden: Robert M. Morgenthau
description: As Robert M. Morgenthau turned 60 last week, the Manhattan District Attorney was clearly unhappy to be at the center of the kind of public controversy he has spent much of his life trying to avoid: the harsh dispute over exactly why he had urged Mayor Koch to dismiss Dr. Michael Baden as the city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: S.E.C. Proposes To Widen Role Of Stockholders
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to propose revisions in the agency's rules governing corporate proxies in an effort to give shareholders a more meaningful role in corporate voting.

title: Election in Iran: Khomeini's Victory May Prove Costly
description: PARIS, Aug. 7  The election of the socalled Council of Experts in Iran is over, but the bets were placed a long time ago and the victory of Ayatollah Ruhollah Xhomeini's Islamic fundamentalists was never in doubt. What is in question is the quality of the Ayatollah's victory and how long it will last.

title: Knocking the Living H Out of istory
description: BOSTON  Each round of updated, revised collegelevel American history textbooks delivers more of the same irrelevant political history. In their race to capture the classroom market, publishers distort our political past and render it superficial.

title: Brewers Defeat Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 (AP)  Sixto Lezcano, Gorman Thomas and Dick Davis cracked tworun homers, Davis's snapping an eighthinning tie, as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 75, tonight.

title: Mets Lose to Cardinals Twice
description: Lou Brock moved within eight hits of his goal of 3,000 last night in Shea Stadium but the New York Mets moved only closer to oblivion as the St. Louis Cardingls swept a doubleheader behind some extravagant rookie pitching.

title: Home Improvement
description: STAPLE guns are nothing new. For years they have been used for all kinds of tacking, fastening and repairing jobs around the house, often as a substitute for a hammer and nails or for adhesives or other fasteners.

title: Bronx Zoo Wins Feathered Race by a Flutter
description: A concavecasqued hornbill chick, left, is almost as big as its mother, but it still lacks the bony protuberance, known as a casque, that distinguishes the species. On disp1ay at the World of Birds in the Bronx Zoo, the chick is the first of the species to be born in the United States, but only by a matter of days as the Sacramento Zoo announced that it, too, had a concavecasqued hornbill chick. The chick at the Bronx Zoo left the nest last week while the Sacramento Zoo's chick left Tuesday. The birth is a complicated affair for the species. The adult female is walled inside a tree hollow by her mate, leaving only a small feeding hole. Thirty to 35 days later, the chick is hatched and about 100 days later, mother and chick leave the nest.

title: FEODOR LYNEN
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 8 (AP)  Feodor Lynen, winner of the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, died today at the age of 68 after a long illness.

title: A Slain Jewish Nun Is Symbol of Interfaith Harmony
description: Edith Stein was a Jew, and she was a Roman Catholic. She was a philosopher, and she was a nun. She was one of millions of people herded into the gas chambers by the Nazis, and she is a special individual to thousands of followers today.

title: Making the Maid's Room Work
description: ONE look at a former maid's room on Park Avenue is enough to know why maids preferred to commute to work from less chic addresses: The rooms are short, narrow and claustrophobic. But now, with the livein servant little more than a memory, spacestarved New Yorkers are taking another look at abandoned maids rooms  as well as other underutilized small spaces  and they are finding that the tiny rooms can be made useful and attractive.

title: 354 Air Taxi Concerns Close as Federal Rules On Safety Take Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  Rather than meet new Government safety standards, 354 airtaxi companies have chosen to go out of business, the Federal Aviation Ad ministration reported today.

title: Moynihan Bars 'sacrifice of Israel
description: The Camp David agreements are solemn and must be kept, according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. You cannot simply change because the Saudi King, Prince or whatever has said, Well, we'll let you have another million barrels of oil a day as a Fourth of July present.

title: ItalianAmericans Take Warm but Critical View of Carter's Performance
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 8  When President Carter spoke here yesterday to the national convention of the Sons of Italy, Barbara Tucci was impressed. He was down to earth, said Mrs. Tucci, a medical technologist from Baltimore. I feel like he was a genuine human being, not a figurehead.

title: Heat Is a 4Letter Word, But for Some So Is Cool
description: You're hot. You're so hot you envy the shopping bag ladies who spend their nights on the airconditioned F train, riding back and forth between Coney Island and Jamaica. You've been riding the Fifth Avenue bus during rush hour, sitting over the engine compartment, feeling a chemical bond forming between the melting plastic seat and your dissolving acrylic dress.

title: Askew to Get Trade Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) President Carter will nominate Reubin O., Askew, who was Governor of Florida while he was Governor of Georgia, as special trade negotiator to succeed Robert S. Strauss, the White House announced today.

title: Baghdad Executes 21 Officials for an Alleged Plot
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 8  Baghdad executed 21 officials today, including prominent political and trade union leaders, for having taking part in an alleged conspiracy against the Government.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M. RadioWMCA, WGBB, 8 P.M.)

title: Books: Victoria Ocampo
description: VICTORIA OCAMPO: Against the Wind and the Tide. by Doris Meyer. Illustrated. 314 pages. Braziller. $15.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART: CHAMBER MUSIC, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. Preconcert recital, 7.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE corner of 60th Street and Fifth Avenue is as much of a formal entrance as Central Park has ever had  a fact recognized by Huntington Hartford some years ago, when he announced his misguided plan to put a huge cafe near there, as well as by today's park users, who stroll up the avenue to enter the recreation area at that lovely location. The Plaza, Pierre and SherryNetherland hotels provide a serene and sumptuous backdrop.

title: Mets Beaten by Cardinals, 84
description: Swamped by four doubleheaders in eight days and staggered by injuries to their pitching staff, the New York Mets pushed the selfdestruct button yesterday in Shea Stadium. They rushed into a fourrun lead over the St. Louis Cardinals in the first inning, blew it in the fifth and lost their third straight game, 84.

title: Family Trapped by Inflation Does Without
description: HARTFORD. Aug. 3  We do without. Martin Owens said this morning. The money runs out very quickly, and everything keeps going higher and higher, and when the money runs out, we just do without.

title: 3 Bodcaw Bids Held Cleared
description: The Federal Trade Commission has given three bidders for the Bodcaw Company provisional, clearance to proceed with plans to buy the giant timber and oil producer, sources close to the situation said yesterday.

title: CARTER SEES ENVOY OF ISRAEL IN EFFORT TO RELAX TENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  President Carter conferred for 90 minutes today with Ambassador Ephraim Evron of Israel to ease the mounting tensions between the two countries caused by some real and some anticipated problems in their relations.

title: Alzado to Pursue Boxing Career
description: DENVER, Aug. 8 (AP)  Lyle Alzado, the allpro defensive end for thd Denver Broncos, told the National Football League team today that he was retiring from professional football to pursue a professional boxing career.

title: Stage: Holiday on Ice
description: HOLIDAY on Ice came into Madison Square Garden yesterday. It is being brought to us by the same folks who bring us the circus, and in its amiable, glitzy heart. it is very much like the circus. It is also very much like a Las Vegas revue, scrubbed clean and with only minimal suggestions of decolletage and cleavage. Underneath its feathers, sequins and yards of perfectly capped teeth, Holiday on Ice is a good deal of fun.

title: Senate Panel Reports Major Spying By 5 Nations on Foreigners in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  Five foreign Governments have maintained extensive intelligencegathering operations in the United States to spy on, and in some cases harass, their citizens here, according to the draft of a report prepared by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Directors of the Integon Corporation announced yesterday a decision neither to accept nor reject two $200 million proposals for the purchase of the WinstonSalem, N.C., holding company, which has extensive interests in the insurance business.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 8, 1979

title: Market Rises Again in Heavy Trading
description: The stock market registered a modest advance yesterday in continued heavy trading although late selling pressure wiped out some of the earlier gains. Some of the bigger price moves were made by the specialsituation issues.

title: Technology
description: THE laser has beamed its way into law enforcement. Fingerprints that are undetectable by traditional techniques can now be made visible and photographed using a method called the laser latentfingerprint detector system.

title: TOPPOP  RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles na tionwide, compiled by Record World. a trade publico. bon. Attums are determined by, sales figures from major retail outlets, singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fas selling record.

title: Harper's Headache With Lippincott
description: Almost a year ago, Harper & Row Publishers, the venerable New York book publishing house, bought the J.B. Lippincott Company. Lippincott was in financial distress, but it had something Harper & Row coveted, a valuable medical and nursing publishing operation. The $16 million paid out in cash and stock made the Lippincott transaction the biggest, in Harper's 162year history.

title: Besana, Giants Back, Facing Crisis Calmly
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8On the day Coach Ray Perkins said that right now the No. 1 quarterback job was between Joe Pisarcik and Randy Dean, and with Phil Simms certain to be on the Giants roster, Fred Besana said he was not worried.

title: Calm Weather Stalls Slick's, Advance on Texas Coast
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 8 (AP)  Calm weather today stalled the northward drift of the oil slick that has defiled Texas resort beaches for two days.

title: Williams and the Seats of Power
description: Why in the world would Edward Bennett Williams, the noted Washington barrister, want to buy a baseball team, the Baltimore Orioles, as he did last week for S12 million?

title: The Art of Stripping Furniture
description: STRIPPING furniture is messy but not that difficult a task. Most beginners want to hurry the job and add more finish remover before the first application has had a chance.to work. An apprentice restorer spends his early training stripping furniture slowly and methodically learning the job can't be rushed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio
description: 78, WNCN. Ruins of Athens Overture, Beethoven; Sinfonia in E flat, C.P.E. Bach; Romance for Bassoon and Orchestra, Elgar; Alcina, Overture, Handel.

title: 50 Writers Demand BookAward Boycott
description: Fifty of the country's bestknown authors and critics this week called for a boycott by all serious writers of the 1980 American Book Awards.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The week's first significant test of corporate bond yield levels, focusing on the sale of $50 million of new highgrade bonds for the Kentucky Utilities Company, apparently met with buyer resistance yesterday.

title: Koch Plans to Name Dr. Gross as City's Chief Medical Examiner Today
description: Mayor Koch plans to name Dr. Elliot M. Gross this morning to replace Dr. Michael M. Baden as the city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHORE SCENE The Seamen's Church Institute at 55 State Street seems an especially apt setting for a series of Friday, night programs featuring sea songs and square dancing to nautical melodies. These festive gettogethers take place in the institute's Harbor Room, with its wraparound picture window fronting the harbor with a panorama of ships, sky and water. After dark, there is the inspiring, dependable sight of the Statue of Liberty, its torch alight.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 9, 1979

title: McDonald's Offering
description: The McDonald's Corporation said had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $100 million variablefixed rate sinking fund notes due 1994. Proceeds of the financing will be used to retire bank debt and for general corporate purposes, including other debt reduction and capital expenditures.

title: Soviet Murder Mystery': A Death in Switzerland
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  The official Soviet Government newspaper printed what it presented as a gripping murder mystery today  an account strongly suggesting that a Western intelligence service had murdered a SoViet diplomat in Switzerland with an overdose of the hallucinatory drug LSD.

title: U.S. Delegation Arrives In Hanoi to Begin Talks
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 8 (AP)  A United States Congressional delegation flew here today to talk with Government officials about the refugee crisis after Vietnam lifted a ban imposed because of a Congressman's harsh criticism of Vietnam's human rights policies.

title: I.T.T.'s Profits Fall 16.2%; Currency Losses Cited
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation disclosed yesterday in its semiannual report that its secondquarter net income fell 16.2 percent as a result of a foreign currency translation loss, without which the operating earnings rose 11 percent.

title: 2 Opponents Challenging Petitions On Marrero's Candidacy in Bronx
description: The petitions that would qualify Victor Marrero as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of the Bronx have been challenged by two of his opponents.

title: The Region
description: The Long Island Lighting Company declared its opposition yesterday to the State Energy Office's plan for converting three of the utility's oilfired power plants to coal. A Lilco spokesman said the conversions, all at plants in residential areas, would be environmentally, economically and esthetically unsound.

title: Sound
description: LIKE other music makers, sound systems are occasionally indisposed, but often in such cases they suffer only minor ailments that you may be able to cure without professional help. The important thing is to try the most likely remedy for the particular symptom.

title: Heating Oil Adequacy Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)Despite Administration assurances of adequate supplies of homeheating oil for the winter, a House subcommittee said today that production might not be adequate to meet President Carter's stockpile goal.

title: Hers
description: MY uncle was raised in four rooms above his parents' grocery store on Sackman Street, In the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. He was notorious on his block as a prankster and a bad boy. Through the store he would run, grabbing a pickle from the barrel and a bagel from the shelf, then up the stairs he would race to the front room, where he would station himself at a window and squirt the passersby with a seltzer bottle. Out he would go again, snatching a slice of lox and a fistful of cream cheese.

title: Talking Business /with Foy of Bethlehem Steel
description: Just as the steel industry was beginning to enjoy more than a year of surprisingly high demand and falling imports, the current economic climate, led by a fall in auto sales, has caused orders for steel to drop. Now the industry, which is still healing wounds inflicted by the last severe downturn from which it emerged smaller and more cautious, faces another touch period.

title: Oil Output of Refineries Off in Week
description: Production at the nation's oil refineries dropped slightly in the week ended last Friday, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Model Rooms Focus On Entertainment
description: MOVING across the vast expanses of Macy's furniture floor, one is reminded that in the World's Largest Store there may not be groundbreaking design news, but there is something for everybody. In the store's new model rooms, which opened Sunday and will be on view until Thanksgiving, one recognizes design trends instead of discovering them.

title: Adroit Zambian Leader Seeking Rhodesia Peace
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 8  At a dinner after the Commonwealth conference's ratification of a proposal for ending the war in Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Kenneth D. Kaunda, the President of Zambia, turned to Margaret Thatcher. the British Prime Minister. Let us hope God acts quickly, he said.

title: Rockland Aide Is Questioned on Cadavers Organs
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 8Dr. Frederick Zugibe, former Rockland County Medical Examiner, was unable tonight to provide a special legislative panel with explanations for all of the 16 preserved human brains that were kept in the Medical Examiner's office for periods as long as four and a half years.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Pick Hotels in Americana Tie
