description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  Two Washingtonarea activists seeking to force disclosure of the Central Intelligence Agency's use of universities for drug- and humanbehavior experimentation have won a limited victory in their Freedom of Information Act suit.

title: Bail: From Glass jars to Skylab
description: MUNCIE, Ind. - The Ball Corporation, the diversified space age company built on a foundation of home-canning jars, is looking to a new process to improve profits in its oldest line of business.

title: Pop: Jerry Lee Lewis and Band
description: THE new Club Lorelei, 231 East 86th Street, wasn't really ready for its grand opening on Wednesday night. The stage lighting didn't work, the sound was snotty and the staff seemed harassed.

title: Badillo Defends His Candidate for BorouEh President
description: Herman Badillo, left, an outgoing Deputy Mayor, with Victor Marrero, center, the State Housing Commissioner and Mr. Badillo's choice for Borough President, at a news conference yesterday at City Hall. Standing at right was Representative Robert Garcia. Mr Badillo took the op, portunity to chide members of the Democratic Party's re- former ranks who are challenging Mr. Marrero's peti- tion. Mr. Marrero complained that the challenges were an undemocratic tactic customarily used by boss candidates and representatives of political machines.

title: Bonn Disavows a Mideast Plan
description: BONN, Aug. 9  The Weft German Government moved quickly today to digsociate sitself from an eightpoint Middle East position paper by a leading member of Parliament that called for the establishment of a Palestinian state and right of Palestinian selfdetermination.

title: Fuelinventory Totals Revised
description: The American Petroleum Institute said yesterday that inventories of gasoline and distillate fuel for the week ended last Friday were larger than the figures released on Wednesday showed.

title: For Children
description: THE MUPPETS: A CELEBRATION, features the art and history of Jim Hensen's creations on The MuPPet Show and Sesame Street, Monday and Thursday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Tuesday and Wesnesday, A.M. to 6 P.M. and Friday and Saturday, noon to P.M., through Aug. 11, at The New York Public LIbrary, Amsterdam Gallery, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Free. Call 799220).

title: PENTAGON TO ASSIST CAIRO'S ARMS OUTPUT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 - A Defense Department team of 20 specialists left for Cairo today as part of a new Carter Administration policy to help Egypt upgrade its arms industry, Pentagon of& einiqcsaitt trtrlav

title: Around the Nation
description: DALLAS, Aug. 9 (AP)  The Justice Department dispatched a communityrelations specialist to the coastal town of Seadrift today to help ease tensions between American and Vietnamese crab fishermen.

title: Jersey Denies Plea for 10 Gas Rise
description: NEWARK, Aug. 9 - About 50 chanting, singing gasoline dealers stalked into the State Energy Department office here today and argued heatedly for an extra dime on their allowable retail markup of 15.4 cents a gallon. But the State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson decried their confrontation tactics as rude and crude and refused to recommend that Governor Byrne exercise his authority to grant the extra 10 cents.

title: For Taiwanese Violinist A Career Takes Shape:
description: Choliang Lin, an acclaimed young violinist who won the first Queen Sofia competition in Madrid two years ago at the unlikely age of 17, will make his debut tonight in the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall. His per- tormance, of Mozart's Concerto in G, will in effect mark the start of his fullfledged solo career.

title: ProducerPrice Rise Sends Dow Falling
description: A larger-than-expected rise in producer prices last month weakened the stock market yesterday as the trading pace dropped sharply from the previous two hectic sessions.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THE South Street Seaport Museum, which is building bright future on a glorious seaborne past, will strum to the different guitar of inland rhythms this weekend when it is filled with the Seventh Annual Bluegrass and Old Time Music Contest and Crafts Fair.

title: EARNINGS; Procter ?? Gamble Net Climbs 10.3%; Lear Siegler; Sunbeam
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that it had a 10.3 percent gain in net earnings for the latest quarter and a 12.8 precent rise for the full fiscal year ended June 30.

title: Advertising
description: WHETHER they want to or not, Millions of Americans are receiving sleek, fullcolor merchandise catalogues through the mail, in their local newspapers or in local stores.

title: Tennessee Atom Plant Releases A Radioactive Substance Into Air
description: ERWIN, Tenn., Aug. 9 (AP)  About 300 grams of a radioactive substance was released into the atmosphere at a nuclear fuel processing plant here, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: Music: The Recent in Retrospect
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 - Whether by design or by chance, this year's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood has concerned itself less with showing us where music may be heading than with reminding us where it has bawl. This glance over the shoulder has proved enlightening, if also a bit sobering.

title: COMPANY NEWS

description: WASHINGTON,Aug. 9 - President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea said today that if the Organization of African Unity could establish its projected panAfrican peacekeeping force, there would no longer be any justification for the presence of Cuban soldiers in Angola.

title: Error Sets Up 40 Loss for Mets
description: In the painful world of the New York Mets, grief comes in different forms at different times: four ailing pitchers, four doubleheaders in eight days, a lock on last place in August. Last night in Shea Stadium, it came in the form of a bouncing ball to first base with the in- field drawn in tight.

title: Film: DeLuise Directs Himself in 'Hot Stuff':'Butterfly' in Huntington
description: "HOT STUFF" is the kind of immensely cheerful comedy that runs as much on good will and a genial attitude as on its own energy. The movie, which has its basis in fact, is about a team of Miami burglary cops who open their own fencing operation to catch (and record on tape) petty thieves in the act of disposing of their goods. It stars Dom DeLuise, the portly, often hyper-tense actor who's been making me laugh ever since he got his foot stuck in a flower pot 13 years ago in "The Glass Bottom Boat," and it marks Mr. DeLuise's debut as a director, which may or may not be a good thing.From the evidence on the screen here, Mr. DeLuise can direct a screenplay as casually constructed as the one for "Hot Stuff" as well as probably a dozen other people, but being able to do something as well as a dozen other people really isn't good enough. Rather, it's a convenience.Behind these comments, I must admit, there's the suspicion that Mr. DeLuise's performance might have been more loosely, more manically funny if, while acting, he hadn't been carrying around the worries of the entire production. Perhaps not. In addition to having surrounded himself with a lot of fine character actors, he also had with him on this production his real-life wife and two sons who, naturally enough, play his wife and two sons on the screen. It wasn't a production hampered by homesickness."Hot Stuff," which opens today at Loew's Tower East and other theaters, was written by Michael Kane and Donald E. Westlake and has the form of an extended television sketch that can never be any better or more than its individual parts. More important than anything else, though  and don't underrate the surprising effect of this  "Hot Stuff" is a movie about essentially nice people. Its petty thieves are endearing, its Mafia godfather and his soldiers powerless in the face of such innocence and its serious hoodlums always inept. No one, good or bad, ever gets seriously injured in the mayhem.Mr. DeLuise's cop-cohorts in the fencing business are played by the beautiful Suzanne Pleshette, Jerry Reed (the country-music star who was so good in "W.W. and the Dixie Dancekings"), and Luis Avalos, who is the Spanish-speaking member of the outfit.The four policemen have private lives of a sort, but the movie is almost entirely concerned with their adventures with the characters who pop in and out of their pawnshop, like the characters in Fred Allen's "Allen's Alley." Because Mr. DeLuise has cast his movie so well, "Hot Stuff" manages the feat of being continuously amusing while not going anywhere.Some of the peripheral characters who make the movie as much fun as it is are the real owner of the pawnshop, a fellow named Hymie ("I'm a legitimate businessman!"), played by Sydney Lassick; the Miami godfather, played by Marc Lawrence, who is all style and no substance; a fellow (Pat McCormick) who unloads a case of Cuban cigars that are more than they seem to be; and an elegantly phony English couple who deal in marajuana. Playing it straight throughout the movie is Ossie Davis, who never quite loses his dignity as the senior officer responsible for the bizarre police stakeout."Hot Stuff" may not be the funniest movie of the year but it is the most sweetly tempered."Hot Stuff," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some vulgar language.

title: Screen: Double Debut From Britain at Thalia:Contrasting Roles
description: SEVERAL years after their production, screen versions of two plays, "The National Health" and "No Sex Please  We're British," are having two-day premiere engagements in this country, today and tomorrow at the Thalia."No Sex Please" is one of those knockabout farces that flourishes in the West End but usually dies quickly, as this one did, when transplanted to Broadway. "The National Health," which had its premiere in London in 1969, had successful runs at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven and then at the Circle in the Square in 1974, and has since been revived elsewhere in this country.It is hard to imagine that any of these productions could have been superior to this film rendition, made in 1975, of the Peter Nichols play about life, and death, in a men's ward of a shabby London hospital, interrupted by burlesque soap-opera episodes of romance among physicians and nurses at a far grander institution.In fact, the impact of seeing the same performers at one moment pale, over-worked but concerned with their scruffy patients, and the next involved in an absurd six-sided romance that culminates in an interracial kidney transplant, is, if anything, intensified by the quick cuts possible only in film.Lynn Redgrave, Eleanor Bron, Jim Dale and Donald Sinden, Sheila Scott-Wilkinson and Neville Aurelius, play the dual roles expertly. Colin Blakely is moving without seeking our sympathy as the ward's Everyman, an baffled, stubborn, unreformable working-class alcoholic.Under Jack Gold's thoughtful direction, every part, even the bits, is firmly delineated. Mr. Nichols, properly confident of the dramatic validity of his characters and situations, has only occasionally felt it necessary to open up the action to the world outside the ward. In this concentration of unforced emotion, the rattle of the wheels of the stretchers on which the bodies of the men who die, one by one, are rolled across the yard to the hospital mortuary sounds like the drums of judgment.One often listens skeptically to tales of the existence of splendid films that for one reason or another are kept from public view. It turns out that "The National Health" has, until now, been one of these. It will be odd indeed if it is not now given a chance to reach a wider audience.Its companion feature, "No Sex Please," which dates from 1973, deals with the complications that ensue when a box of pornographic photographs is sent by mistake to the home of a newly married Junior bank executive in Windsor, one of the stuffiest of English towns. In its own way it is well done, and its simpleminded and by now rather outdated double and triple entendres provide a coarsely amiable contrast to the deeply felt emotions of "The National Health."

title: Film:Acapulco 'Sunburn':Romance and Comedy
description: THERE'S no reason why the attributes that made Farrah Fawcett such a big star on television shouldn't eventually work just as well for her in feature films. Miss Fawcett (who has officially dropped the "-Majors" lately) seems adorable without guile, and she also manages to convey the impression that she's very, very nice. Her popularity on posters and in hair-care ads attests to the fact that she's fun to look at, too. Whether this describes the full extent of her talent is hard to say, at least on the evidence of either her first film, "Somebody Killed Her Husband," or now "Sunburn," the better of the two. Each of these movies takes a counterproductive tack, starting out as a vehicle for the leading lady and then losing her in a web of trumped-up intrigue."Sunburn," which opens today at the Gemini I and other theaters, concludes with a shot of Miss Fawcett and Charles Grodin uncorking a bottle of champagne. And indeed, this is a movie that, for all its unnecessary twists, aspires to nothing more than being bubbly. Mr. Grodin, as a private detective with perhaps the world's biggest expense account, is supposed to be investigating an insurance fraud in Acapulco, a job that requires him to rent an elaborate villa and a Rolls-Royce. Miss Fawcett is a model hired to pose as his wife. Her job involves changing her clothes a lot and calling him"Honey."Together, they embark on one of those romantic-comedy-adventure-mystery stories that fall into no particular genre save that of the breezy mishmash. The romantic angle seems almost extraneous, since the camera is so evidently in love with Miss Fawcett that Mr. Grodin doesn't need to be; in any case, her overriding sweetness turns every would-be clinch into a sisterly hug. As for comedy, Mr. Grodin's deadpan manner supplies a fair amount of that until the adventure-mystery aspects become overpowering. The insurance fraud goes slack so early that the movie winds up with too much plot. It all culminates in a car chase that wrecks half a village before it screeches into the middle of an ongoing bullfight  all this while the soundtrack plays the film's pretty, very mellow, very un-car-chase-like theme song. Oh, well. Ole!Art Carney is on hand to give the beginnings of a good performance, as a south-of-the-border gumshoe whose help Mr. Grodin enlists, though neither of them seems altogether qualified for this line of work. Soon enough, Mr. Carney is off disco-dancing with Miss Fawcett, and from then on his role loses its edge. Of the other supporting performances, Joan Collins' stands out most, and not for the best reasons. Miss Collins' aggressive-nymphomaniac routine is supposed to be funny this time. It's not."Sunburn" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a shootout finale and one episode of bedroom farce.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)  Fred Lynn, the American League leader in home runs, cracked his 31st of the. season and Torn Poquette belted his first as the Boston Red Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers. 54. tonight.

title: Electrical Fire Closes Bank
description: The Israel Discount Bank, at 511 Fifth Avenue, at 43d Street, closed for the day yesterday after a fire broke out at 9:11 A.M. in an underground transformer, shutting off power to the building's 'ater pumps and elevators for five hours..

title: U.S. Agency Moves to Head Off Racial Conflicts Over Allegations of Police Misuse of Force
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  Officials of the Department of Justice moved cautiously yesterday toward the formation of a national coalition of blacks, HispanicAmericans and policemen in an effort to head off serious racial conflicts as a result of policemen killing minorities under controversial circumstances.

description: Deaths

title: Fires Spread on French Riviera
description: MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 10 (Reuters)  Weary firefighters today battled new blazes fanned by strong winds in forests along the Riviera. The firemen halted one fire last night that cut the main MarseillesNice railway line and forced more than 2,000 campers to flee. The new fires broke out today north of Frejus.

title: Preview of Folk Art Show Sept. 11 to Aid Museum
description: A fundraising preview of the Museum of American Folk Arts Fall Antiques Show will be held Sept. 11 from 6 to 9 P.M. at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street. Tickets for the preview are $35 and will entitle purchasers to entrance at the show during its fiveday run starting Sept. 12. The proceeds will go to the museum.

description: Deaths

description: Americas Episcocrats

title: Brighton Board Votes Test of Nude Bathing
description: BRIGHTON, England, Aug. 10 (UPI) - Nude bathing will be coming to the coast of England, thanks mainly to 47-year-old grandmother and a Town Council member with an allover tan.

title: Rival Coast Publishers End Suits, Barring Data on South Africa Tie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 - In a private meeting today, the rival Sacramento newspaper publishers, John McGoff and C. K. McClatchy, agreed on an out-ofcourt settlement of antitrust suits pending against each other.

title: Hayes to Receive A Jaycees Award
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, Aug. 10 (UPI) - Woody Hayes, the former Ohio State head football coach who was dismissed after he punched a Clemson player in last year's Gator Bowl; is to. receive an award Sunday for outstanding contribution to character building.

title: 5 Forest Fires Still Uncontrolled; Situation Termed Extraordinary
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 10 (AP)  Five forest fires still burned out of control today in western areas where more than 150,000 acres have been devastated in what United States Forest Service officials described as one of the worst fire seasons on record.

title: Mets and Expos Split
description: One heartwarming feat stood out at Shea Stadium last night as the Mets divided a doubleheader with the Montreal Expos. Ed Kranepool came up with four hits in four times at bat for New York in the second contest. The Mets won the opener, 71, but dropped the second, 65.

title: European Summer: A Downhill Brighton
description: BRIGHTON, England  On the wet days, when the striped backs of the canvas deck chairs on the promenade flap in the wind like distress flags and the air seems to smell more of damp wool than brine. Charley and Vi take walk, find a warm place to sit and drink coffee.

title: 3 Mostly Mozart Nights To Be on WNYCFM
description: Three more of the Mostly Mozart Festival chambermusic concerts will be broadcast live in the next two weeks by WNYCFM. One was broadcast last Wednesday.

title: Leader of Red Brigades Affirms Use of Violence
description: ROME, Aug. 10 The ideological dispute in the Italian terrorist movement took a new turn today with the publication of an 18page document in which Renato Curcio and other founding mem- bers of the Red Brigades defended the present leaders and urged continuation of terrorist attacks in the most brutal form.

title: Article 2 -- No Title

title: Guide

title: Congress Balking At Chrysler Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 - The Carter Administration's decision to help the Chrysler Corporation formulate loanguarantee plan is likely to encounter strong opposition on Capitol Hill, initial Congressional reaction indicates.

title: Music: Schuller Leads Contemporary Finale
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10  Whatever other impression one might carry away from the Festival of Contemporary Music that closed here at Tanglewood last night, the remarkable quality of the student performers will leave a lasting imprint. For the final concert of

title: Vendetta Called Possible Motive In Yonkers Fire
description: YONKERS, Aug. 10  Police and fire officials are investigating the possibility that that the arson that damaged the home of a black family hours after they moved into the Colonial Heights section here last Wednesday was the result of a personal vendetta against the builder of the house and was not racially motivated.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANAnna, on August 10, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Sigmund. Member of Hadassah and East Concourse Jewish Center. Beloved mother of David, Seymour and Morris. Loving grandmother of Rosalind, Edward, Ellen, Sharon, Lois and Stephen. Adored great grandmother of Elizabeth, Victoria, Adrienne, Jennifer, Brian and Jill. Services at Boulevard Park West, 115 West 79 St, NYC, Sunday, August 12 at 1PM.

title: Nixon Agrees to Buy Apartment On 5th Avenue From Hirschfelds
description: Richard M. Nixon has agreed to purchase the 12room condominium apartment of Abraham Hirschfeld, the millionaire builder, at Fifth Avenue and 63d Street, and - barring any hitches - the former President will move back to Manhattan early next year, a lawyer familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: 120 Workers Cut At CBS Records
description: CBS Records, a leading name in the record business and a division of CBS Inc., dismissed 120 employees from its marketing staff, effective yesterday. The dismissals follow the recent layoffs of 52 CBS Records workers involved in field and label activities. The two cuts represent about 6 percent of the CBS Records employees active in the affected areas.

title: World Gold
description: By The Associated Press

title: Hunt Unit Buying Bodcaw Properties
description: The International Paper Company, which bought the Bodcaw Company of Dallas for $805 million on Thursday, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Bodcaw's mineral properties for about $188 million in cash to the Placid Oil Company, also of Dallas. Placid is owned by the family of the late H.L. Hunt, the Texan oil millionaire.

title: Indians Launch Their First Space Vehicle but It Falls
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 10  India fired its first satellite launch vehicle toward space today but the rocket failed to achieve orbit and fell to earth.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Governors of six states asked the Carter Administration to help Chrysler rehabilitate itself. Governor Carey joined William G. Milliken of Michigan, who spearheaded the plea, as did Pierre S. duPont 4th of Delaware, James A. Rhodes of Ohio, James R. Thompson of linois and Joseph P. Teasdale of Missouri. All are key industrial states where Chrysler has operations. [25.] Initial Congressional reaction to the Carter Administration's decision to help Chrysler with a loanguarantee plan was negative. [27.]

title: Texaco to Test Sale of Gasohol
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would begin testmarketing gasohol this fall on a smallscale basis in the Boston, New York and Indianapolis metropolitan areas.

title: ExFirestone Officer Settles
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP) - The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has confirmed that it negotiated an outofcourt settlement of lawsuits involving the nation's No. 2 tire maker and Robert P. Beasley. once Firestone's vice chairman and chief financial officer. The dispute had opened the company's financial and legal affairs to public scutiny.

title: Highway Closed by Vapors
description: CONCORD, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP)  A twomile stretch of state highway was blocked off today because of vapors leaking from a tank truck filled with nitric acid. Motorists were warned to stay away from the area near the stretch of Massachusetts 2.

title: Judy Chicagos Rochester Dinner Party Is Canceled
description: Because of a dispute over exhibition costs and control, a scheduled showing in the fall of The Dinner Party, the vast work celebrating women of myth and history by Judy Chicago. the West Coast artist, has been canceled by the Memorial Art Gallery of Rochester.

title: High Fuel Cost and Empty Seats Put Concorde's Future in Doubt
description: PARIS, Aug. 10  Back in the 1960's, France and Britain, the coproducers of the Concorde, were talking about building 300 of the supersonic planes, about the dawn of a new age of supersonic flight, about a major European challenge to American industry, about whisking pea ple from one continent to another between breakfast and lunch.

title: New Ecuador Firesident Vows to Champion Democracy
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 10  Jaime Rold6s Aguilera took office today as the first elected Ecuadorean President of this decade and pledged himself to the propagation of democracy and human rights throughout the hemisphere.

title: Woman Killed in Central Park as Violent Thunderstorms Sweep City
description: A line of powerful thunderstorms rumbled across parts of the metropolitan area late yesterday afternoon and early evening, causing the death of a young woman in Central Park and power failures in more than 100,000 homes in the area.

title: Jazzmobile Schedules Series for Olympics
description: The Immobile ensemble, headed by Billy Taylor, will perform at the Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid, N.Y., next year. The concerts, which will be held at informal settings at Lake Placid and other sites in theAdirondacks, is part of the effort by the International Olympic Committee to bring the arts of the host country to the Games international audience. A work is being commissioned by the Jazzmobile to be performed at the Games.

title: Queens Auctioneer Guilty of Lying During an Inquiry Into Court Sales
description: In the first conviction stemming from a major investigation into alleged corruption involving New York City marshals and auctioneers, a 47-year-old auctioneer from Queens was found guilty of Federal perjury charges yesterday.

title: Texas Surviving Worst Oil Spill, but Experts Say Harm May Not Be Known for Years
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Aug. 10The skies over the emerald waters of the Gulf of Mexico are abuzz with reconnaisance helicopters and planes. The Coast Guard and Navy are on continuous alert. The gift shop of the Bahia Mar nutei is oiienng a i sum mat reaas, Survivor 79 Oil Slick. On the beach outside, vacationers tiptoe gingerly around the sticky black globules of petroleum tar - actually, tarry globs of crude oil formed by the chemical breakdown of crude in salt water - that have washed up in the surf. Some take pictures of the globs.

title: Scientists Fight APlant Cutbacks
description: Calling the proposed New York State master plan for energy a blueprint for poverty, a national organization that said it represented more than 700 scien- tists, said yesterday that it would fight the Plan, particularly its provision bar- ring the construction of new nuclear power plants.

title: Yanks Beaten, 86, As Murray Sparks Oriole Rally in 7th
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 10  The Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles tangled in another twofront war tonight. On one front, the troops from the two teams waged another scintillating battle; on the other, the field generals of the two teams clashed in the latest episode of their psychological warfare.

title: How to Rebuild Mr. Porter's House
description: The residential Colonial Heights section of Yonkers, where an average house sells for around $100,000, has changed over the last 20 years. Successive ethnic groups have arrived, and residents say that each in turn has been subjected to abuse, even physical attack.

title: The Honorable Mr. Hughes
description: Richard Hughes, the Chief Justice of New Jersey's Supreme Court and twice governor, won't surprise anybody if he finds ways to help his state for years to come. But yesterday he removed his robes for the last time. He is 70 years old and by law, had retire.

title: Savings Banks Faulted on Pledge
description: New York State savings hanks provided fewer homemortgage loans in the state for the second straight quarter even though the interestrate ceiling continued to rise, a legislative committee charged this week.

description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP)  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it was closing two of its oldest biasply tire plants, one in Los Angeles and the other in Conshohocken, Pa., eliminating a total of 1,225 jobs.

description: By The Associated Press

title: 4 Steel Makers Agree To Settle U.S. Price Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) - The Federal Government and four steel companies have agreed to settle a fiveyearold civil antitrust suit that accused the manufacturers of price fixing and allocating contracts on reinforcing steel bars in Florida, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Japan Decides Against Importing Canadian-Built Nuclear Reactor
description: Japan Decides Against Importing Canadian-Built Nuclear Reactor

title: Pentagon Seeks to Give Policy Post To Vietnam War Pacification Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10- Secretary of Defense Harold R. Brown has asked President Carter to approve the appointment of a controversial aide, Robert W. Romer, to the Pentagons top policy-making Job, Government officials said today.

title: Ben Zuckerman, Clothier, Is Dead; Leader in Ready-to-Wear Industry
description: Ben Zuckerman, dean of the American ready-to-wear coat and suit industry, who retired in 1968, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and had an apartment at 907 Fifth Avenue and one in Palm Beach.

title: Three Chosen for White House Posts
description: Sarah Ragle Weddington ... Born Feb. 5, 1945, in Abilene, Tex. . Daughter of Methodist preacher . Attended McMurray College in Abilene, received law degree from University of Texas in 1967 . . . Served as assistant city attorney in Forth Worth .. . Served in Texas House of Representatives two terms . . . Named general counsel of United States Department of Agriculture in 1977 by President Carter . . . Chosen by President as his special adviser on women's issues in fall of 1978, succeeding Margaret Costanza . . . Won national attention in 1971, at age 26, when she argued a landmark case before the United States Supreme Court that struck down state antiabortion laws .. . Has been active in National Organization for Women and National Abortion Rights League . . Helped plot strategy for Senate passage last year of bill extending time for ratification of equal rights amendment . . . Divorced, no children . . . Would like to be elected Governor of Texas someday.

title: About New York
description: Two master builders of model sailing ships sound Faustian as they revel in the secrets they share: how to splice the separate strands of the wispiest silk thread to simulate miniature heavy rope bindings, how to miX the right Kitchen concoction to corrode mutiny the tiny plates of a copper keel. Finally, both insist their minds and hands are such now that they actually could build fullsized versions of the ships they have done in model form.

title: Letters
description: I agree with Mayor Koch that our nation is facing a grave energy crisis. His recent proposal to curtail automobile use in portions of New York City by establishing free zones raises interesting concepts and ideas. However, without a full commitment to changing life style, establishing carfree streets will do little, if any, good.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Leonel J. Castillo, the Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner, said today that he would resign by Oct. and return to Houston, Tex. Mr. Castillo, 40 years old, said that he would pursue  private endeavors and would remain active in immigration affairs as a private citizen.

title: 35 on India Bus Feared Drowned
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 10 (Reuters)  At least 35 people were feared drowned today when a tourist bus skidded in heavy rain and plunged off a bridge into the Savitri River in western India, the Press Trust of India reported. Six people swam to safety after the accident near Mahad on the road from Goa to Bombay, the news agency said.

description: DALLAS, Aug. 10 - Many lawyers are slipping badly. They're becoming mechanics.

title: OBSERVER Anything But Money
description: At three o'clock the other morning was awakened by John, my neighborhood burglar. Sorry to wake you, governor, said John; but I've looked all over the house for the loot and can't find it. You'll have to show me where it is.

title: Books: The Place of Performance Art
description: This is the first book devoted to an area of avantgarde activity that has become increasingly prominent in the last few years in lower Manhattan performance art, or art made by art- ists that is in some sense theater, dance, mime, concept art, often music and in no real way (except lamely, through video documentation) repeatable or sellable, except on a onetime basis.

description: Florence Flast, the New York City pub- lic school system's 'irector of pupil transportation, whose efforts at reform- ing the schoolbus contracts led to a long and sometimes violent busdriver's strike earlier this year. resigned yesterday.

title: Miller Reported to Meet Bankers on Chrysler Aid
description: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller met Thursday with top executives of major banks that serve the Chrysler Corporation in an initial effort to find out what role they might play in a rescue plan for the troubled auto company, company and banking sources said yesterday.

title: Transfers in the Marshal Service Laid to Enmities, Not Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) - An of- ficial of the United States Marshal Serv- ice testified today that four deputies were transferred from Atlanta to Florida and Texas because they and their boss had be- come antagonists and not because they had complained to Congressmen about onduty drinking and gambling.

title: Murdoch Wins On Sydney TV
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 10 - Ru- pert Murdoch, whose News Ltd. group of companies has substantial media in- terests in the United States, Britain and Australia, has won his battle for control of one of Sydney's highly profitable commercial television stations.

title: The Table That's Set For All Time
description: The china and silverware have been chosen. So have the goblets, which are blue and green cut glass. Theres even a croissant at each place, sitting neatly on the laceedged tablecloth. Its all an illusion  a trompe l'oeil table top created by the Italian artist Piero Fornasetti, who has been producing similar images since the 1930's. In this case, Mr. Fornasetti started with a drawing, which was then photographed, laminated to a wood top and lacquered. Depending on the height of the legs chosen for the table top, it can be used as either a coffee table or a dining table. It is available at Carole Stuoell. 61

title: New White House Appointee Quits After Jersey FeeSplitting Charges
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10  Daniel W. Horgan, former executive director of the Democratic National Committee, resigned last night from his $47,500-a-year post as personnel consultant to the Carter Administfation after his name was linked to a state and Federal investigation into the operation of the New Jersey Housing Finance Agency.

title: C.I.A. Recruits Madison Avenue

description: DETROIT, Aug. 10  The governors of six key industrial states in which the Chrysler Corporation has operations asked the Carter Administration today to help the moneylosing automobile manufacturer rehabilitate itself.

title: Charges Set in Dumping Of Poisons in Bronx Lot
description: New York City officials began a variety of legal proceedings yesterday against a truck driver, his employer and a dump operator on charges stemming from the dumping of hundreds of containers of deadly chemicals on a vacant lot in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

description: Rosemary S. Pooler, executive director of New York State's Consumer Protection Board, pressed a tomato into an Economaster $12.95 plastic food-processing machine, turned the handle and the tomato was mangled.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  With highly unusual comment on a recent Supreme Court decision, Chief Justice Warren E Burger has focused public attention on a problem of legal interpretation that has plagued judges and lawyers for nearly 200 years.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 - Substantial concessions by Angola have enabled the United States and four allies to revive negotiations with South Africa aimed at bringing peace and independence to SouthWest Africa.

Britton Browne, was married yesterday to Stuart Warren Mar- tin, a widower, of Los Angeles and New York. The Rev. Seymour St. John, for- mer headmaster of the Choate School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the brides New York apartment.

title: Caller Asserts Missing Sindona Is to Be Shot at Dawn
description: A telephone caller told a news agency in Manhattan yesterday that Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, would be shot to death at dawn today.

title: The Dance: Lynn Daily
description: New Yorkers had a chance to get reacquainted on Thursday with Lynn Dally, a choreographer who worked here in the mid1960s and is now a part of the Los Angeles dance scene. Miss Daily brought her company into the American Theater Laboratory as part of the Dance Theater Workshop sum- mer Out-of-Towners series. And for the record, her New York audience seemed to love what it saw.

title: Record Soybean And Corn Crops Expected in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  This fall, American farmers are expected to produce the largest corn and soybean crops they have ever grown and to bar= vest the secondlargest wheat crop in history, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: A Judge Upholds 8 L.I. Physicians In Refusing to Treat Some Patients
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Nas- sau County yesterday dismissed- indict- ments charging that eight Long Island doctors had violated the state's antitrust law by conspiring to refuse to treat non- emergency patients under workmen's' compensation and the nofault auto-insur- ance law.

title: MELVIN RYDER, AT 86; ARMY TIMES FOUNDER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Mel- vin Ryder, founder and board chairman of Army Times Publishing Company, shed yesterday after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Kathleen Mundin Dead; Founder of Cancer Fund
description: Kathleen A. Mundin, president of the Children's Cancer Fund of America, died yesterday at the Glen Cove Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L.I., after a brief illness. She was 84 years old and had lived in Manhattan until she became ill.

title: Amdahl's Founder Quits; Memorex Talks Still On
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 - The Amdahl Corporation announced today the resignation of its founder, Gene M. Amdahl, as chairman, effective Sept. 1, and the appointment of Eugene R. White, the company's deputy chairman, as his successor.

title: Connors Gains Clay Semifinal
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) Topseeded Jimmy Connors and fourthranked Jose Higueras of Spain scored straightset victories today in the quarterfinals of the $275,000 United States open clay court tennis championships. The two victors met last year in the final of this tournament.

title: Shakespeare Is Still the Challenge
description: It should come as no great surprise that the American theater is endlessly divided on how to approach William Shakespeare, the supreme dramatist in our language. Easily the most frequently produced playwright in this country today, Shakespeare is constantly proving scholar Jan Kott's succinct evaluation of him: Like the world, or like life itself. But in America on the threshold of the 1980's - a culture splintered in countless ways - our dedication to the Bard is less coherent than fragmented, less a matter of unified style than of uneasy vaccilation between extremes.

title: ART `Tenth Street Lives
description: GREENWICH FOR artists in New York during the 1950's, Tenth Street meant the block between Third and Fourth Avenues, where the storefronts, basements and parlor floors of many houses were occupied by galleries. The term included galleries around the corner on both avenues and on 12th Street.

title: Staff Director for White House Aims at Smoothing Management
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 - Alonzo L. McDonald Jr. said today that he expected to apply professional management principles to his new job as staff director at the White House to reduce the frustration intensity that inhibits Presidential decisionmaking.

title: A Decade in the Making, the State's First Criminal Code Takes Effect Next Month
description: TRENTON - Beginning Sept. 1, New Jersey will have its first composite criminal code, reflecting the Legislature's view of current public morality in the Garden State.

title: DINING OUT Original Food Served Presumptuously
description: WHEN we first visited the Tulip Tree restaurant in Glen Cove several years ago, we were highly impressed with the food at lunch but less taken with the dinner. After a couple of recent visits, our assessment of dinner remains unchanged, but lunch, although still the better meal, has slipped somewhat. Furthermore. the pretension and presumptuousness of the place have become quite offensive in the light of spiraling dining costs.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Cabbage butterflies are not exclu- sive. Check flower borders for tiny caterpillars chewing holes in petunias, geraniums and zinnia foliage; use ma- lathion or Orthene. . . . Groom window boxes and patio planters often; remove faded flowers. . . . Use fungicide dusts for mildew on roses and phlox. . . .Drop a tablespoonful of mineral oil on ripen- ing corn silks to discourage corn ear worms. . . . Check yews and azaleas for mealybugs; use malathion or Orthene.

title: Big Labor, Big Questions
description: CHICAGO - The talk of the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s Executive Council meeting last week was not, in that traditional labor phrase, wages, hours and working conditions. Capitalism came in for a few catdalls, as usual, but that seemed secondary. The subject was this: Will George Meany, the federation's aging president, seek another term? If not, who will succeed him? And, in other politics, will labor support President Carter, as it has, rather halfheartedly so far, or will follow the hearts of some labor leaders and push for Senator Edward M. Kennedy next year?

description: Laura Elizabeth Kennedy, daughter of Capt. Alfred F. title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Paper dolls. Tom Tierney, a New York freelance fashion illustrator, had an inspiration. As a movie buff, he concluded that Rudolph Valentino and Marilyn Monroe, both of whom led tragic lives, have become the two great American sex symbols of the 20th century. As a collector of antique paper dolls, he knew that there has been a nationwide resurgence of interest in these relics of a more innocent age. So why not bring the two expressions of popular sentiment together in softcovered albums?

title: Ridership on L.LR.R. Up Sharply Over 1978
description: Ridership on the Long Island Rail Road has risen sharply this year and the increase has been attributed partly to the gasoline shortage and partly to the continuation of a longterm trend.

title: Father And Son
description: GEOFFREY WOLFF'S autobiography, The Duke of Deception - the harsh but affectionate portrait of his father, whose sustaining line of work till shortly before he died was as a confidence man -- is a book abundant with the complexities and contradictions of family sympathy. Keenly perceptive of family ties and family shame, Geoffrey Wolff has succeeded in being true to his emotionally complicated subject while also being divinely easy read. In the words of other family members, Geoffrey's father emerges as difficult in the extreme. I always trusted him, a cousin said, and he treated me well. He was a goodlooking guy, and good company. Another said simply: He was my friend. And third looked straight at Geoffrey and told him that his father was a gonif, a schnorrer. He was just a bum. That's all he ever was. In the delicate telling of his father's story, the son manages to bring all versions Duke Wolff to light.

title: Homosexuals Still Fight U.S. Immigration Limits
description: One United States agency has decided to stop questioning foreign visitors about their sexual preferences, but, despite ac- tivists hopes, the fight over the exclusion of homosexuals from this country contin- ues in the courts and the Federal Govern- ment.

title: Therapy Association Combats Current Massage Connotation
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 10- Protein is a poison - when you get bitten by a snake, it's pure protein, said Jo Wil- lard, as the audience at the 34th annual convention of the American Massage and Therapy Association listened in rapt attention.

title: Southern Baptists, Lutherans and Other Faiths Are Divided by the Issue
description: A civil war is being fought in several large provinces of American Christianity over the origin and accuracy of the Bible. In June, the largest American Protestant group, the 13-million-member Southern Baptist Convention, elected the ultraconservative Rev. Adrian P. Rogers of Memphis as president and threatened to investigate allegedly liberal leanings in seminaries and church bureaucracy.

title: A Room Where West Meets East
description: STAMFORD HIGH on a hill set back from the winding Rockrimmon Road stands the white stucco and stone house that June and Larry Laben bought less than two years ago. They are not quite certain how many rooms there are (nine or 10.). But they do know the two vital factors that determined the purchase:  lots of wall space for their collection of more than 100 Japanese prints and hangings and a bright, spacious room to serve as a gallery.

title: Dominica Is Racked by Political Upheaval and Depression
description: ROSEAU, Dominica, Aug. 8 - Columbus named this island for Sunday, the day he discovered it on Nov. 3, 1493, and there is a bittersweet joke that if he retarned to the eastern Caribbean today, Dominica is the only place he would recognize.

title: Rockhill Native Scores Upset in Sapling Stakes
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 11 Harry A. Oak's Rockhill Native scored a mild surprise in the $125,610 Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park today when he decisively defeated the 45 favorite, Antique Gold, by three lengths.

title: Scholars Search in Ethiopia In Study of Early Christians
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Minn.,Aug. 8 The mountainous regions of northern Ethiopia are dotted with hundreds of monasteries, many of them chiseled from solid rock centuries ago. If experts here are right, the monasteries are a storehouse of ancient manuscripts that could greatly alter prevailing views of early Christianity.

description: HARTFORD IN this summer.of worrisome gasoline supplies, it has become customary, even mandatory, for us to seek out alternatives to our ingrained habits of traveling, habits that almost invariably have involved the use of an automobile.

title: A DogDays Course in Fundamental Football
description: STORRS THE thermometer cries out 96 degrees, and the humidity seems to have mistaken the area for some equatorial country. There is no breeze, and wherever mere Is concrete, rippling waves of heat permeate the tropic air. The sun burns into the earth, the brown grass is brittle, plants go limp and dogs lie motionless except for panting.

title: MANY RUSSIAN JEWS DROP OUT IN VIENNA
description: VIENNA With disapproval and worry, Israeli officials call them the Vienna dropouts. They are Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union who arrive here and, instead of flying on to Israel, apply for visas to the United States, Canada or Australia.

title: Casinos Don't Pay
description: Governor Carey's Study Panel on Casino Gambling has now done all the studying he intends to do on the way to recommending that. New York amend its Constitution to bring in the slot Fnachines and gaming tables. The panel finds only two possible justifications: pro- tecting the state's tourism from diversion to other areas and economic development. It estimates an annual state income of up to $450 million by 1990 and the creation of perhaps 100,000 new jobs. It also predicts certain but incalculable offsetting cost that would be financial, social and political. It leaves the choice to the people of the state. On the basis of all the evidence now before us, we vote no.

title: Jewish Home in Berlin Destroyed by Arsonists After Nazi Sentencing
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 11 - Arsonists set fire to the home and business of a Jewish restaurant owner last night. They daubed the walls with antiSemitic signs, then pouring gasoline into the building and set it alight.

title: A Port in St. Croix: A Coup for Leon Hess?; Islanders welcome the jobs, but are wary of tax breaks he might get.
description: ST. CROIX, V.I. - Amid the kind of controversy that always seems to surround him, Leon Hess, the reclusive oilman, broke ground this month for an $18 million container port here. It would complement his Amerada Hess Corporation's gigantic refinery nearby - the world's biggest - and make St. Croix a major Caribbean cargo point. It would also eliminate the costly and timeconsuming shipment of goods through San Juan, P.R., and provide jobs for Virgin Island residents.

title: Body of Queens Girl Is Found
description: The bruised body of a 16-year-old girl was found yesterday morning on the roof of her apartment building in East Elm- hurst, Queens, hours after her mother had reported her missing. The police said that the girl, Paula Simpkins of 3344 104th Street, had suffered bruises on her neck and body and that her death was being investigated as a possible homi- cide.

title: Writer Finds Riches
description: CLINTON WHILE the names and faces of famous Connecticut writers such as Arthur Miller of Roxbury appear often in gossip columns and magazines, one of the state's most financially successful writers is by choice anonymous. He earns a sixfigure annual in- come and has had more than 200 books published in the last 25 years. His latest book, just three weeks after publication, is already climbing the bestseller chart of Publisher's Weekly, a trade magazine.

title: Tribesmen in India Attack Town
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 (AP) - Officials said that one person was killed and another seriously injured when Mizo guerrillas armed with automatic weapons attacked a town in the northeastern state of Tripura, the United News of India re- ported Inursday. The second major attack this week by the tribesmen, who have been fighting for independence since 1966, it raised the death toll in six weeks to at least 13.

title: Lacemakers Preserving An Ancient, Delicate Art
description: The bobbins clicked together, making a busy music that sounded like wind chimes. In frames and on tables were examples of the lacemaker's art: Helas lace, a specialty of Hungary; Tonder lace, named for the Danish town where it originated; Chantilly, the French lace as fragile as cobwebs. This week, the International Old Lacers were having their 26th annual convention at the Waldorf Astoria, and even in the dim lighting of the hotel suite, the lacemakers worked away at their pillows, producing intricate patterns as though they had sight in their fingers.

title: Plumbing the Riches Of Barrelhouse
description: During the early years of the 20th century, black American pianists who acquired their musical educations in country juke joints, loggingcamp dance halls or barrelhouses and ghetto taverns forged a fresh approach to their instruments. Black pianists who had received more formal musical educations were already making polished ragtime and jazz, but it was their academically untutored contemporaries who investigated the piano's percussive and polyrhythmic resources most exhaustively and who ingeniously translated the black vocal idiom, with its moans, slurs, shakes and blue notes, into pianistic terms.

title: West Germany Feeling Ripples Of Iran's Revolt
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 11 For Iranians; the situation is similar to the sort of reunion that American fami. lies experienced 10 years ago at Columbia or Berkeley or Madison. Visiting a child away at college, parents discover that there has been a change in views, that political gulf has opened.

description: Having gone from coal to oil, utlli- ties are leery of going back.

title: What's Doing in NANTUCKET
description: GRAY LADY - The Little Gray Lady by the Sea, Nantucketers affectionately call their 15-mile-long, threeand-a-half-mile-wide island 25 miles off Cape Cod. She is gray for the bayberries on her moors, gray for the fog that swoops over her scruli oaks and pines and nestles around her wharves. She is gray for her seagulls, the weathered shakes of her old houses and the gray garb of the Quakers who brought her her fortune. But then there are those days when the sky is sweptclean blue; the clouds billow like spinnakers; the sun burnishes the brass door knockers of the red brick mansions and dapples the cobblestones of Main Street. And then there are those stunning days of fall. By then, the moors have turned russet, and the wild cranberries crimson.

title: A Packet of Pleasing Poesy
description: ENEE and Theodore Weiss, who have edited the Quarterly Review of Literature with unusual disUnction since they founded it, 35 years ago, have done poetry many a service in the past. Their new format for QRL raises their commitment to the art to a still higher level. Beginning with the current number each issue of the magazine will consist of several entire volumes of poetry, appearing both in cloth and in paper. In the future, the series may include volumes of translation and long poems; occasionally it may present the work of a single poet, along with essays about the writer. Using QRL's subscription list as a base, the Weisses hope to keep the price down and to reach a larger audience than an in- dividual book of poems would. At $13 in cloth and PM in paper, the first number in the series is indeed a bargain: It contains four collections of poems - by Brian Swann, M. Slotzniclr., Reginald Gibbons and David Gellerand a verse play for radio by E. G. Burrows.

title: HOME CLINIC Shading Windows Outside to Shun the Sun
description: ON hot sunny days homeowners should do everything possible to keep the sun's heat from penetrating through windows and other openings. One of the steps often recommended is to close the Crapes or pull the shades down when the sun is shining directly on the glass, especially on the east and west sides of the house. While these measures will undoubtedly help a great deal, it is much better to provide shade on the outside of the windows whenever possible in order to keep the sun's rays from ever striking the glass. Shading the glass on the outside before the sun's rays get to it is about seven times more effective in helping keep the inside cool than blocking the sun off after it gets through the glass.

title: Remembering the 1960's, as Seen on TV
description: We have seen the images dozens of times. By now they are visual clichs: the dashing young President. Jabbing the winter air with his forefinger; the same young man, hands jerked to his throat, an instant before his death; the young man's son saluting a flagdraped coffin. We remember images of triumph - a shadowy figure descending a ladder to drop softly onto the surface of the moon - but they are overwhelmed by the images of conflict: firehoses and police dogs, police with clubs and soldiers with rifles, thatched huts bursting into flames at the touch of a cigarette lighter, mobs racing through firestormed neighborhoods, chants and songs from a crowd whose attire and hair style still look as though they came from another culture.

title: One Man's Family
description: AS tabloid headlines go, I still consider TOT SLAYS DAD, MOM the alltime gem of lurid compression, but the title of Alan Saperstein's first novel comes very close. The use of such homey words as mom and kids together with the spacesaver self (which stimulates philosophical speculation at the same time that it depersonalizes) juxta- posed with a form of the verb to kill provokes the terror and helpless interest that no newspaper account can hope to slake. But it is not the purpose of a tabloid story to improve on its headline, and Mr. Saperstein, who does not work for The National Enquirer, has glossed his horrific title with a fulllength, accomplished novel, a daring exploration of love, marriage and life in the family that commands attention.
