title: Nicaragua Provided a Rare Chance for United Political Action
description: QUITO, Ecuador - The five nations of the northem reaches of the towering Andes Mountain range now share a common political outlook that is gaining its own prominence in hemisphere affairs. Four those countries, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela are democracies, and the military leaders

title: Suffer the Little Children
description: OLD GREENWICH services are mental health services are getting the short end of the stick in Connecticut. Children have been slighted for so long that nobody seems to expect any real improvement. The condition is chronic. And it's outrageous.

title: Music Is Lively at Monadnock
description: One thing you are not likely to be at a Monadnock Music concert in southwestern New Hampshire is bored. James Bolle, a bearded bear of a conductor, impresario and musicologist, seems to be proving that intimate interaction between audience and musicians plus musical excellence can prevent either complacence or tedium. He aims to please, on his own terms, infuriate sometimes, but never to soothe or lull.

title: Subway Rider Is Injured in Jump
description: A passenger on a Lexington Avenue local subway train was listed in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital yesterday after he jumped between two cars as the. train was going north between 14th and 23d Streets, the police said. The man was not immediately identified.

title: The Birth
description: When a disparate group of individuals that included Barry Commoner, the ecologist, and Archibald I. Gilles, the Manhattan philanthropist, announced formation of a new political party the other day, no one was surprised that the news failed to stir much interest. Third parties have been numerous, shortlived and generally ineffective in recent years. The announcement contained little evidence that the Citizens Party would prove otherwise.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Because Charles Lindbergh took off from Roosevelt Field on his historic flight, Nassau County is claiming Cradle of Aviation honors. Hence, the Cradle of Aviation Museum, which is now being put together (by volunteers) at Hangar No. 3 at Mitchel Field in Garden City. For the first time, the museum is open to the public on free special preview guided tours from to 4 P.M. on Sundays and Wednesdays. Reservations are a must (2924348) to see the replica of the Spirit of St. Louis, a Republic P.47, a Republic Seabee and the Curtis Jenny once owned by Lindbergh.

title: CHESS
description: AMSTERDAM There never is any scarcity of hardluck stories after a tournament, but what is palmed off as bad luck is usually some defect in one's play.

title: The Summer of '39
description: THIS summer marks the 40th anniversary of two events that significantly altered the history of our society and caused an immense rupture in American literary and intellectual life. On August 23, 1939, the infamous HitlerStalin nonaggression pact was announced in Moscow. Among much else, this effectively shattered the socalled Popular Front that, since its proclamation at the Seventh World Congress of the Communist International in 1935, had insured the alliance of a great many liberal and leftwing writers and artists with the Communist Party in the name of an antifascist crusade. Eight days later, on September 1, Hitler's armies invaded Poland. World War II had begun, and what W. H. Auden then newly arrived in the United States - promptly dubbed a low dishonest decade came to an inglorious end in the unmentionable odour of death. (Auden's poem on this subject, originally called September: 1939, was published in The New Republic on October 18,1939.)

title: Steelers Turn Back Giants, 103
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 - Quarterback is still a problem with the Giants, but Phil Simms showed enough ability tonight in his National Football League debut to look as if he might eventually be the solution.

title: Widespread Border Burglaries Put a County in Arizona on the Alert
description: PALOMINAS, Ariz., Aug. 11 (AP) Cows and horses nibbled at the seemingly endless range stretching under cloudless skies to shadowetched mountains in the background.

title: Fruits of Victory Bitter for Hanoi
description: Empty barrels are always very noisy declared a Vietnamese official last week as he dismissed Western horror at the forced exodus of hundreds of thousands of Indochinese refugees. Hanoi would manage with- out the very small Western aid halted in protest, added Nguyen Co Thach, acting Foreign Minister.

title: or Can You?
description: IF President Carter arrived on my Dix Hills doorstep asking for advice on how to save energy, here's what I'd do: Invite him into the airconditioned house. elGive him a glass of ice water from the frostfree refrigerator with automatic icemaker and fingertip-touchcontrol beverage dispenser.

title: FAMILY AWAITS NEWS ON FATE OF SINDONA
description: Nothing was heard yesterday regard- ing Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, despite a threat that he was going to be killed at dawn.

title: Newark Exhibition
description: NEWARK

title: Ice Cold, Red Hot; Red Smith; Sports of The Times; To Move or Stay?; Meanwhile, There's Pete
description: WASHINGTON - Ice cold and red hot here. It's cold, ice cold, really cold. They're hot, really hot, red hot. Ice cold and red hot . . .  The chant droned on, rhythmical, almost lyrical. The voice was conversational in tone, the same voice that has addressed judges, juries and lawmakers on behalf of clients named Jimmy Hoffa, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Richard Helms and George M. Steinbrenner 3d. Edward Bennett Williams was recalling his boyhood.

title: Gone Away Farms Wins
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 11 - The Gone Away Farms polo team defeated Village Farms, 126, today in the semifinal round of the Monty Waterbury Tournament at Hickox Field. Gone Away Farms will face the Fairfield, Conn., team tomorrow at Bethpage State Park in the final.

title: Kathy Horvath, 13, Wins Girls 16
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 11 (AP) - Topseeded Kathy Horvath, 13-year-old from Hopewell Junction, N.Y., became the youngest girl ever to win the United States girls 16 championship today by scoring a 61, 61 victory over Kate Gompert of Tucson, Ariz.

title: OnceEndangered Elephant Seal Is Resurgent and Poses Problem.
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. - The elephant seal, once near extinction after hunters slaughtered it indiscriminately in the last century, has now become such a prolific breeder that it is colonizing the beaches of California.

title: Nurse in Queens Slain After She Opens Door To a Visitor at 4 A.M.
description: A 40-year-old nurse, roused from her sleep by knocking at the door of her Queens home, was shot dead at 4 A.M. yesterday moments after she opened the door, the police said.

title: WouldBe Pianist Becomes Architect, Businessman, Artist, Athlete
description: VICTOR ELMALEH is 60 years old now, and the how and why of the crucial event that shaped his life still mystifies him 54 years after it happened.

title: Pink Slips for White Collars, But Chrysler Gets a Boost
description: The prospects brightened a bit last week for the lossridden Chrysler Corporation. True, the Federal Government rejected its plea for a $1 billion bailout, but Treasury Secretary G. William Miller announced that the Carter Administration will help Chrysler formulate a loanguarantee plan to be submitted to Congress.

title: S. D. Stark Fianc Of Sarah E. Wald
description: The engagement of Sarah Elizabeth Wald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Wald of Chevy Chase, Md., to Steven David Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Stark of Bethesda, Md., has been announced by the future bride's parents. An Oct. 21 wedding in Washington is planned.

title: Long Island /This Week
description: CUTCHOGUE - Outdoor art show, sponsored by Old Town Arts and Crafts Guild; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday; Village Green.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: There is one thing to be said for Marxist art historians. They are more interested in the relations between art and life than our art histo- rians are. Or so it would seem, to judge by the excellent exhibition, titled Fotografia Polska, at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through Sept. 15.

title: `Streetcar at Drew
description: MADISON HE New Orleans flat of Stanley Kowalski is almost dark, except for a blue haze through which we see the motionless figure of Blanche DuBois.

title: New York's Inimitable Audiences
description: Believe me, coming to this city is an act of courage. In fact, I was advised not to come. I was told there was no gasoline, so nobody could drive to the theater. I was told the summer is a bad time. I was told I'd be playing against such favorites as Nureyev and Alonso. But I said to my well- meaning advisers, as pleasantly as possible, Oh, go to hell, everybody. We had to come, we had to test ourselves against the best.

title: Health Religion Energy
description: What will be next - air?

title: John Cardinal Wright Dies at 70; TopRanking American in Vatican
description: John Cardinal Wright, the highest ranking American in the Roman Catholic Church, died Friday in Cambridge, Mass., at the age of 70 years. He was a controversial figure in religious circles because of his strong espousal of such so- cial causes as civil rights and his stead- fast resistance to other causes, such as the ordination of women as priests.

title: Shading Windows Outside to Shun the Sun
description: N hot sunny days homeowners should do everything possible to keep the sun's heat from penetrating through windows and other openings. One of the steps often recommended is to close the drapes or pull the shades down when the sun is shining directly on the glass. especially on the east and west sides of the house. While these measures will undoubtedly help a great deal, it is much better to provide shade on the outside of the windows whenever possible in order to keep the sun's rays from ever striking the glass. Shading the glass on the outside before the s'n's rays get to it is about seven times more effective in helping keep the inside cool than blocking the sun off after it gets through the glass.

title: 300 Birds Die of Botulism
description: OCEANVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) About 300 birds in the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge have died of botulism in the last two weeks, and officials fear that many more will succumb unless there is a break in the weather. The ref- uge manager, Gaylord Inman, said the birds had died because stagnant water has a low oxygen and high alkaline content - conditions that, when combined with a warm temperature, are ideal for the growth of botulismcausing bacteria. Mr. Inman said the problem was confined to about 180 acres of marshland in the Barnegat section of the refuge in Ocean County.

title: NICARAGUA OFFICIAL WARNS U.S. ON ARMS
description: .QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 11 - A Sandiaist Government official said today that Nicaragua would turn to the Socialist bloc for weapons if the United States did not agree to a request the new regime has made for American arms.

title: 300 Will Be Dropped By N.F.L. Tuesday
description: On Tuesday, the 28 National Football League teams must cut their rosters to 60 players each, the first roster limit of the season, and thus about 300 players will leave the league, the hard work of a month in a hot training camp for naught. At least the anxiety is terminated.

title: Changes Wrought by 60's Youth Linger in American Life
description: DES MOINES  In thousands of small, almost imperceptible ways, in the routine transactions of daily work, play and family life, Woodstock nation is alive in Des Moines.

title: The Gentle Magic of The Javanese Gamelan
description: Ever since Debussy, Western composers have been facinated by the sound of the Javanese and Balinese gamelan, or bronze percussion orchestra. But long before Debussy, the West had accepted exotic strains into its culture, musical and otherwise. The interactions between East and West can be traced back to the Greek and Roman eras. Moorish influence on the music of Spain is clear, as are the vogues for Turkish effects in Mozart and Beethoven and for chinoiserie just a little bit later on.

title: Lee Holderby Sets Bridal for Aug. 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Holderby of Boulder, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lee An Holderby, to Stephen A. Marquard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Marquard of Quogue, L.I. The wedding will take place Aug. 25 in Boulder.

title: Joyce Ellen Rowe Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Joyce Ellen Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Rowe of Nashua, N.H., to Robert M. Michaels, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Michaels of Greenwich, Conn,, took place yesterday in St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in Nashua. The Rev. Thomas Peters performed the ceremony. The bride and her husband were graduated from Middlebury College. Mr. Michaels is studying for his master's degree in applied geophysics and Stanford University. His father is the editor of Forbes Magazine in New York. 1

title: GARDENING
description: THE American elm provided an abundance of cool summer shade, and grass grew well beneath its branches. For these reasons, it was perhaps the finest .of lawn trees until its demise from Dutch elm disease.

title: Mailbox: Baseball Not a Contact Sport
description: Murray Chass's article on baseball's injury problem (The New York Times, July 29) covered several possible causes of injuries that might be subject to correction and thereby result in a decrease in the frequency of incapacitation of players by trauma. Avoiding playing while fatigued, shortening the schedule and meticulous attention to the safety of playing areas all may have significant value.

title: Congressional Lines May Alter
description: WASHINGTON 111.11.11E rapid growth of Ocean and Sussex CAwriies arid the decline of Newark and other older cities mew that New Jersey will have to redraw its Congressional District boundaries after the 1980 census, according to information released by the Census Bureau.

title: The Slump of ;79: It Should Be Mild
description: Recession. Some of the sting has gone out of the word this time around, probably because so many people have known it was coming for so long. Eco- nomic forecasters, furthermore, don't expect a real blowout this year compared with the recession of 197475. But like all such slumps, this will have its own special character, and mild or not, some parts of the economy will suffer more than others.

title: FOOTNOTES ON THOSE HIGH HEELS
description: Women's shoes for this fall look fashionable and sexy, but they will, no doubt, rekindle discussion about the effect of high heels and imprisoned toes on one'\s health. Asking foot and leg experts in New York about the advisability of wearing highheeled shoes yields some interesting new information on that malady commonly referred to as my aching feet.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It is legally permissible to be drunk in public in New York City. But it is against the law to drink in public.

title: Computer Eviction Notices Jar Tenants
description: A Manhattan psychologist named Ann Fitzpatrick got a zloty surprise recently. She had been paying the rent on her Greenwich Village apartment by the tirst of the month for six years. But one mown ner check was a week late getting to the management firm's post

title: Surf Kayaking Rides a New Wave
description: tubes, left behind inner tubes, rafts and surfboards, 18-year-old Gavin Watson of Brookhaven has found a new ocean challengesurf kayaking.

title: Some.Shun DC10, but Passenger Load Is Normal
description: The United Airlines flight from Chi- cago to. Detroit was taxiing out for takeoff last week when Torn Saiiter, a 45-year-old supervisor for Michigan Bell, settled back for a snooze. He pulled down the window shadeand panicked.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE CITY OBSERVED: NEW YORK, by Paul Goldberger. (Random House. Cloth, $15. Paper, $7.95.) A highly informative, entertaining, even passionate guide to the architecture of Manhattan.

title: Canada's Park on the Pacific
description: Only the most stalwart of individuals originally chose to live in the raindrenched fishing villages of Tofino, Ucluelet or BamfieId on the southwest coast of Vancouver Island. They were drawn by the isolation, the simple, independent way of life and the beauty of the Pacific Ocean and the western Canadian seascape.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Wins Fifth ClapCourt Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (AP) Topseeded Chris Evert Lloyd won her fifth United States Open claycourt tennis championship tonight, defeating Evonne Goolagone. 64. 63.

title: Lithuania Is Home for Hottest Soviet Jazz Combo
description: VILNIUS, U.S.S.R. The hottest mod- ern jazz combo in the Soviet Union is based in Lithuania The musicians are pure Russian. The music they produce in the cool and Western atmosphere of this Baltic republic is something else again.

title: Chinese Test New Typesetter
description: PEKING, Aug. 11 (Reuters) - Re- searchers at Peking University have suc- cessfully tested a new computerlaser typesetting system, the Guangming. Daily said today. The newspaper said that the researchers had produced a one- page newspaper in Chinese characters, edited and laid out by their computerized laserphoto setting machine on July 27.

title: Israelis Charge A P.L.O. Tilt By Washington
description: Israel and the United States were ar. guing about a relationship between holy places and oily places, Dr. Yosef Burg, Israel's chief negotiator, said last week.

title: Roger Thompson Weds Gail Sandra Chem
description: Gail Sandra Chem, a secondyear law student, was married yesterday in Lancaster, Pa., to Roger Sherman Thompson, a New York lawyer. The ceremony was performed at the I arc Valley Resort Inn by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Wilson Boots, Methodist minister.

title: Other States Studying Georgia's Road Gangs As Economy Example
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (AP) - The chain gang has gone the way of the rock pile, but Georgia's three-year-old policy of putting inmates to work on road crews is drawing increasing attention from other states.

title: Bright Notes From String Quartets
description: It would be interesting to know how many American string quartets have been established over the past decade. To judge by recordings alone, dozens are now flourishing where only 25 years ago the Juilliard Quartet had the field pretty much to itself. One of the most talented groups to achieve prominence recently is the Cleveland Quartet which this year celebrates its tenth birthday. To mark the occasion, the four musicians have taken up that ultimate challenge of the repertory, the complete Beethoven quartets. The first installment in this series has just been released by RCA, an album devoted to the five middleperiod works.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The trouble with obscene Language in movies is that it's such a &%! *(?$! difficult subject to write about, and not just for reasons of taste. There are as many different reasons for a film to incorporate swearing as there are ways of expressing oneself when a hammer is inadvertently dropped on one's big toe. Sometimes the strong words are perfectly apt. Just as often, they can be embarrassingly illchosen. In any case, cursing comes in all styles and colors. It's a wise screenwriter who knows exactly which synonyms his or her characters ought to be using for Darn! or Scram! or Ouch!

title: Under the Volcano
description: THE packaging and promotion of ancient art have now attained successes undreamed of just a few decades ago. Tickets to the Tutankhamen show have brought out the kind of allnight queues usually seen before Horowitz concerts. The eruption of Vesuvius that wiped out Pompeii and adjacent places is a more familiar event now than it was in antiquity. The busi-

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Rental Housing Declines
description: RRY Truman was still President when Alfred Blackman, retired consulting engineer now 102 years old, moved into Greenwich Lodge, a 59unit apartment building on Lafayette Place in Greenwich.

title: You Can't . . .
description: pRESIDENT CARTER, in his turning point address to the nation on July 15, said at one point, And I'm asking you for your good and your nation's security, to take .... public transportation whenever you can.

title: STATE STUDY GROUP SUPPORTS 4 REGIONS FOR GAMING CASINOS
description: New York State's casinostudy panel issued its final report yesterday, recommending that casinos be permitted, subject to local approval, in only four areas of the state: New York City, including Manhattan's West Side, Coney Island and Rockaway; Long Beach in Nassau County; the Catskills resort area, and the Buf-

title: GARDENING Ground Cover Under Shade Trees
description: THE American elm provided an abundance of cool summer shade, and grass grew well beneath its branches. For these reasons, it was perhaps the finest of lawn trees until its demise from Dutch elm disease.

title: Alexandra Remmel Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Liveright Remmel of New York and Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of Mr. Remmel's daughter, Alexandra Cary Remmel, to Charles Carter Swoope Jr., son of Mrs. Swoope of Newton, Miss., and the late Mr. Swoope of Memphis.

title: Third Nuclear Sub Is Launched
description: GROTON, Conn., Aug. 11 (AP) - The U.S.S. La Jolla, taking her name from a California community, yesterday became the third nuclearpowered submarine to be launched at the Electric Boat shipyard this year. Nearly three years behind schedule, the 6,900ton sub slid into the Thames River shortly after noon.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: Washington Is Spending $60 Million on the Technology in 1979
description: There's something In the wind these days, and to growing number of people it's called energy, lots of it. While national attention to alternative energy sources is focused principally on the development of synthetic fuels and the like, there is also a movement to press back into service one of man's olc:ast forms of motive power, the windmill.

title: Brian Eno Slips Into Trance Music
description: Avantgarde Muzak? Actually, the concept is not as queer as it seems at first thought, since it dates back at least as far as the turn of the century and the French composer Erik Satie. Still, it's odd for a musician known primarily for his work in rock-and-roll to aspire to make a record that whispers subliminally in your ear, that is as ignorable as it is interesting. But that's precisely what Brian Eno, a founding father of Roxy Music, the producer of Talking Heads, and doyen of the New Wave, says he is up to in the liner notes to his seventh solo album, Ambient Music for Airports.

title: Other World Events
description: We are proud to have you in this country, President Carter told Ahmed Sekou Toure, President of Guinea, last week. Thus greeted, Mr. Toure began a weeklong visit the United States during which he will, among other things, seek more,American economic assistance. The words and the hospitality (though not on a state visit, Mr. Toure was allowed to bed down in Blair House) seemed to mark a sharp improvement in the United States diplomatic relations with Guinea. Not long ago, Guinea was regarded by the White House as too insensitive to human rights and much too cozy with the Soviet Union.

title: More Strangers Share Housing
description: Once it was mainly young career girls who shared apartments, but high rents and a scarcity of apartments have made the sharing of housing, even with total strangers, a growingly familiar phenomenon.

title: The Gas Club
description: What with the squeeze on gasoline, it's not surprising that someone would start looking for unorthodox solutions, not all of them entirely above board. Take the gasoline club. Last month Terrance Stewart and Mark Crockett placed an ad in the Kansas City Star soliciting memberships in Prestige Marketing Inc., a Missouribased gasoline club limited to 1,500 investors.

title: GARDENING
description: COMMUNITY gardening projects have become so commonplace these days that they scarcely merit a second glance. Yet occasionally one comes along that is unusual, such as the Long Island Food and Energy project at Friends World College in Lloyd Harbor.

title: New Report Describes Some Possible Effects Of a Chrysler Collapse
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) - A financial collapse by the Chrysler Corporation would trigger temporary instability in the nation's economy and mean a perma- nent loss of 200,000 to 300,000 jobs, a study prepared for the Congressional Budget Office concludes.

title: A Breeze From the East
description: Caldor department stores have sold 10,000 household electric fans in the last ten days. Merchandising Magazine says they are selling like dynamite. And who's skimming off the cream? Not General Electric or Westinghouse  they don't make them  but the Japanese, who in this case as in so many others have shown an uncanny knack for spotting new markets.

title: Shading Windows Outside to Shun the Sun
description: N hot sunny days homeowners should do everything possible to keep the sun's heat from penetrating through windows and other openings. One of the steps often recommended is to close the drapes or pull the shades down when the sun is shining directly on the glass. especially on the east and west sides of the house. While these measures will undoubtedly help a great deal, it is much better to provide shade on the outside of the windows whenever possible in order to keep the sun's rays from ever striking the glass. Shading the glass on the outside before the sun's rays get to it is about seven times more effective in helping keep the inside cool than blocking the sun off after it gets through the glass.

title: Klan Leader to Run in Jersey
description: BARNEGAT, N.J., Aug. 11 (UPI) David Duke, Imperial Wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, said today in a speech to 19 supporters at a rally here that he would enter the state's Democratic Presidential primary next year

title: Trustees Name an Acting President as the Search Team Regroups
description: For the last seven months, the Board of Trustees of the City University of New York has been playing beat-the-clock in an effort to name new presidents for Brooklyn, City and Hunter colleges. Usually, collegiate presidential search takes anywhere from year to a year and a half. But with the board's term due to expire Dec. 31, its members have been pushing to fill the three important vacancies before they leave.

title: Joan Barbara Weiss Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Weiss of Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Barbara Weiss, to Barry N. Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Kaplan of Cranbury, N.J. Miss Weiss, a graduate of Hofstra Law School, and her fianc, Brooklyn Law School alumnus who is with the New York law firm of Kraditor & Haber.

title: Namibia Ends Curb on Blacks
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug,11 (UPI) - A law barring blacks from living in whites only residential areas was offically abolished today as the first step of a plan to end all racial discrimination in the disputed territory. Under the new law, people of all races can now buy; own, rent or live in a house in any area previously reserved for whites.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of author Shirley Frances Barker (191165), I would like to hear from anyone having anecdotes, papers, letters, photographs or other materials relating to her, her family, associates and work.

title: Hanoi Raises Doubts on Letting American Consuls See Refugees
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 11 - Vietnam threw into doubt American hopes of sending consular officials to Ho Chi Minh City to screen thousands of requests by Vietnamese citizens to emigrate to the United States.HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 11 (AP) - Representative Lester L. Wolff said today that he was told that Vietnam would allow American planes to fly to Ho Chi Minh City at any time to pick up 258 refu-

title: Martha McDowell Affianced
description: Martha Murray McDowell, a senior at the University of Cincinnati, plans to be married next month in New Haven to Dmitri Romanoff Ilyinsky, son of Mr. ad Mrs. Paul R. Ilyinsky of Cincinnati. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Richard 0. Pollard of North Haven, Conn., and Edward I. McDowell Jr. of Hamden, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Salvador Clergy Protests Killing
description: SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 11 (AP) Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador called a meeting of El Salvador's clergy today to protest the assassiA nations of six priests in two years, the latest on Aug. 4. The White Warriors Union, a rightwing terrorist group, has claimed responsibility for the assassinations.

title: INTERVIEW
description: JERSEY CITY L1 ne is a member of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, Harold Krieger, the County Counsel of Hudson County, says: I'm not good planner; I'm a realist. I want to see it in being. It's always been disturbing to me because, whether it's the city, the county, the state or the regional association, they always draw plans and plans and plans, and we never see any fruition of the plans.

title: PowerMower Users Urged to Play It Safe
description: NEW JERSEY man took it into his head to trim the top of the hedges in front of his home with a power lawnmower. He was hoisting up the heavy machine when he caught his hand in the rotary blade, amputating one of his fingers.

title: Bust of Dr. King Unveiled
description: SELMA, Ala., Aug. 11 (UPI)  Civil rights leaders unveiled a bronze bust of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today in front of a church where he began several civil rights marches in the 1960's.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Numismatics has a new Piece, which has laid claim to the title of world's. most valu able coin' It is a Brasher doubloon the first to appear at public auction in more than half a century.

title: The Nation
description: A Senate report alleging widespread Spying and harassment by foreign agents in the United States caused a thunderstorm of denials in Washingtoil last week. Although no one pretended to be surprised by the presence of foreign operatives, officials were wet over what they called unfounded conclusions, especially charges that Washington gave the agents free rein, and in some cases cooperation, in acting against foreign nationals here.

title: The Quiet Battle Behind the Yankee Plate
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 11  Brad Gulden had finished putting on his Yankee uniform and now, sitting on the stool in front of his locker at Memorial Stadium, he was talking with a visitor. As he spoke, however, his eyes darted around the clubhouse, following the progress of his new teammates.

title: On the Making of Modern China
description: AMONG all the great revolutions, the Chinese revolution of the past hundred years has been, in many ways, the most authentically Marxist. It did not take place in a rich industrial society, but revolutions have never been effected in such a society. However, it is the only revolution that, in line with Marx's prediction, moved to socialize after a long era of capitalism and with a dynamic roughly compatible to the one Marx postulated. By the 19th century, China

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The leading edge of the world's largest oil spill, the 60 million and more gallons that have been pouring from

title: Seoul Opposition Leader Says Raid Was Part of Park's War on Critics
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 11 - The leader of South Korea's largest opposition party alleged today that an attack by the police on his headquarters in which woman was killed and scores of people injured was part of a systematic campaign against the opposition by President Park Chung Hee.

title: No More Gas Ever
description: KINGSTON, N.Y. - Slowly, the gasoline seems to be returning to the towns and villages of Ulster County, as it is almost everywhere else. The No Gas signs are still around, but less so. Service stations are staying open a little later now; some are even pumping on Sundays again.

title: `Boat People Find a Haven in the State
description: MORRISTOWN

title: Now, Home Movies
description: VIM FORMER showman has brought entertainment techniques into the realestate business, in the form of movies of houses for sale.

title: Simms Goes Against His Idol, Bradshaw
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 - The man Who resembles Phil Simms, but with less blond hair and a lot more National Football League statistics, had some advice for the Giants rookie quarterback.

title: Miss Ekblom Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Harry E. Ekblom, chairman and chief executive of the European American Bank, and Mrs. Ekblom of Ridgewood, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Maryann L.H. Ekblom, to Lieut. Robert James Cudd, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Cudd of Wilmar, Minn.

title: CONGRESS TO DEBATE MERCHANT SHIP RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 - A House committee has set the stage for a national debate this fall on the future of the United States merchant marine, with draft legislation aimed at revitalizing the dwindling fleet. Industry officials say it is the largest attempt at shipping reform since 1916

title: Rainout Postpones Managerial Battle

Muzorewa's fourmonthold Government, called for an allparties conference in London to draft a new constitution that would eliminate the white minority's continuing political control. After that, Britain would supervise new elections.

title: DANCE VIEW

The other is that the festival's board of trustees has named Liz Thompson, a dancer-choreographeradministrator from New York, to succeed Mr. Walker in September.

title: ART VIEW

Sometimes they can ignore it: it not likely, for instance, that we shall ever see modern art in either the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, the Dahlem Museum in Berlin, or the Uffizi in Florence. The collections in question are so big, distinguished and so selfevidently the product of a particular phase in history that no one wants to see them burdened with a flimsy and irrelevant appendix.

title: Headliners
description: As if being out of power for two years were not enough grief, Israel's Labor Party now has to deal with a savage personal dogfight between its two top dogs. Yitzhak Rabin, who was Labor Prime Minister from 1974 to 1977, has begun serial publication of his autobiography, and the naughty parts of the book appear to be blistering attacks on Shimon Peres, Mr. Rabin's Defense Minister at the time and his successor as party leader. Mr. Rabin reportedly accuses Mr. Peres of lying, leaking classified information and trying to subvert his Government, though full details of the accusations have not yet appeared. In one case, however, Mr. Rabin is said to allege that when he threatened the entire cabinet with a lie detector test to find out, who was leaking, he saw Peres turn pale as he objected and it all became clear. For his part, Mr. Peres has declined formal comment but said There are standards even in political life and we will have to take the damage which Rabin did to the party into ac-

title: The Day Peace Returned
description: IT was a summer afternoon in 1945, no warmer or cooler than any other that August. My sister and I, both in our early teens, had dates that evening for the seven o'clock show at the nearby Larchmont movie theater. I was going with a local boy and she, always more adventurous than I, had got a date with the out-oftown lifeguard from the Larchmont Shore Club.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Eddie Feigner, the undisputed king of softball, will bring his fourman team to Memorial Stadium, Garden Avenue and Sanford Boulevard, Mount Vernon, at 8 P.M. Wednesday to play the Hantscho Machinists, a winning local team. It will be the 25th appearance in Mount Vernon of the team known as the King and His Court.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Before Milford was a town it was an oystering, center, and it is said that there are chronicles that record 50-foothigh mounds of oyster shells in 1752. with Indians coming from miles around for wit& feasts. Be that as it may, the Fifth Annual Milford Oyster Festival will take place from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. on Saturday, and orders have been placed for 17,000 oysters to be served on the halfshell or roasted over charcoal, for dozens of pounds of breaded oysters for frying and for gallons of oyster chowder.

title: The Traveler's Bookshelf
description: A garden is a lovesome thing, God wot, quoth the poet (Thomas Edward Brown, 1830-07, if you. must know ) and many travelers will agree. For them, we have a splendid new guide to the parks and gardens of Europe. And, since lovesome is in the eye of the beholder, books on divers other subjects  from antiques to Atlantic City  as well.

title: Added Electrification For L.LR.R. Unlikely Under Gabreski Policy
description: Extension of electrification on the Long Island Rail Road, held out to harried commuters for years as a solution to many of the line's difficulties, has been dropped from the railroad's immediate plans and apparently may never be fulfilled.

title: Inwood Split on Hall's Future
description: INWOOD

title: Pamela Whitley Leib Married
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday Pamela Whitley Leib, daughter of Gordon B. Leib and MIS. H. Clifton Whiteman, both of New York, was married to Decatur Sawyer Higgins Jr., son Of Mr. and Mrs. Higgins of Locust Valley, L.I., and a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant. The Rev. Richard Cosnotti performed the ceremony.

title: CONFLICT OVER THE CABINET
description: Was it worth it to you to cause some destabilization of the dollar, some demoralization of the Federal Government, spreading doubt throughout the land, in order to repudiate much of your Cabinet? That question, posed by a reporter at President Carter's news conference on July 25, offered a small sampling of the risks faced by Presidents who fire their Cabinet officers.

title: Whereas the Party of the First Part Said to the Party of the Second Part...
description: THE PlainLanguage Law is the fruition of an idea whose time has come. It is to be hoped that it is just a humble beginning. Perhaps in 50 years, we may become like China and have no lawyers.

title: DINENG OUT
description: THERE are hot dogs and there are hot dogs. There are allbeef hot dogs, kosher hot dogs, pork hot dogs, even chicken hot dogs. There are hot dogs sold in big restaurants New York City and at roadside stands, under yellowandblue umbrellas and from the sides of stainlesscteel trucks_

title: Bolshoi Ballet: Miss Semenyaka Back
description: CHOREOGRAPRICALLY, the Bolshoi Ballet's offerings at he Metropolitan Opera House may not be to everyone's taste. Yet, as some weekend cast changes demonstrated, whatever one may think of the repertory, one can only admire the dancers fervor.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Archdiocese Seeking to Have Pope Meet People in Two City Stadiums
description: Roman Catholic Church officials in New York City and the Vatican are discussing a program that would have Pope John Paul H visit with some of the city's poorest residents as well as greet people at Shea and Yankee Stadiums during a whirlwind stay of about 24 hours here in October.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE only difficulty I face in praising Geoffrey Wolff's remarkable The Duke of Deception: Memories of My Father is deciding what about it I admire most. As a portrait of Arthur Samuels Wolff, known as Duke for his aristocratic tastes and manners, it is simply superb. Mr. Wolff manages, without pulling any punches, to convey the full horror of the man, whose appearance did not exactly match his reality. Duke would have had you believe that he was a highborn Wasp who graduated from Groton, Yale (Skull and Bones), and the Sorbonne (in engineering!); that he was married to the daughter of a rear admiral; that he flew for the Royal Air Force, transferred to the O.S.S., and then served as a sapper for the French Resistance, which he pronounced RayZeeStaunce, and that the gold signet ring with its motto, Nulls Vestigium Retorsit (Don't look back, he claimed it meant) had come down to him from distinguished ancestors.

title: C.I.A FINDS OUTPUT OF IRAN OIL AT LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  Iranian oil production will be permanently re- stricted to its current level of four million barrels a day and could drop to 2.9 million barrels by 1985 if the nation continues to neglect its oilfields for three or four more months, oil analysts at the Central Intelli- gence Agency said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: I am confused as to the rules governing trades in major league baseball. What is a waiver, and when is it required? Mickey Rivers needed to clear waivers, but did Dick Tidrow and Bobby Murcer?

title: 'scandinavization
description: WALPOLE, Mass.  The most obvi- ous developments can be obscured by the weight of established thought. Such is the case with the abandonment of warfare as a means of pursuing na- tional goals  a process we may call Scandinavization because of its his- torical and geographical origins.

title: De Gustibus Chicken's Feet Help
description: Not long ago, a reader wrote to say that her mother  from the other side  always made chicken soup with chicken feet. We agreed that the feet, because of their gelatinous nature, do contribute a great deal to soup. She wondered, however, how to go about ridding the feet of their yellow outer coating because the color imparts itself to the broth.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERDorothy Gordon. August 11, 1979, 74 years Beloved wife of Sidney Alexander. Also survived by children, Mrs. Joy Gordon Eisenberg and Dr. Joseph Gordon, daughter-in-law. Mrs Marione Gordon. and six grandchildren. Gordon, David, Daniel, Derek, Amy, and Seth Services 12 Noon, August 13, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, L I.

title: Decade of Change for 60's Youth Altered Living Styles but Not Some Attitudes
description: Carol Green remembers feeling that there were infinite possibilities in the late 1960's. She was 22 years old in the sum- mer of 1969, had just dropped out of col- lege to learn what real life was all about and was unemployed. Then one day in June a friend called and invited her to go to upstate New York and help set up the Woodstock Festival.

title: LI Fireworks Concern Takes Prize in Monaco
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Aug. 12 (AP)  On the strength of a spectacular finale, a Bellport, L.I., fireworks concern has won Monaco's 14th annual International Fireworks Competition, considered by many enthusiasts to be an unofficial world championship.

title: TV: A Biography of the Hudson River
description: IF nothing else, Henry Hudson's River: A Biography, which will be seen from 10:30 to midnight tonight on WNETTV, demonstrates that it is possible to make documentary about that waterway without showing or even mentioning the George Washington, Tappan Zee or Bear Mountain Bridges, the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, or the Indian Point nuclear power station.

title: Houston Has Misgivings Over Problems of Growth
description: HOU4TON, Aug. 12  Jim McConn, the Mayor of the Golden Buckle on the Sun Belt, stood amid the smoking rubble of Houston's worst fire since a lantern upended in a barroom brawl burned down 40 souare blocks back in 1912.

title: Italian Cabinet Wins Senate Vote
description: ROME, Aug. 12  The new Goiernment of Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga won a vote of confidence in the Senate today and promised quick action on Italy's pressing economic problems including inflation, housing and energy.

title: U.S. Plans a Suit Assailing Police In Philadelphia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  The Justice Department accuses the entire Philadel- phia Police Department of widespread and systematic brutality in a civil rights suit that the Federal Government is ex- pected to file tomorrow in Federal Dis- trict Court in Philadelphia.

title: Storm Drenches Area, Toppling Trees and Cutting Power Lines
description: Joel Bronson checking damage to his car after storm felled tree outside his home in Falls Village, Conn. Ends of tree limbs were cut to facilitate removal. Rain fell on region for third consecutive day, causing power failures and creating hazardous driving conditions. Accompany- ing winds toppled some trees in suburban areas. Page B4.

title: Connors Stops Vilas, 61, 26, 64
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (AP) Jimmy Connors survived a shaky second set and defeated Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 61, 26, 69, today to capture the United States open clay court tennis championship for the fourth time in six years.

title: Deaths
description: O'TOOLETheresa M. On August 9, 1979 At her residence. Beloved wife of the tate Edward. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 25PM and 79PM, Mass of Christian burial Chapel St. Vincents Hospital, 153 West 11 Street, N.Y.0 Monday, 10:00 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of N.Y.

title: Entertainment Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA. Avery Fisher Hall, 8. Preconcert recital, 7.

title: Commodities
description: H.J. Maidenberg

title: Steinbrenner Checking Yanks Conduct
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 12 (UPI) - George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, said today that he was looking into ports that his players autographed and photographed a young woman's bare bottom during a recent trip to Chicago.

title: Political Controversies Surround War Film Being Shot in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea

title: Seaver Gets 9th Victory in Row
description: When a veteran pitcher loses that extra zip on his fastball, he either changes his style or retires. At age 35, Tom Seaver would rather switch than bow to his age.

title: Lincoln Center Outdoor Festival Starts Tomorrow
description: Clowns and chamber music; mimes, magicians and Maxine Sullivan; the Sylvan Wind Quintet children's theater; the Art Blakey, Billy Taylor and David Eyges jazz groups; Asian, Latin and Trinidadian dance and street theater companies; bluegrass music, Broadway music and Dinizulu and His African Dancers, Singers and Drummers  these are some of the entertainments scheduled for Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors Festival, which will run for 18 days starting tomorrow.

title: Chinese Will Try to Halt Growth Of Population by End of Century
description: PEKING, Aug. 12  China has committed itself to achieving zero population growth between 1985 and 2000 and will punish through taxation and other ecopomic measures couples wbo have more than two children, according to Deputy Prime Minister Chen Muhua.

title: Upstate Tramway Riders Make Unexpected Exit
description: A young visitor to the Storytown Amusement Park near Lake George, N.Y., being carried down a ladder Saturday by a volunteer fireman as other riders In stranded tramway car waited their turn. Fifty people were stranded for up to two hours when ride malfunctioned. No one was injured in the incident

title: 164 Klan Marchers in Alabama Arrested Over Permit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 12  One hundred and sixtyfour Ku Klux Klan members submitted to arrest without violence today on charges of marching without a parade permit on a highway outside Montgomery.

title: St. Lucia, Newly Free, Feels Winds of Political Violence
description: CASTRIES, St. Lucia, Aug. 10  Chase Manhattan and other downtown banks and businesses in the capital of this new island nation are wearing plywood windows these days, and few tourists venture from their beachfront hotels into the city shops.

title: Earthquake Rocks Tokyo Region
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  A fairly strong earthquake jolted the Tokyo area today but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. Japan's meteorological service said the earthquake's epicenter was off the coast of Chiba, south of Tokyo.

title: Advertising
description: How is Madison Avenue's fastestgrowing agency faring in period of recession, inflation and soaring energy costs, not to mention agency shifts?

title: $60,000 Question: Who Forgot theCash?
description: Somebody  no one yet knows who  forgot to put a canvas moneybag containing $60,000 into the vault at the Richmond County Savings Bank at the close of business Friday afternoon. Instead, the bag was left under the head teller's desk when everybody went home.

title: Patriots Beaten, 153; Rams Find a Punter
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 12  Pro football's preseason games are supposed to help the veteran players get in shape, give the coaches a clue as to which new players to keep or cut, and provide the fans with an idea of what to expect when the real games begin.

title: Book by U.S. Catholics On Sex Assailed in Rome
description: The Vatican has criticized a book on human sexuality that was commissioned by the Catholic Theological Society of America and nublished two years ago.

title: Montanez Traded to Rangers
description: The New York Mets traded the highestsalaried player in their history last night when they sent Willie Montanez to the Texas Rangers for two players who will be named and delivered later.

title: A Quiet Crusader for Civil Rights, Still Active at 67
description: The Great Depression was ripping apart the seams of American life, but Dorothy Irene Height, then a shy teenager in Rankin, Pa., was determined to find the financial means to attend college.

title: Confederate Warship May Have Live Shells
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 12 (AP) The Confederate ironclad Georgia, mired in Savannah River mud since 1869, may still be loaded with live and possibly very unstable ammunition.

title: Laurence M. Stern, a Top Editor Of Washington Post, Dies at 50
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  Laurence M. Stern, an assistant managing editor at The Washington Post, died yesterday of probable heart attack while jogging at Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where he was vacationing with friends. He was 50 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: METULLA, Israel, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Israeli military authorities today denied reports on Lebanon's staterun Beirut Radio that Israeli commandos attacked southern Lebanon by air and sea last night.

title: Markets Await Fed Rate Move
description: The credit markets will focus on tomorrow's monthly meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, and the guessing on Wall Street calls for tightening move in credit policy.

title: Rain Washes Out Beth Daniel's Big Edge
description: JERICHO, LI., Aug. 12 Beth Daniel qualified for the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour in January, played in her first tournament in midFebruary and said today, When came out I thought I would win in the first two months.

title: Social Services Appointment
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Norris Phillips, executive director of the BedfordStuyvesant Community Mental Health Center of Brooklyn, has been named deputy commissioner for the services division of the State Department of Social Services. His salary will be $44,940 a year.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Replacing bothersome paper cups and unsanitary pail dippers is team drinking fountain called the Gunga Din, a polyethylene tank that comes with a pump handle for building up pressure. When you squeeze the brass nozzle at the end of a hose, a steady stream of water emerges. A wide opening allows you to put in chunks of ice, and a coneshaped mouth guard on the nozzle prevents lips from making contact. The threegallon size sells for $64.15, plus $1.40 for postage, with a twowheel cart as an option for $25.80, plus $1.42 for postage. The twogallon size $45.75, plus $1.32 (no cart available). All can be ordered from the B. & Equipment Company, Applebutter Road, Plumsteadville, Pa. 18949, (215) 7668811.

title: New England CB User Aids Caribbean Rescue
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 12 (AP)  A quirk in the atmosphere and the alertness of a CB operator in New Hampshire's White Mountains sparked a rescue that saved the lives of four Americans adrift thousands of miles away off Colombia's Caribbean coast, the authorities said today.

title: BUSINESS  Digest
description: The average American faces a much lower standard of living the 1980s unless the nation's productivity growth accelerates soon, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress warned. The committee, influential in that many of its members head such other powerful bodies as banking, finance and ways and means committees, said its midyear economic review that productivity would be the economic lynchpin of the 1900's. [Page Al.]

title: Comex Offering Futures Permits
description: The New York Commodity Exchange is selling 100 permits to trade in its new financial instrument futures at $10,000 each on a firstcome, firstserved basis, Comex announced over the weekend. The exchange is the world's largest metals futures market, trading in gold, silver, copper and zinc contracts.

title: A Slice of the 50's Reappears as Hot Rudders Meet at Midwest Drag Strip
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Aug. 12  Gas crisis? What crisis?

title: Washington Watch
description: Clyde H. Farnsworth

title: Pell Clan: A Nice Little Thing to Belong to
description: TICONDEROGA, N.Y. More than half a century ago, a young woman named Pyrma Tilton, who lived in Tuxedo. N.Y., was taken to the Pavilion at Fort Ticonderoga to meet various members of the Pell family who had just become her relatives by marriage. Miss Tilton's mother had remarried, and her stepfather's name was Herbert Pall.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: New Brunswick AT A GLANCE
description: For 300 years a commercial center along the Raritan River, this 5.5squaremile city is the seat of government of Middlesex County. Many reminders of its riverfront past can be found in the Hiram Market area, now a predominantly Hispanic neighborhood.

title: Eurobonds Draw U.S. Companies
description: BONN, Aug. 12 United States cornpanies, faced with tight money and high interest rates at home, have flocked in record numbers this year to the Eurobond market in an attempt to shave their borrowing costs.

title: Sudan Vice President Ousted Amid Protests Over Increase in Prices
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 12 (AP)  President Gaafar alNimeiry dismissed the secondranking official in his Government today in an apparent effort to defuse continuing unrest over rises in the price of food and fuel.

title: Baptists Evangelizing Greek Immigrants in Boston
description: In a dispute that raises questions about missionary efforts among ethnic Americans, officials of the Greek Orthodox Church in America are criticizing the Southern Baptist Convention's appointment of a Greekspeaking couple to do evangelical work among Greek immiirrants in Boston.

title: Overskate Overtakes Timbo To Win Saratoga's Baruch Cap
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13  J.H. Stafford's Canadianbred Overskate won his seventh consecutive race of the year today by taking the 21st running of the Bernard Baruch Handicap before a small crowd of 19,477 that braved a steady downpour.

title: Poor Opposing New Brunswick Project
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  A much- heralded $150 million redevelopment project in this small, decaying city on the banks of the Raritan River faces mount- ing opposition by lowincome black and Hispanic residents who believe that the project, known as New Brunswick Tomorrow, holds no promise for them.

title: Movers Cutting Backlog Of a Long, Dry Summer
description: The diesel fuel shortage and accompanying fuel price increases combined with the strike of independent owneroperator truck drivers in early June left the companies in confusion and saw families around the nation waiting for as long as two months to have furniture and possessions picked up and delivered to new homes.

title: Miller Following a Tough Act, But Orioles Are Glad He's Back
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 12  According to Earl Weaver, the Baltimore manager, the man who replaced George Bamberger as the Orioles pitching coach last year has exhibited good judgment on pitchers, worked hard, handled his assignments properly and done his job without complaining.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Late last week, just about a month after the formation of Great Lakes International as the holding company for Great Lakes Dredge and Dock Company, the concerns announced new titles for the top two officers, effective Sept. 1. John A. Downs, president of Dredge and Dock, was elected chairman and chief executive officer of both companies, while William L. Colnon, executive vice president of Dredge and Dock, was named president of both.

title: Sports Briefs
description: SILVERSTONE, England, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Kenny Roberts of the United States virtually assured his second straight world 500cubiccentimeter motorcycle championship today when he scored a narrow victory in the British Grand Prix.

title: Apollo Defeated
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 12  The New York Apollo fell within 1 point of elimination from playoff contention by dropping a 10 decision to the New Jersey Americans in overtime today.

title: P.L.O. LEADERS WARN U.N. ON RESOLUTION
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 12 (AP) The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it would reject any United Nations resolution that did not explicitly recognize the Palestinians right to an independent state.

title: LAG IN PRODUCTIVITY CALLED MAJOR PERIL TO LIVING STANDARD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  The aver- age American is likely to see his standard of living drastically reduced in the 1980's unless productivity growth is accelerat- ed, the Joint Economic Committee, a Congressional body, warnedtoday.

title: Solar Energy Incentives Spur Development
description: In the legislatures and on local councils, in the courts and over blueprints. Americans have begun to lay a legal and economic foundation for the future use of power from the sun.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOOD CITIZEN Chita Rivera's lustrous career on Broadway and her activities in behalf of civic betterment will be saluted today in City Halt Plaza. At 12:30 P.M., Mayor Koch will present New York's Certificate of Appreciation to the dancersinger, followed by musical tribute to Miss Rivera featuring Jose Ferrer and the American Dance Machine. The guest of honor will then reprise America and All That Jazz, two milestone numbers she introduced in West Side Story and Chicago.

title: The Editorial Notebook On Losing Productivity  and Face
description: Japan's largest industrial combine, the Mitsubishi Group, is embarrassed that its cars are imported into the United States by the faltering Chrysler Corporation. Mitsubishi fears that its proud image as Japan's top business group could be tarnished by Chrysler's bad management and poor labor relations. A wellrun Japanese corporation simply doesn't consort with such associates. But it is this country that should be embarrassed not so much by Chrysler as by the poor productivity of American industrial performance as a whole.

title: Greenland As Part Of the U.S.
description: PLANTATION, Fla.  Perched near the top of the world, protecting Canada's northeastern edge from the Arctic Ocean's cold blasts, Green- land's iceencrusted mountainrange shores have long been forbidding and desolate.

title: Chrysler Cites Curbs On Costs
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP)  A Chrysler Corporation spokesman said today said President Carter must have been unaware of the troubled auto maker's costcontainment efforts when he said the company, which is seeking Federal aid, could make sacrifices to

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (RadioWINS, 7:50 P.M.)

title: Escaped Rapist Holds 3 Captive In Upstate Siege
description: More than 100 lawenforcement offi- cers this morning surrounded a house in rural Gardiner, N.Y., about 20 miles south of Kingston, where they said an es- caped convict was holding a man, his pre- gant wife and their 6-year-old son hos- tage.

title: Around the Nation
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 12 (AP)  The huge oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico has resumed a slow northward movement, and experts conceded today that they did not know where it would go next.

title: 25,000 Trout Killed by Vandals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 12 (Reuters) Vandals killed 25,000 brown trout valued at more than $7,000 at an experimental hatchery in Leetown, W. Va., last week, the Interior Department disclosed Friday. The vandals reportedly entered the department's National Fisheries Center and caused the water to drain out of two 100-foot-long outdoor fish tanks, suffocating the fish. Governmentoperated hatcheries produce more than six million pounds of fish annually for stocking waters.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Nicaraguan Says Red Bloc Won't Be Asked for Arms
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 12 Nicaragua's Interior Minister said today that the country would avoid buying arms from Communist nations in order not to give pretext to feelings that we are aligning ourselves with them political- ly.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Adagio in G minor, Albinoni; Sonata in B flat for Recorder, Oboe, Violin and Continuo, Fasch; Concerto in D for Guitar and Orchestra, Vivaldi.

description: 10, 1979, beloved mother of Sally Harris and David Harris, both of NYC and daughter of Walter A. Wurth of Cranford, N.J sister of Mrs Marcia Gorrie of Columbia, Md Graveside services Tuesday, 11AM at Marshall Cemetery, South Newbury, N.H Please omit flowers. description: SAILING TODAY

title: Tanker Oil Spill in Delaware Bay
description: DELAWARE CITY, Del., Aug. 12 (AP)  Several hundred gallons of oil spread along Delaware Bay yesterday when fuel lines from a tanker ship broke in stormy weather Friday night, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Undefeated Leonard Stops Ranzany in 4th
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 12 (AP) Sugar Ray Leonard used a flashing series of left hooks to stop Pete Ranzany at 2 minutes 41 seconds of the fourth round today and win the North American Boxing Federation welterweight title.

title: Pool Players Shooting for Title
description: Since the fee to enter the $100,000 World Open Pocket Billiards championship is $350, it is not surprising that each of the 48 players does not think of the remaining 47 as a possible winner of the weeklong event that began last night in the Embassy Ballroom of the Holiday Inn on West 57th Street.

title: Gottfried Triumphs
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP) Brian Gottfried scored a surprisingly easy 63, 60 victory over the topseeded Eddie Dibbs to win a $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today at Muirfeld Village.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Carter Mystery: I
description: BOSTON, Aug. 12  When Jimmy Carter emerged from political obscuri- ty, in 1975 and 1976, he made his way by meeting small groups of people and im- pressing them with his intelligence, his sensitivity. his inner confidence. He

title: Going Fishing at Thousand Islands
description: To fish the Canadian waters in the Thousand Islands area, an Ontario license is needed. Nonresidents must pay $6 for three days or $10.75 for the season.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Trash Company Loses in Struggle To Keep License
description: The revocation of the license of the city's largest private carter has been up- held by Justice Jerome W. Marks of the State Supreme Court.

title: Riverside to Do Henry IV On Columbia's Campus
description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company, a New York City theatrical group that since 1977 has been offering free performances of Shakespeare's plays, will present Henry IV (Part I) starting Aug. 24. The play, directed by Stuart McDowell, will be presented outdoors in the Van Am Quadrangle of Columbia University, east of Columbia's main gate at 116th Street and Broadway. It will run Wednesday through Sunday evenings at 8 until Sept. 9. For information call 2223581.

title: Cosmos Top Diplomats, 54; Face Blizzard in Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ., Aug. 12  The Cosmos defeated the Washington Diplomats, 54, in a shootout tonight at Giants Stadium, but their attention was in Canada, where the Toronto Blizzard defeated the Philadelphia Fury by 43 and became the Cosmos opponent in the first round of the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: The City
description: There were no new developments yesterday in the investigations into the disappearance of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who was last seen Aug. 2 at his apartment in the %Pierre Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street.

title: A New Premier To Lead Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 12  Francesco Cossiga, the new Prime Minister of Italy, combines the reputation of a tough practical politician with the benign and witty manner of a slightly distracted professor.

title: News Summary
description: A battle in Teheran between Islamic militants and demonstrating leftists in- . jured hundreds of people. It was the most serious outbreak there since the street riots six months ago that resulted in the Shah's departure. About 4,000 people clashed and thousands of others took part in the demonstrations, called to protest new Government controls on the press [Page Al, Col. 6.]

title: Ivy Greenstein Is Married to Christopher John Doolittle
description: Ivy Jane Greenstein and Christopher John Doolittle, who graduated with the class of 18 from Kirkland and Hamilton Colleges, respectively, were married in Cresskill, N.J., yesterday. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Robert Greenstein. He was assisted by the Rev. George Haley of the Clarence (N.Y.) United Methodist Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Doolittle of Williamsville, N.Y.

title: Browns Get Alzado For Draft Choices
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP)  The Cleveland Browns announced today that they had obtained Lyle Alzado, the allpro defensive end, from the Denver Broncos in exchange for unspecified future draft choices in 1980 and 1981.

title: Woodstock, Long Decade Later
description: POPULAR music has changed enormously in the decade since Woodstock. Some of the artists who performed there are still with us; others have fallen by the wayside. Today the bulk of popular performers came to prominence during the 1970's. But much of their impact is determined now by a radically different set of presuppositions, both within the music business and in the society at large.

title: CarterKennedy Issue Splits Democrats
description: The growing split in the Democratic Party over a Presidential nominee next year is dramatically demonstrated in New York, where the second- and thirdranking Democratic state offi- cials are on opposite sides of the fence.

title: A.B.A. WEIGHS POLICY ON LAW SPECIALITIES
description: DALLAS, Aug. 12  The American Bar Association, responding to fundamental changes in the legal profession, is moving toward recognizing and regulating specialization in the practice of law.

title: Sheriff's Deputies Back on Job
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP) Alameda County sheriff's deputies returned to work yesterday after three days in which most of the county's 481 deputies called in sick. A spokesman at the sheriff's office said that the department was operating at full strength. The deputies, who are demanding higher pay and improved fringe benefits, began staying off the job Wednesday. The county has offered the deputies an 8 percent wage increase; they are asking for 12.2 percent.

title: Hundreds Die in India As Dam Break Frees 20Foot Water Wall
description: By The Associated Press

title: Nurturing Democracy in the Andes
description: We cheered earlier this year when Ecuador and Bolivia elected new presidents to replace their military regimes. But we also held our breath, knowing that such transitions sometimes go awry between polling day and inauguration day  especially where, as in both these countries, the voters choose candidates not favored by the soldiers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Committee of Conference on the Law of the Sea  9:30 A.M.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Hymns Accompany Treaty Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska and a junior member of the Armed Services Committee, was asking Secre- tary of Defense Harold Brown whether it was true that by making adjust- ments in the burst height of our nuclear weapons the United States could mainly negate the protection of bomb shelters for the Russian popula- tion.

title: My Kingdom For a PinchHit
description: THE baseball season is getting to the stage where manager will try almost anything to win a game, score a run or even get a hit. You know, any little thing: like Gene Mauch's sending up seven consecutive pinchhitters for the Minnesota Twins the other night.

title: No Medical Utopia
description: What Murphy's Law is to technology  for example, the DC10  Powell's Law is to medicine. Yet curiously Powell's Law has gone virtually un- mentioned in the current debate over national health insurance.

title: Jennifer Moore Is Bride Of Ron Rieger Kopito
description: Jennifer Mills Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Moore of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Ron Rieger Kopito, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kopito of Brookline, Mass. Town Justice Susan R. Shimer of North Castle, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Moore home.

title: HighWire Walker Finds New Challenges to Span
description: In the dark gymnasium, Philippe Petit is strolling, like a thinker spirit- ually exalted above a crowd, 20 feet over the freethrow lines painted on the wood floor.

title: The O'Malley, Pro and Con
description: WITH a cigar in one hand and a Scotch in the other, Walter O'Malley ambled about World Series headquarters in the basement of Brooklyn's Bossert Hotel, a suitably genial host. He stopped to exchange pleasantries with a pair of newspapermen, and as he moved on, one of them gazed after him. Nice man, he remarked. His companion agreed with reservations. Yes, he said, a little too much the grand seigneur for my taste.

title: U.S. Athletes Look to Moscow: Optimism but Apprehension
description: HIS name is not a household word, unless the house happens to be Pistol Patties in Stillwater, Okla. At Pistol Patties, a pub of which he is part owner, no one messes with Jimmy Jackson. Then again, no one messes with Jimmy Jackson anywhere. He stands 6 feet 6 inches and weighs 350 pounds.

title: Trial Run for the Marathon but, With Any Luck, Not the Weather
description: A group of 20 specially invited longdistance runners in the rain on the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge yesterday at the start of the Baked Apple Invitational. It was the fourth annual fulldress rehearsal for the New York City Marathon, which this year will be run on Oct. 21, and is expected to draw a record 14,000 entrants. The preview run enabled marathon officials to remeasure the 26- mile, 385yard course and check for obstacles along the path such as pot holes.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Joan Joyce is the star pitcher and part owner of the Connecticut Falcons, who have won the championship of the International Women's Professional Softball Association the last three seasons. Crown No. 4, she hopes, will come in the league's World Series on Labor Day.

title: 2 Tons of Pennies Go to Capital To Object to Waste and Inflation
description: HUNGTINGTON, W.Va., Aug. 12 (UPI)  A coal truck loaded with two tons of pennies left today for Washington, where it is to deliver the copper to the Treasury tomorrow in a protest against inflation and Government waste.

title: Kermit Coleman, Chicago Lawyer And Activist on Civil Rights, 54
description: Kermit B. Coleman, a lawyer and civil rights activist, died at his home in Chicago on Aug. 6. He was 54 years old.

title: Commerce Chief's Goal Is Rebuilding Industry;
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The new Secretary of Commerce, Luther H. Hodges Jr., has come to Washington with a mission nexttoimpossible; finding a way to stimulate the nation into what he calls a fundamental re- building of American industry.

title: Huge Idaho Fires Spur an Argument Over Strategy
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 12  At the twice- aday briefings, the serious, uniformed men wave their pointers at squiggly lines on topographical maps depicting ad- vances and retreats, and speak with cau- tious optimism of control or containment, of logistics, of weather.

title: Dick Foran, Singing Actor, Dies; Was Veteran of Western Movies
description: Dick Foran, a veteran actor in western movies who appeared with Cene Autry, Roy Rogers and, .more recently, John Wayne, died Friday at Panorama City (Calif.) Hospital at the age of 69.

title: New Correction Head Backs Plan for Dispersing jails
description: Benjamin C. Ward, who takes office today as the New York City Commissioner of Correction, says that among his priorities will be the construction of smaller city prisons throughout the five boroughs  a plan the outgoing Commissioner opposed  and the easing of reported friction between management and prison union leaders.

title: The Region
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Men's and women's jewelry valued at $100,000 was reported stolen from a house in a quiet, affluent suburban neighborhood in this upstate resort. It was the second major theft of the 111th annual horseracing season here.

title: Notes on People
description: In the past, Gabriel Grayson has taught courses on the lives of Jesus and Houdini, but neither one should be taken necessarily as a prelude to Mr. Grayson's next undertaking.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has named Alfred G. Goldstein to the newly created post of senior vice president, consumer businesses.

title: Andrea Berman, Teacher, Wed
description: Temple Bethel in North Bergen, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Andrea M. Berman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berman of Brooklyn, to David B. Bedick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Bedick of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Sidney Nissenbaum performed the ceremony. The bride teaches mathematics at Public School 44 in Brooklyn, where her husband teaches writing at Public School 305.

title: U.S. Delegation to Hanoi Succeeds on Some Issues
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 12 (Reu- ters)  Members of the United States Congress who returned here from Hanoi today made progress on issues delaying establishment of diplomatic relations be- tween the United States and Vietnam, Representative Lester L. Wolff, Demo- crat of New York, said.

description: Satellite Photograph

title: Alan Jones Wins Again; Engine to Be Inspected
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 12 (AP) Alan Jones of Australia, racing in a Williams sponsored by Saudi Arabian interests, scored his second straight Grand Prix victory in the Austrian Grand Prix Formula One race today.

title: Japanese Ship Orders Up
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Foreign orders for ships received by Japanese shipyards in July rose to 24 ships totaling 499,600 gross tons from 22 ships totaling 407,900 tons in June, the ship exporters association said. The July total was also up from nine vessels totaling 180,671 tons ordered in July 1978.

title: Directors Call In Salomon Brothers
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12  Outside directors of the troubled Chrysler Corporation have retained Salomon Brothers, the investmentbanking house in New York, to counsel them on what strategies might be consid- ered during the coming months

title: Rain Curbs Sports Card
description: A persistent rain that swept over much of the Northeast yesterday interfered with several sports events, resulting in postponements and cancellations.

title: NonCommunist Editor's Newspaper Is Flourishing in Ho Chi Minh City
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  There was party recently in the unpretentious secondfloor offices of the newspaper Tin Sang on the edge of downtown Ho Chi Minh City. It was the independent daily's fourth anniversary.

title: Karen Lynn Malitz Is Married to Allen Katz
description: The marriage of Karen Lynn Malitz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Malitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Allen Gerald Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Katz of Pittsfield, Mass., took place at Tappan Bill in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday. Rabbi Paul Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge:
description: Among the sizable band of workers who promote organized bridge in the metropolitan area, one of the most enthusiastic and energetic is Saul Bronstein, who serves in a double capacity as general secretary of the Greater New York Bridge Association and chairman of activities for newcomers to the tournament scene.

title: Moscow Leadership Said to Expect No Changes That Would Kill Pact
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12  Though the Sen- ate debate on the SovietAmerican nu- clear arms treaty is not yet over, the Kremlin leadership now believes the pact will be approved by the Senate without unacceptable amendments this fall, ac- cording to Soviet insiders and the official nress.

title: Flash Floods in California Desert
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Flash floods struck parts of the Southern California desert today. Houses in the community of Mecca were flooded after a cloudburst dropped 1.72 inches of rain.

title: DeSantis Will Play Basketball In Italy
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 12 (AP) Joe DeSantis, the top draft pick of the Washington Bullets and the top career scorer at Fairfield University, has decided to play in Italy rather than in the National Basketball Association.
