description: Karen W.Arenson

title: 650 Attend Services in California For F.B.I. Agent Killed in Office
description: EL CENTRO, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP) More than 650 mourners, including 40 F.B.I. agents and 125 law enforcement officers from across the nation, heard Robert Porter, a slain agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, eulogized yesterday.

title: Chess:
description: The OudeMeester Grand Prix in Durban, South Africa, a tournament in which each of the four players met each of the others four times, was won by Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland. The exchallenger for the world championship scored 83 to surpass Grandmasters Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany, 65, Anthony Miles of Britain, 57, and Anatoly Lein of the United States, 48.

title: Elizabeth Newspaper Strikers Put Out Own Daily
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 9 In a sec- ondfloor walkup over the Greenbrook Tavern at 257 North Broad Street here, a group of perspiring and somewhat des- perate newspaper strikers work each day at makeshift desks fashioned from 2 by es and plywood to put out The Com- munity Paper, a daily newspaper.

title: Simms Impresses In Giants Debut
description: It is now less than three weeks before the Giants open their National Football League season, and the players still don't know who is their starting quarterback.

title: Phyllis L. Freund Wed to Dr. David Ritvo
description: At the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens yesterday, Phyllis Laurel Freund, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Freund of Fresh Meadows, was married to Dr. David Zvi Ritvo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Ritvo of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Solomon Goldman officiated.

title: Outdoors: An Evening's Angling, and a Rare Pastime
description: CAPE VINCENT, N.Y.

title: How to Help the Poor Buy Heat
description: The shock of this winter's home heating costs will be felt with particular force by the poor. The poorest fifth of American families already spend 13 percent of their income on home energy (while the richest fifth spend 3 percent of theirs) and heating oil prices are soaring. Now the President has proposed a relief pro- gram, which everyone realizes must be adopted, and linked it to enactment of his windfall profits tax, a less certain proposition. It is a shrewd linkage, and both parts deserve to succeed. But the program for the poor is distressingly tardy and there are some clear, even essential ways to improve it.

title: Koch Shook Up Staff in Irritation at Unwieldiness
description: Not long ago, Mayor Koch took a quick tour of the warren of mayoral offices in the basement of City Hall. After passing room after room of hardworking staff aides, Mr. Koch exclaimed to an associ- ate: Who are all these people? What do they do?

title: 3Day Parley to Set Up Minorities Arts Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 The Paul Robeson International Center for the Performing Arts and other minority art organizations will sponsor a threeday conference from Aug. 30 to Sept. 1 at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Deborah L. Paikin, Student, Is Wed to Brian Earle Klock
description: Deborah Lynn Paikin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Paikin of Nanuet, N.Y., was married at her parents home there yesterday to Brian Earle Klock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Klock, also of Nanuet. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Dr. Lee Schneider, Methodist minister.

title: Agents of Change at the F.B.I.
description: For a half century, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was headed by a national monument. Visitors about to enter J. Edgar Hoover's office were advised to wipe their palms; he hated sweaty handshakes. He made or personally reviewed any decision of importance, and many trivial ones as well, including how to punish critics of the Bureau. Not a memorandum, no matter how technical or who prepared it, left his office without bearing his blueinked JEH.

title: Chrysler's Hope: Electronics

description: Eight clubs within each of the two conferencesAmerican and National  qualify for the North American Soccer League's playoffs. Six of these clubs are the first and secondplace teams from each division, and the two others are wild cards. Within each conference, the two wildcard teams are those that had the greatest number of points among all the clubs that finished below second place.

description: Dudley Dowell, a former president and chief administrative officer of the New York Life Insurance Company, died last Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Little Rock. Ark. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: IAN MCEWAN'S mind is an interesting place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there. It is dark, and smells of ether. Freud hangs from the rafters on a meat hook. The footlocker is full of human skulls. Scorpions and bats abound. Every sexual transaction is a failure. We are some where between Samuel Beckett and the Rolling Stones.

title: Rev. G. V. Florovsky, Theologian

title: A Greek Home for the Games
description: The argument that the Olympic Games should return to their birthplace has surfaced again. The Greek editor Helen Vlachos suggested in an OpEd column on Sunday that every nation could build its own pavilion the tradition of the Greek citystate. Mrs. Vlachos may be overly optimistic in maintaining that the pure air and harmony of ancient Olympia would somehow im- part a new spirit to the Games, but the Olympic spirit is now so flawed that any change would probably be an improvement and this change the best imaginable.

title: Smart Angle Captures Adirondack at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 - Ryehill Farms Smart Angle hung on to her early lead and won by a neck today in the 64th running of the $44,725 Adirondack Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

description: The Broadway producers of The Elephant Man and Bernard Pomerance, author of the highly successful play, filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday in an effort to prevent Mel Brooks from using the same title for a movie scheduled for production in London in October.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) - The Carter Administration said Monday that an Ohio brick company was violating antiinflation guidelines, but it cleared the Getty Oil Company after having challenged its price rises.

title: Sudan Leader Takes Over Party, Saying He'll Punish Communists

Gaafar alNimeiry, the Sudanese leader, took over the leader- ship of his nation's only political party today and promised tough punishment for what he called the Communist insti- gators of student riots protesting in- creases in the price of food and fuel.

title: Britain's Output Up
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP)  Britain's industrial output, on a provisional but seasonally adjusted basis, rose 1.5 percent in June from the preceding month and was 4.4 percent higher than a year earlier, the Central Statistical Office reported today. Output of manufacturing concerns alone rose 1.8 percent in June than in May and was up 2.2 percent from a year earlier, the office said.

title: Superior Oil Sets 5-for-1 Stock Split

title: Tilting at Oil Refineries
description: Once again critics charge that the Carter Administration has been suckered by the oil industry. The focus of their anger is the socalled Tilt Rule, a Department of Energy regulation that allows refiners to charge more for gasoline. The Tilt was meant to en- courage gasoline production and investment in additional refining capacity. But the only thing the public certain to get from it is a pain in the wallet: the Energy Department concedes that the Tilt has already raised the price of gas nearly a nickel a gallon.

The Xerox shuttle carried 18,000 employees and 45,000 pounds of interoffice mail last year.

title: Crash Kills 2 Marines in Greece
description: ATHENS, Aug. 13 (UPI) - Two United States Marine Corps pilots were killed yesterday when their A111 Cobra helicop- ter crashed during a Sixth Fleet exercise in northern Greece, an American mili- tary spokesman said today. The helicon- ter, flown from the aircraft carrier Guam, went down in the area of the Strymonic Gulf, the spokesman said. The names of the two pilots were withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: Escapee Holds Out With Hostage
description: GARDINER, N.Y., Tuesday, Aug. 14 - A 28-year-old escaped prisoner remained barricaded in a white house at the edge of a cornfield here early this morning with the last of six hostages he had seized. He barged into the house early Sunday as scores of - law enforcement officials hunted for him in a nearby woods during a heavy rainstorm.

title: About That Monster You Sighted . . .
description: THE next time you catch a glimpse of a lake monster, take note of the water and air temperatures. If the water is much colder than the air above it - as is often the case in lakes where monsters have been sighted - the atmospheric conditions are ideal for optical trickery, reports a Canadian scientist.

Quello, the son of a member of the Federal Communications Commission, has been sentenced to four years in Federal prison for defrauding the National Bank of Detroit in a $17,000 business loan. Quello, is a former general manager of radio station WJR in Detroit.

In tact, just about everything was different from what he had seen before, or expected to see again.

title: Stage: Teeth n Smiles, World of Rock n Roll

Unlike his most re- cent play, Plenty, which deals with the cataclysmic social, political and personal upheavals caused by World War II, the earlier Teeth n Smiles deals with the lesser subject of rockandroll. It is about the breakup of small provincial band, the breakdown of its lead singer, and the decline of the 1960's.

title: Half Way on the Darvon Warning
description: It was only a few weeks ago that former H.E.W. Secretary Joseph Califano announced an unusual plan to reduce the risk of death from the pill Darvon. This popular painkiller is lethal to a small percentage of users through accidental or deliberate overdose. still. Mr. Califano concluded there wasn't enough evidence to justify reclassifying Darvon to make it harder prescribe. He called instead for more research and announced also that the manufacturer, Eli Lilly and Company, would undertake a major educational effort warn doctors and patients of the risks.

Edward J. King today signed a bill restoring capital punishment in Massachusetts.

title: Film: Neil Young's Rock:Rocking Along
description: ROCK films come in two categories. More common is the film designed solely for an act's fans. But some appeal beyond the cult to the general public, as in Richard Lester's two Beatles movies. Neil Young's "Rust Never Sleeps," which opens a limited run at the Palladium today, might seem to be in the latter category. In fact, it's very much a fan film.Its credentials as a message beyond the cult rest largely on its extra-musical conceits. Instead of being a straight concert documentary, "Rust Never Sleeps" calls itself a "concert fantasy." As he was during last fall's tour at which this was filmed, Mr. Young is discovered "asleep" on top of one of the loudspeaker banks, which has been disguised as an oversized pirate chest, and "wakes up" to begin the concert.The "roadies" who move equipment about have been dressed as "roadeyes," the little scavengers with brown robes and beady pinpoint eyes from "Star Wars." The idea, reinforced by playing tapes of crowd-control announcements from the Woodstock Festival, is to comment on rock's aging, on the discrepancies between veteran rock performers and their teenage audiences, and on rock's allegiance to youthful rebellion and innocence. All of this reads better than it appears on the screen, however, where an otherwise fine concert is continually interrupted by laboriously miming "roadeyes" and other cuteness.Mr. Young, who directs the film under the rather coy pseudonym of Bernard Shakey, further limits its appeal by extremely grainy and underlit footage. And the Palladium, as rock's principal rock concert hall in New York, is likely to attract more rock fans than film buffs. Perhaps that's what he meant to do, in a film that reaffirms the purity and unity of rock. But it's too bad, because Mr. Young has the talent to appeal to intelligent people outside his world.For Mr. Young is, in the opinion of some of us, the leading creative figure in present-day rock-and-roll, and this film has stirring, even triumphant passages. He writes songs of unsurpassed metaphoric richness with deceptively simple, melodic tunes. He sings with haunting evocativeness and plays guitar with more personality and stark individuality than almost anyone else."Rust Never Sleeps" offers some of his strongest songs, both new and old, in performances as fine or finer than those on his recent, partly live record album of the same title. The effect here is rougher than the record, less polished with overdubbing; at one point, Mr. Young even mangles the words of one of his own best songs. But the intensity of the singing and the playing of Crazy Horse, Mr. Young's longtime partners for electric-rock projects, is as moving as rock can offer. It's so good, in fact, that it almost lets one overlook Mr. Young's theatrical conceits, and almost makes the film recommendable for the general public, after all."Rust Never Sleeps" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). There's a passing indelicate word, but otherwise, unless a parent is implacably opposed to rock-and-roll, there seems little reason to prevent children from seeing this film.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THERE are three kinds of people at dinner parties these days: Those who didn't buy house or apartment two or three years ago, those who did, and those who know they can't afford anything now but are still looking. Members of the first group are miserable, mad (as in YOU fool you), and inclined to spend most of the evening verbally kicking themselves. Members of the second group are insufferably complacent, inviting more than a verbal kick. And those in the third group are more to be pitied than censured.

title: Metropolitan Diary

In general, there is not much of a clamor for swampland. But in this instance, there was a prospective buyer - the Mafia, which proceeded to dispatch a representative to the lawyer's office.

title: Cross Winds in Nicaragua

In the first weeks of Sandinist rule, officials and the press have referred sharply to Yankee imperialism while appealing for American economic and military assistance. The contradictions, and the resentment, are inevitable. The deposed Somoza dynasty was in- stalled by the United States Marine Corps and for 40 years was regarded as an American vassal.

title: The Crew of the Lonesome Lady
description: According to Barton Bernstein, a Stanford history professor, several American soldiers imprisoned in Hiroshima were killed on Aug. 6, 1945, when an American atomic bomb destroyed the city. There would be nothing extraordinary about this footnote to history, if Mr. Bernstein is right. Military forces do kill their own sol- diers by mistake sometimes. But it's regrettable that, so long after the fact, the Defense Department still hasn't clarified the matter to everyone's satisfaction. For instance, the mother of one possible victim - Sgt. Ralph J. Neal, a crew member of the bomber Lonesome Lady, which was downed near Hiroshima about week before the blast - has been trying to establish just how her son died. The city of Hiroshima, meanwhile, wants to put these men's names on its memorial to the dead.

title: Northwest Airlines Pact Voted
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 19 (AP) Northwest Airlines flight attendants have approved a new 17month contract, averting a strike called for today. Sylvia Dombrosky. president of Teamsters Local 2747, said 48 percent of flight attendants voting had approved the contract, while 52 percent voted to reject the offer. Under union bylaws, approval required affirmative votes by more than onethird of the 1,997 eligible voters. Top pay after 12 years will be $1,365 a month, increasing to $1,502 on Jan. 1. Previously, the flight attendants top pay was $1,020 monthly after 10 years.

title: The Screen: 'Apocalypse Now':Faces of War
description: SCENE: Day. Jungle. A small United States Army patrol boat pushes its way up a river overhung with dense foliage. The members of the crew make no comment on the burnt-out ribs of an American helicopter that remain stuck in a tree like the struts of a child's forgotten kite.Scene: Day. Jungle. The little patrol boat cuts through the water with uncharacteristic speed, drawing behind it an exultant crew member on water skis. The brown-skinned farmers on the river bank watch impassively.Scene: Day. Jungle. The patrol boat stops to search a Vietnamese dugout filled with people and produce. Are they friends, enemies or, as is most likely, simply uncommitted? No way to know. No language to communicate in. A young Vietnamese woman makes a sudden move to protect a particular crate. An American, armed with a machine gun, begins to fire. In several seconds these boat people are dead. The one survivor is a puppy.Scene: Night. Jungle. The patrol boat, now deep in hostile territory, rounds a bend in the river to come upon a brilliantly floodlit stadium preparing to receive a U.S.O. troupe of Playboy bunnies.In dozens of such scenes Francis Coppola's "Apocalypse Now" lives up to its grand title, disclosing not only the various faces of war but also the contradictions between excitement and boredom, terror and pity, brutality and beauty. Its epiphanies would do credit to Federico Fellini, who is indirectly quoted at one point."Apocalypse Now," which opens at long last today at the Ziegfeld Theater, is not about any war but about the disastrous United States involvment in Vietnam, which, probably because it was disastrous, seems now to have been different, but was it really? The technology was as up-to-date as the taxpayers' billions could buy, but everything else was essentially the same. At its confused heart: a fearful hunger to survive. No matter what.When it is thus evoking the look and feelings of the Vietnam War, dealing in sense impressions for which no explanations are adequate or necessary, "Apocalypse Now" is a stunning work. It's as technically complex and masterful as any war film I can remember, including David Lean's "The Bridge on the River Kwai," which comes to mind, I suppose, because both productions were themselves military campaigns to subdue the hostile landscapes in which they were made. "Kwai" was shot in Ceylon; "Apocalypse Now" in the Philippines, which became, for Mr. Coppola, his Vietnam, swallowing men, money and equipment as voraciously as any enemy."Apocalypse Now," though, wants to be something more than a kind of cinematic tone poem. Mr. Coppola himself describes it as "operatic," but this, I suspect, is a word the director hit upon after the fact. Ultimately, "Apocalypse Now" is neither a tone poem nor an opera. It's a adventure yarn with delusions of grandeur, a movie that endsin the all-too-familiar words of the poet Mr. Coppola drags in by the bootstrapsnot with a bang, but a whimper.I realize that a movie's ending should not deny all that has gone before, but almost from the beginning of "Apocalypse Now" there have been portents that the film means to deal not only with the looks and expressions of war but also with such heavy things as the human condition, good, evil, fate and various other subjects whose weight, in an earlier century, demanded that they be capitalized.Mr. Coppola and John Milius, with whom he wrote the screenplay, have taken as their source material "Heart of Darkness," Joseph Conrad's classic story about a mad ivory hunter in 19th-century Africa. This shadowy man, named Kurtz, comes to represent to Conrad's narrator, Marlow, all the terrible possibilities of a soul returned to some precivilized state. Conrad is rather vague about the terrible things that Kurtz is up to. We know only that he rules his local tribes with a bloody hand and charms them with his sorcery. The point of the story is Marlow's realization that Kurtz is a heretofore unrecognized aspect of himself, which, being known, is safely manageable.Mr. Coppola and Mr. Milius have attempted to update Conrad, who really doesn't need updating, by placing this story more or less on top of the Vietnam War. Kurtz (Marlon Brando), whom we meet in the film's concluding section, is a renegade Green Berets officer who has taken refuge in the Cambodian jungles, where, to the fury of his superiors, he wages his own wars  for and against whom is left blurry  at the head of a group of ferocious Montagnard tribesmen.The Marlow character is now a battle-scarred Special Services officer named Captain Willard (Martin Sheen), who is assigned by the commanding general to go into Cambodia, find Kurtz and to "terminate" him "with extreme prejudice." This plot, which seems to have been imposed on the film from above, keeps interrupting the natural flow of Mr. Coppola's perfectly sound, sometimes incredibly beautiful, meditation upon war.The major part of the film is occupied with Willard's adventures as he travels upriver in the small patrol boat provided by the Army. These sequences are often spellbinding, none more so than one in which Willard and his companions are forced to observe an assault on a Vietcong village by American fighter planes and helicopters under the command of an exuberantly manic officer who's also a surfing nut. This fellow, played with breathtaking force and charm by Robert Duvall, exhibits most of the qualities we miss in the foolish pretensions of the movie's Kurtz, whose actions and words, when they finally come, have little to do with the rest of the movie.From time to time in the course of his upriver odyssey, Captain Willard muses on the nature of the man he seeks  soundtrack narration that makes one's flesh wet with embarrassment. When we hear Willard say, "Everything I saw told me that Kurtz had gone insane," it not only fails to establish any bond between the two men, it's also an understatement to break a camel's back.With the exception of Mr. Brando, who has no role to act, the actors are superlatively right, beginning with Mr. Duvall and Mr. Sheen, and including Frederic Forrest, Albert Hall, Larry Fishburne and Sam Bottoms, who play the members of the patrol boat's crew. Dennis Hopper, looking as wild and disconnected as ever, turns up briefly at the end as a freelance photographer who has fallen under Kurtz's spell, apparently because Kurtz reads T.S. Eliot aloud (though none too well).Vittorio Storaro, who photographed "Last Tango in Paris," among other fine films, is responsible for the extraordinary camerawork that almost, but not quite, saves "Apocalypse Now" from its profoundly anticlimactic intellectual muddle.

title: The Law On Tests Is Bad
description: New York's new truth-in-testing law, passed by the state Legislature and signed into law by Gov. Carey, guarantees that anyone who takes an entry test for college, graduate or professional school is entitled to get copy of the test, along with the correct answers. Passaire of the law is a tri- umph for Ralph Nader and his associates, who have been campaigning against standardized tests in general, and the Educational Testing Service in, particular, since the early 1970's.

title: Capture of Fugitive Ends a Family's TwoDay Ordeal

title: MauritaniaAlgeria Ties Revived
description: ALGIERS,Aug. 14 (Reuters) - Algeria and Mauritania have decided to resume diplomatic relations after three years of conflict over the Western Sahara, it was announced today. Relations were broken off in 1976 when Algeria recognized the Democratic Saharan Republic proclaimed by Polisario guerrillas fighting for the independence of the Western Sahara.

title: Alfa Romeo Is Seeking Partners to Cut Losses
description: ROME, Aug. 13  Alfa Romeo S.p.A., one of Italy's leading producers of sleek sports cars and highperformance sedans, is seeking joint ventures with foreign and domestic companies in an effort to cut its vast operating losses. However, Alfa directors say that the company is not for sale, contrary to a report that appeared recently in a leading Rome weekly.

title: Nuclear Concern Is Told To Clean Up July Spill
description: The state of New Mexico has issued a detailed and probably costly order to the United Nuclear Corporation to clean up the radioactive and heavymetals waste left from a massive July 16 spill at the company's Church Rock Mill.

title: MICHIGAN GETS LAW TO AID YOUNG VOTER
description: DETROIT, Aug. 14 - A bill aimed at increasing voter turnout by young people by deputizing high school principals as voter registrars was signed into law by Gov. William G. Milliken here today, with cheers from the bill's chief backers, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IHAVE been asked a few thousand times over the years whether ever eat and savor foods that come in cans and the answer, course, is yes. There are times when my appetite craves sardines; on occasion I will dine on canned tuna with great enjoyment; and if there is absolutely no fresh salmon to be had. I can willingly feast on the canned variety.

title: China and Vietnam End 10th Round of Bitter Talks
description: PEKING, Aug. 19  Vietnam and China ended their 10th round of talks on normalization of relations here today with each side accusing the other of car- rying on an irrelevant propaganda cam- paign at the conference table while con- tinuing provocations and war prepara- tions along the border.

title: McDermott Net Off 43%
description: Stockholders of J. Ray McDermott & Company, at a stormy annual meeting yesterday in New Orleans, were told that the company's net income for the first fiscal quarter ended June 30 was $18.4 million, or 34 cents a share, down 43 percent from the $32.3 million, or 76 cents, earned in the corresponding three months last year.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: N the hot and muggy days of summer. one turns to cold cuts for relief, as if they were airconditioning. Cold cuts are produced more often than not by the man behind the deli counter, assisted by some massive mashine that seems more competent than any hand acting alone could be, as it turns slabs of Genoa salami and Virginia ham into thin. uniform slices.

title: Personal Health
description: MORE and more these days, matters of food safety are being decided by emotions and politics rather than by law and scientific evidence. The saccharin issue is the bestpublicized recent example: Congress, in response to intense public pressure, stepped in to prevent the Food and Drug Administration from carrying out the law that prohibits the addition of cancer-causing chemicals to foods.

title: Private Lives
description: IMEAN no disrespect, but wading through the reams of copy devoted to the death of Thurman Munson, the Yankee catcher, has left me tired and confused and angry. A gifted athlete is gone. The unqualified approval he wanted so much, so palpably, is at last his, only after he is no longer around to answer questions. The rest, the overkill of column inches, is either guilt - we are ashamed of ourselves for not having loved him enough while, inconveniently, he was still with us or necrophilia.

She is the customer who always gets to Bloomingdale's before me and grabs the pitifully few pairs available in that size. She probably has them put away for her. She has the clout. She also has some nerve, as she could afford to have her feet shortened to a nice normal 7.

They are members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, and one of them was quoted as having said: We perform

title: Chess:
description: The value of a central pawn majority sn a middle game where few pieces have left the board is far greater than that of a pawn majority on a wing. The chief threat of flank pawn superiority is to produce an outside passed pawn, and in an end game, this could well suffice for a victory. But it won't count for anything if the enemy's center pawn phalanx smashes through first.

title: Sound
description: NEXT and last in our miniseries on handy home remedies for common hifi ailments, we turn to acoustic feedback, a frequent but readily curable complaint. Acoustic feedback oc- curs when vibrations from the loudspeaker sneak back to the record player. The sound returning from the speaker then gets picked up once again by the phono stylus, again runs through amplifiers and speakers, and then back again to the turntable as the whole process repeats itself ad infinitum - the sound looping back on itself like a dog chasing its tail. As the repeated sound is superimposed on the new signals picked up by the stylus from the record groove as the music moves on, all these sounds pile up like a multicar collision. The net result, at best, is a sonic blur fogging the music. At worst, it is a banshee howl.

title: Hers
description: IT happened in the 70's, in summer. Professor Freed, having disposed of all academic and other duties for the year, now set to work in earnest. The three months ahead had been bracketed for the completion of Women in the Bible. In moments of domestic idleness, playing with her daughter, Isabel, for instance, Freed would suddenly be dazed by the panic that she was wasting her time, not attending to something that required doing, just as when she had been a student she could never fully enjoy a movie, say, because of the spectral squeeze of some unfinished assignment. In the matter of this book, however, it was clear to her that she had better dig in at once, for the theys would not be patient forever, and pretty soon she would be stranded without an obituary. I'm not to be disturbed for anything, she said to Nicky, her housekeeper. She entered her study and bolted the door.

title: The Ayatollah Draws the Curtain
description: The world cannot be sure about what is happening in Iran these days except that progressively it will know even less. Foreign correspondents are now expected to behave like stenographers in government offices, duly transmitting what they are told by chaperones from the Ministry of Guidance, yet they will be sworn to write only the truth a maddening conflict indeed. They are also subject to expulsion if anything unflattering from any source is printed by their publications. As for Iranian writers, they are being arrested if they criticize Ayatollah Khomeini or other religious figures, who comprise the most influential group Iran today. Critical publications are simply closed.

If the grounds were a beautifully closecropped green in the style that only money could buy, the weather was cool, clear and bracing in the way that money couldn't buy.

Most recently active as New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, she has been a moving force in daycare and child-development and welfare programs in New York and a trustee or officer of dozens of charitable and philanthropic organizations.

title: A Mansion Up for Auction, Piece by Piece

title: A Letter From Missing Financier Reported by Lawyer
description: A letter apparently written by Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, says that he is being held captive but that he has not been harmed and that he ex- pects to be released soon, his lawyer an- nounced yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Catholic Church's Help Is Sought In Census Count on Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON,  Census officials have despaired of being able to persuade illegal aliens that they will not risk deportation if they are counted in the 1980 census and are trying to enlist the aid of the Roman Catholic Church to reassure the aliens that census data are confidential.

title: Some U.N. Delegates Found Post Had More Glamour Than Power
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 The chief American delegate to the United Nations holds a position that, as a number of A'drew Young's predecessors discovered, has glamour and prestige but very little real power or influence. Some left disappointed, complaining, at least privately, that they had been little more than glorified messenger boys.

title: Frederick B. Newell, 89, Was a Methodist Bishop

Bishop Ne- well, who lived in Avon, Conn., and had a summer home in Groton Long Point, was 89 years old.

title: MORN ACCEPTS LONDON'S INVITATION TO RHODESIA PARLEY

Mr. Mugabe made the statement at a news conference broadcast from Luanda, Angola. It was Monitored here by the South African radio.

The charges against him included using false names on prescriptions, falsifying business records and not prescribing in good faith.

Certain fashionable Oriental elements have been picked up, often with hilarious imprecision; but the new minimalist interior designers are clearly influenced by the Japanese idea that a house is not a series of large cubes in which furniture is placed, but a succession of planes and platforms changing purpose.

title: A $200 Million Cushion: Not to Sit On

It turns out that the city ended its fiscal year with $800 million in cash instead of the $600 million it expected. This does not mean it has balanced its budget for the year just ended. That would have been great news. But it does mean that the city's deficit for the year just ended, once Comptroller Goldin completes his final audit, will be smaller than originally feared. Mayor Koch, we're happy to report, achieved this extra $200 million largely by cutting ex- penses  a feat in inflationary times.

A few hours later the same day, Aug. 4, Ricardo Gonzales, also and also of the Bronx, fell five stories, but there was no one to catch him and he died on the way to the hospital. Twentyseven other small children have fallen out of upperstory windows this year; of them, 17 were severely injured and 10 died.

When she declined, he wcnt to her neighbor's house, but no one answered. As the woman watched, he walked to a window of the house and climbed through. She called the police, who arrested Mr. Joseph and a companion, Henry Pinkston, 19.

title: Film: Dutch Offer 'Soldier of Orange':Dash and Dinner Clothes
description: "SOLDIER of Orange" is the story of a Dutch war hero who performed most of his derring-do in dinner clothes. That gives the movie a certain unmistakable dash  and so does the fact that the man upon whose memoirs it is based, Erik Hazelhoff, helped supervise the filming. The "official patron" of the project, according to the production notes, was Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, who happens to be Mr. Hazelhoff's friend.For these reasons  and because Mr. Hazelhoff is virtually the only one of the principals who lived to tell the tale  the movie might be expected to be a bit overprotective of his interests. Oddly enough, that doesn't do it any harm. The determination of the film makers to build a better "Late Show" out of Mr. Hazelhoff's already-colorful exploits simply leads them in the direction of swashbuckling, which is perfectly at home in a war movie anyhow. This time the hero just has a little more trouble than usual dividing his energies between the tennis court and the battlefield."Soldier of Orange," which opens at the Beekman today, begins very strangely. A group of freshmen are being subjected to some sort of university initiation rite, and not-so-young-looking Erik (Rutger Hauer) is being singled out for sadistic treatment by an upperclassman named Guus (Jeroen Krabbe). Guus pours noodle soup all over Erik's newly shaven head, and for a moment it looks as if this incident is going to serve as some preamble to the hardships of war. Instead, the scene is supposed to pave the way for a lifelong friendship between the two men.Here, as in his previous film "Keetje Tippel," the director, Paul Verhoeven, shows such a penchant for having his characters wallow in muck that the squalor can become actively confusing. Later on in "Soldier of Orange," when Mr. Verhoeven wants to show that a very available young Englishwoman has a kinky side to her nature, he uses a close-up of her crushing flies with a pencil. Most of the movie is more delicate than that.It turns out that the freshmen all grow up to be friends, until World War II shuts down the university and puts a cramp in their gentlemanly style. Under pressure, they go their different ways with melodramatic flair, as one becomes martyred, one turns traitor and one becomes a hero even more remarkable than Erik himself. Throughout the war years, they meet only intermittently but share some of the same women, who lend the film a bit of romantic spice to match its elements of intrigue. There's a tragic flavor to it, too, particularly whenever anyone offers to sleep with anyone else "while I still can.""Soldier of Orange" may not be great art but it's a good yarn. And the combined effects of Mr. Verhoeven's comfortingly old-fashioned storytelling and Mr. Hauer's unexpectedly brittle performance keep it moving at a fast clip. Though the screenplay provides him with every opportunity to turn matinee idol, Mr. Hauer shows little interest in making himself adorable, and that in itself is intriguing. His Erik is a vain, arrogant and shrewd aristocrat, capable of bravery when it's called for but by no means overeager to risk his neck. He's a much more temperamental and complex fellow than the dependable Guus, who is carefully turned by Mr. Krabbe into the one fixed element in an atmosphere of terrifying up-heaval.Erik's principal feat in the movie is his escape to England, where he meets the exiled Queen Wilhelmina and agrees to return to the Netherlands to do her bidding. The film's two main English characters, an officer (Edward Fox) and his trampy, ridiculous assistant (Susan Penhaligon), are so weirdly caricatured that they may make a great comic impression on American viewers.

title: Cabaret: Patch, a Revue With Cheer for Over 30's
description: THE title song of the new cabaret revue Patch, Patch, Patch refers to a lifes passage. According to Alan Menken, the composer and lyricist of the entertainment, after age 30 it is a downhill plunge. All one can do is to reach for cosmetics - depressing words ior anyone embarking on a later decade. However, Mr. Menken's remarks are delivered cheerfully, as if they are lines in a singing telegram.

title: Ballet: Grigorovich's Romeo by Bolshoi
description: THE new tuRomeo and Juliet by the Bolsboi Ballet's artistic director, Yuri GriguruvIck is not for the literalminded. At its New York premiere Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, it turned out to be an ambition distillation of both Shakespeare's tragedy and Other ballets set to Serge Prokoliev's score. It offers a welcome approach, tint one that promises to look better when a stronger cast takes over the title roles.

title: U.I.P. Plans Tender For 1 Million Shares
description: The U.I.P. Corporation said it planned a general tender offer for up to one million of its 3,327,097 outstanding shares at S5 a share.

title: Fishkill Is Transferring 190 HighRisk Prisoners
description: State prison officials said yesterday they were transferring all 190 highrisk prisoners from New York's new $45-million maximumsecurity prison at Fishkill. N.Y.

title: Gale Winds and Irish Sea: A Deadly Combination; Wind Drives Shallow Water; Storm Grew Through the Night; Modern Yachts Too Light?; Dangerous Sailing; Sea and Wind: Deadly Pairing
description: At the Fastnet race, which has become the worst disaster in the history of yacht racing, the tumultuous seas off Southern England are subsiding. It's the questions that are on the rise. Why are 17 sailors dead and 24 boats, worth close to $4.5 million, sunk or abandoned?

title: Dr. Andrew Ruotolo, Psychiatrist
description: By JOAN COOK

title: High Officials Say Young Became Diplomatic and Political Liability
description: WASHINGTON,  High Administration officials insisted today that it was prinfarily for reasons of state that Andrew Young, the United States representative at the United Nations, had to leave the Government.

title: Wide Gaps Separate Rhodesia Protagonists; News Analysis; Will Guerrillas Accept Less?; Key Issues Identified; No Reference to Blocking Plan; Smith's Strongest Card
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 15  For the ninth time since 1965, a major effort is under way to resolve the white Rhodesians dispute with the world and bring Zimbabwe Rhodesia to an internationally recognized form of black rnaiontv rule. But the con ferincethat Britain will convene in London on Sept. 10 faces many of the obstacles that have blocked agreement from the outset of Ian D. Smith's rebellious declaration of independence.

title: Japanese Seek U.S. Fishery
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP)  Japan's third largest integrated fishery company, Nichiro Gyogyo Kaisha Ltd., is negotiating a takeover of Peter Pan Seafoods Inc., a United States company based in Seattle. A Nichiro Gyogyo spokesman said his company was hoping to acquire all of Peter Pan's stock, valued at $23.5 million.

title: DR. ROBERT S. BRODEY
description: Dr. Robert S. Brodey, professor of surgery and head of the Tumor Clinic at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, died Friday of injuries suffered in an automobile accident near Denbigh, Ontario. He was 51 years old and lived in Perkiomenville, Pa.

title: Black Leaders Back Young; Jews Still Fearful on P.L.O.
description: American black leaders expressed support for Andrew Young after his resignation yesterday as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, while Palestinians expressed anger over the incident.

title: Books: Bishop Moore Reflects on His Service
description: THE Episcopal Bishop of New York, Paul Moore Jr., was deeply involved in his church's dispute over women's ordination and the question of whether avowed homosexuals should be admitted to the clergy, two highly sensitive issues that are being faced by a growing number of denominations. Bishou

title: G.&W. Reported to Fail On Dominican Payments
description: Gulf and Western Industries report- edly failed to make payments of more than $19 million to the Dominican Re- public stemming from sugar agree- ments between 1974 and 1975, accord- ing to press reports from the Caribbean nation.

title: Project Admits Tenants to End A 3Year Delay
description: Taino Towers, a Federal housing development in East Harlem that has stood nearly completed but vacant for three years because of a dispute over finances and operation, has opened its doors to its first residential tenants.

title: Of Angels,
description: BEL AIR, Md. They wait Sphinxlike where Nothingness is something. They are philosophers, gentlemen who can mix a gindry question with the perfect sniff of Vermouth: Tell us now, does the light in the refrigerator really go out when you close the door? Then the pause before the fall of the single, silvery orb of Vermouth: Can you prove that it does?

title: Soviet Astronauts Spend 83 Minutes Outside Craft!
description: MOSCOW. Aug 15 (AP) - Two Soviet astronauts who have) been in orbit in the Salyut 6 space laboratory for a record 171 days made an 83minute excursion today to dismantle ofterior equipment in preparation for their return to earth.

title: Beaths
description: McKEONMary (nee Durkin), on August 14, 1979. Born June 12. 1887. A native of Bailin, County Mayo Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Andrew, devoted mother of John, Andrew, James. Timothy, and Richard. Also survived by 20 granchildren and 1 greatgrandchild. ReoosInn at the Abbey, Madison Ave & 81 St on Wednesday from 79pm & Thursday from 25 & 79pm. Funeral Mass Church of St. Vincent Ferrer 66 St. & Lexington Ave, Friday at 10am. interment Calvary Cemete-

title: New Season in Wings As 2 Musicals Rehearse
description: Among the first shows going into rehearsal for the new Broadway season are two musicals, The 1940's Radio Hour and The Most Happy Fella, both starting this week. A third musical, Daddy Goodness, has just completed a month of rehearsals and opens tonight in Philadelphia, with a New York premiere scheduled for the Winter Garden on Oct. 17.

title: Richard Alewyn, an ExProfessor Of German at Queens College, 77
description: Richard Alewyn, a former professor of German literature and language at Queens College, died Tuesday in Prien Hospital in southwest Germany. He was 77 years old.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Liner France Barred by Workers From Sailing to West Germany
description: LE HAVRE, France, Aug. 15 (AP) Dock workers barred the liner France, now renamed the Norway, from leaving Le Havre today on a voyage to West Germany for refitting.

title: Ambassador Young's Offense
description: The value and charm of Ambassador Andrew Young's affronts to conventional diplomacy have always resided in one special quality: his candor. With abandon, or exaggeration, he deflated his own Government's cliches about democracy in Queens, Cubans Angola or Communism in Africa. By recognizing rac- ism as a major force in human affairs, he advanced the cause of reconciliation in a multicolored world. Even while thus periodically embarrassing the United States, he served its interests well. But when, in the affair now exposed, Mr. Young momentarily dropped candor from his portfolio, what appeared? A clumsy, foolish diplomacy that led his Government into a lie, violated its policy and broke its promises.

title: Japan to Back Engine Project
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP) - The Japa- nese Government will back a joint project of four Japanese and British in- dustrial makers to design and manu- facture aircraft engines, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: 2 Days of Misery on the Toscana
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 15 Toscana, a 47foot sloop owned by Eric Swenson, a 61-year-old bookpublisher from Weston, Conn., sailed the race with a crew that consisted of nine Americans, mostly from Connecticut, as well as an English navigator and an Irish cook. Three of the 11 crew members were women, and two women stood watches with the men.

title: Swan and Allen Hurl Mets to 63 Triumph
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 15  One way to turn a hitter's park into a pitcher's park is to start with a fastball pitcher and finish up with a curveball pitcher. That was the pairing the Mets used tonight, with Craig Swan and Neil Allen, in defeating the Atlanta Braves, 63.

title: POWELL IS STUDYING PHOTOGRAPHER CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 - The White House sought today to reach an accommodation with several news orgaidzations that have declined to send photographers to accompany President Carter on his Mississippi riverboat trip, protesting certain conditions set by the White House.

title: 1,000Mile Slick Is Aiming North For Louisiana
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 15 The stream of oil from a runaway Mexican well now stretches nearly 1,000 miles across the Gulf of Mexico to the vicinity of Louisiana, Federal officials reported today.

title: Cabrini Doctors Repair Man's Mangled Hands
description: Surgeons at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan early this morning completed a 12hour operation to repair,the severely mangled hands of a Brooklyn construction worker.

title: Prime: Loan Benchmark
description: The prime lending rate is ostensibly the minimum rate that commercial banks charge to their best corporate borrowers, who customarily put up no collateral. However, banks have been and continue lending at rates lower than the prime. In effect, it is the benchmark rate from which other corporate lending rates are scaled.

title: Bat Panel Bids Law Schools Stress Practical Training
description: DALLAS, Aug. 15  Citing substantial opportunities for improvement in the quality of legal education, a committee of Federal judges, lawyers and educators has called for significant changes in the way law is taught.

title: 150 Are Feared Dead As 2 Soviet Airliners r Collide Over Ukraine
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  Some 150 people, including players and officials of a prominent soccer team, were believed killed when two domestic airliners collided over the Ukraine Saturday in one of the Soviet Union's worst air disasters.

title: Scientology Fraud Suit Gets Woman $2 Million
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 15 (AP) jury awarded more than $2 million in damages today to a 22-year-old woman who contended that the Church of Scientology defrauded her by failing to fulfill promises of improving her life.

title: Pol Pot's Ousted Regime Applies To Represent Cambodia at Talks
description: PEKING, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  The ousted Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia has named a sixmember delegation to attend the meeting of socalled nonaligned nations in Cuba next month, its envoy to China said here today. But the envoy, Pich Cheang, said there had been no reply from Cuba to the delegation's request  for visas, made through its representative at the United Nations.

title: Q&A

Do you think it is necessary to replace these shakes to prevent leaks, or is this how they normally weather?  Monsey, N.Y.
