title: Japan's Output Up
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Japan's industrial production index (1975-100) rose 2.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted 131.6 in the second quarter from 128.5 in the first quarter, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The secondquarter index was up 8 percent from the yearearlier period.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: WHEN summer comes, gas shortage or not, people spend more time in and around their cars. Two new items for car owners are a triangular oil drain pan and a spotlight that plugs into a car lighter.

title: Turkey Settles Claim Of Continental Grain
description: The Turkish stateowned Snil Prod- ucts Office and the Continental Grain Company, a leading American com- modities concern, have settled a long- standing dispute involving a Turkish default on a wheat contract, according to an official announcement in Ankara, Turkey.

title: Payroll Tax Loophole on Social Security Stirs Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  A loophole in the Social Security laws could save big employers millions of dollars in payroll taxes each year, but some experts caution that it has drawbacks for workers.

title: Dull Blades for Cutting Inflation
description: Inflation may be President Carter's number one domestic challenge but it has more than doubled 13 percent  since he took office. The Administration can respond with justice that it has been battered by food and energy price increases beyond its control.

title: Chrysler Offering $400 Rebates to Cut Big Backlog
description: DETROIT, Aug.16  In a move to reverse its slumping sales of new cars and trucks, the Chrysler Corporation has decided to offer direct cash rebates to its customers of $400 on the purchase of nearly any vehicle in the company's fleet, excluding its fastselling subcompacts and import models that it sells. Details of the plan, currently being discussed with dealers, are expected to be announced tomorrow.

title: Restaurants
description: IT is hard to imagine that anyone who is interested in New York and its past would not be lured at least occasionally to Sweets, the city's oldest seafood restaurant. Opened in 1842 at the edge of the Fulton Fish Market, this charming, old, secondstory restaurant is one of the few genuinely antique eating places New Yorkers have a chance to visit. In the best of all possible worlds the experience would be as satisfying gastronomically as it is romantically. Unfortunately, we have never found that to be the case, even though optimism draws us back time and time again. Because of its proximity to the wholesalefish market, Sweets does offer fish and seafood that are fresh and of high quality, but the disappointing final results are due to the cooking (or, more Ocactly, the overcooking) and to the inferior quality of secondary dishes, such as vegetables, sauces, salads and desserts. Nevertheless, those who enjoy walking around the South Street Seaport Museum and the interesting side streets of this beguiling old neighborhood, can find enough acceptably prepared dishes on the Sweets menu for a satisfying not inspiring dinner.

title: Graham Leads by 3 Strokes
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 16  When you've got it, flaunt it. David Graham, riding the crest of selfassurance that carried him to the championship of the Professional Golfers' Association on Aug. 5, took up today where he left off on that day.

title: Jeweler and a Chef Slain in Separate Midtown Attacks
description: An 82-year-old jeweler who carried gun and permitted customers entry to his store only by buzzer and a 39-year-old pastry chef at the Four Seasons Restaurant were slain early yesterday in separate incidents in midtown Manhattan.

title: Music Defineth Turf
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y.  We are driving down the sweltering, crowded street in our sealed pod of a vehicle. We are encapsulated, chilled (below 78 degrees Fahrenheit), assuaged by the emollient of our private radio. The woria is our worla. inen at a crosswalk, a teenager with megaradio in tow and sweat in rivulets cuts in front of the car. His music blares the alien beat of some Caribbean rhythm. Behind him, another radio, or rather an amplified set of speakers attached to a couple of knobs. He swings his orchestra with him, the slightest twist in his wrist launching unharnessed decibels toward a new congregation of the unsuspecting. I look toward my passenger. Why must they allow those radios?

title: Boy Starves After Mother Dies
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 16 (AP)A 2yearold boy starved to death after lying for three days beside his young mother, who had died of heart failure, the authorities said today. Another son, 3, was found wandering in the apartment.

title: Mainland Ways Restyle Exotic Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 15  There is still an air of the exotic in Hawaii, where widely diverse peoples have settled on dots of land in the Pacific. But life in this capital city is as mainland as McDonald's Golden Arches, Sears stores and those familiar faces delivering the news every night that was seen in New York six hours earlier.

title: Behind Chrysler's Long Decline: Its Management and Competition
description: DETROIT  The Chrysler Corporation's urgent plea for $1 billion in. Federal aid, coupled with warnings that economic disaster is at hand, has a familiar ring in auto industry circles.

title: The City
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man was stabbed to death yesterday after he fought a group of youths trying to steal his bicycle.

title: Bill Grieve, an Umpire 18 Years In American League, Dies at 83
description: William T. (Bill) Grieve, an American League umpire for 18 years, died Wednesday at Yonkers General Hospital of cancer. He was 83 years old and was a lifelong resident of Yonkers.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 17,1979

title: Leonard S. Janofsky
description: DALLAS, Aug. 15  For many men who reach the presidency of the American Bar Association, the position represents a lifelong goal, doggedly pursued through decades of committee memberships, conventiongoing and toil in the service of the organized bar.

title: Dr. William C. Wilentz; ExJersey Medical Aide
description: Dr. William C. Wilentz, former Middlesex County (N.J.) Medical Examiner, died of a heart attack Sunday at Perth Amboy (N.J.) Hospital. Dr. Wilentz, who retired from private practice as a urologist in his hometown of Perth Amboy early this year. was 79 years old.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced late yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose substantially in the week ended Aug. 8, its second consecutive increase. Earlier in the day, the Fed apparently signaled that the new target rate for Federal funds is 11 percent.

title: PHILLIP E. SYKES
description: Phillip E. Sykes, manager of Lubin Galleries Inc., New York auctioneers, died of a heart attack Sunday en route to St. John's Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He was 36 years old and lived in St. James, L.I. Mr. Sykes graduated from the Missouri Auction School in 1975, before joining Lubin, where he rose rapidly to managerial position. He is survived by his wife, the former Judi Weischer; a son, Phillip, and a daughter, Deborah.

title: New Disquiet On Park's Rule
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13  The onslaught by riot policemen against the headquarters of the main South Korean opposition party last weekend, in which several leaders were severely beaten, has caused many people to ask whether the political situation has come to a turning point.

title: journal Reaches Latin Americans
description: A Spanish journal by the name of Opiniones Latinoamericanas is 13 months old, and its editor suggests that North American companies would be well advised to consider placing institutional advertising into publications read by Latin Americans.

title: Film: Comic 'Rich Kids':Unpushy 12-Year-Olds
description: THE problem with most films about adolescents with problems is that the children are less real as children than as projections of adult fantasies, especially of adult guilt trips. This was one of the things that made George Roy Hill's "A Little Romance" so cloying and even self-serving.Robert M. Young, in his beautifully acted, sometimes very funny new comedy, "Rich Kids," written by Judith Ross, comes close to solving the problem. His secret: children who only occasionally talk above their station and worried, frenetically sophisticated, upper-middle-class adults who are so immediately recognizable that they lend credence to the kind of 12-year-old who'd say solemnly of children, "We have no human rights.""Rich Kids," which opens today at the Coronet, marks a big step forward for Mr. Young, who only recently branched out from the direction of documentary films to make fiction features, his first being the excellent screen adaptation of Miguel Piero's "Short Eyes." "Rich Kids" is something else entirely, a witty exploitation of material that makes me think of a certain kind of affluent New York society as Paul Mazurskyland.Though the film's focus is on two nice, unpushy 12-year-olds  Franny Philips (Trini Alvarado) and Jamie Harris (Jeremy Levy), each a product of parents either split or splitting, "Rich Kids" is equally concerned with, and knowledgeable about, their achingly well-meaning, hilariously self-deluding parents and their parents' various lovers and friends.Like Mr. Mazursky's best films, "Rich Kids" is a New York movie, born and bred. It knows what Manhattan looks and sounds like. It appreciates the awful panics of people who've become so terribly understanding of changing manners and morals that it's a shock when they realize they don't understand a thing and that, really, they're miserable.That's the seriously comic point of Miss Ross's good, unsentimental screenplay about the mess being made of their lives by Paul and Madeleine Philips (John Lithgow and Kathryn Walker). At the opening of the film, Paul and Madeleine are living under a flag of truce. They are separated, but to hide the fact from their daughter, Franny, they continue to live together in their handsome, West Side town house.At the crack of dawn each day, Paul creeps home from his mistress's apartment, climbs into bed with the unwanted Madeleinealways somewhat irritated by her cookie crumbs and the rumpled sheets  to be on hand when Franny awakes. Franny, of course, is quite aware of what's going on and keeps a time-sheet of her father's early-morning arrivals."Rich Kids" is about Franny's innocent affair with Jamie, whose parents are even more thoughtless and possibly funnier. His mother (Roberta Maxwell) is remarried to an incredibly smug but exceedingly happy psychiatrist (Paul Dooley). His father (Terry Kiser), a producer of television commercials, is an aging hipster who drives a Maserati, dates flight attendants and lives in an apartment furnished with jungle trees, cockatoos, piranhas, a jukebox, slot machines, neon lights, fun-house mirrors and a waterbed."Rich Kids" observes its characters with sensitivity as well as humor. Mr. Lithgow and Miss Walker are sweetly perfect as the mismatched parents who come to have some small idea of the foolishness of their existence. Equally good are Mr. Kiser, Miss Maxwell and Mr. Dooley. There's not an off-key performance in the entire film, which is prodigal in its use of New York talent; in addition to those named, that includes David Selby as Franny's mother's lover, Jill Eikenberry, Olympia Dukakis and the beautiful Irene Worth, in her first American film role, as Franny's liberated grandmother.The two youngsters, Trini Alvarado and Jeremy Levy, are as charming as the script and other conventions allow."Rich Kids," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly suggestive situations and a few vulgar words.

title: How Mac Davis Got To Play Quarter back
description: Some people starve themselves so the movie screen will not make them look fat. Mac Davis went the opposite way, pouring nutriments into himself and building up his muscles so he would look like a football player instead of an entertainer. In one month the slender songwritersinger gained 20 pounds, to match his Southern drawl and the cocky look in his eyes, as he portrays a selfcentered quarterback in the new film North Dallas Forty.

title: New President of the Bar
description: New President of the Bar

title: Court Weighs the Case of the Hidden Gold
description: Another tale of a huge cache of gold has been told in the continuing quarrel involving members of a Long Island family who have been arguing over an estate.

title: Antibiotics Prescribed In Unnecessary Doses, Medical Report Finds
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  American hospitals could save $100 million to $200 million a year if doctors stopped prescribing unnecessary doses of antibiotics after their patients undergo surgery, researchers reported today.

title: Italian Woman Gives Birth to 8, but one Dies
description: NAPLES, Aug. 16 (AP)  A 29yearold woman who used fertility drugs gave birth today to five girls and three boys, one of the biggest multiple births on record.

title: The Pop Life
description: ROCKANDROLL can be cruel profession, enforcing stylistic limits on those who'd like to grow and branding others as losers before they've even had a chance to win. These eloomv notions are brought to mind by the career of David Johansen, whose latest album, In Style, has just been released and who will appear with Rockpile at the Palladium next Monday night.

title: Ann Arbor to Train Its Teachers To Assist Black English Pupils
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 16 (AP)Officials of the Ann Arbor school district have adopted a $42,000 plan to help teachers at one school deal with black English. It is believed to be the first program of its kind in the nation.

title: Oil Spill Likely to Menace Gulf Till Tides Shift in Fall
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 16 (AP)  The relentless crude oil slicks from a runaway Mexican oil well that have blackened nearly 20 miles of Texas beaches will menace the coast possibly as far north as Louisiana until autumn winds and tides begin, a leading scientist said today.

title: Gimbel Loss Put at $5.2 Million
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. reported a consolidated net loss yesterday for its second fiscal quarter ended June 30 of about $5.2 million, essentially the same as last year, said Brown & Willimson Industries, which operates Gimbels and Saks Fifth Avenue stores.

title: Sidewalk Cafes: The Best Seats In Town
description: WHILE New York cannot rival Paris and Rome for sidewalk cafes, the city nonetheless has its cafe society, dedicated sitters who will stretch a glass of wine. and a salade nicoise or a cappuccino and a cannoli for an hour or more to watch the world go by. To novices who need just a little help to start becoming boulevardiers in repose this weekend, the following selective survey of New York's sidewalk cafes is dedicated. It is also for those who already enjoy the delights of outdoor cafes and want more.

title: City Acts to End Ban on Auction Of Its Buildings
description: The Board of Estimate approved a policy statement yesterday that was the first step in lifting a ban on selling cityowned buildings at auction that has lasted nearly a year and a half.

title: At the Movies
description: WHAT would Gurdjieff, who traveled the remote regions of the world in search of ancient wisdom, have said if he had known that Peter Brook had had to beg his way across Europe and the United States to raise the money to make Meetings With Remarkable Men, his biographical film about the Russian sage, which is at Cinema 3?

title: U. S. Aides Say Pakistan Is Reported to Be Building an ABomb Site
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Government officials said today that the Carter Administration had received reports that Pakistan was preparing an underground test site for detonating a nuclear weapon.

title: Coastal's Mobil Claim Rejected
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 16  A claim by the Coastal Petroleum Company that the Mobil Oil Corporation broke part of a drilling contract by withholding information has been dismissed in a state court here. Coastal said it would file a revised claim within 30 days.

title: Jazz: Brubeck Sons Band
description: TWO sons of the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck  Darius, a pianist, and Dan, a drummer both of whom have been playing with their father in recent years, have formed a quartet called the Brubeck Brothers Band, subtitled Gathering Forces, which made its New York debut Tuesday and Wednesday at the Other End.

title: Aflame With Power
description: Dragons have always been elusive. At certain periods in their history when subjected to provoca tion and persecution by gods and heroes, they have seemed more evident and more destructive than at others. In the past certain dragons, because of an inordinate greed for sheep or virgins or elephants or ordinary citizens, have attracted notoriety and savage reprisal. But obviously all that is past history.

title: Furniture Industry Moves South, So Furniture Union Moves South
description: The national furniture union, which has made its home in New York City for 45 years, has watched much of the industry move from the highly organized North to the South, where taxes and wages are lower. Now the union is following and plans a major organizing effort there.

title: Harlem Holds a Celebration in 5th Annual Festival
description: In a bygone era, Harlem represented for many New Yorkers a place of gaiety, with a vibrant cultural life paced by the rhythms of its music. Today, however, that uptown community represents to many onlookers little more than the archetype of a beleaguered city ghetto with its accompanying travails.

title: Conservatives Plan $ 700,000 Drive To Oust 5 Democrats From Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Conservative political activists served notice today that they were taking early aim at five Democratic liberal Senators seeking reelection next year, using a relatively untested campaign weapon of major potential.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Buhning Gains Semifinals On StraightSet Victories
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Aug. 16 Fritz Buhning of Short Hills, N.J., a 19yearold University of California, Los Angeles, sophomore who is competing in two tournaments this week, became the first player today to reach the men's semifinals in the United States Tennis AssociationCelanese national 21's tennis championships. The matches are being held at Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club. the first player today to reach the men's semifinals in the United States Tennis AssociationCelanese national 21's tennis championships. The matches are being held at Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club.

title: Deaths
description: PORTEAnna Turkel. Beloved wife of Raphael. Devoted sister of Esther and Max Levine, Florence Robinson, Sonya Bernen, Hope and Leo Pfeffer and Herbert, Irving and Reeven Turkel. Services Friday, August 17th, 11:45 AM, The River side 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Westinghouse Talks Resume
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Representatives of three unions striking against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation resumed talks today with a cornpany bargaining team in an attempt to end a nationwide walkout by 37,900 workers, now in its second month.

title: John Diefenbaker Is Dead at 83; Was Canadian Premier for 6 Years
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 16  Former Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker, one of the most colorful and combative figures in Canadian politics since he was elected to the House of Commons in 1940, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He would have been 84 years old next month.

title: Mobile Theater Stages Mighty Gents at Pier 84
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's new version of Richard Wesley's The Mighty Gents opens tonight on Hudson River pier on the edge of Manhattan's Theater Development District. It will be an evening  weather permitting  of firsts: the directing debut of Ntozake Shange, the first appearance by Joseph Papp's Public Theater in the newly renascent West 40's, the curtain raiser (if there were curtain) for the Festival/Public's 1979 Mobile Theater Season and the first play to be staged on Pier 84, at the foot of West 44th Street. The city has just rehabilitated the pier for public use with new paving, seating, plants and a Water Cafe.

title: TopLevel Changes At Time Inc.
description: Time Inc., the diversified communications company, has elected J. Richard Munro, 48 years old, to the newly created post of executive vice president. Mr. Munro, who had been group vice presidentvideo, will join Andrew Heiskell, chairman, and James R. Shepley, president, in supervising the company's five operating groups as well as its financial and administrative areas.

title: Coleman Acquisition Halted
description: The Coleman Company, a maker of camping and other recreational products, announced that its planned acquisition of Laser International Holdings Ltd. of Montreal had been called off following notice from the Canadian company that it had been offered assistance by the Canadian Government.

title: E.P.A. Withholds Final Approval On '80 G.M. Diesel Automobiles
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) The Environmental Protection Agency today withheld final approval of General Motors' 1980 diesel cars, but said they would be allowed to go on sale pending further pollution tests.

title: Curb on Sales is Sought On Kit for Birth Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  A consumer group urged the Government today to restrict the sale of a test kit for detecting serious birth defects in unborn infants, saying that improper use of the kit could lead frightened women to get unnecessary abortions.

title: Ken Johnson Faces a Giant Step
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Aug. 16If you asked him to, Ken Johnson could write a book about how far it is from the Miami ghetto that blacks call Overtown to the Giants training camp here at Pace University. Johnson thought he would never make it.

title: Unrest Said to Show Rising Opposition to Khomeini
description: PARIS, Aug. 16  Diplomats in Teheran and Iranian exiles here are hesitant to speculate how far the opposition to Ayatollah Ruhallah Khomeini will go or how potent it is. But they say that the outspoken and determined nature of the current demonstrations against the revolutionary leader bear the seeds of a mass movement not much different from the one that dethroned Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in February.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 16 (AP) The Government announced today that 232 people taken prisoner during the war that ousted Idi Amin would be released within two weeks.

title: Propaganda
description: A couple of weeks ago, Dresser Industries ran a striking twopage ad in The Wall Street Journal. It was a handwringing message from Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist, under the headline, I was the only victim of ThreeMile Island. It seems that following that nuclear accident, Dr. Teller, the 71yearold inventor the hydrogen bomb and a passionate promoter of nuclear energy, worked 20 hours a day to rebut the antinuclear propaganda put out by people like Jane Fonda and Ralph Nader. The strain was too much and he suffered a heart attack.

title: Cosmos Win, 31, In Playoff Opener
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16  The Cosmos succeeded in their first game of the playoffs without really trying today.

title: U.S. Planning Loans and Other Aid for Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 16  In a move to encourage improved relations with Nicaragua's new Government, the United States plans to grant it substantial loans and to begin sending it emergency aid directly. Until now, this aid has been channeled through the Red Cross.

title: With Driving Up, State Officials Fear Holiday Gas Crisis
description: Motorists in the New York metropolitan area are returning to the highways in increasing numbers, according to records of major toll roads, and some energy officials are now concerned that a renewed gasoline squeeze might develop over the Labor Day weekend.

title: Ballet: New Lovers Spark Bolshoi's Romeo
description: SLAVA and Nadia, as they are known to their adoring fans, have done it again. On Wednesday night, Vyacheslav Gordeyev and Nadezhda Pavlova stepped into the title roles of Romeo and Juliet and made the Bolshoi Ballet's newest version of Shakespeare's tragedy fall into place.

title: Around the Nation
description: Collision of 2 Ships Laid To Errors of Seamanship

title: H.F.C. Raises Wien Air Bid
description: SEATTLE, Aug.16 (AP)  The Household Finance Corporation has raised its price in its bid to buy Wien Air Alaska, a prize also sought by Alaska Airlines Inc. and its subsidiary, Alaska Northwest Properties Inc.

title: Screen: 'Orchestra Rehearsal' by Fellini:Raucous Ensemble
description: AS is the way of the world, Federico Fellini's comparatively short, gloriously funny new film, "Orchestra Rehearsal," being both profoundly and simply common-sensible, will probably be subjected to as many interpretations in this country as it already has been in Italy.The film, written as well as directed by Fellini, and acted with pricelessly comic conviction by one of his well-known casts of (with one exception) amateurs, is a divertissement commissioned by Italian television. Though it is about nothing more or less than an orchestra rehearsal, the film at one point threatened to become so controversial that it couldn't be televised, which would have been an extension of the sort of small-minded madness that the movie pokes fun at.When the film opens, we see a handsome, empty, 13th-century oratory, the burial place of three popes and seven bishops, but best known for its perfect acoustics. Our guide is an old but still lively copyist, who gives us a bit of the history of the room as he sets up the music stands and then explains what's about to happen, that is, that this particular rehearsal is to be covered by a television crew. Singly and in small groups, the members of the orchestra arrive, followed by two formidable union representatives and the members of the television crew.There is both bickering and good fellowship. One violinist fusses with a barometer. Another fellow objects to being interviewed by television without getting paid. Most of the orchestra members, though, are hams. They can't resist talking, and once started, they won't shut up. Each has a particular relation to his own instrument and is inclined to look down his nose at all the others.When someone claims the first violin to be the heart and the brains of the orchestra, a clarinetist suggests that the clarinet is its penis. The trombonist finds the trombone comic, and the pianist talks grandly of her piano as a king. "It doesn't come to you," she says with passion. "You have to go to it."The instruments are analyzed, described, adored and ridiculed with increasing testiness, until the conductor (Baldwin Bass), an aloof, aristocratic German, comes in to assert his control. Things go badly. As the false starts accumulate, the members of the orchestra become increasingly angry. Their anger is soon matched by the conductor's when he is told by a union man that the saxophonist is staying away "in protest," though he's never told in protest against what.In the course of a union-demanded break, the conductor, in his dressing room, talks eloquently but coldly of his function as a conductor. He recalls his relations with conductors when he was a musician and sees himself as "drawing music out of silence" with his baton. "My job," he says, "is to turn wine into blood, bread into flesh." He's not a bad fellow, but his interests are far removed from the needs and fears of the people he works with."Orchestra Rehearsal" follows the ups and downs of this particular rehearsal with such close, deadpan scrutiny that we are deep inside Fellini's wickedly comic imagination before we are even aware of the change in atmosphere. The orchestra members rebel against the conductor's authority. They overthrow him and replace him with a giant metronome whose reign lasts only a few minutes before it is physically destroyed. The musicians fight among themselves, chant slogans that recall the student riots of 1968 ("Musicians at last/Freed from the past!") and threaten the life of the conductor himself until suddenly. . . well, I can't give away the entire plot, if that's what you want to call it."Orchestra Rehearsal" is, I suppose, a moral lesson of sorts about the cyclical nature of all things. The danger is to see it as a small lesson, one having to do with right-wing and left-wing politics, with unions, capitalism and Communism. Like any film worth thinking about more than 60 seconds, it can be interpreted in a number of ways, but it is so complete, so clear, so wise, so humane and so witty, as just what it is, that to interpret it clumsily is to be in danger of dismantling it forever.I leave that job to those who respect Fellini less than I do. "Orchestra Rehearsal" is of a piece with this brilliant director's very best work.Historical note: The music, which recalls a number of Fellini films, is the last work of Nino Rota, who wrote the scores for every Fellini film from "The White Sheik" on. Mr. Rota died of a blood clot last April 10. He will be missed by the master.

title: Youth Assists Police in Capture of 5
description: A youth who came to Manhattan from Queens early yesterday to look for a job helped Transit Authority policemen capture five members of a teenage gang who allegedly attacked two elderly people in the Times Square area.

title: Reserve Raises Loan Rate to Banks To Record 10% From 10% Level
description: The Federal Reserve Board increased the discount rate to a record 10 percent from 10 percent yesterday in another move to combat inflation and support the dollar in world currency markets.

title: Overstating of Profits Laid to Gulf & Western
description: The following article is based on reporting by Jo Thomas in the Dominican Republic and Jeff Gerth in New York. It was written by Mr. Gerth.

title: Wanted: Exchange Chairman
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16  The Pacific Stock Exchange board of governors took a major step this week toward revamping the nation's thirdlargest stock exchange. If the exchange members approve the move, will begin a search for both a permanent chairman and a fulltime salaried president.

title: Music Hall Searches for Snow White
description: Of course, it's not easy to find Snow White in New York City.

title: Jazz, Readings and Games at Snug Harbor
description: Something for jazz buffs, literary fans and children will be offered this weekend at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 914 Richmond Terrace in Staten Island.

title: Deaths
description: CUTTLEREva (nee Malamud), on August 16, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Benlamin. Beloved mother of Muriel. Devoted grandmother of Bruce and Stuart. Dearest sister of Abrahm and Pessia. Funeral Sunday, August 19, 12 Noon at The Forest Park Chapel, 11403 Queens Blvd.

title: Tomjanovich Suit to Jury
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  A $2.65million damage suit, filed against the Los Angeles Lakers by the Houston Rockets and Rudy Tomjanovich, went to a fiveman, onewoman Federal court jury tonight. The jurors, after listening to 2 hours of final arguments, agreed to begin deliberations tomorrow.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Bayer A.G., a large West German chemical company, must divest itself of some assets in the United States under a consent agreement announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Broadway
description: THE Phoenix Theater will do five full productions this season, as well as five staged readings and two workshops. It also will await the arrival of the six plays it has most recently commissioned. This will be the 27th season for the Phoenix, and whereas the plays it once did, no matter how well it did them, had no place to go after the Phoenix, now they seem to have a life of their own. In recent seasons, Getting Out, Uncommon Women, G. R. Point, A Sorrow Beyond Dreams and Ladyhouse Blues have gone on to other places, and although the Phoenix did not originate all these productions, it did a great deal to help them along. It's a wonderful time to be a playwright, says T. Edward Hambleton, managing director of the Phoenix. For the first time, playwrights can support themselves.

title: YOUNG'S ROLE IN U.N. COULD BRING ABOUT MORE P.L.O. CONTACT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  A new controversy appeared to be developing today when Andrew Young, the outgoing chief United States delegate to the United Nations, indicated that he might have further contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization when he presides over the Security Council this month.

title: Rickover on Job After Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  Adm. Hyman G. Rickover returned to work today only three days after undergoing what was described as a minor hernia operation. The Navy said that the 79yearold Admiral, a pioneer in the development of nuclear submarines, was hack at his office following surgery Monday at the Bethesda, Md., Naval Hospital.

title: The Scene at Lincoln Center Moves Outdoors
description: The potpourri of midsummer gladness that is the Lincoln Center OutofDoors Festival moves Into its first weekend in classical fashion beginning today. The free festival, now in its fifth year, will offer a wide variety of entertainment, ranging from the chamber music of the flutist Elizabeth Brown and the contrabassist Richard Myron (at 6 P.M. today on the North Plaza) to dance and jazz, Latin and AfroCaribbean music.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: For Children
description: Boscobel

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 16, 1979.

title: 4 Studies Conclude That Chrysler Was Damaged by Regulatory Costs
description: DETROIT  Few outsiders attribute all the Chrysler Corporation's problems to the Federal Government, but a consensus appears to be developing that regulatory costs have indeed suffocated Chrysler and damaged the auto industry's competitive structure.

title: New Faces: Frances Conroy and Kaiulani Lee
description: One of the most haunting scenes in the current Othello now playing in Central Park occurs near the end, when Emilia, Iago's wife, is preparing the doomed Desdemona for bed. The love

title: PHOTOGRAPHY CURB RELAXED BY POIVELL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  The White House today relaxed its rules for photographing President Carter on his Mississippi riverboat trip, leading several news organizations to reverse themselves and agree to send photographers along.

title: Aileen O. Webb, Leading Figure In National Crafts Movement, 87
description: Aileen Osborn Webb, one of the most influential figures in the burgeoning of the crafts movement in this country in recent decades, died Wednesday at her large stone and frame house in Garrison, N.Y., after a brief illness. She was 87 years old.

title: Mixed Arts in Greenwich
description: Works by artists, including sculptures, paintings and weavings, will be on display through next weekend in the third members show at the Greenwich Art Barn, 143 Lower Cross Road in Greenwich, Conn., north of the Merritt Parkway. Weekend hours are 9:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. today and tomorrow. 1 to 4 on Sunday. Admission is free. For information, call (203) 6619048.

title: Berta Ohlin Is Dead; Won the Nobel Prize In Economics in 1977
description: Bertil Ohlin, winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for work in the field of international economics, died on Aug. 3 while vacationing in northern Sweden. He was 80 years old.

title: Business and the Law
description: DALLAS

title: S.A.S. Orders 2 Boeing 747 Jets
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Scandinavian Airlines System said today that it had ordered two new Boeing 747 aircraft and taken options on five more jetliners.

title: Bridge:
description: If Virgil had played bridge, he might have chosen a different application for one of the most famous lines ever written in Latin: Timeo Danaos et dona ferentis (I fear Greeks even when they bring gifts). Greeks arrive bearing tricks rather more often than they bear horses, and they are not always attackers.

title: SAWHILL IS REPORTED GETTING ENERGY JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  John C. Sawhill, a highranking energy official under Presidents Nixon and Ford, will become Deputy Secretary of Energy under Charles W. Duncan Jr., the new Secretary, Administration officials said today.

title: Connors Conquers Dibley And Reaches Quarterfinals
description: STOWE, Vt., Aug. 16 (UPI) Jimmy Connors easily advanced to the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Stowe Tennis Grand Prix today by defeating hardhitting Colin Dibley of Australia, 64,62.

title: Korvettes Denies Plan to Close Store
description: Korvettes Inc., the New York Metropolitan area's secondlargest retailer, after R.H. Macy & Company, denied reports yesterday that it planned to close its store on Fifth Avenue.

title: Lilco Plans Experiment In HomeHeating Costs
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 16  The Long Island Lighting Company is looking for 50 families to participate in an experiment on savings in homeheating costs.

title: As Promised, U.S. Drops Case Against Park  Only One of 31 in Congress He Named Was Convicted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  The Government's investigation into South Korean influencebuying efforts among Congressmen came to a close today as the Justice Department, as it had promised, dropped its long list of indictments against Tongsun Park, the major player in the drama.

title: Westchester Board Makes Gain In Solving WasteDisposal Issue
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 16 After more than a decade of studies, debates and delays, the Westchester Board of Legislators appears to be on the verge of adopting a countywide plan for disposing of its garbage in the next 20 years.

title: Hearing on Rise In Rent to Affect Stabilized Units
description: The agency that sets allowable rent increases for the 850,000 rentstabilized apartments in New York City will hold a hearing to consider new rent rises based on climbing prices for fuel oil.

title: Advertising
description: THIS year is the 25th anniversary of color television, and, while the peacock is not expected to jump out of a cake, the consumer products division of the RCA Corporation is planning to spend 23 percent more in the second half on national advertising for its new television and video recording products than it did in the period last year.

title: Kurdish Rebels Said to Seize Town In Western Iran After Fierce Battle
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 16 (AP) Kurdish rebels today overran the town of Paveh, near the Iraqi border, after two days of fierce resistance by Islamic revolutionary guards and state police forces, according to reliable Kurdish sources and press reports in Teheran.

title: Youth Arrested In Girl's Killing In Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 16  A 16-year-old Burlington high school student who lives less than half a mile from the wooded spot where the police found the body of 12-year-old girl was arrested yesterday for her murder.

title: A Bid by Pullman to Quash Subway Subpoena Rejected
description: The chief judge of Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday denied a request by the Pullman Standard Company to quash a subpoena for thousands of documents. The papers are being sought by a grand jury investigating the Transit Authority's purchase from Pullman of 754 defective subway cars.

title: DETROIT EDISON SETS PAYMENT IN BIAS SUIT
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16The Detroit Edison Company, one of the nation's largest electric utilities, agreed today to pay some $5.3 million as part of a plan to resolve a decadelong legal dispute over its hiring and promotion policies for blacks.

title: When Broadway Casts Change, So Do the Shows
description: THE casts of Broadway shows seldom stay intact, and in the last few monthS a number of new actors have come into important Broadway shows. This means that, perhaps invidiously, possibly unfairly and certainly inevitably, they will be compared with the actors they have replaced. Sometimes new actors enhance a play; sometimes they make it work less well. Always, however, they alter it one way or another. What follows is a critical look at some of the new actors and the alterations they have made.

title: Schlesinger, in Farewell, Demands Balance With Russians in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  In a farewell address focusing on what he called the geostrategic landscape, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger warned today that security of American interests in the Middle East rests upon the protection of Allah.

title: Outflow of Savings Set Record in July
description: The mutual savings banks of New York state had a savings outflow in July of $645 million, for a total outflow $2.2 billion so far this year.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Aug. 16, 1979

title: Dr. Donald H. Golf, 60; Consultant on Criminals
description: Dr. Donald H. Goff, a consultant on criminal matters for the Department of Justice and a former general secretary of the Correctional Association of New York, died Tuesday at his home in Pennington. N.J. He was 60 years old.

title: Africa Commission Says Bokassa Had Role in Massacre of Children
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire ordered and probably took part in the massacre in April of about 100 schoolchildren, an African commission of legal experts said here today.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Pared
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Japan's trade surplus narrowed to $210 million last month from a $1.09 billion surplus in June, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: Mets Defeat Braves For Sweep of Series
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 16 The Mets went south this week and found themselves. They beat the Atlanta Braves, 63, tonight to complete their first threegame series sweep since last September.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: TV Weekend carol Burnett Begins Summer Series
description: HERE'S a switch: A summer return that is not a rerun, a familiar face in familiar circumstances but bringing to your home screen entertainment that is fresh and funny. The bearer of these good tidings is Carol Burnett, who tomorrow starts a summer series of four Saturdaynight shows at 8 o'clock on ABCTV.

title: Economic Scene
description: The most vexing economic problem facing the Carter Administration and the Federal Reserve System is the fact that cutting total spending to combat inflation is likely to have a much bigger impact on output and employment for many months to come than on inflation.

title: Mill Basin Buses Run Again
description: The residents of Brooklyn's remote Mill Basin section had bus service again yesterday after the Transit Workers Union agreed to stop obstructing the temporary extension of the Transit Authority's B2 bus route. The service had been suspended at 10 A.M. Wednesday. The obstruction by the union was linked to its strike against the nowdefunct Pioneer Bus Company.

title: New President Is Elected in Nigeria, But 2 Losers May Contest Results
description: LONDON, Aug. 16  Shehu Shagari, Moslem who used to teach science in grade school, has been elected President of Nigeria, the Government radio announced today.

title: State Suit Accuses Carvel and 19 Of Conspiracy to Seek Monopoly
description: The New York State Attorney General charged yesterday that the Carvel Corporation and 19 other defendants, including Thomas Carvel, its founder and president, conspired to monopolize the sales of soft ice cream and supplies to 400 franchised dealers in the state.

title: Air Force Grounds 48 F16's
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  The Air Force announced today that it has grounded the first 48 new F16 jet fighters as a safety precaution after a bolt broke in one engine.

title: Notes on People
description: Call me by my rightful name is what Harry Patterson is telling the Library of Congress, which since 1963 has been wrongly listing the writer's first name as Henry.

title: Art: Painters Take A Brush to Artpark
description: ARTPARK is the name of a 200acre piece of land just outside the little town of Lewiston, N.Y., just north of Niagara Falls. It has a memorable location. We sense (though we cannot see it) that one of the seven wonders of the natural world is just round the corner. The Niagara River flows . past Artpark through a rocky gorge that in itself is awesome. Wooded bluffs race out into the distant plain like headlands the ocean has long ago receded from. Engineering feats of one sort or another give sculpture some stiff competition. The skies are huge and mercurial.

title: Crab and Fluke Abound Off Jersey, Long Island
description: AREA A  Last weekend's storm slowed the fishing, but fluke are beginning to move out of bay waters and are being taken close to the beaches, along with small bluefish and an occasional weakfish to 10 pounds, according to reports from Captain Andy's Marina at Margate, N.J. Boats trolling umbrella rigs in 70 feet of water off Great Egg Inlet were catching 10to12pound blues. The foul weather hurt angling off Point Pleasant, N.J. according to reports from Ken's Landing, and little was caught Monday and Tuesday. By Wednesday, the roiled water began to clear and fishing for fluke improved. weakfish to 10 pounds, according to reports from Captain Andy's Marina at Margate, N.J. Boats trolling umbrella rigs in 70 feet of water off Great Egg Inlet were catching 10to12pound blues. The foul weather hurt angling off Point Pleasant, N.J. according to reports from Ken's Landing, and little was caught Monday and Tuesday. By Wednesday, the roiled water began to clear and fishing for fluke improved.

title: MRS. BRUTTO'S ROLE EMERGES IN PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 12  Pakistani analysts and foreign diplomats here say that as matters now stand, President Mohammed Zia ulHaq, the country's military leader, faces the prospect of turning over power to the widow of the man whose death warrant he signed four months ago.

title: The Opening of Peter Pan Is Postponed Until Sept 6
description: Peter Pan, starring Sandy Duncan and George Rose, has set a new Broadway opening date Sept. 6 at 6:15 P.M. at the LuntFontaruie Theater. Previews will continue until then.

title: Auctions
description: THE booming market in prints  from old masters to pop art works  gained more momentum in New York this season.

title: Prelude to the Beethoven: Vichyssoise and Quiche
description: It is Arthur Cafiero's custom to begin his annual New pork Philharmonic concert series with a cold Hungarian cream of plum soup. If he fails to start with the plum soup, by far the showiest in his repertory, his guests tend to sulk on their picnic blankets on the Central Park Sheep Meadow and to bang spoons against their thermos bottles.

title: Nicaraguans Jubilant At Newspaper's Return
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 16 La Prensa, Nicaragua's leading independent newspaper, returned to the streets at noon today after a 10week absence and copies were snatched up hungrily.

title: Some Still See Young's Meeting As Sign of a U.S. Shift on P.L.O.
description: Israeli officials and some American Jewish leaders continued to express concern yesterday that despite Andrew Young's resignation, his meeting with a Palestinian diplomat might be evidence of a shift in United States policy favorable to the Palestinians. They, along with many black leaders, focused criticism on President Carter.

title: Typhoon Heads for China
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Typhoon Irving, gathering intensity over the East China Sea, headed for China today. Authorities warned the 30 million residents of the Shanghai area to be prepared for torrential rain.

title: N.Y.U. Art at Gracie Mansion
description: Ten paintings by 20thcentury American artists have been lent by New York University to New York City to decorate Gracie Mansion, the official residence of Mayor Koch.

title: Clement R. Hoopes, 72, Novelist
description: Funeral services for Clement R. Hoopes, an author and former State Department adminisirator, will be held today at Christ Episcopal Church, Greenville, Del.

title: Stocks Decline a Bit In 79's Peak Trading
description: Stock prices closed slightly lower yesterday in the heaviest trading of the year. The biggest price moves were posted by some of the specialsituation and bluechip issues.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: ADVICE FOR NEW ATTORNEY GENERAL: Griffin B. Bell, right, the departing Attorney General, conferring yesterday with Benjamin R. CIAIOU during swearingin ceremony at the Justice Department, Mr. Civilettl took the oath of office as Attorney General from Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

title: Sales of Furs to Men Gaining as Season Starts
description: Reggie Jackson has a nutria jacket and an otter coat and is in the market for another fur. Peter Kriendler, a restaurateur, chose a raccoon coat, while John Goldwater, a publishing executive, bought a black beaver coat last year, and Graham Orley, a real estate investor, recently purchased a Canadian otter. And Walt Fraziet's furrier reports the athlete has bought 15 fur coats in the last 10 years.

title: 42 Franklin Simon Stores and Hearn's Are Closed
description: The Franklin Simon chain of 42 women's apparel stores and Hearn's Department Store in the Bronx have been closed as a result of the bankruptcy petition filed on July 27 by the parent City Stores Company.

title: Court of Appeals to Test Televised Oral Arguments
description: After years of resisting televised court proceedings, the New York State Court of Appeals has decided to permit the televising of one day of oral arguments before that court, the state's highest.

title: A DraftKennedy Group in Florida Permitted to Seek Unlimited Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The Federal Election Commission ruled today that an unauthorized Draft Kennedy committee in Florida could raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to influence state party convention in November that will take a nonbinding Presidential straw vote.

title: Publishing: Chinese Weekend in Iowa
description: IN the middle of next month, Chinese writers from China, from Taiwan and from the United States will meet for a weekend of literary discussions at the University of Iowa in Iowa City in an unusual, privately arranged gathering. The organizers are Paul Engle and his Chineseborn wife, the novelist Hualing Nieh, founders of the international writing program at Iowa's School of Letters. To mark the occasion, the Engles are calling Sept. 1516 a Chinese Weekend.

title: Hospital Board, Lacking Funds, Shuts Lutheran
description: The lobby of Lutheran Hospital in Brooklyn was full yesterday  not with the sick seeking medical attention but with employees demanding their final paychecks. The hospital closed its doors unexpectedly Wednesday evening, trans.. ferring 28 patients to nearby St. Mary's Hospital and putting 300 employees out of work.

title: Arbitrators Give Carter a Medal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)  President Carter received a medal from the American Arbitration Association today for his role in the Middle East peace negotiations. I was just the mediator, Mr. Carter said as he was given the award.

title: Anna Turkel, a Soprano In Many Opera Troupes
description: Anna Turkel, an American soprano who made her opera debut in Genoa in 1930 and sang later with opera companies in Rome, Cairo and Chicago, died of cancer Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla., where she had lived for the last two years. She was in her mid70's.

title: EARNINGS Shell Group Net Up 80%; Harvester's Rise Is 89%
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's secondbiggest oil company, today reported an 80 percent rise in its secondquarter profits, a result of higher oil prices and increased North Sea oil production.

title: A Chronology of Events in Young Controversy
description: Following is a chronology of events leading to the resignation of Andrew Young as the American delegate to the United Nations:.

title: Owner of Rams Dismisses Her Stepson as Top Officer
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (AP) Steve Rosenbloom has been dismissed as executive vice president of the Los Angeles Rams and replaced by Don Klosterman, the National Football League team announced today.

title: Screen: 'More American Graffiti' Covers '64 to '67:Where Did They All Go?
description: "MORE American Graffiti" is grotesquely misconceived, so much so that it nearly eradicates fond memories of the original. That film ended in 1962, with its characters poised on the edge of a precipice; this one finds them deep in the abyss. The times  the story is scattered like buckshot from 1964 to 1967  have grown dangerous, but these people haven't awakened at all. They're still the same fun-loving rock-and-rollers, and there's nothing they can't trivialize. So here is a comic look at campus rioting. Here are the beach party aspects of the Vietnam War."More American Graffiti," which opens at the National and other theaters today, couldn't be opening at a less advantageous time, arriving as it does on the heels of "Apocalypse Now." Whatever reservations one may have about that film, the best of its combat footage is phantasmagorically beautiful and presented with haunting sobriety. "More American Graffiti," with its burning-jungle footage drowned out by the Supremes' "Stop! In the Name of Love," is revoltingly flippant by comparison.When Terry the Toad (Charles Martin Smith), one member of the gang who winds up in Vietnam, goofs up an attempts to give himself a flesh wound and get sent home  "ter-rific," he complains, about the rifle that misfires  he is mistaken for a sniper and shot at. He isn't hurt, but his buddies are embarrassed, because a visiting Senator or Congressman has witnessed the scene and expects a body count. "Oh, heck," Terry fudges, "I don't know  you'd have to count up all the arms and legs and stuff  I'd say two dozen." Funny as a corpse, you might say.Things aren't any better on the home front. Hamstrung by the ending of "American Graffiti," which listed the fates of all the principals, the new film becomes one long juggling act. The writer and director, B. W. L. Norton, had a tiny bit of leeway because the original film neglected to mention what happened to most of the women, except for Laurie (Cindy Williams), who of course married Steve (Ron Howard). So Mr. Norton has planted Debbie (Candy Clark) in San Francisco in 1966 as a flower child, and given her Carol (Mackenzie Phillips)  now called Rainbow  for company. Carol, the baby of the first film, seems much older than anyone else in the second.We know John Milner (Paul Le Mat) was killed by a drunken driver in 1964, so the movie has to roll back in time to visit him. And Terry disappeared in Vietnam a year later, so the movie pitches forward again. The Steve-and-Laurie sequence, involving twin sons and a marital spat, culminates among the billy clubs, after Laurie's left-wing brother (now Will Seltzer, formerly Richard Dreyfuss) burns his draft card at a rally; this tale is set in 1967 for balance. The only things that link these separate episodes are the fact that each takes place on New Year's Eve, and the now-hackneyed use of an incessant rock score.The remarkable production notes for "More American Graffiti" explain that each section of the story was shot in the prevailing cinematic style of that period, with Debbie's story full of split-screen psychedelica, Terry's looking like 16-millimeter war footage, John's in a wide-screen Hollywood style and Steve and Laurie's shot like a commercial. The scheme is interesting, but it fits in all too well with the frighteningly scientific method by which Mr. Norton, George Lucas, the executive producer, and Howard Kazanjian, the producer, concocted the screenplay. It seems they divided the proposed running time by four, and then broke down each character's segment into two-minute installments, so that each scene could be accompanied by its own song. They arranged these things on index cards and did the appropriate shuffling. Precisely calculated monotony can be a lot more grueling than the haphazard kind.It's nice to see the original cast reassembled, even if they're only treading water. Mr. Le Mat, who has been given a beautiful Icelander (Anna Bjorn) to romance, has less to do than the others, but with the absence of Mr. Dreyfuss, he becomes the one character of any weight in the story. Miss Williams makes an effective transition from angry sweetheart to angry homemaker, perhaps because so much of the present character is preordained by her earlier performance. Harrison Ford makes a very brief (and uncredited) appearance as a policeman giving a ticket to the perennially flaky Miss Clark, who seems to be right in her element in the drug culture of the mid-60's. Wolfman Jack, heard bellowing on the soundtrack for old times' sake, has long since worn out his welcome."More American Graffiti" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains some war footage and occasional coarse language.

title: Screen: Alan Alda Writes and Stars in 'Joe Tynan':Coping With Fame
description: ALAN ALDA'S Joe Tynan isn't altogether believable as a politician, but he's a warm, sensitive, intelligent character, around whom an uncommonly well-meaning movie has been fashioned. Mr. Alda's screenplay for "The Seduction of Joe Tynan," which opens at the Gemini 2 and other theaters today, is ambitious enough to touch on even more aspects of this man's life than it can comfortably handle  especially because Tynan's main problem is how to keep his wife, children, mistress and dizzying career from running away from him. The film, like Senator Tynan, is in danger of being spread too thin.But Mr. Alda offers someone who genuinely cares about his diverse interests, even when they conflict, and who has a natural talent for making sound choices. The title is a bit misleading, and so is any notion that the film is about politics. For one thing, Mr. Alda's Tynan, while certainly human enough to have his head turned by sufficient flattery, isn't passive enough to be seduced. For another, he isn't chilly enough to pay single-minded attention to political life. Mr. Alda plays Tynan's professional smoothness to the hilt, but he never gives the man enough ruthlessness to match his alleged charisma, or enough charisma to explain his status as a budding national hero.A crucial scene at the end of the movie shows Tynan, about to make a nominating speech at the Democratic National Convention, more eager to have a heart-to-heart talk with his wife than to make the speech. Indeed, as he steps out before an auditorium full of cheering delegates, the thing that gives him the greatest satisfaction is his wife's smile. Implausible as this may be in the arena of national politics, it seems applicable enough to a more generalized kind of fame, which is perhaps what Mr. Alda meant to consider in the first place. In any case, Tynan's colleagues in the Senate are so well played that the film's wheeler-dealer scenes work nicely enough on the level of simple character study. And his complicated home life could just as well be that of any man who is suddenly more celebrated than he ever expected to be.Barbara Harris plays Tynan's bright, pretty, admirably self-sufficient wife, with whom he is very evidently in love. Meryl Streep, more stunning with each new appearance on the screen, has an equally tangible hold on him as a cool, clever, irresistible labor lawyer with whom he is thrown into professional contact. It can't remain strictly business for long. But Miss Streep's remarkable accomplishment is to keep both Tynan and the audience perpetually off balance, to turn a predictable affair into a source of constant surprise.The director, Jerry Schatzberg, achieves the most subtly impressive scene in the film when, as Miss Streep realizes during a private conference in the Senator's office that their flirtation is about to become something more, he simply trains the camera in closely on her astonishingly versatile face."The Seduction of Joe Tynan" bends over backwards too far to make sense of this romance. Miss Streep, who is supposed to be married, is given an unnecessary scene with a husband who's always traveling and altogether neglectful of her; however, she has already made her character too alluring for this to make sense. Similarly, Mr. Alda is able to decide, with unconvincing ease, how to solve the problem of having two marvelous women in his life.Midway through the movie, once the conflicting forces at work on Joe Tynan have been explained, the whole thing switches into too high a gear, rushing through solutions that are simpler than the problems at hand. In a quick and mystifying montage, Tynan is seen gearing up for a possible Presidential campaign; then, just as abruptly, he's back home in Westchester County, trying to cheer up his troubled teen-age daughter. The optimism of Mr. Alda's screenplay is surely admirable, but by this stage of the story something more complex is called for. Joe Tynan, after digging himself into what ought to be a gigantic hole, suddenly sprouts wings and flies away.The principal thing that keeps "The Seduction of Joe Tynan" engrossing is the level of acting it sustains throughout. Rip Torn brings a new dimension to political sleaziness in the role of a skirt-chasing (and catching) Southern Senator, and Melvyn Douglas is suitably alarming as an elder statesman on the verge of senility. Miss Harris is particularly graceful in avoiding the stereotype of the politician's wife. Just as Miss Streep does, she shows the audience something new.

title: Film: 'Monty Python's Life of Brian':Gospel of Lunacy
description: FOLLOWING the star, the Three Wise Men make their way across the desert to the manger to adore the newborn babe, tended by his mum, a snaggle-toothed crone named Mandy. Until they produce their gifts, Mandy will have none of the Three Wise Men, whom she takes for fortunetellers. Mandy grabs the gold and the frankincense but is suspicious of the myrrh. "What is myrrh?" she asks with a sniff. "It sounds like some kind of animal to me. Something with horns . . ."Thus begins "Monty Python's Life of Brian," which should restore our confidence in the belief that not all of the earth's unnatural resources have been depleted. Just when you thought that the uproarious English comedy troupe had taken bad taste as far as it could go in "Monty Python and the Holy Grail," along comes "Monty Python's Life of Brian" to demonstrate that it's possible to go even farther in delirious offensiveness. Bad taste of this order is rare but not yet dead."Monty Python's Life of Brian," which opens today at the Cinema 1, succeeds in sending up not only movies like "The Greatest Story Ever Told" and "King of Kings," but also a lot of the false piety attached to the source material. It is the foulest-spoken bibical epic ever made, as well as the best-humored  a nonstop orgy of assaults, not on anyone's virtue, but on the funny bone. It makes no difference that some of the routines fall flat because there are always others coming along immediately after that succeed. The film is like a Hovercraft fueled by comic energy. When it comes to a dry patch, it flies blithely over with no reduction in speed."Life of Brian" is the not-so-reverent account of the life, times and apotheosis of one Brian of Nazareth (Graham Chapman), a none-too-bright, would-be Judean freedom fighter who deeply annoys Pontius Pilate and whom people keep trying to turn into a messiah. According to the Monty Python gospel, the principal business in the Holy Land is the organization of inept liberation movements, while the people are made dozy by dozens of aspiring messiahs, including one fellow who warns of the coming of the awful day when "things will go astray . . . a father's hammer, various household items . . ."The movie was directed by Terry Jones (co-director of "The Holy Grail") and written by Mr. Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle, Mr. Jones and Michael Palin, all of whom turn up in the film in dozens of major and minor roles, not all of which can be distinguished by anyone except the mother of the individual actor.Some people who wander into this film will stalk out in as high a dudgeon as is possible in the dread darkness of a movie theater  as did one fellow sitting behind me at a sneak preview. Others will want to see it a second time to catch the dialogue overwhelmed by laughter during the first viewing.There is no way to criticize these hijinks adequately, except to inventory some treasured moments. One that I recall most fondly is a sermon on a mountain so distant that the listeners can't quite catch the words. "Blessed are the Greeks?" says one man. "How very curious." "What did he say?" asks another fellow, "'Blessed are the cheesemakers?'" A third man explains: "He's not talking literally. What he means to say is blessed are manufacturers in general . . ."Go.

title: The Youngest Millionaire
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 16  When the Metropolitan Golf Writers gave Tom Watson their Gold Tee Award Wednesday night for winning a million dollars faster than anybody else, he told what it was like to feel pressure on the course. Sinking a putt to win the British Open was one thing, he said, but that wasn't a patch on the strain he experienced at the age of 7 when his father took the family out for a round on a vacation in Colorado. They were about to tee off when the club pro put up a holler, saying he couldn't have little kids cluttering up the course. Tom's father pointed to a ditch cutting the fairway 75 yards from the tee. If the boy could carry the ditch, he asked, could he play? The pro agreed.

She never really made it big back home, however, until she started appearing on the Happy Days television show and had a recent hit with a song called Stumblin In. But that was in a softer, more middleoftheroad idiom than her past, so one was curious as to what style she'd espouse at her twonight engagement at the Village Gate, which began Thursday.

Bozzuto of Watertown, Conn., was married there last evening to William Thompson Tolley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wooster Tolley of Port Edwards, Wis. The Rev. Marshall A. Filip performed the ceremony in St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. William Zito, a Congregational minister, assisted.

title: Governments At All Levels Ignore Toxic Wastes, Rockland Jury Finds
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 17  After an eightmonth investigation, a special Rockland County grand jury sharply criticized government agencies at all levels today for the way they dealt with hazardous wastes, which it termed profitable business for callous individuals and corporations.

title: The City
description: Legislation to authorize the prompt removal of street peddlers property when it creates a hazard to public safety was proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Farm Exports Value Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Farm exports in the next accounting year could be worth 9 percent to 25 percent more than this year, increasing the nation's favorable balance of agricultural trade by up to $4.3 billion, to $20 billion, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 400 Lakes in Adirondack Area To Be Tested for Acid Content
description: ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP)  More than 400 lakes in the Adirondacks will be tested to determine the amount of damage done to them by acid rain, it was announced today.

title: Hewlett Cites Earnings Rise
description: The HewlettPackard Company, the world's largest maker of electronic measuring instruments and producers of computers, data terminals, disk memories and printers, yesterday reported a 57.6 percent jump in earnings for the third fiscal quarter on a sales rise of 44.2 percent.

title: CALIBER SUPPORTED BY GROUP OF BLACKS
description: A group of 20 black city and state political figures gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to announce their support for State Senator Joseph L. Galiber in his bid for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of the Bronx.

title: Biologist Says Tanzanian Troop Are Decimating Uganda Wildlife
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 17  Tanzanian soldiers are decimating wildlife in Uganda's game reserves, one of the world's richest, according to an American biologist who arrived here from Uganda today.

title: Snow on Plane Blamed In a Crash Fatal to Two
description: WASHINGTON, AUG. 17 (AP)  Government investigators said yesterday that excessive snow on the wing and tail of an Allegheny Airlines commuter plane caused it to crash last February near Clarksburg. W. Va.. killing two persons.

title: John Cardinal Wright Is Buried; Dignitaries Attend Boston Mass
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  John Cardinal Wright, ranking American in the Roman Catholic hierarchy, was buried today after a mass attended by 11 Cardinals and countless bishops, priests, government leaders and friends.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Puerto Rican Poets, Music In Central Park Monday

title: Newspaper Contract Is Ratified
description: Members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers voted 61 to 1 yesterday to ratify threeyear contracts with The New York Times and The Daily News. The agreements were the last covering 11 unions and replacing contracts that expired March 30, 1978, at the two morning papers and at The New York Post. All of the contracts provided $68 in added weekly wages spread over the threeyear term.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Aug. 17  A Londonbased human rights organization charged in report to the United Nations today that the life of Haitian workers in the neighboring Dominican Republic could be compared only with slavery.

title: Jewish Unit Offers Three Free Concerts
description: Three free concerts will be offered in Manhattan and Queens during the next two weeks, in a series sponsored by the American Jewish Congress and financed by the Federal Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Dance: Ram Island, From Maine
description: The Ram Island Dance Company came down from Portland, Me., to give a pleasant concert Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory. Directed by Sam Costa and Nancy Salmon, the group presented works by company members and by two guest choreographers, the imports proving to be the stronger offerings.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Legionnaire's Disease Kills a Brooklyn Man; 1st Fatal Case in Year
description: A 55yearold Brooklyn bus driver died of legionnaire's disease last Sunday, the first fatality from the disease this year in New York City, the city's Health Department announced yesterday.

title: Letters
description: Statesmen and Sycophants

title: McEnroe Defeats Fibak, Gains Toronto Semifinals
description: TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP)  Secondseeded John McEnroe of the United States and 19yearold Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia gained quarterfinal victories today at the Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Miss Wright Offers Songs And Comedy
description: In a tiny Greenwich Village cabaret such as the Duplex at 55 Grove Street, where the performers are usually young singers and comedians trying to find their directions and honing their talents, Margaret Wright comes as a distinct surprise. Miss Wright, a mature, strikingly handsome and warmly communicative woman who is appearing at the Duplex on Thursdays at 9 P.M. only through this month, has paid her dues  and now those dues are paying off for her.

title: Around the Nation
description: DELANO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers union said today that it would file a civil rights suit against a grape grower whose workers voted to oust the union from the site of its first major victory under California's pioneering farmlabor election laws.

title: Iraq Reportedly Cuts Military Aid To Eritrean Guerrillas in Ethiopia
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug 17 (Reuters)  Iraq has halted military and financial aid to one of the guerrilla groups fighting for the independence of Ethiopia's Eritrea Province, Persian Gulf diplomatic sources said today.

title: Reforming Immigrant Policy
description: The uncertain fate of the boat people has captured worldwide attention and highlighted the need for a thorough review of United States immigration policy. With the creation of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, there is the opportunity to review the historic evolution of our immigration policy and its relevance to our foreign and domestic needs in the next two decades.

title: About New York.
description: There has been so much thought given in these last several years to the right to die, to the hopelessness of those who have little reason to hope, that it is refreshing to meet Alan Murfitt, 32 years old, a Bronx New Yorker who grew up on tough, mean streets and knows that, before anything else, you have to keep going.

title: Kathy Studeny Married To Gregory T. Vesonder
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jude the Apostle in Erie, Pa., last evening, Kathy Ann Studeny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Studeny of Erie, became the bride of Gregory Timothy Vesonder, son of Mrs. George Vesonder of Duquesne, Pa., and the late Mr. Vesonder. The Rev. Robert Levis, director of the Pontifical Institute for Catechetical Studies at Gannon College, performed the ceremony.

title: Oil Stocks Advance As Dow Slips a Bit
description: The stock market finished slightly lower yesterday in much slower trading, with oil issues scoring some of the best gains after President Carter signed an order to decontrol prices of heavy crude oil.

title: EDO Gets Navy Contract
description: The EDO Corporation, a New Yorkbased producer of electronic and other equipment for industrial and military uses, has received a $16.2 million United States Navy contract for pro+ duction of sonar systems, including special tools, test equipment and field change kits.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: STATE DEPT. AVOIDS A CLASH WITH YOUNG
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 The State Department appeared today to have resolved what some saw as a possible disagreement with Andrew Young, who suggested yesterday that it would be unconscionablefor him to refuse, as President of the Security Council, to see representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Officials Baffled by Oil Splotches Over a Vast Area of Northern Gulf
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 17 Vast expanses of the northern Gulf of Mexico are now splotched with a film of oil. But the authorities are uncertain about how much of it is coming from Mexico's runaway offshore oil well, how much of it may reach the United States coast and whether it could cause significant damage.

title: Even the Touts Aren't Sure
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17  It was the day before the Travers, a time when any selfrespecting tout should have had everything all figured out.

title: Railroad Union Delays Strike to Examine Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Union officials have postponed a strike scheduled for tomorrow against the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad in order to study a proposal by a Federal mediation panel.

title: Checker Sells Assets
description: In announcing an agreement in principle to sell $34 million of assets, the Checker Motors Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., said the purchasers included Koch Industries; two board members of Checker, and one private investor. The assets do not include certain real estate in Kalamazoo.

title: Bell to Be Crime Aide For Mayor of Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (AP)  Griffin B. Bell, who resigned recently as Attorney General, will serve as an adviser on crime to Mayor Maynard Jackson.

title: Union Carbide Study To Relate Chemicals And Employee Deaths
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug. 17 (UPI)  The Union Carbide Corporation announced today that it would survey the health histories of 40,000 employees to determine why they have been dying from certain kinds of cancer at a rate three to four times normal levels.

title: Muzorewa Says Regime's Forces Began Clashes With Rival's Units
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa said today that Government troops had opened fire first in clashes that killed at least 183 counterinsurgency auxiliary forces loyal to his chief internal rival, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole.

title: RCA REACHES ACCORD ON BUYING COMPANY IN $1.35 BILLION DEAL
description: The RCA Corporation and the C.I.T. Financial Corporation said yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle for RCA to acquire C.I.T. for $1.35 billion in what would be one of the largest mergers in American corporate history.

title: Fuel Oil Supply Projected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  The Energy Department says heating oil supplies appear to be heading for an adequate stockpile level this fall, with an added safety margin likely to develop as demand slows down.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Volkswagen of America raised the sticker price of its 1980 United Statesbuilt Rabbit by $196 today and said it was increasing the price of options by an average of 8 percent.

title: President Decontrols Price of Heavy Crude
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 President Carter made good today on a pledge last month to decontrol the price of heavy crude oil, a small portion of total domestic oil production. In addition, as previously promised, the President said he would ask Congress to exempt the special oil from the windfall profits tax now under consideration on Capitol Hill.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. That was not a lie, it was just not the whole truth, the man pictured above said of a remark he made that provoked not only controversy but his resignation as well. Who is he, to what remark was he referring, and from what nosition did he resign?

title: Curran Says Cigarette Bootlegging Is Ruinous and He Calls Carey Lax
description: The special Federal prosecutor Paul J. Curran declared yesterday that the wholesale cigarette industry in New York State was being driven out of business by organizedcrime bootleggers, and he charged Governor Carey with inexplicable inaction in initiating legislation to combat them.

title: Supporters of Kennedy in Florida Plan a FundRaiser in New York
description: The Draft Kennedy committee in Florida, armed with a Federal ruling that lets it raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to influence the state's psychologically important straw vote, will seek funds at a $250aticket cocktail party in New York City Sept. 13.

title: F.R. Duffy, ExSenator and Judge
description: F. Ryan Duffy, former Senator from Wisconsin and chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, died Thursday in Milwaukee. He was 91 years old.

title: Lloyd Cutler, Washington Lawyer, Is Named as White House Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  President Carter today selected Lloyd N. Cutler, wellknown Washington lawyer, as his counsel.

title: NonOpenable Windows Become an Energy Issue
