description: The design of windows in planned and existing office buildings and hotels has become a central issue in the debate among architects and realestate developers over the best ways to save energy and reduce operating costs.

title: Albert Markov to Give First Carnegie Hall Recital
description: Albert Markov, the Soviet migr violinist, will give his first Carnegie Hall recital on Oct. 28 at 8 P.M. The Kharkovborn violinist, who studied with Pyotr Solomon Stoljarsky, made his debut in the United States in November 1976.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, Aug. 17, 1979

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Companies

title: Court Curbs Takeover By Exxon
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a merger of the Exxon Corporation and the Reliance Electric Company could proceed only if Exxon would refrain from using Reliance to market a new motor control during a court review of antitrust implications of the merger.

title: INITIATIVE A SURPRISE
description: TEL AVIV, Aug, 17  The United States, in a surprise move, proposed today that Israel support an Americansponsored Security Council resolution on Palestinian rights that might be attractive to socalled moderate Arabs. It was imediately rejected by Israel.

title: 7 Days That Shook Los Angeles
description: As we stagger to the end of another hot and troubled August, my mind winds back to Aug. 11, 1965. On television, in prime time  in fact around the clock for seven days that shook not only Los Angeles but the world  was an urban nightmare, coming live from Watts.

title: Hanoi Official Asserts Thousands Are Being Held for Own Protection
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 17  Vietnam continues to hold without trial several thousand people in reeducation camps and does so largely for their own protection, according to Nguyen Co Thach, Hanoi's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Film

title: U.S. MAY BUY ISLAND FOR NUCLEAR WASTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  The Carter Administration is considering buying a small, uninhabited island in the South Pacific for storage of nuclear waste from Asian reactors, Government officials said today.

title: Rock: Talking Heads and B52's Finally Get Together in Concert
description: The combination of the Talking Heads and the B52's seemed one of the strongest bills at the 1979 Dr Pepper Festival, but it took three tries for the concert to take place. The first two efforts were rained out, and it was only Thursday that the pairing finally got to make music in Central Park.

title: Conservative Youth Group Finds Itself in a More Centrist Position
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  Young Americans for Freedom, normally the ultimate in political outsiders, has unexpectly acquired sort of an establishment status, and the members don't quite know how to react to it.

title: The Open Disarray of Closed Justice
description: The fallout from the Supreme Court's decision closing certain court proceedings to the public and press seems to have distressed Chief Justice Burger, who voted with the majority. The ruling, handed down on July 2, has already produced an epidemic of court closings across the country. Often the closings have come in situations very different from the case the Court decided. The Chief Justice, departing from tradition to comment on the case, told reporters recently that many judges were misreading the Court's decision. Maybe the judges, he suggested, are reading newspaper reports of what we said.

title: Chrysler Loan Plan Opposed by Reuss
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the influential House Banking Committee, said here today that based on current information, he could not support loanguarantee legislation for the ailing Chrysler Corporation.

title: Empire State Games Big, But Relatively Unknown
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 17  The Empire State Games being held here this week are, in terms of participants, bigger than the Pan American Games, bigger than the National Sports Festival, bigger in fact than any Olympictype sports event ever staged in the United States, including the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles. So why have so few people heard of the Empire State Games?

title: New Swimsuits Bare a Lot
description: You don't have to wear a bikini to show lots of skin on the beach. In the swimwear shows for the 1980 resort season, suits are cut dangerously low in front and back, revealingly high on the thigh.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 18, 1979

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Florida Keys Face Water Scarcity
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP) Residents of the Florida Keys face jail terms of up to 60 days or fines of $500 if they water lawns, fil swimming pools or wash cars while the island community struggles with a severe water shortage.

title: Maurice H. Matzkin, an ExJudge
description: Maurice H. Matzkin, a former Criminal Court judge and Acting Commissioner of the New York City Department of Hospitals under Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died in a Miami nursing home after a long illness. He was 80 years old and had lived in Miami since his retirement in 1968. His wife, the former Hannah Simensky, died July 30.

title: Letter: On Chemical Wastes
description: To the Editor:

title: A OneYear Test of Dirtier Fuel
description: Con Edison is one of the cleanest utilities in the country. It got that way because it is barred from burning either coal or highsulfur fuel oil. Now Con Ed wants to try a oneyear test. It would burn highersulfur oil at two generating units on Staten Island and at another in Queens and if New York City's air quality didn't deteriorate after a year the three plants would be converted to coal that was comparably sulfurous. The utility says coal supplies would be more secure than imported oil and would save customers $150 million a year on their electric bills.

title: S.E.C. Cites Riklis on Debt Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Meshulam Riklis, the chairman of the RapidAmerican Corporation, of paying off his personal debts by arranging business deals between his companies and his creditors.

title: Sawhill Speaks Out on Energy Crisis
description: John C. Sawhill, expected to be named Deputy Secretary of Energy, said yesterday that the energy situation has become more critical than it was when he served as the nation's energy chief in 1974.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Parkies to the Rescue
description: New York City's fiscal troubles have claimed many victims, none more visible than its parks and playgrounds. Fifteen years ago, recreation workers manned virtually every playground, supervising games and keeping an eye on the physical plant. By 1977, fewer than half the city's parks were covered so closely. Parks Department maintenance workers were even known to offer the fiscal crisis as an excuse for not picking up the debris in front of them.

title: The Region
description: WESTBURY, L.I. A gas explosion ripped through a shopping area here yesterday, injuring four persons who were rushed to the Nassau County Medical Center's special burn unit in East Meadow. The interiors of three stores were destroyed in the ensuing onehour blaze on Post Avenue.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: TV: Arthur Godfrey Celebrates Fifty Years on the Air Tonight
description: It was 50 years ago that Arthur Godfrey took to the air, both as broadcaster and airplane pilot, and tonight at 6:30 he is Celebrating the halfcentury, on WNEWTV, with a 90minute show that is part album of reminiscence, part variety show.

title: City Intensifying Its Efforts to Cut Bank Robberies
description: Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that more city detectives would be added to joint FederalNew York City force that has been formed to deal with the increasing number of bank robberies in the city: They said members of the force would stake out banks.

title: Dance: Ludmila Semenyaka Is Star of Bolshoi's 'swan Lake
description: It has been no surprise to see the State Theater sold out for the Bolshoi Ballet every night. This is one of the greatest companies in the world, totally itself and unlike any other.

title: Joe Hill Pardon Sought; Radical Was shot in 15
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17  In a small office on East Harrison Street, almost under the elevated train, Leslie Orear, a 68yearold retired publicist for the meat cutter's union, is directing a campaign to exonerate Joe Hill, the fabled labor radical and balladeer who was executed by a Utah firing squad Nov. 19,1915.

title: 4 Children Found Slain In Burning Texas House
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  The bodieS of four children, three of them bound hand and foot and all apparently strangled, were found today in a house fire that investigators said was arson.

title: Clare Boothe Luce at 76
description: HONOLULU  There was a time when Clare Boothe Luce was very much in the center of things. Now, at age 76, she lives quietly just outside Honolulu in a sprawling house by the ocean, surrounded by lush gardens that seem to creep inside, when no one is looking.

title: Associates Say Haskell Ward Will Quit Post
description: Associates of Haskell Ward said yesterday that he would resign as Deputy Mayor for Human Services in a dispute over the Koch Administration's plans to close four municipal hospitals.

title: Vivian Vance, Actress, Dies at 66; CoStar of I Love Lucy TV Show
description: Vivian Vance, a longtime star of the I Love Lucy television series, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Belvedere, a town across the Golden Gate from San Francisco. She was 66 years old.

title: Bundy Will Get Hearing Aug. 27 On Plea for New Trial in Murders
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 17(AP) Theodore R. Bundy, the convicted murderer, will get to argue for a new trial on Aug. 27, Circuit Judge Edward D. Cowart said yesterday.

title: Officer Slain Chasing Midtown Bank Holdup Suspect
description: A New York City police officer was shot and killed and a plainclothes detective seriously wounded yesterday morning in a gun battle with a robbery suspect near an East 42d Street entrance to Grand Central Terminal.

title: European Summer: Glum Days at Rumanian Beach.
description: MAMAIA, Rumania  It was Wednesday. Clouds again, the third day in a row. Kids crabbing. Marital disputes in German, Hungarian, French and Rumanian. The last traces of goodsport restraint shriveling for lack of sun. And this conversation, in strong Berlin accent, at the casino cotfee bar:

title: China Rewards Small Families
description: PEKING, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Salary increases have been awarded in Tientsin to 28,000 couples with one child who pledged to have no more children, the official Communist Party paper reported today. The People's Daily said each couple was give an increase of $3.24 a month.

title: Coast Panel Asks Further Study On Nuclear Plant's Alleged Peril
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 18 (AP)  The California Coastal Commission has called for further research to determine whether the San Onofre nuclear power plant is harming marine life.

title: I Fed Voted To Lift Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  In a special meeting, the Federal Open Market Committee voted on July 27 to push up shortterm interest rates to slow a rapid increase in the money supply, according to meeting records published today.

title: Black Leader Will See Israeli and P.L.O. Separately
description: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference announced yesterday that the chief Israeli representative at the United Nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer there had agreed to meet separately with the president of the black civil rights group.

title: ALFRED J. SCOTTI, 75, FORMER PROSECUTOR
description: Alfred Joseph Scotti, a meticulous lawyer who prosecuted some of the city's most spectacular criminal cases in nearly 36 years as an assistant to two Manhattan District Attorneys  Thomas E. Dewey and Frank S. Hogan  died Yesterday at the age of 75.

title: Miss Wilde to Head Ballet School
description: Patricia Wilde, the ballerina whose strong technique dazzled New York City Ballet audiences for 15 years, has been named director of the American Ballet Theater School. She will begin her duties with the start of the scnoors fall term, Sept. 4. Leon DanielLan, whom she succeeds, will remain as a consultant to the school.

title: Suit Alleges Itel Inflated Stock Price
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (AP) The financially troubled Itel Corporation of San Francisco became the target today of a class action suit by a group of shareholders in Federal court alleging a conspiracy to inflate the price of its stock artificially.

title: French Taking Hard Look at Military Policy
description: PARIS, Aug. 17  A quiet but increasingly profound debate is developing in France on basic military policy, which has been essentially unchanged and virtually unquestioned since it was set by President de Gaulle a generation ago.

title: Film: A Late Rossellini And an Early Carpenter:The Cast
description: One of the odder but more interesting film programs in the city is the one that opened yesterday at the Thalia: Roberto Rossellini's "Fear," made in 1954, the last of the extraordinary features in which Rossellini directed Ingrid Bergman, who was then his wife; and "Assault on Precinct 13," the 1976 film made by John Carpenter, who later directed the more notorious horror picture, "Halloween."Though Rossellini's films with Miss Bergman, including "Stromboli" and "Europe '51," never created a popular stir in their own day, they now constitute one of the more moving personal records of a love affair ever to be contained in supposedly commercial motion pictures."Fear," adapted from the Stefan Zweig story, "Angst," is about the absolute end of trust in what must at first have seemed a perfect marriage. It's the story of a wealthy, able German businesswoman (Miss Bergman) who submits to the terrors and humiliation of blackmail in order to preserve the innocence of the husband she adores, but whom she systematically undercuts at home and in his career."Fear" is not especially concerned with what went wrong in the marriage. Its subject is the depth of a bitterness that can pass for love. It's a simply but beautifully constructed movie that is far more austere than the elegant clothes and upper-middle-class decor would indicate. Even while he was closing out this phase of his film-making career, Rossellini was apparently preparing for the series of great teaching films that were to be the obsession of his last years.Miss Bergman is splendid in a role that quietly hints at her bravura possibilities realized by Ingmar Bergman in last year's "Autumn Sonata." Matthias Wiemann plays her husband, a fellow who has apparently spent time in a concentration camp and whose profound feelings provide the film with its unexpected revelations."Assault on Precinct 13" is a much more complex film than Mr. Carpenter's "Halloween," though it's not really about anything more complicated than a scare down the spine. A lot of its eerie power comes from the kind of unexplained, almost supernatural events one expects to find in a horror movie but not in a melodrama of this sort.The title tells the story, which is about a small group of people  a police officer, a couple of prisoners and several civilians  who find themselves besieged in a precinct station on the edge of a desolate Los Angeles slum. What makes the film so effective is that the attackers seem to be as motiveless, and relentless, as the zombies who stalk through "Dawn of the Dead."If the movie is really about anything at all, it's about methods of urban warfare and defense. Mr. Carpenter is an extremely resourceful director whose ability to construct films entirely out of action and movement suggests that he may one day be a director to rank with Don Siegel.The program will be shown only today at the Thalia.

title: Notes on People
description: Hammersmith Farm, the childhood home of Jacqueline Onassis, is up for sale again. The asking price this time is $5 million.

title: Black Theater Alliance To Open Tuesday Sept. 5
description: Tuesday, a play with no words by Jewel Walker, a drama professor at the University of Wisconsin, will have its New York premiere at the Black Theater Alliance, 410 West 42d Street, on Sept. 5.

title: Corporate Profits Off 2.4% As U.S. Growth Falters
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Corporate aftertax profits slipped 2.4 percent in the second quarter this year, but the nation's overall economic performance did not fall as abruptly as had been thought at first, the Government reported today.

title: Toll Is 173 in Soviet Air Collision, Second Worst Disaster in Midair
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP)  The collision of two Soviet Aeroflot jetliners over the Ukraine killed 173 people, a reliable Soviet source said today, making it the second worst such disaster in aviation history.

title: Bridge:
description: The tendency in recent years has been for the number of tournaments in suburban areas to increase while the number in New York City remains constant or diminishes. A prime cause is the growing difficulty of finding suitable accommodations in Manhattan at affordable prices, coupled with the reluctance of suburban players to come to the city to compete.

title: C.S.C. in Itel Deal
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation announced yesterday in El Segundo, Calif., that it had reached an agree.. ment in priniciple with the Itel Corporation for the purchase of three Itel operating units for $19 million in cash. The agreement is subject to approval by both companies.

title: Inquiry Set on Report of Soccer Collusion
description: The North American Soccer League said yesterday that it would investigate a report that an attempt was made to have the Rochester Lancers and the New England Tea Men intentionally give up goals to each other in their final regularseason game last Friday night.

title: PRE'81 CASIN0 VOTE RULED OUT BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey has abandoned his plan to push for a statewide referendum this year or next on the question of legalizing casino gambling, top aides to Mr. Carey said yesterday. Instead, the aides said, he intends to ask the Legislature to nut the issue before the voters in 1981.

title: Iran stages Huge Rally in Support of Palestinians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 (AP)  Hundreds of thousands of Iranians converged on Teheran University today in a demonstrationof support for Palestinians.

title: Hijacking Suspect Held In Florida in Air Piracy
description: MIAMI, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Allah R. Kagan, accused of taking over an Eastern Air Lines jet last night and trying to divert it to Cuba, was arraigned today on air piracy charges and ordered held on $150,000 bond.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Aug. 12,1979

title: Brown Going to New Hampshire To Speak at a Democratic Picnic
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who has all but announced his intention to seek the Democratic nomination for President, will travel to New Hampshire next month to appear at a Democratic Party picnic.

title: Death Toll Reaches 18 in Yacht Disaster
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 17 (AP)  As the death toll climbed to 18, final stragglers from the stormblasted Fastnet yacht race limped into port today and official inquiries began into the world's worst yachting disaster.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: End Oil's Foreign Tax Credit
description: WASHINGTON  Since the Nixon Administration, energy independence has been the rallying of Government policymakers. In June, President Carter began decontrol of oil prices, an action that, at a cost to consumers of $1.2 billion this year, is designed to promote domestic production and reduce oil imports. Later, the House overwhelmingly passed legislation to fund development of synthetic fuels at a likely cost of at least several billion dollars. Again, the explanation was the need to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. Yet, while Americans are asked to pay higher prices and higher taxes in the fight for energy independence, the Government is paying the major oil companies $1.2 billion a year

title: Books of The Times
description: CHRISTO: WRAPPED WALK WAYS. Text by Ellen R. Goheen. Photographed by Wolfgang Volz. Unpaginated. Harry N. Abrams. $20.

title: Citibank Increases Prime Rate to 12%
description: Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, announced yesterday that it was joining the move to a 12 percent prime rate.

title: Banker to Aid Carter Fund Drive
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) Robert H. McKinney, an Indianapolis banker who has just stepped down as head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, will help guide the financing of President Carter's reelection campaign. John Dalton, national treasurer of the CarterMondale Presidential Committee, said today that Mr. McKinney would serve on the national finance steering committee for the campaign.

title: CharterRevision Bid Is Pushed in Passaic
description: PATERSON THE final signaturegathering effort in the campaign to change Passaic County's form of government  putting an elected County Executive in charge begins today, with Its sponsors professing confidence that they can get the question on the November ballot.

title: GETTING A KICK OUT OF DOOM
description: With the energy crisis, the economy crisis and growing fears about the environment, many people have become prophets of doom. Are they right, or is it still possible to believe in the future?When President Carter declared, in his much publicized energy speech, that the erosion of our confidence in the future is threatening to destroy the social and political fabric of America, he touched, in very different ways, two important groups of Americans. One  probably the majority must have included Americans who, troubled by the gasoline shortage and a sense of the nation's diminishing power, drew from Mr. Carter a sudden, though perhaps only brief, revival of hope. For the other group, the words had the opposite effect. These people heard a confirmation of their own belief: America is doomed.

title: Inflation Grips Aged in LifeCare Homes
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J.  Paul Onderdonk feels that he and many of his fellow residents at Meadow Lakes, a lifecare facility in this central New Jersey community, are engaged in a somber race between death and bankruptcy.

title: A Secret Meeting And a Very Public Exit at the U.N.
description: In the 30 months that Andrew Young has served as United States delegate to the United Nations, President Carter has several times resisted demands that the outspoken former civil rights leader be dismissed. Last week, after it was disclosed that Mr. Young held an unauthorized meeting with representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization and then lied about the nature of the meeting, the President quickly accepted the Ambassador's resignation. But, despite his departure, some Israeli officials, their American supporters and American blacks expressed doubts about whether he had really violated Washington policy against dealings with the P.L.O. or simply had gotten too far ahead of a shifting Administration attitude toward the guerrilla group.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: DeWillenichCountess Pauline Untermeyer. On August 17, 1979 in Cannes, France.

title: Jazz: NiemackWettenhall Duo
description: Judy Niemack, a singer, and Simon Wettenhall, a trumpet player, have formed a jazz duo that seems to have a variety of roots  Lennie Tristan, the team of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross and, at times, a bit of Jackie Cain and Roy Kral. But, even admitting these sources, their work has a distinctive flavor of its own.

title: Mine Union's Head to Run Again; Says He May Back Carter in 80
description: BENTON, III., Aug. 18 (UPI)  Arnold R. Miller said yesterday that he would seek a third term as president of the United Mine Workers in 1982 and might support President Carter for reelection in 1980.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States

title: Postage Ruling on Bills Adds to Amount to Pay
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 18 (AP)  The United States Postal Service is in hot water here after ruling that the city must pay double postage on combined city and county water and sewer bills.

title: Hungry Twin s in Thick of Race
description: Standing in a corner of the clubhouse, his long arms draped over a uniform rack, Dave Goltz recalled the last day of the Minnesota Twins 1977 season, the damp, cold day he gained his 20th victory.

title: Chinese Use Spiders to Kill Pests
description: PEKING, Aug. 19  In an effort to reduce chemical pesticides on rice crops, China is encouraging the use of spiders to fight harmful insects that have become resistant to the chemicals.

title: Birth Notice 2 -- No Title
description: Births 5016

title: STAGE VIEW
description: LONDON He has hung A Midsummer Night's Dream from trapezes, devised a lengthy theatrical production in an invented language for a festival in Persepolis, directed Timon of Athens and Measure for Measure in French, conducted a troupe of fretful actors through the villages of the Sahara and subSahara; and in general, established himself as one the leading theatrical innovators of our time.

title: British Inflation, Now Over 15%, Is a Political Issue
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  Britain's steeply rising cost of living became a major political issue again this week in a wrangle over the latest inflation figures.

title: McKinsey &
description: A big, diversified finance company was sitting on a bundle of idle cash last year, its management wondering how to use it. Like many companies, it decided to make an acquisition and identified four likely targets. But before putting its chips on the table, it called in a fiveman team of highpriced consultants. In all four cases they uncovered things that we hadn't come across ourselves, including some issues that the investment community to this day isn't aware of, said a senior executive of the company. They're expensive, but they're good.

title: News Summary
description: Egypts leaders had mixed reactions to the new plan for a compromise resolution on Palestinian rights, which the United States may put before the United Nations Security Council, American officials said yesterday. The compromise resolution, rebuffed by the Israelis Friday, was outlined to top Egyptian leaders by Robert S. Strauss, President Carters special envoy to the Middle East. He is trying to win Egyptian and Arab support for the move. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Last weekend's deluge may help to bring back strawlike and drought ravaged lawns, to a point. The rainfall was generous enough to penetrate down deeply to thirsty root zones. Some of the lawns have started to come back. If they have not responded, be patient. Cooler weather next month will help to set things right again.

title: Miss Meagher Sets U.S. Mark In A.A.U. 100Meter Butterfly
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Aug. 18  Mary T. Meagher of Louisville, Ky., swimming's 14yearold prodigy who broke the world record for the women's 200meter butterfly twice in nine hours two days ago, set an American record today in winning the 100meter butterfly at the Amateur Athletic Union's national longcourse championships.

title: After 15 Years of Delays, a Plan to Bring New Life to Senegal River Delta Is Set to Begin
description: DAKAR, Senegal  After more than 15 years of feasibility studies and false starts, a landmark threenation project to harness the 1,100mile Senegal River and halt the encroachment of the Sahara appears ready to begin.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Today's collector of antique airplanes was more than likely a child in the 1920's or 30's  a child of the Golden Age or Lindberg era, that is  who spent Sunday afternoons at the local airport watching demonstrations of the amazing flying machines. The daredevil pilots who manned them were his heroes. For many such aficionados, whether or not they made flying their career, acquiring their own antique airplane was the fulfillment of a longtime dream.

title: How to Ship Home Foreign Purchases
description: Suppose you are in Italy  Florence, sayand spot an 85yearold desk that you simply must buy. Striking a bargain with the dealer, regardless of price, may be the easiest part, if you can afford it. Getting the desk home may prove a lot harder.

title: Country Houses Near Piccadilly.
description: Visitors to Kenwood enter its grounds through a forest of rhododendrons, twice the height of a tall man, and follow a narrow meandering path that leads, after a fiveminute walk, to a large, 18thcentury house of cream stucco and white brick in a park of cropped lawns, open fields, copses of trees and horizonwide vistas.

title: Another Way to Raise Cash
description: There are lots of ways for companies that need cash to get it.

title: A Million Workers Struck Briefly Last Week
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Menachem Begin may have won a Nobel Prize for peace, but most Israelis wouldn't give him the prize for economics. After more than two years in office, his Government has run up a huge debt that is fueling unprecedented inflation, placing the domestic economy in such peril that Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan was prompted recently to warn that Washington was having doubts about Israel's stability.

title: F.B.I. Agent Challenged in Murder Solicitation Trial.
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 18 (AP) The retrial of T. Cullen Davis, the industrialist charged with trying to arrange the murder of a judge, ended its first week yesterday with the defense attacking the testimony of an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investieation.

title: AT HOME;On Becoming Lord of the Manor
description: I WANT you to help us choose house, my friend said. He was young and recently married, and this would be his first house.

title: View From a Wheelchair
description: Max M. Schlossel, who was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan 77 years ago, decided after living out West for 31 years that he wanted to see New York City again.

title: THE MARKETS Credit Moves Strengthen Dow
description: The stock market, fueled by heavy buying from cashladen institutions, scored another sharp advance last week in hectic trading.

title: Nauvoo, the Town the Mormons Left
description: Nauvoo, the old Mormon holy city in Illinois, might well be characterized as a ghost town, almost, but it is far from dead. Somewhere beneath the layered years since the Mormons left in the greatest wagon train of all time, there is life, memory, promise. A section of rail fence stitching its way westward across an empty field seems not so much a sign of something done as something continuing, and Nauvoo is not so much a tombstone to a dead past as a monument to a living present.

title: ART
description: BROOKLYN THOUGH a corps of professional artists is said to exist in China, most of the art reaching the West has been done by peasants with litle or no training. Exhibited first in Paris, in 1975, this type of work has also appeared at the Brooklyn Museum and the Art Institute of Chicago. Now, Connecticut residents can glimpse it here at the New England Center for Contemporary Art (through Sept. 3).

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: ALTHOUGH it has failed to generate much attention among consumer activist groups, the state's New Home Warranty and Builders Registration Act, passed in March 1978 and effective last July 1, will have a significant impact on builders and home buyers.

title: Stamford Did It. Can Nassau County?
description: FOURTEEN years ago Regional Plan spoke of Nassau County's opportunity to fill the hole in the doughnut. We were referring, of course, to the immense opportunity afforded by the turnover of Mitchel Field to the county by the Federal Government  the hole within the fabric of the then rapidly urbanizing county.

title: Pamela M. Gelber Is Fiance Of Dr. Roger Scott Madris
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gelber of Brookvillle, L.I., and Miami Beach of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela M. Gelber, to Dr. Roger Scott Madris, son of Mr. and Mrs, George Madris of Harrison, N.Y. The wedding will take nlace next month.

title: E.P.A. Show, on the Ohio, Floats Warnings
description: JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Aug. 17 As President Carter and his staff steamed down the Mississippi campaigning for the Administration's energy program, another Federal troupe wended its way down the Ohio with a far more cautionary message about energy development.

title: Feds Say It's a City Of Brotherly Hate
description: As Philadelphia Police Commissioner from 1987 to 1971 and as Mayor since then, Frank L. Rizzo has often been accused of encouraging and covering up police brutality. The big gest complaint yet came last week when the Justice Department, in a highly unusual suit, charged him, 19 other officials and the entire Philadelphia Police Department with repeatedly violating civil rights.

title: CAMERA
description: Serious amateur photographers who work in black and white and who may also be interested in having their work exhibited can set up their own darkroom, or they can take their work to a custom lab for processing and printing  few would be willing to take their chances with leaving their film at the corner drugstore for processing and enlarging.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Since the days of Adam and Eve, snakes have been regarded by many as frightening and dangerous. In an attempt to combat these oftenirrational fears, as well as to teach the value of snakes in nature, the Greenburgh Nature Center in Scarsdale will hold a special program on snakes this afternoon.

title: SPORTS
description: TEAM tennis lives! Those of you who thought the concept had expired with the demise of Billie Jean King's coasttocoast extravaganza, World Team Tennis, probably never heard of the South Connecticut Junior Team Tennis League. But that's no surprise: it's one of the bestkept secrets around, though unintentionally so.

title: Boccie Experts Keep Eyes on the Pallino
description: TED CURASI, a 71yearold with a large shock of white hair and a broad smile, was standing in a light rain yesterday morning as firstround play began in the sixth annual Sambuca Romana boccie tournament at the Thompson Street Park in the Soho area of Manhattan

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds are visible over New England, the North snd Middle Atlantic States, the lake region, the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys and the Gulf Sttates. Clouds also cover the Northern Plains States, the Northern Rockies, the Southwest and the Pacific Northwest.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The vehicle that first swept America off its feet was not the automobile but the trolley car, according to Louis lasil10, assistant superintendent of transportation at the Branford Trolley Museum in East Raven, where a twoday festival clangs into gear Saturday from 11 to 8:30 and Sunday from 11 to 6.

title: Do Congressional Contributions Buy Gratitude and Votes
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional candidates, already gearing up for the 1980 election, can count on a bonanza of $50 million or more to help pay their campaign bills, money furnished by interest groups eager to make new friends and reward old ones.

title: The Fiction of a Scientist
description: EOPLE often ascribe the supposed decline of fiction in our times to the flight of our best minds from the arts to the sciences. A phenomenon less remarked upon is the growing number of scientists who are becoming novelists. Their interest in science fiction is, of course, predictable, but their renovation of more traditional genres such as the historical novel, the romantic novel, the family novel and the novel of manners has been noticed less  but is perhaps even more sweeping.

title: Trail Riding in Galilee
description: Yehuda Avni, 53 years old, born Edward Stone, loved horses when he lived in his native Chicago before the establishment of Israel. Today his Vered Hagalil (Rose of the Galilee) on 30 acres of oncebarren land has 15 Arabian horses, a riding ring, clubhouse restaurant and overnight accomodations for about 30 guests.

title: Towns on Mississippi Welcome Carter
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 18  President Carter received an enthusiastic welcome today from townspeople on the banks of the upper Mississippi as he began a sevenday riverboat journey to St. Louis.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE politicians usually make their obligatory visits to Caffe Puglie in Yonkers on Sunday mornings, so if prospects of having expresso with your favorite alderman please you, then that is the time to be there.

title: Mary Lowrey Married to Daniel P. Gregory
description: Mary Coolidge Lowrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Lowrey of San Francisco, was married there yesterday afternoon to Daniel Platt Gregory, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Gregory of Santa Cruz, Calif. The Rev. David R. Forbes performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Cathedral.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Leslie Sukenick Married

title: Submarine Patrol Plane Now Stalking Oil Slicks
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 18 Takeoff was scheduled for 9 A.M. but one of the four engines of the big Navy P3 was hiccuping. Puffing both breath and mild expletives, a stocky ordnance technician, John Fussell, unstowed the plane's ladder, clambered down, did some tinkering and shortly had the engine pacified.

title: Business and Elections
description: WASHINGTON  Mythmaking is big business in American politics, and the myths with the best chance of succeeding today seem to be those in which business is cast as the villain. This year's debate over Congressional campaign financing is a good case in point.

title: New Operas About Famous Monarchs
description: Very few new operas garner enough critical and popular acclaim to justify the expense of a complete commercial recording, but here are suddenly two that obviously did  Aribert Reimann's Lear and Thea Musgrave's Mary, Queen of Scots, both taped in live performances. Lear received its premiere on July 9, 1978, at the Mu:tich Opera and was recorded there last October by Deutsche Grammophon. Mary, first staged at Edinburgh by the Scottish Opera on Sept. 6, 1977, arrives through the courtesy of the new VoxMMG label, which in a few weeks will release the Virginia Opera production of March, 1978.

title: POINTS OF VIEW Energy: Things Aren't All That Bad
description: If there aren't exactly silver linings to all those clouds overhanging the world energy situation, the view beyond today's sense of crisis is not one of unrelieved gloom, either.

title: Battered Prisoners Photographs Asked in Philadelphia Police Suit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Federal Government, pressing its police brutality suit against the city of Philadelphia, has asked a Federal District Court to order city officials to turn over videotapes and photographs of battered prisoners.

title: Mary J. Stichnoth, Accountant, Bride Of John Truelove
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Julia Stichnoth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John August Stichnoth of Ridgefield, to John Martin Truelove, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Truelove Jr. of Norwell. Mass., and Freedom, N.H. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lucian Beltzner.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on television in the 1980's in The New York Times Magazine today, the photograph of a man identified as Edgar H. Griffiths, president of the RCA Corporation, is in fact a picture of Corydon B. Dunham, executive vice president and general counsel of NBC.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Moslem rebels fighting Afghanistan's Marxist regime said today that they had established an Islamic government in a central province, part of which they liberated from Government forces.

title: H.O. Hagens Weds Adelaide L. Bennett
description: Adelaide Louise Bennett, who is on the research staff in the Index of Early ?hristian Art at Princeton University, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Herbert Orland Hagens, a can??date for a Ph. D. in German at Princeton. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony in the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The other day we talked with an old friend, Nadine Gordimer, whose new novel, Burger's Daughter, has just been banned in her native South Africa. It is reviewed on page one of the Book Review today. American admirers of her novels and short stories should find it as deep, as daring and as revealing about the human and inhuman condition in the land of apartheid as any of her works. It is published here by The Viking Press and is a BookoftheMonth Club alternate selection.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: More about people. What are the authors of those books you're curled up with doing this summer? Herewith some additional notes:

title: Double Daylight Time
description: Harold Jerry, whose letter appears on this page, has seized the day by resetting his clock. On summer vacations, his family lives in its own little time zone not just daylight saving time but D.S.T. plus 2. When it's 5 A.M. on most East Coast clocks, it's already 7 at the Jerrys'. They rise with the birds and play out the day to its almost Arctic close, around 11 o'clock at night.

title: Her Younger Self
description: PENELOPE MORTIMER has shown, in her novels (The Pumpkin Eater, My Friend Says It's Bulletproof and others), a gift for presenting the single, precise detail that implies a whole stream of other details flowing underground. What else? we want to ask her. She suggests such a wealth of possibilities that she makes us greedy.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Santa Fe and Aspen can serve as illustrations of the booming chambermusic phenomenon in the United States. What was once a fairly arcane musical form has become big time, and also big business. In Santa Fe, where the summer opera gets most of the publicity, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival has been quietly going from strength to strength since founding in 1973, and at the end of this month it is in effect :oing public, with festivals in Seattle and at the 92nd Street Y in New York.

title: Reagan's Candidacy Is Endorsed By Young Americans for Freedom
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California won an informal endorsement of his Presidential candidacy today from the conservative Young Americans for Freedom.

title: Karen Staller Wed To Jeffrey A. Silber
description: The marriage of Karen Maria Staller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Staller of Ithaca, N.Y., to Jeffrey Alan Silber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Silber of Yonkers, took place yesterday at the Anabel Taylor Chapel on the campus of Cornell University. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel of Riverdale, the Bronx, performed the ceremony.

title: Letters
description: I am once humiliated, once divorced . and once a harebrained fool in my pursuits of love. Still, I feel the need to reply to Richard Stengel's rather lengthy ruminations on the illusion of love [No More MoonJune: Love's Out, OpEd Aug. 5]. I do this despite the fact that I live daily with the small pains and deep longings that accompany any heart's search for a true companion. I do so not to defend my own follies but rather to offer their promise to others who may fear the consequences of a rapidly quickening pulse.

title: Without the Male Prism
description: THIS is Elizabeth Fisher's first nonfiction book, but her work will be familiar to many from her newspaper articles and her editorship of the first feminist literary magazine, Aphra, which she began in 1969. Much of the strength of her book flows from this background: stylistic grace and care for documentation from her editorial experience; a critical, nononsense assessment of longstanding theories of human evolution from the skeptical perspective of an experienced pioneer in a social movement; a broad and ambitious scope made easier to envision and perhaps attain for someone working largely outside academe and free from pressure to overspecialize.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Hopes for a West GermanStyle
description: LONDON  In less than four months as Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher has launched a drive to restore Britain's longlost prosperity, largely by reversing Socialist policies the country has followed since World War II.

title: Jeanne Marie Treat Is Bride
description: Jeanne Marie Treat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney C. Treat of City Island, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Raleigh M. Tozer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot F. Tozer of Tappan, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Tappan Reformed Church by the Rev. Gordon Draght. The bride, an artist, teaches at the Link Elementary School in New City, N.Y. Her fianc is a senior attorney in the legal department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: SoccerGoal Collusion: True or a Joke?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 18  Busy with its playoffs, the North American Soccer League indicated today that it would not have a progress report until at least Monday on its investigation of a goal collusion report.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: Irecently discovered that standingroom tickets for Ain't Misbehavin  at the Plymouth Theater box office now cost $8  I repeat, $8! I find this absolutely appalling. A musical revue boasting only four performers and a truncated orchestra charging such exorbitant prices for the privilege of standing, causes one to reconsider the oilpricing policies of OPEC. It should also be noted that this sam show is an enormous success and has paid back its initial investment.

title: Iran Is Said to Crush Kurd Revolt; Khomeini Bypasses Army Leaders
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 18  Iranian Government forces acting on direct orders from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini crushed a Kurdish revolt today in the town of Paveh, near the border with Iraq, the state radio announced.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly was back at the Capitol last Monday for a quick special session, leading some legislators to wonder whether the trip was really necessary.

title: Lawsuit Reminds Hartford of Circus Tragedy
description: ALAWSUIT filed by the Ringling Brothers, Barnum & Bailey Circus has revived memories of a disastrous circus fire here 35 years ago. The suit is a result of the collapse of the Hartford Civic Center last year.

title: Addonizio, 65, Is Told By U.S. to Surrender And Resume Sentence
description: Former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark has been ordered back to prison by the United States Parole Commission.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF you see a twotone blue electric car cruising around the Hartford area, it may be carrying Governor Grasso.

title: Sarah Davis Smith Is Married
description: In St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion, Mass., yesterday, Sarah Davis Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Smith of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Peter Converse McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. James McDonald Jr. of Boston and Marion. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Harvey H. Guthrie Jr., dean of the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., where the couple are students. The Rev. Ruth Tiffany Barnhouse, adjunct professor at the Virginia Theological Seminary, assisted.

title: Melanie Vosburgh Wed To Thomas E. Anthony
description: Melani Eve Vosburgh and Thomas Edward Anthony, graduates of Syracuse University, were married last evening in Oneonta, N. Y ., where the bridegroom is assistant news director of radio station WDOS. The ceremony was performed jointlyin the First United Methodist Church by the Rev. John D. Garhart, an Evangelical Lutheran minister, and the Rev. Anthony J. Chiaramonte, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: LEADERS TRY TO HALT A BLACKJEWISH  RIFT
description: The resignation of Andrew Young as United States representative at the United Nations has touched off a controversy that is prompting black and Jewish leaders to seek ways quickly to improve relations that they agree have been in gradual but detectable decline for more than a decade.

title: LongShot Is Victor at Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18Hillion Brillouard, alongshot French trotter, broke stride at the start but came through with a driving finish to score an upset tonight in the $50,000 Challenge Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Revised Master Plan For Meadows Urged
description: THE Regional Plan Association has urged the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission to reconsider its 1972 master plan because of the plan's potential for frustrating business activity in nearby communities.

title: A Disastrous Season for A tian tic Salmon
description: The Atlantic salmon, regarded by many as the most glorious sport and food fish in the world, is having a disastrous year.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: THE FRANCE LEAVES WITH A NEW NAME: The France, renamed the Norway by her new owner, leaving Le Havre yesterday on her way to Bremen, West Germany, to be refitted. The former luxury liner, bought recently by Knut Klosters, a Norwegian shipowner, will be stripped of her art treasures, which will be returned to France, and readied for her new life as an economy cruiser In the Carribbean. She left the port despite several days of strikes and demonstrations by French union members who feel the refitting should be done in France.

title: A State Report Labels Transit Pension Fund As Unsound Fiscally
description: A pension fund for 6,000 city transit workers is grossly underfunded, jeopardizing the employees benefits and making the city liable for tens of millions of dollars in the future, the state charges in a report being issued today.

title: GARDENING
description: SPRING has its flowering trees, autumn has trees with colorful fruits and foliage, but what of summer? While the green leaves of summer provide us with cooling shade, there is otherwise a paucity of color overhead. The number of trees that flower in the summer are limited, but a few come to mind that would make excellent additions to our gardens.

title: Atlanta's Troubles
description: Fifty Georgia state troopers were in Atlanta last week to help combat an upsurge in crime that has jeopardized the convention business and put Mayor Maynard Jackson in a political squeeze. Both Mr. Jackson and Gov. George B. Busbee, potential rivals in next year's United States Senate race, warned that news articles about crime were hurting the city. Then Mr. Busbee, in a move seen as embarrassing to the Mayor, offered to send in the state police without being asked. Mr. Jackson had little choice but to accept. The troopers went on duty the day after Atlanta recorded its 149th murder of the year, more than in all of 1978.

title: 2 Russian Astronauts Prepare for a Return From Salyut 6 Today
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Two Soviet astronauts who have spent nearly a half year in space will end their record flight tomorrow and return to earth, the press agency Tass said today..

title: GARDENING
description: SPRING has its flowering trees, autumn has trees with colorful fruits and foliage, but what of summer? While the green leaves of summer provide us with cooling shade, there is otherwise a paucity of color overhead. The number of trees that flower in the summer are limited, but a few come to mind that would make excellent additions to our gardens.

title: Riverwind Is Full of MiddleAged Charms
description: FRED and Louise return to the scene of their wedding night. It is Riverwind on the banks of the Wabash River, a resort as rundown as their 17yearold marriage.

title: It's Not Sailing, It's Not Surfing, It's Wind Surfing
description: WIND SURFERS try to be one with wind, water and sail. Either they're riding their boards with the wind at their backs or they have lost that contact  and their balance  and spilled into the water. In this sport, agility counts.

title: Native Returns to the Wilds of Westchester
description: DON'T cry to me about your problems of readjusting to being back from your vacation. I have returned from twoweek safari in Kenya with a rare malady. I am unable to step into a car without staring out the window and squinting for game.

title: The Nation
description: Jimmy Carter called a group of food retailers to the White House last week for a stern lecture on markups. He said it seemed odd that supermarket prices were rising when prices for farm goods were falling. He warned that Federal antitrust investigators would keep an eye on the industry.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Ironbound has done It! After one or another of a series of Portuguese restaurants in the vicinity of Ferry Street  the main street of Newark's Portuguese community  just missed being extra good, along comes Chateau Lisboa, a relatively new establishment that is at once the best restaurant in the enclave and easily one of the best in the state.

title: Marriage Announcement 9 -- No Title
description: Joyce Pilz Wed to Paul Stevens

title: Woman Suing Parents, Citing Abandonment
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP)  A 27yearold handicapped Michigan woman, suing her parents for abandoning her at birth, says that when she first met her father 10 years ago he handed her $20 and said: Go away. Leave us alone.

title: 1,000 Attend Funeral
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18 (UPI)  More than 1,000 Haitians attended a funeral mass today for Mrs. Lorfils and her five children who drowned Monday.

title: NEW URBAN RANGERS A FORCE FOR ORDER
description: They have been taken for Boy Scouts because of their uniforms, teasingly referred to on their rounds as Smokey Bear and have even been mistaken as members of a border patrol unit from Mexico.

title: Economic Troubles in the Sudan Threaten Sadat's Neighbor and Friend
description: CAIRO  The summer languor of the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, has been interrupted twice this month by violent street demonstrations, with students rioting over sharp increases in the price gasoline.

title: Graham Regains Golf Lead
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 18  David Graham broke out of a tie with Scott Simpson late this afternoon and took a onestroke lead after the third round of the $400,000 Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: The Spirit of Homesteading Lives On
description: CENTRAL ISLIP NYONE who believes that the spirit of homesteading has faded into history hasn't met Eugenio and Dorothy Cardona and their five children, who live here in a large, rambling Cape Cod house.

title: STAMPS
description: The United States is putting out two new definitives, which mark the nearend of the new Americana Series issues, and a commemorative which is its first for the 1980 Olympic Games  the first of many to come.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: No apology is warranted for the effect upon lawyers of the enactment of the new rules under amendments in the Ethics Code [A Code's Impact on Lawyers, Aug.]. The conflict is open and obvious in the situation of a law firm representing a client before a state regulatory body of which a member of the firm is a legislator.

title: Shorn of Trains, the Penn Central Rolls Again
description: The company only emerged from bankruptcy proceedings in October. Already it has bought out a Houston real estate developer for $20 million, snapped up a propane distributor for $55.8 million and acquired a Los Angeles amusement park for $51.3 million. Then, a few days ago, it bid $340 million for the Marathon Manufacturing Company, the nation's leading builder of offshore oildrilling platforms.

title: Pro Golfers Mine the Gold
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 18 There are more than 10,000 golf courses in the United States, but the only one where a man could win $72,000 this weekend was the one here at the Westchester Country Club.

title: Navy Espionage Plea Entered
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  A Navy yeoman, Lee E. Madsen, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he stole topsecret military documents and sold them to an undercover agent for $700.

title: The Oasis That Is Dumbarton Oaks
description: Dumbarton Oaks, with its gardens and its two small museums of Byzantine and PreColumbian art, is one of Washington's best kept secrets. Situated at the highest point of Georgetown, the gardens are an oasis of shaded greenery  a cool retreat on the muggiest of days when other parts of the capital are clogged with tourists.

title: Instruction Given On Home Repairs
description: Throughout the summer, Cornell University's Cooperative Extension has been bringing to New York City neighborhoods a program of instruction in home repair and maintenance. Some of the courses in the program, subsidized by Citibank and organized with the aid of neighborhood leaders, have been taught directly from a traveling Handivan.

title: Ronald Abramson Weds Sarah Hines
description: Sarah Hardin Hines, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Hines of Alexandria, Va., was married last night to Ronald Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Abramson of Lakewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. A.T. Mollegen, an Episcopal priest and a former professor of New Testament at the Virginia Theological Seminary, and Rabbi Jay Heyman officiated at the ceremony in Anchorage House in Alexandria.

title: Heroism in South Africa
description: IT'S strange to live in a country where there are still heroes. The words seem to echo through this book, which is concerned above all with the nature of commitment and heroism in South Africa. But it is not about romantic heroworship; it is about the problems, the humanity, the ruthlessness and the cost of political involvement, all against a background of love, squalor or boredom.

title: Finding Bargains At One of France's Outdoor Markets
description: It's Friday, I say to my guests, Milt and Ralphyne, who are spending a few weeks in my house in St. Jeannet, a small village in the hills behind the French Riviera. Let's pick up Bruce and go to the Vence market. Bruce is a 15-year-old from Denver visiting his expatriate American aunt near Vence.

title: CAIRO APPEARS WARY OF LATEST U.S. PLAN ON THE PALESTINIANS
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18  The tentative American plan to offer a compromise resolution in the Security Council on Palestinian rights reportedly received only a mixed reception from Egyptian leaders today, United States officials said tonight.

title: Problems Greet New H. U.D. Chiefs As Agency Seeks Broader Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  The Department of Housing and Urban Development, the smallest department of the Federal Government and its perennial stepchild, is getting new leadership and new headaches.

title: Victoria Alessandra Mele Wed
description: Victoria Alessandra Mele, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Greditzer of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Edward V. Mele of Barneveld, N.Y., was married yesterday in Barneveld to Dennis David Zacek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Zacek of Rome, N. Y. Town Justice Brian J. Donohoe of Trenton, N. Y., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: Klein vs. Cohalan: A Bitter Start
description: WHEN Islip Supervisor Peter F. Cohalan strode into Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein's office last week to challenge him to a political debate, he was clearly trying to take the initiative in his attempt to take the Republican nomination for County Executive away from the incumbent. to take the initiative in his attempt to take the Republican nomination for County Executive away from the incumbent.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jersey City's Mayor Is Running Hard, Fast and Bankrolled
description: TRENTON  Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City, the selfstyled kid from a coldwater flat, has moved in the last two years from an unknown city clerk to a contender for the Democratic nomination for Governor in 1981.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Moslem rebels fighting Afghanistan's Marxist regime said today that they had established an Islamic government in a central province they liberated from Government forces.

title: A Diary of a Pro Football Camp: Working, Waiting, Wondering
description: Three years ago Vince Papale came up from the sandlots of Philadelphia to win a place on the Eagles roster as a 30yearold wide receiver and special teams performer. Papale, a schoolteacher, won a place in the National Football league against considerable odds and without much of a football background. His college, St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, had no team. He had played for the Aston Knights of the Seaboard League and then briefly with the Philadelphia Bell of the World Football League.hard time making this team. He said, Vince, don't cut yourself. We'll do the cutting.

title: Do Not Disturb: Bankers at Play
description: SENECA, Md.  The road winds through a wooded grove with picnic benches, past a children's playground and 14 tennis courts, along five manmade lakes complete with the requisite ducks. Motorized carts scoot across the 18hole golf course, and striped summery umbrellas and chaise lounges surround the two 25meter swimming pools and the children's wading pool. Officially, this 280acre retreat, 22 miles from the nation's capital is called the Bretton Woods Recreation Center. But among those who can't get in, it is known as fund's country club.

title: Attorneys Pondering The Ethics of Their Trade
description: DALLAS  More than a century ago, a Philadelphia judge, George Sharswood, gave a series of lectures on lawyers ethical responsibilities. At one point, he urged lawyers to represent clients with warm zeal. For over one hundred years, those words served lawyers searching for ethical guidance, as his lectures formed the basis for a code of ethics adopted in 1887 by the Alabama State Bar Association, and the Alabama Code in turn was the model for the canons of professional ethics adopted by the American Bar Association in 1908.

title: Lonie A. Walker, Joseph Thieringer Are Wed on L.I.
description: Lonie Adle Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married in East Hampton yesterday to Joseph Conrad Thieringer, son of Otis P. Thieringer of Bradenton, Fla., and Helen Fleming of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Christopher Huntington, assisted by the Rev. Peter McCrann, performed the ceremony in Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Patricia Denk, Actress, Wed To William Michael Powers
description: The marriage of Patricia Ruth Denk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Joseph Denk of San Antonio and Hiram, Ohio, to William Michael Powers, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Powers of Brooklyn, took place in Sag Harbor. L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Joseph ORourke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Wilfrid Sheed, the author, and Mrs. Sheed.

title: Deaths
description: HAGENBUCKLECedric R. 75 Died while sailing, August 10th. He was owner and former director of Camp Viking in Orleans on Cape Cod. Graduate of Amherst College. Survived by his son, John, of Cambridge, Mass. Services private.

title: LETTERS
description: Monopolies

title: A Potent Weapon for the Irish Political Clout in the U.S.
description: BELFAST  Ever since the disclosure in the early 1970's that Americans were contributing thousands of dollars to Irish Republican Army funds, there has been an awareness of an IrishAmerican dimension to Northern Ireland's troubles, but only recently has the full impact of political pressures been felt. As seen by experienced observers.

title: Many Fastnet Crews Lacked Experience
description: In the wake of the storm that blasted across the Irish Sea last week turning the Fastnet Race into the worst disaster in yacht racing history, it appears that lack of experience in heavy weather among the clublevel sailors in the 306boat fleet may have been the biggest single factor leading to the loss of life and craft.

title: Retired Farmer Is Busy Fulfilling Demand for Stitched Harnesses
description: DANVERS, Ill. (AP)  Paul Murphy of Danvers does more than remember the past. He makes it a part of the present. The retired farmer devotes all of his time to the art of harness making.

title: For Resort Wear: Trousers Are Shorter and Waistlines Easier
description: Perry Ellis calls it his midwinter collection  to be sold in the stores from October to December and to be worn into the 1980's.

title: Expanding Use of Microsurgery Brings Gains on Many Frontiers
description: Peering through a stereoscopic microscope at 20power magnification, Dr. Yale L. Fisher watched a tiny scalpel, smaller than a sewing needle, enter his own field of vision. The scalpel had pierced the white of the eye at an angle and now the blade appeared behind the patient's lens. Dr. Fisher, an ophthalmologist, guided the scalpel to the back of the eye until the blade touched a scar on the surface of the retina, which is an extension of the brain.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TO replace a damaged piece of tongue-and-groove wood flooring, the first thing you will have to do is remove the damaged section without causing any additional damage to the boards on either side. The easiest method is to drill holes at each end of the damaged area so that you can insert the tip of a keyhole saw or electric sabresaw blade, after which you can cut across the board. Then use a hammer and a chisel to split out the damaged piece of wood so you can lift them up and out without damaging the tongue-arid-groove joints on the adjoining boards.

title: MR5. CARTER'S AIDE IS LIVEN LAICH RANK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  Edith J. Dobelle, Rosalynn Carter's new chief of staff, has the same rank as Hamilton Jordan and the same salary as Zbigniew Brzesinski, the President's national security adviser. She will manage a 19member staff.

title: GARDENING
description: SPRING has its flowering trees, autumn has trees with colorful fruits and foliage, but what of summer? While the green leaves of summer provide us with cooling shade, there is otherwise a paucity of color overhead. The number of trees that flower in the summer are limited, but a few come to mind that would make excellent additions to our gardens.

title: Large Slick Reaches Land
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. (UPI)  A mat of thick crude oil began washing ashore on South Padre Island today, staining an area running 50 miles north from the mouth of the Rio Grande. Federal environmental officials said it was the largest batch of oil from the Campeche Bay well to reach land thus far.

title: Out of the Shadow of Pills and Drink
description: STAMFORD DISQUIETING things have been happening to the American Dream. In many cases Mr. Blanding's dream house has become an energy nightmare, and Mr. Blanding himself is on the verge of an executive coronary attack. At least onecenter's staff. of the children is tripping out on something or other, and Mrs. Blanding, having achieved the best of all possible worlds, is now a confirmed alcoholic.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: A LONG with all the other new questions facing car buyers in this era of gas lines, high prices and changing habits, there is yet another: whether to order a factory radio or one from the burgeoning list of aftermarket suppliers.

title: Ruthanne Kurtyka Wed to H.E. Corn
description: Ruthanne Kurtyka and Harvey E. Corn, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in the bridegrooms apartment. Mr. Corn is law secretary to Surrogate Marie M. Lambert, who performed the ceremony.

title: 6 Sea Deaths Focus Attention on Plight of Haitians
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18Dieumerci Lorfils is a small, muscular, wiry man of 34 years. His deep brown, almost black eyes are redrimmed and he is alternately withdrawn and then agitated. His words come in dense thickets of Haitian Creole French and tortured English.

title: 38,695 Endure Rain To Watch Yankees Defeat Twins by 53
description: Eight hours of foul weather had passed since Rich Gossage, the Yankee's top reliever, arrived at Yankee Stadium, but Gossage did what he gets paid to do. He had closed out the Yankees 53 victory over the Minnesota Twins last night by pitching to the last Minnesota batter, the switchhitting Butch Wynegar, and forcing him to ground out on a 32 Ditch.

title: Miss Faenza Wed To Delano Ladd 3d
description: Nancy Ellen Faenza and Delano Wood Ladd 3d, who are with Robert Landau Associates Inc., a New York marketing and sales promotion concern, were married yesterday in St. Mary's Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Narragansett, R.I. The Rev. Joseph Lennon. vice president of community affairs at Providence College, performed the ceremony.

title: Australian Prisoners Riot
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Inmates at Australia's largest jail threw burning mattresses and other flaming debris from their cells last night in protest against a strike by guards that they said endangered their safety. The police said the fires at Long Bay Jail in Sydney burned themselves out.

title: Letter
description: Carter Agonistes, by Eugene Kennedy (Aug. 5), which concludes that the President's comments about a crisis of the spirit and of confidence in the future stem from echoes of his own profoundly troubled spirit, seems to fall into the category of amateur theorizing of the psychohistorians and clinical guesses made at a distance which Mr. Kennedy condemns in the same article.

title: Developer of Soul City Files Suit Saying U.S. Has Hindered Project
description: SOUL CITY, N.C., Aug. 18 (AP)  The Soul City Company, the development concern that is backing the formation of new black town, has filed a suit in Federal District Court accusing the Department of Housing and Urban Development with deliberately obstructing the project. Floyd B. McKissick Jr., president and founder of the company, said he filed the suit yesterday in Washington.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TO replace a damaged piece of tongue-and-groove wood flooring, the first thing you will have to do is remove the damaged section without causing any additional damage to the boards on either side. The easiest method is to drill holes at each end of the damaged area so that you can insert the tip of a keyhole saw or electric sabresaw blade, after which you can cut across the board. Then use a hammer and a chisel to split out the damaged piece of wood so you can lift them up and out without damaging the tongue-arid-groove joints on the adjoining boards. holes at each end of the damaged area so that you can insert the tip of a keyhole saw or electric sabresaw blade, after which you can cut across the board. Then use a hammer and a chisel to split out the damaged piece of wood so you can lift them up and out without damaging the tongue-arid-groove joints on the adjoining boards.

title: Modern Railroad Gangs Replace Links With Nation's Coal Fields
description: RENOVO, Pa., Aug. 18 (AP)  Their backs strain and their brows sweat under the glaring August sun.

title: Music Boxes Preserve a Family Tradition
description: THEY play operatic arias, oldfashioned waltzes and American folk songs. The music is sometimes like that of a harpsichord, sometimes more like a carrousel's calliope. The sound can be whimsical, stately, even a bit eerie but it is always tinged with nostalgia.

title: In Hawaii, Poverty and Racial Animosity Contribute to Violence
description: HONOLULU  An upsurge in attacks on white servicemen by local youths has alarmed military and civilian authorities in Hawaii and led to a reexamination of social ills, especially those affecting disadvantaged youths, that have long festered behind the serene facade of life in these sunny islands.

title: Realty News
description: The 645unit apartment house at 11 Riverside Drive, known as Schwab House. has been sold by Citibank to an investing group organized and headed by American Continental Properties.

title: A Simple Bill of Fare That Works
description: SPIRITED is the word that comes to mind at Connolly's. This yearold addition to Westport's dining scene has a lively, likable air that should translate into longevity.

title: Linda Anne Hettlemen Is Engaged to Stephen J. Hanlon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Hettleman of New York and Westhampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Linda Anne Hettleman, to Stephen Joseph Hanlon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hanlon of West Caldwell, N.J. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Africans Ask Cease Fire At Conference on Chad
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Nine African foreign ministers trying to end the civil war in Chad have agreed to ask for a ceasefire and the dissolution of the Government of National Union in Ndiamena, Lagos Radio reported today.

title: Second City Is Still First in Comedy
description: John Belushi did it. So did Alan Arkin, Joan Rivers, Peter Boyle, Barbara Harris and Shelley Berman. Many times week, for 20 years, young comic actors have been turning themselves into something like standup playwrights for a theater of everyday life called Second City.

title: Something of a Scientific Dandy
description: LATE in 1998, Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J., gave a longterm appointment there to a young English physicist, Freeman Dyson. Mr. Dyson asked Oppenheimer what he should pursue. Oppenheimer told him, Follow your own destiny.

title: Congress Confronts Housing Apartheid
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress returns from summer recess next month, it will have to deal with bills meant to break down what is probably the harshest racial barrier that an upwardly mobile black family faces today: finding a home or apartment in the kind of neighborhood it wants.

title: Jeffrey Balkind Is the Fianc Of Miss Duer
description: Mrs. Douglas H. Duer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kreszentia Margaret Duer, to Jeffrey Balkind of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Balkind of Johannesburg.

title: Empire Games Reflect Attitudes Of 2 Different Types of Athletes
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 18  Paul Salisbury is a 31-year-old worldclass weight lifter who has won a gold medal in the National Sports Festival. Steve Cea is a 16-year-old pole vaulter who won a gold medal, by default, in the Big Apple Games.

title: Park Boss Is Planting More Than Merely a Few Trees
description: Gordon J. Davis delights in telling stories about his 19 months as New York City Parks Commissioner and this one is a favorite:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TO replace a damaged piece of tongueandgroove wood flooring, the first thing you will have to do is remove the damaged section without causing any additional damage to the boards on either side. The easiest method is to drill holes at each end of the damaged area so that you can insert the tip of a keyhole saw or electric sabresaw blade, after which you can cut across the board. Then use a hammer and a chisel to split out the damaged piece of wood so you can lift them up and out without damaging the tonguearidgroove joints on the adjoining boards.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING New Solar Heating Unit Or, Pennies From Heaven
description: THE other night, I washed a load of clothes, ran the dishwasher and took a deep, hot bath  and all the heat was free, unless one counts the $2,800 I had just spent for the new solar hotwater heater on my roof.

title: '84 OLYMPICS FACING FINANCING STRUGGLE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18  Organizers of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games here, who have been waging a threeyear battle with taxcutting sentiment in California, are facing still another battle over financing the Games.

title: Righting an Unrightable Wrong
description: AT THE time of my recent article about my hyperactive grandson, Robbie, and our experiences with special education [Speaking Personally, June 24], things were still touch and go and was very angry. The anger has since been replaced by gratitude, and I'd like to share the reasons for this surprising change.

title: WOMEN CADETS FIND WEST POINT'S HARSH
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP) Kathryn Ann Wildey spotted another young woman with hair hanging in her eyes. With a sharp Miss! she called the underclassman out of line and ordered her to cut her bangs or get hairspray.

title: Veteran Actor Still Stagestruck
description: RIVER EDGE HEmight have had only featured roles in the films, but with the audience at the library showing he was the big star. The actor is Philip Trent of this Bergen County community, and Bergen libraries have been showing some of the motion pictures that he appeared in during the 30's and 40's.

title: The News in Oil for $780 a Week
description: When foreign oil dignitaries visit New York, they may drop in on the chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, or perhaps the chief executive of Exxon or Mobil, or sometimes even Mayor Koch. But they will almost always call on Wanda Jablonski.

title: Debate on French Military Policy Bursts Into Open
description: PARIS, Aug. 18  A rumbling behindthescenes debate on basic French military policy exploded into the open today with proposals from two veteran Gaullists for a FrenchWest German nuclear force.

title: A.M. Schwarz Weds Loring La Barbera
description: Loring Brooke La Barbera and Andrew M. Schwarz, who have master of science degrees in forestry and environmental studies from Yale University, were married yesterday in New Haven. The Rev. Joan Bates Forsbere of the United Church of Christ, assistant dean and director of admissions at Yale Divinity School, performed the ceremony in the university's Marquand Chapel.

title: Mailbox: Munson Should Be Judged on Playing Ability
description: While it was understandable that many of Thurman Munson's admirers wished to see him gain immediate entry into the Hall of Fame, their hopes were misguided and a disservice to the man himself.

title: Topics
description: Increasingly, there is a new sight on city buses  people eating breakfast. We haven't seen anything like it since vaudeville died. Eating breakfast on a bus is an act of legerdemain as good as anything the Palace used to put on before closing the show with Willie Howard or Sophie Tucker.

title: In Peking, 2 Miles of Botched New Ho using
description: PEKING  The new 10story buffcolored apartment buildings stretch one after the other for almost two miles along one of Peking's main thoroughfares. To all appearances, they are an answer to one of the city's worst problems, a severe shortage of housing.

title: Salty Stories
description: When the fishermen of Lofoten Island, Norway, saw Tristan Jones's Cresswell  a 36foot converted lifeboat, her mainmast gone, her lines tangled and her motor useless  come limping into the harbor, they must have wondered: Why does he do it? And this nearshipwreck is

title: Most Militant Union of Public Workers in Hawaii Is Considering a Strike
