description: HONOLULU, Aug. 18  Hawaii's most militant public workers union is about to announce whether it will accept a cornpromise wage offer or prepare for a general strike.

title: Leaders Investing Carefully
description: HARTFORD AREVIEW of the tax records and financial statements of the state's top officials shows that Connecticut, one of the wealthiest states in the country, is governed largely by people of modest means.

title: BANK THEFT SUSPECT FLED JERSEY CENTER
description: The suspect in the murder of a New York City policeman and the wounding of a detective after a bank robbery Friday had walked away from a rehabilitation center in Newark, to which he had been assigned as part of a 27year prison sentence he was serving for armed bank robbery, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Reds Conquer Mets With a Run in 9th, 43
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 For the second night in a row, the Mets lost to Cincinnati, 43, as the Reds staged another decisive rally in the late innings.

title: Susan Mellor, T. C. Turner Wed on L.I.
description: Susan Helen Mellor, daughter of Mrs. Alfred J. Seaman of Upper Brookville. L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., and A. Willard Mellor of Locust Valley, L.I., was married in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., yesterday to Thomas Caldwell Turner, son of Mrs. Thomas Turner of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Turner. The Rev. Stephen Babbos performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: Since the birth of OPEC, half a dozen years ago, there has been much talk about the possibility of reducing housekeeping costs through the conversion of the sun's rays into heat and energy, but as of last May solar systems had been installed in only 40,000 homes onethird of them in California, the rest in the Sun Belt, with a liberal sprinkling in New England and the Pacific Northwest. However, since the renewal of the energy crisis, the situation has been changing fast. It is estimated that during each day of the past month, construction was started on as many solar homes as were begun during a whole month in 1978. Herewith some justpublished books on this timely subject:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TO replace a damaged piece of tongue-and-groove wood flooring, the first thing you will have to do is remove the damaged section without causing any additional damage to the boards on either side. The easiest method is to drill holes at each end of the damaged area so that you can insert the tip of a keyhole saw or electric sabresaw blade, after which you can cut across the board. Then use a hammer and a chisel to split out the damaged piece of wood so you can lift them up and out without damaging the tongue-and-groove joints on the adjoining boards.

title: THEATER Musicals Reprised
description: BROADWAY TONITE! the creation of Mara Joyce, one of the six performers who sing their way through an evening of big numbers from the recent and ancient Broadway past.

title: Paterson Primping For Great Falls Fete
description: ALL is not lost for those looking for something interesting to do over the Labor Day weekend, but are wary of the continuing gasoline shortage. Paterson

title: Miss Lidgerwood Becomes a Bride
description: Graeme Anne Lidgerwood, daughter of William van V. Lidgerwood of Farmington, Conn. and Shirley Sturtevant Macbeth Lidgerwood of Rome, was married yesterday to Karl Braun Eckhardt Jr., son of Mrs. Eckhardt of Denver and the late Mr. Eckhardt.

title: Tax Breaks Lure Questions
description: ALproperty tax abatement programs being tried by several municipalities on the Island are meeting with mixed success as local governments use them as a lure to attract industry.

title: Phyllis J. Cela, Lawyer, Married to Gary Sidell
description: The marriage of Phyllis J. Cela, a trial lawyer with the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice in Washington, to Gary M. Sidell, associate chief counsel on the President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island, took place at the West Hempstead (L.I.) Jewish Center yesterday. Rabbi Arnold Sher performed the ceremony.

title: Jim Briggs Weds Trudy Harder
description: Trudy Harder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry U. Harder of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Saranac Lake, N.Y., yesterday to Jim Briggs, son of James A. Briggs of Damariscotta, Me., and the late Janice Murchie Briggs. The Rev. Charles Sheerin performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Ascension.

title: Children: Endangered Species?
description: RECENT ideas on proposals to reduce or fight vandalism in the schools have prompted me to offer a solution derived from long experience as an educator.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE DUKE OF DECEPTION, by Geoffrey Wolff. (Random House, $12.95.) Life with a father who was a goodlooking guy, a good companion, a con man: a harsh but affectionate memoir.

title: Nike: The Shoes That Go 'swoosh
description: BEAVERTON, Ore.  After running 14 earlymorning miles from his home in the tiny town of Laurel, Ore., to his office in this suburb of Portland, Philip H. Knight takes off his Nike running shoes and looks them over for signs of wear.

title: The New Artistry of Joni Mitchell
description: This century has seen a number of figures from the world of entertainment win deserved reputations as artists. George Gershwin comes immediately to mind, but he still worked in a traditional orchestral idiom. More recently such unabashedly popular musicians as the Beatles and Bob Dylan have been taken seriously  sometimes so seriously that they themselves become embarrassed. What's new is that the pop people have by now created their own artistic traditions and that their traditions have begun to merge, in some still vague and elusive sense, with the mainstream of high art.

title: Jane Clarke Lucey And Jeff Deegan Wed in New Jersey
description: Jane Clarke Lucey, assistant to the executive officer of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in Boston, was married yesterday in Bay Head, N.J., to Joseph Francis Deegan 3d, manager of manufacturing at the Astor Jewelry Company in Providence.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Miss Sheedy Plans Bridal
description: Laurelle Foote Sheedy, an associate in the corporate finance department of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, and Robert Trimble Mathis, a first vice president of Blyth Eastman Dillon, plan to be married in October.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL I
description: AFTER a yearlong study, the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a private, nonprofit organization that aims to preserve natural tracts of land, recommends that open space is a good buy and urges continued acquisition of property in critical locations, such as floodplains, marshes, dunes and other natural habitat.

title: The Scientist of the Fiction
description: Thomas McMahon recently organized a conference on trees. Shortly before that he published an article on a new indoor running track that he invented and installed at Harvard. He predicts that the springiness the track surface is calculated to allow the world's fastest mile runner to cut six seconds off his record. At the moment he is secluded on a small island off the coast of Maine, writing a monograph on the mechanics of human muscles, and missing the bees and chickens he used to raise in Wellesley, Mass. All of that makes sense. Mr. McMahon is, after all, a tenured professor at Harvard in an eclectic science called biomechanics.

title: When Loss of a Breadwinner Casts Homemakers Adrift
description: THERE is a new term for an ageold problem  displaced homemaker. This is the woman who, through the death, divorce or disability of her husband, finds herself barely able to scratch out a living. After years of cooking, cleaning, bringing up children, helping elderly parents, she finds herself displaced.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: This extraordinary novel is a sequel to Milton Dank's earlier The Dangerous Game, and takes its hero, French Resistance fighter Charles Marceau, from Normandy's Dday, the fabled 6th of June, through the liberation of Paris to the end of World War II and the collapse of Hitler's Germany. Its distinction lies in both its grasp of the crucial fact of modern history the fact of totalitarianism and its swift, compelling, believable and consistently wellhandled narrative.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: The Young View
description: Not everyone these days is suffering from what President Carter has called a crisis of confidence. In fact, some young Americans are decidedly optimistic, because for them the American Dream is still very much alive.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FOR CAPITAL PUNISHMENT Crime and the Morality of the Death Penalty. By Walter Berns. 214 pp. New York: Basic Books. $10.95.

title: Snowmobiles in National Parks Will Be Kept to Roads and Lakes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  New rules of the National Park Service will limit the use of snowmobiles in the national park system to roads used by cars and on lakes used by motorboats in the summer. The new plan, announced this week, prohibits racing and other contests.

title: MadeforTV Films Hollywood's Stepchild Comes of Age
description: LOS ANGELES Coming soon to a theater near you are such movies as Freedom Road, starring Muhammad Ali and Kris Kristofferson; All Quiet on the Western Front, with Ernest Borgnine, John Gielgud, Richard Thomas and Patricia Neal; S.O.S. Titanic, with David Janssen, Cloris Leachman, Blythe Danner, Susan Saint James and David Warner; White Mama, starring Bette Davis; And Baby Makes Six, with Colleen Dewhurst, Warren Oates and Mildred Dunnock; Gide on's Trumpet, with Henry Fonda and John Houseman, and Streets of L.A., starring Joanne Woodward. To a theater very near you  in fact, to your television set.

title: E. Lloyd Bemegger, 70; Retired Drug Executive
description: E. Lloyd Bernegger, a retired pharmaceutical executive, died Friday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Madison, N.J., before moving to Florida.

title: FILM VIEW
description: EM. Forster, who, by his own admission, was not always nice man, once wrote of Joseph Conrad that he is misty at the center as well as at the edges. The secret casket of his genius, Forster said, contains a vapor rather than a jewel. A case can by made for Forster's complaints, but they can be made only by a rather cavalier dismissal of Conrad's method, which was not to weave a gossamer web around some hard, prefabricated truth but to create an approximation of the unthinkable and unspeakable by using words that must be both speakable and thinkable. The heart of Joseph Conrad is dark, not easily defined; yet it still beats strongly enough to make the reader catch his breath, with wonder and in recognition, when he reads such stories as Victory, The Secret Sharer, Lord Jim and especially Heart of Darkness. In Heart of Darkness, Conrad, before the fact and in dazzling prose that reads like poetry, gives us an apocalyptic vision of an Africa after a century of colonial ex

description: Tanner and I are playing Monopoly, but I am worried about him. His play lacks spirit. Often he doesn't even try. President Carter is wurried about him, too. The President says Tanner is in a crisis of confidence brought un by the assassination of President Kennedy, Watergate scandals and a traumatic war in Southeast Asia.

Schang Jr., a founding father and former president of Columbia Artists Management, the world's largest concert agency. In all the historic documents of every nation, the wora Happiness appears only once  in the Declaration of ndependence, the 85-year-old Mr.  chang declared in an interview not mg ago. I associate music with hapdiness.

Hamisevicz, son of Nicholas Hamisevicz of New Britain. Conn., and the late Helen Hamisevicz. The Rev. James Carlone, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Design
description: Decor that seems dreamy when a couple is childless can turn into a nightmare once a baby arrives. With planning, however, adults and children can live well and still keep the house intact.

title: Notes
description: As more signals of a determination to push ahead with tourist development emanated from Peking last week, two airlines announced plans for big tour programs to China in 1980. Pan American World Airways is scheduling 50 departures and Japan Air Lines 56.

title: MarriagesWeddings 5024
description: Mr and Mrs Harold fetter of Oceanside, NY, announce the marriage of their daughter, Lori Fran, to Mr Joseph Henry Feldman, son of Mr and Mrs Mark Feldman, of Millburn, NJ, Sunday evening, Aug 12th, at Congregation Beth Sholom of Lawrence. The bride, granddaughter of Mr and Mrs Moses H. Moenig, of Brooklyn and Long Beach, NY, is a graduate of Stern College for Women of Yeshiva Univ. She received her Master's Degree in Business Administration from Fordham Univ. The groom, an alumnus of Columbia Univ, is a 3rd year student at Fordham University Law School.

title: 11 Reported Executed Near Paveh
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sunday, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Eleven men arrested in the wake of fierce clashes in the western frontier town of Paveh were executed by a firing squad early today, the state radio announced.

title: N.C.A.A. Lifts Probation For NevadaLas Vegas
description: MISSION, Kan., Aug. 18 (AP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association is lifting its probation against the University of NevadaLas Vegas basketball program but retaining sanctions imposed on Coach Jerry Tarkanian pending the outcome of Tarkanian's court action.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDSamuel F. Beloved husband of Naomi; devoted father of Linda; dear brother of Marlorie Maged and Mildred Hyman; loving grandfather of Roy. Services were held Monday August 13, 1979,

title: Deaths
description: STEINJohn P. Of Garden City. Formerly of Queens Village. Died suddenly on August 17 at the age of 58. Mr. Stein is survived by his wife Eleanor and daughter Eleanor Hetfernen, son Daniel, sister Elizabeth Pawlowski. Mr. Stein was general superintendent for over 25 years at Fischbach 8 Moore, Inc., electrical and mechanical contractors. He was a member of Local No. 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers for 35 years serving on various labor, safety, apprenticeship and foreman committees. Mr. Stein is reposing at Fairchild Funeral Chapels, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City. Funeral services at St. Ann's Church, New Hyde Park Road, Garden City, on Tuesday August 21 at 10 AM. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, L.I.

title: Young Asserts State Dept. Learned Of the P.L. O. Meeting Within Days
description: Andrew Young, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, says that by July 30, four days after his meeting with a Palestine Liberation Organization representative, the State Department had learned of the meeting and a virtually verbatim account of the conversation was circulating at the highest levels of the department.

title: Margaret Stark Bride of Paul Menneg Jr.
description: Margaret Johanna Stark and Paul Edward Menneg Jr. were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Julius Stark of Westminster, Pa. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Menneg of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla. Federal Judge Ruggers Aldisert of Pittsburgh performed the ceremony.

description: The longanticipated recession was officially declared weeks ago, but last week the economic indicators were still catching up.

The Rev. Robert Bearden performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church. The couple graduated from Brown University. Mr. Jones is a student at the University of Michigan Graduate School of Business. His father is managing partner of the New York stock exchange firm of Lynch, Jones & Ryan.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  A legal confrontation is taking shape in Massachusetts, which this week became the 37th state to adopt a law reinstating capital punishment.

description: LAST month, the Council for the Arts in Westchester announced its 197980 grants, ranging from $250 to help the Y.M.C.A. of White Plains continue its music program for senior citizens up to $30,000 to assist the Neuberger Museum in developing a publications program. Nearly 60 awards were made to community cultural agencies as well as to ensembles or organizations devoted to theater, dance, visual arts and other cultural disciplines.

description: ALBERTSON  Works by Mildred Pawl; through Aug. 30; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, CH 8.7363.

title: Lions Defeat Browns As Danielson Excels
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 18 (UPI) Gary Danielson completed seven of 10 passes for 155 yards tonight, including firsthalf touchdown tosses of 33 and 39 yards to Luther Blue, to spark the Detroit Lions to a 2110 preseason victory over the Cleveland Browns.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE seems to encounter hard luck when it comes to getting his picture in the papers  a flattering photograph, that is.

title: FOOD
description: CUTCHOGUE THE Cutchogue Fire Department is expecting more than 3,000 people for dinner next Saturday, but the cooking won't start until Thursday. The reason the firemen and their wives are so relaxed is that they have become used to this. The annual chicken barbecue is a 23yearold tradition, and members of the department say it is the oldest chicken barbecue held in the state.

title: DOWN ON THE FARM WITH THE YANKEES GENE MICHAEL
description: In a jinxed year for the Yankees, the happiest moments have been provided by their No. 1 farm team, the Columbus Clippers, and super manager. Already a standout in the highly efficient Yankee organization, Michael may be heading for a top Yankee position.

title: Situation Vacant Andrew Young  the Symbol For a Changed Africa Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  In his own view, his President's and many of his colleagues', Andrew Young's chief diplomatic legacy to the Carter Administration is the goodwill he generated for the United States in Africa and other poorer parts of the world.

title: Two Aides to Gov. Brown to Run Fledgling Presidential Campaign
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. picked two top political lieutenants today to run his fledgling Presidential campaign.

title: On Language Presidents and the King's English
description: President Carter's recent speech to the nation on energy and the American spirit was both more forceful and more polished than most of his earlier addresses. But one speech or even one President cannot reverse the longterm decline over several administrations in the quality of English spoken at the White House. The undeleted expletive, the unfinished sentence, the uncouth metaphor, the uninspired, ungrammatical, unstructured or unoriginal statement have all been too frequently heard in Presidential conversations and press conferences in recent years. (Mr. Carter's image advisers could thus cite ample precedent in urging him to sound tough in his two highly publicized references to Senator Edward Kennedy, one threatening to whip the Senator from behind, the other denouncing a Kennedy charge as baloney.)

description: Nancy Ellen Long, a dancer with the Joyce Trisler Danscompany was married yesterday to Richard W. Loomis, art director of Sailboat Survey magazine. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's mother, Barbara McMartin, in Canada Lake, N.Y., by Justice of the Peace Harold Hayner. The bride is a daughter also of Dr. Edward B. Long 3d of Medina, Ohio, a researcher for the Department of Environmental Conservation in Cleveland. Mr. Loomis, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Russell Loojnis of Dolgeville, N.Y., and the late MC;. Loomis. The brade's mother is an author, painter and nathematician.

title: Turkish Delights
description: ASHAR KEMAL, now in his late 50's, has for several years been acknowledged to be the outstanding Turkish novelist of the present day. The place he writes of is the southern central part of his country, Antalya, in the foothills of the Taurus Mountains. As Mr. Kemal presents it, it is a timeless, primitive world; though there is brief mention of radios and trac tors, the Government in Ankara is unbelievably remote  certainly much more remote than specters, saints, devils, witches and jinn, all of whom are real rather than metaphorical. In fact, the timelessness

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AT first we just thought there were a lot of birds in the neighborhood, but the number of them perching in our trees seemed abnormal, said Linda Barone, who had recently moved with her husband, Edward, to the northern part of New Rochelle and found hundreds of starlings suddenly roosting on their property. The birds first appeared in early July, on Broadfield Road, and covered area property with feathers and droppings.

title: Anne W. Herbers Wed To Thomas Chad Farris
description: Anne Wood Herbers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Herbers of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Thomas Chad Farris, son of Prof. and Mrs. Jack Farris of Memphis. The ceremony was performed at the Evergreen Presbyterian Church in Memphis. The Rev. Carl Walters Jr., professor of religion at Southwestern College there, performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Each time the Bolshoi Ballet is about to descend upon us from Moscow, we are greeted with the sane advance warnings in print. The behemoth of ballet has slumped. It isn't what it used to be. In the last 10 years, this thesis has preceded every season given in New York by the various touring contingents of dancers that carne here under the Bolshoi imprimatur. And yet each time the Bolshoi sells out to an audience that must be the most fervently loyal public any ballet company can have. And each time the BiIshoi brings us some of the greatest dancers and some of the greatest dancing to be seen anywhere in the world.

title: It Didn't Fly
description: That multimilliondollar advertising campaign to restore public confidence in the DC10 has not yet gotten off the ground, and there is now some question whether it ever will.

title: Records Keep Britain's Coe on the Run
description: LONDON SEBASTIAN COE, Britain's overnight track superstar, is on the run again. But this time, in the aftermath of his third worldrecord run in 41 days, he has dashed into hiding with friends somewhere in the south of England to elude a British news media that for weeks has been featuring the country's most recent sports hero.

title: Police Upstate Seek Slayer of City Museum Worker
description: Forty state policemen and several sheriff's deputies yesterday were investigating the murder Thursday evening of Charlotte Louise Rivenburgh, a member of the public relations staff at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in rural Delaware County about 35 miles southeast of Binghamton.

title: Bank in Flushing a Strong Lender in J51 Projects
description: The city tax incentives that work to encourage the upgrading of older buildings as modern apartments has brought the Flushing Savings Bank to the fore as a source of funds for housing production in Manhattan and as an equity participant in these ventures.

title: SOVIET HOSTS LAUDED AS CONFERENCE ENDS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18  The Western organizers of a conference of 1,600 political scientists from East and West praised their Soviet hosts today for good faith and tolerance in permitting a week of lively and open debate on subjects that are normally taboo in the Soviet Union or discussed only as propaganda.

title: MALCOLM X: AN
description: In 1965, three men were convicted of assassinating the black leader. Now the only one who confessed has named four others who he swears were his true accomplices. Ought the case to be reopened?

title: An Envoy's Worry: How Will I Shop?
description: WASHINGTON NNE C. MARTINDELL of Princeton, who is scheduled to leave this week for her new post as American Ambassador to New Zealand, is more than half serious when she wonders how she is going to manage all the shopping for the many social functions at her new post.

title: Biggest Little Man on the Race Track
description: Somebody sent a tear sheet from The Daily Racing Form with Barney Nagler's column about the new book by Bill Heinz called Once They Heard The Cheers. The column made agreeable reading, for Barney knows Bill Heinz and appreciates his integrity as a reporter and his mastery of the writing art. Just below

title: Cambodian Urges Death Penalty At Trial of ExLeaders in Absentia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 18 (UPI) The prosecutor in the trial of former Prime Minister Pol Pot and his deputy, Ieng Sary, called for the death penalty today, the official Phnom Penh radio said

title: Sara Moore Complains of Prison
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP)  Sara Jane Moore, in the eighth day of a hunger strike at a West Virginia prison, today accused officials of keeping her in unjustified confinement. Mrs. Moore, serving life sentence after pleading guilty to trying to assassinate President Ford in September 1975 in San Francisco, said in a telephone call to a newspaper that she had been held in special detention beyond the time limit set by regulations at the prison in Alderson.

title: TV VIEW
description: At the television networks, programming decisions are made in New York and the creative decisions in Hollywood. This is the reason for considerable executive shuttling between the two Coasts, with rarely a stopover in the 3,000 miles between. The public, a network president once astutely observed, is what we fly over.

title: Zambia Reports Emerald Racket
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  The illegal mining and smuggling of emeralds costs Zambia up to $125 million a year in lost foreign exchange, according to a report submitted to President Kenneth D. Kaunda yesterday.

title: INTERVIEW A Workaholic of Many Hats
description: WESTFIELD JOAN SMITH wears more than one hat, and she wears them all well. She conducts interviews and is a drama critic for WJDM, a radio station in Elizabeth; is executive director of the Westfield Chamber of Commerce, whose newsletter she writes; is the tennis reporter and music critic for The Press Box, a sports and entertainment weekly; has her own publicrelations business, which is called Media Management, and is president of Words and Music, a group of professional writers and musicians.

title: Carter to Attend Energy Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) President Carter will travel to Atlanta on Aug. 30 to attend an energy seminar at the Georgia Institute of Technology and will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree from Emory University, the White House announced Wednesday. He will also will participate in groundbreaking ceremonies for the William R. Cannon chapel and religious center at Emory.

title: Friendly Town Is Set Up By Pennsylvania Couple
description: How does a rural community in Pennsylvania with a fraction of the population of New York City react when 65 city youngsters, many of whom have never seen a field of grass, arrive for a twoweek visit in the area for the first time?

title: Greg Louganis Is Victor In Platform Diving Event
description: DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 18 (UPI) Greg Louganis scored 808.775 points today to win the men's platform event and become the first diver in 15 years to capture all three men's events in the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor diving championships.

title: Food
description: When Ann Cook, a teacher and children's book author, and Anna Sweitzer, who is an educator, discovered that their children were being fed junk food at a highpriced nursery school, they decided to start a wholesale business called Good Food for Kids. Their fledgling firm now supplies daycare centers and schools with nourishing snacks for children. Here are their recipes for four kinds of munchies that have made a hit with kids. With some supervision, kids can even make them.

title: TELEVISION ENTERS THE 80'S
description: On a balmy evening last May, the limos pulled up to the marble curb of Los Angeles's Century Plaza hotel with clockwork precision. Inside, in the candlelit California Ballroom, the National Broadcasting Company was giving a gala reception for station executives and their wives. The owners and managers of NBC's 215 affiliated stations had gathered to hear about their network's plans for the 197980 television season, but most of all they had come to hear Fred Silverman, NBC's 41-year-old president, deliver the Good Word.

title: For Mayor Frank Rizzo, One Issue Has Been Enough
description: PHILADELPHIA  The tiny brick row houses of South Philadelphia abut, like dominoes, block after block. Dainty lace curtains cover most of the windows. Inside, pictures of the Virgin Mary or the Suffering Christ are common on living room walls.

title: A.B. Nichols 4th Weds Constance Wootton
description: Constance Barron Wootton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henry Wootton Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married in New Canaan, Conn., last evening to Arthur Boylston Nichols 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols 3d of New Canaan.

title: Barbato Is Implicated In L.I. Extortion Case By Key Trial Witness
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 17  Reversing his earlier testimony, the chief prosecution witness in the extortion and grandlarceny trial of Nicholas Barbato, the former Smithtown Republican leader, testified yesterday that he had put Mr. Barbato on the payroll of his insurance company out of fear that he would otherwise lose a lucrative Suffolk County insurance contract.

title: Indian Dancers, American Roots
description: From the Radcliffe dormitory where she is staying for the summer, she walks down Brattle Street toward Harvard Square. Stopping to wait for the light, she adjusts her bright red sari, shifts to her other hand the everpresent tan umbrella she uses as a parasol. When the light changes, Indrani, teacher of Indian dance at Harvard summer school, turns up Boylston Street, drawing stares as she goes.

title: Blacks Meet and Pledge To Fight Racism on L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 18  In the aftermath of a crossburning in Valley Stream Tuesday night, religious and civilrights leaders of the local black community met here today, vowing to continue their fight against the scar of racism and for the right of blacks to live where they choose.

title: Editor in DC10 Crash Ruled Dead Though Body Was Not Identified
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Sheldon Wax, the managing editor of Playboy magazine who apparently died in the crash of an American Airlines DC10 May 25, has been declared legally dead though his body was never identified.

title: G.N. Ryland, Didi Gerry Are Married
description: Marjorie Gerry, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry of Old Westbury, L.I., and Delhi, N.Y., was married in Delhi yesterday to G. Neal Ryland of Topsfield, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Ryland of Richmond. The Rev. Ray Donahue performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Nationalized Networks Are Gearing Up for 200 M.P.H. Trains
description: PARIS  Snubnosed, streamlined, wired for sound, Pufferbilly or the Iron Horse, is alive and well in Europe. Even without the oil crisis, a combination of geographic and political reasons had kept European railroads from lapsing exclusively into the province of nostalgics and toymakers. Now gasoline difficulties have given the rails a new momentum.

title: Illegal Dumping
description: ASEWAGETREATMENT plant here has been rendered virtually inoperative because of damage to equipment caused by the illegal dumping of chemical wastes into municipal sewer systems.

title: Saad Muhammad Wins by Decision
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18  Matthew Saad Muhammad knocked down John Conteh of Liverpool, England, twice for 8counts in the 14th round and retained his World Boxing Council lightheavyweight championship this afternoon.

title: Beauty
description: One of the distinct advantages of being a child is that the natural look is always in style. Healthy skin and hair are all that children need to look their best. With a little nudging from their parents, they can learn to follow simple and sensible guidelines to protect the natural good looks that they tend to take for granted.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE Rates: Volcker's Weapon
description: WASHINGTON  Paul A. Volcker is playing out the role just assigned him by the White House as the antiinflation point man. The question is how long he will continue to spearhead the attack on the price spiral, using aggressive monetary policy as his weapon, before coming into conflict with his own troops.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: ALONG with all the other new questions facing car buyers in this era of gasoline lines, high prices and changing habits, there is yet another: Whether to order factoryinstalled radio or purchase one from the burgeoning list of aftermarket suppliers.

title: Historical Dispute Settled by Football Contest
description: LANCASTER, S.C., Aug. 18 (AP) To many among the 4,052 people who paid to see it, the Old Hickory Football Classic was more a chance to have fun and see their high school teams in action than a way to settle a 200yearold controversy.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ON Tuesday, New York City was to have put five cityowned watershed land sites on the Island's South Shore, between Freeport and the Suffolk County line, on the auction block as part of its program to sell surplus properties.

title: Melancholy Themes
description: THERE are few 20thcentury composers who have earned enough royalties to make musical composition economically worthwhile. Certainly one would not expect to find one among the 12tone composers who studied under Arnold Schoenberg; such music has generally inspired little more than public rejection. Yet Alban Berg achieved what was denied completely to his colleagues. And though the purists may have been embarrassed  one critic called him the Puccini of twelvenote music  the public response, particularly to Berg's operas, Wozzeck and Lulu, has never been in doubt. With royalties from Wozzeck, a monthly stipend from his publisher, and commissions for the concert aria Der Wein and the Violin Concerto, Berg had few financial worries in the years before his death in 1935 at the age of 55. In fact, his widow, Helene Berg, aided equally by her eccentric frugality and the growing royalty payments, accumulated a large fortune and in 1968 established a wellendowed Alban Berg Foundation to aid composers less fortunate.

title: BRIDGE
description: The biggest bridge tournament ever played anywhere in the world was staged at the beginning of this month in a very unlikely place: Las Vegas. One might think that this would be a natural center for card players, but there is a wide gulf between the tension of the blackjack tables and the intellectual excitement of duplicate play. A surprisingly small number of bridge players are gamblers, although a handful are experts in both fields. There are a few bridge stars who can play blackjack well enough to make a small profit and run the risk of expulsion by the casinos who do not welcome winners, even honest ones.

title: Oyster Bay Cites Two Critics on Violations
description: OME residents of the Town of Oyster Bay, who have in the past been critical of their town's government or its agencies, have charged recently that they have been harassed by the town's building division. They contend that they have been cited for minor violations, in their homes and yards, of regulations that the division does not enforce against most other residents.

title: EAST GERMANY USING PRUSSIAN DISCIPLINE
description: EAST BERLIN, Aug. 18  The brass band played a Prussian march and behind it a column of goosestepping soldiers came marching down Unter den Linden. It was an East German Army parade, a display of military might that the Communists stage each week.

title: Tenure: A Given Is Taken
description: HARTFORD ASTATE Supreme Court decision that could give local school boards more power to get rid of tenured teachers has stunned some teachers' representatives and has set up another issue for the General Assembly to grapple with next year.

title: A New Look at Graham Greene's England
description: In a terraced Victorian house on a leafy London square, Nicol Williamson, Sir John Gielgud and Sir Richard Attenborough are waiting while a scene is readied for the cameras.

title: Children's Fashions
description: The clothes that American children wear  serviceable togs that can take the knocking around kids are bound to give them  are popular around the globe. Here, American children and friends from the United Nations school show off new pintsize classics.

title: For Ecology Expert, The Horizon Widens
description: TRENTON AFTER five years as chief scientist of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, Dr. Glenn Paulson has resigned to become vice president for science of the National Audubon Society, a job that he said signaled a new direction for the 400,000member organization.

title: Dance: Karen Bernard Presents Her Experimental Interphase
description: There's a lot to be said for giving experimental dance performances in handsome spaces. A huge Ioft with clear interior detail in the old Ball, Black and Company building on Broadway and Prince Street provided Karen Bernard with such a space for her Internhase. performed there on Friday.
