title: Dr. Martha Jean Macdonald, Pediatrician, Becomes Bride of Dr. Richard Noel R
description: Dr. Martha Jean Macdonald, a pediatrician, and Dr. Richard Noel R, an endocrinologist, were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven, N.J. Msgr. Ronald Boland Macdonald, godfather of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: A Resident Theater Flourishes in Bergen
description: ENGLEWOOD I READ hundreds of scripts every year, said Chariz A. Herfurth, artistic director of the Center Stage company, but I only produce plays that I haven't seen myself. That's important to me not to be affected by anyone else's interpretation.

title: 100 Protesters Allowed To Enter Georgia Prison
description: REIDSVILLE, Ga., Aug. 18 (AP)  Inmates waved white towels from windows of a nearby compound while 100 civil rights activists marched across a bridge today to the Georgia State Prison, where 67 protesters were arrested last weekend in violation of a court order. No incidents were reported today.

title: ART
description: So much contemporary photography is overwhelmed with esthetics, as if esthetics alone were the sole raison d'tre of a work of art. Thus when we come across

title: Blacks Link Arson To Racism in County
description: COUNTY Executive Alfred B. DelBello stood in the charred interior of the house at 229 Underhill Street in Yonkers. It had been heavily damaged by arson hours after Thomas Porter, a black executive, and his family moved in. Mr. DelBello tried to express sympathy to the family, but like many of the people milling about on the front porch of the house on Aug. 8, the morning after the fire, he seemed to be at a loss for words.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Connecticut Dairyman Is Losing Much of His Herd to Brucellosis
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP) Most people have never heard of brucellosis, but every dairy farmer knows the bacteria that cause the disease can spell big trouble.

title: Support for Reagan Is Increasing Among New York G.O.P. Chiefs
description: ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 18 Despite a state Republican policy of temporary neutrality in the party's Presidential contest, two major New York City Republican leaders said today that they would support Ronald Reagan, and a top suburban Republican leader said he believed Mr. Reagan's nomination was virtually assured.

title: Miss Alcott in 3Way Tie For Lead in Indiana Golf
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., Aug. 18 (AP) Amy Alcott, Sandra Spuzich and Sally Little shot fourunderpar 68's today and shared the firstround lead in a raindelayed, $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Dodgers Turn Back Pirates, 51
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (UPI) Gary Thomasson and Dusty Baker combined to drive in five runs tonight, and Jerry Reuss, a former Pirate, tossed an eighthitter to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to their fifth straight victory, a 51 decision over Pittsburgh.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Suburban Gentrification Lends to Mortification

title: Pulaski Day Set for Oct. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  President Carter has proclaimed Oct. 11 General Pulaski Memorial Day in honor of the 200th anniversary of the death of the Polish patriot. Gasimir Pulaski, whose death was caused by wounds suffered in the Revolutionary War, was praised Thursday by Mr. Carter for his heroism and his selflessness in the struggle for American independence.

title: The Stakes in the Young Affair
description: Andrew Young was not the first American Ambassador to the United Nations to have been cruelly deceived into believing that he was sent there to make foreign policy. Adiai Stevenson thought the job would be second in importance only to that of Secretary of State. Arthur Goldberg was lured off the Supreme Court with the fiction that he could end the Vietnam War on the East River better than anyone on the Potomac. No other nation has so politicized its representation at the world organization. No other has therefore had to suffer such erratic changes of voice or to muffle so many intellects yearning to break free. It is time to grasp the truth: Ambassadors are linemen in this game; they don't carry the ball.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  The Surflight Review (through tomorrow). Dames at Sea, opens Tuesday (through Aug. 27). 8:30 P.M. $5$5.50. (609) 4929477.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE has been a change in management at Gil Clark's in Bay Shore, and the change has been for the better. While the restaurant may still not be up to the standards of yore (very yore  we're talking about 15 to 20 years ago), the improvement is encouraging and we can recommend the restaurant for its good seafood.

title: Confederates Descendants Keep Tradition in Brazil
description: AMERICANA, BrazilI declare, I love to sit here and watch those poinsettias when they're so vivid like they are now, said Judith Jones, 64 years old, in a Southern accent as soft and sweet as a fresh slice of watermelonrind pickle.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT was midnight at the supermarket. Fluorescent lights bathed the shelves in artificial glare. Along one wall, shopping carts formed a neat metal line; boxes filled with the coming morning's unpacked inventory lay in the aisles.

title: LAY CATHOLICS TAKE EVANGELIZING PATH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  Who is the church? asked the Rev. Alvin A. Illig. We are, shouted hundreds of people in the audience.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR AT ONE time, it was sufficient for a museum director to be nothing more than a connoisseur of art. All he had to know was something about the past glories of painting and sculpture and a little about the modern ones, too.

title: ART VIEW
description: The only way to get to know the great Russian collections is to go to Russia and stay there for quite some time. The experience cannot be tidied shortened. Highlights from the Hermitage makes no sense; Russia is by its very nature enormous, unhurried, allenveloping. There are many resonan tverbs in the Russian dictionary, but encapsulate is not one of them. A stay of two or three months is mandatory, where those collections are concerned: not merely to see them in their entirety but to put down roots in a country where friendship, once established, runs true, straight an deep.

title: Transit Officials Alarmed by Costs Of Easier Access for Handicapped
description: The heads of transit systems around the country are expressing alarm about new regulations requiring every form of public transportation to be made accessible to the disabled, who in turn have fought for years to win what they regard as a basic civil right too long denied them.

title: She's Not Bugged By 17Year Cicadas
description: CIRISTINE SIMON was different from most youngsters, and she's different from most adults, too. Ever since she can remember, she has liked insects.

title: Byrne Endorses Nuclear Power at End of 'summit
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP)  The state cannot meet its shortterm energy needs without the increased use of nuclear power, Governor Byrne said today at the conclusion of his twoday New Jersey summit meeting on energy.

title: Issue in LandlordTenant Cases: Level of Services Given in the Past
description: Were they not, demanded longtime tenants of Walden Terrace in Queens, entitled to new toilet seats upon renewal of their leases? And window shades? And a stovecleaning?

title: First Victory Still Eludes Burns
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 18  George Burns is moderately wealthy but very frustrated.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Casino Applicants Challenging State On Privacy Rights
description: TRENTON

title: Poor Nations Badly Hit
description: WASHINGTON  Developing countries trying to modernize grain farming have been hit hardest by the latest round of oil price increases, which sent tremors through world agriculture. Some countries the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries claims to be helping with grants and loans are among those suffering the most.

title: Palestinians in U.S. Back Young
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  Delegates interviewed at the constitutional convention of the Palestine American Congress here this weekend blamed Israel for the resignation of Andrew Young as United States delegate to the United Nations after his meeting with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: With a little bit of something to attract almost everyone  international foods to taste, antiques to buy and colonial crafts demonstrations to watch  the Huntington Historical Society holds its annual Heritage Festival today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Naturally, since it is Huntington, the town's Minutemen will also be on hand to recreate a small encampment, in preparation, no doubt, for the battalion's Weekend Muster (complete with guest units and a large tactical demonstration) slated for all day Saturday and next Sunday on the Village Green. Anyway, the Heritage Festival will be at the Heckscher Ball Park, Route 25A. The donation is $1.25; children 5 to 14, 50 cents; under 5, free.

title: Carol L. Zigarelli to Be Bride Of John DeBlois Next Month
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Zigarelli of Mendham, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carol Lynne Zigarelli, to John Steven DeBlois, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. DeBlois of Pawtucket, R.I., and Franconia, N.H. The couple will be married next month at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Test Car Receives Praise For Safety in Collisions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Transportation Department had praise today for an experimental research car that gets 28.2 miles to the gallon and that would allow people in the front seat to survive collisions at 80 miles an hour, according to test results.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY There's a Transient at the Front Door
description: OUR house in Rochelle Park, in Bergen County, is bordered on all sides by highways. Only a few houses away, at the end of the street, is a stop for buses to New York, Jersey City and Newark. It should not seem strange, then, that there are so many transients in my town.

title: Equatorial Guinea Says ExDictator Is Captured
description: MADRID, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  The ousted dictator of Equatorial Guinea, Nguema Biyoto Masie, was captured today near his home village of Mengomo, the Spanish national radio said tonight.

title: Visitors And Exiles
description: AS I write this, the annual American invasion of England is in full flood. At the bottom of the Haymarket, crowds of tourists are milling around the American Express office demanding letters, and at Stratford the lawn between the theater and the river is dense with Frisbeethrowers. The English are no doubt responding as usual with varying degrees of phlegm, while agreeing with the Duke in Zuleika Dobson, who thought that Americans had a perfect right to exist but regretted that they exercised that right in England.

title: Narragansetts, Land Suit Settled, See Small Victory
description: CHARLESTOWN, R.I., Aug. 18 (AP)The Narragansett Indians will receive 1,800 acres here this fall under the first Indian land claim settlement on the Eastern Seaboard, but many in the tribe feel it is too little too late.

title: Joanne Maragos Bride on L.I.
description: Joanne Maragos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Maragos of North Babylon, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald DeAngelis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald DeAngelis, also of North Babylon. The Rev. John Dragland performed the ceremony in the Ascension Lutheran Church in Deer Park, L.I. The bride, her father and the bridegroom are cable operators with Western Union International Inc. The bridegroom's father is assistant dayshift foreman of the photoengraving department of The New York Times.

title: Airline Withdrawal
description: THE impending withdrawal of Allegheny Airlines from Westchester County Airport could force changes in the travel patterns of the Connecticut residents who use the airport.

title: The Political Costs for Carter Could Run Into 1980 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  It is possible to argue that one of the biggest favors Andrew Young ever did for Jimmy Carter was to refuse to let him off the hook.

title: Headliners
description: Koreagate, the Pandora's box opened under the dome of the Capitol, is closed. The Government last week dropped a spate of indictments against Korean rice dealer Tongsun Park and closed the books on the twoyear investigation of his alleged influencebuying among members of Congress. Despite much sound and fury, the episode produced only one conviction  of a former California Congressman  though it caused embarassment to dozens of Senators and Representatives who accepted money and hospitality from Mr. Park, who said he thought he was merely taking part in the American political process. He may yet get to take part in another aspect of the process: The Internal Revenue Service says he owes $4.5 million in back taxes and interest.

title: ANTIQUES
description: NEW LONDON

title: 2 Ritual Bathhouses Get Mixed Reception
description: TO serve a changing, more observant Orthodox Jewish community, the first ritual bathhouse in the southern part of Nassau County is nearing completion in the basement of a Colonial house in West Hempstead. But another bathhouse, to be constructed in Hewlett, has run into opposition from some neighbors of the proposed facility, which is designed to serve residents of the Five Towns.

title: INVESTING
description: As numbers of inflationweary investors have placed portions of their savings in precious metals, many of them have discovered that they can, in effect, finance their purchases of gold, silver, platinum and copper at interests costs far below current borrowing rates. What's the catch? There isn't any. What savvy investors are doing is simply buying futures contracts.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Andrew Young, former delegate to the United Nations.

title: A FloodControl Debate Hinges on Dollars vs. Lives
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug. 18 (AP)  Along the winding Tug Fork Valley of southern West Virginia, a debate in Washington on flood control strikes people as a bewildering equation juggling dollars versus lives.

title: Much Ado About Growing Mosses In the Home Garden
description: In the early days of botany before the microscope had been invented, many kinds of simple plants were lumped together under the category of mosses. This ancient usage is still reflected today by such terms as Spanish moss for a mosslike flowering plant which really belongs to the pineapple family, club moss for a fern relative and Irish moss for an edible seaweed.

title: Page Palmer Bride Of Stephen Butkus
description: Page Palmer, a regional service consultant in the group pension department of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in boston, was married yesterday to Stephen Ronald Butkus, an account executive with Martin Segal Inc., actuarial consultants in Boston.

title: Art Program Fills Spaces and Needs
description: WHITE PLAINS PINSTRIPES and batting helmets, pennant races and just plain pennants, ticket stubs and scorecards  such is the stuff that Todd Radom's art is made of.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: DRIFTING with the summer ebb and flow of the Long Island Rail Road  more ebb than flow, same as the winter service  the rider finds the broken airconditioner combining with traincar windows, sealed tight as fate, to provide a tracery of sweat and a reverie of selfpity about the brow.

title: Discount Cars From the Chrysler Corp.
GARDENING
description: SPRING has its flowering trees, autumn has trees with colorful fruits and foliage, but what of summer? While the green leaves of summer provide us with cooling shade, there is otherwise a paucity of color overhead. The number of trees that flower in the summer are limited, but a few come to mind that would make excellent additions to our gardens.

title: Lang Son Mirrors Vietnam's Pessimism Over china
description: LANG SON, Vietnam, Aug. 15  This onceflourishing town of 50,000, now lying in piles of rubble, will not soon be rebuilt, said Vi Gia Le, a leading official of the provincial government, for Lang Son, even more than the rest of Vietnam, has no faith in the possibility of peace.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ROSSMANKarl J., on Aug. 17, dearly beloved husband of Ilse, devoted brother of Lucy Kahn, dear brotherinlaw of Herman Kahn and Hans and Rena Wirth, loving uncle of Judy Florsheim, Barry Kahn, and Barbara Stanczak. Services Sunday, August 19, 1 PM, Hirsch 8 Sons, Jerome Ave. and 167th St.. Bronx.

title: Cautious Use of Investigative Hypnosis Is Growing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  As hypnosis gains acceptance as an investigative tool for the police, critics of the practice are finding more and more cases in which evidence gained through hypnosis turned out to be unreliable. And proponents relate other stories of success in solving difficult crimes by using hypnosis.

title: Richard Oppenheim Jr. Marries Ronnie Schwartz
description: Ronnie Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Schwartz of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Richard E. oppenheim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Oppenheim of Scranton, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center by Rabbi David Gordon and Rabbi Milton Richman of Scranton.

title: SHOP TALK More Than Seashells
description: CHERRY GROVE EOPLE generally ferry across the Great South Bay to Fire Island to get away from it all. They want to escape noise, traffic, heat and crowded beaches on this narrow strip of sand facing the Atlantic, and they do. But you can't get away from commerce, not even here. There are stores in Cherry Grove, and they aren't just selling seashells from the seashore.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Monmouth County, East Freehold Show Grounds, Freehold, N.J. Regular, special, adult amateur, and nonthoroughbred working hunters; novice Jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Barnegat Bay: Is War on Pollution Making Headway?
description: BAY HEAD THE beneficial effects of the efforts to rid Barnegat Bay of pollution in this decade have yet to be fully realized, despite reports of unusually good fishing and persistent statements that the bay, the largest body of inland water in the state, is coming back.

title: ART
description: CONTRARY to the usual pracice of introducing exhibitions through middlemen, Dan Flavin, at the Hudson River Museum, has done the job himself. And perhaps it's as well. For a curator or critic would have been tempted into many more than the 18 lines he takes to account for what can only be called a fascinating aberration.

title: ElPBtiS
description: ALLENJohn H. Of Summit, N.J. on August 17, 1979. Husband of the fate Amy G. Allen and father of Mrs. Albin B. (Marjorie) Nelson of Maplewood, N.J., Mrs. Philemon (Patricia) Truesdale of N.Y.C. and also of the late Mrs. William (Joyce) Drushel of Houston, Texas. Also survived by a sister Mrs. Richard (Ivy) Russell of Woodstock, England, eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Service at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, N.J. Monday August 20th at 11 AM. Visiting at the Burroughs & Kohr Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, N.J. Sunday 46 PM. Memorial contributions may be made In in his memory to The Seaman's Institute, 15 State St., New York City or the Salvation Army, 80 Washington St., Newark, N.J.

title: Problem Closes Nuclear Plant
description: CRYSTAL RIVER, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP)  The Crystal River nuclear power plant was shut down early today for an indefinite period because of problems in controlling the flow of water in the plant's steam generation system, a company spokesman said. The plant had been operating at limited capacity since Thursday because of problems with a seal in pump, according to the Florida Power Corporation, which operates the facility.

title: Striking Union at Westinghouse Reaches Agreement, but 2 Balk
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has reached a tentative agreement with the striking International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers on a new threeyear wage contract, but two other striking unions, the International Union of Electrical Workers and the United Electrical Workers, have rejected the proposal.

title: Connors Advances To Final
description: STOWE, Vt., Aug. 18 (AP)  Jimmy Connors breezed to a 67minute 63, 60 victory over Johan Kriek and unseeded Mike Cahill upset Tim Gullikson, 64, 63, in the semifinals of a $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Neighborhood Power  a Term Representing a New Constituency Entering National Political Life
description: In recent months, an army of journalists, policymakers, social scientists and politicians has begun to discover that a neighborhood movement forms a kind of invisible saga of the decade, below the antics of Presidents, rock stars and football heroes.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Counting the hordes of China has never been easy, in large part because the country that everyone agrees has the world's most people has, since the revolution, been secretive about how many Chinese there really are. Now the exact number doesn't matter any more. Whatever it is  the current estimate is 960 millionthe new leaders of the People's Republic have decided it is too many.

title: CRIME
description: Flawed heroes are always more interesting than the Galahad types, and Lovejoy, the hero of GOLD BY GEMINI by Jonathan Gash (Harper & Row, %8???), is flawed indeed. Lovejoy, who made his previous appearance in The Judas Pair late in 1977, is an English antiques dealer. He scrambles for a living and is not above turning a dishonest deal or two; his speech is ribald, and his manner can be offensive. Yet he is a genuine hero because, like Don Giovanni or Carmen, he is faithful to himself. In his way, he seeks the truth, the unattainable vision, backed by tremendous knowledge and a rapt love for what he is doing.

title: A Kind of Everyday Ecstasy
description: WE all think we know something about sexual excitement, but as yet no one has given us a good theory of it. Psychoanalysts have had surprisingly little to say about sexual excitement as such, perhaps reflecting the weakness of psychoanalysis in addressing experiential states as opposed to origins of disturbance.

title: A 16Pound Box for $599
description: The glory of the transistor was its way of making big things small, be they computers, calculators  or radios. It made the radio truly portable, small enough to fit in a pocket. But like men and beanstalks, the little radio grew and grew. Its heir is known as a box, in the vernacular of the street, and while it still might be called portable, so is a steamer trunk.

title: Owners of Texas Town Seeking Right Buyer
description: LUCKENBACH, Tex., Aug. 18 (UPI)  The town of Luckenbach, Tex., has been put up for sale by its three residents, but there are a few conditions that a prospective buyer will have to meet before claiming the tiny hamlet.

title: Good Old Westhamburger
description: HERE I am, on the patio of my home in Westhampton, which has been featured in House Beautiful four times, watching my yacht bobbing on the bay, and wondering how in the world I can let David B. Saxe's article, Going Westhampton, My Friends? Good! [Opinion Page, Aug. 5], spoil a perfect morning.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: IN a small office in downtown Stamford, Diana Crouse, director of the Stamford Fair Rent Commission, has been running what she finds is an increasingly frustrating operationtrying to reconcile escalating financial realities facing landlords with tenants ability to pay.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Before the invention Of photography, vacation snapshots were made by watercolorists and lithographers, They were not, of course, photographic snapshots but Iiey served the same purpose as the kind of Snapshot or color slide that nearly everyone takes on vacation today. They served to remind the traveler and his friends of the strange and wonderful places he had seen.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Greater Lowell Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Middlesex County 4H Grounds, Westford, Mass.; 1,098 dogs, 9 A.M.

title: Purcell Aims for a NoIncrease Budget
description: MINEOLA FOR the next five days, the heads of some 50 Nassau County departments and agencies will appear at public hearings to make their requests for a precious and diminishing commodity  operating funds for next year.

title: Faces Charges Over Welfare
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP)  Barbara Williams, who is serving a prison term for what is believed to be the nation's largest welfare fraud case, has been charged along with five other persons in another welfare scheme involving more than $100,000. John Van de Kamp, the District Attorney for Los Angeles County, said the new case involved false welfare claims filed for 30 nonexistent children. Mrs. Williams, known here as the Queen of Welfare, is serving an eightyear prison term for defrauding the Government of $240,000 in welfare payments.

title: Desegregation Trial Set Between H.E.W. and U. of North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 18 (AP)  The desegregation dispute between the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the University of North Carolina will be heard at a formal administrative trial scheduled to begin Jan. 7,1980.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: ALONG with all the new questions facing car buyers in this era of gas lines, high prices and changing habits, there is yet another: Whether to order a factory radio or to install one from the growing list of aftermarket suppliers.

title: GREEKS CRIME PATE IS LOWEST IN EUROPE
description: ATHENS  While the rest of Europe is experiencing a soaring crime rate, Greece is enjoying domestic tranquillity and freedom from violence.

title: Two More Octuplets Die In Italy, Leaving Three
description: NAPLES, Italy, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Two more of the eight babies born to a Naples woman died today, leaving only three baby girls surviving.

title: Consider Peaches for the Backyard Orchard
description: peach Melba is the favorite dessert of one of my friends. Since she already grows her own raspberries, she asked me one day if she couldn't grow her own peaches as well. I replied I didn't see why not, since I do and with great success.

title: Jill Nexon Engaged To Jeffrey Bercow
description: Phillip J. Nexon of Boston and Mrs. Elinor W. Nexon of Auburndale, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jill Nexon, to Jeffrey S. Bercow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Bercow of Scotch Plains, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: Paddling the Waters Of the Voyageurs
description: A wealth of wild islands, windblown waters, beaches, rocky cliff and rarely explored forest is our gift in one of our newest national parks, Voyageurs, in northern Minnesota. The 219,400acre park, a third of it water, was opened to the public in 1975. It lies in that geographically mysterious 200mile stretch of the United StatesCanadian border between International Falls, Minn., and Lake Superior, where the two countries by treaty share the waterways that officially divide them.

title: General Assembly Sets Saratoga Mark; Davona Dale Fourth
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 18  Davona Dale went to the post as the favorite, but General Assembly saved the day for male chauvinists this afternoon by winning the 110th Travers Stakes at Saratoga in record time.

title: Apartments In Flushing Snapped Up By Koreans
description: Eight years ago Richard Fiorenze bought a lot on Union Street in the Flushing section of Queens with the idea that he would build an apartment house there and live in one of the apartments himself when he retired. In the old days that's what all builders did, he said.

title: POLITICS
description: N marked contrast to the frequent governmental and political pyrotechnics of his predecessor, Ralph G. Caso, Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell is running a lowkey, lowvisibility administration in which he admits he is not looking to make dramatic changes in government.

title: Revolutionary Art
description: From left, advertisement for babybottle nipples (1923) by Alexander Rodchenko and Vladimir Mayakovsky; Meeting (linocut, 1919) by Vladimir Kozlinsky; advertisement for galoshes (1923) by Rodchenko and Mayakovsky; illustration for Alexander Blok's poem The Twelve (1918) by Yury Annenkov.

title: The Real Shame in Medicaid
description: THE Rev. James Holmes Davis expressed concern for those elderly persons caught up in the state's nursing home dilemma ["Medicaid at Issue in Nursing Homes, Opinion Page, July 71. Unfortunately, Mr. Davis's argument was like a smashed glass plate: when put together, it revealed large cracks in marred surface.

title: Landslides Kill 15 in NorthIndia
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 17 (AP)  Landslides caused by monsoon rains killed at least 15 people in northern India, United News of India reported today.

title: Ambassador to Nigeria Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) President Carter said today he would nominate Stephen Low, now the Ambassador to Zambia, to serve as Ambassador to Nigeria. Mr. Low, a 51yearold native of Cincinnati, joined the Foreign Service in 1956.

title: Recordings
description: Hugh the Drover, begun by Ralph Vaughan Williams before 1914 but not produced until a decade later, was intended, as the Composer wrote to his librettist, Harold Child, to be something on the lines of Snetana's Bartered Bride... an opera written to real English words. with a certain amount of real English music, and also a real English subject

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Price Of SALT
description: WASHINGTON  Several weeks ago, three powerful Senators wrote to President Carter arguing that the strategic arms limitation treaty (SALT II) should not even be seriously considered without a commitment to increase defense spending 4 percent or 5 percent above inflation.

title: Will Carter Be Another L.B.J.?
description: ALTHOUGH Election Day is still more than two months away, Republican and Democratic leaders have been busy giving campaign advice to candidates for the 80 State Assembly seats.

title: FORREST M. DOUDS
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18  Forrest M. Douds, the first coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers football team, died Thursday in Sewickley, Pa., Valley Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: A Record Run of Robbing Banks
description: Willy Sutton used to say he robbed banks because thats where the money is, and numerous latterday Willies have recently been smitten, it seems, by the masters logic. Late last week the rash of robberies this year took a tragic turn in the banking capital of New York: a policeman was killed in a midday shootout at Grand Central Station by a gunman suspected of holding up nearby branches of both Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan. A plainclothes officer was wounded.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Empire Division Jaguar Clubs of North America concours d'elegance, at Lyndhurst, Route 9 (South Broadway), Tarrytown, N.Y. (halfmile south of Tappan Zee Bridge). Registration: 10 A.M.; judging 1 P.M.; awards at 4. Public invited.

title: Freeport Fishermen Seek Deeper Inlet
description: FREEPORT EARLY each morning, while most of the Island sleeps, Frank Cona, a sixthgeneration commercial fisherman, revs up his boat, the Apache II, and sets out to harvest the ocean for seafood to sell in his Freeport fish market.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: An otherwise healthy childhood was pestered by an occasional cold, a few strep throats and a case of acne that defied medical science. In Feed Your Kids Right, Dr. Lendon Smith suggests that if Mother had known to administer the barrage of vitamins known as megavitamins, these ailments could have been cured quicker than they were by conventional medical treatment  and possibly even prevented altogether.

title: Earthquake Hits San Francisco
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)  A minor earthquake registering about 2.3 on the Richter scale struck the San Francisco Bay area yesterday. No damage was reported.

title: 3 Palestinians Captured By Israeli Navy off Coast
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 18 (UPI)  An Israeli naval patrol intercepted a seaborne raiding party near Israel's northern coast, the military command reported, and three Palestinians were captured and another was believed to have drowned.

title: The World
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's frayed Islamic revolution unraveled bit further last week as Kurdish rebels seized the town of Paveh near the Iraqi border and claimed to have shot down an Iranian Air Force Phantom jet sent to strafe them. (The Government said the crash was accidental and that Paveh had been retaken.)

title: Publishing
description: WASHINGTON  Without making a formal announcement, the Federal Trade Commission has dropped its investigation of the friendly takeover last year of J. B. Lippincott & Company, the Philadelphia publishing house, by Harper & Row, the New York book firm. By quietly informing Harper & Row that the acquisition is no longer under scrutiny, the Government avoided a showdown in the antitrust arena in the peculiar  because it is so personal and so volatile in an inflationary marketplace  world book publishing. But for publishers, editors, writers and for the Government itself, the Lippincott takeover remains controversial, an example of the domination of conglomerates in the book field today.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: This has been a busy summer for Joseph Turrin, who will conduct a 40member orchestra in the ninth concert of the Summer Festival of Music series in Fair Lawn. The program begins at 8:30 P.M.

title: Hudson La Salle Weds Lucy Ryan
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Lucy Skeer Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Wallace Ryan of Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn., became the bride of Hudson Norman La Salle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hudson A. La Salle of Arlington, Va. Msgr. Robert Brown performed the ceremony.

title: David Gray Weds Abby Aldrich
description: Abby P. Aldrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Aldrich of South Nonquitt, Mass., and New York, was married yesterday to David M. Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gray of Dover and South Dartmouth, Mass. Assistant Bishop J. Brooke Mosley of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Chapel in South Dartmouth.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Firefighters brought Idaho's huge Mortar Creek timber fire under complete control today.

title: Passage Through India
description: THE photographs in this volume remind me vividly of New Delhi and London, where I often saw Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit going about her diplomatic duties, a beautiful whitehaired woman with such dignity of bearing that she seemed tall. It was a surprise to realize that she is in fact rather short.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: TOP HOG FOR SECOND STRAIGHT YEAR: Junior, a 1,150pound boar, being coaxed onto the scales by Harold and Donald McDermit at the Indiana State Fair in Indianopolis. Junior won the title of the World's Largest Boar for the second straight year, and the fourth time in the last five years at the fair.

title: Michaelle Bouchereau Engaged
description: The engagement of Michaelle Bouchereau to Joseph Orozco has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Ghislaine Bouchereau. The bride-to-be, daughter also of Gerry Bouchereau of Los Angeles, attended Manhattan College. She is with Gross & Associates, New York publicrelations counselors. Mr. Orozco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustavo Orozco of Brooklyn, is a student at Brooklyn College and is a laboratory techniciar at the CDC Chemical Corporation i New York.

title: CHESS
description: What is a slight positional advantage worth? With correct play on both sides, it is not enough to decide a game, but it is enough to present problems for the the defender.

title: Last Week, Benjamin R. Civiletti Took Over a Rehabilitated Department
description: WASHINGTON  In his final days as Attorney General last week, Griffin B. Bell maintained the form that characterized his 30 months in office. Tuesday morning, over a breakfast of roasted quail which he had shot himself, Mr. Bell bluntly told reporters that Jimmy Carter had a tendency to diminish the Presidency by dealing personally with too many trivial issues, and by actine like one of the boys.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: With the signing of the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty last March, one small matter all but escaped public notice: the future of the electronic surveillance system operated by Americans in the Sinai to insure compliance with a previous agreement. The system  three watch stations and sensors to detect intruders into a buffer zone  began operating in February 1976 between the Gidi and Mitla Passes.

title: Foes See Klan Impeding Growth of a New South
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 18 (UPI)  The acting executive director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference said today there could be no New South unless the Ku Klux Klan, which he termed alive and sick, was stopped.

title: The Region
description: Good news, said Mayor Koch as he began a news conference on fiscal 1979 last week. We are not in a situation where we can say the patient is cured. But the patient is getting well.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: ALONG with all the other new questions facing car buyers in this era of gas lines, high prices and changing habits, there is yet another: Whether to order a factory radio or to install one from the burgeoning list of aftermarket suppliers.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's (Aug. 12) column, the diagram failed to identify as white a bishop at Black's KR3.

title: Is Science Ahead Of the Forger?
description: Michelangelo, aged 21, buried one of his statues so it could be sold to a Cardinal as a work of antiquity. Casanova's brother, Francesco, passed off three of his own paintings as Pompeian, and it is said even titter made a precarious living for a short while by forging oil paintings, which he baked in an oven to simulate the cracks and spider webbing of old paint. titter made a precarious living for a short while by forging oil paintings, which he baked in an oven to simulate the cracks and spider webbing of old paint.

title: Other World Events
description: Every year, when the monsoons sweep across India, hundreds of people die and politicians bicker over what more could have been done to prevent the tragedies. But little has been done and last week more than 1,000 and perhaps as many as 20,000 people perished when a rainsodden dam collapsed in western India, sending a 20foothigh wall of water crashing through the city of Morvi. Local politicians charged that the city's 75,000 residents had not been alerted quickly enough, that rescue and cleanup operations were disorganized and that the collapsed dam contained structural faults.

title: Erna Mankiewicz Stenbuck, 78, Retired New York Schoolteacher
description: Erna Mankiewicz Stenbuck, a retired teacher in the New York City schools, died Aug. l in Villach, Austria, where she had lived for several years. She was 78 years old.

title: Mixed Emotions Greet Robinson Selection
description: It was a scene that will remain vivid, a frozen slice of football life that eloquently evoked the Jets and their feelings for one another.

title: Singapore Said to Plan Purchase Of Military Aircraft From the U.S.
description: SINGAPORE Aug. 18 (AP)  Singapore has agreed to buy an unspecified number of military planes from the United States, Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California, said here today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Susan B. Anthony dollar has gained wide publicity in the seven weeks since its introduction, much of it negative and focusing on faults people find with the coin. However, this new dollar does still attract attention.

title: SINDONA CASE YIELDS NO CLUES TO POLICE Disappearance of Italian Financier Contains Elements of a Novel of International Intrigue
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who disappeared 17 days ago in Manhattan, remains the central character in a mystery that contains the elements of a bestselling novel.

title: Why Europe Still Prospers
description: Continued from Page 1

title: Saudi Papers Criticize U.S. on Young Incident
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  President Carter's Administration has come under heavy attack by the Saudi Arabian press for its handling of Andrew Young's resignation and his meeting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The Haste to Bail Out Chrysler
description: If President Carter can enact his guaranteed loan program for the Chrysler Corporation, it should be called the Large Corporation Management Protection Act of 1979. Together with the Lockheed bailout by a Republican Administration, it would clearly establish a bipartisan policy of not allowing major employers fail in the marketplace. Whatever the merits of Chrysler's bid for help and of the Administration's proposal, there is something unseemly about the haste with which the White House went to work. Indeed, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that a backroom deal was struck even before Chrysler made its formal request.

title: Dental Association Chief Named
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Dr. John M. Coady has been appointed executive director of the American Dental Association, the fifth chief executive in the association's 121year history. Dr. Coady, of Chicago, had served as acting executive director since last December following the resignation of Dr. C. Gordon Watson. The appointment was announced Thursday.

title: School Districts Aided by Sharing
description: THE 197980 school year is almost here, and it will be attended by more manifestations of the crisis confronting our schools. The chief question for educators, however, remains the same: how can the schools maintain strong instructional programs?

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Waves of Immigrants To the Carpet Mills

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: In his talk On Science Fiction, C. S. Lewis said: Many reviews are useless because, while purporting to condemn the book, they only reveal the reviewer's dislike of the kind to which it belongs. Let bad tragedies be censured by those who love tragedy, and bad detective stories by those who love the detective story.

title: Voting Booth: It Pays to Advertise
description: In a political campaign, how much does money talk? It certainly talks when there are candidates on the ballot, and even more so when the issue is the law.

title: Andrea Diehl Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Andrea Lull Diehl to Harry Jay Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Katz of Melrose Park, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. James G. M. Harper and Donald W. Diehl, both of Easton, Pa. An Oct. 7 wedding is planned.

title: What's Doingiin DELHI
description: TWIN CITIES  A drive around the (Id city of Delhi and its younger sister, New Delhi, is a visual pageant of India's long history. The massive Purana

title: Beth Ann Roberts, Teacher, Affianced to John Hanauer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norbert J. Roberts of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Ann Roberts, to John william Hanauer. son of EdnaJean Hanauer of Short Hills, N.J.

title: The Sheik Of Tennessee
description: DEER LODGE, Tenn  The folks in the Appalachian villages of Morgan County haven't had so much to talk about since James Earl Ray fled the state prison two years ago. Oil has been gushing from a hole on the property of the Russian immigrant who retired here after 40 years as a commercial painter in Detroit.

title: Army Relieves 48 in Investigation of Recruiting Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  The Army has undertaken a major investigation into allegations of fraud in its recruitment and already has relieved of duty 47 sergeants and a lieutenant colonel, an Army spokesman said today.

title: Army Relieves 48 Over Fraud
description: The Army has relieved 47 sergeants and a lieutenant colonel from duty in a wide investigation of recruiting fraud, a Pentagon spokesman said. Page 22.

title: Hospitals Agree on A Link
description: NEW HAVEN THE YaleNew Haven Hospital has entered into a contract with the Park City Hospital of Bridgeport to provide management services to the smaller, 200bed hospital in a move that officials of the two organizations say may help set a national pattern.

title: Fire Destroys 5 Stores in Bronx
description: A twoalarm fire that burned out of control for almost two hours destroyed a row of five stores in the Bronx yesterday, authorities said. Two firemen were treated at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for injuries suffered while battling the blaze. A Fire Department spokesman said the fire had heavily damaged a row of five stores at 33753395 Boston Road, in the Williamsbridge section of the borough.

title: Commuter Flights Seek to Fill Alleghany Role
description: WHEN Phillip Cronis, a Boston businessman, boarded a flight for Westchester the other day, his first encounter with a commuter airline was a surprise.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: The miracle of multiple births is that they're not a miracle anymore. Fertility drugs have made them a relative commonplace but the babies survival can not be so easily assured. In Naples, Italy, last week, octuplets were born to a woman who bore sextuplets only three years ago, in both cases while being treated with a fertility drug. All the sextuplets died but there was some hope that some of the octuplets would survive. So far, several have died and the remaining few have been distributed to intensive care units in four hospitals. Doctors were saying that of the five girls and three boys born to Pasqualina Anatrella Chianese, two might make it.

title: Regrouped L.I. Symphony to Settle in Long Beach
description: INSISTING that reports of its demise were highly exaggerated, the Long Island Symphony will formally announce on Tuesday that the orchestra is alive and well and now based in Long Beach.

title: James Chamberlain, Ann B. FitzSimons, Law Students, Wed
description: Ann Baxter FitzSimons and James Osborn Chamberlain, members of the class of 80 at the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday afternoon in Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Michael J. Dempsey performed the ceremony in Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church.

description: QUESTION: The death of Walter F. O'Malley, who engineered the shift of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants to the West Coast, brought back memories of Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds, the parks in which those two teams played. Who hit the last home run in each park and who drove in the last run in each before the Dodgers and Giants left New York City?

description: Special Committee Against Apartheid 10.30 A.M.

title: Ozark Air Lines and Union Reach Accord as Strike Deadline Nears
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (UPI)  A tentative contract agreement was reached today in 19 hours of negotiations between Ozark Air Lines and the International Association of Machinists, just hours before 1,700 workers were to eo on strike.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American MaizeProducts Company, a New Yorkbased cornproducts, tobacco and candy producer, has named Edward P. Norris corporate controller.

description: Peter D. Sternlight, 51 years old, has been named manager for domestic operations and Scott E. Pardee, 42, has been appointed manager for foreign operations of the Federal Open Market Committee, the key policymaking body within the Federal Reserve System.

title: Title to Miss Piatek
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19  Mary Lou Piatek of Whiting, Ind., won the first United States Tennis Association international championship for girls 18 years and under today by defeating Alycia Moulton of Carmichael, Calif., 67, 62, 64, in the final.

title: Tax Sought On Foreign Farm Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 A move is afoot in Congress to require foreign investors in American farm land to pay capitalgains taxes on their transactions.

description: WILLIAM H. TEHAN, a widely known monetary analyst, has been concerned about possible world deflation for five years. Last week he read in these pages that gold shares might neak soon and called to exoress disagreement.

title: Rabbi Joel Teitelbaum Dies at 92; Leader of the Satmar Hasidic Sect
description: Rabbi Joel Teitelbaum, the spiritual leader of the Satmar Hasidic sect, died of a heart attack yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Imports and Trucks Aid Dealers
description: The 19731974 oil embargo depressed automobile sales at Anthony Ursomarso's Pontiac dealership in Wilmington, Del., but it also impressed upon him the fact that the automobile industry was changing and that he had better change with it.

title: Yankees Play in Old Style And Conquer Twins by 43
description: A 43 victory over Minnesota yesterday on Lou Piniella's runscoring single delighted the Yankees, but it also gave them reason to dream about what might have been.

title: If You Dislike Lawyers, Read This
description: HOUSTON  Kingman Brewster remarked while president of Yale that the best minds of each generation go. into the law. He never did say what happened next.

title: ENVOY SUGGESTS U.S. PLAY CANCEL ITS PLAN ON THE PALESTINIANS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East envoy, said today that the United States would give serious consideration to dropping its proposal to sponsor a moderate resolution in the United Nations Security Council on Palestinian rights because of the lack of support he had found in Israel and Egypt for the intiative.

title: Petty Triumphs In Michigan 400
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Aug. 19 (AP)  Richard Petty overtook Buddy Baker on the last turn today and won the $161,830 Michigan 400 NASCAR race by half a car length.

title: Raiders Trounced By Patriots, 3514
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 19 (UPI) Matt Cavanaugh threw three touchdown passes in a span of 2 minutes 22 seconds in the fourth quarter as the New England Patriots posted a 3514 exhibition football victory today over the Oakland Raiders.

title: Speculating in the School Market
description: It's open season on public schools, what with education malpractice suits, competency tests for pupils and teachers and now the campaign in California for a constitutional amendment to grant school vouchers. If the amendment is adopted, parents could enroll their children in any Public. private or parochial school and use state vouchers to pay the tuition. One possible advantage is that competition would improve the public schools. It's an appealing theory. But surely it's too new an idea to freeze into the constitution of the nation's most populous state.

title: Miss Linehan Sets Swim Mark
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 19  Kim Linehan of Austin, Tex., swimming in 80degree temperature and 80percent humidity, broke the world record tonight for the women's 1,500meter freestyle.

title: Bridge:
description: The Old Guard was to the fore in the New York Swiss Team championship at the Skyline Motor Inn in Manhattan during the weekend.

title: Israeli Survivors of Raid Lunge at Arabs' Lawyer
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19  Survivors of an Arab terrorist massacre lunged at an Israeli lawyer defending two Palestinians charged with the killings in a military court today. The assailants were restrained by military police.

title: 3 in Kentucky Family Are Killed, 2 Held After Dispute and Gunfire
description: MANCHESTER, Ky., Aug. 19 (AP)A longsimmering family dispute in the southeastern Kentucky hills erupted yesterday in gunfire that left three persons dead, another hospitalized and two others in jail, the authorities reported.

description: Music

title: Medieval Pageantry and Skulduggery at the Pallo of Siena
description: SIENA, Italy, Aug. 17  The jockeys took bribes, and some of the horses were drugged. But the best jockey on the fastest horse won. The losers made money. The winner paid $60,000 or more in bribes and other agreements and received as the sole prize a painted statue of the Virgin Mary, to whom the race was dedicated.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Soviet Astronauts Return to Earth After Record of 175 Days in Space
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19  Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth today after orbiting the earth in a space station for a record total of 175 days.

title: Canadian Inflation Up
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Inflation in Canada rose eighttenths of 1 percentage point in July from the preceding month, mainly because of higher food prices and increased transportation costs, Statistics Canada has announced. On an annual basis, the inflation rate stood at 8.1 percent last month, compared with 8.9 percent in June.

title: Shorten the Energy Gauntlet
description: When President Carter asked Congress to create an Energy Mobilization Board to cut red tape on nonnuclear energy projects, the White House braced for attacks from environmentalists. Opposition has indeed come from the expected sources. Their case is unconvincing: the Board that the Administration proposes would not, contrary to their fears, be able to alter the substance of environmental safeguards. But now the proposed Board faces a more serious threat, from Congressmen loath to delegate authority to the President.

title: 75 Hospitals Violated Law on Care of Poor, State Says
description: A New York State health agency has charged that nearly half of 151 private hospitals in the state failed to meet their obligation last year to provide a reasonable amount of free and reducedcost care to the medically indigent and working poor.

title: Three Nigerian Parties Call Results of Vote a Fraud
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 19 (AP)  Officials of three of the four parties whose candidates lost in Nigeria's presidential election say that the results were fraudulent.

title: State Is Investigating An Investing Scheme Begun by Queens Man
description: The New York State Attorney General's office said yesterday that it was investigating complaints about an alleged scheme by a Queens man to defraud investors, enticed by exorbitant interest payments, of millions of dollars.

title: Books of The Times
description: RUSSIAN WRITERS AND SOVIET SOCIETY 19171978. By Ronald Hingley. 296 pages. Random House. $15.

title: Radical Grenada Symbolizes Political Shift in Caribbean
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Aug. 13 New signs at Pearl's Airport say in large, emphatic letters Support Your Revolution! But the soldiers are out of sight the hoteliers complained that they frightened visitors  and the exit is watched by a youth in a United States Army shirt.

description: RICHMOND, Aug. 19 (UPI) Martina Navratilova took one hour to defeat Kathy Jordan, 61, 63, today and capture the $100,000 Richmond tennis tournament.

title: Too Tall Jones Is Tackling A Tough New Challenge
description: ED (TOO TALL) JONES knows exactly what he is doing and why. He is learning a new trade six mornings a week at the Times Square Boxing Club on West 42d Street and then running eight miles in the afternoons in Central Park.

title: Mexico Will Limit Sale of Gas to U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) Initial sales of Mexican natural gas to the United States are likely to be much smaller than originally discussed if current negotiations resuit in a contract, the Foreign Ministry here said.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Oil Slick Mousse
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 19The big Gulf of Mexico oil spill, which entered its 12th week today, has produced some corresponding prodigies of nhotoeranhv and vocabulary.

title: Auto Output Off in Week
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19 (UPI)  United States auto production slipped to 74,535 units last week, and efforts by auto makers to balance inventories brought the first cutbacks in the assembly of 1980 models, according to an industry journal.

title: Airport Patrol: Wild Beasts, Diplomats and the Dreaded Call 34
description: It encompasses 5,000 acres, but most of that is scrub grassland crisscrossed by concrete runways, longeared jack rabbits and packs of oncecivilized family pets. Nobody lives at Kennedy International Airport except for survivors of damaged cargo shipments and their descendants.

title: Rizzoli Sets Retrospective Of Ruth Orkin's Photos
description: A major retrospective of photographs by Ruth Orkin will be shown at the Rizzoli Gallery, 712 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, from Sept. 8 to Oct. 10. Itwill be the first comprehensive exhibition of color and blackandwhite works by Miss Orkin, whose photographs have appeared in leading magazines and are in the permanent collections of many museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Notes on People
description: Anybody can love New York. But what about at 4 A.M., when even hardy souls walk the streets with one eye over their shoulders?

title: Cosmos Capture Series, 20
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 19  Everything seems to be going the Cosmos' way in the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: Suit Opens Against OPEC Fees
description: A highly unusual lawsuit that challenges the right of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to fix oil prices goes before the Federal District Court in Los Angeles today, with the oil industry, the Carter Administration and the legal community intensely interested in the outcome.

title: West Coast Ports Making Inroads
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19  With a little help from the nation's railroads and truckers, West Coast ports are making deep inroads into international trade, a business once dominated by Gulf and East Coast ports.

title: Carter Woos Crowds on Both Sides of River
description: PRAIRIE DU CHIEN, Wis., Aug. 19The rainswept Delta Queen steamed between the politically potent states of Iowa and Wisconsin today, and President Carter worked drenched crowds on both sides of the river for a day that bore all the trappings of an oldfashioned, whistlestop Presidential campaign.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The Knicks have taken a big step to become more colorful this coming season. No, they haven't hired Pete Maravich, the Dallas cheerleaders or the San Diego Chicken.

title: 1980 Election Could Bring Split in New York G. O. P.
description: ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 19 With the strong hand of Nelson A. Rockefeller gone, and that of Thomas E. Dewey gone before him, New York Republicans are for the first time in 35 years ripe to be divided and conquered in the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: 3 Rescued in Alaskan Wilderness 2 Days After Crash of Their Plane
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 19 (AP)  Two dog sled racers and a pilot have been rescued after spending two days in the Alaska wilderness following a plane crash.

title: J.G. Freund Weds Linda Sexton
description: Linda Gray Sexton and John Gordon Freund, who graduated cum laude in 1975 from Radcliffe and Harvard Colleges, respectively, and were editors of The Harvard Crimson, were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Sanford Seltzer performed the ceremony at Harvard University's Memorial Church.

title: Nantucket Gropes for Architectural Future
description: NANTUCKET, Mass. T is common to hear any new building on this tranquil island described as sticking out like a sore thumb. It is not that residents of Nantucket do not want to see new construction  on the contrary, many of them are pushing for a great deal of it. It is just that when new buildings are built, they would prefer that no one knew that the new structures had not been there for generations.

title: Poll Finds Carter Decline Ending
description: The steady decline of President Carter's strength against two potential Republican Presidential contenders appears to have ended, according to the latest Gallun Poll.

title: 3 Nigerian Parties Call Results of Election Fraudulent
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 19 (AP)  Officials of three of the four parties whose candidates lost in Nigeria's presidential election say that the results were fraudulent.

title: Alabama Editor Takes White House Press Job
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 19 (AP) Ray Jenkins, editor of The Montgomery Advertiser and Alabama Journal, will benamed No. 2 in the White House press office effective in September, it was disclosed today.

title: Music: The Young Mozart
description: FRIDAY night's Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall might well have been subtitled The Young Mozart  if any works by a composer who died shortly before his 36th birthday could be called early ones. At any rate, all the music on the program was written before Mozart reached the age of 25, and the performances were, appropriately enough, in the care of young musicians.

title: Smaller Is Sounder in the Bronx
description: Even before he resigned his office, Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo dissociated himself from the South Bronx planning effort when his Charlotte Street housine oroiect was reiected by the Board of Estimate. But the planner he chose, Edward Logue, has now published an interim report that outlines a new approach. It is less sweeping than the plan that started with Charlotte Street. It also appears much sounder.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: After last week's rapidfire series of interestrate increases, market analysts believe that even higher rates are in store as the Federal Reserve Board orchestrates the nation's battle against inflation and the rapid growth of the money supply.

title: Derailed Freight Routs Families
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (UPI) Twenty families were evacuated today in the Kensington section of Philadelphia after a Conrail freight car carrying acetone derailed, causing a minor leak into the street. Firefighters neutralized the flammable paint remover with a chemical foam and sand, the police said. The car, one of 20, jumped the track and fell on its side about 5:20 P.M., a Conrail spokesman said. He did not know the cause of the accident.

title: Mine Kills 4 South Africans
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 19 (AP)  A landmine explosion near the Angolan border in SouthWest Africa yesterday killed four South African soldiers, Government officials reported today.

title: Mets Lose to Reds Third Time by a Run
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 19  The undermanned New York Mets lost to the Cincinnati Reds today, 65, marking the third time in the threegame series that they had dropped a onerun decision.

title: No Title
description: Barbara Ann Cooperman Wed

title: LotteryTicket Holder Loses Gamble to Police
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Aug. 19 (UPI) Having 200 state lottery tickets in his possession brought bad luck today to John Picciano. The police said the tickets had been stolen.

title: Notre Dame Fragments To Be Shown at the Met
description: Recently unearthed fragments of great medieval statuary that once adorned Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris but which were beheaded by mistake during the French Revolution. will be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Sept. 6 through Nov. 25.

title: Paul Newman Takes 2 Division Races
description: SUMMIT POINT, W. Va., Aug. 19 (AP)  Paul Newman led wire to wire today in two division races of a Sports Car Club of America event at the Summit Point Raceway.

title: New Scout Program Helping Poor Young People Find fobs
description: There was a time when Sherry Ann Swinnie thought her life had come to a standstill  that she was boxed in a room with four walls and no door and that there would be no moving forward.

title: Seminar on Shaker Life To Supplement Exhibition
description: A seminar on Shaker life in America will be held on Sept. 1415 at the Sotheby Parke Bernet lecture hall, 980 Madison Avenue, as a supplement to an exhibition on the Shakers in New York State scheduled at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street, from Sept.13 to Nov. 21.

title: NUTRITION IS CALLED MAJOR HANOI WORRY
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 17  A whole generation will bear the stigmata all their lives, said Dr. Ton That Tung, Vietnam's most renowned physician. The Vietnamese people do not have enough to eat.

title: McEnroe Triumphs
description: TORONTO, Aug. 19 (UPI)  John McEnroe set up his sixth career showdown with Bjorn Borg, the fourtime Wimbledon champion, by defeating Vitas Gerulaitus, 63, 63, today in the semifinals of the $210,000 Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Adversity Forges Unity Among Rebel Nicaraguan Leaders
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 18 month after rebel troops marched into the Nicaraguan capital, it appears that the country's devastation and economic strife are forging the revolutionary Government into a united oreanization.

title: Advertising
description: THE Chrysler Corporation's announcement on Friday that would offer a $400 rebate on the purchase of the company's 1979 cars and trucks is being backed by a $10 million advertising campaign that was put together in about 10 days.

title: Car Ind 4 Sale. Orig Own.
description: WASHINGTON  Signs of gloom are all around the automobile industry.

title: Lawyer Assails $1.3 Million Bond Imposed in Killing of F.B.I. Agent
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (UPI)  An attorney for Melvin Bay Guyon, who is accused of killing an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Cleveland, today criticized the $1.3 million bond set for Mr. Guyon. He also said his client might plead not guilty to the charges on the basis of selfdefense.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Mary J. Werthman Is Married to Paul Rand
description: Mary Joan Werthman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Werthman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul David Rand, son of Mrs. Bernadene Rand Goldfeld of Greenwich, Conn., and Paul David Rand of Stamford, Conn.

title: DISPUTE OVER COURT INTENSIFIES ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19  An investigation into allegations that political considerations have influenced the California Supreme Court has turned into test of strength between at least two of the justices and the Commission on Huai cial Performance, the state agency assigned to make the investigation.

title: McDonald's Cuts Hamburger Price
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP)  The McDonald's Corporation announced today that it would cut the prices of hamburgers and cheeseburgers by a nickel, effective Tuesday, in what company officials described as an effort to help young families fight inflation. The price of a hamburger will be cut from 43 cents to 38 cents, while the price of a cheeseburger will drop from 48 cents to 43 cents.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Three music ensembles will perform at the Lake Placid Olympics this winter as part of the arts program required to accompany the sports events. They are the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Gerard Schwarz; the Cantilena Chamber Players, a New York group headed by the violinist Edna Michel, and the Jazzmobile, another New York organization. They will appear in various sites, including the Center for Music and Drama in Lake Placid and the Agora Theater.

title: Furry Friends and Balloons in a Breeze as Fantasies Fly on Summer Sunday
description: With favored stuffed animal at hand and balloons flying in a breeze that cooled an otherwise warm day, a group of childen found yesterday to be a perfect day for an outing in Central Park. Tempertures in the metropolitan region reached the middle 80's under partly sunny skies. Warm temperatures and partly sunny skies are expected today.

title: De Gustibus A WellLoved Herb
description: It would never in a thousand years have occurred to me that lovage, an herb for which I have had little use in my kitchen and have never grown in my herb garden. would have had so many champions. But there are, judging from the response to a Q&A column of July 25. Tom Stobart, the authority on herbs and the author of Herbs, Spices and Flavorings (International Wine and Food Publishing Company, 1970 and 1977), whom I quoted in that column, called its flavor difficult to describe and averred that its commonest use is in soups. Not so, said quite a few readers.

title: Sports Briefs
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 19 (AP)  Mike Ormsby polevaulted 15 feet and Lou Calvano outran a field of 137 in the marathon to win gold medals today in the finale of the Empire State Games.

title: Beard Oil in Talks
description: The Beard Oil Company of Oklahoma City, an exploration concern, said that the Mesa Petroleum Company, a production and exploration company of Amarillo, Tex., had indicated interest in acquiring Beard Oil and that preliminary discussions were to over the weekend. No terms were disclosed.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Medical Identification Holder

title: Lower Bond Rating Troubles Lilco
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, the last of the major New York State investorowned utilities to retain a highgrade bond rating from Moody's Investors Services, last week lost that rating on its publicly held first mortgage bonds.

title: Jersey's Elderly Say Casino Tax, Pledged to Them, Is of Little Aid
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 15  Elderly New Jerseyans on fixed incomes, hardpressed by inflation, are gravely disappointed by what they regard as the meager benefits they have received thus far from the state tax on casinos.

title: New York Opening 34 Experimental Taxi Stations
description: In an experimental move against the Manhattan taxi tradition of unlimited cruising, a new network of 34 marked taxi stations will dot a 10blocklong section of midtown between Third and Fifth Avenues beginning Thursday.

title: Renner's Birdie on 18th Wins
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 19  Jack Renner, a dedicated golf professional who has wanted to win a tournament since he was 3 years old, got his wish today.

title: 2 Rob Inwood Store During Pickup by Armored Truck
description: Two armed men invaded a crowded supermarket in upper Manhattan yesterday morning as an armored truck was making a pickup and made off with $58,555.

title: Violence Grows in Combat Zone Along U.S. Border Near Tijuana
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Aug. 16 Scarcely a night goes by that the beleaguered agents of the United States Border Patrol do not encounter gunfire or barrages of stones from across the rickety chainlink fence that divides this hamlet from the bustling border city of Tijuana, Mexico.

title: Floral Laments Mark Neighbors' Grief for Slain Jeweler
description: Friends and neighbors of Abraham Rappaport, a jeweler who was slain in his store at 340 West 57th Street during a robbery attempt on Thursday, fastened flowers and notes in his memory to the gate in front of the store yesterday. A funeral service attended by about 500 people was held during the afternoon for the 82yearold victim. Page B5.

title: Vanessa Redgrave Says She Won't Quit TV Role
description: Denying that she was antiSemitic, Vanessa Redgrave said yesterday that she would not give up her television role as a Nazi concentration camp survivor despite the real survivor's protests.

title: The City
description: About 120 cheering children left yesterday for a 10day vacation at summer camp paid for by donations collected on Harlem streets.

title: Political Test in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18  A political crisis appears to be in the making in South Korea, where a court next week will hear a lawsuit that could unseat Kim Young Sam as head of the leading

title: Fell Wins 5th Stakes Of Saratoga Meeting
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 19  Jeff Fell continued his stakeswinning touch today by riding favored Pearl Necklace to victory in the $58,350 Diana Handicap for fillies and mares.

title: Real Estate Boom Again Grips Florida
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18  With homeheating costs soaring in the North, people are lining up to pay high prices for homes in Florida.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOWN WITH GLOOM As comedians and musical satirists, Ellen Mandel and Michael Lydon have drawn a lot of favorable mention for their sprightly performing in clubs during the last six years, first in California and more recently on the night scene in New York, where the humorists now live. The pair spoof everything from celebrity endorsements of products to the perils of show business. They also sing and play the piano, guitar and chromatic harmonica.

title: SALLY D. BALDWIN
description: Sally D. Baldwin, a member of the corporation and of the visiting committee of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, died in that hospital Friday after a long illness. She was 66 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill and Marblehead, Mass.

title: Connors Trounces Cahill by 60, 61
description: STOWE, Vt., Aug. 19 (AP)  After a rain delay of two hours, Jimmy Connors took only 40 minutes to overwhelm Mike Cahill by 60, 61 today and win the $75,000 Volvo Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Outdoors: Challenging the Bluefish Is Half the Fun
description: NOMAN'S LAND ISLAND, Mass.

title: Primitive Tribes in Indian Islands Face Extinction in 2 Generations
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 19 (AP) Primitive tribes in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, an Indian territory in the Bay of Bengal, face a threat of extinction in two generations because of an unknown fertility problem among their women, a Government study has warned.

title: World News Briefs
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 19 (Reuters)  Pope John Paul II said today that he would do everything possible to achieve closer links and perhaps a meeting with China's Roman Catholics.

title: Facing Up to Retirement: More Companies Help Ease the Way
description: Hank retired at age 65 from the brokerage house where he had long worked. Only then did he realize that all his friends were the people he was used to working with. On his own, he spent day after endless day sitting by himself in his room or feeding the pigeons alone in Central Park.

title: Financing Picks Up
description: The pace of financing activity will pick up somewhat this week in the corporate calendar with the offering of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company's $300 million debenture issue. It is the largest financing ever for this subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: He Fears Needless Bloodshed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Andrew Young today characterized as kind of foolish the United States policy of shunning contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization and implied that it could cause unnecessary bloodshed in the Middle East and economic hardship in this country.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Yellow Pages: A Split Personality
description: The Manhattan Yellow Pages, the fat, informationrich advertising guide, is being given a trimmer look, and advertisers are not altogether pleased.

title: Baseball's Grand Old Man
description: LATE in a baseball season dominated by bare bottoms and bared souls  i.e., the young lady on the Yankees bus; Reggie Jackson's psyche attention has been commanded at last by the surprising performance of the Minnesota Twins. In the twoyearold era of the free agent, 15 players have walked away from Calvin Griffith's underpaid organization, and some of them were among the best in the American League  Larry Hisle, Lyman Bostock, Bill Campbell, Eric Soderholm. Yet after losing half a team and trading away another half named Rod Carew, the nameless, shapeless numbers and silhouettes commanded by Gene Mauch have been and still are contenders for the championship of the American League West. When they shaped up yesterday for the final game of a series in Yankee Stadium, they were three games behind California's pace, only two back in the gameslost column.

title: Washington Watch
description: MAIL to Congress, aides report, is running against a Federal bailout of Chrysler. Administration officials say they are wait

title: Miss Little Gains Lead On 69137
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., Aug. 19 (AP) Sally Little shot a threeunderpar 69 today and took a onestroke lead over Amy Alcott and Dot Germain after the second round of the $100,000 Barth Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: L.I.R.R. 's Plans Spur Challenge To State Bonds
description: The question of extended electrification of the Long Island Rail Road has become an issue in the campaign for the state's $500million transportation bond issue, with two State Senators saying they will fight it unless there is a commitment to spend some of the money to electrify the railroad in their areas, which are served by diesel locomotives.

title: Commodities
description: TRADERS of copper futures have long been inured to illogical market behavior. But last week's price moves on New York's Commodity Exchange left many of them, particularly those holding short positions, even more perplexed than usual.

title: Saad Jumaa, Was Jordan Premier And Ambassador to Washington
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Saad Jumaa, a former Prime Minister of Jordan, died early today in a London hospital, a Jordanian Embassy spokesman said. He was 63 years old.

title: Blacks Promoting Music Charge Widespread Bias
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19  In the arcane backstage world of music promotion, it seems almost a tradition. On stage, the singer or musician is black. The audience is black. But the promoter is nearly always white.

title: I.B.M. Facsimile System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced that scientists of its Research Division had developed an experimental method representing an improvement in the facsimile machines widely used in business for telephone and satellite transmission of typewritten and printed materials. It said the system transmits a page of material in one minute, compared with transmission times of three to six minutes for analog machines.

title: Senator Byrd Is Fit as a Fiddler at Fair
description: LEWISBURG, W. Va., Aug. 19  He stood alone in the small, underground cementblock room, his green cigar lying on the edge of a galvanized steel bin made for icing down soft drinks, his Frenchmade violin squeezed between his chin and the shoulder of his blue and white seersucker suit. His tie was pulled up snugly.

title: Mets Sell Twitchell
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 19  The Mets sold Wayne Twitchell, one of only two pitchers on the team with a wonlost record above .500, to the Seattle Mariners tonight.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 (Reuters)  The Xerox Corporation and the Itel Corporation have announced an agreement in principle for Xerox to acquire Itel's Autex operation for about $22 million.
