description: Q.I have a Formica counter top that is gray and I would like to change the color. Can I glue a new piece of Formica on top of the old one, or is there a paint that I can apply to change the color?  J.K.L., Highland Park, Ill.

title: An Early Exit for Smith As CocaCola's President
description: J. Lucien Smith, 60 years old, has taken early retirement as president of the CocaCola Company, effective immediately, according to a curt, threeparagraph announcement released yesterday by the world's largest softdrink corporation. Mr. Smith was not in his office and a Coke spokesman said that he had declined to be interviewed.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS Southern District Wednesday, Aug. 22,1979.

title: Police Hold Man They Say Admits Pushing Girl Before Subway Train
description: The police said yesterday that a 26yearold mail clerk with a record of arrests for sexual offenses had admitted that he pushed Renee Katz off a subway platform last June, causing her right hand to be severed by an oncoming train.

title: Cabaret: D'Jamin Bartlett
description: D'JAMIN BARTLETT, who won considerable attention singing the gamey The Miller's Son in A Little Night Music, is, in her own person, delicate of feature and a reddish blonde, a pretty woman with a pretty voice.

title: MONDALE OFFERING HIGHER TRANSIT AID
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 22  Vice President Mondale told a sweltering crowd of New York and New Jersey officials today that if the windfall profits tax on oil passes, President Carter plans to add $3 billion to the Federal aid already promised for local mass transit systems.

title: Turkish Consulate Is Bombed
description: GENEVA, Aug. 22 (UPI)  A bomb was thrown outside the Turkish Consulate today, slightly injuring the driver of a passing car and two pedestrians but causing little damage. The Swiss police and Turkish officials said the bomb was thrown just after the Turkish vice consul had driven away.

title: Conrail Riders Delayed By Power Interruption
description: A 40minute power interruption on Conrail's New Haven division yesterday delayed 8,000 commuters heading for Manhattan during the morning rush hour.

title: Letters; A Wealth of Energy in America's Coal Mines; JAMES A. RHODES; Governor of Ohio Columbus, Aug. 13,1979; 'so Why Bother To Be Nice?
description: To the Editor: Energy is at the root of our major national problems. The negative balance of payMents in our foreign trade accounts, caused by oil purchases, is a major cause of inflation. The instability of the dollar is related to our dependence on OPEC. Energy costs are an influence on domestic unemployment. Perhaps most seriously, our nation is for the first time in history at the mercy of foreign governments, which can cut off half of our oil supply at will.

title: Home Beat
description: MOST young architects just talk about it; these two actually did it. Not only did they set up their own operation, ignoring the rule of thumb, Don't go out your own until your outside work exceeds your salary, they also went into the real estate business. They had known each other as students at the University of Pennsylvania. Six years later, Peter Shelton, far left, was at Edward Durell Stone Associates and Lee Mindel was at Skidmore Owings & Merrill after having earned a master's degree in architecture at Harvard University. They met by chance on a department store escalator and in 1978 opened their own office. The fee for their first job was only $3,000, so the partners ventured into real estate development, becoming the owners, designers and general contractors. It was an experiment, said the 28yearold Mr. Mindel, about the 2,200squarefoot space on upper Broadway that they renovated. The twobedroom space shown above has a glass block wall, a double shower, 110 feet of windows on three sides and 60 feet of storage. We wanted to see if there was a market for highquality customized construction, Mr. Shelton, 32, said. Meanwhile, the two entrepreneurs are developing a fiveacre shopping center near Princeton and designing the 45,000squarefoot Bond's disco near Times Square.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHAT does Roger Sale mean by the provocative title of this selection of his criticism, On Not Being Good Enough, which, according to his In troduction, he was fond enough of to steal from a speech he once gave that is not included in this volume? He means it to refer to a number of things among them, the tendency of so much of what a working book critic reads and reviews not to live up to the ideals he sets up for it, as well as the fate of novelists who write books that are good enough to last, at least in Professor Sale's opinion, but not good enough to keep their authors in the forefront of the public's awareness.

title: Sale of Dollars Rises Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Foreign official assets invested in the United States fell by $10.1 billion during the second quarter, mainly because of continued sales of United States dollars on currency markets, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Associated Press
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22  In a rare action, the United Automobile Workers union said that nearly a million workers across the nation stopped work today for as long as six minutes in a protest against the Government's handling of energy problems.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW NIBBLES Serious Bizness is the label of four young satirists who have been winning acclaim on the night scene for several seasons. Their material centers on characters and situations, although one of their vignettes was a musical version of The Cherry Orchard called Pits.

title: U.S.O.C. Is Critical
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 22 (AP) Coach Bobby Knight's conviction for striking a policeman during the Pan American Games in Puerto Rico was blatant, outrageous and unwarranted, according to the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Coast Superior Court Sentences ExConvict to Death for Murder
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (UPI)  A 23yearold former convict was formally sentenced to die in the gas chamber yesterday for the 1978 murder of a University of Southern California librarian.

title: Textile Import Volume Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) United States imports of textiles from Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea  the world's four major suppliers  fell by 27 percent in the first half of this year compared with the first half of 1978, the Government said today_

title: Thai Project to Japanese
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 22 (UPI)  C. Itoh & Company, a Japanese concern, has won a $750 million contract to build the world's largest floating power plant for Thailand, company spokes.. men said today. The Japanese Government's Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund will finance the project, which involves building and installing power station and barge, three substations, 200 kilometers of transmission lines and supply barges, the spokesmen said.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE Compact Folding Racks
description: FOR people with limited storage space, there are two useful racks that fold almost flat to the wall when not in use and can be opened when needed. Both are manufactured in Europe by Leifheit International. One is Telegant, a drying rack with four retractable plasticcoated lines on sliding steel rails. This rack can be mounted in a bathroom or laundry room for wet clothes or it can be used in the kitchen for dish towels, or for drying pasta, herbs or flowers. When it is closed, Telegant is a discreet white plastic rectangle, 2 inches deep and 28 inches long. The front of this rectangle is actually two arms, which open at the press of a button, allowing the drying lines to be pulled out. Its compact design also makes Telegant useful for boats, cabins and campers. It is easily installed and the two screws needed come with the rack. Telegant is available at Ad Hoc Housewares, 842 Lexington Avenue, and the Linen Pavillion at Saks Fifth Avenue. It costs $27 and comes in white only. Leifheit also makes a plastic necktie rack with three swingout rails. It holds 30 ties and has a builtin holder for cuff links and studs. Ridges along the arms hold ties in place and when the rack is closed, it makes a neat storage unit. The tie rack comes in beige or brown and costs $7.50 at Home Base, 2335 Broadway.

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART: CHAMBER MUSIC, Avery Fisher Hall, 8; preconcert recital, 7.

title: Downstream in the Middle East
description: Is there an American Middle East policy, and if so, who is shaping it? Not since the gaudier years Franklin Roosevelt has so much confusion over authority been so visible in Washington.

title: Midtown Shriners Parade Turns Into TrafficStopper
description: Clad in colorful garb, marching in disciplined units or astride prancing horses, the Ancient Egyptian Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, North and South America, World Jurisdiction Inc., Prince Hall Affiliated  in other words, the Shriners  paraded through midtown Manhattan yesterday.

title: Board Holds Up Action On Nixon's Apartment
description: The fivemember board of managers of the Fifth Avenue condominium building at 817 Fifth Avenue, where Richard M. Nixon has agreed to purchase a 12room apartment, withheld a vote yesterday that was expected to approve the sale.

title: About Long Island
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 21  It almost too bucolic, too soothing to make sense to the visitor from the city itself, where fortune and poverty furnish the streets where they live. But out here in Nassau, the open spaces deceive you and the summer skyblue and grassgreen create an impression of indolent ease that suppresses concern about major issues.

title: G.I. Deaths in Hiroshima Are Documented
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20 When the atomic fireball bloomed over Hiroshima one August morning 34 years ago, it is now apparent, despite the long silence of the United States Government, a dozen or more American prisoners of war were among the first victims of the Atomic Age.

title: Boy, 11, Accidentally Kills Sister
description: HEMET, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)An 11yearold boy shot and killed a younger sister with a gun he had added to the plastic toy pistols with which the children were playing. Police investigators said that Benjamin Moreno was playing cowboys and Indians Monday when he shot his 10yearold sister, Magdalena, in the head. The police said he had found the 22caliber revolver on a closet shelf in his parents bedroom.

title: Associated Press.
description: OVER AND OUT: Duane Kuiper of the Cleveland Indians leaping over Angels Rod Carew after force at second in the ninth inning yesterday at Anaheim, Calif. Kuiper's throw first was not in time for double play. Indians won, 133.

title: Weapon Sought in Upstate Killing of Museum Official
description: DEPOSIT, N.Y., Aug. 22  Detectives from Troop C, New York State Police, crawled through the muck of forest ponds and tramped through rattlesnakeinfested underbrush near here today, looking for a murder weapon in a case that is testing their investigative skills.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold prices soared to record levels yesterday on both sides of the Atlantic, touching off maximum allowable advances in silver and platinum. But cautious brokers noted that the copper, grain and soybean futures markets fell back under heavy selling pressure all day.

title: Kuwait Raises Gas Price 18.6%
description: BAHRAIN, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Kuwait has raised the average export price of its liquefied gas by 18.6 percent, from $170 to $201.66 a ton, the Gulf News Agency reported from Kuwait today.

title: Census Study Finds City Losing Legislative Seats
description: If current population trends hold up through the 1980 census, New York City will lose three or four seats in the State Assembly and could have its strength in the State Senate diluted, according to an analysis conducted by a state legislative panel.

title: Oil Line at West Coast Is Urged by Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger recommended today the approval of the proposed Northern Tier pipeline project to carry Alaska oil inland from a tanker port on the West Coast.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)  Usually unreceptive to Hollywood extravaganzas, the Soviet press nevertheless gave a thumbsup verdict today to Francis Coppola's Vietnam War epic, Apocalypse Now, which will make its debut here this week, but not in competition, at the Moscow Film Festival.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk. of Payrkd Rate record able

title: Petitions Demand Vote by Public On Pay Raises Given City Aides
description: An effort to force a public vote on the pay raises that New York City officials have voted for themselves has passed the 50,000signature mark, according to its sponsors, the publisher of a weekly newspaper and an unusual coalition of peopleaboutpolitics.

title: Stocks Hold Steady On Strong Turnover
description: The stock market closed practically unchanged yesterday in heavy trading, with some of the specialsituation issues posting the best gains.last Friday and tell 5% to 59%. The stock had not traded since Exxon announced it would wait for resolution of a Federal Trade Commission suit before deciding whether to acquire Reliance shares already tendered. Last week, the F.T.C. issued an administrative complaint against Exxon's proposed takeover of Reliance.

title: Hadassah Convention Projects 1980's Plans For More Aid to Israel
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP)  Leaders of the Women's Zionist Organization of America said today that the group was moving into the 1980's with a larger membership and planned to do more for Israel. The group's 65th annual convention ended today.

title: Gold Hits A Record Of $311.50
description: BONN, Aug. 22  The price of gold soared by $11 on European markets today, hitting a record $311.50 a troy ounce during the day before easing somewhat at the close.

title: Art: Patrick Henry Bruce, American Modernist
description: PATRICK HENRY BRUCE: American Modernist, at the Museum of Modern Art through Oct. 10, is a remarkable achievement. The joint work of William C. Agee, director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, and Barbara Rose, the critic, it recreates as far as is now possible the life and work of an American painter whose contribution to the modern movement has never before been made clear. Isolated paintings by Bruce make an impact wherever they are shown, and he looked very well in the ParisNew York exhibition in Paris two summers ago. But as to what manner of man he was, and what became of his work as a whole, no one quite knew.

title: DumpingSuit Shift Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)  A laborindustry coalition is appealing a decision that would send to the United States Customs Court its suit aimed at collecting required fees from importers of Japanese color television sets allegedly dumped on the American market.

title: Somoza Blames Carter for Fall, Sees Latin Communism Gaining
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 22 (UPI)  Former President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua today blamed President Carter for his overthrow and said Communist domination in Latin America will soon extend right up to the border of the United States.

title: 2 Agencies Offer Steps To Deregulate Industries
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Two independent Federal regulatory agencies have proposed modest steps intended to deregulate the industries they supervise.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL TOLD OF EARLY WARNINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  The President's commission studying the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant heard testimony today about three early warnings that if acted upon by the Government might have prevented the accident.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: AUDIT CLEARS F.B.I. ON INFORMANTS USE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in a threeweek internal audit of its oftcriticized program for using informants, has found that with few exceptions its rules and guidelines are being followed.

title: Tellers Are Stoical About the Dangers
description: Well, what can you do?  I';ve been through holdups, but in this job the possibility is just something you live with, Ken Tiffany, a Manhattan bank teller, said with a shrug yesterday behind his open, orangeandwoodtoned counter, which was not much above chest level.

title: PRESIDENT OF INDIA SETS FALL ELECTION
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22 President Sanjiva Reddy today ordered that national elections be held in three months and dissolved the fractious lower house of Parliament.

title: U.S. PROPOSES SHIFT OF 3 POWER PLANTS IN THE CITY TO COAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  In the first initiative of its kind, the Federal Department of Energy today proposed requiring three power plants in New York City to burn coal instead of oil.

title: Hearst Raises Stake In Southwest Forest
description: The Hearst Corporation, a newspaper and magazine publishing concern, said that it holds 637,598 shares, or 8.4 percent, of the common shares outstanding of Southwest Forest Industries, a producer of newsprint and other forest products.

title: 600 U.S. and Canadian Homes to Test EnergySaving
description: WASHINGTON IT'S a typical evening in a typical household. Father has plugged in his selfpropelled swizzle stick and is stirring highball. Mother has switched, on her automatic eyebrow pluckers and is giving her forehead a Greta Garbo arch. In the playroom, little Lobelia is operating her electricpowered bubble gum inflator.

title: Richard L. Newburger, a Broker In Philadelphia Investment Firms
description: Richard L. Newburger, an investment broker who was a member of the Philadelphia financial community for 45 years, died yesterday at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia after brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Huntingdon Valley, Pa.

title: Iranians Sued Over Oil Rig
description: An Oklahomabased oil exploration company filed a $62 million suit yesterday against the National Iranian Oil Company contending that the Governmentowned concern had unlawfully confiscated its mobile offshore oil rig.

title: Tim Kantor
description: James T. Farrell, whose three Studs Lonigan novels made him a dominant figure among realistic writers of the 1930's, died of a heart attack yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 75 years old.

title: PAULINE TYLER KAUFMAN
description: Pauline Tyler Kaufman died Tuesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: 10 City Agencies Seek To Speed Up Payment On Bills to Suppliers
description: In an effort to eliminate persistent complaints that New York City does not pay its bills promptly, 10 municipal agencies are engaged in a pilot program to speed bill payments to vendors doing business with the city.

title: Around the Nation
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 22 (UPI) A Delaware Superior Court judge decided today to continue the armed robbery trial of the Rev. Bernard T. Pagano, even though another man has admitted involvement in the robberies. The judge refused to say whether he would dismiss the charges when the trial resumes tomorrow.

title: Knight Is Convicted, Given 6Month Term
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 22 (AP) Bobby Knight, Indiana University's basketball coach, was found guilty today of assaulting a Puerto Rican policeman during last month's Pan American Games. He was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $500.

title: Teetering Near Divorce
description: My husband and I are going to be divorced. At least I expect we are.

title: VW Profit Up 13.2% In Half
description: BONN, Aug. 22  Volkswagenwerk A.G. reported today that its net profit in the first six months of this year rose 13.2 percent on a sales gain of 10.6 percent.

title: Lawyer Is Found Dead in Boat
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP)  A Santa Barbara lawyer was found shot to death in his boat hours after he radioed the Coast Guard to say that he had,.been kidnapped and was being tortured aboard his 41foot yacht, sheriff's deputies said today. The authorities were conducting an investigation into the death of James J. Oppen, 58 years old. Mr. Oppen was perhaps best known for a lawsuit he filed on behalf of commercial fishermen after the large Santa Barbara oil spill in 1969.

title: Weather Cited in Oil Drop in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 (AP) Exports of crude oil from Iran have dipped below one million barrels a day because of bad weather conditions for several days at loading areas at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf, a source in the National Iranian Oil Company said today.

title: Cooney Stops Mason In 4th at Felt Forum
description: Gerry Cooney, a 225pound heavyweight who has been trying to gain recognition in the ranks, knocked out Broderick Mason at 1:44 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10round bout last night in the Felt Forum.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW type of pipe insulation that can be installed on hot or coldwater pipes is now available with a zipperlike closure. Made of cellular polyethylene and marketed by the Frelen Corporation, 991 Dutton Street, Lowell, Mass. 01852, Prelen Pipe Insulation comes in sizes to fit most residential water pipes, from onehalfinch copper or threeeighthsinch iron, up to oneinch copper or threequartersinch iron pipe.

title: Typhoon Lashes Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Thunder storms and torrential rain caused by Ty. phoon Judy lashed western and central Japan today, killing one person. At least six persons were reported missing.

title: Farmers in State Report Losses
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 22 (UPI) A state survey shows that some farmers lost business because consumers feared cancercausing radiation in foodstuffs as a result of the Three Mile Island nuclear accident.

title: U.S. Calls Raid Unfortunate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) The United 'states said that today's raid by Zimbabwe Rhodesia planes northeast of Lusaka was especially unfortunate in view of next month's conference in London on Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: Is U.S. Share Understated?
description: When the oil companies prompted headlines and wide criticism with their sharply higher secondquarter profits, the big companies seemed at pains to attribute the startling gains to operations abroad. The fat profits did not come out of the American consumer's pocket, or so the implication ran.

title: Furniture Fixers: Soft Pens to Hot Irons
description: WINGATE, N.C. FELTTIP pens, crayons and an iron come in handy for repairing minor damage to some furniture, according to J. Ben Helms, a furniture and decorative accessories executive. Because hardwood is increasingly scarce, such softwoods as country pine are more widely used for Yurniture crafting and decorative accessories, Mr. Helms says. They are more easily damaged than hardwood.

title: Chiola Hanover Is Favorite In $275,000 Yonkers Trot
description: Chiola Hanover, the colt owned by Allan and Mickey Chasnoff, yesterday drew the outside post for the $275,000 Yonkers Trot on Saturday. Jimmy Allen will be the driver.

title: Armco Plans Expansion
description: Armco Inc., a producer of steel products and oil and mining equipment, announced yesterday that it would invest $7 million in an oilfield equipment factory to be built near Londonderry, Northern Ireland. The plant, which will employ about 500 persons, will operate as part of the American company's British subsidiary, the National Supply Company U.K., Ltd.

title: Bausch & Lomb Backs Stock Split
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., the optics and scientificinstruments manufacturer, announced that its board had approved a 2for1 split of the company's common stock, of which there are about 5.7 million shares outstanding.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 22 (AP)  A New York state senator says he has asked the Japanese Government to help rebuild the devastated South Bronx.

title: Market Place
description: WALL STREET, which has thrived on mergers for months, doesn't like to see a deal die - and neither, it appears, do some disappointed suitors.

title: Fluor Units Given South Korean Jobs
description: The Fluor Corporation, an energy, engineering and chemical concern, said that several of its subsidiaries had been selected to participate in a $90 million project to increase capacity of an oil refinery in South Korea.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (AP)  Hugh J. Addonizio, the former Newark Mayor, will be returned to Federal prison to continue serving a 10year term for extortion, a United States Parole Commission aide said yesterday. Mr. Addonizio's reporting date will not be set until after a court hearing Monday.

title: Socialist Workers Party Selects Candidate for Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)  The Socialist Workers Party, a small Trotskyist political organization, today named Andrew Pulley, a 28yearold Chicago steelworker, as its Presidential candidate.

title: The New York Times/Jim Cummins
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 22  Chris Evert Lloyd overcame a lapse in concentration in the second set to gain a 64, 67, 62 victory tonight over Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia before 3,126 fans in the second round of the $75,000 Volvo Cup women's tennis tournament at Ramapo College.

title: Julia Waller, 69, ExWAC Officer And Volunteer Hospital Worker
description: Julia H. Waller, a former captain in the Women's Army Corps and an active hospital volunteer, died Monday at her home in New York City. She was 69 years old.

title: STATE DEPT. DEFENDS INTELLIGENCE SETUP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  Caught in the crossfire of conflicting statements about when the Carter Administration first learned of Andrew Young's meeting with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the State Department's intelligence collection and distribution system has emerged in recent days as a key factor in the events leading up to Mr. Young's resignation.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets reacted positively late yesterday to the announcement of a 5 percent plunge in durablegoods orders during July.

title: Cabaret: Merle Travis
description: IF there had been no Merle Travis, there would have been no Travis picking, and if there had been no Travis picking, an entire generation of country, rockabilly and early rockandroll guitarists would have been deprived of its most important influence.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata for 2 Violins and Continuo in E minor, Dandrift; Scipio, Overture, Handel; Scenes historiques, All Overtura, Sibelius; Iberia, Navarra, Albaniz; Violin Concerto No. 2.

title: Text of Draft Resolution in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 Following is the text of the draft resolution approved yesterday by the General Assembly Committee on the Exercise of the Inalienable Rights of the Palestinian People. The resolution is expected to be offered for debate by the Security Council tomorrow.

title: 41 Finalists Exhibit Stained Glass Work
description: GEORGE SELL, a painter and sculptor, said he wasn't certain why he had awkwardly lugged a cow's skull back to his New York City studio after a vacation upstate, but he had known that one day it would provide inspiration.

title: McGuire Placing Plainclothesmen In Certain Banks
description: Police Commissioner Robert I. McGuire ordered additional police measures yesterday to halt the rising tide of bank robberies in New York City, including the identification of all robbery prone and vulnerable banks.

title: MATTIE H. BOWE
description: Mattie H. Bowe, a leader of the Women's Auxiliary of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan, after a brief illness. She was 88 years old.

title: Bankers Trust Sets Unit Sales
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell 19 New York City branches to the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Republic National Bank of New York.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Moody's Current

title: U.S. Accused on OPEC
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (AP)  The United States Government agreed in advance to billiondollar price increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to testimony filed in a Federal antitrust case by Dr. Morris A. Adelman, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economics orofessor.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The article by Jane Geniesse [How to Hide a Bed Under a Platform, Aug. 2] brought back to me a very old memory.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Administration is very cautious on Chrysler loan guarantees, President Carter said at an outdoor town meeting in Burlington, Iowa. Such guarantees would be conditioned upon a reorganization of the company's management, he added. [Page A1.] Chrysler said it would sell its profitable Chrysler Realty subsidiary, which owns or leases 780 dealerships, to ABKO Realty of Wichita, Kan. [D5.]

title: Notes on People
description: It seemed simple enough when Gov. Ella T. Grasso declared tomorrow to be Muhammad All Day in Connecticut. The boxer would visit a state veterans home and hospital in the town of Rocky Hill, receive an American flag and, no doubt, say more than a few words. For the residents, said the hospital's commandant, Col. Robert D. Houley, a visit from a celebrity would be a welcome break in the routine.

title: Two Climbers Are Saved in Alps; Copters Recover Bodies of Four
description: ZERMATT, Switzerland, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Helicopters rescued two seriously injured climbers today and recovered the bodies of four climbers killed in falls yesterday on the icy slopes of the 14,689foot Matterhorn, according to the police.

title: RKO Radio Set to Start A Network
description: RKO Radio, one of the largest groups of radio stations in the country, plans to begin a new satellitelinked national network in October tailored to the popular music stations that are vying for listeners in the age group of 25 to 34.

title: News Summary
description: Jimmy Carter accepted a Mideast plan recommended by his advisers, Robert S. Strauss, the special Middle East envoy, announced. They suggested that Washington abandon plans to sponsor a resolution on Palestinian rights in the United Nations Security Council later this week. In allowing Mr. Strauss to make the announcement, President Carter made him the spokesman on this crucial issue. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Pressure Is on Seoul To Control Inflation
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 22  Two Americans entered a restaurant here, perused the menu and settled on a cold dish of assorted meats, jellyfish and black eggs aged in the ground. They asked for a mediumsize portion.

title: U.S. Legislators End 3Day Visit With Soviet Leaders and Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22  A delegation of 14 members of the United States Congress completed three days of talks here today in which they met with both Soviet officials and dissidents.

title: Jersey Youth Who Was Kidnapped Is Happy to Be Back With Family
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 22  A 13yearold Randolph Township boy, who was kidnapped Sunday evening and held captive for two days in a Massachusetts home before he was able to escape, said today that he was happy and grateful to be back with my family.

title: Carter Cautious On Chrysler Bid For Federal Aid
description: BURLINGTON, Iowa, Aug. 22  President Carter said today that the Administration was proceeding very cautiously on the question of granting Federal loan guarantees to the Chrysler Corporation, and added that such guarantees would be conditioned upon a reorganization of the company's management.

title: Furniture Complaints By the Truckload
description: GETTING a new piece of furniture delivered on time, in perfect condition and in the right color  there are those who swear it does happen. But more often, or so it seems, something goes awry. The delivery man you've taken off from work to wait for fails to show up. One table leaf is missing. There's nick in a dining chair. The armoire doors are crooked.

title: Town Hall Meeting Scheduled
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP)  President Carter plans to hold a town hall meeting. in Tampa, Fla., Aug. 30, White House aides announced today.

title: Robert B. Cunningham Jr. Dies; Advertising Manager for A.T.&T.
description: Robert B. Cunningham Jr., an advertising manager with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York, died yesterday in Springfield (Mass.) Hospital following a heart attack at his summer home in Huntington, Mass. He was 56 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Music: Beaux Arts Trio
description: ONE way of enjoying concerts is to go to them with preconceptions and, yes, even prejudices. The muchpraised open mind is often as not an empty mind. The trick, however, is to recognize when your preconception has been confuted, or at least challenged, and that is not an easy trick to learn.

title: Smith Will Attend London Parley As Member of Rhodesia Delegation
description: SALISBURY; Zimbabwe Rhodesia,. Aug. 22  Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, the Prime Minister of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, announced today that his delegation to a constitutional conference in London next month would include former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: Lebanese Bitter at U.S. for Israeli Shelling
description: TIBNIN, Lebanon, Aug. 23  A group of women sat in the shade in this market center today, sifting and pounding thyme, while boys in blue gym suits played soccer. In the distance, the dull thud of heavy artillery fire bould be heard from time to time.

title: Arnritraj Eliminates Lloyd
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 (UPI)  Vijay Amritraj of India beat John Lloyd of Britain, 76, 61, tonight to reach the quarterfinals of the 52d Annual United States Professional Tennis Championships.

title: ARTHUR KERR
description: Arthur Kerr, executive director of the New York Foundation for the Arts, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Improved Security Pressed by Banks
description: The current rash of bank robberies in New York City is part of a nationwide trend that has caused some bankers to pay renewed attention to improved security measures and protective devices.

title: Carnegie Study Finds Status, Not Brains, Makes a Child's Future
description: Jimmy is in the second grade and he likes school. He pays attention in class and does well. He has an above average I.Q. and is reading slightly above grade level.

title: Mzzilli Is Signed By Mets
description: The New York Mets, a lastplace team struggling to prove to its fans that its present ownership is committed to the future, announced yesterday the signing of Lee Mazzilli to a contract through the 1984 season.

title: The First Double Quasar Is Reported Discovered
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  Astronomers say that what appears to be a distant double star is actually the first double quasar ever found.

title: Questions Raised in Death of Man Whom Police Had Shot 16 Times
description: The mother and a neighbor of a former mental patient who was shot to death by the police in Brooklyn Wednesday night questioned yesterday whether his death had been necessary and disputed details of the police account.

title: Deaths
description: BAFFAMaria Sofia. The Board of Directors of the Catholic Big Sisters extends its sympathy to its esteemed executive director Hortense Bela and her family on the death of their mother.

title: City Opera's Daughter
description: The New York City Opera will give a free staged performance of Donizetti's The Daughter of the Regiment, tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Lakeside Theater of Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, L.I. The opera, conducted by Charles WendelkenWilson, will be sung in Engish. Cynthia Auerbach will direct. Information: (516) 2924175.

title: Court Orders Damage Payments by Hauser
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a Federal District Court here had ordered Joseph Hauser, an insurance promoter, and several other defendants to, pay nearly $4 million in connection with the looting of millions of dollars in insurance premiums of union members from the National American Life Insurance Cornpany.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: A detail of a portrait by Robert Peake the Elder at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio WMCA, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Bloomington. (Television  Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Market Place
description: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC. has an unusual rights offering under way that leaves it with problem: how to deal with any money left over. The chosen solution could have a side effect considerable interest.

title: Sculptured Jewelry by a SelfConfessed Scavenger
description: When Marcia Yerman walks, there's a tinkling small bells and a castanet clicking of shells. She's wearing her foundobject necklace made of Oriental bells, wooden spools, an odd earring or two and, yes, the clam shells left over from a dinner, now lacquered a rosy red. I'm,a scavenger, she says. I see possibilities in the things people throw out.

title: Proxmire Gives Award For Waste to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Senator William Proxmire today gave his monthly Golden Fleece award to his colleagues in Congress, saying the lawmakers spending for staff has soared by 270 percent over the last decade.

title: Wheelchair Athlete Walks
description: YORK, England, Aug. 23 (UPI)  As far as his coaches and teammates were concerned, Ian Moor was a dedicated wheelchair athlete training the national paraplegic championships. They said they had no idea that walked a mail route during the day.

title: New Taxi Stations Begin Service
description: A new network of 34 taxi stations, designated places where cabs can wait at curbs to attract passengers, was inaugurated in midManhattan yesterday in an effort to reduce the congestion and air pollution caused by cruising taxis. The first day was not a great success.

title: Tug Crews Strike in Rotterdam
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Shipping here to a near standstill here today as tugboat crews began a wildcat strike demanding a pay raise.

title: Rare Capek to Open SoHo Rep's 5th Year
description: Who has not looked at a bug at work and marveled at its singleminded devotion to the task at hand? Karel Capek, the Czechoslovak novelist, journalist and playwright, must have done that. But he, with his less wellknown brother Josef, saw more: they saw in the fluttering butterfly or the laboring ant reflections of humanity. In 1921, with Europe just recovering from the technological brutality and human devastation of World War I, they wrote The Insect Comedy.

title: Koch Cites HospitalClosing Report
description: Reacting to a Federal report on the effect of proposed city budget cuts and the recent proposals to close two municipal hospitals, Mayor Koch observed yesterday that the report had concluded that there were no lifethreatening conditions at either of the hospitals because of the pending actions.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Aug. 24

title: Roughnecks Down Cosmos, 30
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 23  With Jack Brand, once a Cosmos hero but traded to Tulsa in June, leading the way, the Roughnecks defeated the Cosmos, 30, tonight in the first game of their North American Soccer League quarterfinal series.

title: Chase Quits ShipLease Operation
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has pulled out of a shipleasing transaction because of its concern over the possibility that at some point during the life of the lease Chase could come under foreign control.

title: New Faces Are Brightening Screen and Stage
description: IN Apocalypse Now he is Chief, the tough river patrolboat pilot who seethes with repressed fury as he reluctantly obeys orders to deliver Captain Willard to a Cambodian destination deep inside enemy territory. But his crew is killed off one by one as the mission progresses, and the Chief's silent menace finally erupts into murderous rage when he himself is mortally wounded and, dying, tries to strangle the Captain.

title: ISRAELI FORCE RAIDS VILLAGE IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 (UPI) About 50 Israeli soldiers crossed six miles into southern Lebanon early today to attack a village that was said to have served as a departure point for Palestinian guerrillas assigned to attack targets in Israel.

title: Deaths
description: HOPPPhilip, on Aug 22. Beloved husband of Grace. Father of Audrey Weil and Richard. Brother of Harriet Gold. Grandfather of Richard, Steven, Gary and Philip. Greatgrandfather of Steven. Uncle of Myron Gold. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St., Thurs., 69PM. Services Fri., Temple Israel, 112 E. 75th St. at 11AM

title: Events and Openings
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hail, 8; preconcert recital, 7.

title: Peru's Babies Are Dying
description: Maria Gomez came with her baby in her arms to the house of the parish in the Peruvian city where I serve the people. She knew the baby was dying. So did I. It was the third emergency baptism I had to perform that day.

title: A Jersey Family Mourns Teller, Slain at 23
description: GLEN ROCK, N.J., Aug. 23  Daniel M. Tishman spent last weekend with his family and his friend Jane McCullough at Lovejoy Pond in Maine, having a grand time.

title: Suarez to Visit U.S. in October
description: MADRID, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez will pay an official visit to the United States starting Oct. 3, the Foreign Ministry announced today. He is expected to stay a day or two.

title: Essex Sheriff and 2 Aides Indicted With a Former Democratic Chief
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23  A Federal grand indicted the Essex County Sheriff, two of his highranking assistants and a former Essex County Democratic chairman today on racketeering, conspiracy, bribery and extortion charges.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Money Supply Rises Sharply
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply jumped by $1.8 billion in the week ended Aug. 15, an unexpectedly sharp increase in this key determinent of the course of the economy. The rise, reported yesterday by Federal Reserve Bank of New York, portends stillhigher interest rates, according to moneymarket analysts.

title: Pakistan's End Run for the Bomb
description: American efforts to stop a nuclear arms race between Pakistan and India are not getting anywhere. Four months after Washington cut off most aid, Paidstan is still constructing a plant to enrich uranium. Reports of work on a test site, if confirmed, would suggest that a first explosion could happen soon. India is threatening to build an atomic arsenal if Pakistan persists.

title: Con] Ed Says Shift to Natural Gas Will Save Consumers $73 Million
description: Con Edison said yesterday that its consumers will save $73 million on their bills in the next 11 months, thanks to a decision by the federal government to allow the utility to burn natural gas instead of oil.

title: Ballet: Miss Bessmertnova in Legend
description: THE true poetic dimension that Yuri Grigorovich weaves through his beautiful The Legend of Love shimmered like a golden thread when Natalia Bessmertnova made her stunning New York debut in the ballet along with a new Bolshoi cast Wednesday night at the State Theater.

title: A.M.C. Wheels Out New Model
description: BURLINGTON, Wis., Aug. 23 Newcar buyers, already able to select from a maze of automobile models, were shown another one here today as the American Motors Corporation previewed its Eagle, the only allnew product in the company's 1980 model year.

title: Bundesbank To Limit Funds
description: BONN, Aug. 23  The West German central bank signaled today that it intended to combat further domestic inflation by putting upward pressure on interest rates, but it declined to disclose to what extent liquidity would be reduced.

title: Panel Urges Cut in Scope of TriState Planning Agency
description: The TriState Regional Planning Commission could coordinate growth in the New York metropolitan area more effectively if it cut out half of the area it is supposed to supervise, according to a proposal that will be presented today by the staff of the Governors Task Force on the Future of the TriState Planning Commission.

title: Virginia M. Hoge Wed To Anthony V. Barber
description: Virginia M. Hoge of New York and Point O'Woods, L.I., widow of James F. Hoge, was married yesterday to Anthony V. Barber of Tuxedo Park. N.Y.

title: Volcano! Runs Until Sept. 1.3 at Museum
description: Because it is 1,900 years ago today that the Roman resort city of Pompeii was destroyed, and preserved, by the explosive eruption of its backyard volcano, Vesuvius, this would be an appropriate weekend to take a look at Vesuvius and its fellows at the American Museum of Natural History, which has an exhibition called Volcano!

title: John Perkins Weds Margery S. Cuyler
description: Margery Stuyvesant Cuyler, an editor of children's books at Holiday House Inc., publishers in New York, and John Newman Hewson Perkins, a psychotherapist, both of Rowayton, Conn., were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Callahan, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART WK370141

title: Repeal of MilkDrink Rule Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  A consumer advocacy group for food petitioned the Federal Department of Agriculture today to repeal regulations that it says keep the price of reconstituted milk artificially high.

title: Diuretic Found in Horses Results in 18 Suspensions
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23  Eighteen trainers received 30day suspensions today because traces of diuretic were found in their horses systems after harness races at Saratoga Raceway.

title: 30 U.N. Soldiers Held Prisoner
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Lebanese leftists took 30 United Nations soldiers prisoner yesterday after one of the Lebanese held a gun to the head of a United Nations commander, a spokesman for the world body announced today. The soldiers were later relesed.

title: Bank Robber Caught; Teller Had His Number
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 23 (AP)  A 23yearold Savannah man is being arraigned today after his arrest following a bank robbery in which the robber slipped the teller an unusual note, authorities said. According to the police, the note contained his name and Social Security number.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 23, 1979

title: Sitter and Bronx Child Missing Since Aug. 13
description: The sitter, Carmen Arroyo of 74 West 89th Street, was last seen with young A 15yearold baby sitter subject to blackouts and disorientation and her 4yearold charge vanished after being seen by Bronx neighbors as they were going to Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Budget Deficit Estimate Raised to $30.3 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Carter Administration has quietly raised its estimate of the budget deficit this fiscal year to $30.3 billion, according to a report released today by the Treasury Department.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: If all the year were playing holidays, to sport would be as tedious as to work; But when they seldom come, they wish'dfor come, And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents. So Shakespeare wrote in 1598, and it's just as true 400 years later. This wishedfor weekend, the Riverside Shakespeare Company will present a new outdoor production of Henry IV, Part 1, tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. in Columbia University's Van Am Quadrangle just inside the main gate at 116th Street and Broadway. A halfhour before curtain, there will be refreshments as well as street players to stroll through summer's bower. Then audiences will see the historye of Henry the IVwith the conceipted mirthe of Sir John Falstoff. The Riversiders, with Stuart McDowell, director, in the lead, will play unmiked, with live music. No hurlyburly innovation here. It's free. Information: 2223581.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: EVERYTHING in Small Futures is obvious. It is also radical. The obvious tends to sound radical after decades of systematic selfdeception. We have deceived ourselves into thinking that we are a classless society, a meritocracy constructed according to egalitarian principles. To be sure, some of us are poor, but our children need not be. Just wait a generation. The public schools, related family services, various constitutional amendments and much legislation, most of it enacted in the 1960's, insure equality of opportunity for all our children. If, then, our children don't make it up a couple of rungs on the status ladder, it's their fault, or ours. Society is not to blame.

title: The New York Times/Jim Cummins
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 23  Billy Britton, a 23yearold from Staten Island who has been a professional for only five weeks, became the youngest player to win the Metropolitan Golf Association open championship when he beat George Bullock today on the sixth hole of a playoff.

title: 11 Jewish Groups Reject Criticism From Blacks, but Urge Cooperation
description: Leaders of 11 major American Jewish organizations, reacting with sorrow and anger to black leaders criticism of Jews in the wake of the resignation of Andrew Young, said jointly yesterday that they would continue to cooperate with the black community on many fronts.

title: Jersey's Assembly Backs Measure To Up Drinking Age From 18 to 19
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The State Assembly voted 49 to 17 tonight to raise the state's drinking age from 18 to 19 and sent the measure to Governor Byrne, who had said that he supported it.

title: Rabbi Aaron Reichel Marries Helen Kon, Graduate Student
description: Helen Kon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emil Kon of New York, was married last night to Rabbi Aaron Reichel, son of Rabbi and Mrs. 0. Asher Reichel, also of Manhattan. The bridegroom's father officiated at the ceremony in the New York Statler, where the bridegroom's uncle, Rabbi ShaarYashuv Cohen, Chief Rabbi of Haifa, Israel, assisted.

title: Assets Surge At Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The assets of mutual funds rose $4.8 billion in July, the secondlargest monthly increase on record, the Investment Company Institute reported today. Money market funds, with assets of $30 billion, less than half the total for all mutual funds, accounted for $4.1 billion of the increase.

title: East Side Tenant Is Found Slain
description: A 71yearold man who lived alone in an apartment building on the East Side of Manhattan was found stabbed to death around 5 P.M. yesterday, the police said.

title: The HitlerStalin Pact
description: On Aug. 23, 1939, the German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop secretly arrived in Moscow; on Aug. 24, he and Stalin signed the SovietNazi pact, and seven days later World War II began with the Wehrmacht invasion of Poland.

title: Broadway
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS has just flown to New York from his home in Key West, Fla., to spend a few days working on his new play with Jose Quintero, who will direct. The play, which concerns the lives of F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, is called Clothes for a Summer Hotel. Elliot Martin plans to produce it on Broadway this winter.

title: Jersey's Assembly Urges A Day to Honor Young
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23  The New Jersey Assembly tonight adopted a resolution praising Andrew Young, the former chief United States representative to the United Nations, and urging Gov. Brendan T. Byrne to name a day in his honor. The vote was 21 to 16.

title: Shoestring Tour Starts at Brooklyn Bridge
description: For participants on tonight's Adventure on a Shoestring tour, getting to the other side of the Brooklyn Bridge will not be the only reason for crossing it.

title: He's Hedging High Food Prices
description: Recession and inflation may be twin specters for the economy at large, but they seem to be doing wonders for the home foodservice industry.

title: Advertising
description: THERE is no television ratings race, contends Michael Dann, communications consultant who formerly headed the programming departments at both NBC and CBS. Despite all the hoopla about program lineups and their prospects, and despite the abiding interest the public seems to have in what share of audience a show is capturing, Mr. Dann says there really is no doubt about which network will be No. 1.

title: For Weekend Beachgoers, the Summer Pales
description: There is an epidemic of sorts sweeping the city this summer. It has no official name but the primary symptoms are all too apparent: a pale face, pale body and extreme Monday morning moroseness, the latter especially severe on gloriously sunny Monday mornings.

title: Auctions
description: THE setting for a Sotheby Parke Bernet country auction tomorrow and Sunday will be a sprawling, whiteclapboard Dutch Colonial farmhouse in Bennington, N.H., which the late Gilbert Verney, a textile and paper producer, called home from 1948 until his death last year. The sale consists of more than 500 lots, ranging in value from about $50 (for a sixpiece dresser set) to about $70,000 (for a rare and important set of prints of ducks). These 45 prints, one of only seven complete sets known, were used as the models for duckhunting permit stamps issued by the Federal Government between 1934 and 1978. Other objects reflect the nautical interest of the Britishborn Mr. Verney, who went to sea at the age of 11 and enjoyed yachting and racing throughout his life. A Currier and Ives print, The Yacht Squadron at Newport, is estimated to sell for up to $1,500; a carved bust of Lord Nelson may bring up to $900, and there are 23 models of ships in the sale that may sell for $200 to $3,000. Also of note are an Aaron Willard shelf clock, estimated to bring up to $10,000, and a 1951 Jaguar Mark V saloon, which is likely to sell for up to $7,000. The Verney property is 30 miles northeast of Keene, off Route 101. Admission (for two) is one catalogue ($8).

title: Detectives Tell How They Tracked Clerk Accused in Subway Pushing
description: Allen Curtis Lewis, the 26yearold mail clerk accused of pushing a music student off a subway platform last June, was followed so closely by three Transit Authority detectives investigating the case, they said, that they could sometimes see his heart beating through his shirt.

title: Pitcher Has Perfect Game As Taiwan Advances, 180
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP)  Chen Chaoan pitched a perfect game  striking out all 18 batters  as Taiwan defeated Aviano, Italy, Airbase, 180, today in a Little League baseball world series semifinal game. The games preliminary to the final are six innings.

title: Flamboyant Dancer Was Wayward Boy of Soviet Ballet
description: Aleksandr Godunov's defection from the Bolshoi Ballet not only brings to the West a dancer of great charismatic, even popstar, appeal, but also marks the first time a major dancer has defected from the famed Moscow troupe.

title: Climbers on Mt. Kenya Search for Lost African
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 23 (AP) Rescue teams were searching the slopes of 17,000foot Mount Kenya today for a barefoot African without climbing gear who went up the mountain to pray, park officials said.

title: Stock Prices Ease; Trading Still Heavy
description: Gold mining issues and some special situation stocks were the best performers yesterday as the general market declined moderately in continued heavy trading.

title: 8 Die in Collision of Motor Home And TractorTrailer in Wyoming
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 23 (AP)  A headon collision between a tractortrailer rig and a motor home killed eight persons near here in what the authorities termed the worst traffic accident in the state's history.

title: The Bills for World War II
description: With the impending retirement of 13 million veterans of World War II, the expenditures of the Veterans Administration on health care and income security are about to go through the roof. Yet no one seems to be paying much attention to the facts:

title: Music: Steel Cellos at Showing Room
description: WHEN Robert Rutman and a handpicked group of musicians made music on his large steel sculptures in the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden series a few years ago, this listener heard some interesting sounds and not much else. On Wednesday night, at the Showing Room, 563 Broadway, in SoHo, Mr. Rutman and his steel cellos, which are played with bows, much as conventional stringed instruments are, made sounds that were even more interesting, and that wasn't all. The instruments are still new, but now there seems to be a tradition associated with playing them, and the players are firmly in control.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Cleveland Board of Education voted tonight to appeal to the United States Supreme Court a desegregation plan that would require busing as many as 52,000 students by September 1980.

title: Weakfish Being Taken Closer to Jersey Shore
description: AREA A  Weakfish are plentiful in the Margate area, according to a report from Capt. Andy's fishing station The weaks, which had been seen offshore for a few weeks, are being taken by surfcasters as well. Top and bottom rigs, used from Sea Owl to Brigantine, are said to be extremely effective. Good catches of fluke also are reported. In the Manasquan Inlet region, bluefish up to 4 pounds are being landed from Manasquan Ridge as far south as Barnegat Ridge. Inshore fishing for fluke has been slow.

title: Visit by Carter Leaves Hannibal Flattered but Politically Cautious
description: HANNIBAL, Mo., Aug. 23  When the Delta Queen swung away from the shore here shortly after 2 P.M. today, it left behind a town flattered by a visit from the President, but still troubled by the same problems that have made this a jittery summer in Middle America.

title: MEXICO BARS U.S. BID FOR OIL SPILL TALKS
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 23The Government of Mexico tonight rejected a proposal by the United States for talks to discuss compensation for damages to the American coast of the Gulf of Mexico that were caused by oil from Mexico's runaway offshore well.

title: Chains Deny Burger War Despite Marriot's Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)The Marriott Corporation said today that its Roy Rogers fastfood outlets would join McDonald's in cutting hamburger and cheeseburger prices, but other chains tried to cool speculation that a hamburger price war was imminent.

title: Mrs. King Beaten
description: MAHWAH, N. J., Aug. 23  Billie Jean King was upset in secondround action tonight, but Tracy Austin advanced to the quarterfinals with an impressive victory in the $75,000 Volvo Cup before 3,208 fans at Ramapo College.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Paul A. Volcker said a tax cut now would be premature, but, added the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board at a breakfast meeting with reporters, when a tax cut comes, it should be slanted ward business to improve capital investment and worker productivity. He also indicated that interest rates were likely to remain high long as inflation continued at a torrid pace. [Page A1.]

title: Gold Bugs Confound the Monetarists
description: Outwardly, it was just another monthly gold auction that the General Services Administration conducted for the Treasury on Tuesday. Up for sale were 750,000 ounces of lowergrade (900 fine) bullion that came from gold coins melted into 400ounce bars many years ago. And the sale represented only a small part of the 275 million ounces owned by the Government.

title: A Power Plant to Burn Garbage Wins Approval in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23  Westchester County, rapidly running out of space to continue garbagedumping practices of the past, gave final approval tonight to a resource recovery plant that it had been arguing about for more than a decade.

title: Street Peddlers Face New Limit On Selling Areas
description: New York City's crackdown on street peddlers continued yesterday as the City Council passed a measure that would allow certain areas to be designated offlimits to peddlers and permit the police to confiscate a peddler's wares in those restricted areas.

title: Donzietti's Rita to Be at Riverside Church
description: A staged version of Donizetti's Rita will be presented in English tonight at 8 o'clock at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Dance, Dance, Dance

title: Julio de Diego, 79, Artist Who Also Was an Actor
description: Julio de Diego, an artist and actor, died of cancer Wednesday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and had divided his time In recent years between Woodstock, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Restaurants
description: THAI cooking, with its intriguing contrasts of flavors and textures, is among the world's more entertaining and savory cuisines. And so it was with much pleasure that we anticipated sampling it again while reviewing Soomthai, the sixweekold restaurant on Second Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets. It is gratifying to be ableto report that we were not at all disappointed, for this newcomer to the Thai restaurant scene offers many fine examples of that country's bestknown specialties.

title: Evalyn Baron
description: IN the years before she turned 5, Evalyn Baron flirted with many career ambitions: detective, reporter, foot doctor and elevator operator. But then, she said, I decided on something stable. Acting.

title: A Guide Hunting In Nearby Country Museums
description: ANY true traveler likes to go to a small museum in a town that is not too large. Nothing goes on for too long in such a museum, and we don't lose our way in the streets outside. We walk into the museum in high expectation, and we walk out an hour later with plenty to think about and our feet still in perfect repair.

title: Paul Cadwell, at 90, Still Master of Banjo
description: The Philadelphia Folk Festival will mark its 18th season this weekend by paying tribute to an even older institution  Paul Cadwell, the banjo player. On Saturday afternoon, the festival will offer a 90th birthday tribute to Mr. Cadwell who is still fingerplucking repertory of specialties that date, for the most part, from the turn of the century.

title: U. S. AND IRAN TALK ABOUT RESUMPTION OF ARMS SHIPMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  Defense Department officials said today that the Carter Administration was talking with the Government of Iran about resuming largescale shipments of American arms to that country.

title: RESERVE CHIEF COOL TO A TAX CUT NOW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  Paul A. Volcker, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, agreed today with the Carter Administration that a tax cut now would be premature. But he said that when a reduction came, it should be more heavily slanted toward business than previous tax cuts, so as to promote capital investment and worker productivity.

title: Surgeon, on Witness Stand, Says 4 Intruders Murdered His Family
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 23  Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald, the former Green Beret captain who is charged with the murder of his pregnant wife and two daughters, wept today on the witness stand as he talked of what he contends took place in his duplex at Fort Bragg, N.C., on the night of Feb. 17,1970.

title: Rock: Dixie at Dr Pepper
description: DR.HOOK and the Dixie Dregs are two putatively Southern rock bands that include a number of New York and New Jersey natives, and they were both at the Dr Pepper Festival in Central Park on Wednesday night. There the resemblances end. The Dixie Dregs blend Southern folk and bluegrass strains with elements of jazz and progressive rock in an innovative and appealing manner, while the musicians in Dr. Hook attempt to disguise their ragged harmony singing, tired instrumental arrangements and middleoftheroad orientation with gratingly manic staged routines.

title: Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival at the Y
description: Not many years ago, New Yorkers in search of good summer music had to seek it out of town. An outdoor concert here or there scarcely disturbed the great quiet. That situation changedit is worth the trip from New York to New Mexico to hear its concerts, and it has established a nationwide reputation for the high quality of its participants, who include Europeans as well as Americans. with the initiation of park concerts by the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera and the Mostly Mozart series at Avery Fisher Hall. There always remained, however, a brief period at the end of August when silence prevailed in the concert halls.

title: Liabilities and Alternatives
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The United States has asked Mexico to begin discussions on issues arisingfrom the oil spill in the Bay of Campeche, including compensation for damage and the costs of cleaning up Gulf Coast beaches.

title: Associated Press
description: POLICE ARREST SUPPORTERS OF JAGJIVAN RAM: As police moved in, demonstrators shouted in protest yesterday outside the presidential palace in New Delhi. The Janata Party, headed by Mr. Ram, demanded the impeachment of President Sanjiva Reddy, charging that he had been too hasty in dissolving Parliament and calling national elections. Mr. Reddy, seeking solution to India's worst political crisis since gaining independence from Britain 32 years ago, dissolved Parliament Wednesday and ordered general elections be held by December.

title: CRITICISM REVERSES A DAYOLD DECISION TO LICENSE REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Members of the Presidential panel investigating the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant today criticized the decision of a top official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to resume the process of licencing new reactors. Hours later, the official reversed himself.

title: Lionel Hampton Swings At Kensico Dam Plaza
description: A free performance by Lionel Hampton and his 10piece orchestra will be given today at 8 P.M. at Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla in Westchester CounThe concert, the second of three sponsored by Citibank, will feature Wild Bill Davis on piano. Mr. Hampton, the vibraphonist, and his band will play old favorites as well as new arrangments.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The right way to end the rampant inflation currently plaguing us is to impose mandatory price controls, even a price freeze  but not wage controls. Under the ceiling created by such a restriction on price increases, labor and management should be left free to make whatever deal they can as to the level of wages and salaries.

title: For Children
description: THE VALLEY RAILROAD, In Essex, Conn., travels a with vintage cars. There are also cruises up the Connecticut River aboard riverboatsthe Viking or the Silver Star, leaving from the Deep River Station. At the centuryold Essex Depot, there is a 1915 Grill Car Restaurant and glft shop, and nearby, the old seaport town of Essex Village. Train tickets: children, under 12, 5I.50; adults, S3. Tickets for onehour train and boat ride: children, $3.50; adults, $6.00; twohour train and boat ride: children, 54.50; adults, $7.25. Information and a brochure: (203) 7670103.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE search for financial remedies for the ailing Chrysler Corporation has followed a predictable course. The United Automobile Workers union and the company have indicated that relief is only a swallow away if the Federal Goverment would infuse a billiondollar pill in the form of a direct investment in the company or an advance taxcredit refund. The Government, meanwhile, has recommended natural healing while hinting that a loan guarantee of indeterminate amount may be provided.

title: The Region
description: A Federal grand jury in New Haven yesterday issued a 17count indictment against Alexander Gorski, a Newington, Conn., travel agent, on charges of conspiring to help aliens enter and remain in the United States illegally, according to United States Attorney Richard Blumenthal.

title: The Pop Life
description: NEARLY two years ago, Randy Newman came out with an album called Little Criminals. It was his first album in some time; always a painfully slowmoving composer, he had fallen into a long period of depressed inactivity. But Little Criminals had on it what no previous Randy Newman album had contained: a hit single, in the form of the controversial Short People.

title: Seoul's Justice Minister Defends Political Arrests of 10 Journalists
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20  I am! convinced, said Justice Minister Kim! Chi Yoi, that there is sufficient freedom! in South Korea, perhaps more freedom than we can afford.

title: Jazzmobile Travels Uptown for 2 Shows
description: Jazzmobile, the jazz show on wheels, will make two stops in Manhattan this weekend.

title: Deere: RecessionProof Product
description: MOLINE, Ill.  While recession fears may have already touched nerves in some corporate offices, top executives at Deere & Company headquarters just outside this western Illinois industrial city remain solidly optimistic.

title: Screen: Herzog's 'Woyzeck':Jewish Tunes in Queens
description: THE films of Werner Herzog, the West German director of "Aguirre, the Wrath of God," "Kasper Hauser," "Heart of Glass" and "Stroszek," among others, are night landscapes lighted briefly by lightning. Everything is brilliantly clear and profoundly eerie, and the after-image is even more vivid than the original.At the heart of each Herzog film is a mystery, not because information is arbitrarily withheld, but because every Herzog film is a record of the director's questions and speculations about his subject  which is, I suspect, why he chooses to do the films he does. To do anything else would be storytelling of a kind that doesn't interest him. Questions for which the answers are simple aren't worth asking.This is the hypnotic effect of Mr. Herzog's newest film, "Woyzeck," which opens today at the Cinema Studio 2 and the Quad 3 Cinema, and which contains the performance that won the Best Supporting Actress award for Eva Mattes at this year's Cannes Festival.Mr. Herzog's screenplay is based on the unfinished German play written by Georg Buchner in 1836 shortly before he died, the title of which was misspelled as "Wozzeck" when it was first published in 1879. "Wozzeck," which also served as the basis for the Alban Berg opera, was itself based on the true story of Johann Christian Woyzeck, a barber-solider who was beheaded in Leipzig in 1821 for murdering his mistress.Though the narrative is as straightforward as that of a fairy tale, Mr. Herzog's "Woyzeck" is, if possible, ever more mysterious by the time we reach the end than it is at the beginning. His Woyzeck, played by Klaus Kinski, who was the obsessed conquistador in "Aguirre," is a good deal more than Society's victim, which is the accepted Marxist interpretation of the story.Mr. Kinski, with his deeply lined faced that is simultaneously youthful and ancient, looks like death given a reprieve. From the moment we first set eyes on him, he is occupied by demons, furiously going through calesthenics that seem to be some kind of punishment. As others drive Woyzeck, he drives himself. He never walks if he can run. He is late for life. When he shaves his captain, the officer has to tell him to slow down, that he still has 30 years of service ahead of him.Woyzeck supplements his meager soldier's pay by allowing himself to be the guinea pig for the town's doctor, a loony man-of-science whose grand experiment requires Woyzeck to stay on a diet of nothing but peas. The doctor is bent on proving that it's possible to turn a man into a donkey.The focal point of Woyzeck's life is Marie (Miss Mattes), a buxom young woman who has borne him a son simply because  one gathers  there wasn't much else to do. When it becomes apparent even to Woyzeck, who'd prefer not to think about such things, that Marie is having an affair with the garrison's robust drum major, Woyzeck takes Marie for a walk in the fields and murders her. It's a measure of the Herzog style that this scene is actually painful to watch, though it's less violent in detail than a flat tire.This is the outline of a film that is neither about the exploitation of one class by another, nor about something as easily diagnosed as jealousy. Mr. Herzog's Woyzeck is, instead, possessed by intimations of the mortality of mankind. He tries to ignore the awful voices he hears and the wicked visions he sees, but he can't. He must accept everything. One day the sky over the town turns into what he describes as "white fire." He fears that "nature is running out." The doctor, who is delighted by Woyzeck's various aberrations, pays no attention when Woyzeck anticipates the day when "the world goes dark, and everything crumples up like a spider web."Even though doom and dark stalk all of Mr. Herzog's work, his films are too cool and too beautiful to be gloomy in any sentimental way. Also, when a film so involves the viewer in its speculations, there's no time for the kind of identification with character, the method by which most movies operate.Mr. Kinski is a riveting screen presence who threatens at any minute to burst beyond the limitations of the medium. It would be impossible to imagine either "Aguirre" or "Woyzeck" without him. Miss Mattes, best known here as the spoiled, pouty patricide in Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "Jail Bait," gives a surprising dimension of intelligence and sadness to the role of the unfortunate but not unknowing Marie.Mr. Herzog is a poet for whom neither Marx nor Freud supplies all the answers. He cherishes as well as guards the mystery at the heart of Woyzeck.

title: Giants Get Mike McCoy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP)  The Giants, in an effort to shore up their defensive line, acquired Mike McCoy today from the Oakland Raiders for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: U.N. Gets Its New Vienna Office
description: VIENNA, Aug. 23  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, on behalf of the United Nations, today formally took over a $500 million office and conference complex that Austria has built in an effort to make this city the world organization's third headquarters, together with New York and Geneva.

title: U.S. Is Suing to Take Land at Breezy Point For Part of Gateway
description: The Federal Government moved in court yesterday to take control of 285 acres of beachfront land on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens so that it might be used by the public as a part of the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Powell Denies Vacationing President Is Out of Touch
description: ABOARD DELTA QUEEN, on the Mississippi, Aug. 23  As President Carter neared the end of his sevenday working vacation aboard a Mississippi riverboat today, White House aides said that he was unconcerned by some editorial criticism that he had become an absentee President whose Administration was adrift.

title: Marshall E. Newton Dead at 81; Editor at The Times for 44 Years
description: Marshall E. Newton, a former assistant metropolitan editor of The New York Times and a member of its staff for 44 years, died Aug. 16 at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and had lived in nearby Interlaken in recent years.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the meanings of the word bisque concerns handicapping in such games as tennis, croquet and golf, but it has no bridge application and many bridge players do not know it. Nor do they know the extended meaning: a small favor due to some one, or a nonfinancial debt.

title: The New International Madison Ave.
description: It is an elegant street, Madison Avenue. At Sotheby Parke Bernet one can pick up a Monet or a Rubens, then walk across the street for tea at the Carlyle Hotel  real tea, as the manager says, made in a pot, never with teabags.

title: Critic's Notebook Jazz Festivals Without Jazz Come East
description: APHENOMENON has been spreading across the country for more than five years  the jazz festival that is not a jazz festival  and it reached the metropolitan area two weeks ago. The Kool Jazz iestival at Giants Stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands was a jazz festival in name only. In its lineup of soul performers  Aretha Franklin, Ashford and Simpson, the BarKays Chic, Rose Royce and Peabo Bryson  it made no pretense of offering anything that might be covered even by a broad, umbrella use of the word jazz.

title: Raising Salaries, and Hackles
description: Sponsors of an attempt to roll back the salary raises recently granted to members of the New York City Council and the Board of Estimate claim they have 50,000 signatures on petitions to put the proposition on the ballot. They will need 100,000 more by Sept. 6 and appear unlikely to succeed. But in any case, the most interesting thing about the entire matter is that the raises, which amount to a tiny fraction of 1 percent of the city budget, have caused such a furor.

title: The Garbagemen's Horse
description: As the opening number in the trotters triple crown series, the $275,000 Yonkers Trot is a prize coveted by the beauty and chivalry of harness racing and contested by the most fashionably bred steeds from the grandest stables the sport. As always, the rich and famous will be on hand tomorrow night when a field of eight sets out on the trail that leads to the renowned Hambletonian a week later in Du Quoin, Ill., and winds up at the Kentucky Futurity on Lexington's storied Red Mile Oct. 5. This year, not for the first time. the rich and famous include the Brothers Antonacci, the most famous garbage collectors in the world.

title: TV Weekend Historical Series On Settling Australia
description: SOMETHING rare on the American airwaves  a major Australianmade television serialwill make its debut Sunday night on WNEWTV, Channel 5. Pictorially handsome and graced with an able and attractive cast, the 13hour historical melodrama, Against the Wind, stands out as an exotic vessel in a sea of summer reruns.

title: Big Brother's Cousins
description: PHILADELPHIA  Applying checks and balances to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government intelligence agencies in the wake of the shocking revelations of the 1960's and 1970's is proving to be a far from easy task, despite efforts at the executive and legislative levels.

title: Publishing: New Laura Hobson Novel
description: LAURA Z. HOBSON once again shows her instinct for capturing headline events in fiction in her 10th book, Over and Above, coming from Doubleday early next month. In the background of the novel are clashing views about Israel and the Palestinians within one family.

title: Egypt Gives a Warm Welcome To Its First Israeli Tour Group
