description: CAIRO, Aug. 23  Under the open borders policy of Egypt and Israel, the first Israeli tour group has arrived in Cairo to visit the pyramids, search for relatives and explore the opportunities for tourism in a onceforbidden land.

title: Unmarked Police Van Cruising on BankHoldup Alert
description: On a rare day, when there were no bank robberies in the city, anonymous male callers dialed 911 a total of 20 times yesterday to falsely report robberies in midtown and lower Manhattan. According to the police, the last day on which there were no bank robberies was June 21.

title: Scotto's Racketeering Trial Set To Begin Sept. 10 by U.S. Judge
description: A judge said that the racketeering trial of Anthony M. Scotto, a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, would begin Sept. 10 in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Quigley's New Putting Style Produces a 63
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 23  Two weeks ago, Dana Quigley, a golf professional in the lower levels of achievers, nearly drowned in Narragansett Bay, off Rhode Island, after his fishing boat broke up and sank in a freakish storm.

title: The City
description: With the jury saying it was hopelessly deadlocked, a mistrial was declared last night in the Federal trial of John Grammatikos, whom authorities accused of having headed a major drugsmuggling ring operating between the Middle. East and the United States.

title: Killing of Black Troops Adds to Rifts in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 23  Last year, faced with a guerrilla challenge that was outstripping the capacity of its regular forces, the Salisbury Government took a calculated risk:

title: Carey Misses Meeting With an Upstate Man On Care for Retarded
description: Yesterday Governor Carey was supposed to honor a fourmonthold promise to meet with Edmund Gillette, the father of a retarded child, to discuss the problems of parents caring for retarded children at home.

title: E.P.A. Curtails Pesticide Use
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Douglas Costle, ordered a partial ban today on the pesticide chlorobenzilate, which has caused cancer in laboratory animals ancdamage to reproductive organs in humans. The order permits continued use of the pesticide on such citrus fruits as oranges and grapefruit, but use is prohibited on apples, cherries, cotton, trees, ornamental plants and nuts, the agency said.

title: 2 Men, One a Suicide, Are Killed In Separate Falls on Fifth Ave.
description: Two men fell to their death on Fifth Avenue last night in two separate incidents. The police said that one death was accidental and the other an apparent sulpeace said. hey Riedolled timi ployee of a law firm in the building, but were not able to say which one. They also did not release the victim's address.

title: Black Leaders Meeting: Watershed Effort for Unanimity
description: What we accomplished in there was a miracle, Bayard Rustin, president of the A. Philip Randolph Institute, remarked after leaving Wednesday's meeting of a wide variety of black leaders who had gathered at the headquarters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to consider the impact of the resignation of Andrew Young as the chief United States representative at the United Nations.

title: More Oil Washes Ashore
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 23 (AP)A fresh sheet of oil spilled onto five miles of beach on Mustang Island today, and two thicker concentrations of spilled crude were reported moving toward two entrances to the environmentally sensi tive Laguna Madre.

title: Art People
description: WHAT does a curator do, anyway? Dust the pictures? Count the flies on the wall? Lunch and dine with the board of trustees? Many people would like to know, but few dare ask.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  The Houston Oil and Minerals Corporation announced today that it had agreed to acquire the thirdlargest oil producer in Colombia, PetrOleos ColomboBrasileros S.A. (Colbras), for about $55 million.

title: Elk, Official of the Astros, Dies in Philadelphia Hotel
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (UPI) Herb Elk, director of public relations for the Houston Astros, died of an apparent heart attack tonight in his hotel room, team officials said. He was 49 wars old.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker City Island, a Boater's Paradise
description: CITY ISLAND may be New York's bestkept summer secret. Yet, geographically, this boating haven just off the northeast coast of the Bronx is not unlike coastal New England, offering activities similar to a Yankee fishing village. And one undisputed City Island attraction is its accessibility by public transportation.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Tickets are available at the public desk in the main lobby, United Nations headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M.4:45 P.M.

title: Garcia Excels as Orioles Turn Back Rangers, 65
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 (AP)  Kiko Garcia doubled to highlight a tworun firstinning rally and hit a threerun homer in the second to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 65 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight.

title: Developing Cities That Need Help Most
description: There's still a trace of life in the Carter Administration's battered, halfforgotten urban policy. The White House has long since given up on creating a national development bank and on reorganizing other urban aid programs. But its proposal to increase the scope and funding of the Economic Development Administration seems headed for Congressional approval. Still to be settled, though, is the perennial issue of targeting. The Senate backs the Administration's plan to focus on depressed urban and rural areas. The House Public Works committee, generous as ever, wants to make money available to even more communities than today's already excessive number. We trust this issue will be settled sensibly soon after Congress gets back from its August recess.

title: CONGRESS, IN RECESS, IS TRAVELING ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  At least 73 Representatives and 16 Senators are traveling abroad on official duty at taxpayer expense in the August recess. The visits include the capitals of Europe, the Soviet Union, China and Vietnam.

title: Rowdies 3, Fury 2
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (UPI) Jan Van Der Veen and Rodney Marsh each scored in a shootout tonight and led the Tampa Bay Rowdies to a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Fury in the quarterfinal round of the N.A.S.L. playoffs.

title: Mother of Murder Suspect Struggles to Understand
description: Vivian Smith sat in the kitchen of her Brooklyn apartment yesterday and shook her head in disbelief. Her 17yearold daughter, Roslyn, was in a Rikers Island detention center. An aged couple who had been her neighbors  and, as she recalled, used to give her youngest child cookies  had been stabbed to death. And the authorities say her daughter was one of those who did it.

title: Key Figure in South Africa Scandal Returns Under Guard From France
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 23  Eschel M. Rhoodie, the central figure in South Africa's influencebuying scandal, returned under armed guard from France today to face trial on charges that he misappropriated part of a $75 million secret fund that was used to try to gain support in the United States and elsewhere for South Africa's racial policies.

title: Notes on People
description: He insists it has no major political significance, but the fact is that James L. Buckley, the former United States Senator from New York, has switched his voting registration to Connecticut. The reason for the move is that he's been spending more and more time in Sharon, where he has a home, said Mr. Buckley, who also keeps a New York apartment.

title: Business and the Law
description: DANIEL AND MICHAEL BARR decided they wanted to operate a securities investment partnership during their summer vacation, and they agreed on a name  I.G. Barr & Company. There was one hitch: for their partnership papers, the brothers needed approval from New York City, and Norman Goodman, the amiable county clerk in Manhattan, said that Daniel and Michael, 14 and 16 years old, respectively, were just too young. He refused to issue them the necessary certificate.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: George Ablah, a Wichita, Kan., real estate man who has been involved in millions of dollars of big deals in the last 25 years, had previously been able to shun the glare of publicity. But now, as chairman and chief executive officer of the newly formed ABKO Realty, which agreed this week to buy the Chrysler Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, Mr. Ablah has become very much in the public eye.

title: Elka A. Lauterbach Is the Bride of Gerald Allen Rottman
description: Elka Amy Lauterbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Lauterbach of Yonkers, was married yesterday in Yonkers to Gerald Allen Rottman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rottman of Denver. Rabbis Shlomo Twersky and Solomon Sternstein performed the ceremony in the Lincoln Park Jewish Center.

title: Progress, Remember?
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  Inflation, unemployment, declining productivity, trade deficits, disenchantment with government, loss of international position  all these are related directly to our recent neglect of the science and technology that energize our economic processes. And so there is. fortunately, a growing consensus, as we celebrate the Thomas A. Edison centennial of light, that we must do something about it before it's too late.

title: Deaths
description: RYANEdward D. On August 15, 1979. Husband of Olga Azar Ryan. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Services private.

title: Chilean Weekly, Shut 2 Months, Is Back With Vigor
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23  Chile's leading opposition publication, Hoy, which was closed by military decree two months ago, reappeared today with increased readership and record advertising.

title: Vietnamese and Chicanos Clashing in Denver Barrio
description: DENVER, Aug. 23  Outbreaks of violence between the Chicano and Vietnamese communities on Denver's west side are focusing attention on the problems of an American city trying to handle racial conflict between two minority groups.

title: Rhodesia Reports Raids On Guerrillas in Zambia
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 23 (AP)  Government troops and planes have struck six guerrilla targets in Zambia, the Zimbabwe Rhodesia military command said today.

title: Hertz Cuts Car Rents
description: The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday a reduction of its carrental prices for leisure travel by an average of 33 percent on a nationwide basis. It also said that with the reduction there would be a simplified standard touring rate under which charges are the same throughout the continental United States.

title: President and an Auto Worker Debate Foreign Policy at 5 A.M.
description: QUINCY, III., Aug. 23 (UPI)  It was a strange setting for a strange exchange: The President of the United States and an auto worker debating foreign policy alongside the Mississippi River at 5 o'clock in the morning.

title: Nathan's Famous In Merger Talks
description: Nathan's Famous Inc., a name that has become synonymous with hot dogs, is the object of acquisition interest by some companies and groups, Murray Handwerker, the company's chairman and president, said yesterday.

title: Carter Expected to Act Quickly To Choose a Successor to Young
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  Administration officials said today that they expected President Carter to move quickly upon his return to Washington tomorrow to choose a successor to Andrew Young as United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Godunov, Bolshoi Dancer, Defects to U.S.
description: A leading Soviet dancer, Aleksandr Godunov of the Bolshoi Ballet, has sought and been granted asylum in the United States for at least a year, officials of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday.

title: DC10 Lands Safely in Montana After Engine Fire During Takeoff
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., Aug. 23 (UPI)  The No. 3 engine of a Northwest Airlines DC10 jetliner carrying 168 passengers caught fire on takeoff tonight, but the pilot landed the plane safely using the other two engines.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Aug. 23, 1979

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (01 overthecounter.

title: Knight's Resignation Is Refused
description: After an hourlong meeting of Indiana University officials yesterday, John Ryan, president of the university, said he would not accept the offer of Bobby Knight, the school's basketball coach, to resign. Mr. Knignt naa been convicted the day before in Puerto Rico of assault in connection with an incident during the Pan American Games last month.

title: Delaware Drops Robbery Charge Against a Priest
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 23 (AP) The State of Delaware today dropped all charges against the Rev. Bernard T. Pagano, the Roman Catholic priest who had been on trial as the alleged Gentleman Bandit in a series of armed robberies. A Pennsylvania man who had admitted involvement in the holdups pleaded guilty to three of them.

title: Associated Press
description: Jack Clark of the Giants fouling off a bunt during 86 victory over the Pirates in Pittsburgh on Wednesday.

title: News Summary
description: Possible U.S. arms sales to Iran are being discussed by the two governments, Pentagon officials disclosed, but they said that little progress had been made because of divisions and confusion about responsibilities in the Iranian regime. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Egypt Supports Mideast Resolution At U.N. but Israel Calls It a Danger
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23 Egypt today supported a Security Council resolution proposed by Arab and thirdworld countries that calls for national independence, selfdetermination and sovereignty for Palestinians, but Israel contended that the measure's adoption would greatly jeopardize the peace process in the Middle East.

title: One Missing After Sea Collision
description: POINT JUDITH, R.I., Aug. 23 (UPI)  A 300foot barge collided in heavy fog early today with a 31foot sailboat carrying four persons off the coast of Rhode Island. William Austin of New York City, believed to be the captain of the sailboat, which apparently sank, was reported missing. The Coast Guard suspended its search for him at dusk. The boat's other three passengers were rescued by a tugboat.

title: Jane Bauer Brown Is Married To Barry Adelman, Executive
description: Jane Bauer Brown, a New York City public school teacher, and Barry Adelman of New York, an assistant vice president with Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., were married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park, where Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Judge Backs OPEC in Antitrust Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23  Federal District Court Judge A. Andrew Haul( ruled late today that his court did not have jurisdiction in the antitrust suit brought to challenge the right of the 13 member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to fix oil prices.

title: C.A.B. Approves Routes to Europe
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board awarded 13 United States airlines authority today to fly from 21 American cities to Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. President Carter must also approve the action because international routes are involved.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A large spiral cloud system covers the Middle and South Atlantic States, the lake region and the upper Mississippi Valley. Thunderstorms are scattered in the Texas and clouds cover the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies cover the rest of the country.

title: Fourth of Guyana's Work Force On Strike With No Pact in Sight
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 23 (AP)  Nearly a fourth of Guyana's 80,000 workers are on strike, and no settlement is in sight.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Aug. 23  Stillmeadow Farm's Calypso, a newcomer to the division, won the open jumper class after a sevenhorse jumpoff today at the Nassau County horse show.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 23, 1979

title: 2 Securities Cases Settled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The Securities and Exchange Commission accused two individuals today in separate court cases of violating securities laws by buying and selling stock for their own accounts on the basis of insider information.

title: U.S. Reaches Accord With Bishop College To Solve Its Fiscal Ills
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Government announced today that it and Bishop College had agreed on a financial oversight plan and a schedule for repaying debts that would permit the predominantly black college in suburban Dallas to participate in Federal aid programs.

title: North KoreaNicaragua Tie
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  North Korea and Nicaragua have agreed to establish diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors, the official North Korean press agency reported today.

title: Ruth A. Loftus, 89
description: Ruth A. Loftus died Monday at the Woodhaven Retirement Community in Concord, N.H. She was 89 years old.

title: Meryl Streep pauses for family matters.
description: ATALL, thin woman in a funnylooking beaded hat was making her way through the garden of the restaurant, handing out fliers for the boutique she represented and telling patrons that her suit was made of wool. Got anything in this size? muurmured Meryl Streep, with a mischievous smile. Miss Streep, 30 years old, is seven months pregnant and looking even more serenely lovely than she does in The Seduction of Joe Tynan, another movie in which her only problem  if you could call it that  is that she's just too attractive for her role.

title: Radio
description: 7Noon, WNYCFM. Contrapunti and Fuga (Op. 144), Schubert; Ouverture in D for 2 Violins and Continuo, No. 2, Leclair; Quem vidistis pastores, Gabrieli; Air Ecossais No. 2, Beethoven; Divertimento (K. 439b2), Mozart; Symphony No. 49, Haydn; Legend for Piano and Orchestra, Ireland; La Mer, Debussy.

title: Fears Rising in Washington That an IndiaPakistan Nuclear Race Is Inevitable
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  Five years after India detonated what it called peaceful nuclear device, doubts are growing in official circles that the United States and other nations can prevent an atomic arms race between India and Pakistan.

title: 10 Hunted in Maryland Jailbreak
description: JESSUP, Md., Aug. 23  Thirty prisoners broke out of the state House of Correction late last night, and 10 of them remained free this evening.

title: Spanish Police Accuse Basques In Bomb Attacks Against French
description: SARAGOSSA, Spain, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Bombs exploded in a French bank and a French immigration office in northern Spain early today, causing damage but no injuries, according to the police.

title: About Real Estate Study Asks Change in Construction Cycles
description: It happens every winter in the housing industry: Plants become idle and employment declines. This seasonal nature of the construction business and in particular the residential market, which peaks in the spring and summer, results in higher costs for the builder, the consumer and the public.

title: Itel Ousts Two and Talks To Semiconductor Corp.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23  The struggling Itel Corporation and the National Semiconductor Corporation, supplier of computers that Itel markets, are holding talks that could lead to National's acquisition of part or all of Itel's computer operations, National spokesman said today.

title: Pop Music: Abbey Lincoln Returns
description: WHEN Abbey Lincoln first came to New York, in 1957, she made her singing debut at the Village Vanguard. Twentytwo years later, she has returned to the Vanguard, where she is singing through Sunday, after an absence from New York of more than a dozen years, most of which she spent in California, where she has been an acsinger.

title: EARNINGS Esmark's Profits in 26.8% Rise
description: Esmark Inc., the holding company with interests ranging from meat packing to automotive products, reported yesterday a profit surge of 26.8 percent for the third fiscal quarter ended July 28 and 16.7 percent for the ninemonth period. Donald P. Kelly, president, said revenues and earnings are still likely to reach record levels for fiscal 1979.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 23 (UPI) Vietnamese forces in Cambodia have been reinforced for a new push against the forces of the ousted Pol Pot regime after the rainy season ends in midOctober, a Thai military spokesman said today.

title: Olympic Fieldhouse Passes Test
description: ALBANY, Aug. 23  An engineering firm said today that the Federallyfunded, $15 million fieldhouse completed this week in Lake Placid for the 1980 Winter Olympic Games meets generally accepted structural designs standards.

title: 40 Youngsters to Perform in East Hampton
description: Forty youngsters, ages 12 to 15, will sing, dance and act in a presentation Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Boys Harbor Amphitheater, off Springy Banks Road in East Hampton, L.I. The boys and girls took part in a performingarts program this summer run by Boys Harbor, a private youth agency started in 1937. The organization's services include a summer camp, a daycare center, an arts program and careerdevelopment assistance.

title: Louise Goffin Tests Musical Wings
description: Actually, it was 19yearold Louise Goffin who was wearing the bottoms of her white trousers rolled. But it was impossible to interview her without feeling old oneself. It seems like only the day before yesterday that Miss Got. fin's parents  Gerry Goffin and Carole King  were writing classic pop songs such as Will You Love Me Tomorrow, Take Good Care of My Baby, The LocoMotion and Up On the Roof, and just yesterday that Miss King became a solo performer and recorded Tapestry, one of the biggestselling albums of all time. Yet here, in the offices of Elektra/Asylum Records, sprawled Miss Goffin in a tangle of elbows and knees and billowing curls through which she childishly ran her fingers as she discussed her debut album, Kid Blue, and her first New York appearance, tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. in Central Park's Wollman Skating Rink Theater as part of the Dr. Pepper Music Festival. (Tickets are available at Korvette record stores and at the box office after 5 P.M. on the evening of the concert.)

title: MidAugust Auto Sales Up by 21%
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP)  Aided by heavy price cutting, and despite a decline by Chrysler, midAugust sales of United Statesmade automobiles rose 21 percent from a year earlier to record for the period, according to company reports issued today. ne inaustry aenverea zAztubo cars in the 10day period from Aug. 11 to Aug. 20, compared with 199,634 in the period last year. There were eight selling days in the period, the same as last year. The gain in sales was the first yeartoyear increase in a 10day period since March.

title: Mental Patient Is Held as Hijacker
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 23 (AP)  A mental patient involved in a 1975 threat to blow up a hospital was in custody today after hijacking a jetliner by pretending to have a bomb, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Jersey's New Environment Chief
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23  Jerry English, who was sworn in today as Governor Byrne's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, has inherited a variety of challenges, such as what to do with 1.2 billion gallons of chemical waste generated annually by New Jersey's huge chemical industry.

title: U.S. Halts Soviet Airliner to Ask If Dancer's Wife Is Going Freely
description: United States officials held up the departure of a Soviet airliner at Kennedy International Airport last night and this morning to determine if the wife of Aleksandr Godunov, the Soviet dancer who has defected here, was returning to Moscow of her own free will.

title: Public TV Wins Fund Dispute With Public Radio
description: A dispute between the radio and the television networks of public broadcasting, centering on the apportionment of Federal funds to each, was resolved in favor of the television side by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the organization that distributes the Government funds.

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 8; preconcert recital, SANTA FE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, 8. Bach recital at 7.

title: Innovative Farmers Shave Energy Costs
description: PAOLA, Kan., Aug. 24 (AP)  Last winter, Paul Haley was easy prey for the spiraling energy costs that wreck many farm budgets. He had 40 hogs crowded into a small building using $60 a month in electricity. And he was paying another $100 for propane to heat his home.

title: HENRY J. TASCA DIES, EXU, S. AMBASSADOR
description: GENEVA, Aug. 24  Henry J. Tasca, former United States Ambassador to Greece and Morocco, died in a road accident near Lausanne, Switzerland, on Wednesday, the police announced today.

title: Philips Bids For Stake In Grundig
description: BONN, Aug. 24  N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken, Europe's largest electronics producer, said today that it was negotiating the purchase of an 18.7 percent stake in West Germany's privately owned Grundig A.G. for $200 million.

title: Canada Protests Arrest Of Shcharansky Lawyer
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  Canada protested to the Soviet Union today over the arrest and expulsion of a Canadian lawyer hired to act on behalf of jailed dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, an External Affairs Department snokesman said A Soviet diplomat was summoned to the department and handed a note protesting the expulsion of Irwin Cotler, who was arrested in Moscow Sunday and put on a plane to London.

title: Body of Suicide Victim Is Found
description: The body of a 43yearold man was found hanging from his belt yesterday in a narrow space betweeen two walls on the lower level of the Western Union Building, at 1440 Broadway, at 40th Street. The police said the man, a resident of Indianapolis, left a suicide note, the contents of which were not disclosed. The identity of the man, who had been dead for a week to 10 days, was also being withheld, pending notification of his family.

title: Cabaret: A Revue on Cole Porter
description: The traditional view of Cole Porter's world  sleek, sophisticated, clever and bitchy  is avoided almost meticulously in Hot and Cole, a revue made up of Porter's songs that is being performed at Savannah, the cabaret in the Edison Hotel, 47th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.

title: Snowden Waring Is Married on L. I.
description: Snowden Wainwright Waring, daughter of Mrs. Parsons Wainwright of Washington and Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d of Wainscott, L.I., was married yesterday to Edmund KirbySmith 4th, son of Col. KirbySmith 3d, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. KirbySmith of Sewanee, Tenn.

title: Priest Released in Delaware May Face New Charge
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 24 (AP) The Rev, Bernard T. Pagano, cleared of charges that he was the Gentleman Bandit who held up six northern Delaware stores at gunpoint, could still face trial in Pennsylvania on a charge of attempted robbery, the authorities said today.

title: Associated Press
description: NEW ENERGY SECRETARY SWORN IN: Charles W. Duncan Jr., smiled as President Carter and Mr. Duncan's wife, Anne, applauded. Mr. Carter took the oppor tunity to praise former Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger for his services. Article on Mr. Carter's return to Washington from his riverboat trip is on page 6.

title: Carter Fails to Gain Assurances on Carey In Presidential Race
description: Gerald M. Rafshoon, a consultant to President Carter on the news media and politics, sought private assurances from New York political leaders yesterday that a possible favorite son role for Governor Carey in the 1980 campaign was not intended as a threat to the President.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ENERGY PLAN A warmweather display of athletic suppleness will be this afternoon's free event for pedestrians in Rockefeller Center, as some 25 gymnasts, ages 6 to 30 years, perform from 1 to 5 P.M. in the plaza between 49th and 50th Streets. The athletes will be demonstrating their skills on the balance beam, parallel bars, trampoline and floor mats as part of the Saturdays in the City weekend series geared as family entertainment.

title: DETAILS OF KILLINGS UNCLEAR TO DOCTOR
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 24  With a Government attorney poised above him, holding a wooden club that, the prosecution says, Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald used to beat his two daughters to death, Dr. MacDonald testified today that he could not recall all the details of the night nine years ago when his wife and children were slain.

title: Kroc, Citing $100,000 Fine, Gives Up Control of Padres
description: Ray Kroc, the owner of the San Diego Padres whose hamburgers have been more fulfilling than his baseball players, moved to the top of the list of executives penalized by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn with the disclosure yesterday of a 5100.000 fine.

title: Bid for Hidrogas
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. of Toronto said yesterday that it planned to make a tender offer of $15.50 a share for Canadian Hidrogas Resources Ltd.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 23.

title: Jordan Under Inquiry on Cocaine; He Denies the Report by Studio 54
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  The Attorney General has ordered a preliminary investigation into an allegation that Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, used cocaine during a 1978 visit to the New York discotheque Studio 54, Justice Department officials dISCIOSed today. The Attorney General was following provisions of the Ethics in Government Act, which requires investigations of any allegations against top officials that are more serious than a petty offense.

title: The City
description: The city failed to collect only 3.62 percent of its realestate taxes in fiscal year 1979, the lowest percentage since fiscal 1965.

title: No Extradition for Knight
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 24 (UPI)  Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo of Puerto Rico said today that he would not ask the State of Indiana to extradite Coach _Bobby Knight, in view of the costs involved, to serve a sixmonth sentence for hitting a Puerto Rican policeman.

title: Land Claim By Cayugas Stirs Anger
description: UNION SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Holder of the Heavens, in a gesture of beneficence, placed his great hand upon central New York to bless it, and the depression left by his fingers became the basins of an elegant series of lakes, around which lived the nations of the Iroquois So goes the Indian legend.

title: Study Confirms Aiding a Neurotic Can Harm a Marital Relationship
description: Two British researchers have reported evidence confirming an observation often made by family therapists: that neurotic symptoms can cement a marriage and that when the mental health of one spouse improves, the relationship between the partners sometimes deteriorates.

title: United Press International
description: TWOLEVEL PLAY: Pete Rose of the Phillies puts the tag on Cesar Cedeno in an unsuccessful pickoff play in the fifth inning last night at Philadelphia. The Phillies won, 53.

title: For the Younger Set, a Special Place to Shop
description: Even Baby Snooks would have approved. Saks Fifth Avenue's new children's department, which officially opens Tuesday night with a benefit party for the New York Special Olympics, is a sprightly, colorful place for a child to be taken shopping and it's called, naturally enough, K.I.D.S.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda Aug. 23; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: 3d Concern In Bid for Flintkote
description: A third suitor for the Flintkote Company, described by security analysts as an assetrich prize, appeared yesterday when the LouisianaPacific Corporation said it was holding preliminary talks with the buildingmaterials producer.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: U.S. Steel said that it would suspend operations at two plants in Illinois that employ 1,160 workers this fall because the plants have been unprofitable. The nation's largest steel producer said it would conduct a feasibility study to see whether the plants, which are in Waukegan and Joliet, should be closed permanently. The action was the most serious in the industry since the 1974 downturn. [25.]

title: U.S. Captive Escapes Salvadorans
description: SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 24 (UPI) The American business executive held captive for 10 days by striking workers has escaped, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: OBSERVER
description: I had not taken the Rustmobile out for a spin in over seven months when I got behind the steering wheel recently. This had nothing to do with fuel conservation or bile toward the gasoline industry. I had made a New Year's resolution last January to stop driving, partly to see if it could be done and partly to stanch the flow of the tribute I was paying the pirates who operate Manhattan parking garages to keep the Rustmobile sheltered.

title: Stuart R. Heisler Is Dead at 82; An Early Hollywood Film Director
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI) A private funeral was held today at the Eternal Hills Mortuary for Stuart R. Heisler, a wellknown Hollywood movie director in the 1920's and 30's, who died Tuesday. He was 82 years old.

title: Debentures By Sharon Steel Set
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering to sell $50 million in debentures, the proceeds of which will be use for equity investments or acquisitions, the company said yesterday.

title: Good Work No Mystery To Shriners
description: The guard at the door of the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel wore a threepiece summer suit, a gold necklace and a maroon velvet fez. As people whispered a password to him so they could enter the inner sanctum, he casually swung a silver scimitar back and forth.

title: Waldheim for IsraelP.L.O. Deal
description: VIENNA, Aug. 24  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today in an interview that an agreement should be reached to obtain reciprocal recognition by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Oreanization.

title: Union to Press Its OPEC Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP)  The lawyer who lost a bid for a Federal court injunction against price fixing by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that he would appeal the decision.

title: Florida Couple's Slaying Studied
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 24 (UPI) The police pressed an investigation today into the underworldstyle slaying of wealthy couple who operated trucking companies in nearby Hialeah and in New York.

title: ABCTV Promotes Chief Of World News Tonight
description: Av Westin, a vice president of ABCTV News and the executive producer of the network's evening newscast, World News Tonight, has been named to a newly created position of vice president of program development.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto in E minor for Flute and Orchestra, Corrette; String Quartet No. 1, Haydn; Piano Concerto No. 5, Bach.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Coppola Widens Film Network
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24  Francis Coppola, Academy Awardwinning director of The Godfather II, is bringing his American Zoetrope Production Company under the wing of Orion Pictures Company.

title: LEBANESE CIVILIANS KILLED IN SHELLING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 (UPI) Several civilians were killed in the southem port of Tyre today as the city came under heavy artillery fire for the sixth day.

title: SmallBusiness Men Complain
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 23  The Stanle3 Plating Company thought it had me government requirements when its expensive pollutioncontrol equipment was approved by the state Department of Environmental Protection and the Federal Environmental Protection agency. Then inspectors of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration visited the metalfinishing plant in Bristol, which employs 110 workers and ships $3.5 million in orders annually.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Draths

title: White House Appeals for Restraint In Teheran's War With the Kurds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  The Carter Administration called on the Iranian Government and Kurdish rebels today to exercise restraint in the fighting in western Iran.

title: Crowd of 100 Gathers Outside Police Station For Protest on Slaying
description: About 100 people led by the Rev. Herbert Daughtry of the Black United Front gathered outside the 79th Precinct station house in Brooklyn yesterday to protest the shooting death of Luis Baez.

title: Rock: Carl Perkins's Nostalgia
description: Although Carl Perkins counts as one of the early giants of rockabilly and rockandroll, he was really only a onehit artist. His record of Blue Suede Shoes, which he composed, was the most successful of three competing versions of the song in 1956, even surDassine that of Elvis Presley.

title: Troy Loses Plea In Court to Shut Pretrial Sessions
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the oncepowerful New York City politician who faces trial next month on larceny charges, has lost a bid to have pretrial hearings in the caseclose to the news media and public

title: Miss Austin Wins, Loser Cries
description: MAHWAH, N. J., Aug. 24  Tracy Austin, unperturbed that her match was moved indoors to the Ramapo College gymnasium because of rain, used skillful ground strokes to defeat Regina Marsikova of Czechoslovakia, 61, 62, today and reach the semifinals of the $75.000 Volvo Cup tennis tournament.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MAPLEWOOD, Minn., Aug. 24 (AP)  Beth Daniel eagled the seventh hole today by sinking a 40foot chip shot on her way to a fourunderpar 69 and a threeshot lead after two rounds of the $100,000 Patty Berg Golf Classic.

title: Bridge:
description: Many topranked players in their 30's are finding themselves upstaged nowadays by youngsters who were not even born when they themselves learned the game. Prominent among this group of young prodigies is Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., who at the age of 22 is having a magnificent year.

title: Der Spiegel Publisher Is Arrested On a Drug Charge by Sardinians
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, Aug. 24 (UPI) The police said today that they had arrested the publisher of the West German magazine Der Spiegel, Rudolf Karl Augstein, on charges of drug possession.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  A British food services company has agreed to acquire Bluebird Inc., a major American pork processor, for $14.875 a share, or a total of $72 million, the companies announced today.

title: Carter Aides Appeal on Ration Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  The Carter Administration, unhappy with House amendments to its standby gasoline rationing plan, has appealed to Congressional negotiators to drop the sections it finds offensive.

title: Books of The Times Metaphors in Medicine
description: What distinguishes The Body in Question is Jonathan Miller's deftness and originality in using metaphors to clarify so accurately much of the biological basis of medicine. Rarely have metaphors been used so well to communicate complex medical concepts and to pay tribute to the magnificence of the human body.

title: Washington Puts on Its Skates and Starts Rolling
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  By day it's just another commercial area with crowds spilling into the sidewalks from Government agencies, law offices, lobbyist suites, boutiques, banks urging you to save your money and restaurants sounding their siren songs to spend it.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Bids To Postpone Nevada Execution
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP)  A Federal appeals court today rejected two bids to delay the execution of Jesse Bishop, a confessed killer who is scheduled to die Monday in Nevada's gas chamber.

title: The Region
description: A 33yearold Massachusetts laborer who had been sought in the alleged kidnapping of a teenaged New Jersey boy last Sunday walked into a Boston police station last night, ending a nationwide manhunt under way since the boy escaped from his abductor last Tuesday.

title: Tax Agents Visit a Boy To Get 64
description: The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance has cracked down on a small businessman upstate who wasn't paying his quarterly sales taxes.

title: New York City Bank Holdups Dip; Publicity Called a Deterring Factor
description: There were four bank robberies and one aborted attempt yesterday in New York City and none Thursday  and the chief police inspector in charge of these things said that the publicity was a contributing factor.

title: Sohlo and Shell Raise Gas Price
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (UPI)  The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has increased gasoline prices by four cents a gallon for both companyowned and independent stations. Robert Griffin, vice president for marketing, attributed the increase to rapidly rising crude oil costs in July.

title: The New York Times/Vic DeLucia
description: The Mets bowed for the sixth time in their last seven games last night, but in losing to the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium, 10, they may have found a new starting pitcher.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  A group of 45 citizens from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia have demanded selfdetermination for the three Soviet republics on the ground that they were annexed illegally under the 1939 nonaggression pact between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany.

title: After a Year, Dominican Democracy Still Feeling Its Way
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 22  Along the streets of the capital, washed with sunlight and disco music, one can see the fortresses and monuments built over the centuries by conquerors, generals, and dictators as tributes to themselves and to a way of life many Dominicans now hope will be history.

title: White Sox Postponed
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) Tonight's American League baseball game between the Chicago White Sox and Baltimore Orioles was postponed because of unplayable field conditions. The postponement came about when part of the outfield was ripped up during a recent rock concert at Comiskey Park, attended by 70,000. Constant rains added to the burden.

title: Yankees Topple Twins by 75
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 24 The New York Yankees continued tonight to batter the teams contending for the top spot in the American League's Western Division.

title: About New York
description: It was somewhat surprising that there was so little ceremony marking the recent joining of two sections of what will be the East 63d Street subway line to Queens. Historic linkups are always occasions: the Russian and the Yank meeting on the Elbe, the golden spike of the transcontinental railroad, the wide grins of two tunnelers, one going east, the other going west, meeting at point of junction.

title: Jackson Cites China Oil Find
description: PEKING, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  China has discovered highquality oil in a field off Hainan Island in the south of the country, Senator Henry M. Jack son, Democrat of Washington, said today.

title: Mother of Missing Bronx Boy, 4, Thinks Baby Sitter, 15, Has Him
description: The mother of a 4yearold Bronx boy who has been missing for nearly two weeks said yesterday that she thought the child was in the hands of a troubled teenaged girl she had tried to befriend and whom she had hired as a baby sitter.

title: U.S. ACHIEVES DELAY IN U.N. COUNCIL VOTE ON PALESTINIAN ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 The United States, which had said that the current Security Council debate on Palestinian rights was illtimed, succeeded today in postponing a vote on a proposed Council resolution calling for selfdetermination, national independence and sovereignty for Palestinians.

title: Draper L. Kauffman; Retired Rear Admiral Led Naval Academy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 24 (AP) Rear Adm. Draper L. Kauffman, retired, a former Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy who was known as the father of the Navy's underwater demolition teams, has died at the age of 68, the Academy announced today.

title: Texaco Raises Gas Allocation
description: Providing the first indication of what gasoline supplies may be like next month, Texaco Inc. said yesterday that its allocation figure for September would be 80 percent, compared with 78 percent in August.

title: Oil Pipeline Breaks in Missouri, Spewing Thousands of Gallons
description: WALNUT GROVE, Mo., Aug. 24 (AP)  A Shell Oil Company oil pipeline cracked open late today near this southwest Missouri town, spilling thousands and thousands of gallons of crude oil into Asher Creek, the authorities said.

title: Freedom to Say Yes in China
description: Peking has been finding that, as much as China needs modernizing, its people need galvanizing. Buffeted by party turmoil and the uncertainties that followed the death of Chairman Mao, both party and public have shown a certain lassitude. The new regime, seeking to overcome those tendencies and encourage confidence, has been been brandishing the sword freedom and raising the banner of human rights.

title: Smith Pledges to Leave If He Hurts Peace Talks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 24 (AP) Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he would stay away from the constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia in London next month if his presence proved to be,a stumbling block to a settlement.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold futures rose to records for the third consecutive day yesterday but closed lower after traders took profits, while signs that the Federal Reserve has tightened credit depressed interest rate futures.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchanve, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: New Sculpture at Fort Clinton Blends With the Shape of Its Surroundings
description: Don Gummer with his sculpture in the center of Fort Clinton's gravel courtyard. The piece is one of four commissioned for the onestory fort in Battery Park by the National Park Service and the Manhattan Cultural Council. Made of Canadian blue stone and wood painted black, the sculpture repeats the circular shape of the fort. It is intended to be viewed from all sides, the artist said, as visitors walk past the gun batteries along the fort's loggia. Each side varies slightly, with openings in the stone uprights resembling the fort's doors and gun ports, alternating from inner perimeter to outer. The six sections took three weeks to build and will be on display until Sept. 23.

title: Samuel Bock, Chinatown Lawyer
description: Samuel Selig Bock, a lawyer long active in Chinatown community affairs, died during openheart surgery Thursday at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: U.S. Acts on Insulation Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  In an attempt to prevent homeowners from being victimized by misleading claims about home insulation, the Government is requiring companies to say just how effective their products are.

title: Price Index Goes Up 0.7% Here
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York metropolitan area rose seventenths of 1 percent last month, bringing the increase to 8.7 percent since July 1978, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: Bank Holdups, Rising in Nation, Laid to Growth in Branch Offices
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24  Bank robberies increased by 22 percent, to 2,713, in the United States in the first six months of the year over the same period of 1978, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported. The major reason for the rise, which continued a threeyear trend, was the banking industry's drive to open more and more small branches in cities and suburbs, law enforcement officials and banking executives say.

title: Notes on People
description: I swear, I will not have a baton in my hand for a solid year, said Leonard Bernstein, who has canceled all of his conducting engagements for 1980 in order to take a sabbatical to compose anti writ

title: In Columbus, Visiting The Ohio State Fair
description: I look at the hog. The hog looks back at me with maraschino eyes. Its legs are splayed across a metal rack above smoking coals. There is a green apple in its mouth, and upon its head is the tattooed blessing of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

title: Federal Reserve Seems To Tighten Credit Again
description: The Federal Reserve System tightened credit another notch yesterday, according to money market participants.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Worries about inflation in the United States and rumors of Arab bullion purchases pushed the foreign price of gold to records yesterday for the second time this week. But bullion prices began to ease toward the close of trading in the United States.

title: A.T.& T. to Cut 44 Foreign Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would reduce the rates on customerdialed calls to 44 overseas locations.

title: Your Money
description: WITH the steady rise in retail prices, the rental instead of purchase of many products appears to be gaining in variety and popularity.

title: Miss Ashford Impressive Victor
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 24  Evelyn Ashford made it a night to remember for United States women's track and field with a goldmedal performance in the 200meter dash at the opening night of World CUD II tonight.

title: Draths
description: HELDBelle. On Aug 24, 1979. Widow of Philip J. Dear mother 01 Morton L. Held and Paula Sharf. Sister of Samuel and Abraham Glauberman. Adored grandmother cf Glen, Zena, Kerry, Barry and Erica. Services Sunday 12noon at Sunset Chapels 1285 Northern Blvd Manhasset LI.

title: Market Weakens; Dow Closes Off 0.18
description: Unfavorable economic news weakened the stock market somewhat yesterday with special situation and takeover issues again in the spotlight.

title: Mostly Mozart: 6 Offer Much Joy
description: Of the six musicians who took part in Thursday night's Mostly Mozart program in Avery Fisher Hall, two were relatively unfamiliar  Pierre Pierlot, a French oboist from the Paris Opera Orchestra and a teacher at the Paris Conservatoire, and John Steele Ritter, an American pianist and harpsichordist who teaches at Pomona College in Claremont, Calif. Their colleagues were JeanPierre Rampal, flute; Jaime Laredo, violin; Michael Tree, viola; and Leslie Parnas, cello. Mr. Rampal and Mr. Pierlot knew each other as students at the Conservatoire and were cofounders of a Baroque ensemble in Paris.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY DE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691600; CONNECTICIT (200) 141 7767.

title: White Rhodesians Mourn but Stay Defiant
description: MARANDELLAS, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 23  Don Baker's friends and family came here today to pay homage to him and to reaffirm their dedication to a way of life that each day seems more nerilous.

title: A Better Way to Pick Judges
description: On Primary Day, Sept. 11, registered Democrats in Brooklyn can nominate candidates for eight Civil Court judgeships assigned to their borough. They will confront at least 16 easily confused names on their voting machines, and only the staunchest will remember whom they had planned to support. The processreduces the number of voters to a small percentage of the eligible population  and this handful of votes will be divided this yearAmong the 16 candidates. As result, the names on the machines in Brooklyn will be all, or nearly all, Jewish, a fact that will further reduce the turnout. The problem, of course, is that Brooklyn's often middleclass Jews, practicing good citizenship, exercise their franchise even in relatively minor elections while other ethnic groups do not. The inevitable result is ethnic imbalance among those who are elected.

title: Convicted Slayer Who Has Denied Guilt Flees Prison
description: A man who has for more than 10 years contended that he was only a mugger, not a murderer, and who has made, repeated unsuccessful appeals for clemency, is missing from his cell at the Green Haven prison in Dutchess County. He is the object of an intensive search by the state police and correction guards.

title: In China, Visiting The Roof of the World
description: The camp belongs to Tagarrni People's Commune. The valley below us is wide and open. It is the time of summer migration. Through the green meadows the herds are passing on their way to the summer grazing. The lambs bleat and the ewes answer, and the yaks tread slowly and heavily in front of their calves. The snowy mountains are white as chalk against the deep blue sky. The air is pure and every detail seems emphasized. The cliffs on the other side of the valley are sharp and rough. White clouds form and swirl over the mountaintops. We are sitting on the thick felt rug outside our host's yurt.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Judge Bids Soul City Open Books
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 24 (AP) Judge Joyce H. Green of Federal District Court in Washington has ruled that Soul City must let Government accountants examine its books even though an earlier ruling relieved the project of its obligation to make an interest payment on Federal loan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday included an incomplete quotation from the statement issued after a meeting of black leaders Wednesday. The complete quotation about Jews and blacks working together is: It is also clear that Jewish organizations and leadership have done so when it is in their best interests to do so, as do we.

title: China Accuses Vietnam of Raids And Artillery Attack Near Border
description: PEKING, Aug. 24 (UPI)  Vietnam launched several border raids into China last week and bombarded Chinese territory with artillery fire, the New China News Agency reported yesterday.

title: Drawing Steady Profits From an Old Crayon Box
description: In an era of shortening product cycles and emphasis on marketing gimmicks, Binney & Smith Inc.'s attitude toward its principal product, Crayola crayons, stands out.

title: Phils Stymie Astros, 53, As Carlton Strikes Out 9
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) Lefthander Steve Carlton tossed a sevenhitter, struck out nine and drove in two runs to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 53 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

title: Cartoonists Reach Pact, Ending Strike at 2 Studios
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (UPI) Cartoonists have reached tentative agreement with two more movie studios and will end a strike that began nearly two weeks ago against the cartoon industry, a union official said today.

title: City Computer, Unaware How Good It Is, Fails Twice
description: New York City's $12 million computerized system for keeping financial records, described as the best administrative model that money can buy, was out of commission twice this month, holding up about half the payments due to those who provide goods and services to city agencies.

title: B.P. Cuts Crude Supply, Citing Nigeria Takeover
description: The British Petroleum Company, having losts its assets in Nigeria to nationalization in a dispute over the African policies of the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said yesterday that it had informed most of its thirdparty customers that, starting next month, it would have to stop selling them crude oil.

title: Miller Leads Golf by 3 Strokes on 63132
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 24 Remember Johnny Miller, the blond golf professional who won the United States and British Opens, 16 other tournaments and $1 million between 1971 and 1976? Remember Johnny Miller, who abruptly vanished after 1976 into the limbo of pro golf?

title: Gatemouth Brown Gets Bravos From Russians
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24  Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown and his country fiddle turned them on at a Moscow concert hall Wednesday night, and the young Russian fans crowded to the front of the stage shouting bravo and tossing flowers.

title: Strauss Seeks Unpaid Status for His Mideast Post
description: Special to The New York Times

title: U.S. Communists Meet in Detroit as Party Turns 60
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24  The Communist Party of the United States this week celebrated its 60th anniversary of predicting the collapse of American capitalism.

title: Martin Returns to Giants but Will Miss Clash With Jets Tonight
description: EAST RUTHERFORP, N.J., Aug. 24  George Martin ended his threeday walkout today, but not in time to play in the 11th annual GiantsJets preseason game here tomorrow night.

title: Bank Unknowns: I.R.S. and Times
description: The whereabouts of The New York Times, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the Internal Revenue Service, the Bank of America and the Motor Vehicle Department seem a mystery in an advertisement by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: In Selma, A Bridge Links Eras
description: SELMA, Ala.  An uncomfortable feeling, something akin to guilt, attaches to elegant dining in full view of the imposing steel presence of the Edmund Pettus Bridge.

title: Letter: On Three Mile Island
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 17 editorial Propaganda contains a fact: a valve was involved in the Three Mile Island accident. That valve was manufactured by Dresser Industries, and this has been freely stated by Dresser. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission implies in its early report that the failure was probably due to the control mechanism of the valve, for which Dresser was not responsible. The editorial omits mentioning a number of other facts:

title: China Said to Be Irked With U.S.
description: PEKING, Aug. 24  Senator Henry M. Jackson asserted today that Chinas leaders were frustrated and unhappy about the slow pace of improvement in ChineseAmerican relations in general, and inaction by the Carter Administration on their trade aereement in particular.

title: Deaths
description: DBE RMANGretchen. Congregation Beth Elohim sorrowfully records the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the family. Funeral services will be held at 1:30PM on Sunday, August 26, 1979 at New York Riverside.

title: Complaint on Stove Fire Hazards Is Settled by Montgomery Ward
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)  In the last three years, Montgomery Ward & Company sold more than 200,000 Franklin stoves and wood furnaces with confusing installation instructions, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The instructions apparently posed a potential fire hazard.

title: Envoy Was Economics Expert
description: Henry Joseph Tasca, a career diplomat who specialized in economic matters, had lived in Rome since his retirement in 1974, but he remained an adviser to the United States Government on European and thirdworld economic matters. Acting in that capacity, he organized a meeting of economic experts from developing countries in Rome last March.

title: HERB ELK
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  Herb Elk, pressrelations director for the Houston Astros baseball team, was found dead last night in his room at a hotel in Philadelphia, where the Astros were meeting the Phillies in a weekend series. He was 49 years old. Donald Davidson, traveling secretary for the Astros, said a preliminary examination indicated he had suffered a heart attack.

title: Studs at Second Base
description: One day last summer, a wiry little 75yearold man wearing eyeglasses and a black beret walked into Central Park carrying his Louisville Slugger baseball bat. He was James T. Farrell, and he just wanted to get in a little hattine oractice.

title: Harlem Robbery Suspect Is Shot In a Courtyard Battle With Police
description: A robbery suspect was wounded by the police early yesterday as he and three companions exchanged shots with officers in the courtyard of an apartment building in Harlem, authorities reported.

title: ExHoward Hughes Adviser Gets Prison Term in Obstruction Case
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) former adviser to Howard R. Hughes was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for obstruction of iustice.

title: Mondale Leaves for China
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  Vice President Mondale left for China today and said that he would discuss a whole range of objectives from trade to culture and further normalizing of relations with Chinese leaders.

title: 2 U.S. Steel Plants Face Shutdown
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would suspend operations in late October and early November at two plants in Illinois that employ 1,160 workers because the plants have been unprofitable.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds cover the Northeast, while thunderstorms dot the Ohio Valley and Gulf Coast. Cloudy skies and thunderstorms are also scattered across portions of the Central Plains States and the northern Rockies, while the remainder of the West remains clear.

title: F.B.I.'s 1978 Seizure of $115,000 Linked To Indictment of Sheriff and 3 in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 It was the seizure of more than $115,000 in cash from a safe in the Essex County sheriff's office last year that led to the indictments yesterday of the sheriff, two of his assistants and a former Democratic county chairman, according to an official close to the case.

title: ENERGY COSTS PACE 1% RISE FOR MONTH IN CONSUMER PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  Paced by increases in energy and housing, consumer prices again rose after seasonal adjustment by a full 1 percent in July, keeping the annual rate lodged securely in doubledigit territory.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Greece Tells Citizens To Give Up Smoking. And Stop Overeating
description: ATHENS  Television viewers watch a Governmentproduced commercial showing members of a typical Greek family around a festive dinner table gorging themselves with goodies.

title: Harry W. Colmery, 88, A Former Legion Leader
description: Harry W. Colmery, a lawyer and former national commander of the American Legion, died of an apparent heart attack Thursday, while attending the organization's convention in Houston. He was 88 years old and lived in Topeka, Kan.

title: The Cities Stake in the Meadowlands
description: The deserts and soybean fields of Texas and Georgia aren't the only open places in America that attract developers who want to build from the ground up. New Jersey, for instance, has plenty of open land. But certain kinds of extensive development there could hinder Pf forts to rebuild the state's old cities.

title: Letters
description: GARY KNIGHT

title: News Summary
description: The U.S. succeeded in delaying a vote in the Security Council of the United Nations on a proposed resolution calling for Palestinian selfdetermination, national independence and sovereignty. The delay, possibly for two months, was regarded by many delegates as a significant achievement for Andrew Young, the United States delegate, who had said that he would veto the measure if it was brought up for a vote by Arab delegates and their thirdworld supporters. Mr. Young reaffirmed the Administration's view that the Palestinian issue could be resolved through EgyptianIsraeli negotiations. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Excerpts From Young's Speech to the Security Council Session on Palestinians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23  Following, as transcribed by The New York Times, are excerpts from a speech delivered today to the Security Council by Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of converting a gasoline engine to a diesel engine was patented this week for the J.I. Case Company of Racine, Wis. Joseph T. Kulhavv and Donald G. Shelton were granted patent 4,164,915 tor the process and apparatus. The patent notes that the recent energy crisis has increased the demand for diesel engines because they normally have a higher efficiency and lower fuel consumption than conventional motors.

title: Around the Nation
description: JESSUP, Md., Aug. 24 (AP)  State police and patrol dogs trekked through rural countryside, helicopters buzzed overhead and police cars cruised the highways today searching for the last eight fugitives from a mass breakout at the state House of Correction.

title: Twin Girls Killed and Mother Hurt In a HitandRun Crash in Queens
description: Twin 6yearold girls were killed and their mother was seriously injured last night in a hitandrun accident at an intersection in the Far Rockaway section of Queens, the police said.

title: One Corner on Fifth Avenue Rezoned for Splashing
description: A sign on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 51st Street warning northbound pedestrians of the possibility of an impending cleaning bill. Those on the other side the street are presumably on their own, because there no such sign on that side. The sign was put up because the cleaning of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The process requires great amounts of water, which mostly ends up the street. Periods of rain yesterday added to the flood there and elsewhere about the city. While showers fell heavily across the metropolitan area at times, the total rainfall was not great, reaching threetenths of an inch the city. Weather today should be pretty much the same.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Police Chief Given a Summons
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 24 (AP)  Police Chief Theodore Adams received a traffic summons yesterday in connection with an accident in which his cruiser ran into the back of another car. The 46yearold Chief was northbound on Route 202 about 12:90 P.M. Thursday when he crashed into the rear of another northbound car that was preparing to turn left, authorities said, The police cruiser was heavily damaged, and Chief Adams and the other driver were treated at New Milford Hospital and released, the police said. Chief Adams was accused of failure to drive a reasonable distance behind the other car. with black boots. Miss Arroyo was described as 4 feet, 10 inches tall, weighing 135 pounds, with black hair and brown eyes.

title: Money Problem Licked With Borrowed Stamps
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24 (AP)  County workers today licked 1,500 postage stamps borrowed from the county bar association as they mailed out alimony and child support checks that had been delayed for up to a month because the county could not afford to mail them.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: FollowUp on the News
description: I fully expected to die. Chell Roberts, a Salt Lake City graduate student, was speaking for all 80 passengers aboard the Boeing 727 in April that suddenly spun into a terrifying 27,000foot dive near Detroit. Disaster was averted only at the last instant.

title: Bomb Damages Ulster Buildings
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  A car bomb exploded in Dungannon last night, seriously damaging buildings but causing no casualties, the police said today. The town in central Ulster was evacuated after the police received a warning.

title: An Idyllic Afternoon In an Autumn Forest
description: LITCHFIELD ISAT on a bench by the pond and was peaceful. The sunny autumn afternoon offered itself. The warmth penetrated, the serenity seeped in and, staring off through colorful trees, I dozed.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Tenn., Aug. 25 (AP) Some 2,500 residents were evacuated from their homes for about 12 hours today after highly toxic nitric acid leaked from a tank truck, the police said.

title: Art: A Promise of Excellence
description: It would be difficult to think offhand of a more promising exhibition season than the one that is now coming up in our major museums. Already September, October and November between them offer a liberal education of the kind that would once have been spaced out all over the year; and over that same period anyone who travels around the country can hope to catch at least half a dozen shows of the kind that makes one say Why couldn't it come here?

title: Mayor Kucinich Himself Is Issue In Upcoming Cleveland Primary
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 25  The large red, white and black banner inside the sweltering hall of the Holy Rosary Catholic Church proclaimed: Little Italy Welcomes Cleveland's Black Leaders.

title: Benjamin Out for a Month
description: MIAMI, Aug. 25 (AP)  Guy Benjamin, thirdstring quarterback for the Miami Dolphins, will be out for at least a month after undergoing surgery today to have his appendix removed.

title: Miss Brimmekamp Wed to James Prial
description: Susanne Lingg Brimmekamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Gerd Brimmekamp of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Robinson Prial, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Prial 2d, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Those words that you memorized, Ben Sills tells his daughter, Lena, are not cotton to see how much you can stuff in your sack and get rewarded for. They're rules to live by. They're to aspire to. It means to reach up to something high, with all your heart.

title: Escapees Captured in East River
description: Four men escaped from the city prison on Rikers Island last night, but three of them were captured as they swam through the East River toward the Bronx, officials reported.

title: Peat's an Untapped Resource
description: PORTLAND, Me.  Winter is never far off in Maine, and it seems especially near now as this vulnerable and economically depressed state worries about getting enough homeheating oil and finding the money to pay for it.

title: The Nation
description: Prices rose an even 1 percent in July, an increase that can be taken with equanimity by only a few classes of people: those who hate messy fractions, and those who don't care to travel, use fuel or buy houses.

description: IF THE Tristate Regional Planning Commission wants to keep the rest of its dwindling influence over the future development of region that does not seem to want to be a region, it should give up half the area it supervises.

title: Vineyard Race Offers Challenge With No Fastnet Backlash Seen
description: Once more, sailors are gearing up for what one veteran describes as a wonderful obstacle course. In the case of the Vineyard Race, the obstacles are a light tower, an island and the shifting winds and currents in Long Island Sound.

title: Hungary's Leading Writer Is Facing Official Curbs
description: TIHANY, Hungary, Aug. 22  At 77, with a lifetime of poetry, fiction and sociology behind him and a number of the most noted prizes of literature to his credit, Gyula Illyes should be above the hurlyburly of literary survival in an East European country.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  United States allpro funny car drag races, muscular dystrophy benefit; at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J. Gates open 1 P.M.

description: DETROIT, Aug. 25  The Environmental Protection Agency has granted five automobile manufacturers twoyear delays in having some of their engines meet the 1981 standards for carbon monoxide emissions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Concerts in the Offing
description: Liza Minnelli, Carnegie Hall. Sept. 414.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is the season when efforts expended in the vegetable garden pay off. No other produce can compare with that freshly harvested from one's own garden and immediately prepared for the table.

title: A Riding Family...
description: WHITNEY CROSBY is a member of Westchester's horsey set, with a 7yearold mare named Topper, a wardrobe of riding clothes that cost more than $1,000 and a schedule of shows and lessons that takes up every afternoon and weekend.
