description: EAST HAMPTON

title: For Tristate Agency, an Uncertain Future
description: IF the Tristate Regional Planning Commission wants to keep the rest of its dwindling influence over the future development of a region that does not seem to want to be a region, it should Rive uo half the area it supervises. That is the conclusion of a task force on the agency's future.

title: Jets Beat Giants By 146
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 25  Matt Robinson threw two touchdown passes, and Chris Ward and Gary Jeter threw punches tonight as the Jets beat the Giants, 146, in what was more of war than a preseason football game.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: A s the Bolshoi Ballet closes its season today, it obvious that this season was the most successful one by any foreign ballet company to visit New York this year. Only the Netherlands Dance Theater. under its new artistic director, Jiri Kylian, was more warmly received across the board but attendance at the City Center was a great deal smaller than the Bolshoi's sellout houses at $30 top in the New York State Theater.

title: Mobile Movie Program Is Rated a Big Success
description: On an especially humid evening recently, residents of East Fourth Street, in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, cooled off by sitting on their front lawns, watching Coney Island's famous roller coaster, the Cyclone, run through its tour of dips and curves. No, the Cyclone hadn't jumped its tracks at the amusement park and taken the elevated line to Midwood. It was there on an outdoor screen, along with 19 other films that traveled that evening to Midwood via Filmmobile, a free, traveling show of short, independently produced films, offered for the first time this summer by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: When Corporations Get Up and Leave Town
description: WASHINGTON  American corporations have found themselves yet again with one foot on each side of the fence.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Island boasts but a handful of Mexican restaurants (not counting the fastfood places), and Hacienda Don Pancho in Merrick is one of the more elaborate examples. Despite a simple, storefront exterior, the dining room is large and heavily decorated with every possible southoftheborder clich: stucco walls, dark wood beams, wroughtiron accessories, pottery, serapes, sombreros, pierced tinware, pitiatas and paintings on bark or depicting battles. A strolling mariachi group entertains on Thursday through Sunday evenings, enlivening an otherwise somber, inadequately illuminately atmosphere.

title: Miss Bator Has Nuptials
description: Francesca Bradley Bator and William Philip Johnson were married at noon yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Padanaram, South Dartmouth, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Ronald Crocker. The Rev. Harry Dooley, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bridegroom, assisted.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Among the scientific goals of the Soviet Union is a permanently manned orbital space station. To that end, Russian astronauts have been spending increasingly long periods aloft, and last week the new record holders, Lieut. Col. Vladimir Lyakhov and Valery Ryumin, a civilian engineer, came down in Kazakhstan after 175 days. The previous record, also set by a Soviet team, was 139 days.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The theater has condemned itself to death and must hand over its inheritance to the cinema, wrote the Russian poet Vladimir Mayakovsky in 1913. With his customary flair for hyperbole, Mayakovsky may have overstated his case just a bit. And yet, there is no denying the fact that for much this century, the cinema has put the theater  at least the realistic theater  on the defensive, forcing it to rethink its raison d'tre. The theater can, of course, assimilate certain cinematic effects  simultaneity, rapid crosscutting between scenes, and so on. But when it comes to suggesting that what we are witnessing is set in the real world, a tangible world of physical objects that Marxists like to call material reality, the cinema clearly has the upper hand.

title: Should Voting Be Mandatory?
description: AS ALL political commentators, pollsters, pundits and politicians are well aware, Bergen County and New Jersey are suffering from a serious case of political apathy. Fewer and fewer eligible voters are going to the polls.

title: 2 Theaters Driving For Subscribers
description: CAN the Island support two professional, nonprofit yearround theaters? Members of the Nassau Repertory, which up to now has played second fiddle to the widely acclaimed, innovative PAF Playhouse, think so. And to prove it, the Nassau Rep, which revives theater staples, is mounting an extensive campaign to establish itself, in the process challenging PAF, which until this year specialized in producing new plays.

title: 15 Women Discharged By Army 60 Years Late
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 25 (AP)Fifteen women, aged 80 to 91, received their Army discharges this week, 60 years after leaving Government service as wartime telephone operators in France.

title: A Tribute to a Mighty 1800's Mule
description: BELLAIRE, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP)  At the city limits is a sign paying tribute to Jacob Heatherington and his mighty mule.

title: Diplomats Go At Snail's Pace In Airport Talk
description: In the brightly lighted waiting lounge at Gate 10, United States and Soviet officials and an attendant cast of security men and bewildered passengers were all caught up in a snailpaced choreography of delicate high diplomacy yesterdayand the leading lady was not even in sight.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Traditional crafts show: work by Berman, Clark, Hart, Weigel. Farmington Valley Arts Center, through Saturday 11 to 4 Thesday through Saturday, 1 to 4 today. 6781876.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: House on the Sound Resounds With Jazz
description: LARCHMONT THE Vollmer home here faces a scenic cove of Long Island Sound where on many occasions the quiet environs of 11 Dogwood Lane reverberate to the rousing sounds of live, traditional jazz.

title: TV VIEW
description: Editing tends to be a dirty word in television. Typically in television news organizations, an editor is someone who cuts film or videotape on demand. The title managing editor may actually belong to the head of the assignment desk. While these are key jobs, they are not normally occupied by people with power to say to a newsgatherer or a documentarian, You haven't done it right.

title: Christina L. Madden Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Christina L. Madden to Charles Seymour Whitman 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. H. Adams Ashforth of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Civil Court Judge and Mrs. Whitman Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., and a grandson of the late Mr. Whitman,who was Governor of New York from 1915 to 1918.

title: TELEVISED GAMES IN NEW YORK
description: There will be 60 regularseason N.F.L. games televised in the New York area this season. All the Giants home games have been sold out, and Channel 2 is expected to televise these eight contests. The Jets expect to have sellouts at several of their home games, which will mean a lift of the local blackout and a telecast by Channel 4. When a Jet home game is not sold out, and is therefore blacked out, an outoftown game will be televised in New York. The local stations will televise all Jet and Giant away games.

title: Joyce on the Continent
description: First witness: He drooped like a rag. He looked around as if he were lost. He was as passive as a repentant sinner and exuded humility. Walking the streets with his head in the clouds or entering the classroom with a pious bow, pinched face, and sheep's eyes, he looked like the Grand Black Knight in the Lodge of Benevolent Death.

title: Ann Elizabeth Stillman Is Married to William B. Wilson
description: Ann Elizabeth Stillman, a marketing coordinator with the TAD Technical Services Corporation, a contract engineering concern in Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to William Burton Wilson, an employee relations specialist with the aircraft equipment division in Wilmington, Mass., of the General Electric Company.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  According to Nicholas Carbone, Hartford's Deputy Mayor, 61 percent of the city's population lives on fixed incomes, either welfare, unemployment compensation or Social Security benefits. And Mr. Carbone, who wants to be Hartford's Mayor, says that it is his skill in bringing in state and Federal money  with an urban policy expertise that President Carter recognized by summoning him to the Camp David economic conferences  that has kept the city afloat.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: PATERSON A DOLLAR may not buy much these days, but in Paterson it buys a house. That is because the city has embarked on an urban homesteading program whose twofold purpose is to offer home ownership to those who might otherwise not be able to afford it, and by doing so to halt the spread of blight often triggered by the presence of dilapidated, boardedup houses.

title: Filipino Pistol Practice Results in Two Deaths
description: MANILA, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  A policeman taking target practice with his pistol in his backyard committed suicide after missing his target and hitting his wife, the police said today.

title: THE PEOOLE'S CHOICE
description: What would you buy this fall if you had to choose just one article of clothing? Several prominent personalities offer some thoughtprovoking and wideranging answers to this question.

title: DINING OUT
description: HARTFORD LIKE many restaurants, 36 Lewis Street has a day self and a night self. Unlike many, it has the luxury of welldesigned space. By day this twoyearold Hartford estahlishment projects an image of youthfulness and intense busyness and offers a luncheon menu that is lively, light and wellsuited to a downtown office clientele. The spacious, highceilinged Garden Room is ringed with hanging plants and its glass roof adds to the sense of openness.

title: Water Samples Secured At Crippled Atom Plant
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Aug. 25 (AP) Technicians have drawn the first samples of radioactive water from the basement of Three Mile Island's Unit 2 nuclear reactor, a spokesman for the plant said today.

title: Dispute Over Oil Spill Imperils U.S.Mexican Talks
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)  President Jos Lpez Portillo has indicated that a Washington proposal for talks on compensation by Mexico for damage caused by a spill from a runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico could affect his meeting with President Carter next month.

title: GCUBAN PLAN FACING CHALLENGE AT TALKS
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25  Led by President Tito of Yugoslavia, a group of third world leaders are reportedly planning to challenge a declaration proposed by Cuba for approval at a conference of the socalled nonaligned nations in Havana early next month, sources close to the group said today.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: TEHERAN, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  In an attack on his political opponents, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini told a crowd in the holy city of Qum that Iranians who wanted total freedom craved only bars, brothels, casinos and drugs.

title: Miss Muskie Wed in Maine
description: Melinda Muskie, daughter of Senator and Mrs. Edmund S. Muskie of Kennebunk Beach, Me., and Edward John Stanton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton of West Roxbury, Mass., were married yesterday.

title: Gypsy Moths Take Toll on State Trees
description: TRENTON THE New Jersey Department of Agriculture has reported a statewide decline in trees, due both to the proliferation of gypsy moths, which defoliate wooded areas, and a severe winter, which especially affected the health of dogwood trees in northern counties.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  Nicaragua's new Government today barred anyone from entering the country until Monday as part of a measure to void money it says was stolen by officials of the former Government.

description: Of Special Interest

title: On Language Coinage and Change
description: The great controversy continues. On the one side, the Guardians of the Language (John Simon, Edwin Newman, contrived usage panels, assorted writers of letters to the editor), all grimly determined to preserve the chastity of English from her wouldbe violators. On the other, the socalled Permissivists, among them most practicing lexicographers and linguists.

title: Janet Perkins, Mother of Actor, Ran Wartime Canteen in Boston
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 25  Janet Perkins, mother of Tony Perkins, the actor, died last night in Cape Cod Hospital after a brief illness. Mrs. Perkins, who lived in New York City, had been visiting her son at his vacation home in Wellfleet, Mass. She was 89 years old.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AS WITH all injustices, discrimination exposes its most painful characteristics when it affects one directly.

title: CHANGES SINCE LAST SEASON
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN wood shingles on the outside walls of a house start to warp or pull loose at the lower ends, it is usually possible to make a quick repair simply by nailing the raised corner or edge of the shingle back into place.

title: Coal Industry Is Ailing Despite New Energy Goals
description: JASONVILLE, Ind., Aug. 25 (AP) year ago Dave O'Bryan's job at the Latta mine of the Peabody Coal Company was more demanding and paid more. But Mr. O'Bryan says he is lucky: He is still working.

title: Long Island/ This Week;
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  Group exhibition; Saturday through Sept. 27; 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. weekdays; noon to 8 P.M. weekends; Peter S. Loonam Gallery Ltd., Main St. Reception 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. Saturday.

title: Cable Cars Running Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 (UPI) The cable cars returned to the streets of San Francisco yesterday after an eightday shutdown caned by mechanical problems. The city has undertaken a multimilliondollar refurbishing program that it hopes will end repeated breakdowns in service on the popular openair vehicles.

title: Keeping Abreast Of the Air Fares
description: One prospect is certain for air fares: Like much else in this time of inflation, they are going up, up, up.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVINGTODAY, Aug.26 VOLENDAM (Holland America). Left Bermuda Aug. 24; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Professional Rodeo Riders Get a Hall of Fame
description: In the northwest corner of Colorado Springs, Colo., sits a new tourist attraction, the Prorodeo Hall of Champions, a twostory triangular building of agate and concrete, which houses the Hall of Champions on the 17,000squarefoot lower level and the national offices of the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association on 10,000 square feet upstairs.

title: INTERVIEW
description: COMPETENCE in language and writing is the first step to career success, Dr. Herman A. Estrin said with conviction, and for anyone in a technical field. it is esoeciallv valuable.

title: Jazz Swings Back to the Cabaret Scene
description: Since the subject is jazz, it should not be surprising that even the trends swing  in this case, from one extreme to the other. During the past couple of years, the trend in New York jazz was toward the avantgarde. After more than a decade in the relative obscurity of lofts and a failed effort to make a festival out of the loft scene, the experimental side of jazz began to move into the spotlight  at the Public Theater, at Symphony Space, in such clubs as the Jazz Emporium of Beefsteak Charlie's at 12th Street and Fifth Avenue, the Tin Palace, Sweet Basil, 7th Avenue South and, most recently, at Squat Theater.

title: BRIDGE
description: Adecade ago American bridge enthusiasts were stunned by some news from Brazil. For the first time, and so far the only time, there was no American squad in the world team championship final. A strong United States sextet had been beaten in the preliminaries not only by their old rivals, the Italians, but also by an unknown Taiwan team with two unknown captains and playing an unknown system.

title: 2 Killed, 10 Are Hurt In New Rochelle Fire At Home for the Aged
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP)  A fire at a home for the aged that was not brought until control until early this morning killed two elderly women and injured two firemen and eight policemen. Officials said the blaze may have been the work of an arsonist.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AS Karol Cardinal Wojtyla, Pope John Paul II visited Felician College in Lodi on two occasions, in 1969 and 1976. This came as no surprise because the Order of Felician Sisters, which runs the college, was founded in Poland, and Pope John Paul has a special rapport with the order.

title: Preparing for the Fall Season of Crafts Classes
description: IBOUGHT pottery at fairs for two years before I finally enrolled in a class so I could make my own. Now Claudia Schwartz, from the Guilford area, supplements family income by selling her own pottery.

title: A COOL BLONDE AND
description: July 13 is a hot and airless Friday in Philadelphia. Inside the soldout Tower Theater, tempers and temperaments are running high among 3,100 young fans eager to see the hottest new presence on the popmusic scene  the sixmember rock band Blondie on its summerlong national tour.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 2) For Our Times: 50 Years of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

title: Sandra Beth Rosenman Bride
description: Sandra Beth Rosenman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Rosenman of Bayonne, N.J., was married last night to Bruce H. Lenore, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Lenore of Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Zachery Heller performed the ceremony in Temple EmanuEl in Bayonne.

title: Wine
description: On March 4, 1976, at the Monredon Bridge in the old French city of Narbonne, a gun battle broke out between a group of farmers and the not police. The growers used carbines and rifles; the police used tear gas and submachine guns. A grower and a police officer were killed. What was the fight about? Wine.

title: On the Go Again
description: THE OLD PATAGONIAN EXPRESS By Train Through the Americas. By Paul The roux. 404 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $11.95.

title: CHESS
description: The trickiest part of using some of the currently favored sophisticated defenses is setting them up properly. After all the bricks are in place the defensive edifice is unassailable, but if they are not laid in the uniquely correct order the foundation may collapse before it has anything to support.

title: Florida Pilot Is Rescued After Crash in Catskills
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 25 (UPI)A Florida man was found alive in his crashed twinengine plane today, more than a day after the craft went down while attempting to make a landing in fog at the Sullivan County airport.

title: Theater Emptied in Bomb Scare
description: The audience watching A Chorus Line at the Shubert Theater last night was evacuated shortly before 9 P.M. and stood outside the building at 225 West 44th Street for 30 minutes because of a bomb threat. After the police and theater per sonnel searched the building and found no bomb, the performance of the musical re sumed.

title: Allen Directs Chiola Hanover To Easy Yonkers Trot Victory
description: YONKERS, Aug. 25  Chiola Hanover, a horse that finds it much easier to win than have his name pronounced correctly, took the lead at the halfmile mark and was never seriously challenged in winning the 25th running of the $237,765 Yonkers Trot, the first leg of the trotting triple crown.

title: Engagements
description: BREGMANCASSEL

title: Text Monmouth Winner On Claim of Interference
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 25  They came thundering down the stretch, Cox's Ridge and Text, matching stride for stride and neither showing any inclination to waver.

title: In Border Towns, Mexican Children Crowd Into Overburdened Schools
description: SAN LUIS, Ariz., Aug. 23  There go my six new classrooms, said Jim Wornbacher, cradling the steering wheel of his dustcovered Pontiac with his left hand and pointing with his right at a weathered sign, Lotes Ventas  Lots for Sale.poverished part of the United States. As is true of many border towns, there is little revenueproducing industry here in San Luis.

title: Tank Trucks Are Used in Cleanup Of 500,000 Gallons of Oil in Creek
description: WALNUT GROVE, Mo., Aug. 25 (AP)  Work crews used huge tank trucks today to clean up more than 500,000 gallons of crude oil that spilled into a creek after an oil pipeline burst yesterday.

title: 800 NUMBER IS A KEY TO INFORMED PUBLIC
description: ALBANY  Eight hundred is a number that is changing the way New Yorkers are reaching their government.

title: The Steelers
description: PITTSBURGH JUST across the Homestead High Level Bridge, next to the union monument dedicated to workers killed in the Carnegie Steel Company strike of 1892, is Chiodo's Tavern. If you have trouble finding it, ask directions from the old guy in the Tshirt squinting out his apartment window above Russian Club No. 4, and he'll point it out with his fist wrapped around a can of Iron City Beer.

title: Housing for Elderly Gains in Great Neck
description: GREAT NECK EDITH MONNIER is a 68-yearold widow with a total income of less than $300 a month from Social Security and a veteran's pension. For the last two years, Mrs. Monnier, a Great Neck resident since 1940, has paid $140 a month to rent room in the Great Neck Women's Club. She would much prefer to live in an apartment, but she says it is virtually impossible on her limited income.

title: ExSurgeon, at 75, Heads Art Program
description: AT the age of 75, Dr. Kaare K. Nygaard of Scarsdale is embarking on a new adventure at a time when many are thinking of leisure and retirement.

title: Minority Students Sought for Engineering Careers
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)  I couldn't watch, DeWayne Davidson said. II turned my head.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It was 1938 when I first heard that Francis Ford Coppola had begun working on Apocalypse Now. I was playing pinochle with several other boys on the steps of Lithuanian Hall on West Lombard Street in southwest Baltimore when Milton Sommers came running up with the news.

title: The French Connection
description: THE explosion of the first nuclear bombs at the end of World War II generated a number of troubling questions not only about military power but about scientific power as well. Who or what controls science and technology? Are the results of research determined by the laws of nature, the ambitions of scientists, military exigencies, industrial interests, the will of the people? In the decades of technological expansion since the bomb, answers have been slow to emerge. Particularly puzzling has been the position of scientists, who have increasingly argued either that it is not their place to shape science policy or that they are ineffectual when they try.

title: Closed Primaries: An Open Question
description: PRIMARY elections are peculiar to the United States. In no other democracy are voters given the opportunity to choose between competing contenders for a party's nomination. Yet rules governing primary elections vary widely among the 50 states, and for each state those rules must be examined to see whether they are appropriate for the state's own situation and needs. In New York, they clearly are not.

title: Research Ship's Course Is Diverted to Oil Spill
description: MIAMI, Aug. 25 (AP)  Instead of steaming through the Gulf of Mexico studying fish and other oceanic life, the Miamibased scientific research vessel Researcher will be sent by the Federal Government to track the world's largest oil spill.

title: Housing Bias Fought in Elmont
description: ELMONT WHEN Richard McCabe walked into a realestate office here not long ago and inquired about homes for sale in the community, the agent, he said, stubbornly avoided showing or mentioning any Elmont listings.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hydrofoils Set for Lake Ontario
description: TORONTO, Aug. 23 (AP)  Hydrofoil service across Lake Ontario between Toronto and Youngstown, N.Y., will begin in May, according to John Rahn, president of Royal Hydrofoil Cruises, the Floridabased company that will provide it. He said that three hydrofoils would be used. Each can carry 225 passengers and will make the trip in about 40 minutes.

title: Hitting the High Notes
description: New York City Opera opens at State Theater, Naughty Marietta. Aug. 30.

title: Editors' Choice
description: BURGER'S DAUGHTER, by Nadine Gordimer. (Viking Press, $10.95.) The daughter of a South African political martyr struggles to keep her father's cause alive and to find an identity of her own: a dazzling novel.

title: CAMERA
description: Enticed by travel, adventure and a desire to be a witness to and a recorder of eventsplus the healthier marketplace that has developed due to the return of picture magazines such as Life and the influx of various European magazines like Geo  photojournalism has been making a strong comeback in this country. As a result, more and more photographers are becoming interested in careers in photojournalism.

title: The Auto Workers' Windmill
description: The United Auto Workers showed last week that they want action on energy: they briefly stopped production lines across the country to protest political inertia in Washington. We're glad that U.A.W. members all seem to know that they have a stake in an energy solution. But their own program, the Campaign For Lower Energy Prices, is itself a depressing denial of the roots of the problem.

title: Sculptures Stand Out In Sumptuous Setting
description: SANDS POINT THE Island has had its share of elegant estates, but many of them, developed at the turn of the century, have disappeared. Some have survived, however, and it is fortunate that they have been opened to the public as museums. Places such as the Frick, Vanderbilt and Marshall Field estates have become major cultural assets on the Island.

title: Tips for Home Sellers Seeking $100,000 Exclusion
description: Age is not the only test that must be met for the house seller to qualify for the $100,000 exclusion. The taxpayer must have owned and used the house as his or her principal residence for at least three years in the fiveyear period preceding the sale.

title: Other World Events
description: Eschel M. Rhoodie may have had his last chance to put up before being shut up. Extradited from France, Mr. Rhoodie, the former South African propagandist who fled the country last November, returned home under armed guard last week to face charges of stealing part of a $75 million slush fund meant largely to buy foreign friends for apartheid. While on the run, Mr. Rhoodie claimed to have evidence implicating Prime Minister P.W. Botha in the scandal surrounding the fund; South African prosecutors suggested last week that his trial might be held in camera.

title: ART
description: SOUTHAMPTON RENE MAGRITTE (18981967) is one of the most enigmatic figures associated with Surrealism  a movement that was itself often obscure and contradictory. The Surrealist ohilosonhy. erowing out of the anarchistic Dadaism and fostered by the creative turmoil and experimentation sweeping Europe in the 1920's, was largely devoted to the development of an irrational, subjective and revolutionary expression in literature and art.

title: The World
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  The largest hotel in town had just lowered its exchange rate to 8.5 cordobas on the dollar, from the official 10, and the head of Nicaragua's Central Bank was upset. Tell them we're considering putting a Government exchange office in the hotel, Arturo Cruz instructed an aide. It was no idle warning  the Government now owns a quarter of the hotel. Within 48 hours, the exchange rate was raised to 9.5 crdohas for cash transactions, and a notice posted that the official rate was higher.

title: Torn Up Field Postpones Doubleheader in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)  Lee MacPhail, the American League president, was on hand tonight when a twilightnight doubleheader between the Baltimore Orioles and the Chicago White Sox was postponed because the field was deemed unplayable.

title: Notes
description: As summer wanes, fall's promise of a good harvest catches the fancy not only of growers and gardeners but also travelers, who this year have an especially healthy crop of fall fairs and festivals to choose from.

title: The Draw for the United States Open Tournament
description: MEN'S SINGLES

title: They Heard the Cheers
description: When Bill Heinz and Skipper Lofting got to Conroe, Tex., they learned that Roy Harris was a lawyer now and head of Roy Harris Real Estate and also clerk of Montgomery County.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: TO raise money for political campaigns, so far this year the Republicans have raffled off two automobiles, and the Democrats in one town sold chances on fuel oil. The Democratic Town Committee in Darien, however, auctioned the Senate majority leader, Joseph I. Lieberman, or at least his services as tour guide and luncheon partner.

title: Music: All Eyes Are On Opera
description: Probably you remember the old New Yorker cartoon. A vine of some voracious sort has gone mad and thrown itself several times around a house, entangling in its grip one of those indomitably scruffy George Price males. From a window a disheveled woman is crying out helpfully: Watch out, Fred! Here it comes again! Well, once a year at about this time every obsessive music listener in New York must feel like Fred. Here it comes again: the season.

title: Anne Whitehead, Lawyer, Wed
description: Anne Elizabeth Whitehead, daughter of John C. Whitehead of Essex Fells, N.J., and Mrs. Helene S. Whitehead of Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday in Essex Fells to Bernard Keating Crawford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crawford of Montclair. N.J.

title: Vindicated Priest Questions Power of Policemen
description: ST. GEORGES, Del., Aug. 25  For five years, as the Roman Catholic chaplain at the Delaware State Mental Hospital near here and as chaplain of the Newcastle County Police Department, the Rev. Bernard T. Pagano came into close and not always sympathetic contact with lawmen.

title: A ShoeSandal for Men: Surprise Summer Hit
description: It's known variously as the fisherman's sandal, the dress sandal, the city sandal and the British Colonial sandal; for a change of pace, it's also referred to as the Tstrap shoe or the cutout shoe. By whatever name, it's a shooin for the title of summer's surprise best seller. men's footwear division.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Jesus Christ Superstar. Starring Alain Van Achte. Tonight at 8 P.M., Wednesday to Saturday at 8:30 P.M., and next Sunday at 8 P.M. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: Rock: The Cars Play at Festival
description: The Cars, a rock band from Boston that appeared at the Dr Pepper Festival in Central Park Friday night, have probably inspired more corny metaphors from rock writers than any band in recent memory. Readers of this review, whatever else they may derive from it, can at least take solace that they have been spared motoric imagery.

title: Cowboys Defeat Steelers on LastSecond Field Goal
description: IRVING. Tex., Aug. 25 (AP)  Rafael Septien, who missed a pointaftertouchdown attempt in the second quarter, connected on a 47yard field goal with two seconds to play tonight to give the Dallas Cowboys a 1614 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: HeatingOil Prices Worry MetropolitanArea Cities
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 24  Despite the Carter Administration's proposal for $1.6 billion in special assistance to offset the cost of home heating oil for the poor and elderly. officials in New York. New Jersey and Connecticut continue to express concern that the rising energy costs will put a major burden on the cities this winter.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Behind the Waste Debate
description: JUST before the White Plains City Council was to convene to vote on Westchester County's solidwaste disposal plan, Paul B. Bergins, the city's Corporation Counsel, paced the reception area in his office, accompanied by William F. Maguire, the deputy city clerk.

title: Why Electric Bills Keep Rising
description: MINEOLA EACH time Cora Froehlich of Levittown receives her bill from the Long Island Lighting Company, she adopts the ostrich syndrome.

title: Gina Marie Graham Is Married to Edward Wooster Cook
description: The Church of the Brethren in Lancaster, Pa., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gina Marie Graham of Chatham, N.J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur J. Graham of Mountville, Pa., to Edward Wooster Cook, also of Chatham, son of Georgamay Wooster Fuller of Ithaca, N.Y., and John M. Cook Jr. of CanalWinchester, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John D. Long.

title: Jersey Zoning: After 4 Years, Many Lawsuits, Little Housing
description: Four years ago the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that municipal zoning laws could not be used by localities as screen to keep out lowincome and middleincome people. Since then, legal battles across the state have underscored the complexity of the ruling and the difficulty of reshaping patterns residential development by iudicial order.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Paul Theroux, whose travel book The Old Patagonian Express: By Train Through the Americas is reviewed on page 1 of this issue, is spending the summer on Cape Cod doing what comes naturally  writing. An American who lives in London, he is one of the most prolific writers of serious fiction and fact on both continents. Travel books, short stories, novels all flow from his pen. Does he have a system, we wondered in a recent telephone conversation.

title: April Alexander Married to Mark Cushing
description: April Gay Alexander and Mark Elliott Cushing, graduates of Colgate University, were married yesterday afternoon in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Coleman Brown, Protestant chaplain at Colgate, assisted by the Rev. Christopher Thomforde, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the Old Presbyterian Church.

title: Selling a Trip on the Delta Queen
description: President Carter had not even disembarked last week when the ads of the Delta Queen Steamboat Company started running in the news pages of major papers. Steamboatin', they said. It's still the only way to travel.

title: Click Today, Save Tomorrow
description: THE Hampton System infiltrated the Island in a sort of roundabout fashion. It took off one weekend on the East End during a happy hour, a chance meeting of two advertising executives and a lowkey Long Island duck farmer. He told them about the system.

title: Carl Ullrich Weds Suzanne Stryker
description: The marriage of Suzanne duVivier Stryker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Bartlett Stryker Jr. of Darien, Conn., formerly of Locust Valley, L.I., to Carl Richard Ullrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Farnum Ullrich of Annapolis, Md., took place yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Newberry in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ATLANTIC CITY (Viking Theater, North Carolina Avenue and the Boardwalk) The Mind With the Dirty Man, with Joey Bishop. Nightly at 8:30; Saturday matinee, 3 P.M. (through Saturday) (609) 3485467.

title: Wellness Project for Campers a Success
description: MONTCLAIR FOUR years ago, Dr. William Hettler, a young, athletic physician who had become increasingly concerned about what he calls our illness culture. Drowsed an

title: Reporter's Notebook: 3 Dramas at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25  This turned out to be a week of theater. In three different dramas in and around these precincts, there was one central character  Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate at the United Nations.

title: Sprinting to Moscow
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25  Evelyn Ashford saw the bright lights and scores of newsmen, shook her head and said, I'm not used to this: what is this?

title: FILM VIEW
description: All right. Time's up. You've been away (at the beach, in the mountains, in a place that turned out to be a swamp, on unfamiliar continents) for (two weeks, three weeks, four weeks, the summer), during which time you thought you'd catch up on your reading and see some new movies. Yet instead of Sophie's Choice you read a dogeared paperback of Jackie Oh! and you didn't see one movie except for a part of an anonymous feature on TV that starred either June Allyson or Jill St. John  the reception was poor. You are totally unprepared for the mad whirl of this movie season. You haven't even had time to scan the reviews.

title: Music: Rampal's Mozart
description: A longtime favorite with Mostly Mozart audiences, JeanPierre Rampal presided over the festival's final pair of concerts Friday and Saturday night, spreading his Gallic charm warmly over the musical proceedings as both flute soloist and conductor. Also on hand was the French oboist Pierre Pierlot, who was making his Mostly Mozart debut this summer.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is the season when efforts expended in the vegetable garden pay off. No other produce can compare with that freshly harvested from one's own garden and immediately prepared for the table.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: It is widely believed that business is essentially exploitative, that if left alone it will serve only itself, and that economic competition has been so greatly weakened that it can no longer be relied upon to protect the public. Gone is the conviction that actions to serve enlightened selfinterest in a competitive situation will result in the greatest good for the greatest number. Profits are thought to be excessive and to represent a withdrawal from the stream of national income at the expense of those who need a larger piece of the economic pie.

title: Private and Universal
description: THE DREAM AND THE UNDERWORLD By James Hillman. 243 pp. New York: Harper and Row. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $3.95.

title: 7 CHRISTIANS CHARGE SEOUL WITH TORTURE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 21 Seven young Christian teachers at an adult education institution in Seoul have charged in court that they were tortured in prison by investigators of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Valerie Steele Wed To John S. Major
description: The marriage of Valerie Fahnestock Steele, who is studying for a Ph.D. degree in modern European history at Yale University, to John S. Major, an associate professor of history at Dartmouth College, took place yesterday in Portsmouth, N.H. The Rev. John Lemkul, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. William G. Wendell.

title: Food That's Tastier Made at Home
description: EAST HAMPTON THE idea is: better than storebought, insist Helen Witty and Elizabeth Schneider Colchie, authors of a new cookbook called Better Than StoreBought.

title: Geraldine Petrizzi Is Married To James Dillon, Accountant
description: Geraldine Petrizzi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Petrizzi of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to James Dillon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Dillon of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Robert J. Polli performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Food
description: Arfter years of neglect, terines (or tureens) filled with cold vegetable or fish concoctions have come back into culinary style. These delectable mixes  light in texture and delicate in flavor  are ideal fare during weather.

title: STAN KENTON DIES; INNOVATOR IN JAZZ
description: LOS ANGELES, Sunday, Aug. 26 (AP)  Stan Kenton, the pianist and bandleader who was an innovative force in jazz for more than 35 years, died yesterday at Midway Hospital in Hollywood, Calif. He was 67 years old and was hospitalized last week after suffering a stroke.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN wood shingles on the outside walls of a house start to warp or pull loose at the lower ends, it is usually possible to make a quick repair simply by nailing the raised corner or edge of the shingle back into place.

title: Six Years Ago, Most People Thought Education Had Improved
description: In 1776, upon the arrival of a ship from Belfast and Cork, an advertisement in the Maryland Journal proclaimed that its cargo included various Irish cornmoditles, among which are schoolmasters, beef, pork and potatoes.

title: Ideology Counts for Less
description: Orville Freeman recalls that when he was Secretary of Agriculture in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, United States farm exports to Korea were in the $30 to $40 million range. Now they are over $1 billion, he said last week. Korea's economy, still classified as developing, has grown 10 percent annually for 15 years, and KoreaUnited States trade is close to 37 billion a year.

title: Morocco With a Difference: An Apartment in the Medina
description: While my husband, Dennis, and I were visiting Marrakesh on a working vacation with two friends, Helen and Jim Scott, we hit upon the idea of renting a beach house for the remainder of our Moroccan trip and sharing costs. It would be an ideal arrangement for finishing the animated film project we were collaborating on. So we left the heat of the Gateway to the Sahara and headed due west 100 miles to the nearest coastal town, Essaouira, formerly known as Mogador. None of us dreamed we would soon be living in the medina, or native quarter, with its crabbed alleyways, arches and tunnels that have remained the same since ancient times. It is this experience which left a lingering flavor of another way of life.

title: Stone Estate Loses Kennedy Center Fee Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  The Federal Government will collect most of the fee due the late Edward Durell Stone for designing the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts because of faulty planning, the Court of Claims held yesterday.

title: Martha Sullivan, William Sword jr. Wed in Princeton
description: The Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Martha Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Sullivan of Princeton, to William Sword Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sword, also of Princeton. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Town Readies 2d Compost Unit
description: BROOKHAVEN Town, which already composts more leaves than any other town in the state, will expand its operation this fall, according to Ken Schwindt, supervisor of the town's nineacre composting project in Coram.

title: Runaway Prices for Racehorses
description: SARATOGA, N.Y.  The graceful bay filly pranced around the auctioneer's booth as the bidding crept upward  $310,000, $320,000, $325,000. Come now, ladies and gentlemen, the announcer chided the fashionable audience, gathered at the annual yearling sale here earlier this month. This horse is very inexpensive at this price in this market. The bidding went onto well over $400,000.

title: Sleuths,
description: The new television season will be a celebration of the familiar. Detective and police shows, which had been in hiding for the past few years, are coming back. So, to a lesser degree, are the trusty medical melodramas. NBC will be reaching back into the area of war dramas with From Here to Eternity and into the comedyWestern genre with The Misadventures of sheriff Lobo. And the same network  despite the fizzle of ABC's Battlestar Galactica on last season's launching padwill be taking another flyer on sciencefiction with Buck Rogers in the 25th Century.

title: Technology Separates the Rich From The Poor
description: When specialists at the World Bank decided a decade ago that agriculture in Pakistan needed a technical boost they arranged a loan that led to the purchase of 18,000 heavy tractors that were offered to local farmers at favorable financing. Avid for Western technology, the farmers quickly snapped up the machines, but soon found that their economical use demanded larger plots. Smaller tenants were forced off the land; crop yields remained the same, but the number of workers required fell 40 percent.

title: Plan for 'sex Class
description: HICKSVILLE THE proponents of a planned group of school courses here have dressed it in a fancy title  Strand III, Mental Health. But opponents say it's nothing new; they call it sex education.

title: Freedom and Brothels Equated by Khomeini
description: Freedom and Brothels Equated by Khomeini

title: On the Gas Front: New Hotline Number
description: The gasoline hotline for Montgomery County, Pa., has been changed to 2152754636. The number may be called 24 hours a day every day for information about gasoline availability in the King of Prussia/ Valley Forge historic and recreation area of suburban Philadelphia.

title: CRIME
description: Ever since Nicholas Meyer sprang The SevenPerCent Solution on an unprepared world about five years ago, there has been a spate of Sherlock Holmes pastiches. Now Michael P. Hodel and Sean M. Wright join the club. They have edited a posthumous memoir of Mycroft Holmes, ENTER THE LION (Hawthorne, $9.95). Mycroft, of course, was the older brother of Sherlock: a portly man with equally fearsome deductive powers, but loath ever to leave his premises. Some Baker Street irregulars firmly believe that Mycroft was the father of Nero Wolfe, and strenuous efforts have been made to establish the paternity.

title: 2 Say Jordan Didn't Use Drug
description: Two officials of the President's campaign committee contradicted allegations that Hamilton Jordan used cocaine at a discotheque. Page 17.

title: Susan Hildebrand, A Teacher, Is Bride Of Arthur Ruegger
description: Susan Elsa Hildebrand, who teaches biology at the Spence School, was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to Arthur Hermann Ruegger, a lawyer.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Gloomy economic news eased the stock market into a downturn last week. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had risen about 55 points in the previous four weeks, fell 3.16 to 880.20. A further slide was halted by continued heavy institutional purchasing, which analysts said was an encouraging sign.

title: Executives Taught to Improve Images at Seminars
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  A small group of business executives gathered here recently for two days of intensive training to become more effective communicators and to cope with what some people perceive as an increasingly poor public image of businesses.

title: PROTEST OF KREMLIN OVER JET REPORTED
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25  The Soviet Government has lodged a resolute protest against the action of the American authorities in continuing to hold up the departure of an Aeroflot plane carrying Lyudmila Vlasova, the official Soviet news agency, Tass, said today.

title: Soft Golden Fleece
description: We wouldn't say that Congress does not deserve Senator William Proxmire's latest Golden Fleece award for wasteful spending. As Mr. Proxmire notes,. the Senate and House now employ staffs totaling 18,400 people, costing taxpayers $550 million a year. Our disappointment is that Congress seems too easy a target for a man who has amused, edified and occasionally terrorized the public with his awards. Did he single out Congress this time because congress won't sue him?

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Great Barrington Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Fairgrounds. Route 7 Great Barrington, Mass.; 1,113 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: For Every Man, There's a Woman, etc.
description: ON THE surface, the Sociability Club appears to be just another of New Jersey's many dating services that promise much and deliver little. Like many of its counterparts. it uses matchbookcover advertising, multiplechoice questionnaires and computer readouts.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON IN RECENT years, corporations and businesses of all types have demonstrated an unusual interest in art: collecting and exhibiting it and underwriting shows in museums. In fact, there are those who now consider industry to be the preeminent patron of the arts, the modern Medici.

title: 50 Years Later, a Search for a Child's Lustrous Dream
description: THE sun glistened over the Muscoot Reservoir waters. I had driven my husband to the 7:42, his daily train to New York City, and with halfclosed eves I had scarcely noticed the landscape on the routine run. Returning fully awake, the scenery came into sharp focus. The timeless quality of this unspoiled rural stretch seeped through my consciousness.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: A certain calm seems at last to be settling over the world of oil. After months of turbulence, a combination of factors seems to be smoothing things out: A nearly 70 percent increase in prices by the oil cartel has started taking its toll on demand: a recession in the United States, the world's largest consumer of oil, has begun, further dampening demand, and Saudi Arabia has decided to sell the world an additional million barrels of oil a day to boot. Though the experts are hedging heavily, aware that any new international disturbance could upset the tentative balance, they are starting to say out loud that supplies will soon be in balance with demand and that they will probably remain that way, at least through 1980.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: LETTERS, by Devis Grebu. (Ballantine, $3.95.) Like many other men, Devis Grebu, a Rumanianborn Israeli now living in Paris, has been writing and receiving letters for many years. Unlike many other men, Mr. Grebu is a talented artist able to capture in a few crosshatched lines the passions, lofty dreams, silly scribblings and subtle games that attend their comings and goings. The drawing reproduced above is characteristic of the 50 that this amusing small album comprises.

title: The Region
description: Last week's bank robbery hit list

title: Plane and Dancer Still Held As Russians Protest to U.S.
description: Rebuffing an angry Soviet protest, American authorities continued to hold a Soviet jetliner at Kennedy International Airport early today to determine whether a passenger, a Soviet ballet dancer whose husband defected last week, was being forced to return to Moscow.

title: A Homesick Girl Yearns For 1980 Fresh Air Trip
description: Nineyearold Kharisma Jackson was homesick last week in Harrisonburg, Va. I was crying, she said. I wanted to see my mother. This week Kharisma is back in the Bronx. But now she wants nothing more than to return to Virginia next summer.

title: Deaths
description: PLUMPHoward J., beloved husband of Sondra, loving father of Andrew and David, devoted son of Israel and Charlotte, dear brother of Paul Plump and Phyllis Pickholz. Services Sunday, 9:30AM at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels, Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: Curtains Going Up
description: Losing Time, by John Hopkins, starring Jane Alexander and Shirley Knight. Manhattan Theater Club, Sept. 23.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWIMMERRhoda. The Officers and Members of Local 178, ACTWU, record with sorrow the passing of Rhode Schwimmer, wife of Dr. Frank Schwimmer, Medical Director of the Sidney Hillman Health Center. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Schwimmer and family.

title: Gerulaitis at Crossroads as Open Begins
description: KINGS POINT ON the court he is 6 feet of poetry in motion, his curly blond hair streaming, his lithe form flowing into the ball, his racquet connecting with a solid thud. The shot executed. he dances back to the center of the baseline, bouncing on the balls of his feet, tense and alert, awaiting the return. After a while his face, with its high cheekbones, becomes gaunt. He weighs only about 155 pounds and looks almost fragile. But he is tough, as he has demonstrated in fiveset struggles time and again.

title: Free Service in Nassau Seeks to Avert Blockbusting
description: ELMONT, L.I.  When Richard McCabe walked into a realestate office here not long ago and inquired about homes for sale in the community, the agent, he said, stubbornly avoided showing or mentioning any Elmont listings.

title: Jersey's Metro Park Adds Office Complex
description: Construction has begun on the first phase of a $40 million office project in the Metro Park Executive Center in Edison, N.J., by M. Alfieri Company of Union, N.J.

title: Looking Past the PopMusic Blues
description: The first twothirds of 1979 have found the popular musicbusiness in a slump, both in record sales and concert attendance. Slumps start for all sorts of reasons, and musicbusiness insiders are themselves divided as to the causes of the current one. But slumps also tend to be selfperpetuating. If albums aren't selling, record companies pull back in their support of tours, especially if concerts in turn aren't doing all that well. The resultant smaller number of big, nationwide tours may eventually lead people out of the habit of going to concerts altogether, which could plunge the business even deeper into the red.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Husbands Adjust to Roles
description: WHAT happens to a medical marriage when the person who walks out of the house each morning with the fat black satchel is also a mother and wife?

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: NEW JERSEYANS apparently will have Governor Byrne to kick around for quite some time. In the last month or so, Mr. Byrne has been placing some of his longtime faithful assistants in moresecure jobs, leading to speculation that the Governor himself was planning a move.

title: 5 U.S. Senators Arrive in Soviet For Discussions on Arms Treaty
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  Five United States senators arrived in Leningrad today in the latest in a series of visits by American legislators to discuss the strategic arms treaty with Soviet officials.

title: Nassau Theater Challenging PAF's Preeminence on L.I.
description: Can Long Island support two professional, nonprofit yearround theaters? Members of the Nassau Repertory, which up to now has played second fiddle to the widely acclaimed, innovative PAF Playhouse. think so. And to prove it, the Nassau Rep, which revives theater staples, is mounting an extensive campaign to establish itself, in the process challenging PAF, which until this year specialized in producing new plays.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WETHERSFIELD AUCTIONEERS say that there are three types of auctions. The stars of the business are those sales made up exclusively of fine, early American antiques. Budget sales are auctions of modern household furnishings, otherwise known as used furniture or secondhand goods. And then there are those good, solid estate sales that are the backbone of the general auction business  sales that are a mix of some antiques and collectibles, wellmade reproduction furniture, attractive porcelains, silver, crystal and paintings, all produced before World War II.

title: The Question of Black Leadership
description: Inaccurate statements which appeared in The Struggle to Rally Black America by Paul Delaney (July 15) need to be corrected. Mr. Delaney states: By 1977, when Mr. Hooks succeeded Mr. Wilkins, the N.A.A.C.P. was $1 million in debt. He further states that the membership had fallen below 400,000. These statements are contradicted by the record. In January 1977, the financial report of the N.A.A.C.P. showed a surplus of $133,834,000. At the same time, the membership rolls totaled 426,588. I left the N.A.A.C.P. on July 30, 1977. At no time between August 1931 and July 1977 did the N.A.A.C.P. ever have a deficit as large as $1 million.

title: Three Novels
description: HE title of this novel William Goldman's 11th  rather too adequately sums up the book. A title on the order of Casting would have offered the reader a bit more hope. The book describes the attempt of a superproducer named Julian Garvey to cast what he hopes will be a blockbuster movie, to be called Tinsel. While the suave Garvey is attempting to cast his movie, the fluent Mr. Goldman is casting his net out into the Los Angeles basin, hoping to drag in a novel. Mr. Goldman continues to cast until Garvey finally completes his casting, which is long after most readers will have ceased to care about Garvey, Goldman or Tinsel.

title: Headliners
description: Ordinarily, a birdie is welcome on the golf course; but heck hath no fury like a doctor interrupted in his game. Last week, Dr. Sherman A. Thomas of Washington paid the price of an illegal operation he performed on a Canada goose that interfered with his progress down the 17th green of the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md. The doctor clubbed the goose to death, and Federal prosecutors, who look after such geese, were impervious to his plea that the bird had been wounded by an approach shot and that he was only supplying euthanasia. It cost him $500 in Federal court, but prosecutors dropped charges that might have led to a year in jail.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: NEW ENTENTE CORDIALE
description: Since World War II the American President has been the unchallenged leader of the Western world. He has maintained his position throughout the worst of times  the cold war, misadventures in Cuba, the Vietnam War, the collapse of the dollar, chaos in the Middle East. Our Western allies have accepted an untested President (Kennedy), suffered an unpopular one (Johnson), endured an impeachable one (Nixon) and supported an unelected one (Ford). But under President Carter the traditional United States leadership role has begun to shift.

title: The Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill Illustrates the Dangers
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex.  Through most of history, marshes, bogs, fens and other wetlands have had a negative, sinister reputation  haunts of snakes and bugs, sources of noxious vapors. Extirpating marshlands by draining them, diking them and filling them in was considered a civic good. A century ago, Congress encouraged this in the Swamplands Act. As recently as 1953 the Soil Conservation Service suggested that 75,000 square miles of the nation's swamps might be beneficially filled in.

title: Angela Elizabeth Cuccurullo Is Wed to Peter K. Anglum
description: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Angela EIizabeth Cuccurullo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Cuccurullo of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Peter Kelly Anglum, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Anglum of Mountain Lakes, N.J., and Stratton, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Patrick Grace.

title: Design
description: Chantal and Bruce Thomass met as teenagers growing up in Monfort L'Amaury, near Paris; they married, and now have become a talented fashion team in the French readytowear industry. They have an atelier in Monfort, a boutique in Paris and, adding to the aura of what seems a charmed life, they are restoring, one room at a time, a country house on a hilltop near Monfort that looks as if it were borrowed from a fairy tale. Beyond the iron gate and stone wall stands the small, gabled house with a garden full of vegetables and herbs. Inside the house are acres of oak floors and woodwork, old ceramic tiles, and a still unrestored, ghostly billiard room with Gothic fireplaces. Each room is painted in the palest of pastels: One is a pale lemon, another a pale peach bordered in a faded mauve. Oakframed windows are left uncurtained; here and there a hooked or Oriental rug breaks up expanses of oakplank flooring. Objets here, objets there, each one a story that Chantal, an inveterate collector, never tires of telling. Some were expensive  a Robj porcelain lamp and fashion drawings from the 1920's. Others, thriftshop finds, cost next to nothing. The whole house is a melange of old and new, of taste and patience, inspiring fantasies that begin once upon a time, and end with after.

title: Sculpture at Home in Corporate Front Yard
description: AMID the gleaming silvery office buildings along Westchester Avenue in White Plains is a scene as restful as the vacation homes of the executives who occupy the offices. It is a sculpture garden that offers a haven of grass, red and yellow plants, gently rippling ponds, redbrick paths and craggy terraced rocks.

title: Tax Break Tempts Homeowners
description: Last summer an executive living in Darien, Conn., retired from his job, sold his home and moved to a condominium on the shore. The closing had been set for July 15, but the buyer postponed it until the 28th.

title: Utilities Still Wary
description: NEW HAVEN THE state's electric utilities, having opposed for two years Federal orders to burn more coal and less oil, foresee major problems if President Carter's proposal to require their industry to cut oil use in half by 1990 takes effect.

title: She Once Screamed Rock and Blues, but Now She's Singing Jazz
description: EAST HAMPTON

title: U.S. Aid in Jeopardy For 2 Sewage Projects Being Planned in City
description: Federal funds for New York City's two major waterpollution control projectsthe North River and Red Hook sewagetreatment plants  have been placed in jeopardy because the city and New York State say they cannot meet a deadline specified under the Federal Clean Waters Act.

title: Abortion Bill: Debate On
description: THE County Board of Legislators is considering a bill that would require doctors to notify in writing the parents of a minor seeking an abortion. Those for and against legal abortion differ as to whether the rule would be constitutional, but both sides agree that it will be passed if the committee now studying it reports it out for a vote.

title: Wendy L. Walker Bride in Vermont
description: Wendy Leland Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leland Walker of Barrington, R.I., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Roger Huntington Megroz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Megroz of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Stratton Mountain The Rev. Robert Wallace performed the Protestant ceremony in the Chapel of the Snows in Stratton Mountain..

title: STAY OF EXECUTION IN NEVADA IS ISSUED
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 25 (UPI) The scheduled execution on Monday of Jesse W. Bishop, a convicted murderer who has said he will not resist death in the Nevada gas chamber, was halted today by a stay issued by William H. Rehnquist, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Jersey Public Warned Fish Taken in Streams May Be Unsafe to Eat
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP)  Fish caught in creeks and streams from the New Jersey Turnpike west to the Delaware River may be tainted by high levels of the pesticide chlordane, Camden County health officials said.

title: Architecture: Bigger  And Maybe Better
description: If there is one word to characterize architecture as it stands at the threshold of the 1980's, it is big. There will be bigger buildings everywhere, and contrary to all predictions about the decline of urban centers, construction in big cities is on the

title: A Remembrance Of Things Proust
description: Great cities subsume great men, and the Proustian pilgrim in Pads must be quick of eye to notice a modest plaque at 44 Rue Hamelin, where the novelist died in 1922, or to discover that a pathway in the gardens of the Champs Elysees, where the author, like the Narrator of his book, played as a child, has been renamed the All& Marcel Proust. The building that stands at 102 Boulevard Haussmann bears no sign that in it, in the famous corklined room, Proust set down the major portion of Remembrance of Things Past; nor is 8 bis Rue LaurentPichat memorialized as having at one time housed both Proust and the actress Rejane, one of the models (the other was Sarah Bernhardt) for the fictitious actress Berma. Paris is Paris, and Proust only one of her illustrious sons.

title: American Legion Last Week Gave  the Pact Conditional Backing
description: WASHINGTON  Only a few months ago, political experts nearly all agreed that President Carter faced a close to impossible task in gaining Senate approval for the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. But after a month of Senate hearings, White House aides are confident that Mr. Carter will prevail. Their optimism was reinforced when the A.F.L.C.I.O., the politically influential labor federation, endorsed the treaty and again last week when the American Legion gave it conditional approval.

title: Miller Leads by One Shot
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 25 Johnny Miller, who has rarely been so close to winning a tournament in the last three years as he is now, says he would like to go down to the wire with Tom Watson to see how good I can do. He will have that chance tomorrow afternoon in the final round of the ColgateHall of Fame golf classic.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Time to Cope With Greenhouse Heating
description: The rapidly ascending cost of heating fuel may cause greenhouse gardeners to think twice about pursuing their hobby. A few may even be considering putting their growing space in mothballs for the duration.

title: The Trials of an Ice Cream Man
description: The voice is nothing short of divineAndy Devine. His intonation and cadence are enough to give adults the giggles. And he is on the enemies list of every elocution teacher who ever watched him transform an ordinary television commercial to a 60second comedy of syntactical errors.

title: Mayor Koch Has Continuing
description: The choice of Metropolitan Hospital Center as the main target of Mayor Koch's plan for closing municipal hospitals in New York City was hardly a surprise when it was announced in June. Neither is the furor that the proposal has generated, culminating in the resignation last week of Haskell Ward, the Deputy Mayor for Human Services and the top black official in City Hall, who quit rather than go ahead with a plan that he himself presented to the Mayor two months earlier.

title: Knocking The Nukes
description: MOST people are rightly worried about the dangers of nuclear power. Are reactors safe enough  or will we eventually have an accident far worse than the close call at Three Mile Island? Can we find a way to store radioactive waste safely? Will the spread of nuclearpower technology accelerate the spread of nuclear military power? The debate has become so polarized that it's hard to find trustworthy answers. Each of the books under review portrays the hazards of nuclear fission. None is a satisfactory guide for the perplexed citizen.

title: The Vision of Elijah
description: By 9:30 AM. the heat of a summer's day is already radiating off the little bit of sidewalk in front of Elijah Pierce's barbershop in Columbus, Ohio. The pink hollybocks growing by the side of the shop seem to thrive on it; so do the corn and tomatoes out back. The shades on the beauty salon across the street are still drawn, the iron gate locked tight across the window, but Elijah Pierce is open for business.

title: Camping Out Close to Camp David
description: I had always felt that there was something completely inaccessible about the area around Camp David, the rustic Presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains, which so frequently figures in the news but where few persons below Cabinet rank ever tread.

title: The Time for a Decision Is Getting Near for Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON  While President Carter was steaming energetically down the Mississippi River aboard the Delta Queen last week, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was beating his way up the New England coast from the Cape to Maine on his 55foot sailboat Curraugh. This maritime coincidence aside, the two Democrats who may be rivals for their party's 1980 Presidential nomination were engaged in entirely different pursuits. The President was campaigning at full throttle. The Senator was vacationing out of the public eye with a small crew of friends, perhaps pondering in odd moments whether he was prepared to trade such private sport for the rigors and dangers  of a national campaign.

title: $800,000 Is Awarded To Woman Who Said Drug Caused a Cancer
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)  A Chicago woman who asserted that she contracted vaginal cancer as a result of a drug taken by her mother to prevent miscarriage was awarded $800,000 in damages yesterday by a Federal jury.

title: AirFreight Line Is Struck
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (UPI) Members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers went on strike against the Flying Tiger Line when their contract expired at one minute after midnight today, a spokesman for the airline said. Thomas F. Grojean, president of the airfreight line, said representatives of the airline and the union were unable to reach agreement on a threeyear contract.

title: Deaths
description: FURMANDavid. Temple EmanuE?? of Boro Park records with profound sorrow the passing of its devoted Trustee. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife, Sylvia, and the Furman family. Rabbi Baruch Silverstein Irving H. Fine, President

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The mighthavebeens of musical history! Take the phonograph. Thomas Alva Edison constructed the first phonograph in 1877, but there was nothing the physical theory of the 18th century that would have prevented the machine from having been invented in 1777. In which case we would have examples of Mozart playing his own concertos, of the premiere of the Eroica Symphony, of Liszt and Chopin at the keyboard, of Malibran and Pasta singing Bellini. Dream on, dream on.

title: An Actor Who Found a Home at Yale
description: STRATFORD

title: Nephew of Mob Figure Is Wounded in Village
description: A 21yearold man identified as the nephew of a reputed organizedcrime figure was critically wounded early yesterday when he was shot during an argument betweeen youthful members of two gangs in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error in a letter to the editor by Roy Wilkins in The New York Times Magazine today, the N.A.A.C.P. surplus as of January 1977 was misstated. The figure should have been $133,834.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT BEAUTY
description: Are we liberated when it comes to choosing our lipstick color and hair style, or do we still want to be told what's in and follow suit? Here are the opinions of some observers of women and beauty.

title: Chelsea Town House
description: For several years, many of the 19thcentury town houses on 23d and 22d Streets between Ninth and Tenth Avenues in Chelsea have been sealed up, worrying neighbors, mystifying passersby and inciting envy in the hearts of many developers.

title: The Economy: More Dark Clouds, But Auto Sales Brighten
description: There was little respite from gloomy news last week: inflation remained entrenched at doubledigit levels, consumer purchasing power declined, the money supply jumped another $1.8 billion, and the new Federal Reserve chairman indicated that interest rates are likely to remain high and that the outlook is bleak for a tax cut this year.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: BASEBALL

title: Photography: A Retrospective Air
description: I don't know how to look at photographs anymore, said the director of one of New York's most avantgarde galleries only a month ago. He's not alone. During the past decade, during which photography has emerged as a major presence in the museum and gallery world, promoters of the medium have been running as fast as they can in two apposite directions. In one direction, the past, they have been rediscovering or reevaluating the old masters of 9th and early 20thcentury photography In the other direction, the future, they have been encouraging, even forcing, the emergence of young photographers who would, it was hoped, do for photography what Cezanne, Picasso and Pollock did for painting.

title: THE AMERICAN STYLE
description: Liberated, elegant, seductive: these three compelling words may make an odd team, but they very satisfactorily describe fall '79 American fashion. The best designers have merged the freemoving practicality of American sportswear with a luxury of color, fabric and attitude that epitomizes contemporary elegance. And seeping through everything is a pervasive air of seductiveness, expressed in a kittenish kick, a flirtatious swoosh, a revealing dip, that softens any hard edges the practical clothes may have and removes the aloofness that elegance can impart. This pretty, heady mix has resulted in some of the most beautiful, delightful and desirable clothes to have come our way in many seasons. They are a sort of melding of the unencumbered clothes that were in fashion as 1978 rolled in, and the constricted, wideshouldered, tauttothebody silhouette that appeared to take over as 1978 rolled out. The resulting silhouette is one with a slight broadening of the shoulders, a generally closertothebody line that defines the breasts, the waist, the curve of the hips, and a shorter skirt that looks best hovering somewhere around the knee. As this feminine, flattering silhouette is developed by the large number of good American designers, it takes on a variety of interpretations that will probably appeal to many more women than any of the recent fashion flipflops of this decade. At one extreme there are the controlled  in line, as well as attitude  designs that will bring back fond memories of the security, glamour and correctness of the 1950's. (I'm so glad Donald Brooks is back designing, one buyer of a Middle West specialty shop said. I think women want that again  some of them never did get with matte jersey.) At the other end of the spectrum is Calvin Klein who, perhaps better than any other designer, understands the relaxed, uncomplicated aspect of the word elegance and whose designs most clearly spell out liberated, elegant, seductive  and in doing so, point the way to dressing for the 1980's. In between there are all shades of diverse designs for all sorts of women  from the glamour and unabashed bravura of Bill Blass's designs. to the flirtatious flounces of Oscar de la Renta, to the cool, practical approach to luxury espoused by Halston, to the unconventional but confident style of Perry Ellis, to mention just a few of the remarkable talents working in America now.

title: Mailbox: The Urban Runner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Writing Mocking Writing
description: THERE are some books that deserve unstinting acclaim not because they are perfect (few are) but because they set out to qualify or displace the whole idea of perfect literature. In these books bad writing can become as good as good  an excuse for invention, a playground of pleasure, a way of getting at the stuff from which all fiction, good and bad, is made. Since all literature is susceptible to parody, why not, then, make parody literature? Gilbert Sorrentino has, with impressive results. Mulligan Stew has given me as much pleasure and intellectual joy as I have had from a novel in a long time.

title: Raffle Bargain... Scenario for Crises
description: In the daily packet of news releases and proclamations from the office of Mayor Frank Logue of New Haven the other day was the following memorandum:

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR;
description: Re: Riding in the Middle on the 5:45 [a recent Opinion Page article that was a reply to Riding Up Front on the 8:11, also an Opinion Page article]:

title: THEATER
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IF YOU happen to spot a swarthy, curlyhaired man of medium height bustling about the George Street Playhouse  greeting friends, answering calls, brushing past palebrick walls and sporting a harried thougn nappy smile  me same man may be observed, almost simultaneously, gripping a briefcase or manuscript as he enters New York theaters or rehearsal halls.

title: MUSIC
description: ASPEN, COLO. YOU have to keep your attention level high, the conductor Murry Sidlin was telling the orchestra during a rehearsal of the Brahms First Symphony. I know there are a lot of distractions, but the music has to come first. If you don't hold your concentration, we'll all be wasting our time.

title: Rene Linda Weinstein Sets Oct. 7 Nuptials
description: The engagement has been announced of Renee Linda Weinstein, daughter of Mrs. Lucille Arditti Weinstein of White Plains, and Stanley Weinstein of Los Angeles, to Dr. Thomas Simon Walter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Walter of Wilton, Conn. The wedding is planned for Oct. 7 in Armonk, N.Y.

title: The World
description: By dissolving Parliament last week and calling new elections, President N. Sanjiva Reddy was acknowledging the central fact of Indian politics: that the unity forged in opposition to Indira Gandhi's authoritarian policies has dissolved and no one faction now has the parliamentary support to rule.

title: Other Regional Events
description: New Jersey last week joined the parade of states raising their drinking ages. The Legislature approved a bill to raise the age from 18 to 19. Gov. Brendan Byrne was expected to sign it and three others required to put it into effect. The others require photographs on beginners' driver's licenses, new alcohol education programs and tougher penalties for drinking age violations.

title: Polly P. Arnoff Married To Peter DuPont Cahill
description: Polly Payson Arnoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Edgar Arnoff of Riverside, Conn., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter duPont Cahill, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Francis Cahill Jr. of Needham, Mass., and Stoddard, N.H. The ceremony was performed in Siasconset Union Chapel on Nantucket Island by the Rev. Stanley Johnson, an Episcopal priest.

title: Slump Could Upset State Budget
description: HARTFORD THE economic downturn nationally and a softening in the growth rate of proceeds from the state sales tax are causing concern among some legislators about how Connecticut is going to make ends meet next year.

title: The Evolution of an Apartment House
description: Sidney Esikoff has plans and drawings for the apartment house he wants to build in the Kew Gardens section of Queens. He knows how much to charge the tenants who will live there. He knows how many underground parking spaces there will be. What he does not know yet is whether the finished building will have 22 stories, or 18, or 27.

title: Evelyn Ashford Again Conquers An East German
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25 For the second time in within 24 hours, Evelyn Ashford outran a world recordholder from East Germany in World Cup II, a feat no United States woman had acheived in track and field during the last 10 years.

title: Job Discrimination: The Special Case of Cancer Patients
