description: LOS ANGELES  Jane, a 48yearold bank teller, was back at work last month after recuperating from an operation for cancer of the ovaries and five years after she had a mastectomy. She had the second operation during her vacation and told no one at the office.

title: Some Coming Attractions
description: Yanks, starring Richard Gere, Vanessa Redgrave, William Devane, Lisa Eichorn. Directed by John Schlesinger. September.

title: 1,050 Concerns Run Buses in U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25  There are 1,050 intercity bus companies in the United States, covering 277,000 miles of routes and serving 15,000 communities, 14,000 of which have no other form of intercity public transportation.

title: 2 of 3 Rapists From Jersey Prison Elude Recapture
description: Two rapists remained at large yesterday after escaping from a New Jersey treatment center for sex offenders in the Avenel section of Woodbridge, a spokesman for the state's Corrections Department reported.

title: Russian Shares Bread With Americans on Plane as Officials Debate
description: Strains of Back Home in Indiana drifted through the cabin of Aeroflot Flight 316 as the jet's frustrated American passengers, caught in a diplomatic tugofwar over a Soviet ballerina, waited to hear when, or if, their flight would leave Kennedy International Airport for Moscow.

title: Robert A. Johnson, A Lawyer, Marries Selina B. Pedersen
description: Selina Graham Pedersen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Arno Pedersen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Chautauqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Johnson, son of Mrs. Harry A. Johnson of Camp Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Johnson. The Rev, Eleanor V. Drury, cousin of the bride, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Hall of Philosophy in Chautauqua.

title: Willie Sutton Said It First: That's Where the Money Is
description: He was no John Dillinger or Baby Face Nelson, whose bankrobbing exploits are part of American folklore. He wore a gold earring, and, later, as he prospered, rings on both hands and a gold chain and medallion around his neck. If he carried a gun, he did not display it. His main weapon was a demand spoken so softly that only the bank tellers could hear: Give me your $100's and $50's. Don't do anything funny or I'll blow your head off.

title: Some Old Masters of Photography
description: Fox Talbot and the Earliest Photographs, 183346, at the Morgan Library, Sept. 4Oct. 28.

title: On the Architectural Horizon
description: Aldo Rossi: Architectural Projects, at the Max Protetch Gallery, Sept. 18Oct. 13.

title: Merise Hickey Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Hickey of Little Neck, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Merise Hickey, to Thomas P. Nelson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson of Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Engagements
description: engagement of their daughter, Jodi Sue, on August 7, 1979, to Mark Daniel Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Epstein of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. December wedding is planned.

title: Reds Top Mets, 84, With 5 Runs in 9th
description: The Cincinnati Reds, victors over the New York Mets by onerun margins in the previous four meetings between the clubs, changed the theme at Shea Stadium yesterday. This time the Reds won by an emphatic margin, scoring five runs in the ninth inning to earn an 8to4 triumph.

title: Slash in Tristate Agency's Role Urged
description: IF the Tristate Regional Planning Commission wants to keep the rest of its dwindling influence over the future development of a region that does not seem to want to be a region, it should give up half the area it supervises. That is the conclusion of a task force on the agency's future.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: YONKERS, a city that has had several suspicious fires and arson incidents since early this year, including one July 25 that was fatal to an 86yearold woman, is to consider on Tuesday whether to set up a permanent, arsoninformation reward fund.

title: Why There Is So Much of the Child in the Athlete
description: ROY CAMPANELLA'S contention that there is a lot of boy in every baseball player is intriguing, because it can be taken in several ways. One is that athletes preserve a freshness and intensity from childhood. A contrasting one is that they are overgrown kids, childish and immature.

title: SELECTION
description: When his wife showed me into the living room, he was sitting on the floor in front of a radio, legs stretched out, looking for a station with the help of a magnifying glass. He got up in one easy, sliding movement, fixed his gaze on me for a second through his thick glasses, extended a dry hand. Do you have one of these sets?

title: DINING OUT
description: LAST Feb. 1, one of the state's best restaurants changed hands. The ownerchef of The Swiss Tavern, Hans Alpsteg and his wife, Agatha, who had made pilgrimages into the Ramapo Hills well worth the effort, sold their restaurant, which the Alpsteg family had operated since 1939, to Jean Vergnes and Jean Louis Todeschini.

title: Lisa Hansen Plans Bridal for Sept. 22
description: Lisa Gardner Hansen, a trust and estate administrator in the Bankers Trust Company's personal trust division, and Timothy Nye Burditt, a restoration specialist for North Carolina in Raleigh, plan to be married Sept. 22.

title: Most of the East Is Strong, as Are Steelers, Seahawks
description: The key to forecasting a team's destiny in the National Football League is deciding which opponents within the team's division can be beaten. In this division that is next to impossible, because the top four teams are so competitive. With the exception of the Jets, they have all qualified for the playoffs within the last two seasons.

title: Tanner and Fleming Triumph
description: MASON, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP)  The topseeded Roscoe Tanner defeated Bernie Mitton, 75, 75, today to advance to the final of the $200,000 Association of Tennis Professionals championship tournament.

title: Anger Is Directed at Company in Winchester Strike
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 25  A sixweek strike at the Olin Corporation's Winchester Division, an arms factory here, has stirred bitterness toward the company among residents of the largely bluecollar neighborhood surrounding the plant.

title: SPORTS
description: FAIRFIELD THERE'S a newfashioned game in town, and it's got a bit of yesterday and some of tomorrow in it. Like soccer, it involves a round ball that you kick and goal posts. Like hockey, there are faceoffs but no outofbounds unless the ball goes over the fence. Like basketball, you can dribble and pass with your hands.

title: Mondale Greeted by Deng at Start of His Visit to China
description: PEKING, Aug. 25  Vice President Mondale arrived here today for a weeklong visit to China, which Carter Administration officials said they hoped would move ChineseAmerican relations into a new level of political intimacy.

title: Strauss Wants to Be Seen As Carter's Middle East Man
description: WASHINGTON  A week ago, Bob Strauss was relaxing on a couch in his Cairo hotel suite, complaining to an interviewer about the difficulties of putting together a coherent Middle East policy. We haven't really been able to structure this at all, he said. We haven't handed over the baton neatly and completely.

title: Margaret Nye Bride in South
description: Margaret Jacquelyn Nye and Charles Francis Paterno Jr., who graduated in May from Clemson University, were married last evening in Mullins, S.C. The Rev. William Moore Jones, assisted by the Rev. Edward John Tuohy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Macedonia United Methodist Church. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Lanneau Nye of Mullins. Mr. Paterno is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paterno of Rumson, N.J. Dr. Paterno is director of surgery at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Marriages
description: Sunday, August 19, to Mitchell David Ostrover of New York City, son of Mr and Mrs Harvey Ostrover of Great Neck, N.Y. The wedding was performed by Rabbi Schechter at the Pines Manor in Edison, N.J.

title: Dello Joio Puts Hopes On Allegro
description: Ever since he was 5 years old  that was 17 years ago  Norman Dello Joio had dreamed of competing in an international horse show for the United States.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: T. Cullen Davis is a multimillionaire from Fort Worth, Tex., who Is currently facing his third murder trial. The first was for the murder of his stepdaughter, who was in Mr. Davis's fabulous $8million mansion with his estranged wife, blonde bombshell Priscilla, the time. The second, on charges of hiring a man to kill the judge who had presided at his divorce trial, ended in a hung jury. The third, a retrial, is about to start.

title: Who Did Andrew Young In, and Why?
description: Ten days ago, Representative Parren Mitchell of Maryland, a former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, observed that out on the streets, the perception, the feeling is that the Israeli Government went out of its way to embarrass and humiliate a black man ... The feeling is that somebody did Andy Young in. And when you ask who did him in, the people say the Israelis.

title: Sam Nassi, the Corporate Mortician
description: BEVERLY HILLS  In New York a few weeks ago, Sam Nassi handed over a $3 million check for the inventories of the Franklin Simon chain  42 women's apparel stores  and the Heam's Department Store in the Bronx. The next day the stores were being liquidated, and Sam Nassi, who has disposed of more than $2 billion in retail merchandise since 1971, was headed back to the La Costa resort in California to get some sun and lose some weight.

title: Gold  GoGo
description: It's becoming as easy to buy as a share of General Motors. Citibank announced last week it would begin selling its new gold certificates nationwide, through nearly 500 correspondent banks. And the Canadian Treasury said it would introduce a oneounce gold coin  the maple leaf  that will be available through American stockbrokers, banks and gold dealers.

title: Modern Dance Is Making News
description: Balletophobes unite! This your season. Modern dance is in the ascendancy for the next six months. True, American Ballet Theater, New York City Ballet and the Dance Theater of Harlem will be on hand. But with City Center leading the way with a celebration of five of America's leading moderndance choreographers, and new faces  and performing spaces  cropping up with awesome frequency among the postmodern avantgardists, the news of the season is modern dance.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Seafaring enthusiasts will have a chance today to watch a demonstration of boatbuilding in the 1816 Federalstyle barn of the new Eli Whitney Museum in Hamden. They will also be able to debate techniques with the builder, Bill Atmore, a local resident, who will be seen making a dory of plywood. Mr. Atmore says he is prepared to defend his unusual approach and selection of materials with anyone who cares to challenge him. David Sloane, a director of the museum, explained that Mr. Atmore's ideas come from having been fishing for tuna in the Pacific and having too many boats sink under him.

title: Local Art Doesn't Mean Provincial
description: KATONAH WHEN some people hear word local in connection with art shows, they shudder, and justifiably. Everything that is parochial, imitative and dull, frankly, comes to mind. In tact, local might be construed as synonym for inferior. It rates somewhere below regional, another pejorative.

title: What Is the Alien Message?
description: HE fate of our muchravaged, fiercely resilient earth is emerging as one of the great themes of modern science fiction, alongside such classic concerns as the next step in human evolution and the first contact between our species and extraterrestrial life forms. Three years ago Kate Wilhelm dealt with the first two themes in a sensitive novel called Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang. Now she has mixed the first and the third.

title: Sallie Shuping Bride in South
description: Sallie Murrill Shuping, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hampton Shuping of Greensboro, N.C., was married there yesterday to John Spotswood Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Russell, also of Greensboro. The ceremony was performed in the West Market Street Methodist Church by the Rev. William Douglas Tanner, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Shannon.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: County fairs have come a long way since they began as showcases for agricultural products. Take the Suffolk County Fair, for example, which is being held at the Islip Speedway. This year, the 20th edition of the fair, sponsored by the Suffolk County Agricultural and Horticultural Association, features Smokey Warren and Dottie Mae, countrywestern performers; the Harmonica Rascals the Jack Kochman Hell Drivers. There are also demolition derbies, magic shows and trained animal acts  and, yes, agricultural exhibits.

title: A Father Gives His Young Son A Lesson, and Also Learns One
description: CAN you believe that Mickey Rivers got traded? my son asked. My own incredulity at his asking was great, my pride greater still.

title: Panel on Energy Finds Room for U.S. Growth At an Acceptable Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  The United States can conserve energy and protect the environment without sacrificing economic growth, at acceptable but higher energy prices, according to a report on a threeyear study by a nonprofit research organization.

title: OH, THE CAPTAIN, SHE'S A LADY
description: No question about it; the khakicolored ship was headed straight for us, portside, its two sets of .50caliber mounted machine guns pointing skyward out of the fore and aft turrets.

title: Lee Ann Holderby Bride Of Stephen A. Marquard
description: In the Mountain View Methodist Church in Boulder, Colo., yesterday afternoon, Lee Ann Holderby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Holderby of Boulder, became the bride of Stephen A. Marquard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Marquard of Quogue, L.I. The Rev. Phillip Green, associate minister of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: STAMPS
description: With the cost of overseas travel and accommodations soaring, and with the dollar being battered in most foreign markets, this has been an excellent year for Americans to stay at home and tour the world by way of stamps.

title: Japan's Politicians Preparing for an Election in Fall
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25  Although no formal announcement of elections has been made by the Japanese Government, partisans anticipating early national elections have begun compaigning in the streets, extolling candidates and parties through loadspeakers mounted on cars.

title: Fighting Oil Fires
description: PERTH AMBOY WHEN the telephone rang at the Chevron Oil Company's fire headquarters here earlier this month, the response was prompt. The call was from Mobil Oil on Staten Island. It had been fighting a stubborn blaze for almost two hours and was running low on the foam concentrate needed to extinguish it.

title: Realty News
description: Two new tenants have made commitments for a total of 165,000 square feet of office space in the 48story skyscraper at 1633 Broadway between 50th and 51st Streets.

title: Births
description: BAILES

title: Apartments Are Finally Being Built
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Nearly a century after Mark Twain wrote those lines, much of Connecticut  though not Bridgeport  still has the air of Camelot: comfortable singlefamily homes, green grass and trees surrounded by stone fences. True to its Yankee heritage, the state has resisted efforts to alter that character.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  To listen to Paul A. Volcker, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, at his first Washington press breakfast last week, inflation is just about the only economic variable that matters.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: LAMBERTVILLE FROM the outside, the building looks like it might possibly still house Kooker's Sausage Factory, as it did in the early 1900's.

title: Mindel Takes Marathon At Montreal in 2:26.33
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (AP)  Mark Mindel, a teacher of retarded children in Schenectady, N.Y., overtook Larry Frederick of Ilion, N.Y., with a little more than two miles to go and won the Montreal international marathon today.

title: Deaths
description: ALBE RTLillian beloved wife of Philip, devoted mother of Judith and Jean, loving sister of Ruth Rich, Services Sunday 11:30 AM at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel', Long Beach Rd. at Greystone, Rockville Center, L. I.

title: Baylor Paces Angels' 242 Rout
description: TORONTO, Aug. 25 (AP)  Don Baylor drove in eight runs with a double and two homers, including a grand slam, as the California Angels routed the Toronto Blue Jays today, 242. The Angels scored eight times in the first inning and pounded out 26 hits in the game.

title: F.B.I. Agents Search Of Scientology Office Ruled Illegal by Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  A Federal trial judge, ruling that Federal agents had conducted an unconstitutional search of the Church of Scientology's office here two years ago, last night barred the Government from introducing the seized documents in a criminal trial of 11 top officials of the group.

title: Miss Plowden Wed To Riko Metzroth
description: The marriage of Gretchen Pardue Plowden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Plowden of Riverside, Conn., to Riko Claas Metzroth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rupert Metzroth of Greenfield, Mass., took place yesterday in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony.

title: U. S. Aides See No Policy Shift On Africa After Young Departs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  Carter Administration specialists insist that Andrew Young's departure from Government next month will bring no changes in United States policy in Africa.

title: Impure Science
description: ONE of the few phrases to have achieved immorality in the vocabulary of modern politics is Sir Harold Wilson's the white heat of the technological revolution. Sir Harold originally used it 16 years ago in his first speech as leader addressing the Labor Party Conference  a speech in which he quite deliberately and calculatedly sought to ally the cause of socialism with the march of science.

title: Last Week, the Army Was Accused of Playing a Numbers Game
description: WASHINGTON  During the Vietnam war, Representative Robert W. Edgar was a chaplain at Drexel University in Philadelphia, a counsellor for conscientious objectors who was propelled by the anger and turmoil of the time into a Congressional seat. The Pennsylvania Democrat recently returned to Drexel for a debate over a proposal before Congress to reinstate registration for a draft.

title: British Population Still Falling
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Britain's population fell by 17,000 to 55,836,000 in the 12month period that ended in mid1978, continuing a fouryear decline, the Government Statistical Service reported this week.

title: TollFree Numbers List To Call State Agencies
description: ALBANY  The following is a list of tollfree (800) numbers used by various state agencies. Some of the numbers are available only during certain times of the year.

title: Chrysler Dealer's Ups and Downs
description: EAST HILLS, L.I.  Buying a new car is no longer a pleasure for most consumers, observed Kenneth Brodlieb, a Long Island Chrysler dealer whose showroom was filled with cars and signs advertising the Chrysler's $400 rebate sales campaign. Buyers are no longer looking for the American dream machine, but the best bargain, he added. And for many, it's a very upsetting experience.

title: Music: Remembrances of a Time Past
description: That magic word Woodstock didn't appear anywhere in the advertisements for Celebration: Ten Years Later, which transpired at the Felt Forum on Friday and Saturday nights. But the ads did promise The Legend Continues, several of the performers talked about that Woodstock spirit, and three of the names scheduled to appear  Richie Havens, Canned Heat, and Country Joe and the Fish  actually performed at the original Woodstock Music Festival in August 1969.

title: Canadians Learn About Flora Power
description: OTTAWA  Once upon a time a long time ago, a young redhaired woman from Nova Scotia checked her suitcase at the railroad station here and began to look for a job as a secretary. Because she liked to travel, her first stop was the Ministry for External Affairs. She was not hired.

title: COPING WITH THE COST
description: No matter how many, or few, dollars are involved, everyone wants to spend their fashion allowance wisely. Here are some suggestions.

title: Men's Fashion
description: Designers of European readytowear are currently redefining what are called classics in Great Britain and America.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Backstage during the White Plains Community Action Project's production of Purlie last June, Elmo TerryMorgan of Greenburgh listened to cast members' complaints. These ranged from the lack of training opportunities for actors in Westchester, to the dearth of local professional productions in which they could work. With the actors in mind, he conceived the idea for a new theater group, the Pyramid Ensemble.

title: 1979 N.F.L SCHEDULE
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is the season when efforts expended in the vegetable garden pay off. No other produce can compare with that freshly harvested from one's own garden and immediately prepared for the table.

title: The Strong, Silent Types Are Sounding Off
description: PLUMBERS, carpenters, electricians and other people who work with their hands used to be strong, silent types, the sort of men who answered your questions in grudging monosyllables (as if you hadn't paid for the language too).

title: Is Klan Role In the State Waning?
description: TRENTON A PENDING rape case has completed the disintegration of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan in New Jersey, according to the Grand Dragon of a Pennsylvania faction of the klan.

title: YOU ARE WHAT YOU WEAR
description: The clothes we choose to wear  and how we choose to wear them  send out messages that reveal many aspects of personality and emotional health. A number of leading psychiatrists and psychologists talk about the ways that clothes may be considered keys to the psyche.

title: Twins Beat Yanks; No. 17 for Koosman
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 25 Jerry Koosman became the second American League pitcher to post his 17th victory tonight as he outdueled Luis Tiant and defeated the New York Yankees. 41

title: Yonkers Hospital Seeks Identity Of Patient Brought In on Aug. 8
description: YONKERS, Aug. 25 (AP)  Yonkers General Hospital today appealed to the public for help in identifying a man who was taken to the hospital after he had been found wandering around the city on Aug. 8.

title: LIVING/STYLE
description: CENTEREACH I HATE being a doctor's wife, Ann says with an edge of bitterness.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Concerning the article by Diane Henry, Stamford's Conservative Voice in the State Senate [July 22], one can be most grateful to have Richard H.G. Cunningham as State Senator and spokesman in these very trying times. I found Miss Henry to be considerably caustic at times. Yet she could not diminish or discolor what Senator Cunningham's aims are while a State Senator. The bills he has introduced can only better life in Connecticut for all its citizens, which has not been the case in the past.

title: More Than an Athletic Event
description: THERE were 75,000 of them, and they came from places as close as Rye and as far away as Syracuse. The cars they drove were Iong white Cadillacs and family campers and beatup '67 Chevys; some traveled by train or bus.

title: The Upstart Lawyers Who Market the Law
description: Undercutting the competition, counting on volume for profits, saturating markets with television advertising  these are standard tools in corporate America's campaigns to win consumers' dollars.

title: Anna Lee Waldo
description: Anna Lee Waldo is a St. Louis chemistry teacher who sat down in 1969 and began writing a book based on the Indian lore she had been collecting since she was a child. When she finished, 10 years later, she sent her onemillionword manuscript to Avon Books in a twobythreefoot clothing storage box. After Avon had accepted it, she had to wait for four more years while they decided when and how to publish it.

title: Rowdies Advance
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP)  Steve Wegerle eluded Philadelphia's defenders long enough to convert Rodney Marsh's free kick into the only goal as the Tampa Bay Rowdies defeated the Fury, 10, today.

title: Kurds Are Not the Only Angry Minority in the Ayatollah's Iran
description: PARIS  I don't know who told Ayatollah Khomeini this, exclaimed the governor general of Kurdistan, Mohammad Rashid Shakiba, it is a total lie. There is no unrest here. Both the town and the barracks are peaceful and the local commander has not asked for reinforcements.

title: 18 Suspended Horsemen Given Stay by State Board
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP)  Eighteen Saratoga harness horsemen suspended for illegally giving a drug to their horses have appealed the suspension and will receive a stay, a spokesman for the State Racing and Wagering Board said.

title: Other National Events
description: In 1977, Robert Edward Chambliss, accused of taking part in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham that killed four black girls, was found guilty murder charges in a state court and sentenced to life prison. Attorneys for Mr. Chambliss, who prosecutors said was a member of the Ku Klux Klan and had helped assemble the time bomb that was planted in the church, appealed. Last week, the Alabama Supreme Court upheld the conviction, rejecting his lawyers arguments that an unwarranted, unjustified delay in filing charges in the case had given prosecutors an unfair advantage. A further appeal, to the United States Supreme Court, is possible.

title: The Region
description: In New York City last week, the Chase Manhattan Bank contracted with a leading manufacturer of security equipment for the most sophisticated stateoftheart electronic security system developed to date. It will monitor holdups, attacks on branch vaults, automatic teller machines and afterhours depositories.

title: Exxon's Ardor Begins to Cool
description: It started out as a marriage of convenience, and the bride was cool all through the engagement. By last week, however, it was the groom who had cooled off, while the bride was making threatening noises and demanding that the wedding go through.

title: Sockers Oust Sting
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Hugo Sanchez booted home the game's only goal off a pass from Julie Veee at 78:48 today, lifting San Diego to a 10 victory over the Chicago Sting and giving the Sockers a berth in the American Conference final against Tampa Bay.

title: Cosmos Armed for Possible Shootout With Tulsa
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 25  The Cosmos, facing elimination from the North American Soccer League playoffs if they do not beat the Tulsa Roughnecks tomorrow night, did not seem very worried today.

title: Norwich Maintains Lead
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP)  Kevin Bond, son of the team manager, scored two goals today as Norwich beat Leeds, 21, and maintained its lead in the English Soccer League First Division. Nottingham Forest defeated Coventry, 41, and kept even with Norwich on points.

title: Gas Prices Put Travelers in Buses
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 When Greyhound Lines bus No. 1142 rolled slowly out of the bustling terminal on a deteriorating corner of the downtown Loop the other afternoon on its scheduled 52hourand15minute run to Seattle, all 43 of its narrow scats  with no armrests in between were filled.

title: The Sardonic Smile Endures
description: LAST year, the bicentennial of the deaths of Voltaire and Rousseau, there were discussions at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences about an issue of Daedalus on the two ancient rivals. It turned out that men of learning in many fields still had something to say about the meaning of Rousseau for our time, while Voltaire had definitely been relegated to history. The decision to celebrate Rousseau alone and leave Voltaire to his witticisms, grown somewhat stale with age, was probably a wise one, and yet Voltaire cannot be completely abandoned.

title: Desai Dismisses Reports He Plans to Quit Politics
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (Reuters)Former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai brushed aside talk today about his retirement from politics and said he would serve the people as long as he lived.

title: ANTIQUES
description: For those who were reared with strict penmanship classes and grew up with inkstained fingers, the ballpoint pen may have come as a welcome relief. Yet today, the early fountain pen has become a treasured collector's item.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: One of the least publicized chapters of the American Revolution will be reenacted in New Jersey next weekend, and a medal is being issued to mark the occasion.

title: B.G. Hearey Weds Virginia H. White
description: Virginia Horn White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. White of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married last evening in Cleveland to Bruce Gerard Hearey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Hearey of Oaklyn, N.J. The Rev. Laury Larson performed the ceremony jointly with the Rev. Neil Conway, Roman Catholic priest, in the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant.

title: Deaths
description: KERRArthur J. The Board, Staff, and friends of the New York Foundation for the Arts mourn the passing of Arthur J. Kerr and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, brother and his aunts. The New York Foundation for the Arts

title: Plenty of Fancy Footwork
description: Sixteenth Annual New York Dance Festival, Delacorte Theater, Central Park. Sept. 110.

title: In a Minor League, He's Got a Major Job
description: IN case anyone is wondering about the whereabouts of Michael J. Lindner, class of '71, Manhasset High, you can find him with the Little Falls (N.Y.) Mets of the Class New YorkPenn League.

title: Fredman Comments Stir Debate
description: THE complaint last week of Samuel G. Fredman, the county's Democratic Party chairman, that his role had been watereddown and his statement that he would not accent another term have focused attention not only on who might succeed the party leader but also on County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's relationship with his own party.

title: U.S. Stars Going to Japan;
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25 (UPI)  American and National League allstar teams will make a sevengame exhibition tour .of Japan in November. The The Japanese organizers said the American League allstars would consist of 24 players and the National League would provide 21 players. The American contingent is scheduled to arrive in Tokyo on Nov. 4 for the series starting Nov. 7 at Yokohama Stadium.

title: Pam Shriver: Comeback at 17
description: Remember that 6foot teenager with the Orphan Annie curls who made tennis history a year ago? You know, the one who upset Martina Navratilova in the semifinals of the United States Open and who almost took Chris Evert in the final?

title: The Classical Scene Is Fit as a Fiddle
description: The current slump in the pop record industry has had relatively little effect on the classical side of the business. During the coming months there will be the customary plethora of new releases as well as assurances from the record companies of more good things to come. This gives the lie to the old canard that pops support the classics. With judicious and imaginative leadership backed by encouragement from the parent corporation, a classical record line can be made to pay its own way.

title: The Piazza in San Clemente Spain: Amber Amid Rapid Change
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Spain  It is toward the end of day now. The trees around the perimeter of the plaza cast shadows on the stone benches set here a hundred years ago, over the green metal benches set here five years ago. At one end, near the Civil Guard headquarters, is a bandstand. To each side of it sit old men in dark suits and berets, leaning on canes, smoking cigarettes, talking quietly.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 25 (AP)  Antonio. Cervantes of Colombia was awarded a split decision over his South Korean challenger, Kim KwangMin, today and retained his World Boxing Association junior welterweight boxing title.

title: Cowboys and Rams Ahead of the Pack; In Central, a Tossup
description: The Dallas Cowboys (124 last season) have needed enough replacements this summer to test their vaunted squad depth. If their four division rivals hope to knock over the Pokes, who have finished first five years in a row. they had better do so early. Tony Dorsett will miss a couple of games because of a broken toe, and the league's oldest running back, 33yearold Preston Pearson, is filling in.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Beth Arendall Is Married on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Charles Arendall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Baker Arendall of Mobile, Ala., was married there last evening to Schuyler Merritt Tilney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norcross S. Tilney of Lawrence, L.I. The Rev. Edgar M. Arendall, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Dauphin Way Baptist Church.

title: Kate Winslow Fiancee Of Robert S. Sherman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Winslow of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Nicholas Winslow, to Robert Spellman Sherman, son of Mary C. Sherman of Riverside, Calif., and the late Mr. Sherman. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Schmidt Offers West German Cooperation to Poles
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 24 When Chancellor Helmut Schmidt sailed across the Baltic toward Gdansk last week, 40 years after the German attack on Poland that started World War H, he brought a peaceful message to the Polish people, offering good neighborliness and the revival of European cooperation between East and West.

title: Finds Itself Under the Scrutiny of Planners
description: The Federal Government takes broader view, however, and insists that everything from community development blockgrant applications to requests for money from the Federal Aviation Administration and the Department of Housing and Urban Development be reviewed by a regional agency, in addition to the state government. The Government wants to see how it all fits in with existing development, and with future plans, of the surrounding jurisdictions.

title: Ambitious Plan to Aid Schools in Dallas Collapses
description: DALLAS, Aug. 25  It was an idea that seemed so compatible with Dallas's business knows best ethos that no one thought twice two years ago when the Dallas Independent School District announced an innovative plan to create a private, nonprofit foundation that would raise funds for public education.

title: A Season of Choice Exhibits
description: Matisse from the Baltimore Museum of Art, at the Guggenheim Museum, Aug. 24Oct. 8.

title: Taiwan Again Wins Little League Crown
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 When Red Barber first broadcast the Little League World Series from this Susquehanna River town in 1953, Jimmy Herring played first base for Little Rock, Ark., and the only Chinese that the United States recognized politically lived on an island called Formosa.

title: Karla Evans, C. A. Griswold Have Nuptials
description: The marriage of Karla Harrison Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Crabbs Evans Jr. of Washington and Middleburg, Va., to Charles Augustus Griswold took place yesterday in Upperville, Va. The Rev. Joseph B. Doty, headmaster of St. Stephen's School in Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane Griswold of Greenwich and Old Lyme, Conn.

title: ... And the Horse Breeders
description: WHILE most of the 12,100 horses in Westchester are owned for show, hunting or pleasure riding, a few farms in the county breed racing or show horses as a business  a profitable one in which luck, the right breeding and proper training can bring prices ranging from thousands to hundreds of thousands of dollars for a horse.

title: Mrs. Lloyd and Tracy Austin Gain Final
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 25  Chris Evert Lloyd won two matches today, and Tracy Austin won one to set up the seventh clash of their careers tomorrow in the final of the Volvo Cup women's tennis tournament.

title: Film: More For the GrownUps
description: This year is well on its way to being remembered as one in which movies got smaller and better. This may have been a summer without a Star Wars, but it was also a season full of nice surprises, films that arrived without hoopla and still caused quite a stir. Thus far in 1979, Hollywood really has managed to provide something for everyone, and offer a welcome departure from the disheartening spectacle of everyone's lining up to see the same old thing.

title: Wendy Reeves Becomes Bride In Alexandria
description: Wendy A. Reeves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Prentice W. Reeves of Bradenton, Fla., was married yesterday in the Trinity United Methodist Church in Alexandria, Va., to Hays Thomas Watkins 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watkins Jr. of Moreland Hills, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Ronald E. Sleeth of the Garrett Theological Seminary in Evanston, III., and the Rev. Donald Colby of Trinity Church performed the ceremony.

title: Young Case Aftermath
description: Our interest in Africa is long and deep, Margaret Bush Wilson, board chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said last year when asked about a strong antiSouth Africa resolution passed by organization members. She also warned, people had better get used to us taking positions on noncivil rights issues, in defending a new association policy on energy.

title: Women in Soviet Face a Stark Choice: Career or Children
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22  Marina N. Ivanova, a scientist at an institute in a large Soviet city, decided three years ago that she wanted a second child, something the Government wishes more women would do.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DESPITE the increased demand for wood to heat homes, the Long Island State Park Commission is reducing the number of permits to be issued this fall for cutting dead trees in state parks.

title: New Sports Arena Taking Shape
description: THE reddish gray clay in the excavation pit is dry and dusty, and the pit itself is riddled with about 2,000 steel and timber supportpiles and a maze of ducts for the heating, sewage, water and electrical systems of the new Meadowlands Sports Arena.

title: Pop/Jazz
description: Pop/Jarr

title: Call for Action on the Upper Harlem
description: THE Upper Harlem Line Commuter Council's existence is a testament to the failure of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to provide safe, reliable, convenient and reasonably comfortable rail transportation to northern Westchester and Putnam Counties.

title: Behind the Ivied Doors of Science
description: WITH a complete ignorance of the subject, I found myself at the doors of science one September morning. entered because I could type and take some sort of dictation.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Nassau County, Stillwell Woods, Syosset, L.I. Amateurownerjunior hunter classic, Grand Prix for jumpers. 9:30 A.M.

title: 1,335 Died in Indian Dam Break
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The official death toll from a dam that burst and devastated the western Indian town of Morvi and surrounding villages two weeks ago has risen to 1,335, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE big suburban house was empty for hours at a time this summer. He had never been so alone in his own home.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Oh, That Golden Era (Of an Orderly World)
description: A long time ago during the reign of Ike the Good, global politics and economics were a snap. In full possession of the mandate from Heaven, the United States led the Free World against the atheistic, materialistic SinoSoviet monolith. The Free World, an elastic term, embraced not only the democracies of Western Europe but also assorted LatinAmerican, Middle Eastern and Southeast Asian tyrannies. No matter. All were welcome on condition that they pledged themselves to the cause of antiCommunism by signing up for one of John Foster Dulles's regional alliances.

title: POLITICS
description: THE Conservative Party is capitalizing on the problems of Suffolk Republicans just as the Liberal Party made hay out of the dissension in New York City Democratic ranks.

title: 2 AIDES SAY JORDAN DIDN'T USE COCAINE.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  Two former senior officials of the Carter Administration who now head the CarterMondale reelection committee said today that they had accompanied Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, to the New York discotheque Studio 54 in June 1978. They said he had not used cocaine, as has been alleged, but acknowledged that they were not with him all the time at the discothque.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN wood shingles on the outside walls of a house start to warp or pull loose at the lower ends, it is usually possible to make a quick repair simply by nailing the raised corner or edge of the shingle back into place.

title: Dance: Daydreaming Pair
description: Ever daydream to music? Lots of people do, including, one suspects, many dancers. Solo dances, for instance, often resemble daydreams. Toby Armour and Richard Busch offered an hour of musical and choreographic daydreaming Friday night at the American Theater Laboratory. Mr. Busch played the piano and Miss Armour danced to his playing. But she also danced to her own thoughts about the music.

title: City's UniformedForce Fringes Top U.S. Average
description: The cost of fringe benefits  pensions, welfare, hospitalization insurance and annuities  for New York City's uniformed employees is substantially higher than national averages, according to data from the city's Office of Municipal Labor Relations, while the comparable costs for civilians is below the national figure.

title: Joan Markey Wed To Mark H. Shaw
description: Joan Treacy Markey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Markey of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Mark Hamilton Shaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clayton Shaw of Cartersville, Ga. The Rev. Leo Gorman performed the ceremony in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: Milian Stars in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25 (AP)  Felix Milian, formerly of the New York Mets, went 3 for 3 today and drove in a run, raising his Central Leagueleading batting average to .353. He paced the Yokohama Taiyo Whales to a 40 victory over the Hanshin Tigers.

title: PRO FOOTBALL PREVIEW
description: For years the words competitive balance have been favorites of those who run the National Football League, meaning Commissioner Pete Rozelle and an informal cabinet of influential owners and general managers. In their minds, competitive balance means a state of bliss in which virtually all the 28 teams  this year, they believe, a likely figure is 23  contend for the 10 playoff positions in November and December as well as September.

title: Theater: The Past Is Present
description: At least since No, No, Nanette, Broadway has found that there is profit to be made by looking backward, but this season may set some sort of record for recreation. Marauees will be lighted with titles from the past  Oklahoma! , The Most Happy Fella, Peter Pan, West Side Story, and at the Radio City Music Hall, live on stage will be Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

title: Carrick Glenn, Actress, Bride Of M.B. Purdy
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) yesterday, Nancy Carrick Glenn was married to Marshall Bartlett Purdy by the Rev. Allan B. Warren

title: New Series for the New Season
description: This year 21 new weekly series will make their debut on the commercial networks, spread out over the next couple of months. They are, as of this writing:

title: GreatWar Stories
description: ORLD WAR I, that inter minable bloodletting that set the course for our destructive century, is the background for these two ambitious novels The premise of Robert H. Pilpel's To the Honor of the Fleet is at, intriguing one. Foreseeing United State involvement. Colonel Edward Mandell House. Woodrow Wilson's calculating minence grise, arranges to have two American naval officers sent as observers to the fleets of the opposing sea powers. Harris Maltbie, a romantic and guileless young man, is dispatched to Beatty's British fast cruisers. Benjamin Gehiman, the cynical scion of a prominent GermanJewish New York banking house, is assigned to von Tirpitz's German dreadnoughts Robert H. Pilpel's To the Honor of the Fleet is at, intriguing one. Foreseeing United State involvement. Colonel Edward Mandell House. Woodrow Wilson's calculating minence grise, arranges to have two American naval officers sent as observers to the fleets of the opposing sea powers. Harris Maltbie, a romantic and guileless young man, is dispatched to Beatty's British fast cruisers. Benjamin Gehiman, the cynical scion of a prominent GermanJewish New York banking house, is assigned to von Tirpitz's German dreadnoughts

title: A Bolshoi Performance Is Delayed 20 Minutes
description: A Lincoln Center performance by the Bolshoi ballet company was delayed for 20 minutes yesterday while its artistic director returned from Kennedy International Airport, where he had been with the ballerina Lyudmila Vlasova.

title: FANTASY IN FASHION
description: Shoulders out to there, waists strangled into here. Edwardian fancy, Disneyland fantasia. This is only part of the seemingly giddy Paris fashion picture.

title: New Issues Posed By Betty Friedan
description: SOUTHAMPTON THEY say a woman's work is never done, and the saying goes, especially if the woman is Betty Friedan.

title: POLITICS The State's Venture Into 'sunset Laws
description: HARTFORD COUNTERING the legislative tradition that it is easier to give than to take away, a General Assembly committee is about to wade into a political thicket to decide whether some 20 of the state's 100 or more regulatory boards and commissions should be continued or put out of business.

title: Where Henry Probed The Secret of the Seas
description: The world has lots of ends, depending upon where you are standing, but surely one of the strangest is the westernmost point of Europe  Sagres in Portugal

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Carter Gets Human Rights Medal
description: CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, New Brunswick, Aug. 25  President Carter was awarded a gold medal today for his efforts on behalf of human rights and in a written statement he defended the strategic arms limitation treaty as a contribution to those rights.

title: Foul Puts 111 Shot First at Spa
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25  J. P. Brother, the horse who has been called a bum by his trainer, was declared the winner of the Hopeful Stakes today, providing some insight into the quality of this year's 2yearold thoroughbreds.

title: Farm on Coast Hopes to MassProduce Abalones
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  With abalones, the highly prized and increasingly scarce shellfish, selling for as much as $15 a pound, an entrepreneur is planning to massproduce them like chickens.

title: Duncan Kendall Fianc Of Anne Louise Roberts
description: Anne Louise Roberts and George Duncan Kendall plan to be married Sept. 15. Mrs. Edward F. Roberts of Swansea, Mass., has announced her daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Kendall of Peterborough, N.H.

title: Changing Signals
description: The United States fought for additional time for Middle East peacemaking last week after trying unsuccessfully for forward movement on the stubborn issue of Palestinian rights.

title: GARDENING How to Tell When the Time Is Ripe
description: THIS is the season when efforts expended in the vegetable garden pay off. No other produce can compare with that freshly harvested from one's own garden and immediately prepared for the table.

title: Lynn Szwaja Wed To D.B. Crawford
description: In the Marquand Chapel at the Yale Divinity School in New Haven yesterday, Lynn Allison Szwaja, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Szwaja of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married to Douglas Brown Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Crawford of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Hans W. Frei, professor of religious studies at Yale, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: State Fairs: The Pulse Slows In the Heartland
description: DES MOINES  Nothing that happens in the nation's heartland each summer is as big as the state fair, and none is as big as the one that spreads over 400 acres in Iowa. It's an agricultural extravaganza of prizepigs, lambs and cattle, of glistening farming equipment lusting for buyers, of homemade preserves, fancy stitching and blue ribbons. It is grandstands and chuckwagon races and country music. It is the blare, whirling rides and sideshows on the midway, games of chance and flashing lights.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THE Labor Day weekend is celebrated in many ways throughout the state, but perhaps the most colorful observance will take place in Paterson. Beginning Thursday and continuing through Sept. 3, the ninth annual Great Falls Festival, a series of events honoring the natural wonder, will be held in the Silk City.

title: THEATER
description: IN 1972, I was most fortunate to work with Uta Hagen on her book Respect For Acting. The brilliant actressteacher had this to say on the plight of the serious actor in the American theater today. Now we are migrant workers, fruit pickers where we are momentarily wanted and being exploited and then moving on. We have the same emotional and character problems of other migrant workers.

title: News Summary;International
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 26, 1979

title: Chinese Report Typhoon Deaths
description: PEKING, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  A typhoon swept through islands south of Shanghai last night, sinking fishing boats and killing several people, the New China News Agency said today. The typhoon hit inland areas of Zhejiang Province earlier in the day, the agency said last night, causing some deaths there, too.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Season in the Arts  A Special Preview
INVESTING A Piece of a Marketplace for $1,500
description: It is possible today to own a part of Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston for as little as $1,500, or an equally small piece of a 500unit apartment complex in Laurel, Md., or an office and warehouse leased to the General Electric Company in Louisville, Ky.

title: Prisoners Seeking Release Seize 3 in Las Vegas Jail
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 25 (AP)  A group of armed inmates took three guards hostage at the city jail today and demanded the release of all 84 prisoners in the jail.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: HEMPSTEAD WVHCFM, the radio station of Hofstra University, has very little money (an annual budget of $6,500), very little power (550 watts), an unknown range and an audience whose size is a mystery because the station cannot afford a survey. But in that audience are a large number of thoroughly devoted listeners to a program called The Swing Years, whose host is Dave Weiner  record collector, businessman and expert on the jazz and jazztinged music of the 1930's and 40's.

title: Typecast: Like Mother, Like Daughter
description: KATHERINE Ann Davis Roome writes in some outoftheway places. Parts of the first draft of her new novel were written in the Cornell University Law Library. The second draft was produced aboard a borrowed boat. And the final rewrite was completed in a small house on the coast of Maine.

title: U.S. Open Center Is Spruced Up
description: There will be more conveniences for spectators at the United States Open tennis championships, which start Tuesday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: DINING OUT
description: EVERYBODY likes to write about Edward Giobbi's cooking. And while he certainly has no objection  after all, he is an exceptional cook and he is the author of Italian Family Cooking  he happens to be, by profession, an artist.

title: The Nuclear Panel's Independence
description: The Presidential panel investigating the Three Mile Island nuclear accident showed two flashes of independence last week. It rebuffed an attempt by President Carter to head off any recommendation that might criticize nuclear power too fundamentally. And it chastised the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for planning to license reactors again without waiting for the panel's recommendations due Oct. 25. The panel's resistance to these encroachments suggests that it will produce the truly independent evaluation that the nation needs.

title: Future Shock In Corporate City
description: STAMFORD IT is reasonably certain that at least two competent sociologists are preparing to move on Stamford with tape recorders, cameras, and notebooks. The reason: to begin the preparation of anotner Miadletown: U.S.A. kind of study with a title such as Corporate City: Changes in the Life Style of a New England Community.

title: Canal Zone Judge Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  Robert H. McFarland has resigned as a Federal judge for the Panama Canal Zone, the Justice Department has announced. Judge McFarland. who is 59 years old, said in a letter to President Carter that the traumatic experience of the death of his daughter, Dr. Susan Anne McFarland, had been a factor in his decision to resign so that he could be close to our other three children and our three grandchildren.

title: ART Timeless Forms Among Other Treasures
description: Anovelist, it may have been Hemingway, said that literature in this country owed its continued survival to the reading circles in small towns and to Womrath's libraries. Perham some thing similar will one day be said of art and the unpaid enthusiasts who run its centers and museums in the same small towns. In any case, the Southeast Museum of Brewster could not have endured 16 years without the support of its volunteers.

title: AROUD THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: What's Doing in ASHEVILLE
description: LAND OF THE SKY The Capital of the Land of the Sky and The Gateway to the Smokies are only two of the fancy names that Asheville, N.C., likes to call itself. The Asheville Area Chamber of Commerce brags that there are more than 200 milehigh mountain peaks near the city, including 6,684foot Mount Mitchell, which may be the highest peak in the East. The salubrious climate  Asheville, situated on a 2,0003,000foot plateau, has coolish summers  has attracted tourists and healthseekers since the days when the planter aristocracy of South Carolina began fleeing there to escape the heat and disease of the low country. By the late 19th century, the city had become a nationally known resort for the wealthy; by the early 20th, a resort for the sick, where luxurious sanitariums flourished and every other boarding house took in tuberculosis

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Much about nothing. Among the tribal ways of fullfledged bookpeople is the habit of hanging around stores to observe who is buying what. Usually this is merely run; once in a while it produces a Great Idea. Half a dozen years ago, Crown Publishers Bruce Harris was performing the ritual in one of Fifth Avenue's most sedate bookstores when he saw something that began one of the oddest chapters of publishing history.

title: BEIRUT CALLS TRUCE BUT FIRING GOES ON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25  The Lebanese Government announced a ceasefire early today between Christian militia forces and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon. But, although the heavy artillery barrages appeared to be easing, United Nations sources said they had not yet achieved a truce.

title: Warning to Youths: Futility's Unwarranted
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  As an educator, I feel increasing concern about the profound discouragement with organized action that seems to afflict our population. The belief on the part of the younger generation that no Government program, however urgent the need that prompted its development, has ever worked or ever can work, is very dangerous at this time in history.

title: 'slash Urged For Tristate
description: IF the Tristate Regional Planning Commission wants to keep the rest of its dwindling influence over the future development of a region that does not seem to want to be a region, it should give up half the area it supervises. That is the conclusion of a group studying the agency's future

title: Unrest Boils Up In Guyana
description: More than one fourth of Guyana's workers were on strike last week, and his enemies were trying to bring down Prime Minister Forbes Burnham's 15yearold Government. Squeezed by rising prices for oil and other imports, he has been forced into unpopular austerity measures to qualify for international loans.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: SOUTHBURY IF Poverty Road seems a curiously inappropriate name for the thoroughfare that leads into Heritage Village, which has attracted nationwide attention for its design excellence, some villagers chuckle and insist that, on the contrary, it is becoming increasingly symbolic.

title: ROME CLINIC
description: WHEN wood shingles on the outside walls of a house start to warp or pull loose at the lower ends, it is usually possible to make a quick repair simply by nailing the raised corner or edge of the shingle back into place.

title: Cabinetmaker Pleads Not Guilty In Kidnapping of New Jersey Boy
description: WAREHAM, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)  A cabinetmaker pleaded not guilty today to charges in the kidnapping of a 13yearold boy from near his home in Randolph Township, N.J.

title: Lights Out! A Saving Grace Of the Thirties
description: Irecall a family discussion when I was about 7 years old as to whether we could afford to buy and then operate an electric clock. Mama's penciled figures said she could somehow save enough on the Rrocery bill ($1 a day) to buy the item and after careful checking, Daddy announced that the two cents per month for electricity wouldn't consign us to the poor farm. Thus I truly appreciated the great luxury of that electric timepiece, even though its purpose was to time my hour of piano practice. Not many of my parents friends would or could have taken on that extra expense.

title: In an Advanced Modern Manner
description: WHEN the young British writer Ian McEwan's first novel, The Cement Garden, was published here last year, it was highly acclaimed by some of the best American reviewers. In Between the Sheets is a collection of seven stories written in an advanced modern manner owing something to Nabokov and Beckett, also to early H. G. Wells and to Orwell, and Mr. McEwan is quite good mixing humorous, disgusting, grotesque and pathetic effects. The central figures of the stories (they are often the narrators and invariably solitary, or withdrawn, or alienated) appear in diverse settings (a pornographic bookstore in London's Soho, a borrowed apartment above a party and sickroomequipment rental shop in Santa Monica) that are not so very different at bottom. The stories resemble one another also in presenting recurrent references to urination, sexual bondage and situations in which fairly aggressive or selfreliant women take the upper hand in their connections to men.

title: A Revised Program On Energy Under Way
description: TRENTON AREVISED energy plan now being developed for New Jersey will require conservation by both businesses and homeowners, provide for more mass transportation and have an increased emphasis on generating electricity with nuclear fuels. Although details of the revision have not been spelled out, the concepts have been endorsed by Governor Byrne and the state's top energy officials.

title: Peking's Residents Set a Record In Deposits to Savings Accounts
description: PEKING, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  The residents of Peking have deposited record amounts of money in savings accounts, the Official New China New. Agency reported this week.

title: The Economist's Alphabet: J, S, U and Now, Maybe, W
description: Recessions, it ought to go without saying, take the shape of a U. The economy goes down, pauses a moment, and then climbs back up. This time, though, the economists at the Argus Research Corporation in New York think it might go down, pop up, only to sink again before reviving a W.

title: Battle in The Pit': Deter of Giants and Ward of Jets Heat Up Exhibition Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 25  It was the roughest JetsGiants game since the teams first met 10 years ago, said the old pro, Randy Rasmussen.

title: A Correction
description: In an Aug. 12 article on mayoral primaries around the state, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New Haven was incorrectly identified. George Longyear, a thirdterm alderman and former state representative, is the Republican candidate in New Haven. Joseph Adelizzi, who was incorrectly identified as the mayoral candidate, is the newly elected chairman of the Republican Town Committee.

title: EasyLiving Coast City Uneasy About U.S.
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 25  If you've made it to Laguna, the people here say, you've made it.

title: 10 Get Death Sentences In Plot on Togo's Leader
description: LOME, Togo, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  Ten men were sentenced to death today, eight of them in absentia, for their part in a conspiracy to assassinate Togo's President, Gnassingbe Eyadema, in October 1977.

title: Boutique Chain Finds West Side Is the Right Side
description: When Selma Weiser opened her first boutique on the West Side on April Fool's Day in 1967 with $65 borrowed from a friend, many people thought she was being foolish. She was divorced, she had two children in high school, and who shopped on the West Side anyway?

title: Urban Officials Are Encouraged By Emerging U.S. Transit Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  Two young men were swapping subway stories the other night as they rode the Washington Metro Orange Line out to Robert F. Kennedy Stadium to watch the Redskins play. They were impressing their dates

title: Deaths
description: CORRIGANAugusta Sanford. On Aug 25, Wife of the late Walter, mother of Jane O'Rourke of Shelter Island, NY, sister of Mrs Frank Law of NYC and Ross Sanford of Ft Lauderdale Fla. Grandmother of three boys and greatgrandmother of five girls. Memorial Service will be held later.

title: Van Dyk to Appeal Ruling
description: The Van Dyk Research Corporation said that it would appeal a Federal court decision rejecting its claims that the Xerox Corporation had monopolized the copier industry. Last Monday, United States District Judge Frederick B. Lacey ruled that Van Dyk, a small manufacturer based in Whippany, N.J., had failed to prove that Xerox, the industry leader, had created an unlawful monopoly.

title: Hayden Trying to Export His Politics
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26  Tom Hayden, the antiwar activist of the 1960's who has been attempting to build a California political force based on a mutual disdain for both big business and big government, will try to export his fledgling movement to 10 other states next month.

title: Deaths
description: HEFFERNANJudge Edward M., II, on August 24, 1979 of Setauket, LI, (Vice Chairman of the Appeals Board for the New York State Motor Vehicle Department), beloved husband of Catherine, loving father of Margaret Mary, Catherine and Theresa Heffernan. Reposing at the 0. B. Davis Funeral Home, Nesconset Highway (Rte 347) Pt Jefferson Sta, LI. Visitation Monday and Tuesday, 25 and 710PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10AM at St. James R.C. Church, Setauket, LI. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Carey Meredith Zimrnerman Married to Brett A. August
description: Carey Meredith Zimmerman, daughter of Mrs. Herbert I. Zimmerman of Portland, Conn., and the late Dr. Zimmerman, was married yesterday to Brett Allan August, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles August of Peoria, Ill. Rabbi Nathan Levinson performed the ceremony at the Zimmerman home.

title: Elizabeth Sue Merrill Wayne Married to William J. Rappaport
description: Elizabeth Sue Merrill Wayne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Wayne of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to William J. Rappaport, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon G. Rappaport of West Bay Shore, L.I., and Pompano Beach. Fla

title: Exchange Seat Prices
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, or Merc, reported Friday that a membership on the exchange was sold for $300,000, unchanged from the preceding sale, on Thursday. The exchange said the quotation was now $275,000 bid and $350,000 asked. The Chicago Board Options Exchange said that a seat on its exchange had been sold for $100,000, up $5,000 from the last sale, on Aug. 7.

title: Last of 4 Who Fled Prison On Rikers Island Is Caught
description: The New York City police yesterday captured the last of the four prisoners who escaped from the city prison on Rikers Island.

title: Susan Amy Maneloveg Wed to Leonard Rubin
description: The Rye Town Hilton Inn in Port Chester, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Amy Maneloveg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Maneloveg of White Plains, to Leonard Ross Rubin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Rubin of Yonkers. Rabbi Maurice Davis of the Jewish Community Center in White Plains performed the ceremony.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THE regulatory reform movement is still very much alive, but it is taking a little forced respite. After a year of highly publicized efforts to improve the performance of regulatory agencies, dearth of new regulations to use as testing grounds has forced a slowdown.

title: T.I. to Pay Bowmar
description: Texas Instruments Inc. announced over the weekend that it had agreed to pay $5 million to the Bowmar Instrument Corporation in order to settle suits of alleged antitrust and common law violations initiated by Bowmar in 1974. According to a statement by Texas Instruments, a major manufacturer of computer parts, the settlement included the termination of countersuits against Bowmar.

title: Getting a Grip on Cigarettes
description: To judge by the official statistics, New Yorkers seem an enlightened lot, smoking far fewer cigarettes per capita than other Americans. But the statistics are not to be believed. Perhaps half the cigarette sales New York City are never recorded because the vendors pay neither the 23centapack excise tax nor the 8 percent sales tax.

title: Beth Daniel Wins With 208
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 26 (UPI) Beth Daniel, who was 11 under par for the first 54 holes of the Patty Berg Golf Classic, won her first Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament today when heavy rain forced officials to cancel the final round and declare the tournament completed after the third round.

title: Missouri Creek Cleanup Is Begun 1 After Oil Spill From Shell Pipeline
description: WALNUT GROVE, Mo., Aug. 26 (AP)  It will take at least two weeks to clean up a ruptured pipeline's spill of crude oil that covered more than two miles of southwest Missouri creek and killed 32,1000 fish, authorities say.

title: H.R.A. to Get New Chief For Services to Children
description: The division of special services for children in New York City's Human Resources Administration will get a new head at the end of next month when Beverly Sanders leaves the post and Claire Pearce, a 42yearold Legal Aid lawyer, takes over.

title: Women Celebrate Equality Day
description: The National Organization for Women held walkathons and rallies from New York to California yesterday on Women's Equality Day to commemorate the award of voting rights for women and to raise money for passage of the equal rights amendment.

title: In Paris, a Summer Of Relaxed Nostalgia
description: PARIS THERE has scarcely been any summer to notice, if that means balmy sun and bikinis along the banks of the Seine. But the sidewalks and the gardens have flourished in the more urban climate this year. The trees are full and heavy with leaf, the flower beds in all the parks and avenues with luxuriant color.

title: Ballet: Miss Kholina And Koslov in 'swan
description: LIFE does go on. Balletmasters, like natl3re, abhor a vacuum, and every Odette needs her Siegfried. A slip of paper in the Bolshoi Ballet program for Swan Lake on Saturday afternoon, at the New York State Theater, announced simply that Leonid Koslov would be seen as Prince Siegfried and Irina Kholina as the Princess of Naples, parts assigned in the program to Aleksandr Godunov, who was granted asylum in the United States on Thursday, and his wife, Lyudmilla Vlasova.

title: Rochelle Goldstein Bride Of Mark Schaevitz in L.I.
description: The marriage of Rochelle Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldstein of Kings Point, L.I., to Mark Schaevitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sounder Schaevitz of New York, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldstein of Kings Point, by Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein.

title: Buttermilk Soup Redux
description: The column on buttermilk soup elicited a response from M.F.K. Fisher herself, who lives in the Sonoma Valley in California. The soup, incidentally, was simply a blend of cooked shrimp, cold buttermilk, a dash of mustard and a great deal of chopped fresh dill. Mrs. Fisher, it seems, also eschews salt when she prepares it.

title: OSHA Failures Since '70 Charged By U.S. Chamber of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce charged today that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration had failed to reduce worker injuries and illnesses significantly since its inception in 1970.

title: Bonn Aide Begins Tour Of Mideast in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister HansDietrich Genscher of West Germany arrived here tonight at the start of a tour of Arab countries that will include visits to Lebanon,, Jordan and Egypt.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Heads turned in bewilderment last Thursday morning when Glenn Harrison and James Stine arrived at Broadway and 42d Street pushing a 400pound bobsled. Even the Times Square regulars were deeply puzzled.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Chess:
description: Repeating their earlier South American triumph this year in So Paulo, Brazil, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia tied for first at 102 in the Konex Canon International Tournament in Buenos Aires.

title: Rock: Joni Mitchell In Forest Hills Show
description: JONI MITCHELL'S concert Saturday night at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium was the best Joni Mitchell concert this writer has ever heard. Previously, her jazzrocking bands have tended to reduce her songs to a kind of busy sameness. On Saturday, Miss Mitchell's fivepiece band, which included such jazzfusion luminaries as Pat Metheny, Jaco Pastorius and Michael Brecker, managed by and large to support her with considerable sensitivity.

title: Morocco Admits Fall of Garrison
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 26 (AP)  The Interior Ministry issued a communiqu today confirming that Algerianbacked guerrillas had defeated a Moroccan garrison at Lebuirate in southern Morocco and captured a quantity of arms. It said reinforcements sent to the area recaptured the fort.

title: Outdoors: Tuna Offer the Ultimate Challenge to Anglers
description: POUND for pound, few fish pack the punch of a tuna. And when tuna reach the size of 700 to 1,000 pounds, as do the giant bluefins, that's some punch. For the biggame angler, these blockbusters that roam the waters of the northeast this time of year offer the ultimate challenge with the hook and line.

title: Tass Tells Public Woman on Jet Is With Bolshoi
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26  The official Soviet news agency said today for the first time that the woman whom American officials were detaining on an Aeroflot jet was a Bolshoi ballerina. But the agency. Tass still has not revealed that the ballerina, Lyudmila Vlasova, is married to Aleksandr Godunov, another star of the company, or that Mr. Godunov defected last week.

title: Swedes Evacuating 587 From a Grounded Ferry
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Monday, Aug. 27 (Reuters)  All 587 passengers were successfully taken off a Danish ferry early today after it ran aground in stormy weather and sprang a leak off this southwestern Swedish port.

title: Orantes Is Toppled in U.S. Pro Semifinals
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP)  The topseeded Jose Higueras of Spain settled down after an erratic start and advanced to the final of the $175,000 United States Pro tennis championship with a 64, 62 victory over Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia today.

title: Lindsay Hospitalized After Stomach Pains
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York City was admitted yesterday evening into ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after complaining of stomach pains while attending an upstate Democratic fundraising affair.

title: Cosmos Triumph In Playoff
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 26  The Cosmos did what they had to do tonight: they won two games and advanced in the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: How Feminists Bring Up Their Sons
description: One of the thorniest issues confronting many feminist women these days is how to raise their sons. Some say they are rearing them under the principles of equality fostered by the women's movement, but others  even deeply committed feminists  draw the line when it comes to their sons. They retreat to the tradi tional ways of child rearing, out of fear that their sons will turn out to be sissies or otherwise less than the John Wayne image of American manhood.

title: Of Arms and the Ayatollah
description: Until a fortnight ago, these coldblooded arguments could have been made for the Administration's decision to resume arms sales, at a modest level, Iran:

title: Israel Reaffirms Policy of Strikes Inside Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26  After a night of rocket and artillery exchanges between the army and Palestinian guerrillas, the Israeli Cabinet today reaffirmed the Government's policy of conducting strikes in southern Lebanon despite an attempt by the United Nations to arrange a ceasefire there.

title: New Day of Talk Fails to Alter Old Stands
description: At 8:15 yesterday morning, Donald F. McHenry, who is heading the United States negotiating team at Kennedy International Airport, returned from rest period to the lounge in the Pan American World Airways terminal, where talks were being held off and on with Russian officials about the detention of a Soviet jetliner.

title: Mondale and Deng Urge Bolstering Of U.S.China Ties to Aid Stability
description: PEKING, Aug. 26  Vice President Mondale and Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping called tonight for a steady strengthening of ties between the United States and China to promote international stability in the next decade.

title: Books of The Times
description: I HAVE been around a lot of blood in my life, writes the surgeonessayist Richard Selzer (Rituals of Surgery and Mortal Lessons) in one of the lighter pieces in his new collection, Confessions of a Knife. Whole days and nights have seen me, heck and toe, imbued with gore. And he thinks nothing of it. That's his world, and welcome to it, all who dare enter here.

title: Col. Philip G. Cochran, War Hero And Model for 2 Cartoon Figures
description: Col. Philip G. Cochran, the World War II hero who inspired Milton Caniff's creation of two characters in the syndicated cartoon strips Terry and the Pirates and Steve Canyon, died Saturday of a heart attack while on a fox hunt in Geneseo. N. Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Shonni Silverberg Married to Tohn Shapiro
description: Shonni Joy Silverberg and John Michael Shapiro were married yesterday afternoon at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Arnold Turetsky.

title: Susan Jellinek Wed To Solomon Moses
description: The Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale, the Bronx, was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Susan Lea Jellinek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Jellinek of White Plains, to Solomon David Moses, son of Lillian Moses of Hallandale, Fla., and the late Isidore Moses. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jacob Goldberg.

title: High Interest Doubted as Inflation Cure
description: As the Federal Reserve Board has acted to push up interest rates in recent weeks, economists in both industry and Government are beginning to warn that higher rates alone are not going to cure inflation.

title: Honolulu Sniper Shoots 5 Tourists; Had Been Confined in 1973 Attack
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 26 (UPI)  Five tourists were wounded last night by a sniper attack in the heart of the Waikiki beach area, and the police were holding a man accused of injuring a woman in a similar attack three blocks away in 1973.

title: ELLEN MOERS MAYER, WRITER AND CRITIC
description: Ellen Moers Mayer, writer, critic and teacher, died of cancer Saturday in New York. She was 50 years old. The author of many books and studies in American and English literature, she was wellknown for her meticulous research and refined writing style, and was considered a leading authority on women who were literary figures of the 19th century.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In his farewell address, Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger rightly posited the specter of Soviet military preponderance in the Middle East and its stark implications on U.S. interests in the area. His survey of the geopolitical landscape was, however, incomplete. He made no reference to an even more dramatic challenge to U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf  a challenge rooted in the emerging conflict among Western allies in regard to secure oil supplies.

title: Missing Boy and His Sitter Found in a Subway Station
description: A 4yearold Bronx boy who had been missing since Aug. 13 was found by two Transit Authority police officers early yesterday together with Carmen Arroyo, his 15yearold baby sitter, in the Times Square subway station.

title: Ruth Gordon Nowa Theater and Glad of It
description: WESTBORO Mass., Aug. 25 They have named a new movie theater here for Ruth Gordon, and the irrepressible actress thinks that is a fine idea. I love attention, she declared before talking part in an official dedication tonight of the Ruth Gordon Flick, a complex of three small theaters on Lyman Street just off Route 9 near Framingham.

title: Advertising
description: HENRY KISSINGER pushing a magazine? Ronald Reagan pushing a magazine? I.M. Pei pushing a magazine?

title: Gas Price Curb Said to Work
