description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP)  It looks as though gasoline dealers are obeying tougher Federal rules limiting their profit margins, but the price paid at the pumps in the United States continues to rise because of wholesale price increases, the publisher of an oilmarketing survey said today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Battle to Restrict Campaign Gifts Reflects Shifts in Nation's Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  Both the sponsors and the opponents of legislation to curtail specialinterest contributions to Congressional campaigns are looking to member of the House Democratic leadership as a possible key to whether Congress will act on the issue before the 1980 elections.

title: R.J. Reynolds's InHouse Move
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced that it would consolidate the buying of print advertising for all of its products under its internal media department. The work had been handled by R.J. Reynolds's six ad agencies: William Esty, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, LKP International, TathamLaird & Kudner, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Ogilvy & Mather. According to industry sources, R.J. Reynolds did $182.6 million in space advertising last year.

title: Firm Footing for Pound
description: LONDON, Aug. 26  The British pound, which enjoyed a sharp runup against the dollar a few weeks ago, has fallen back of late, But according to currency traders, sterling seems to be firm at its current levels and likely to hold its own.

title: Giants Get New Line Coach
description: The Giants, a football team that does not score touchdowns, continued yesterday to lead the league in strange events.

title: Deaths
description: BLAIRRosemary Kane, on Aug 25, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Edwin Foster Blair, devoted mother of Mary Kane Blair, Kathleen Blair Leisure, Rosanne Blair Kelly, and Edwin James Blair. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral Mass, St Thomas More Church, 65 E 89th St, NYC, 11am, Tues, Aug 28th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Recording for the Blind, 215 E 58 St, NYC.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, Aug. 26 (AP)  Alan Jones of Australia scored his third straight Formula I victory today by winning the Dutch Grand Prix. The triumph was the fourth straight for the Williams team, which is financed by Saudi Arabia. A second place finish for Jody Scheckter of South Africa and his Ferrari increased his lead in the world drivers championship standing.

title: U. N. Envoys Marking Time
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Whether last Friday's postponement of Security Council vote on a resolution urging selfdetermination for the Palestinians represented a victory for Andrew Young in his waning weeks as chief United States delegate, or suggested that the Palestine Liberation Organization had won little of substance, the immediate effect was to give both supporters and op ponents of the measure more time to evaluate the issue.

title: Rabbi Samuel Walkin of Queens; Helped Thousands Escape Nazis
description: Rabbi Samuel Walkin, the leader of an Orthodox Jewish congregation in Queens who helped thousands flee Nazi Germany to China during World War II, died Saturday of a heart attack at home at the age of 72, according to his daughter, Esther Poupko

title: Telegram
description: WASHINGTON  Diplomacy, as Andrew Young found out, is a pompous, portly craft, invested with a Victorian majesty yet crippled with an elephantine gait. In often gigantic and architecturally spectacular embassies and consulates and high commissions, governments commune with one another through the medium of a diplomatic machine that has its origins in the heyday of the Venetian empire.

title: Quake Recorded in Pacific
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 26 (AP)  A strong earthquake occurred today in the Pacific Ocean north of Luzon, the Philippines, the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said. The earthquake measured 6.7 on the openended Richter scale, insufficient to set off a Pacificwide tsunami, or sea wave, the center said.

title: Watson's Par Beats Miller On Second Hole of Playoff
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 26  Just when he seemed to be out of the hunt, Tom Watson eagled the 16th hole today to force a tie with Johnny Miller and then went on to beat the hardluck golfer in a playoff in the Colgate Hall of Fame Classic.

title: Court to Order Concerns to Pay In Mercury Case
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge plans to order the former owners of a mercuryprocessing plant at the fringe of the Hackensack Meadowlands to pay the cost of cleaning up contamination from the dumping of the hazardous substance into the area's soil and water over more than three decades.

title: BatteredSpouse Agency
description: A new agency in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is functioning as an information center for all sources of Federal aid available to groups assisting battered spouses.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The 16th Annual New York Dance Festival, 12 free performances presented by the TAG Foundation Ltd., will open Saturday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park and run through Sept. 11.

title: Deaths
description: RUBINSamuel, died suddenly Aug 25th, at the age of 86. Loving husband of Mathilde, devoted father of Frieda Kaplan, Elaine Sperber, Geraldine Clurfeld, brother of Susan Hecht, Lily Wolsk, grandfather of Michael Miller, Robin Freecienberg, Tina and Miles Sperber, Andrea and Leslie Clurfeld, greatgrandfather of Daniel Freedenberg. Services Tues, 11:45am, The Riverside, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mrs. Lloyd, Heat Stop Miss Austin
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 26  John Lloyd was in his tennis whites, ready to practice. His wife had lost the first set and was down, 42, in the second to Tracy Austin. Lloyd planned to cancel his practice court if the match went into a third set, but, unhappily, he doubted a third set would be needed.

title: Around the Nation
description: KEENE, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI)  The United Farm Workers today reached the first contract agreement with a lettuce grower since members of the union began their strike in the Salinas Valley seven months ago.

title: China Bid to I.M.F. Seen
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)  China plans to join the International Monetary Fund and seek loans from the World Bank to help modernize its hydroelectric power plants, railways and other industries, Nihon Keizai, an independent Japanese economic newspaper, reported Friday.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (UPI)  Japanese press dispatches from Peking said today that China had confirmed that the socalled Gang of Four, led by Mao Zedong's widow, Jiang Qing, would be tried in public soon.

title: Music: Santa Fe Players
description: CHAMBER music is the fairhaired child in the musical arts these days  wherever one turns, it seems, small instrumental ensembles are capturing audiences in a way that would have been inconceivable a decade or so ago. Just one of the success stories in this trend is the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, which for the last seven summers has gradually been garnering almost as much attention in that New Mexican city as its celebrated older neighbor the Santa Fe Opera.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: Week Ended Aug. 24, 1979

title: International Group Urges Peace as a Human Right
description: CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, New Brunswick, Aug. 26  Leading jurists, politicians and civil servants from 21 nations, took another step here today toward trying to persuade the world to accept peace as a human right.

title: Illinois Republican Congressman Asks P.L.O. Leader to New York
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, has invited Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to come to New York to discuss Middle East issues, an aide to the Congressman said today.

title: Denmark to Hunt for TV Viewers Who Have Failed to Buy License
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 26 (AP)  The stateowned radio and television network is planning a nationwide search for Danes who have failed to pay television and radio license fees.

title: Stopover In Shelby
description: SHELBY, MONT. ON the road out of Glacier National Park, a green sign announced, Shelby 58. The plan had been to drive south toward Yellowstone National Park, but for anyone hooked on the romance, and the rogues of American sports, a detour was mandatory. Turning onto Route 2, the twolane blacktop went past the Black Foot and through Cut Bank across Montana's lonely rolling range land. And then, on the dusty street near Interstate 15 that slices down from the nearby Canadian border, a sign with fourfoot high figures of two boxers identified the Arena Motel and Camp Grounds as The site of the Jack DempseyTom Gibbons heavyweight champion fight. In the motel office Mrs. Donald Jones, short and smiling, looked up at her visitor.

title: 25 Latin American Scholars And Artists Get Guggenheims
description: Twentyfive fellowships totaling $397,000 have been awarded to Latin American scholars and artists by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. The competition for these annual awards is open to residents and citizens of nations and other territories in Latin America. Gordon N. Ray, the foundation's president, announced the recipients, their fields and fellowship projects:

title: Myricks's Jump Is 2d Longest
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 26  Three summers ago, Larry Myricks broke a bone in his ankle warming up for the final in the Olympic Games long jump. This afternoon, in the same stadium, Myricks won the event in World Cup II with a leap of 27 feet 11 inches on his last attempt, the second longest jump in history.

title: Some Shelling Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 26  A ceasefire arranged by the United Nations in southern Lebanon appeared to be holding tonight, although there were reports of intermittent shelling in several areas.

title: Reflections on an Ordeal
description: In Cherry Hill, N.J., yesterday, William Boorstein was back home with his family after 10 days of captivity in San Salvador at the hands of striking workers at a textile plant that he had managed.

title: Scott Stops Cometti, Remains Undefeated
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 26  James Scott, who is serving a 30to40 year term for armed robbery and parole violation in Rahway State Prison, stopped Enio Cometti, the lightheavyweight champion of Italy, in the institution's yard today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Kenneth T. Derr, 43 years old, has been named president of Chevron U.S.A., the principal subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Donald L. Bower, 55, who becomes a vice chairman of the parent corporation.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Investors, apparently unconvinced that interest rates are near their peak and worried that the nation may be heading into a credit crunch, are becoming unwilling to commit their money to longterm securities.

title: Deaths
description: McGUIRELou. On August 24. Wife of the late William Anthony McGuire. Grandma to Diane, Mary and Carlyle Bennett. Memorial contributions may be made to the Actors Fund.

title: 2 Negotiators Are Similar in Style Despite Differences
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Despite the wide differences of their origins, their training and their political philosophies, the two men dispatched by their Governments to handle the developing confrontation at Kennedy International Airport  Donald F. McHenry of the United States and Yevgeny N. Makeyev of the Soviet Union  are men of similar style.

title: Few New Issues Planned
description: The schedule for longterm financing will continue to be light this week. The biggest offering, for $150 million, will be made by the Washington Power Supply System.

title: Bridge:
description: Two New York squads and two from New England contested the finals of the Capital District knockout team championship at the Rockefeller Convention Center in Albany yesterday. The survivors were groups headed by Dave Berkowitz and Art Seigenfield of New York City, Ross Grabel of Rocky Hill, Conn., and Bart Bramley of Woolson. Mass.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player hits a ball that goes into the stands and seems like an obvious home run, but he twists his leg while hitting the ball and cannot run around the bases. Is he out, or is it a home run?

title: ExTeacher Wins Pact With Her Power Plant
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP)  Mary Heather, a retired schoolteacher who began her own power company, was presented with contract today. Under it, the Massachusetts Electric Company agrees to buy power from her Housatonic Energy Conservation Associaton.

title: The Wide Range of the Tuna Family
description: The following are the tuna most commonly sought by sport and commercial fishermen in the western North Atlantic region, with the alltackle world records recognized by the International Game Fish Association.

title: Millions of Dollars Are at Stake in Environmental Dispute Over Strip Mine in Montana
description: SARPY CREEK, Mont.  Down the bank of one of the damp draws that nourish scant lines of cottonwood trees in arid Big Horn County, a clutch of Federal officials stood with representatives of Westmoreland Resources Inc. An eyes were fixed on a bathtubsized pool of murky water.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Doctors and Nurses Will Testify On Deaths at Hospital in Georgia
description: MACON, Ga., Aug. 26 (AP)  A grand jury looking into charges that someone tampered with lifesupport equipment at a Macon hospital will hear this week from the doctors and nurses of several patients whose deaths are under investigation, according to District Attorney W. Don Thompson.

title: Market Place
description: THE Exxon Corporation, which stunned Wall Street with a mammoth offer of $72 a share for Reliance Electric last June, is attempting to work out a takeover acceptable to the Government that would not limit its use of Reliance's assets.

title: Gov. Brown Proposes to Debate With President in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 26 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California has proposed debates with President Carter before the New Hampshire Presidential primary next year.

title: U.S. Suit Cites Unit of I.T.T.
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 26 (AP)  The Federal Government has filed an $8.6 million lawsuit against a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, alleging that the company imported millions of dollars worth of products between 1969 and 1979 without paying proper customs duties.

title: The Good Old Days
description: In numerous books and paintings, Eric Sloane offers a vision of an America rooted firmly in the past. From his home in Warren, Conn., the 75yearold Mr. Sloane writes about the way the nation once lived, and he likes to paint pictures of barns and covered bridges and New England villages.

title: Mead Film Festival Sept. 1316
description: The third annual Margaret Mead Film Festival, a program of anthropological films and discussions, will be held Sept. 1316 at the American Museum of Natural History. The festival is a tribute to Dr. Mead, who died in November. The eminent anthropologist began her career at the museum and worked there for 52 years.

title: Taxing Britain's Company Car
description: LONDON, Aug. 26  British businessmen are in an uproar over a Government proposal to levy steep new taxes on one of their most cherished fringe benefitsthe company car.

title: Egypt Seems to Be in Best Shape Since 67
description: CAIRO, Aug. 26  In the wake of its peace treaty with Israel, Egypt has weathered the condemnation and punishments meted out by its Arab critics and appears to be in its best shape since before the disastrous war of 1967.

title: Oil Tanker Explodes in Persian Gulf
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Aug. 26 (AP)  A 631foot tanker on its way to pick up oil exploded in the Persian Gulf today and was reported sinking about 70 miles off the United Arab Emirates, sources in the oil industry said.

title: Law Cited in Detaining Soviet Jet Grew Out of 2 Cases
description: The law that United States officials are citing as the basis for detaining a Soviet airliner was an outgrowth of two incidents in the early 1970's, State Department spokesmen and authorities on international law said yesterday.

title: Radials Allowed on Snow Routes
description: The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles has advised motorists that, under a new law effective Sept. 1, cars equipped with radial tires will be permitted on any roads in the state designated as snowemergency routes in inclement weather.

title: The Russian Connection To Be Broadcast Sept. 25
description: The Russian Connection, an hourlong documentary about the involvement of the Soviet Union in the training of Palestine Liberation Organization terrorists, will be broadcast Sept. 25 at 10 P.M. by PBS and the CBC. WNETTV will carry it Sept. 28 at 11 P.M.

title: Lisa Robbins Wed To P. D. Stathas
description: The Russell Courtyard of Teachers College of Columbia University was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lisa Robbins, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Robbins of Floral Park. L.I. to Panayiotis Demetrius Stathas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Demetrius P. Stathas of Kalamata, Greece. Rabbi Steven Goodman of Temple Sholem in Floral Park performed the ceremony.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Divides Feminists: A Woman in Power, but Not a Sister
description: LONDON, Aug. 26  The British feminist movement is engaged in a bitter debate over what some of its members regard as a momentous triumph, the election of a woman as Prime Minister.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 24 U.S. Soldiers Arrested in Drug Ring in Germany
description: OPPENHEIM, West Germany, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  Twentyfour American soldiers have been arrested by the West German police and the United States Military Police, smashing a heroin smuggling ring, the Oppenheim police said today.

title: Jane A. Himber, Author, Is Bride of Eric Schwartz
description: Jane Arlene Himber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Himber of Deerfield Beach, Fla., formerly of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Schwartz of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Hyman Levine performed the ceremony in the Emanuel Jewish Center in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Drama at Plane Typical of Godunov Career
description: There is a touch of uncharacteristic reticence in the secrecy surrounding the defection of Aleksandr Godunov, but the international drama of the detention of his wife, Lyudmila Vlasova, at ,iennedy International Airport is fully in character with his colorful career on and off stage

title: Israel's Numbers Game
description: Behind the uproar over American diplomatic contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization, there is at least one widely shared assumption: Except for some of the protesting American Jewish leaders, most parties to the Andrew Young dispute appear convinced that the current Palestinianautonomy talks are a sham. The notion is that Israel does not intend to see the autonomy talks, which also involve Egypt and America, through to a successful conclusion. Israel's presumed goal, in this reading, is either to perpetuate the status quo indefinitely or to annex the occupied territories eventually.

title: Yanks Sign Scott, Drop Brown
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 26 The New York Yankees, in need of more righthanded hitting power, dipped into the ranks of the veterans today and signed George Scott.

title: The Region
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I. (AP)  An undentified man shot and wounded a Nassau County policeman at a shopping center here early yesterday and then was shot to death by three other officers, authorities said.

title: United Air Lifting Fares
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)  United Airlines said that higher transcontinental oneway, advancepurchase fares would take effect Oct. 1. The fare between New York and Los Angeles will be $139 during the day and $129 at night, up from $108 and $125. The new fares are subject to Civil Aeronautics Board approval.

title: Times to Increase Price Of Daily Paper to 25
description: The basic newsstand price of The New York Times will rise to 25 cents, effective next Monday, Sept. 3.

title: The City
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday posted new regulations requiring storage warehouse operators to inform customers fully of warehouse rates and services in advance.

title: French Protesters Seize Cottage Where Khomeini Stayed in Exile
description: PARIS Aug. 26 (AP)  About 90 members of the French Communist Revolutionary League, protesting what they called the massacre of the Kurdish people in Iran, today took over the cottage in NeauphleleChteau where Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini spent his days of exile in France.

title: Coast Fire Curbed as 2d Starts
description: BANNING, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI) Firefighters controlled a 1,545acre fire on the Morongo Indian Reservation yesterday and rushed to another nearby blaze that consumed 350 acres and threatened several homes.

title: Royals Turn Back Red Sox by 63
description: Willie Wilson, a fleetfooted outfielder who had been long on promise and short on delivery in his first three seasons with the Kansas City Royals, has begun to play up to his potential. His recent stretch of torrid hitting has had a large affect on both divisional pennant races in the American League.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Deaths
description: ALTMANIsidor. Congregation Kneses Israel notes with deep regret the untimely passing in Sun City, Arizona, of the beloved brother of our esteemed Vice President, Joseph Altman. Our condolences to the family.

title: Yevtushenko Finally Unfetters His Muse on the Screen
description: The face on the screen at the Moscow Film Festival may not have been immediately recognizable to many moviegoers, but many lovers of verse would have had no trouble. It was that of Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, who was making his debut as a film actor in a manner appropriate for a man of his selfabsorption: There are few moments in the threehour movie, Flight, when the camera is not on him. He even doubles as narrator.

title: Bolshoi Ballet Finishes New York Engagement
description: The Bolshoi Ballet concluded its fourweek engagement at the New York State Theater here yesterday afternoon and left for Chicago from Kennedy International Airport shortly after 2 A.M. today.

title: Seaver Tops Mets by 80
description: Tom Seaver, making his second appearance at Shea Stadium against the Mets since being traded to the Cincinnati Reds in June 1977, gave a crowd of 20,619 fond memories as he pitched an 80 shutout for his 11th straight victory yesterday.

title: Entertainment Events
description: PAULA TSUI, pop singer, Avery Fisher Hall, 8.

title: Strauss Hints U.S. Will Seek a Settlement for Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East negotiator, signaled today that the United States would begin a new diplomatic initiative for a moratorium in the fighting in southern Lebanon between Palestinians and the Israelibacked Christian militiamen.

title: North Carolina Blacks Support Troubled New Town
description: SOUL CITY, N.C., Aug. 26 More than 100 members of the North Carolina Black Leadership Caucus picnicked with their familiesat this new town this weekend to affirm their support for its survival.

title: Rock: Louise Goffin Appears On Bill With Greg Kihn Band
description: THE 1979 Dr Pepper Festival in Central Park rather limped to a close Saturday night, but there were reasons. Originally Graham Nash was to be the final act. When he canceled. Ron Delsener booked in a touring show that ordinarily might have been expected to play the Bottom Line  the Greg Kihn Band and Louise Goffin. They attracted a decently attentive but sparse crowd, and Miss Goffin in particular seemed uneasy trying to perform in such a vast, semiempty space.

title: CORRECTION
description: An report by The Associated Press in The Times on Friday said erroneously that Representative Anthony Moffett, Democrat of Connecticut, had traveled to Southeast Asia in early August at taxpayer expense. Mr. Moffett's office said he had declined the trip and spent the time in his home district.

title: U.S. Open Tickets
description: Tickets for the last two days of the 1979 United States OpenSept. 8 and 9  are already sold out. Tickets for Aug. 28 through Sept. 7 competition are available at the National Tennis Center and at all Ticketron outlets from Virginia to Maine. Matches will be played in day and night sessions on 13 courts from Aug. 28 to Sept. 6, and during the day only on Sept. 7, 8 and 9. Daytime tickets cost $9 each in the early rounds and $13 later on; night tickets start at $7 and escalate to $8.

title: An Earful of Grumblings Greets Congress at Break
description: ST. LOUIS  It was a bright, sunny morning, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt was ringing doorbells in a neighborhood of tidy homes, tended lawns and tight budgets. Dee Petry, the wife of a businessman, came to the door, and the conversation meandered over familiar topics: higher prices at the grocery, fewer drives in the family car.

title: Notes on People
description: Predictably, there is now talk about a possible movie or book (or both) about the ordeal of the Rev. Bernard T. Pagano, the priest who was recently exonerated of charges that he was Delaware's gentleman bandit.

title: The 7 Percent Charade
description: NEW HAVEN  It came as a surprise when the clerk informed me that the postage was 11 cents short on the small book I was sending to a colleague. The book rate for one pound had gone up from 48 to 59 cents. In my office, the calculator alerted me to the troublesome aspect of a mere 11 cents. I had witnessed a sudden inflation of 22.9 percent. Recalling that the price for the same service in January 1977 had been 25 cents, the rise over two and one half years had been a frightening 132 percent.

title: Japan Reports Vehicle Output
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle production in July totaled 841,780 units, down 1.1 percent from June but up 11.6 percent from the yearearlier month, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association has reported.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Barclays Bank of New York has elected Albert BushBrown, chancellor of Long Island University, to its board.

title: A Jewish Sect Faces Future Leaderless
description: It is like the Holocaust, said the Hasidic man in the long black coat. It is a second Holocaust.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Sporting Gear
description: A new golfclub wood has been designed that enables a player to adjust the weight and balance to his individual needs instantly. The metal plate on the bottom of the wood has a removable cap, which covers 18 small holes used to insert swingweight pins. By removing or adding pins, which weigh onesixteenth of an ounce, the golfer can move the center of gravity backward, forward or sideways to coordinate with his rhythm, timing and strength. He can also vary the weight of the club head. A fourclub set sells for $75 apiece, but the clubs may be purchased separately for $80 each. The selection includeS a driver, and Nos. 3, 4 and 5 woods in left or righthand models, or, for ladies, a driver and Nos. 3, 5 and 7 righthand woods. They are available from the Minnesota Golf Manufacturing Company, 36 North Plaza Building, Gamble Center, Minneapolis 55416, (612) 5450323.

title: 2 J.A.L. Planes Turn Back
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Two Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 planes carrying a total of 760 people returned safely to Tokyo today after developing engine trouble on flights to Sapporo in the northern island of Hokkaido, the airline said. The cause of the trouble was being investigated.

title: In Peekskill, 1984 Beckons Brightly
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 24  In 1900, Charles Fleischmann founded the Standard Brands Plant on 65 acres at Charles Point here, some 45 miles north of New York City. The first products manufactured on the site were Fleischmann's Bakers Yeast, Fleischmann's White Vinegar and Fleischmann's Gin.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: LOS ANGELES  Back East hardly anyone takes Jerry Brown seriously as a Presidential candidate. He is too odd, people say  too flaky, in the current phrase. His attacks on deficit spending and opposition to nuclear power will offend labor and other mainstream Democratic voters. Political troubles at home in California will hobble him.

title: Early Returns in Nicaragua
description: The hardest tests still lie ahead for the new rulers of Nicaragua. Not even the Sandinist leaders themselves now know whether they will remain true to their promises of democracy when harmony inevitably gives way to conflict over how best to reconstruct shattered society. But in recent days the Sandinists have shown signs that their interest in pluralism is not merely rhetorical. They clearly anticipate a society where Nicaraguans will be free to express dissenting points of view.

title: Pope Blesses Statue on Mountain Peak
description: BELLUNO, Italy, Aug. 26  Pope John Paul II, who was a passionate mountain climber in his native Poland, went up by cable car 10,708 feet to the peak of Marmolada, the highest mountain in the Dolomite Alps, here today to bless a statue of the Madonna in a ceremony above the glaciers.

title: Stan Kenton, Band Leader, Dies; Was Center of Jazz Controversies
description: Stan Kenton, the band leader, died Saturday night in a Hollywood hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: HeatingOil Fears Fade In Europe
description: BONN  Western Europe is discovering that, much like the fears of gas lines and rationing that the oil crisis set off last spring, worries about heatingoil supplies for the winter are also disappearing.

title: Commodities
description: NOT all the commodity profits this month went to the preciousmetals bulls. Indeed, those who bought live cattle futures a month ago made far more money than their counterparts in gold and silver. And with food store chains preparing to kick oft their fall beef promotions with cookout specials for the Labor Day weekend, prices appear headed higher for the next week or so.

title: STANDOFF CONTINUES AS U.S. AUTHORITIES BLOCK SOVIET PLANE
description: The United States kept a crowded Soviet jetliner grounded at Kennedy International Airport for a second day yesterday, but made no progress in efforts to determine whether the wife of a Soviet defector was aboard the Moscowbound aircraft against her will.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended Aug. 24, 1979

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOUR BY FOUR The public is usually invited to share the Dropin Dinner gettogethers of the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences with guests of honor from show business and the literary world. Edwin Newman, the writer and television commentator, was a recent speaker at the event, held regularly at the Copacabana, 10 East 60th Street.

title: Jets Penalties Bother Michaels
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 26  The result had been what the Jets wanted going into their first week of such a hopeful season: a victory over the Giants last nieht.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Environment Chief Vows Firm Jersey Rules
description: TRENTON, Aug. 24  Jerry English, newly installed as Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said today that despite the expected recession and the energy shortage, no industry could expect a relaxation of New Jersey's environmental standards unless someone can make .a very compelling case.

title: In Memoriam Pnwriam
description: ACKERFay. Anril 1, 1979. Grandma, the iewd in our y. April 1, 1979./hearts...the love of our lives... WLY, ...K,J,D,K,D,S,B,

title: Blast Fells 5 Rhodesian Children
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 26 (AP)  Five children playing outside their suburban Salisbury home were wounded when an army explosive device went off accidentally, the police said today. One of the children was in critical condition.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 27, 1979

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Variable Mortgages Languish
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26  In California, where the controversial variablerate mortgage made its debut in 1975, the bloom is back on the more conventional fixed mortgage.

title: Esmark Buys Chemical Stake
description: Reliance Universal Inc., an industrial coatings and chemical specialties concern, said that Esmark Inc., a diversified holding company, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 7percent of the outstanding shares of Reliance Universal to further its efforts to acquire the company.

title: Letter: On Public Education
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L Rookies to Watch: Few but Good
description: BREAKING into professional football is seldom easy. Consider these numbers: After the coaches make the final cuts today, to complete their squads of 45, about 225 rookies out of an original pool of 9,000 former college players will be included among the 1,260 roster openings in the National Football League. But only a couple of dozen will be in the starting lineups when the season begins this weekend.

title: Stevens Mill Workers Protest Their Lack of a Contract;
description: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Aug. 26 (AP)  J.P. Stevens employees gathered for a day of country music and speeches today to celebrate the fifth anniversary of their vote in favor of a union at the textile plant and to protest against the fact that the 3,000 Stevens workers still have no contract.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: RAY KROC has been on television lately doing commercials for McDonald's hamburgers. Lucky he's working. He's got to scuffle up $100,000 one way or another for Bowie Kuhn, and at 76 it isn't easy to get a new iob.

title: It's ShuffleShuffleBarnBarn to Macy's
description: A leggy regiment of 420 tapdancers clattered west on 34th Street yesterday noon from the Empire State Building through Herald Square to the entrance of Macy's.

title: Bjorn Borg Simply Wants to Be the Best Ever
description: THERE is a simplicity about the way he lives. Despite an estimated income of $3 million a year, a home in Monte Carlo, an island off the coast of Sweden, Bjorn Borg lives sparely. Everything about him  his bearing and the shape of his days  has been pared down, controlled to serve one clear goal.

title: Oil Price Rises Put Kenya's Economy in Jeopardy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 19  The Arabs tried to make slaves out of us 500 years ago, a Kenyan journalist said here the other day, and now they're trying to do it again.

title: Zimbabwe to Be Nation's Name
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa has announced that Rhodesia will be dropped from his country's name before the constitutional talks begin in London on Sept. 10.

title: Discount Stores Opened In A. &P. 's Renewal Bid
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26  The first two units in a major new discount food store venture for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company opened late last week in New Jersey.

title: Fair Lanes Talks Off
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 (Reuters) The Penn Central Corporation and Fair Lanes Inc. said today that they were unable to reach definitive agreement on a merger. The negotiations ended amicably and the two companies said they did not rule out the possibility of further discussions in the future. On July 13, the companies had said they reached agreement in principle for the acquisition of Fair Lanes by a Penn Central subsidiary.

title: Chrysler Of Canada Seeks Help
description: TORONTO, Aug. 27  Chrysler Canada Ltd. and the Canadian Government are discussing a financial aid package to assist the company and its Detroit parent, the Chrysler Corporation, through their current financial problems.

title: Duncan to Meet With 9 Governors
description: BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  Governors from nine Northeastern states have scheduled a meeting tomorrow with Energy Secretary Charles W. Duncan Jr. to press for assurances that the region will have enough home heating oil and that residents will be able to pay for it.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Process Cuts Solar Power Cost
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 (UPI)Researchers have found a way to manufacture a key component of solar energy cells at greatly reduced cost, a breakthrough they say could dramatically hasten the day of economic sun power.

title: Roland Elliot, at 42
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 27 (AP)  Roland Elliot, a former special assistant to Presidents Nixon and Ford, has died after a long struggle with the malady known as Lou Gehrig's Disease. Gehrig was first baseman of the Yankee baseball team from 1925 to 1939 and died of a rare type of paralysis in 1941.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Seoul Regime Shows Nervousness
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Representative Park Kwon Hum lay in bed with footprints on his face.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Scherzo No. 4, Chopin; Sonata in E minor for Flute and Continuo, Bach; Variations for Violin and Guitar, Paganini ; Sonata No. 4, Pergolesi.

title: Notes on People
description: Can you imagine an eightstory ramp? Ken Carter was saying yesterday. Can you imagine a car coming off that ramp at 260 miles an hour? With two rockets? One on the ground and one on the ramp?

title: Feature Matches At Open Today
description: STADIUM

title: ExIm Bank Backs Seoul Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The ExportImport Bank announced today that it had given preliminary approval to a $1.17 billion credit to support the construction of two nuclear power plants in South Korea.

title: Excerpts From a Speech Mondale Made in Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Vice President Mondale's speech at Peking University today, as distributed by the White House.

title: Study Asks Earlier Education About Sex
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  Half of all initial premarital pregnancies in teenagers occur during the first six months of sexual activity, three researchers reported today.

title: Epileptics Aided by New Research
description: WHEN Tony Coelho campaigned for the United States House of Representatives last year, his political strategists advised him to suppress one aspect of his life that they feared could sink his chances for election if it became a public issue.

title: Bell & Howell Is Selling Its Photo Unit to Japanese
description: The Bell & Howell Company, which was a principal factor in popularizing home movies, announced yesterday that it was selling its remaining consumer photographic products operations to a Japanese company.

title: Deaths
description: BRENNEREll. The Officers and Staff of the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry express their profound sorrow at the sudden passing of EU Brenner, beloved father of Edith Everett, Vice Chairman of the GNYCSJ. Edith's inspired and dynamic leadership in the cause of Soviet Jewry and Jewish welfare around the world has served as model to all of us. We extend deepest sympathies to her and her family.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Ronald Seltzer, executive vice president of Macy's New York, has been named president and chief executive officer of Lionel Leisure Inc., the toy supermarket subsidiary of the Lionel Corporation, effective Sept. 15. He will succeed Leonard Wasserman, the founder of the chain, who will continue as chairman and become chairman of a newly formed executive committee.

title: Saratoga Meet Is RecordSetter
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27  A dismal rain pelted those who came out to savor the dregs of upstate racing on the last day of the Saratoga meet today, but records for betting and attendance were toppled.

title: Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, 70, Dies; Was a U.S. Commandant in Berlin
description: Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, retired, who was the United States commandant in Berlin from 1957 to 1959, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in Charleston, S.C.

title: The Anatomy Of a jokeStudies Take Serious Look
description: HUMOR can be dissected, as a frog can, the essayist E. B. White said once, but the thing dies in the process, and the innards are discouraging to any but the pure scientific mind.

title: U.S. Investments Overseas Up 12%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)United States corporations and individuals increased their overseas investments 12 percent last year, compared with a 10 percent increase in 1977, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: TV Reruns Are Bought for Record Prices
description: While the networks occupy the focus of the new television season, the three independent stations in New York WNEWTV, WORTV and WPIXTV are girding for a fierce competitive battle of their own, the most expensive one ever waged by the nonnetwork stations.

title: Lawyer for Bolshoi Defector
description: When Orville H. Schell, the lawyer for Aleksandr Godunov, the Bolshoi Ballet dancer who defected last week, visited Russia in 1978 on behalf of Soviet dissidents and met with Government officials, he stressed that he was a Wall Street lawyer.

title: At Least 18 British Soldiers Slain In an Attack by I.R.A. in Ulster
description: WARRENPOINT, Northern Ireland, Aug. 27 (AP)  Two remotecontrolled bombs set off by by Irish Republican Army guerrillas killed at least 18 British soldiers today and possibly as many as 24, the British Army reported.

title: Reserve Pilot Is Killed in Crash
description: HORSHAM, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP)  The pilot of a Marine Reserve A4 Skyhawk jet was killed yesterday when the aircraft crashed shortly after takeoff from the Willow Grove Naval Air Station near here. A Navy spokesman said the pilot guided the aircraft to an uninhabited area but was unable to eject. The pilot was identified as Reserve Capt. Robert M. Baker, 31 years old, of Doylestown.

title: No Change Is Foreseen In Pope's Ireland Trip
description: ROME, Aug. 27  Vatican sources said tonight, after learning of the assassination of Earl Mountbatten of Burma, that plans for the visit to Ireland of Pope John Paul II had not been changed. A statement by the official Vatican spokesman on the Pope's travel plans is expected tomorrow.

title: Q & A
description: Q. What is the evidence that the earth has a molten core?

title: Deaths
description: DE FELICECharles M. The Manhattan College Alumni Society records with profound sorrow the death of Charles M. De Felice 78A. DR EMANUEL V. SORGE 63S,

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1979

title: Lions Maul Tourist in Belgium
description: MANHAY, Belgium, Aug. 27 (Reuters)  A tourist from Luxembourg, Fernand Magersus, was mauled to death yesterday by lions at Safari Park here after ignoring an order to stay in his car, park officials said today.

title: Summer School in Buffalo: Local TV Teaches Reading
description: BUFFALO JUST after Popeye, Spiderman and Mighty Mouse finish their bits, a wideeyed teddybearlike puppet named Rocko has been busy here these days trying to teach youngsters to read.

title: Chrysler Layoff Aid Fund Ebbs
description: DETROIT, Tuesday, Aug. 28  The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that its Supplemental Unemployment Benefits (SUB) fund for laidoff factory workers had been depleted to the point that workers with less than 10 years of service would no longer receive income from the company to supplement their state unemployment compensation.

title: Bonn's Surplus In Trade Dips
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 27 (AP)  West Germany's trade surplus narrowed sharply to the equivalent of $331.8 million in July, down from $944.7 million in June and from $953.4 million in July 1978, the Federal Statistics Office reported today.

title: Oil Kept Out of Lagoon By Booms During Storm
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Aug. 27 (UPI)  Barriers strung across the coastal Laguna Madre today prevented a tropical depression from forcing large quantities of oil from history's worst spill into the ecologically sensitive area.

title: Steel Output Down by 0.6%
description: Steel production fell to 2.54 million tons in the week ended Aug. 25 from 2.56 million tons a week earlier, a drop of sixtenths of 1 percent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I was not allowed to present the case for Zimbabwe Rhodesia at the Commonwealth Conference recently concluded in Lusaka. If I had been permitted to do so, I would have spoken along the following lines:

title: F.T.C. Still Opposes Exxon Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission said today that it remained unalterably opposed to allowing the Exxon Corporation to take over a major manufacturer of electrical motors even if Exxon allowed other companies to use the technology it wants to market.

title: Black American Lobby Backs Palestinian State
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The leadership of a black American lobby for foreign affairs criticized Israel today and said that Palestinians should have a state of their own.

title: LORD MOUNTBATTEN IS KILLED AS HIS FISHING BOAT EXPLODES; I.R.A. FACTION SAYS IT SET BOMB
description: MULLAGHMORE, Ireland, Aug. 27Earl Mountbatten of Burma, one of the heroes of modern British history, was killed today when his fishing boat was blown up in the sea, apparently by terrorists of the Irish Republican Army.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: WATERGATE set off an alarm in the public mind. The question was inevitable: what had these people been taught  not only Richard Nixon but also all those highly educated lawyers and advertising men, those young aides who attended the best colleges? And once the lid was off, the public saw bribery in high places, disregard of civil liberties and of people's privacy, scandals in Congress, misuse of Medicaid by many doctors and reports of flagrant cheating on college campuses by those who would be tomorrow's doctors, lawyers, executives, politicians.

title: Transit in Los Angeles Is Crippled by a Strike Of 5,000 Bus Drivers
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27  Public transportation in Los Angeles was crippled today by a strike of 5,000 bus drivers of the Southern California Rapid Transit District, the area's principal carrier and one of the nation's largest bus systems.

title: Dinosaur Eggs Discovered in Montana
description: Only three days before Shell Oil exploration crews were to set off seismic blasts in the area, a team of Princeton University and Montana paleontologists discovered the first whole dinosaur eggs ever unearthed in North America.

title: New Recipe Sought for Cooking Contest Rules
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 27 (UPI)Enter the best recipe in the pork cookout contest at the Indiana State Fair and the prize is $100. Win the national contest and the prize is a free twoweek vacation in Hawaii  but not if you are a woman.

title: Clerk Slain as Crowd Attacks Store Following Incident Over Cigarettes
description: A clerk in a Brooklyn candy store was shot to death Sunday night during a rockand bottlethrowing incident involving more than 150 people. The police said the death came after a 20yearold man was shot and seriously wounded by another clerk in an argument over the price of a pack of cigarettes.

title: Aided by Computer, Scientists Confront Huge Spill
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, TEX. IN Room 210 ofa hayfront motel here, a machine resembling an electric typewriter chatters intermittently throughout the day, transmitting and receiving cryptic symbols. Ten thousand miles away, in Boulder, Colo., the large computer to which it is linked is helping fend off the torrent of oil, spilled from a runaway Mexican well, that menaces Texas's coast.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The International Association of Machinists is planning to monitor primetime television to see if the American worker is misportrayed and getting short shrift. The union will train 500 fulltime union representatives in the rules and regulations of the broadcasting industry, and they in turn will train several thousand others, mostly union members and their families.

title: Miracle on 54th Street Is Scheduled for Sept. 28
description: Five hours of jazz, theater, dance, cabaret, disco, art and opera, under the collective title The Miracle on 54th Street will be presented Sept. 28 at the Citicorp Center Atrium and St. Peter's Church at 54th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: For a Tax Of 50 Cents On Gas
description: WASHINGTON  The energy crisis is real. For the first week of August, primary stocks of heating oil and diesel fuel in the Middle West fell 10 million barrels 17 percent  below last year's level. This means that the Middle West may well experience a serious shortage of homeheating oil this winter. A survey of secondary stocks of fuel in New England points to an equally serious shortage there. Meanwhile, many energy experts are predicting that gas lines could reappear at any time.

title: Hair Trigger in the Jordan Case
description: The charge that Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, sniffed cocaine at a New York discotheque has triggered not only the special investigation provisions of the 1978 Ethics in Government Act but also an attack on the law itself.

title: Books: Prokofiev's Reminiscences
description: THERE is nothing exactly like this book in musical annals. Composers in the past have left us their memoirs, but too often their accounts are selfserving and pontifical. Nor have composers who have written autobiographies gone very deeply into their childhood and adolescence. The most readable autobiogra

title: Blue Jays 7, A's 0
description: TORONTO, Aug. 27 (UPI)  Phil Huffman allowed one hit, a leadoff single to Jim Essian in the sixth inning, as the Toronto Blue Jays posted a 70 triumph over the Oakland A's today

title: Astros Defeat Expos
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 27 (UPI)  J.R. Richard of Houston fired a twohitter and struck out 12 batters, and Enos Cabell singled home two runs tonight to lift the Astros to a 30 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Music: Two Rarities From Santa Fe Group
description: UNLIKE the rather conventional opening program on Saturday, the Sunday night concert of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival at the 92d Street Y offered a couple of relative rarities. There was nothing contemporary, to be sure, and the rarities were pretty lightweight, as was the entire program. But rarities they were.

title: Lord & Taylor Expanding
description: Lord & Taylor announced that it planned to open several new stores over the next few years in an expansion program that could cost several million dollars. The women's specialty store chain said it expected to open a store in Dade County, Fla. The chain's first operation on the east coast of Florida is scheduled to open in Palm Beach in February. Plans also call for stores in Ann Arbor, Mich., in 1980; Fairfax, Va., in 1981, and Dallas in October.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Aug. 27, 1979

title: Air Canada Fares Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that President Carter reject low fares proposed by Air Canada for United States destinations because the Canadian Government will not let American carriers charge discount prices to that country.

title: Deaths
description: FELDMANAnna I. The Officers and Board of The United Jewish Community of Bergen County (NJ) note with sorrow the passing of Anna I. Feldman beloved mother of Eleanor Silverstein and Phyllis LeBoss, our colleagues on the Board of Trustees, and dear motherinlaw of Sidney Silverstein, our President of UJC, and Gerald LeBoss, one of our ardent supporters. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to entire family. May Mrs. Feldman's memory be for a blessing, and her good deeds serve as a measure of consolation to her loved ones in this hour of grief. Dr. James Young, Executive Vice Pres.

title: Conrail to Add RushHour Seats Starting Sept. 17
description: WHITE PLAINS, August 27  Conrail commuters, who have been confronting standingroomonly in recent months as motorists began turning to trains, will find additional rushhour seats on all three divisions of the railroad starting Sept. 17, according to an official of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Strike at British Nobility
description: LONDON, Aug. 27  By choosing Earl Mountbatten of Burma as the latest target of their campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland, the terrorists of the Irish Republican Army struck at the symbolic heart of British society, the monarchy.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  A Federal judge today refused to compel the Government to continue its financial support of Soul City, an experimental new town in North Carolina that Government officials have decided faces too many obstacles to survive.

title: Let's Hold Trials Here In Spanish
description: Do you speak or understand Spanish?  that question was routinely asked of prospectiire jurors on three recent days when they were examined in a Manhattan criminal court for their fitness to judge the facts of an alleged armed robbery.

title: Deaths
description: OAKLANDBen. We record with deep sorrow the death of our beloved member and colleague, Ben Oakland, on August 26 in California. Stanley Adams, President ASCAP

title: In Hot Summer in Plains, Tourist Business Wilts
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 27 (AP)  The top of the news from President Carter's home town this hot and humid summer is that the tourist business has dropped to a trickle but the farmers have had enough rain.

title: Cleveland Strike Ends
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (UPI)  Striking bus drivers and mechanics, about 2,000 of whom have been working without a contract since July 31, returned to work today, ending a threeday wildcat strike against the Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority. They threatened to stage a much longer walkout later this week if the authority did not return to the negotiating table.

title: Hamilton Township Man's Death Is Laid to Legionnaires' Disease
description: New Jersey health officials said yesterday that John R. Radcliff, 48 years old, a Hamilton Township truck driver who died early Sunday, was the fourth victim of legionnaires' disease in the state this year. Ten cases have been reported since 1979.

title: ExState Mental Patients Live in Neglect in Queens
description: Dozens of former mental patients are living unsupervised, without proper food or clothing, in a group of nine or more private houses in Queens, according to reports by community groups. City investigators say the houses are owned and operated by former employees of the state's Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens.

title: Advertising
description: THE advertising agencies used by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that they did not expect any substantial impact from Reynolds's decision to shift the buying of print advertising for all of its products to inhouse media departments.

title: Guideline Year Is Not Changed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The Carter Administration announced today that it had decided against changing the date on which the second year of its wage and price guidelines program would begin.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6091800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3484707.

title: COMMODES
description: A late burst of buying lifted all Comex silverfutures contracts to record levels yesterday, largely as a result of the strong gold prices throughout the session.

title: Book Finally Closed On City Fiscal Blame
description: The Federal investigation to find out whether New York officials, banks and brokers had misled investors during the city's fiscal crisis came to an official end yesterday with a decision that no criminal charges were warranted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Berco Manufacturing Company, Waterbury, Conn.based subsidiary of the Burndy Corporation that manufactures electrical connectors, has appointed Jeremiah F. Camarota president.

title: City College Getting A New Arts Center
description: City College Getting A New Arts CenterA new performing arts center at City College  said to be the first such complex in New York since the 1960's  will open Oct. 24 with a gala concert. Among those scheduled to perform are the dancers Mikhail Baryshnikov and Patricia McBride, Peter Martins and Suzanne Farrell, the singer Ella Fitzgerald, the actor Keith David, the New York Choral Society and the American Symphony.

title: Sanitation Pier Fire Termed Suspicious
description: Firefighters on land and sea were called yesterday to battle a blaze in an abandoned Sanitation Department garage on an East River pier adjacent to F.D.R. Drive near 23rd Street. Fire Department officials termed the blaze definitely suspicious, and said it was probably started by something flammable. No injuries were reported.

title: Publishers Turning to Packagers and Freelances to Reduce Expenses
description: Major American publishing houses are encouraging more outside packagers to produce books for them and are employing more freelance editorial workers than ever before. They are doing so because inflation has raised the cost of producing books while buyers are counting their dollars more carefully before purchasing the latest novel uie moment it comes out. Publishers find it financially advantageous to keep the number of permanent staff members down and to use outsiders; at the same time, these outsiders offer creative innovations.

title: U.S. Views Vlasova Incident As a Victory for a Principle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The Carter Administration said today it regarded the climax of the drama involving the wife of a Soviet defector as a victory for the principle of no forced repatriation.

title: TV: A 90Minute Special With Andy Kaufman
description: AMBIGUITY was the signal quality of the comedian Andy Kaufman's Carnegie Hall performance earlier this year, and there's no room for ambiguity on network television. So for his first special, the 90minute Andy's Fun House, which will be shown tonight at 11:30 o'clock on ABCTV, Mr. Kaufman has had to clear up his act. Fortunately, the changes are more liberating than inhibiting, and they make for a generally crisp, often very funny program that in no way endangers Mr. Kaufman's comic elusiveness. When any of the several characters Mr. Kaufman impersonates here suddenly proclaims himself the real me, rest assured that he is lying.

title: Critics Question Builder's Drive For U.S. Center Sought by Saudis
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Fifteen months ago, executives of 40 of the nation's largest corporations gathered for an unusual breakfast at the Biltmore Hotel in Santa Barbara, Calif. They had one thing in common: business interests in Saudi Arabia.

title: Shakespeare Blocks Purchase of Its Stock
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 27 (AP)The Shakespeare Company said today that it had obtained a court order holding up the sale of 35 percent of its stock to Anthony Industries of South Gate, Calif.

title: Energy Issues Dominate Opening of Midwest Governors' Conference
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 27 (AP) Energy, particularly the availability of winter supplies of gasoline and heating oil, dominated the opening session of the Midwestern Governors Conference today as participants vented their frustration over Federal energy policy.

title: Policy Called ForwardLooking
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  State Department officials said today that the Mondale speech reiterated the policy set by President Carter when he decided last year to establish normal relations with Peking but that the nuance was different. They said it looked to the future and not to the past and was designed to enable Americans and Chinese to coooperate more closely in trade, politics and cultural relations.

title: KTel Terminates Takeover Talks
description: KTel International Inc. of Minnetonka, Minn., a diversified producer of record albums and leisure products, said that it had terminated talks with an unidentified company about the possible acouisition of KTel

title: Bonn Set to Name Phl As Head of Bundesbank
description: BONN, Aug. 27  The West German Government will nominate KarlOtto Pohl, vice president of the Bundesbank, for the central bank's presidency next month, a high Government official said today.

title: Begin Defends Raids by Israeli Forces Into Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 27Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that any civilian casualties resulting from Israeli strikes into southern Lebanon causes us deep grief and sorrow, but added that the strategy of conducting preemptive strikes against Palestinian guerrilla bases had saved the lives of many Israeli citizens.

title: U.N.Church Rivalry Complicates Pope's Itinerary
description: After repeated delays, the Vatican was expected today to announce the itinerary for Pope John Paul H's trip to the United States in October, putting an end to weeks of rumors and confusion about his plans.

title: Ray Eberle, 60, BigBand Singer
description: Ray Eberle, a former singer with the Glenn Miller Orchestra who recorded such hit songs as Serenade in Blue and Moonlight Cocktail in the 1930's, died of a heart attack Saturday at Douglas General Hospital, Douglasville, Ga. He was 60 years old and lived in Douglasville.

title: Chinese TV: Touch of the West
description: American and Western television fare had been making steady inroads in China's television programming in the eight months preceding Vice President Mondele's debut before Chinese cameras in Pekine.

title: Master Charge Is Restyling Its Card
description: In a move to broaden the image of the Master Charge card beyond that of a chargeaccount vehicle, its licensing organization said yesterday that the card, which is held by more than 55 million Americans, would be redesigned and renamed Master Card.

title: The Market Place
description: NOW that the stock market has experienced its best gains in six and a half years, some investors are complaining that they have missed the recovery rally. But broad based though advances have generally been, many stocks are still selling at prices far below average levels. A number of them have turned up in an update this week of The Magic Sixes, a computer list published periodically since 1974 by Oppenheimer & Company Inc.

title: Tornado Hits New Hampshire
description: NEWMARKET, N.H., Aug. 27 (AP)A tornado ripped through this small southeastern New Hampshire town tonight, uprooting trees, ripping roofs off buildings and plunging the town into darkness, the authorities said. No injuries were reported, although four mobile homes were picked up and smashed. The tornado hit at the height of a violent band of thunderstorms that swept across the state.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday incorrectly quoted John Simpson, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as having said that some subway routes would be eliminated to maintain the 50cent fare. Mr. Simpson was discussing the proposed elimination of nine bus routes in the city. Public hearings on those proposals will be held Sept. 12.

title: Three Jewish Groups Condemn Monty Python's Life of Brian
description: Three Jewish organizations have condemned Monty Python's Life of Brian, a film satire by the British comedy group Monty Python, as blasphemous, grievously insulting and a crime against religion.

title: DONALD W. CAMPBELL
description: Donald W. Campbell, a real estate broker in Chester, N.J., died last Thursday at New York University Medical Center of injuries suffered July 27 in a swimming accident at Point 0 Woods, Fire Island, L.I., where he had a summer home. He was 45 years old and lived in Chester.

title: Delvin Rides Again
description: Remember that Delvin Miller is 66 years old, which means that he's got a quarter of a century on Willie McCovey. And keep in mind that, before the week is out, he might earn more money than even Tom Watson. Now you're getting the drift.

title: Tigers 3, Angels 2
description: DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP)  Alan Trammell squeezed home a run and starred defensively at shortstop as the Detroit Tigers beat the slumping California Angels, 32, tonight.

title: Charles T. Lipscomb Jr., at 71; Led Newspaper Advertising Unit
description: Charles T. Lipscomb Jr., a marketing specialist and business consultant, died yesterday in Hendersonville, N.C., where he was attending the Kanuga Episcopal Church Conference. He was 71 years old.

title: About New York
description: It seems almost a sacrilege to be hatless in the Orthodox Borough Park precincts of 13th Avenue and 50th Street, a neighborhood that breathes Jewish religious tradition unto its very curbstones, which are crossed frequently by bearded men in black caftans with ritual fringes and earlocks and by women, kerchiefs on their heads and wearing longsleeved dresses, more often than not pushing baby carriages.

title: Bill Austin: Demanding Coach
description: When Bill Austin, a neophyte coach, reported to Green Bay 20 years ago this summer to take charge of the offensive line for Vince Lombardi, he found Jim Ringo at center; Jerry Kramer, Fuzzy Thurston and Bill Forester playing guard; Forrest Gregg, Bob Skoronski and Norm Masters at tackle and Ron Kramer at tight end.

title: A Second Big Fish Kill In 2 Years Discovered In Two Virginia Rivers
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 27 (UPI)  The second major fish kill in two years has been discovered in the Piney and Tye Rivers in Nelson and Amherst Counties, state Water Control Board officials said today.

title: Suspended Game Lasts One Inning
description: The New York Mets needed only 12 minutes to gain a 21 victory against Atlanta at Shea Stadium last night, but they then struggled for 3 hours 30 minutes, including a 65minute rain interruption, before losing to the Braves, 51.

title: New Police Tactics Thwart Bank Holdup on West Side
description: A plainclothes police officer posing as bank employee was forced by an armed robber to lie face down on a floor during bank holdup yesterday along with five customers and seven or eight real employees.

title: U.S., in Shift, to Weigh Dollar Substitution Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  An international account for deposit of surplus dollars could be an important next step toward greater global authority over the world economy, a high Carter Administration official said today.

title: Let Milk Float in New Jersey
description: What does all the arguing have to do with the price of milk in New Jersey? Everything  at least in Governor Byrne's Cabinet lately. At a public hearing on the milk industry last week, Attorney General John Degnan argued that milk controls should be abolished. Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi said the controls should stay. The Governor, who presided over this unusual session, should find it easy to settle the matter. For there is almost no justification for regulating the price of milk.

title: I.B.M. Brief Disputed By U.S. as Distorted
description: The Federal Government charged yesterday that attorneys for the International Business Machines Corporation had misrepresented the record in their attempt to get the judge presiding over the huge antitrust case against I.B.M. to disqualify himself.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Bill Torrey, the general manager of the New York Islanders, and Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell announced yesterday that the Islanders would train and practice at two countyowned rinks beginning this season.

title: Yepremian, 35, Gets the Ax
description: MIAMI, Aug. 27 (AP)  A tap on the shoulder and the words, Coach wants to see you, told Garo Yepremian today that the Miami Dolphins no longer required his services. The 35-year-old placekicker, one of the bestknown Dolphins, was waived, ending his nineyear tenure.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Track's World Cup Has Identity Flaw
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 27  It was designed to provide a showcase for the top talent in track and field, and in some respects, World Cup H fulfilled its promise last weekend with exciting performances, particularly by Larry

title: Oil Stocks Lead Moderate Overall Gain
description: The stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday in active trading with some of the oil issues scoring the best gains.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 27, 1979

title: Bridge:
description: Players from New York City dominated the regional knockout team championship in Albany during the weekend. The winners were: Josh Parker and Bill Pollack of New York, Ross Grabel of Providence, R.I., and Les Bart of Chevy Chase, Md. In the threeteam final, they won by 24 points against the New York group headed by Dave Berkowitz, and by 31 points against a side led by Art Seigenfield. The Seigenfield team placed second.

title: Gamble Hits Slam Versus Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug.27  Oscar Gamble, who was traded to the New York Yankees from the Texas Rangers for Mickey Rivers on Aug. 1, turned on his former teammates tonight.

title: The Stakes on the Airport Stage
description: Of the Bolshoi Ballet, our colleague Anna Kisselgoff remarked in a review only the other day that usual standards must be set aside because, It is raw, it is theatrical and it leans toward spectacle. So, too, with the offstage performance at Kennedy Airport involving Lyudmila Vlasova, wife of a defecting Bolshoi star, who may or may not have been bullied by the K.G.B. into boarding a homewardbound Aeroflot airliner. Anyone watching the weekend coverage, in which the event came over as a madeforTV movie, may have wondered if anything substantial was really at stake.

title: Harnischfeger Net Plunges
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation, a manufacturer of cranes, shovels and other heavy equipment, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended July 31 totaled $1.7 million, or 12 cents a share, a decline of 57.5 percent from $4 million, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1978.

title: G.T.E. in Pact For Laser Sale
description: SpectraPhysics Inc., a producer of laser and optical products and scientific instruments, said that it had agreed in principle to acquire certain assets and operations of the laser products department of G.T.E. Sylvania Inc. for $4.1 million.

title: Science Watch
description: Can emotional stress promote cancer? This question has been studied and debated for years, but there has been no consensus. Anecdotes about individuals hint strongly that there is a link, but research results have been inconsistent and often contradictory.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHORE SOUNDS It has been nine years since New Yorkers heard the picturesque folk airs of the High Level Ranters, the popular quartet from Newcastle, England. Their bestknown member is Alistair Anderson, playing the concertina. Collin Ross, Johnny Handle and Tom Gilfellon play the fiddle, pipes, bones, tin whistle and guitar, and join in on the traditional songs.

title: Soviet Ballerina Goes Home After Meeting U.S. Officials
description: Lyudmila Vlasova, the wife of Aleksandr Godunov, the Bolshoi Ballet dancer who defected last week, spurned an offer to meet with her husband and left for Moscow yesterday.

title: CBS Updates News Show For the Coast
description: CBS last night became the first television network to present a regular West Coast edition of its evening newscast, with Terry Drinkwater providing the inserts and updates to the broadcast anchored by Walter Cronkite.

title: MIKA WALTARI, 70, WROTE EGYPTIAN
description: Mika Waltari, the Finnish author who wrote the international best seller The Egyptian, died Sunday in Helsinki, Finland. He was 70 years old.

title: Twins 4, Orioles 3 Orioles 5, Twins 1
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 27 (UPI)  Gary Roenicke and Lee May hit home runs tonight to back the pitching of Jim Palmer and give the Baltimore Orioles a 51 victory over the Minnesota Twins and a split of their twilightnight doubleheader.

title: F.B.I Will Investigate Killing by 5 Officers; Violence Follows Protest Over the Slaying
description: The Justice Department ordered a Federal investigation yesterday into the police killing last week of a disturbed Brooklyn man who the officers said had lunged at them with a pair of scissors. Later, the Police Commissioner ordered a review of firearms training and procedures for subduing apparently disturbed people and said emergency police service units could use Chemical Mace to subdue such an attacker.

title: 2 Inmates Kill Each Other As Siege in Nevada Ends
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 27 (UPI) Two alleged leaders of an uprising in the jail annex at the Las Vegas City Hall shot and killed each other today, ending the rebellion. Three guards who had been held hostage throughout the weekend were freed.

title: 2d Member of Panel in California Withdraws From Court Inquiry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27  Another member of the California Commission on Judicial Performance has withdrawn in protest from the investigation of the California Supreme Court. He is Hillel Chodos, a Los Angeles lawyer, who objected to the continued presence of Justice Frank Newman as a sitting member of the court when it considered matters that had grown out of the commission's investigation.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 27, 1979

title: Apollo Wind Up Season With Loss to Americans
description: The New York Apollo closed out its season Sunday night with a 20 loss to the New Jersey Americans before 2,692 fans at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L. I.

title: Naamah Kelman Is Wed To Elan Ezrachi on L.I.
description: Naamah Kathrine Kelman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Wolfe Kelman of Manhattan, was married Sunday afternoon to Elan Ezrachi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Etan Ezrachi of Jerusalem. The bride's brother, Rabbi Levi Kelman, performed the ceremony in the garden of the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Hess of Sands Point, L.I. Mr. Hess is chairman of the board of Neot Kedumim, the Gardens of Israel on the outskirts of Modiin. The bride's uncles, Rabbis Abraham and Joseph Kelman and Rabbi Moshe Leifman, assistant chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, assisted.

title: Lessons Of Young's Departure
description: Andrew Young's resignation as the United States delegate to the United Nations brings into sharp focus the Israeli lobby's immense power in this country. Can it be seriously imagined that any African nation could compel the United States to dismiss its chief spokesman at the United Nations?

title: Wilson Player of Week
description: Willie Wilson of the Kansas City Royals, who batted .541 and stole nine bases in nine attempts, was named yesterday the American League's player of the week. The 24yearold left fielder was a unanimous choice after having collected 13 hits in 24 times at bat, including two doubles, three triples and an insidethepark home run. He hit safely in all six games last week, scored nine runs, drove home three and notched his fourth fourhitgame of the season.

title: Democrats Vote in Runoff Today In Governor Race in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 27 (AP) Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Gandy and a predecessor in her office, William Winter, are shaking the final hands and making the last appeals in their race for the Democratic nomination for governor.

title: 9 U.S. Writers To Visit Soviet For Parley
description: Nine American writers, including James Baldwin, Norman Cousins, Harrison E. Salisbury, Toni Morrison, Stanley Kunitz and Francine du Plessix Gray, will leave for the Soviet Union next Saturday for a fourday intellectual exchange with a group of Soviet writers.

title: Interest Grows In Insect Whose Webs Filter Streams
description: RECENT research by entomologists has shown that the larvae of caddisflies, the mothlike insects that swarm harmlessly around porch lights on early summer nights, produce incredibly complex miniature structures and webs in the streams they live in and therefore may play a much more important role in stream ecology than was previously believed.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ELGIN, Ill., Aug. 27 (AP)  The McGrawEdison Company plans to sell its kitchen appliance division and the United States operations of its laundry products division to the Raytheon Company for an undisclosed amount of cash, it was announced today.

title: New Obstacle to Hospital Closing Foreseen in Health Agency Report
description: The New York City Health Systems Agency is prepared to recommend that Mayor Koch abandon his plan to close Metropolitan Hospital Center in East Harlem, an agency official said yesterday.

title: Feud Divides Sponsors Of Ballet Competition
description: International Ballet Competition Inc., the New Yorkbased committee of ballet authorities that set up the United States International Ballet Competition held for the first time in Jackson, Miss., in June, has terminated its association with Mississippi Ballet International Inc., the state association that presented the competition.

title: Rangers Pick Farm Club
description: The New York Rangers said yesterday they had signed a full working agreement with the Richmond (Va.) Rifles of the Eastern Hockey League for the 197980 season. Andre Beaulieu was named coach of the Rifles.

title: Film: 'Actor's Revenge':Tale of Old Japan
description: "The Actor's Revenge" ("The Revenge of Ukeno-Jo") was shown at the 1971 Bijou Cinema's festival of Japanese imports. The following review was written by Howard Thompson and was published in The New York Times on June 17, 1971. The film opens today at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.NO, "The Actors's Revenge" isn't about the murder of a drama critic. That might have been more interesting. It is an artistically arranged but extremely rambling exercise full of melodramic bumps and lumps, as a vengeful actor destroys three men who ruined his family years ago.The hitch, of course, is a pretty face, that of a pure-hearted daughter, caught up in the murderous coils. And Ayako Wakao is a beaut.It is the exquisite face of this girl and some artful color dcor that are the main interests. For the general effect of the story, obviously intended as an old-time tale of traditional gravity, is splintery stuff and often confusing.
