And Kon Ichikawa's direction is a curious mixture of stylish artifice and plain bombast.The strangest thing of all, perhaps, for a story of Old Japan is the subtly, sleeky Occidental musical score, slipping into cool and torchy jazz at the oddest moments. The acting is pretty good, with traditional grunts and growls held to a minimum.Even so, it's hard to fathom the supposed charisma of the wily hero, Kazuo Hasegawa, who easily magnetizes his victims. As a Kabuki female impersonator, he's also at it offstage, mincing and mewing with some abrupt, lightning sword work. Yes, there's plenty of chopping. But this time the sound and fury signify only so-so dividends out front, at least here.

title: U.S. Settles First Of Suits Arising From Prison Fire
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27  The Government has agreed to pay $329,000 to settle the first 14 of the many suits accusing it of negligence in an extensive fire at the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury two years ago.

title: News Summary
description: News Summary

title: Medical Detective Story: A Polio Virus Tracked Down
description: To its victims, polio often seems sudden, capricious, unexpected; but public health experts dedicate careers to minimizing such surprise. They need to know where the virus comes from so they can guess where it is likely to hit next.

title: Events
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARKS, Central Park, Sheep Meadow, 8:30.

title: Chronology of Events
description: Moments before its scheduled departure at 5 P.M. from Kennedy Airport, an Aeroflot jetliner with Lyudmila Vlasova on board is halted by United States officials seeking to determine whether she is leaving of her own free will.  Negotiations begin between Soviet and American officials, with Donald F. McHenry, deputy representative to the United Nations, leading the American team.

title: MONDALE DECLARES THAT A STRONG CHINA IS IN U.S. INTERESTS
description: PEKING, Aug. 27  Vice President Mondale told the Chinese people in a televised speech today that a strong and secure and modernizing China was in the American interest in the coming decade. He said the United States was prepared to extend $2 billion in trade credits over five years, and he warned that any nation seeking to weaken or isolate China would also be regarded as acting against the interests of the United States.

title: Disks: Bruch Piano Concerto With Berkofsky and Hagan
description: IF it is peculiar that there are two recordings of such a rarity as the Bruch TwoPiano Concerto, with one of the piano soloists taking part in both, the history of the work is stranger still. It was completed in 1915 for the Baltimore sisters Rose and Ottilie Sutro, who formed one of the earliest piano duos. They took it back to the

title: Guidance for Stepfamilies Suffering From Togetherness
description: I really thought it would all be roses, he says, more sad than bitter now. I just kind of said, well, it will ail work out.

title: Taxes
description: THE Individual Retirement Account, or I.R.A., provides a way for a person who has no company pension plan to make a taxsheltered contribution to his or her retirement fund. But it appears that the biggest beneficiaries of I.R.A.'s are the affluent, not the lowerincome persons who most need retirement protection.

title: 49ers List O.J. Simpson As Temporarily Inactive
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP)  The San Francisco 99ers trimmed six players, including O.J. Simpson on a temporary basis, from their active roster today.

title: Red Sox 4, White Sox 3
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP)  Bob Watson drove in three runs with a double and a tiebreaking tworun single to support the pitching of Bob Stanley and Dick Drago and lead the Boston Red Sox to a 43 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

title: Venice Film Fete in Quest of Glamour
description: The Venice Film Festival has opened in Italy for its 47th year with an array of films geared to mass audiences  a policy change that is expected to reestablish it as a glamorous show business event after 11 years of showing noncommercial films.

title: Productivity Dip Put at 3.3% Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The productivity of the nation's nonfinancial corporations fell in the second quarter at the sharpest rate since the last recession, the Labor Department said today.

title: U.S. Issues Boycott Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The Commerce Department today fined a Swiss subsidiary of the Continental Grain Company the maximum $20,000 for violating United States antiboycott regulations.

title: Earl Mountbatten of Burma, 79, Military Strategist and Statesman
description: One night in 1955, a campaign worker for Britain's Conservative Party called at Broadlands, the country home of Earl Moentbatten of Burma, to plead for money.

title: Canada Raises Oil Export Cost
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 27 (AP)  Canada announced today that it was raising the price of its crude oil exports by about 3.4 percent, effective in September. The move reflects a decline in the exchange value of the Canadian dollar as well as rising transportation charges, the National Energy Board said.

title: 280 Build Castles In the Sand
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 27  There are few opulent estates in the style of Southampton or East Hampton L.I., on this beachlined island, which is perhaps why there is such appeal to the notion of creating makebelieve versions of them in the sand. Or so it seemed Thursday, when what is now one of the great rites of summer here came again: the Annual Nantucket Island Sand Castle Day. It brought 280 Nantucketers to 60 plots staked off on Jetties Beach, where they worked for four hours under the blazing sun on ornate towers and moats and pyramids and tunnels, not to mention on all sorts of things that were not castles at alllike sand sculptures of lions and witches and whales and crocodiles.

title: Tanner Is Defeated By Fleming, 64, 62
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, Aug. 27 (UPI)  Peter Fleming upset the topseeded Roscoe Tanner, 69, 62, today fora surprisingly fast victory in the $200,000 Association of Tennis Professionals final.

title: 1,000 Attend Memorial For Slain F.B.I. Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  More than 1,000 people attended a memorial service today in the courtyard of the Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters to pay tribute to three agents who were killed in two separate incidents Aue. 9.

title: SAMUEL RUBIN
description: Samuel Rubin, a New York trial law. yer, died of a heart attack Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: It Takes a Bit of Flair to Get the Jump on Summer's Rains
description: When day after day the weather forecast calls for showers and thundershowers, the question of what to wear takes on new proportions. After all, after the summertime deluge come the puddles; and chivalry being a fling of the past, no 1979 woman can expect to find either a Walter Raleigh or a cape in her path when she comes to a street corner where the waters lap at the curb. Judging by the pictorial evidence, a woman without a cavalier is simply a jump ahead of the pack. But it is clear that some skirts are better suited than others to puddlejumping. Kneelength and longer, they may pose a problem to those who need a grand jete to traverse a water hazard. When it comes to jumping, the old miniskirt and the slit skirts seem best.

title: The Region
description: BOSTON  Oddeven gasoline sales will probably be ended shortly after Labor Day in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, according to Governor Byrne of New Jersey. Mr. Byrne said that the four Governors were considering acting in concert.

title: The City
description: A consultant hired by the Metropolitan Transit Authority has found that flaws in the Model 870 bus were caused by poor quality control and not by any inherent design failure, the authority announced yesterday.

title: Lucia Chase Says She Isn't in Touch With Godunov
description: Lucia Chase, the director of the American Ballet Theater, said yesterday that her organization did not know the whereabouts of Aleksandr Godunov and was not negotiating with him over performances.

title: Jets Keep Blinka for Key Role
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 27  Ten rookies learned today they are Jets, pro football's youngest team last season, when the club cut four players and moved one to form the 45man roster that will begin the season next Sunday against Cleveland.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Aug. 27 (AP)  The United States Navy sought help today for a Vietnamese refugee boat in distress in the South China Sea after arranging the rescue during the weekend of more than 72 other refugees on two boats.

title: House Freshman Discovers He Must Serve Two Masters
description: MUSKOGEE, Okla.  Every Congressman gets calls from outraged constituents, but not many get them from their fathers.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Oil Price Formula Urged
description: BAHRAIN, Aug. 27 (Reuters)  Iran is urging the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to adopt formula to adjust oil prices automatically at least every three months, the Middle East Economic Survey said today. The journal quoted Mohammed Ali Movahed, adviser to the chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company, as saying Iran would insist on such formula at the next OPEC conference. The formula would have to cover inflation and currency fluctuations, Mr. Movahed said.

title: Stage: Thomas Babe's Kid Champion
description: THOMAS BABE'S Kid Champion (at Stage One) is a play about the the inner disturbances of a public idol, a theme that the author has investigated in subsequent works such as Fathers and Sons. Alone with Sam Shenard Mr. Babe is concerned with American folklore, the making and the unmasking of mythological figures.

title: Bill Rate Is Highest In 5 Years
description: The Government sold sixmonth Treasury bills at 9.645 percent yesterday, the highest level in five years, reflecting the trend toward higher interest rates throughout the economy.

title: Inquiry Sought On Meat Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, the Queens Democrat who is chairman of House consumer affairs subcommittee, asked the heads of six major Federal groups today to examine charges that beef prices are being rieeed.

title: July Machine Tool Orders Down 14%, With Exports Hardest Hit
description: Orders for machine tools declined 14 percent in July from the June level but analysts were wary of linking the drop to the general economic slowdown.

title: I.T.T. Unit is Sold
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Company said that one of its subsidiaries, the Continental Baking Company, had sold its Pearson Candy Company unit to the Farley Candy Company. The terms were not disclosed. Pearson was acquired by I.T.T. in 1969.

title: Toyota Profits Fall 12.2% As Auto Exports Decline
description: The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's biggest auto maker, reported yesterday that earnings for its fiscal year ended June 30 fell 12.2 percent, while sales rose 7 percent from the year before.

title: India Orders Mourning For Slain British Hero
description: NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 (UPI)The Indian Government today ordered a week of mourning for Earl Mountbatten of Burma, who signed India's independence from Britain 32 years ago.

title: Ira Levin Marries Phyllis G. Finkel
description: Phyllis G. Finkel and Ira Levin, the playwright and novelist, were married Sunday in the Kings Point., L.I., home in which they plan to live after Oct. 1, by Mayor Leonard S. Wegman of Kings Point.

title: OBSERVER
description: Diary from a slow August:

title: Conservative DirectMail Expert To Plan the Connally Fund Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Richard Viguerie, the directmail expert who has raised funds for conservative candidates, is embarking on what he hopes will be his biggest drive yet: raising money for the Republican Presidential campaign of former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas.

title: Inflation Called Peril to Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The dollar will lose half of its value each five to seven years if the current rate of inflation continues, a member of the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: GATX Buoyant After Setback
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 The GATX Corporation, its troubles with ocean shipping apparently overcome, has refined a new strategy: It vows to stick more closely to what it knows best.

title: Deaths
description: LEVINSONLouis A. The Rabbi, officers, trustees and members of Temple BethEl, Cedarhurst, N.Y. and its affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of their member. We grieve with the family on their loss.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERChester. In Mathews, Virginia, formerly of Woodbury, New York, on August 27, 1979. Beloved husband of Mary Lorentzen, beloved fattier of Anne. Services Christ Church, Mathews, Virginia 11 AM Wednesday, August 29. In lieu of flowers contributions to Mathews Rescue Squad or Charity of your choice.

title: A Desultory Atmosphere Overhung the Dancer's Drama
description: It was about 4 P.M. yesterday when Aeroflot's Flight 316 to Moscow reappeared on the departing flight information screen as scheduled to take off at 5 P.M. The parade of green letters spelled the end of a threeday international drama: Lyudmila Vlasova went home, leaving her husband behind.

title: U.S.Open, Showpiece of Tennis, On Today
description: The National Tennis Center, a $12 million facility financed and built last year by the United States Tennis Association for the use of New York City residents, was alive with activity yesterday, the day before the start of the United States Open.

title: Miss Horvath, 14, Youngest to Play
description: Kathleen Horvath of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., who was 14 years old last Saturday, became the youngest player ever in the United States tennis championships when she qualified for the Open yesterday at the National Tennis Center.

title: Books of The Times
description: THOUSANDS of feet up in the Andes, sick from the altitude and sick of the food, with leakproof shoes and a bandit's mustache and a copy of Boswell's Life of Samuel Johnson and a tube of the morphinespiked British cement he uses to calm his troubled plumbing, Paul Theroux is on his way from Cuzco

title: Couple in Rosedale Won't Be Run Out
description: With Mayor Koch and other city offidais standing at their side, a black couple whose newly purchased, $47,000 home on an otherwise allwhite block in the Rosedale section of Queens was firebombed last week vowed yesterday, We won't be run out of here.

title: The Editorial Notebook No Need to Borrow Trouble
description: The Federal Reserve, under its aggressive new chairman, Paul Volcker, appears committed to tight money and higher interest rates. That may be good news for jittery international currency traders. They correctly view the Fed's stance as a sign of Mr. Volcker's determination to fight inflation and defend the dollar. But among economists with broader concerns, emotions are mixed.

title: Bolshoi Arrives in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 27  Member of the Bolshoi Ballet arrived here aboard charter plane at 3:30 A.M. today after completing a fourweek season in New York. A spokesman for the Nederlander Producing Company of America, which handling the Bolshoi's United States tour, said there would be no interruption of the tour. The troupe is scheduled to finish its engagement here on Sept. 7, and will then go on to Los Angeles, the last city on its tour.

title: Reds Win, Go Into First
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) Joe Morgan, Ray Knight and Dan Driessen hit home runs off Steve Carlton tonight, carrying the Cincinnati Reds to a 52 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and into first place in National League West.

title: Police Seize $550,200 in Car Trunk
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Aug. 28  State police have confiscated $550,200 in cash found in the trunk of a car that was stopped for traffic violations yesterday on Route 80 in Morris County.

title: ANNA M. KROSS DIES; AN EXCITY OFFICIAL
description: Anna Moscowitz Kross, the first woman to hold the post of New York City Commissioner of Correction, died Monday at the age of 88 at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx after a short illness.

title: Soviet Bars an American From Moscow Book Fair
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)  The Soviet Union has canceled a visa for Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Random House, to attend the Moscow Book Fair opening in the Soviet capital early in September, the Association of American Publishers said today.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: A QUICK glance at the calendar is all it takes to realize that summer  the summer of beachgoers, of weekenders, of cottage renters, of all sorts of seekers of surcease from the superheated bustle of urban life is all but over. Labor Day is almost upon us, and those who have cursed the weather and prayed for sunshine lo these many weekends know they have but one more chance at a carefree long weekend before surrendering on Tuesday to the unofficial end of summer.

title: U.S. and Mexico to Discuss Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher will head a State Department delegation to Mexico this week to resume discussions on purchasing Mexican natural gas, a spokesman said today. Negotiations on the issue have dragged on for two years because of differences over prices.

title: Oil Tracts in Gulf Bring $1.25 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  The Department of Interior said today that it had accepted high bids totaling $1.25 billion for 81 oil and gas tracts covering 391,000 acres on the outer continental shelf off Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana and Texas in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: All About: Adopting an Urban Tree
description: If you are a New Yorker looking to upgrade the appearance of your block... if there's an empty treepit in front of your building and you keep falling into it... if you have an inexplicable longing to nurture a Callery pear, a Honey Locust, a Ginkgo  there is hope. Treeplanting season begins again here in just a little more than a month, and, although the City of New York owns all trees planted on city property, it is possible to become a sort of legal guardian for one, with the bulk of the responsibility for its welfare.

title: Arbitrator Asks Suspension of 9 On Post Faculty
description: The administration of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University has been ordered by an independent arbitrator to suspend nine tenured faculty members who have for the last two years refused either to join the faculty union or to pay agencyshop fees, the equivalent of union dues.

title: Yanks, WPIX In 5Year Accord
description: WPIXTV, which has had a 29year relationship with the New York Yankees, has reached a new fiveyear agreement with the team. The accord is characterized by television sources as the richest local baseball pact in the country.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1979

title: Greek Backs Plato Theory On Where to Find Atlantis
description: ATHENS, Aug. 28  A Greek researcher says he has determined the exact whereabouts of the legendary islandcontinent of Atlantis and has brought together many recent conflicting theories as to its location.

title: School Bus Upsets, Driver Killed
description: MUKWONAGO, Wis., Aug. 28 (AP)A school bus carrying 50 students veered into a field and overturned, killing the driver and slightly injuring a dozen youngsters. The Waukesha County Coroner, Donald Eggum, said that the driver, Mary Lou Winegarden, 25 years old, had apparently died of head injuries suffered when she was thrown from the vehicle.

title: Books of The Times
description: DVID BOULTON, a British investigative reporter, has produced a fascinating and accurate account of the Lockheed scandal, with a side look at the way Northrop and other domestic and foreign aircraft companies paid off foreign politicians to buy their products.

title: Governors Wait to Act On OddEven Systems
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28  In an overnight meeting, the governors of New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Connecticut agreed to wait until after Labor Day to decide whether to lift oddeven gasoline sales in those states.

title: Soviet Dancer Is Hailed as a Heroine in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28 Soviet authorities welcomed Lyudmila Vlasova, the Bolshoi ballerina, back to Moscow today as the heroine of a political thriller and implied that her husband, Aleksandr Godunov, might have been the victim of a plot.

title: At Campobello Estate, Memories of the Roosevelt Days
description: CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, New Brunswick, Aug. 26  James Roosevelt, the oldest of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's four sons, took time off from a conference on human rights he was attending over the weekend and gazed nostalgically out of the picture window in the living room of his family's former summer retreat here.

title: Deaths
description: LEWISNorman. Beloved husband of Ouida. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Art Students League for the Norman Lewis Scholarship Fund.

title: U.S. Steel to Lift Some Prices by 4%5%
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing the prices of about onequarter of its products by 4 to 5 percent effective Oct. 1.

title: Curmudgeon's View Of Children: Dim
description: I AM, as most of you know, often called curmudgeon at my Club. Well, just for the fun of the other day, I asked some members what a curmudgeon was. And I got some answers it's hard to believe. One member said he wasn't sure  not sure, mind you  but he thought it was a weapon. I told him it was a weapon I'd certainly like to have on the streets of New York. Anyway, another fellow told me he thought it was a kind of fish. Well, you may be sure I told Fish Frobisher about that.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates were adjusted upward throughout the credit markets yesterday after the major banks raised their prime lending rate by a quarter point to a record 12.25 percent. But dealers said that trading activity was quite light as buyers held back, awaiting even better yields after Labor Day.

title: Konstantin Simonov, Novelist; Wrote Trilogy on the Red Army
description: Konstantin Simonov, a prominent Soviet author known for his novels, poems and reportage of World War II, died yesterday at the age of 63, the Soviet press agency Tass announced. The cause of his death was not disclosed.

title: Physicists Find Elusive Particle That Binds the Nuclei of Atoms
description: BATAVIA, Ill., Aug. 28 (AP)  An international team of physicists has found what scientists said today was strong evidence of a new particle, called a gluon, that holds together the centers of atoms like glue.

title: Washington Sq. Art Show On for Three Weekends
description: The streets adjoining Washington Square Park will be filled for the next three weekends, as well as on Labor Day, with works by 650 painters, sculptors and artisans at the 96th SemiAnnual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit. The display is sponsored by the nonprofit Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit Inc. Hours are from noon to sundown, rain or shine.

title: A Long, Hard Road For Open Qualifier
description: In a folding chair on an empty walkway by the side of a distant field court, Doris Fairbank crocheted a white doily and watched her 18yearold daughter, Rosalyn, play her first match in the United States Open.

title: Careers
description: SOLAR energy may be a bright spot on the horizon, but the job opportunities, while improving, are not yet as bright as the heat source. In the opinion of Dr. Robert Chambers, a vice president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, there will be a steady rate of growth of jobs in the solar field, but he was unwilling to predict rapid growth. Arco, a major integrated petroleum company, took over a small solar operation now called Arco Solar Inc., he commented the other day, and its work force has grown from eight employees to 200, an indication that the solar field is indeed growing, whatever the rate.

title: Imported Values for the Pantry
description: Imported foods are not only becoming more expensive, the selection available is ever more astonishing and esoteric. Certainly, the price of these foods relates to the limited demand for such items as raspberry vinegar, dried fennel branches or killer bee honey. But their availability is what makes New York City's markets among the most enticing and exciting in the world.

title: EARNINGS Rapid's Net Down 4.3% In Quarter
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation, producer of men's clothing, alcoholic beverages and luggage and an operator of retail clothing stores, yesterday reported declines of 4.3 percent in net income for its second quarter ended July 31 and 19.2 percent for its halfyear period.

title: Jazz: Anne Marie Moss Returns, Singing Solo at Reno Sweeney
description: FOR the third time in two months, a woman who was once partnered with Dave Lambert and Jon Hendricks in one of the most popular jazz singing trios of the 50's and 60's has come to town as a single. In June, Annie Ross of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross was at Reno Sweeney. Earlier this month, Yolande Bavan of Lambert, Hendricks and Bavan was at Syncopation (and she will be at Boltax next month). And this week, through tonight, Anne Marie Moss of Lambert, Hendricks and Moss is at Reno Sweeney.

title: Duncan Pledges to Set Up Reserve Of Home Heating Oil for Northeast
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 The nation's new Energy Secretary, Charles W. Duncan Jr., told the governors of nine Northeastern states today that he would establish a 10millionbarrel reserve of home heating oil in the region to help insure adequate supplies this winter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Black & Decker (U.S.) Inc., the Towson, Md.based subsidiary of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, has elected to its board Robert V. Krikorian, vice chairman and chief executive officer of Rexnord Inc.

title: Norman Lewis, an ArtistTeacher
description: Norman Lewis, an abtractionist painter and a teacher at the Art Students League, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived and worked in the SoHo area of downtown Manhattan.

title: Around the Nation
description: SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Aug. 28  Two persons were killed tonight as severe weather, including several reported tornadoes, moved across Iowa.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Entertainment Events
description: SANTE FE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, 8. Beethoven piano recital, 7.

title: Oliver's 4 Hits elp Rangers Down Yanks
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 28  If the New York Yankees could get Al Oliver out, they would have a much better chance of beating the Texas Rangers.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and ()) over-thecounter.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter Administration is working hard trying to come to grips with the new Nicaraguan situation and hoping that the new Government will not ask for arms aid.

title: Seabed Does Not Support Idea
description: In the last century, theories about lost continent of Atlantis that sank into the Atlantic Ocean have been popular.

title: First Economic Offers In Auto Worker Talks Are Quickly Rejected
description: DETROIT, Aug. 28 The United Automobile Workers union was offered and promptly rejected today the first economic packages from the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. At an afternoon news conference,

title: U.N. Official Seeking $16 Million In Aid for Displaced Nicaraguans
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28Poul Hartling, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, appealed today for contributions to a $16 million program of aid for the victims of Nicaraeua's civil war.

title: As Bacon said: 'some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.
description: Having been a cardcarrying member of the publishing fraternity for much of my adult life, I have followed trends and developments in the industry with more than a little interest. Some of these in recent years have been unsettling.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 28  Eight American boats are being held in the port of Victoria, British Columbia, for illegally fishing for tuna in Canadian waters, Fisheries Minister James McGrath announced today. He said charges would be filed against their crews and warned that action would be taken against 40 to 60 other American vessels alleged to be fishing illegally in waters that Canada says are under its jurisdiction.

title: Niekro's 17th Tops ets, 64
description: Looking less and less like the lastplace team they've been since July 25, the Atlanta Braves used Dale Murphy's firstinning homer to take a 10 lead and led the rest of the way at Shea Stadium last night in scoring a 64 victory over the New York Mets. It was the fifth triumph in the last six games for Atlanta.

title: U.S. Bars Panama Company's Cuban Tours for Exiles
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The State Department is canceling the operating license of Havanatur, a Panamanian tour company that carries up to 10,000 Cuban exiles a month to Cuba for visits, because the Government believes such business should go to American companies, a State Department official said today.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT is time again for another vintage chart. That is, it time again for another vintage chart if you believein vintage charts. There is no such thing as a perfect vintage chart; in fact, it is doubtful that there exists a decent imperfect vintage chart. There are too many variables, too many contradictions, too many uncertainties. It's as if someone had laid claim to an infallible guide for choosing a wife or a husband.

title: Deaths
description: FLEMINGMatthew C. Princeton University, class of 1921. Architect. Age 80. On Aug 28,1979 in Princeton, N.J. Husband of the late Dorothy Stevens Fleming; father of Dorothy F. French and Angeline F. Austin; also surviving, 3 grandchildren, 1 great grandson and a brother. Funeral service 10AM Friday, August 31, Trinity Church, Princeton. Interment Princeton Cemetery.

title: Midwest Governors Meet
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 28 (AP) Governors from the Middle Western states urged President Carter today to seek support from them and from bigcity mayors for his energy proposals. At a meeting here, the governors also urged a program for development of new energy sources that gives private industry, rather than government, the principal role.

title: Gliedman Appointed City's Housing Chief
description: Mayor Koch yesterday appointed Anthony B. Gliedman, the city's Commissioner of Ports and Terminals, as Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: RELIEF CARGO GOING TO CAMBODIA SOON
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 28  The first planeload of what United Nations and Red Cross officials hope will become a steady flow of relief to Cambodia will leave here this week.

title: 80 Cars Face 79 Inventory Jam
description: DETROIT, Aug. 28  The country's automobile manufacturers and dealers, still struggling to sell an unusually large backlog of 1979 model cars, face the prospect of being overtaken by the 1980 models before the task is complete.

title: New Baskets, New Strategy in Litter War
description: Sanitation workers began placing the first new litter baskets the city has purchased in four years along major thoroughfares yesterday, in a new foray against dirty streets.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAP GRIS NEZ, France, Aug. 28 (AP)  John Kinsella, a 28yearold professional swimmer from Chicago, won the 22mile swim across the English Channel to day in an unofficial time of 9 hours 9 minutes, half an hour ahead of Alawi Mekki of Saudi Arabia, last year's winner. Third was Cindy Nicholas, a 21yearold Canadian who has swum the channel nine times, three times this year.

title: 3 Get Mayor's Medal For Personal Courage
description: Three men were presented with the Mayor's Medal for personal courage yesterday, one for catching a little boy who fell from a fourthfloor window and the others for pulling a burned man from an airplane after a crash.

title: Demonstrators Say Police Caused Violence at Protest Over Shooting
description: Representatives of several black and Puerto Rican groups that have jointly protested the shooting death last week of Luis Baez blamed the police yesterday for violence that erupted Monday night in Brooklyn.

title: Wheeling Steel Gets U.S. Aid
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's eighthlargest steel company, signed agreements today for $150 million in loan guarantees from two Federal agencies to help build a new rail mill and to bring the company's eight plants into compliance with air and water pollution standards.

title: Comparing The Prices At Gourmet Food Shops
description: IF you've been out shopping lately for Swiss chocolates, English jams or French oils, you already know the situation. Economically, things are grim: prices of imported foods are rising even faster than those of domestic items. This doesn't necessarily mean anyone has to give up a passion for Leatherwood honey from Tasmania, for shortbread from Scotland or sherry wine vinegar from Spain. It does mean that those who would rather have the dollars in their pockets than in the cash registers of local merchants will have to shop more carefully.

title: Petition Filed Against Robin
description: An involuntary petition for bankruptcy has been filed against Robin International Inc. by the Bankers Trust Company and the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Upstate Indians In Confrontation With the Police
description: From 50 to 200 Mohawk Indians, traditionalists who, refuse to otmcede sovereignty over their land to the State of New York, remained barricaded in a cluster of homes on their upstate reservation yesterday after a predawn police raid.

title: Dance: 5 Choreographers Display Their Works
description: FIVE choreographers got together on Monday for the last of five programs at the American Theater Laboratory to be presented under the auspices of the Cultural Council Foundation Artists Project, a CETA (Comprehensive Employment Training Act)financed program that places artists in communities throughout New York. If the choreographers have found a source of income in the project, the rest of us seem to have gained as well, to judge by the generally high quality of the work on this program.

title: Argus Sues Kodak, Seeking Camera Divestiture
description: Another photographic company, Argus Inc., joined yesterday in the attempt started by Berkey Photo Inc. to break the grip of the giant Eastman Kodak Company on the amateur photographic market, either by forcing it to divest itself of its camera business or by making it change the format of its film.

title: Carter Names Envoy to Fiji
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  President Carter said today that he would nominate John P. Condon as ambassador to Fiji. Mr. Condon is currently ambassador to Tonga and Tuvalu and will serve in his new post concurrently if the nomination is confirmed by the Senate.

title: Be It Resolved, Holidays Come At Bad Times
description: WHEREAS December is a very busy month, what with snowstorms makingextra work for Sanitation Departments and salespeople having to work late doing inventory because white sales are just around the corner, BE IT RESOLVED that Jan. 1 is now Labor Day.

title: Everybody Wants to Be a Poet
description: IN the back room of the Gotham Book Mart, that dusty, venerable haunt of bibliophiles on West 47th Street, hangs a photograph depicting one of the most remarkable gatherings of this century's poets. The event depicted is a 1948 reception at the store for Dame Edith Sitwell and her brother Sir Osbert. The other guests include W.H. Auden, Elizabeth Bishop, Marianne Moore, Delmore Schwartz, Randall Jarrell, William Rose Bent, Stephen Spender and Richard Eberhart.

title: Two Athletes, 48 and 3
description: William Lee Shoemaker, the world's greatest 48yearold athlete, flew East from California last Saturday, rode three races at Monmouth Park and won three. On Sunday he was at Delaware Park, where he won an allowance on Spectacular Bid and the Delaware Oaks with the fine filly It's In the Air. Score for the weekend: five mounts, five victories, worth $212,000. Sometimes top jockeys command more than the standard wage scale, but if Shoe received only the regular 10 percent of winning purses his twoday take was $21,200. I like to keep the little man busy, said his agent, Harry Silber.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Homage To Foods Of Spain
description: FOR anyone with more than a passing interest in the etymology and origins of food, it was more fun than a snare Andalusian, Franklin P. Adams's interpretation of a snare and a delusion.

title: 2 New ABCTV Shows Score
description: To the extent that summer audiencepopularity ratings are an index to what viewer preferences might be next fall, the latest Nielsen report carried some good tidings for ABCTV and CBSTV but little of cheer for NBCTV.

title: Chamber Music: OffBeat Mendelssohn Sonata
description: AH yes, the listener thought when Ani Kavafian and AndrMichel Schub stepped up to play a Mendelssohn sonata on Monday night at the 92d Street Y, ah yes, they've dug out that Sonata in F by Mendelssohn, the one he did not publish. Most interesting. A nice novelty for this third program of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival. Anything for a change, yes?

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The schedule for the 17th annual New York Film Festival has been completed with the announcement of the final nine films, which include a French thriller starring JeanLouis Trintignant and Catherine Deneuve, a collection of Warner Bros. cartoons and a pair of movies produced by Howard Hughes that are rarely seen theatrically.

title: Lakers, Rockets Settle Suit
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The Houston Rockets and the Los Angeles Lakers settled out of court today a $1.8 million damage suit that involved Kermit Washington's punching Rudy Tomjanovich during a National Basketball Association game a year and a half ago.

title: Salaam, Jet Tackle, Put on Reserve List
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 28  With his roster already down to the final 45, Coach Walt Michaels of the New York Jets shuffled two of his players onto the injuredreserve list today and brought back two who had been waived by the Jets within the last week.

title: Irish Police Search Coast for Clues To Blast That Killed Mountbatten
description: MULLAGHMORE, Ireland, Aug. 28 Dozens of police investigators scoured the gentle green coastline here today for clues to the explosion in which Earl Mountbatten of Burma, the British war hero, was killed yesterday. But they reported no significant leads.

title: Economic Scene
description: On Revamping Social Security

title: 51 Kurds Among 500 Shot by Islamic Regime
description: Kurds fighting for independence from Iran have been among the more than 500 people executed since the Shah's Government was replaced in February by forces headed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Winter Defeats Lieut. Gov. Gandy In Democratic Runoff in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 28  Former Lieut. Gov. William Winter, a scholarly, veteran Mississippi politician who gained a reputation as a liberal on racial issues in the turbulent 1960's, defeated the incumbent Lieutenant Governor, Evelyn Gandy, to win the Democratic nomination for governor in the party's runoff election today.

title: 4 States Delay End To OddEven Gas
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28  In an overnight meeting, Governors from New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Connecticut agreed to wait until after Labor Day to decide whether to lift oddeven gas rationing systems in those states. Governor Carey said that he was concerned that there might be gasoline problems next month and wanted to be able to judge more accurately next week.

title: Notes on People
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra's conductor, Seiji Ozawa, has settled his family in Japan, partly to enable him to devote more of his energies to the orchestra, he has told its members, but also because he was worried about his children being unaccepted and cut off from their culture had they settled in this country.

title: Deaths
description: ABI AUUNNassit on AUGUST 25, 1979 Beloved husband of NiIda (nee Garcia). Loving father of Georgette and Michael. Fond brother of Nadim. Also survived by relatives in Ohio and Lebanon. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193 St until Thursday 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial St Kevin's RC Church 10:15 AM. Interment Mount St Mary's Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1979

title: The Region
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized Allegheny Airlines to discontinue service at Westchester County Airport as of Sept. 5, a decision that will leave the county without services of a major airline. Allegheny, also known as USAir, had requested the move, complaining that its jets were carrying too few passengers in and out of the countyowned facility near White Plains.

title: City Challenged By Fire Officers On Fiscal Survey
description: A week after the city distributed questionnaires requiring disclosure of the personal finances of some city officials and employees, four ranking officers of the Fire Department and their wives have filed suit in Federal Court to prevent collection of the information.

title: Casualty Figures in Rhodesia Soaring Since Spring
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Aug. 28  Of the nearly 7,000 black civilians who have been killed since the war began here in December 1972, onesixth of them, more than a thousand, died between April 1 of this year and the end of July.

title: The City
description: The city opened a waterfront recreation area in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn on the site of a burnedout restaurant.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the oddest cooking myths is the notion that a souffl is the most fragile of foods and, therefore, one of the most difficult prepare. There seems to be a belief that it will collapse like pierced balloon if the oven door is opened or if there is a jarring of the oven rack. That is nonsense and so is that old wives tale that a souffl must be served at some magic moment. Tastes in texture vary where souffles are concerned. I happen to like souffles that are quite moist (although cooked) in the center. Others prefer a drier interior texture, a point that comes about through prolonged cooking.

title: Top Coal Official Backs Mine Health and Safety Act
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 28  A top official of the coal industry gave an unreserved, even enthusiastic, endorsement today to the Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act, one of the laws most often cited by coal executives in their allegations of Government interference with increased production.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Friday reported incorrectly that a resourcerecovery plant in Bridgeport, Conn., had no buyer for the fuel it produces. It has a contract to sell the fuel to the United Illuminating Company.

title: New Staff Director Finds White House Very Alive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  When John V. Lindsay called in McKinsey & Cornpany to help manage New York City, the situation already was too far gone, Alonzo L. McDonald Jr., the new White House staff director and a former managing director of the management consulting organization, said today.

title: Country Meets Disco in the Citified West
description: DALLAS IN an age when every fad sprouts another, country disco is the hottest new entertainment in the Southwest. In some ways, Cowboy in Houston, Diamond Jim's in Dallas or even the plain old country Disco in Strawn, Tex., are not much different from other discos. They feature a young clientele, flashing lights, thunderous, nonstop dancing music and disk jockeys who think of their sound systems as musical instruments with which they can create moods, manipulate rhythm and segue different songs together into a throbbing, coherent, sensuous whole.

title: Mobil Will Match 1978 Fuel Deliveries for First Time in Six Months
description: The general loosening in supplies of petroleum products that has gradually become evident in recent weeks gained strength yesterday when the Mobil Corporation said it would deliver as much gasoline, diesel fuel and heating oil next month as it did last September.

title: Canada to Test Home Computer
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 28  Bell Canada and the Canadian Department of Communications will spend $9.7 million over the next two years to place an electronic system called Viewdata, which allows television receivers to be used as computer terminals, in 1,000 Canadian homes and offices.

title: Bars in Hotel Rooms? State Considering Plan
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP)  The State Liquor Authority is considering allowing hotels to equip guests rooms with machines that will dispense alcoholic beverages.

title: Pioneer 11 Focuses Camera for Saturn Rendezvous
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Aug. 28Pioneer 11, six and a half years out from Earth and four days away from the first rendezvous with Saturn, cocked its ninefoot dish antenna Earthward today and prepared for a busy week of picturetaking and datacollecting in the vicinity of the solar system's second largest planet.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The name he bears is familiar to those versed in Wall Street lore of the 19th century. His greatgreat uncle was Jay Cooke, the Philadelphia financier of Civil War days. Now the presentday Jay Cooke spends his days helping young companies obtain the financing required to keep them prosperous..

title: Giants Lose King for 35 Weeks; Acquire Green for Kick Returns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 18  Players came (including a 1978 Pro Bowler, Tony Green) and players went as the Giants got down to the 45man player limit today for the second time. Then Gordon King left by ambulance.

title: North Koreans To Pay Debts
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  A North Korean banking mission initialed an agreement with Japanese creditors today to repay trade debts totaling 85 billion yen, or about $400 million, by 1989, Shinwa Yoshihiko Normura, president of the Shinwa Bussan Company, said today.

title: Small Olympus Camera
description: The Olympus Camera Corporation introduced an unusually small 35millimeter rangefinder camera yesterday that contains features the company says are not found in cameras of similar size. The eightounce Olympus XA  which is a little larger than a pack of cigarettes  uses the standard 35millimeter film format despite its small size and, according to Olympus, has other features usually found only in standardsized cameras.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1979

title: Pop: Russ Morgan's Son Retains Sweet Music in Morgan Manner
description: UNTIL the Russ Morgan band was brought into the Rainbow Room a few months ago, Music in the Morgan Manner, one of the more memorable sweet band styles of the 1930's and 40's, had not been heard in New York for 27 years. The distinctive sound of the band, with its rich, smooth saxophone ensembles and sweeping crescendos punctuated by the wahwah trombone of Mr. Morgan, had not changed noticeably since the group's last New York engagement, at the Hiltmore Hotel in 1952, or, in fact, since the Morgan band first broke through at an earlier engagement at the Biltinore, in 1937.

title: Alaska Airline Deal Overruled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that Alaska Airlines and its former real estate unit had violated the law in acquiring controlling interest in a major Alaskan competitor, Wien Air Alaska, without first seeking the board's approval.

title: News of the Theater Musical Jekyll and Hyde Aims to Chill Broadway
description: DON KIRSHNER, the rock entrepreneur who claims to have a pulse on what's happening, says he detects symptoms indicating that Broadway is ready for a new popmusic treatment. He is putting together a show called

title: Bulaich Rejoins Dolphins to Back Csonka
description: The National Football League's 28 teams each cut their rosters to the final limit of 45 players yesterday, which also meant additions to the injuredreserve lists and, in some cases, acquisition of new performers by trades or waiver claims or even persuasion.

title: Well Off Ireland Halted
description: FINDLAY, Ohio, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  The Marathon Oil Company said today that a subsidiary had plugged and abandoned an exploratory well on block 99/17 in the Celtic Sea off Ireland. It added that minor indications of hydrocarbons were encountered during drilling, but no oil or gas was recovered from any of the zones tested.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP)  Jovan Inc., a fragrance concern especially known for its musk oil, will be sold for $85 million to the Beecham Group Ltd., a worldwide consumer products business based in Britain, Jovan announced today.

title: Freer Climate in Haiti Yields New Political Parties
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Raiti, Aug. 27No one seems to know what to make of it yet, but in this nation where JeanClaude Duvalier is still President for Life, three political parties have surfaced in the last two months.

title: Despite Layoffs, Young Auto Workers Voice Confidence in Their Future and Country's
description: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich.  I'm doing better than I've ever done in my life, Tom Schlutow was saying. If it weren't for the green unemployment benefits card in his hand, you'd never know he had just been laid off  again from his job as stock man at a Ford trim plant.

title: Sydney M. Kaye, 79; Attorney Was Expert On Laws of Copyright
description: Sydney M. Kaye, an internationally recognized authority on copyright law, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and also lived in Cornwall Bridge, Conn.

title: East German Fails to Return
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  An East German cellist failed to return home with his fellow musicians yesterday after taking part in an international festival, the organizers said today. They identified him as Horst Schonwalder and said he had also missed a concert Sunday by the Dresden Staatskapelle, or East German state orchestra.

title: A Man Who Always Gets Fire I. Heat
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I. Fire Island is a narrow strip of some of the world's most expensive real estate despite its being hostage to a sea that, when angry, has broken through its dunes and lifted extravagant summer retreats off their foundations as easily as a child taking a tiny house or hostel from a Monopoly board.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN a company goes through a difficult period and learns a hard lesson  the invest ing institutions tend to say: Look, they failed once; they may fail again. Let's not take chance on the shares.

title: Poetry Fest Aids Efforts to Revive Arizona Mining Town
description: BISBEE, Ariz., Aug. 28  When the rich lode of copper began to run out here a decade or so ago, most of the miners went right along with it, leaving behind the shell of the oncecharming Victorian hamlet their forefathers had built on the steep slope of the milehigh Mule Mountains.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Aug 20, to Sunday. Aug 26), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Carter Is Reported Likely to Seek Supplemental Funds for Military
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 President Carter intends to stick with his proposal to increase military spending by 3 percent in the fiscal year 1980 and is likely to seek a supplemental appropriation to cover inflation, Government officials said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Panatta and Miss Shriver Bow in Open's First Round
description: Some things were the same. The jet planes roared over the stadium court just as loudly as they did last year. spectator wandered in the aisles as points were played. Bjorn Borg, Vitas Gerulaitis, Guillermo Vilas, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert Lloyd won in straight sets.

title: The Refugees Long Passage
description: The recent bitterness in Denver between Vietnamese immigrants and their Chicano neighbors should not detract from a more basic fact: the United States has done pretty well by the refugees from Indochina. The job is widening, though, and getting harder.

title: Light Quake Felt in California
description: WRIGHTWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 (UPI)  A light earthquake shook the mountain resort area around Wrightwood today, but apparently it caused no damage. Seismologists at Caltech in Pasadena said that the earthquake occurred at 1:57 A.M. Pacific daylight time and registered 3.7 on the Richter Scale. The epicenter was three miles west of Wrightwood, 40 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

title: Press in China Admits to Lies, Boasts and Puffery
description: PEKING, Aug. 28 On July 21, Tianjin city's daily newspaper, Tianjin Ribao, printed a glowing frontpage story about how the municipal design institute had greatly increased production, cut waste, economized and improved the quality of its industrial design output.

title: Private Lives
description: THE agreeable young man who teaches my daughter to be a better person in a public school down in Florida dropped by the other day. I was counting my newspaper clippings, and they didn't add up: A doctor in Bethesda, Md., clubs a Canada goose to death on the 17th hole of a golf course. A Manhattan professor of sociology bites off his wife's nose in a dispute over custody of their children. A retailer of phonograph records, explaining the recession in the music business, tells Newsweek, We're competing with a lot more kinds of entertainment now  like roller skates and drugs. What was the world trying to tell me about itself?

title: Small of CBS Will Head NBC News
description: William J. Small, a former CBS News executive with a reputation for being harddriving and toughminded, was hired away yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company to be the new president of NBC News.

title: Best Buys
description: FOOD prices took their biggest oneweek increase of the year last week as the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose nearly 2 percent, to $90.04. According to the Department of Consumer Affairs, the 41item market basket cost 8.1 percent more last week than during the same week in 1978, when the total was $83.31.

title: PRIME BANK RATE UP TO A RECORD 12%
description: Banks across the nation raised their prime lending rate to 12 percent yesterday, the highest level on record, and bankers predicted that the key rate would rise still higher in coming weeks.

title: A Conspiracy Theorist Offers to Sell Pictures Of Kennedy Autopsy
description: Harrison Livingstone, a novelist and freelance journalist, is trying to sell photographs he describes as copies of those taken at the autopsy of President Kennedy. He says that he is selling them because he and his group need at least $800,000 to prove the conspiracy in the murder of our President.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Nofziger Resigns as Aide to Reagan In Reported Dispute Over His Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28  Lyn Nofziger, one of Ronald Reagan's most senior political advisers, resigned yesterday, less than 10 weeks before Mr. Reagan, according to his aides, intends to announce his third bid for the Presidency.

title: Building Awards Off 1% from '78
description: Contracting for new construction fell 1 percent in July compared with the corresponding month a year ago and reached its lowest monthly level this year, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Foreign Equity Up 18% in U.S. in 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Foreign investment in American companies increased 18 percent to $40.8 billion last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Hurricane Weakens and Changes Its Direction, Sparing Barbados
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Aug. 28 (AP)  Hurricane David, one of the strongest storms ever to threaten the Caribbean, lost some of its strength late tonight and shifted northward, sparing Barbados from its full force.

title: July Trade Deficit Narrowed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The nation's trade deficit last month was the second smallest of the year, as exports continued strong and total imports leveled off despite a record payment for foreign oil, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: DISCOVERIES
description: It Started as Doodling

title: E.P.A. RELAXES RULES ON WATER POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would relax water pollution controls for hundreds of companies, a move that the agency estimated would save the businesses $200 million.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Sees Aides On Response to Killings
description: LONDON, Aug. 28  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met today with key ministers to discuss British responses to the killing of Earl Mountbatten of Burma and 22 other people by Irish terrorists yesterday.

title: Personal Health
description: BETWEEN 9 P.M. Sunday and 6:30 P.M. Monday, some 90 million people will tune in to what has become a Labor Day institutionthe Jerry Lewis Telethon. Its purpose is to raise money for the Muscular Dystrophy Association to combat a devastating group of poorly understood diseases for which there are as yet no cures.

title: People Magazine's Novel Rate Base
description: People magazine announced yesterday that from now on it would peg its ad rates to the magazine's circulation on an issuebyissue basis, rather than to the average circulation over a sixmonth period, the traditional method in the magazine business. It said that it believed it would be the first magazine to figure rates on other than a sixmonth or oneyear average.

title: Dow Off Just 0.77, Despite Prime News
description: Specialsituation issues were the best performers yesterday, as the general market fell only slightly despite an increase in the prime lending rate by many of the nation's banks.

title: Irish Rebel Aide in U.S. Terms Killing Justified
description: A spokesman for the Irish guerrilla movement in America said yesterday in New York that the killing of Earl Mountbatten of Burma was justified as an act of war.

title: Advertising
description: SINCE the Hertz Corporation derives most of its carrental dollars from the traveling businessman, it has logically funneled the bulk of its ad dollars his way. And since the businessman, who usually benefits from a handsome corporate discount on his rates, generally is not much concerned about price, the Hertz campaigns have stressed such things as fast service and the number of Hertz sites.

title: Barre Fails to Achieve Austerity Goal in France
description: PARIS, Aug. 28  The Government of Prime Minister Raymond Barre appears in grave danger of failing in its closely watched mission to rescue the country from a combination of economic stagnation and inflation.

title: How to Punish the I.R.A.
description: It may seem vicious and selfdefeating for a minuscule band of terrorists to promote their cause in Ulster by murdering British soldiers, teenage boys and the universally esteemed statesman and hero, Lord Mountbatten. Vicious it may be, but the new wave of killings claimed by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army is hardly futile from the terrorist vantage. A likely result may be to harden intransigent positions in Northern Ireland and to poison prospects in England for a peace initiative based on compromise. That is the I.R.A.'s game, and it would add to the tragedy if terrorists are allowed to win it.

title: Alvin Karpis, Leader Of Ma Barker's Gang Of Robbers in 1930's
description: Alvin Karpis, a leader of the Ma Barker Gang in the 1930's and one of a number of criminals of the time who led the Federal Bureau of Investigation's mostwanted list as public enemy No. 1, was found dead Sunday in his apartment in Torremolinos, Spain. He was 71 years old.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: HAPPY NEW ONE Now ending its first year on the jazz scene, Seventh Avenue South is kicking off anniversary festivities with the booking of the 24th Street Band tomorrow night through Saturday. This is a progressive rock quartet  Hiram Bullock, Clifford Carter, Will Lee and Steve Jordan. The group first appeared at the clubrestaurant in March, and since then has performed there with Dave Sanborn, Bob James, the Blues Brothers and the Brecker Brothers. Randy and Michael Brecker are also the proprietors of Seventh Avenue South.

title: Moscow Bars U.S. Publisher's Trip to Fair
description: On the eve of the second International Book Fair in Moscow, the Soviet Embassy in Washington has canceled the visa of Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Random House, and is delaying the visa or another major publisher, Lawrence Hughes, president of William Morrow and Company. Mr. Bernstein was scheduled to lead the Random House delegation to display, buy and sell books at the fair, next Tuesday to Sept. 10.

title: Japan Reports Auto Exports
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (AP)  Japan's exports of motor vehicles totaled 377,180 units in July, down 1.2 percent from the previous month but up 6.4 percent from July 1978, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Chess:
description: If your club is soon to close for the night and you want to complete one more game, make it a Polugaevsky Variation Najdorf Sicilian. It's either mate or he mated, with little chance of aettine into a lenethv ending.

title: Almost Like Finding California Gold Again
description: I'm going home. I'm going to eat waffles and sourdough bread and barbecued lamb and the best potato salad in the world. I'm going to sleep late and pick posies and talk to my mother until 2 o'clock in the morning. See the Pacific in the fog. Smell the eucalyptus after a rain. Drive with the radio blaring. I'm going to be ten years old. Fifteen. Twenty. I can't wait.

title: PrunePlum Desserts That Hint of Autumn
description: THE arrival in the market of new seasonal produce generally brings with it a feeling of celebration and welcome, marking as it does, the advent of favorite time of year. The slim asparagus and tender pink rhubarb announce that spring is just around the corner, just as pale yellow corn and rosegold peaches herald the warm and lazy days of summer and the hot orange persimmons and spicy tangerines lead us warmly and colorfully into winter's holidays.

title: Bangkok Dock Strike Settled
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  Dock workers agreed to end a twoday strike here today after they were assured that they would receive pay increases of 35 to 40 percent within 30 days.

title: F.B.I. Questioning the Jordan Party on Studio 54 Visit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is interviewing several persons who accompanied Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, to the New York discotheque Studio 54 in June 1978, Justice Department sources said today. Mr. Jordan has been accused by an owner of the discotheque of using cocaine during a visit there, an allegation he denies.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: YESTERDAY in the 90degree heat I was riding in the rear of a crowded Second Avenue bus which was not airconditioned, writes Stanley A. Hoch. The two ear center seats over the engine were unbearably of so that no person occupied them for more than 30 econds until a small, elderly woman threaded her way through the standees and beelined for the mpty seat.

title: Report to Congress Doubts Value of ShelfLife Dating
description: WASHINGTON While the simple shelflife dating of food may increase consumer confidence in the quality of the product, it may have little bearing on the food's safety.

title: Deaths
description: BHANAshok. The staff of the Division of Cardiology at Monteflore Hospital and Medical Center expresses their sorrow at the passing of their friend and colleague, and extend their sincere sympathy to his wife, Rai, and children Ashit and Ameet.

title: 3 Killed as Train Hits Bus
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  Three people were killed and 30 injured when a train crashed into a bus at a crossing 12 miles northwest of here today, the police said.

title: Chrysler Plan Due Soon
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 28 (AP)  Chrysler Corporation officials expect to complete by next week a plan to submit to the Federal Government to help save the troubled auto maker, Chrysler's chairman, John J. Riccardo, said today.

title: Clerics Say China Is Allowing Religions More Freedom
description: All religions are being given greater freedom in China as long as they are led from within the country, four Chinese religious leaders said yesterday as they began a visit to the United States.

title: U.N. Previews Its Film on P.L.O.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 The United Nations previewed its film on Palestinian rights today, evoking a scornful attack by an Israeli representative but also objections from Arab viewers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When you offer instructions for preparing a basic fish broth, you generally say, Use fish bones and preferably the head with gills removed. I live by the ocean, make fish stock fairly often and never remove the gills. Why do you?

title: Indiana Standard Spending
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said today that its 1979 capital and exploration budget had been raised to $3 billion as directors authorized an additional $116.5 million for its domestic exploration and production subsidiary. The new supplement includes $63.5 million for leases on four offshore tracts in the Gulf of Mexico that the company was the apparent high bidder for in a Federal sale last July 31.

title: Pentagon Aides Say Soviet Sent 50 to 70 of Its Best Tanks to Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) Pentagon officials said today that the Soviet Union had provided Syria with 50 to 70 of its most modern tanks, bat said that they were uncertain whether Moscow planned further deliveries.

title: Oxford First to Sell 8,000 Acres of Land
description: The Oxford First Corporation, a Philadelphia holding company, said it had agreed in principle to sell about 8,000 acres of land with a book value of $30 million to a group of investors. The land, representing a substantial part of Oxford's discontinued real estate operations, would include all of the company's unsold real estate on Hilton Head Island, S.C., and in Hawaii.

title: Topics
description: In the wake of speculation on possible sabotage and even military action in the Persian Gulf, British insurance companies recently raised the rates for any ships that sail there. They doubled the basic premium and required that warrisk coverage, which had been good for 12 months, now be renewed for every voyage. Gulf shippers, of course, were furious. The new rates not only raised their costs for imports but seemed insulting and provocative as well.

title: I.R.A. SETS OFF BOMB AT BELGIAN CONCERT
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 28 (AP)  A bomb planted under an openair stage where a British Army band was preparing to give a concert today injured at least 15 persons, including four bandsmen, and caused extensive damage.

title: Jaymar, Gant  In F.T.C. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  Two major clothing manufacturers agreed today not to set prices at which their goods can be sold at retail, a step the Government expects will result in lower price tags for consumers.

title: A Historic Day for 989 Immigrants Sworn In as Citizens
description: George Kalamaras, the 29yearold coowner of a lower Manhattan restaurant, was so excited that he could not sit still.

title: Bridge:
description: Anyone who inspected the list of winners at the regional championships in Albany during the weekend would suppose that five players won two titles each, thereby falling into a nominal trap. Alan Schwartz won the Flight B open pairs with Larry Pfefer, and Alan Schwartz won the Swiss teams. But the former, like his partner, is from Montreal, and the latter is a wellknown New York expert who recently moved to Middletown, Conn.

title: Lawyer Denies Soviet Charge on Godunov
description: The lawyer for Aleksandr Godunov called entirely erroneous a Soviet charge yesterday that his client had disappeared under circumstances which are not yet clear and said the Bolshoi star would hold a news conference this morning, his first public appearance since he sought asylum here last week.

title: About Real Estate
description: The sliver of upper Manhattan that adjoins the Bronx has significant assets: the transportation hub of the George Washington Bridge and bus terminal; three large parks, and such important health and educational institutions as the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and the Audubon Terrace complex of museums at 155th Street.

title: Rock Island Railroad Shut Down by Clerks' Strike
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UPI)  About 1,700 members of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks struck the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad today, shutting down the railroad's operation from Chicago to Texas.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Aug. 28,1979

title: Green Ireland's Bleeding
description: BOSTON  In Ulster, and in Ireland, August is once again the cruelest month.

title: Driver in Auto Mishap Fires Gun Into Crowd, Wounding 8 in Group
description: Eight persons were wounded last night after the driver of an automobile that struck a teenage boy in Hartford began shooting into a crowd that gathered to help, the police reported.

title: Deaths
description: DIAMONDMartha, Beloved mother of Mitchell and Bruce. Dear sister of Blanche and Sally. Loving grandmother of Rebecca and Katherine. Services at Boulevard ParkWest 1901 Fiatbush Ave (at Avenue L) Bklyn 11AM Wednesday. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: MONDALE SAYS TALKS IN PEKING PUT TIES ON A CONCRETE BASIS CARTER AND HUA PLAN VISITS Vice President Asserts New Amity With Chinese Is Not Directed Against Any Other Nation
description: PEKING, Aug. 28  Vice President Mondale, ending two days of official talks with China's leaders, said today that a concrete basis for ChineseAmerican relations had been laid for the next decade but that the new friendship was not directed against any other country.

title: McGraw Gets 95% Of Data Resources
description: McGrawHill Inc. announced that had acquired approximately 95 percent of the outstanding common shares of Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting company headed by Otto Eckstein. a Harvard economist.

title: Officer Indicted For July Slaying Of 18YearOld
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 28  A police officer from the Village of Pelham Manor was indicted today by a Westchester County grand jury on charges of seconddegree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an 18yearold New Rochelle man on July 19.

title: Con Ed and Clean Coal
description: President Carter's smooth assurance that we can burn twice as much coal in this nation and not lower our environmental standards at all may be put to the test in New York City. Con Edison has been campaigning for years for the right to burn dirtier fuel at two generating units on Staten Island and one in Queens. Because of the need to conserve oil, the utility has picked up important support lately from various quarters. And now the Federal Department of Energy, in its first action under a 1978 law, proposes that Con Ed be prohibited from burning oil or natural gas at the three plants. The only obstacle that remains in Con Ed's path to the coal bin is a thicket of environmental regulations  and they were designed to protect the public's health. So the real question is not between coal or nocoal but rather how cleanly to burn it.

title: Kitchen Equipment Electric Skillets
description: AFTER the kitchen has been stocked with the essentials the good knives, the fine pans  an appliance worth considering is an electric skillet. I know that it is easy to turn up your nose at these pans (and I have, on occasion). They are heavily cumbersome, so no flick of the wrist will flip vegetables in them. They cool down too quickly when food is placed in them, and for that reason there is always the worry about overloading them and thus taking forever to prepare a dish.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1979

title: Ulster Protestant Band Is Suspected in a Killing
description: LONDON, Aug. 28  A man, reported here to be a Roman Catholic, was shot to death on the doorstep of his Belfast home tonight shortly after the outlawed Ulster Freedom Fighters had announced a new offensive.

title: Court Orders Teamster to Repay $1.2 Million L.I. Local Gave Him
description: A Federal judge has ordered the secretarytreasurer of a Teamsters local headquartered in Melville, L.I., to pay the union's pension and welfare funds $1,262,500 that the court said he had received illegally, according to the United States Labor Department.

title: TV: Summer, the Old and New
description: SOME observations upon returning to an electronic swamp of reruns:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: UP AND COMING Delightful photographs of places, animals, things and some people taken by hundreds of United States and Canadian junior and senior high school students are in an exhibition at 40 West 40th Street, in the American Standards Company. The pictures won the 1979 Scholastic Photography Awards.

title: EARNINGS
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, the textiles manufacturer involved in a long and labor, reported yesterday that it had its highest quarterly earnings in five years. Stevens said its profits surged 36.6 percent for the three months ended Aug. 4 and 28.4 percent for the ninemonths period.

title: Japan's G.N.P. Up at 1.5% Rate
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29 (AP)  Japan's gross national product, adjusted for inflation, grew at a rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter, against a revised 1.7 percent rate in the first quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said today in a preliminary report.

title: Resorts Report Late Tourism Surge as Autumn Nears
description: HARWICH PORT, Mass., Aug. 27  As the infamous summer of 79 draws to a close on Cape Cod and at other resort areas around the country, a late surge of tourism is buoying hotels and restaurants, antique shops and roadside fruit stands.

title: Spacecraft Peeks at Iapetus, A Mystery Moon of Saturn
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Aug. 29 The Pioneer 11 spacecraft today got a glimpse of Iapetus, a moon of Saturn, but its observations were too brief and distant to be of much help in explaining one of the more curious phenomena of the solar system: why one side of Iapetus is six times brighter than the other.

title: Associated Press
description: MONDALES END PEKING VISIT: Vice President Mondale, his wife, Joan, and daughter, Eleanor, at the Great Wall outside Peking, during their last day in the Chinese capital. They also visited the Forbidden City. Later, they flew to Xian, on their way to Canton, where Mr. Mondale will open a U.S. consulate, the first in China in 30 years.

title: Caesars World Adds Casino in Nevada
description: STATELINE, Nev., Aug. 29 (AP) Caesars World Inc. announced plans today to take over operation of the ParkTahoe hotelcasino in Stateline.

title: Administration Denies a Report U.S. Bugged Young's Apartment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)  The Carter Administration today emphatically denied an ABC News report that American intelligence officials bugged the apartment of Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, and knew ahead of time that he was going to meet with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: GARDENING
description: EVERYONE loves a garden, but, judging from the great number of barren balconies and roofdecks in New York, most people don't have the time or energy to cope with a city garden. Tenants in two cooperative apartment buildings in Manhattan, though, have worked out solution: cooperatively financed and maintained roof gardens. In both buildings, about half of the tenants donate money for upkeep and a small cadre of dedicated gardeners do all the work.

title: Israel Said to Propose Meeting With U.S. and Egypt Next Month
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  The Israeli state radio reported tonight that Israel had proposed a meeting with Egypt and the United States in Washington on Sept. 17 and 18.

title: The Death of Luiz Baez
description: For the black and Hispanic residents of BedfordStuyvesant, the death of Luiz Baez looks all too familiar. Once again, a minor incident has somehow exploded into tragedy. Mr. Baez was released

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)  The strike against the Rock Island Railroad was joined by a second union today, and industry specialists said that a prolonged walkout could have a serious impact on the shipment of crops and other products throughout the Middle West.

title: ITINERARY IS LISTED FOR POPE'S U.S. TOUR
description: ROME, Aug. 29  The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II had regretfully decided not to visit Northern Ireland because of recent violence there, but confirmed that he would tour the Irish

title: New Savings Off in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Savings and loan associations took in $1.5 billion in net new savings in July, the poorest July showing since 1979, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Byrne Denies Report He Sought Job From Gambler in Las Vegas
description: TRENTON, Aug. 29  Governor Byrne today denied a published report that earlier in the month he met privately in Las Vegas with a gambling executive under investigation by New Jersey and suggested to the executive that Caesars World give him a job when his term as Governor ended.

title: Reginald Lanier, 90, ExBanker; Headed Land and Cattle Concern
description: Reginald Lanier, a former New York investment banker, died yesterday at Newport Hospital in Newport, R.I., after a long illness. The 90-year-old financier lived in Newport and Manhattan.

title: German Prices Stable
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 29 (AP)  The West German cost-ofliving index was unchanged in August from the previous month, the Federal statistics office said'today. The office, in a preliminary report, said that the index was up 4.9 percent from August 1978.

title: The Region
